reviews.review: Main shopping Mall very good.. We found that the bars and restaurant front staff were a little pushy but polite and got fed up with the hassel some days

Vacationers Beware. Please do not purchase anything, as far as souvenirs, at the first price they tell you. It is a buyers market. Please be wise with your money. Most things you can get from 20% to 50% cheaper, just by walking away, after having them in your hands. Travel with small bills and exchange dollars or Euros into pesos before you get there. There are many choice to purchase souvenirs. The strip is almost three miles long. You can walk early and avoid the sun, crowds, pick pockets, drug traffickers and hustlers. You can eat at many nice places, however there are some places that just looking at them, they are not to nice. It is a fun time walking together as a family down and back on the strip. The beach in Playa is so much better than Cancún. It is a little more expensive to stay in Playa than in CANCÚN, but it is still nice to visit. Stay safe, alert and be prepared for many changes to the Quinta Avenida. With Cuba opening up, there will be a lot of lost tourism that will hit Playa. Have a great time.

Great Street, Lots of Fun. Stayed in a resort about 15 miles away and had to go twice to 5th Avenue. Once wasn't enough. A street about 2 to 3 miles long that has something for everyone. Restuarants, stores, bars, tours and about anything else you can think of. Did some shopping, eating and drinking. If you are near Playa Del Carmen you have to check it out. There are some really nice hotels within a block or two of the street and on the beach. I think our next trip we'll stay in one of those resorts so we can walk to 5th Avenue. Great time.
Vacation. Wonderful food fun and enjoyable. Dancing clubs young people. But you can search romantic dance clubs as well. I love Playa

Fun main street. 5th Avenue is the more or less main attraction in Playa del Carmen. You can find plenty of restaurants, bars, clubs, shopping, spa,.... on it. A lot of street sellers, musicians and beggars as well though.

Tourist trap of the worst kind.. According to the rep it's the only real place to shop within a reasonable distance from where we stayed in Tulum.It really is a tourist trap. Countless stores selling the same thing over and over again mixed in with bars, restaurants and some big named stores.The amount of stores selling rubbish tat made in China is insane, they all sell the same stuff so if you're determined to get some gifts I guess you come here.Thing is competition is fierce so you will be harassed every five steps at times. Sometimes it's a simple welcome , sometimes it's a rude comment but either way they want you in. It's a pain, you can't relax and don't dare reply in your own language as thats a sign for them to lie. Just shake your head or even better ignore.You will also be offered drugs on numerous occasions, even if there is an armed policeman standing right there as we found. Again ignore.The places to eat are also full of scams, from guitar players demanding tips to hardselling of personalised Tequilla bottles. Saying that the food was ok generous portions, but beware it's English prices so don't expect a bargain. A good one to look for is Aldo's ice cream - great stuff!As mentioned in other reviews it does have brand stores which sell nothing you can't get at home and are the same price but a good reason to visit is that they have air con which believe me is very refreshing!If you get the Collectivo the gift shop just before the pick up station does sell genuinely different sorts of stuff so look out for that. The Collectivo point is 3 blocks down from 2nd avenue btw or just follow the big red and white tower.Overall if you're desperate for last minute gifts or a starbucks then I guess you will visit here but please don't make it a must do for your trip, it really isn't worth it.
Great Spot. La quinta avenida is a great pedestrian road with a lot of shops, bars and restaurants. Very safe too!

These folks know how to SELL!. If you wear any sports hats or shirts - they know them all - they will shout them out to you to enter into a conversation with you. Once you do that, they got you! But walk the avenue. It's a great experience.

Careful. I felt like everyone is out to get your money. A swimsuit shop with prices that go up once you like one, taxi cabs that force you to get into their cabs and overcharge you to shady characters trying to rip you off. I got the feeling that unless you are willing to spend thousands of pesos you are not welcome.
Great shopping. This is really a great shopping street. Except for a lot of famous and known brands there are also a lot of small stores with good stuff. Don't miss the small side streets as well.

Fun day trip. If you are so aging at any of the resorts along the beach (la perla) if you walk the beach till you reach the pier with all the boats that is the beginning of all of the 5th avenue stores. Everyone was friendly and not pushy. Yes they will ask you to stop but a simple thanks but no works. We had a fun time and stopped for a beverage and prices were very reasonable.

Lots to see. The only thing I dislike is all the store trying to sell their stuff by calling you over to look at their stuff. I know people that live in the area and they get the same response. It's like hawkers at a fair! Ne guy even said "I have the best junk in town!" Sorry not looking for junk! Some nice shops, just ignore the sales pitches on the street.

something for everyone. Great prices and some fun finds! While walking down the streets be mindful and careful of the scammers. #1 scam, they see ur resort band and say "Hey I was ur server at (insert resort name here) you got a couple of dollars for me today?
Would've been fun without pushy salespeople. The vendors all up and down the street get in your way and won't take no for an answer, making my wife uncomfortable.
Miles of shopping. This was a must go to spot in the main city of Playa del Carmen. Go to eat or shop, get a massage on the beach. We didn't stay for the nightlife.

Day and night. So quiet in the day but lively at night. You can find so many different places to choose for eating. I felt safe and vendors do not pressure you to buy. Great strip to walk for a day or two.
Friendly. Everything is within a walking distance. The farther you go the cheaper it gets. Excellent for buying souvenirs.
Busy. Quinta Avenida is a must because it offers a lot of shopping variety for souvenirs or any kind. However, be aware of pushy vendors and haggle every price as they overprice their items.
Lots to see and do here . Shopping, restaurants and bars for every taste. Vendors are Aggressive, but not too bad. Lots of walking.

Totally a Tourist Trap in a good way . Just came back from Quinta Avenida and it was just what I expected. Hundreds of vendors mostly selling the same crappy souvenirs, but it has charm and Mexican flair. Bought 2 wrestlers masks for about $17 each. Not bad quality and not bad bartering for a newbie. Helped that I speak Spanish but all the vendors speak English. Bought some bracelets and a junkie pair of sunglasses. Went by taxi for about $40 round trip (15 miles each way). At one point it's Downtown Disney. At the other point it's Dirty Vegas. Liked them both, will be going back before we leave.

Why travel to Mexico for what you get back home? Try other streets.. While Quinta Avenida has a lot ot enjoy, in terms of sights, sounds, smells, etc, a good chunk of the experience is oriented towards tourists. What that really means is a big hit to the wallet, because you're going to pay US/Canadian prices on most things. Not to mention, what's the use of traveling to such a wonderful destination, only to visit some of the same chains that you likely have back home (for the same price, to boot)?You're going to be solicited by every other shop owner, trying to get you inside, along with people trying to sell you various tours. If you planned you trip properly, you won't need to listen to a word they say. They're usually nice, so a firm "no" will end these encounters.My advice: start heading away from the beach, and check the other streets. I won't take you long to start finally feeling like you're really in Mexico. Playa del Carmen is a very walk-able town, and you should enjoy what it has to offer. And if you want to pay the Mexican price for things, you need to get away from Quinta Avenida anyway.

Tourist Central. A nice walk. Be ready to get called to enter every store you pass. Typical tourist center- everything is overpriced, and can be found cheaper elsewhere. But it's worth a walk, especially in the evening.

Bustling street in Playa del carmen. Loved walking this street for fun during the day and night. It seemed to be quite busy no matter when we went. It can be a little unnerving having the shop and stand owners coming up to you begging you to see there store, but if you can get beyond that it is a fun experience. Watch out for the oncoming sales pitches from shopworkers claiming to be moonlighting at sales and remembering you from your resort where they say they work their normal job. I fell for it the first time i heard it, and then realized it is a local prank after it happened again. I had it happen about twenty times before our trip was completed. Depending on your mindset, it can either be annoying or humorous. Lot's of great restaurants. We loved El Fabuloso the best. There is also an inexpensive restaurant owned by Iron Chef Canada winner Xavier Perez Stone on 34th just off of Quinta Avenida. The food is Very authentic and there are some fairly exotic selections on the menu....

Great Shopping Experience. Fifth Avenue is a wonderful mix of artisan shops, high class jewelers, designer stores and your typical beach souvenir type stores. I think it has something for everyone - and - there are great bars, restaurants, a little tea room and street food. Loved it - try Karen's with the swings for a late lunch or early or late drinks, Senor Frogs or Coco Bongo if you have more energy!Love Playa del Carmen - and - any football fans, the atmosphere is phenomenal - go see Inter Playa del Carmen AC - good football with passionate players that are not overpaid.
Great night out. We went on a Saturday night. The place was buzzing. There's a real feel of Mexico here quite a contrast to cancun. Lots of amazing shopping restaurants and bars.

I loved the Catrina Parade!!!!. Excellent! Loved it! Congratulations to Mexico! Fantastic tradition of the Day of the Dead!Good participation of local residents! There were also students from an Acting School.. good job guys! I definitely come back!

So much to buy!!!. La 5ta Ave. Is great to stroll and buy all sorts of things besides souvenirs. Such a variety specially with all the restaurants to choose from. I can hardly wait for my favorite restaurant to open in about 30 days. Lima 12 05 Peruvian restaurant. They are open now in zona Hotelera. The mariachi bands are so entertaining specially if you like to sing. Enjoy!!

Love 5TH Avenida. So much to do and see! Great food, many local shops and some amazing Malls. Close to the beach.I'll make Quinta Avenida a regular part of my daily routine when I move to Playa in December.
Be prepared to say no allot . Lots of shopping. Lots of people. Plenty of opportunity to buy gifts or something for yourself but be prepared to say no allot. Also check out the pier/beach area
Great for shopping, eating and drinking. A great street, but the pestering from shopkeepers is relentless and very annoying. There are plenty of superb restaurants and bars.

Running the Gauntlet!. Same shops repeated every 100m. Walk through quickly without making eye contact lol
Some good bars and places to eat during the day at reasonable prices.
Shopping. Lots to see and do here. Prices beat the gift shop prices and you can try a more authentic mexican meal

Not as expected. A bit disappointed but somewhere to go in the evening to get out of the hotel for a change. All shops seemed to be very similar (souvenir shops all selling the same) and my husband was asked if he would like drugs!! We weren't hassled though when he said no and found it quite funny.

Tourist Gauntlet But fun anyway. "Let me be the first to rip you off" the local vendor on Quinta Avenida shouted at me. I laughed and yes, I entered his market and bought a trinket. This is TOURUST CENTRAL, no doubt. EVERY vendor comes out onto the street and tries to get you into their store. They get you going to the beach, on the way to the Cozumel Ferry, coming back from lunch or dinner. They are just hustling for your dinero, Gringo! So play your part. Buy something! You don't need to be rude, you really don't have to be ripped off. I saw a tourist walking down the street with a paper bag on his head in the mid day sun - BUY A FREAKIN' HAT! You just walked past at least 10 stores that sell them for less than 10 bucks. SHEESH!Don't shop at Old Navy or any other store you have back home. Explore a little. Find a little something for your niece or nephew or that elderly lady in the next apartment. A spoon rest for Mom. Use your imagination. The vendors have to hustle every day. They don't make much. Tip your wait staff generously in local cash. Say Gracias. This isn't rocket science folks. Play your part. Make the world go round. Buenas Dias!

Great souvenir shopping. Quinta Avenida or fifth avenue as we call it is a single street of about a mile long. There are shops coffee bars and restaurants over the whole avenue, there are plenty of souvenir shops and the prices are good they are fixed so no need to barter. We went from the hotel for about a fiver each return which gives you about 2 hours to shop which is usually enough. Well worth the trip, we went twice over our time there, go and enjoy.

Quinta Avenida - playa del Carmen a must!!!. We visited playa del Carmen and did the famous 5th ave walk. They have cool little mom and pop restaurants and shops and was surprised to also see large American stores like Gap and Nike there as well. Was also able to exchange American money for Mexican Pesos there and had the best rates I had seen in Cancun. They also have a very nice beach that is free to the public and very clean and spent a few hours there with the family. They also had some amazing murals and statues and local Mayan Indians were also performing from a large pole. Highly recommended and a must if your staying in Playa del Carmen or Cancun.
Love 5th Ave!. We return every winter to Playa and one reason is to walk up and down 5th Ave. It's lively, fun and there's so much to see!
Playa del Carmen . Love this shopping area. Something for everyone. Lots of small bars too. Fun atmosphere. Great souvenir shops, great high end shops as well.

Must do when in Playa!. This is a must do if traveling to Cancun-Playa del Carmen area. There's a lot of walking, so if it's not something you're used to or can do, consider renting a bike or motor wheelchair. There are plently of shops catering to all types of customers. You can find anything from perfumes to souvenirs and will find all types of restaurants (mexican, italian, steakhouse, vegan, healthy, deli, icecream, etc) I've visited many times and there is always something to do or see.The only Con is that lately I've seen many people offering to sell drugs, in a very discreet way, but if something to consider if traveling with kids. There's policemen everything though, so not something to worry about.

Great people watching!. Love it or hate it, you have to walk down Quinta Avenida when visiting Playa. Twenty years ago it was a crushed shell walk with a few souvenir shops. Now, it's over 20 blocks of shopping and restaurants. It offers everything from cheesy, velvet sombreros to 5 star eateries. You can't walk five feet without someone trying to sell you something. After a few blocks, this can become an annoyance. Learn to say, "No gracias senior" and keep walking! Also many will say remember me from the hotel, or last night? Anything to strike up a conversation. The first several blocks are mostly old souvenir shops and Mexican restaurants. Further up to 30th and 40th you'll find newer eateries and stores , including a couple of open air malls. Although restaurants are cheaper here, clothing is no bargain (except for Playa t-shirts). The best part of Quinta is people watching. It's a bizarre, colorful parade! Grab a cheap taco and beer and sit back and enjoy!

Super touristy but great for a stroll, souvenir shopping, food and drinks. Almost at all times of the day you can expect this street to be flooded with people, this can be good and bad depending on how you look at it. Yes its busy but great for people watching. Their is a wide variety of shops everything from bars/restaurants , endless shops of souvenirs, art stores, street artists, money exchange and more. This is the epicentre of playa del carmen so its where most of the action is. The great thing about it is its one street away from the beach and if you want to escape the crowds for a more local experience than you just walk in the opposite direction from the beach and you very quickly can find more authentic foods, shops and far less tourists.
I love it!. I love this place is very safe to walk by and a lot of shops bars and restaurants.You can find the Mariachis there and live music in most of the bars.

Food Choices were great!. The food choices were great at this location. It's the 'touristy' shopping district near PDC so we expected the prices of the food to be 'medium-priced'. We loved that there are so many Haagen-Dazs locations in it that we didn't have to worry about not taking care of our 'ice-cream' needs. My only regret was not buying the Mexican Chocolate in one of the souvenir shops because it cost way too much at the airport's duty-free shop.
Nice Place. Love this place. Very vivid at night and so m any different places to eat and shop. Anything and everything you can find it here. And the people keeps it very clean.
Best boardwalk. So nice to walk around. So much placed to visit, eat and drink. Be careful with the prices of handcraft. Usually you can get better deals if you try

The place to go in Playa Del Carmen. This is the place to go!!!You will find everything you want: good restaurants, souvenir shops, all the shops (H&M, Sephora, American Eagle(with very good discount when we went), MAC, Nike, Victoria Secrets among many many others).Crowded street however. If you don't like noise and lots of people, don't go there. Or maybe only once to see the atmosphere.

Shop and exercise. We've walked Quinta Avenida many times, from Starbucks at the south end to 110th St. at Paradisus, the all inclusive resort. If you are looking for a nice walk go early, before 10AM. Fewer vendors and cooler temps make this a great way to get exercise, and you can catch breakfast at Carboncitos, or La Cueva del Chango at 38th. You'll find good silver vendors between 2nd and 5th, and Cuban cigars at that end of the avenida, too. We prefer the section north beyond Avenida 20, a little more laid back. Be alert, and ignore the hawkers who greet you with, "Remember me?" Chances are this is the first meeting, and is not your hotel concierge. If you are up for a nice, long walk, the Avenida extends north to several beach access points all the way to Avenida 110, or south to the ruins of Xaman Ha, inside Playacar. A varied shopping experience, easy walking, best in the AM to avoid gregarious vendors.

Magical street. Quinta Avenida has everything you need.From the First to the 40th street you'll find some many places to eat, to have a drink, to party, to go shopping, to have a coffee, or an ice cream... the sky is the limit.

Safe & Happy Place. Not a massive fan of shopping whilst on holiday but 5th avenue is perfect to have a wander around and meet some lovely people and taste some fantastic food. You feel safe both day and night and it really is worth a few hours just to lose yourself for a while!

Pretty fun. Playa was an interesting experience. Tons of great shops and delicious places to eat. The vendors and shop owners are very aggressive here. More so than most Latin American shopping towns I've been to. Catching the ferry to Cozumel was a piece of cake.

Annoying- But good to experience once. People accosting you get's tiring after the first 50 steps you take. They're rude, and pretty forceful. Every 2 stores you're offered drugs or "someones sister". It's pretty Americanized, but we did have a great lunch at a cool restaurant. It was great to experience once but I doubt I would go back. I would likely rent a car next time and tour around on our own since it looks like driving there is pretty straight forward.

Great way to spend some time in playa. A great place to visit. There's something for everyone here. Lined with tons of terai rants, cafes, shops etc. Paseo del Carmen at the south end had some nice shopping. As you move further north you'll find some nicer places...as opposed to the tacky, touristy stuff. Try exploring a bit on some of the streets that come off of 5th.

Would be great if people would stop bugging you when you walk down the road!. While I enjoyed the shops on this street, I did not enjoy all the harassment to enter shops, do this, buy that!.........Nice goods, but too much hassle to walk down the street, and even worse when you are alone! Don't get me wrong, there are some lovely shops and some very nice people, but I would enjoy it more without being called into every shop!

Quite fun just browsing and mooching around. I have not been in the evening when I am sure 5th Avenue comes alive. It was just fun browsing the many, many shops and enjoying the odd pit stop in the many, many bars. You do not get overhassled by hawkers as long as you are reasonably firm. Some of them are quite witty and good natured. Watch out in the bars where you are automatically presented with a service charge on top. Fun place to visit for souvenirs and other tat.

Great Time!!. We loved this place!! Not even a whole day could help you to finish sightseeing 5th Avenue what an amazing experience we had.There is so much to see, lots of souvenirs to buy, lots of food,lots of everything!! We ran into very kind people everywhere we ask for directions an unforgettable time here is guaranteed without doubt!!  This is a must,in your visit to Cancun, it is worth it!! You will enjoy it to the end!!
Group vacation. Love this place so much to see, it is safe to walk day or night. Lots of vendor selling artesian, you just want to buy the all .
Great experience. Decided to visit the area withe relatively no expectations, it was beyond imagination. So much to do with restaurants, shops and interesting places.

Something for everyone. Whether you are shopping for trinket souvenirs or a Michael Kors bag, you can find it on 5th Avenue. Closed to traffic, it's a pedestrian friendly street that runs for blocks and blocks, filled with shops, bars, restaurants, live music, jewelry...you are it, you can find it. There are places open from breakfast thru the wee hours so you can pick a time and just stroll.
Wow. I had no idea playa del carmen was so commercialized. Its pretty awesome. Great restaurants, shopping, and high energy. Something for everyone. Also right by the beach!

Fun but watch for pickpockets . We liked all the hubbub at night it was a lot like Las Vegas Strip. We did have some one bump my purse and maybe try to reach in. We were standing in a crowd watching street dancers. I was glad I always carry a zipped bag. This could gave happened in any big city in the world but be careful.
5 th avenue . Great area for walking shopping, eat and drink.A lot of action,lights and music, great ambiance, spent a few evenings there, different from spending night after night at the resort

Get your walk on. 5th avenue was so fun. so many restaurants and so many stores to choose from. We walked and walked checking out all it had to offer. I highly recommend it. Its very safe, family oriented has a variety of shops.

nice place to shop or eat. Neat places to go for dinner and to shop around, but the street vendors are annoying trying to lure you over or saying that they remember you from your hotel. Good place to go for half a day but wouldn't waste an entire vacation day there

Quinta Avenida Fifth Avenue. I love this place. It is so lively at night. There so many places to shop, eat, and drink. It's a great place to people watch. It is completely SAFE. There are tons of taxis around if you need a ride. I stayed in Playacar and the standard rate was 90 pesos one way. Go just once!

Great pedestrian getaway . 5th Ave offers everything for the international traveler. From expensive malls to low cost souvenir shops, from 5 star restaurants to local diners . You can find a bar/lounge to suit your taste/age . There are many great mom and pop shops/restaurants and massage shops. The massage shops offer massages both on 5th Ave or on the beach( a block away). I suggest you go in the evening to avoid the sun and to maximize your experience

Mish mash of bars and shops. Walked on here several times to be bombarded with shop keepers trying to drag you in to spend in there shop which got a bit much within the first 100 yards ,but later on in the evening they let up and the vibe and bars come alive , some great nightlife but be careful of the prices as they are a little pricey with an added surcharge on top , tequila barrel is great but check out the bars with live music , super night out but try Coco bongo super nightclub but no where near as large as cancun but good fun
Love 5th Avenue. Visited 5th Avenue on many occassions, its great fun, so much going on, you will get hassled but ignore it and move on, you will spend money, some great shops, bars and restaurants.
Out and about. Everything you want on this street. Safe, well lighted, and great food and fun. Both for day time shopping and walking around as well as night life restaurants and bars.
Fun stroll. The village of Playa del Carmen still remains a charming pedestrian thoroughfare. The north side of Avenida Constitueyents is like it was years ago.

great street to go shopping. 5th Avenue is a really cool place to go shopping in Playa Del Carmen.You ve got everything from local shops to H&M and many Hurley stores and Nike.Loads to do loads to see and eat. There are a few little really cool boutique hotels that definitely worth checking

very american, not mexican at all. Nice street, lots of shops and restaurants. It is good because you can find anything you need and you can find nice restaurants to eat all time of days and night. However there is nothing mexican , everything is so "americanized" that you ask yourself why they transformed this city in a little america. You pay money to go to mexico and you find victoria secret, sephora, micheal kors shops, why going? Real mexicans are in the street sitting on the ground trying to sell the real mexican goods. Unbelievable. On top of it, the beach and water is better in Miami. You need to go to Playacar or even south to get nice christalclear water.

Always fun to be had here!!. We are big fans of Fifth Avenue in Playa del Carmen, as frequent travelers to this area, we have seen the changes there the past 15yrs or so, and they are significant.You now have a mix of the local culture, along with high end trendy restaurants and cafe's, along with stores and high end shopping to local gift shops.Everything is here, you won't get bored or be disappointed, you at least have to give it a try, takes you out of your resort for a change of scenery and lots to do and see!

you can find anything you want. walking down from paseo del carmen shopping center all the way to CTM you can find great shops , shoes purses dresses and and an incredible amout of amazing restaurants

Not what it used to be.. If you are going to Playa you will most likely go here at least once during your stay. It is fun to see and experience, but not my favorite. Constant heckling by the shop owners is fine for about 10 minutes, but is unavoidable and becomes quite distracting. There are also a lot of new Americanized shops. Not really all that cool, and is no less expensive than the same crap back home. Check it out for sure, but go for drinks and then go elsewhere.

Best place to shop!. Fifth Avenue is the place for shopping in Playa. Everything from clothes, shoes, jewelry, sunglasses can be found along the streets. Never pay the asking price always bargain with the salesman.There are many great restaurants and bars as well. Check Trip Advisor for reviews!

Awesome. Loved Playa del Carmen and everything is pretty much on 5ta Avenida. From shops to bars, restaurants and a mall... you can find anything here. Really cool souvenirs all over the place. Awesome restaurants and bars. Can't wait to visit again!

Great place to window shop and shop. Quinta Avenida is an avenue where you can walk where you can find restaurants, stores, and hotels. It is great experience, Although, it is quite a walk, we did not finish it. But we highly recommend it.

Souvenir Trip on 5th Avenue. This is great place to pick up souvenirs. We stayed at the Blue Bay Esmeralda resort an they have 4 daily trips to 5th Avenue. I had three people say they were our waiter at the Blue Bay and wanted to take us to their store. You will be inundated with people trying to sell you cigars, silver jewelry, and excursions to area tourist attractions. Just ignore them and you will have a good time shopping on your terms.Be sure to bargain with the sellers.

Nice for a stroll both night and day. Found walking this quite interesting. Many shops and bars and fairly reasonably priced. Lot of people offering massage and "waiters from our hotel" present. Usual ploys to get you into shops , but never felt uncomfortable.

Annoying . Where ever you walk there is always some guy trying to get you to go into there store and hassle you to buy something. The locals will come up to you and say "hey remember me I work at your resort" then try to sell you a dodgy tour for a "good price"The stores are nice and the streets itself are cool to look at the store owners are just very annoying and that's why I have it a 2/5.
Not highly recommended . Left a previous review. Vendors are too pricey and better deals can be found other places. They are very pushy and often rude

Good fun for something to do.. Did a half day tour of Playa del Carmen, and it was more than enough. It would have been much more fun in the evening, but just wanted a feel for the area. The street stretches for over 25 blocks and would take at least 45 mins if stopping didn't occur. It's a mix of shops and restaurants that has the feel of Little Cuba in South Beach. Some great restaurants and shops, and some shops were those I never saw in Canada or the USD, so that was a treat. At night it is said to really come to life, with all the lights, sounds. Didn't do that since made other plans that night, but will try to go again, the next time we come. Though if you don't like vendors trying to pull you into a store, this might not be your thing. Just go with an open mind and enjoy it for what it offers.

5th Avenue!. Great shopping! I love getting deals and just going for the walk! The vendors can get pushy but just tell them no not interested and they back off. I felt like they love to barter for deals! I am a Cheapo and feel I get great deals!

Nice stroll. Visited Quinta Avenida and purhcased my souvenirs and ate at some of their restaurants during the day. Many stores and restaurants to chose from. Close to beach area and all tourist areas. Were comfortable shoes as its a long stroll and many areas to cover. Prices are in Pesos, USD and some Euro.

Playa Del Carmen's "Fifth Avenue". This is great place to pick up souvenirs before heading home. You will be inundated with people trying to sell you Cuban cigars, silver jewelry, and excursions to area tourist attractions. If you spend an hour here, that should be more than sufficient. Be sure to bargain with the sellers.

Touristy but not terrible. There are some great people watching places and you can catch some good live music. Food is really hit or miss so check the reviews. I'd say find places to eat just off 5th but walk 5th for the full on tourist experience. Have a few drinks here and there. It is entertaining.

Love 5th ave. We love shopping on 5th avenue. If you don't like pushy people this place is not for you. My wife and I always play good guy bad guy. When we want to purchase something and want to get a better price my wife will say "No its too expensive lets go" then they will drop the price. Then we will do it over and over until we get the price we want.. We are sad that the big named stores are moving in and taking over the small business.
Overrated. Not enjoyable - people accosting you the whole time and nothing really special to buy. Next time we will rent a car and explore

A little bit of everything. You can literally walk up and down this street for days and not see everything it had to offer, great food, tho a bit more pricey than its off the path and just as if not more tasty competitors. We were a bit, understating, turned off by all of the pushy salesman trying to get us to seer this or but that or look at this or that. We specifically went into shops that did not solicit us to go into and found some GREAT little items.

Fun. Good shopping and overall experience. Street hawkers are pushy, but all it takes is a polite "Gracias, No!" And they leave you alone. If you are wearing a resort wristband, they will come up to you and say " Don't you remember me? I was your waiter at (resort name)? Just politely ignore and they go away. Just part of the experience. But a lot of fun, lots of good bars and restaurants.

Great Spot if You Want to be a Tourist. Quinta Avenida is the most touristy place in Playa. It has great restuarants, shopping and it's a very safe place. When you are in Playa you will definitely go to Quinta Avenida. You can't help it. However, I try to stay away from this street as much a possible. There are other many great restaurants and places to shop just a couple of blocks away. Go here, but enjoy the rest of Playa. This place is a tourist trap where you will pay a lot more for everything. When I go to Playa I always go to Quinta Avenida, but I spend way more time everywhere else in Playa. It's safe and way more fun.

Everyone wants to sell you tours. They have some nice little shops and restaurants however you do get sick and tired of the pushy people trying to sell you tours. Also, the souvenirs here are a little over priced, I would recommend to anyone wanting to buy souvenirs to buy them in chedraui or wal mart instead. They sale the same souvenirs for a much much lower price, trust me. Still fun to look and check out what they have. If you are in playa del Carmen you have to come check quinta avenida out

Love the walk.... Taking a stroll down 5th avenue is fun, window shopping, having a beer or 2 then grabbing a bite and afterwards maybe some live music, it's a great way to end a day on the beach...enjoy my friends.

Great shopping place!!. While bisiting playa del carmen we decided to explore outside our resort an took a taxy to La Quinta avenida there we found tons of shops side to side , places to eat an drink. There you can find gifts at great prices but i must say the vendors can be a bit pushy , if u can ignore that then u must visit this place .we walk an walk an didnt get to see the end on the first day so went back 2 days in a row also found some great places to eat the real mexican food.if ur stayin at a resort an wearing a band just beware u may get approched by vendors that will tell you , hey how are u dont u recognize me? I was ur waiter at an they will say the name of ur resort , first time they got me but then after cpl more did the same thing i realize they know wich color band is for wich resort lol so just ignore them.in overall it was an amazing experience i totally recomend this place
Great for a day of shopping. Wide variety of shops but helps to have general idea of prices. Eat at Froggys and people watch the beach
Very Modernized. Sadly tourism has taken over Fifth Avenue! You can find ALL kinds of American shops. I still support local people who work hard to make a living!

Tourist Beware. My husband and I visited 5th Avenue, the main shopping area in Playa Del Carmen, as part of our honeymoon. We were hoping to see something a little less commercial and more authentic than what we'd heard about Cancun. We were unprepared!Shortly after leaving the taxi a gentleman from our hotel restaurant spotted us, came over to say 'hello', and invited us to visit his shop. We were expecting a little trinket shop, maybe with some leather works and sugar skulls, and would have been happy to buy an item or two as gratitude for the friendly service. The shop was a jewellery one, and being unprepared, and too polite to walk away, my husband grudgingly spent £200 on a pendant for me, and £40 on a sugar skull for a friend, and I bought some earings for £40. Back in England those items would have been at least half the price! That's what we found walking further down the avenue also.We were ready for the next member of hotel staff when they took us the their shop, and all along the avenue there were other shop owners trying to call us in. My husband found himself rather on the edge by the time we left, heading home early.About a third of the shops were tourist ones, all with the same stock. The less commercial looking ones were dishonest, quoting one price for goods, but without exact change, taking everything you handed over, saying that was the price they'd quoted. There were a few bars and restaurants, which we didn't go to as our money was pretty much wiped out in that first shop, they looked good though. There was also the rare genuine shop or stall, and these were actually a pleasure to browse and shop in.We were naive and too polite for our own good. Be warned!

Walking the 5th Ave in Playa del Carmen. The Avenue starts just in front of one of the Playacar main entrances; we were staying in Sandos Playacar Hotel & resort.You can walk through almost 2 miles, but you won't see much difference in the shops when you have already walked 5 blocks.The shopping Mall is at the end of the way, but it is not really worth; it is not a bargain.You can get lots of souvenirs, all of them with skulls or the Playa del Carmen writing.Perhaps, if you look well, you can get some nice silver jewelry. I bought for my wife a very nice bracelet in 925 genuin silver with onix for only 220 USA dollars in the very fashion jewelry store inside the Sandos Hotel.
Great . Great for eat for dance for preformance for all the nice Mexican experience totally recommend to walk with family or friends

Where all the action is. . Lively street with tons of interesting shops and restaurants. Definitely the happening area of Playa. Great just to stroll down the avenue any time of day and browse. I would recommend not limiting yourself to this street in terms of restaurant and shops, especially if you want some more authentic and local experiences. Don't be afraid to ignore the business people trying to lure you into their shops and sell you stuff. They don't take it personally and neither should you.
Funny. A diversity of shops and food. Seems to be safe. Better to visit at night as the temperature is a little lower.

The Lincoln road of Mexico. We visited the Avenida about three times during our stay. There is plenty of restaurants and shops around. We never felt unsafe in the area. We parked for 3 dollars on a parking lot. They have a "plaza" at the end of the street were they do a show of the Voladores and something else I cant remember. Take some time and visit this place even if you are not eating or buying something.

Lovely spot for shopping. Great place to find anything you xan think of, from a great souvenir idea to the designer brand you covet back home but in pesos. I'd recommend ignoring the street vendors and just circle back once you have found what you were looking for
Beautiful. just keep walking and only stop in a store that catches your eye some owners will try to get you in their store but if you go in every store it will take you days before you find anything.

A MUST DO. Yes this place is a little overwhelming but still a great place to go and sit at a nice spot to drink a cold beer or people watch. We went here twice...once at night and another time during the day. Did some great shopping, found a great Thai restaurant here in a cut, got a tattoo done here, and we got a chance to hang out and get out the resort!

Awesome but very hot and humid :) . It's a great place to go after hanging out at the beach bc you have a variety of restaurants, snacks, shopping and little nick nacks that are memorable to bring home.

5th Avenue. Went here several times and had a great time.Do not be put off by the salesmen have a laugh with them and enjoy the banter.A mixture of rustic and modern shopping.Always seemed hotter than Playacar.Go enjoy it and don't be put off by the salesmen if you won't tell them what you will pay and go wit the flow

The nightlife is great!. Lots of shops with the same ole stuff. Then you get down to the middle and it's just a big shopping mall that you find in any bigger US city. The bars and clubs however are great! So nice to go in and listen to a live band and have reasonably priced drinks!

Absolutely beautiful. Awesome, beautiful, exotic... I love la Quinta!!! It's very safe to walk on and people are friendly, there are great restaurants although a bit pricier than in other parts of the city.

It's Changing but is still FUN to visit!. Quinta Avenida has changed quite a bit in the last 10 years. We remember it being simple with more local businesses than the fancy new tourist shops and chain stores. Either way, it is still fun to visit and to have lunch, dinner and drinks. There are souvenier shops everywhere and all I can do is encourage you to shop around and some stores are much less expensive then others depending on what you are buying. If you are looking for alcohol, stop by La Europea in the shopping mall located beetween Avenida Constituyentes and Calle 16 norte on the Quinta Avenuda. This was my fist visit and I confirmed prices were definately cheaper than anywhere else! I am often asked about safety and I can confirm safety is not an issue on the Quinta Avenida and nearby side streets. There are tourists galore and security roaming around everywhere. We have walked to Wal-Mart and Mega off of the Quinta each year and never felt in any danger. Just remember that if you don't feel safe, then don't do it. Stay in the well populated areas and you will be fine.Quinta has become more commercialized each year. We stopped going to Cancun years ago because of this. It felt like we were visiting Los Angeles with all the same chain restaurants and shops. Quinta is slowly becoming the same with the addition of shopping malls and high end retail stores. As an example, there is now an Old Navy at the south end near the Cozumel Ferry.No matter what, Quinta Avenida is a MUST for anyone visiting the Riviera Maya! Enjoy!

5th Avenue in Playa. I've been to 5th Avenue several times and really have fun there. The vendors definitely try to get you to go into their stores. Keep in mind that the first price they offer you is NOT what you should pay. Offer half of that price or even less. The hat my friend bought started at $50 U.S. and she ended up buying it for $13. Beware of these guys - they know how to play the game. They know all of the bracelets and will say "Hey, remember me? I was your waiter last night at [your hotel name]" Guess what - they were not your waiter. It's fun to mess around with them though and let them think you believe them. They're all really nice - just know how to play their game. I love Playa and will continue to go there for shopping, a drink and a snack every time I visit the area.

Fun at night, overpriced during the day. Quinta is a fun little stroll to take at night, particularly where it meets with 12th street (clubs everywhere). For souvenir shopping however I recommend walking around the side streets and exploring a bit further. We ended up buying cute shot glasses and magnets for a third of the price on a side street close to the "La Mega" supermarket. And by the way, for your tequila shopping definitely go to the supermarket and not to a touristy store.Like another visitor commented below, the "remember me from the hotel" scam is a classic way to lure you into shops. I didn't realize it until much, much later and I am so glad to read his review because it confirms my suspicion ;)From Quinta I recommend "La N,20", a nice restaurant/bar next to the H&M store where drinks are good and ambiance is even better. Didn't try the food since we were staying at an "all inclusive", but the music there was really good. On the corner of Quinta and Av. Constituyentes, check out "Ah Cacao" for some gourmet gifts and fancy - delicious - chocolate.

"Hey, remember me from the hotel?" . Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) shopping is a fun experience for those unaccustomed to haggling, or taking a fish spa foot treatment. Priced items are the preferred prices for the seller, but not necessarily the sale price. Have fun and test your skills. My wife saved nearly 65% on a necklace for our daughter. A word of caution though – one of the “hooks” used by street vendors is that they are on their day off from working at the resort. After a couple of times hearing “Hey! Remember me – <name> from the hotel?” I decided to ask which hotel. The vendor got the right resort (by the Paradisus wrist band), but the wrong hotel at the resort. The jig was up, and we got a good laugh out of the lesson.

Paradise beach town . Have visited many places but none which offer everything that 5th and Playa have to offer, all in a convenient contained area just steps from ocean. You will find everthing from large US stores, local stores, jewellery stores, cosmetic stores, hotels, bars and restaurants aligning the street which gets more magical by night as they bright lights start shining. There's nowhere quite like la quinta
Night party. Very nice center , the Quinta Avenida is about 5 km of shopping center , souvenir shop , restaurant and amazing Disco for a crazy night.
Worth the trip. Good experience, lots of shopping wife love it. You will find major brands like any mall in the states average prices, plus Mexican goods. They also have excellent restaurants.

Fun for everyone. We walked around through the what felt like miles of shops. We enjoyed the culture of this and got a lot of fun stuff. I bought a hammock, an outfit, a picture frame, shot glasses, and some bracelets and anklets. We took our three year old and five year old with us. The kids loved walking along side the pigeons.

Very (too) touristic. If you are into bars and (USA like) restaurants and environment, you will have plenty of places to visit here. We found this as a turn off from our visit. We felt a non-traditonal Mexican experience walking around this street. There are too many stores and malls, much like the USA. We were also subject to intense, and aggressive sales pitches from vendors and tour guides.A few steps away, there is a vibrant and more authentic city.

Something for Everyone!. A delightful street with something for every kind of shopper. Higher end stores to kitschy souvenirs, 5th Avenue has it. We had scrumptious shrimp and beef tacos and veggie burritos - authentic Mexican - yay! While Taking advantage of the sun, outdoor seating and people watching.So much to see and do. My favourite store - Prison Art. Exquisite leather hand bags that are truly pieces of art. Besides the originality in the one of a kind pieces is the help that the families of the prisoners receive. Proceeds from the sale of the goods, all made by hand by the prisoners, go to the inmates families.

Mexican Bazzar- Nothing Sspecial. Coming from Arizona and visiting Puerto Penasco Mexico at least once a year, 5th Avenue was disappointing. Shop after shop of the same old Mexican tourist items, serapes, shot glasses, t-shirts, etc. It may be of interest to the college partiers, but seasoned travelers should avoid this place. The constant haranguing from the store working, lying about being your waiter and trying to get you to timeshare presentations also detracts from this.
convenient to walk fast early in the morning !. ti go straight and quickly in the morning, take it, all shops are only opening, no insistant vendors, no trourists, just great !

Nice and colored walk. Is a great street the Strip of Playa del Carmen, with a lot of attractions, bars, restaurants and the great Plaza de fundadores or the port from where you can take the ferri and visit the island of Cozumel. Of course every thing is for tourist. If you want to visit the street around or the Local market you can rent a bike
Expensive!. Thought we could get some bargains in 'Fifth Avenue [Quinta Avenida], but although they like to haggle, was still very expensive. Although at night, it is very lively and worth a visit.

Soak up the atmosphere!!!!. If you're in Playa del Carmen and you're looking for somewhere with atmosphere, then 5th Avenue is it! Be prepared to walk though as it must be about 2km long and ladies wear your flat shoes!!!! Lots of great shops and restaurants for every taste and budget. It's great to visit there day or night, but personally for me there is something about the magic of 5th Avenue at night, kind of has a carnival feel to it.
Touristy. Exactly what you would expect in a location like this. A lot of chinzy shops and American bars with shopkeepers trying to get your attention.

Lots of shops and action!. Year after year it gets more crowded and more shops. Gone are the days of a quiet beach town. We found it overwhelming last year so this year we only went once to pick up some gifts and get off it quickly. The harassment to come into shops can get really annoying after a few blocks but you can find almost anything on this street and many bars, restaurants , and night clubs. If you want authentic food you will have to get off 5th ave and explore other streets.

You Can't miss it. It is the heart of Playa del carmen, full of shops and tours agents to arrange your trip and stays.. nightclubs and restaurant are always open to serve you from cocktails, hookah, cigars, breakfast, snacks or a tasty meal... feel free to bargain on anything and everything (shops are excluded)
Downtown walk. Nice walking by night. Excellent to buy popular souvenirs, have a drink and shopping. If you are looking for truly mexican restaurant or handkraft it might not be the best option.

Shopping and checking out the area. Great ppl the area was cultural. Lots of shops and new tastes. There are places for getting your favorite thing that is a harder to find on the resort (for me it was Canada dry ginger ale). The worst part was some of the places that sell the great souvenirs didn't take credit...and the atm charged $20.

The main street of Playa del Carmen. This is the most tourist street in Playa del Carmen. Year after year it's have been growing in length and in stores. Today you can find almost all major international and local shops there, as a high diversity of restaurants.

Don't drink the tequila samples... . Our first experience started at the end of the avenue early in the day. There are a lot of people that talk to you as you walk by trying to get you to buy excursion from them. We had a couple of guys come up to us and say, " it's me, Jose, form 'hotel name' it's my day off" that's how they think they are going to get you to stop and talk to them. At first we felt awkward not acknowledging them so we would try to explain that we were not interested. After three blocks you get the hang of it and just walk by staying "no thank you." Be careful with the tequila samples. I fell for it when we went to Mexico City when i was like, " yeah I'll take your free samples", and then walked away with all kinds of souvenirs including two sombreros. This last trip my husband bought me a beautiful silver ring off of fifth just to have it tarnish the next day. This happened after my visit to Fat Tuesdays and my "free tequila" shots here. There are good places to sit and have some good food and drinks. Just keep in mind that this is a tourist attraction and the vendors are fast talkers.

Interesting cultural experience but be careful. Checking out fifth ave is a must for the outgoing adventurer. Bars and shopping is all over. Just be wary of aggressive sales tactics and shady merchandise. Pro-tip, if you are staying at an all inclusive and have a resort bracelet on, people on the street will approach you and say they are from your resort to try and lure you into their store or talk to you. Offers for drugs and prostitutes abound. But their are some cool shops, restaurants and a beautiful beach.
Must See in Playa. Almost all of the tourism in Playa lies on 5th Avenue. There's always something going on, the food is great and the shopping is awesome.

long path of shops and vendors. Well what can you expect your in Mexico, pushy vendors and same pricing from store to store. The area can be busy at night and rightfully so as there is a lot of people, September is the best time to travel as business is slower and not as busy. It is still a wonderful place to go and there are some excellent restaurants, such as El Diaz (Argentinian) food, try the flan caramel desert it is to die for. Stroll down to the ferries and you will find some street vendors selling fruit, expect to pay $25 pesos or $2 Canadian, I always get the mangos.

Decent shops . During our cruise shore excursion to Chaak Tun Cenote (Secret River and famous 5th Ave shopping) the tour allowed our group to spend about 1.5 hours shopping and venturing around the 5th Avenue area near the beach at Playa Del Carmen. WE WANTED MORE TIME. My wife and I have already been to this area once before and was teased with a short amount of time to take the area in. Many of the shops are great for souvenirs, or whatever you want, from local vendors to more established shops, to high end clothing. The center area past fifth Avenue is beautiful. During our limited time we saw several musicians all playing music atop of a large pole (50+ft). Several of the stores featured local collectibles and Dias De Los Muertos themed stores and artwork.
5th Avenue. Always a place to visit when in the Riviera Maya .... to just stroll up and down, check out some bars or restaurants, buy a few souvenirs, and just enjoy the day !!!!

Nice night out. It's a great time walking around... They have modernized parts to more like a mall which is upsetting but they still have a long area of the more traditional shopsBeware tho you will hear a lotHey. Come check out my stuff

Tons to look at!. Tons to see and buy but starts getting tiresome after all the sales pitches. You will definitely find what you're looking for here unless it's authentic food. You will have to go a bit outside the tourist area for authenticity.
Stop the hassling. Great little walk way..and shops.Too many ppl staring and asking u to enter the shop.. Avoid the scams and cover your bracelet.. They pretend to work at your resort.. Lies..

Pushy sellers and crowded bars. It's hard to walk a few feet without being harassed, yes harassed, by sellers. It's a very crowded avenue, with people bumping into each other, surrounded by repetitive stores with merchandise often made in China or elsewhere in the world, filled with restaurants offering food usually bought at local "Sam's club" but served at posh New York prices. Why did I use the term "harassed" because when walking as family with kids, we were asked several times by a few different local people if we wanted to buy "weed" or cheap cigars! Definitely not our fav place but, on the upside, if you miss your Krispy Kremes or Starbucks coffee - you can find a few locations along this strip.

A Casual Walking and Shopping Experience. My family and I have vacationed in Mexico for the last 3 years, and we would never miss an opportunity to walk down 5th Avenue in Playa Del Carmen. There is something there for everyone: Restaurants, shops, hotels, you name it! It's a "Don't Miss It" destination! Do yourself a favor and go!
Fun. Good for shopping as well as drinking and eating totaly safe we went down 5th ave four times in our two week holiday and had lot's of fun.

Very touristy ... but where the 'action' is. I was GRANDPAcking in PDC for 2 weeks and visited 5th Avenue often.It is a 2km stretch of tourist shops, restaurants, and bars ... at tourist prices.Weak Happy Hour 2-for-1 cocktails for about MXP85.Buckets of 5 x 330ml beers for as low as MXP100-120.Meals averaging about MXP200.There are so many restaurants and bars that the tourists can't fill them; on many occasions you will be one of the few people there.BUT, it is where the 'action' is ... there is very little else outside of 5th Avenue ... yes, you can find restaurants and bars in the surrounding streets ... but, not with the same 'ambiance'.If you come to PDC, you will want to be within walking distance of 5th Avenue.

combination of new and old. First time I visited in '99.... 4 blocks long... NOW 1 mile!! Great combination of traditional and new UPSCALE shops and restaurants!! Can spent days exploring everything. Has traditional "Hawkers" trying to get you into their "Uncle's" Shop. Just part of the experience. Just tell them no thanks. Negotiate in dollars and Pesos and keep the conversion rate in mind. We got better prices when we paid in Pesos.

A must see!. Everytime we've been to Mexico, we've gone to 5th Avenue. It's filled with tons of shops, and steps away from the beach. It's very safe, and filled with tourists. Beware of one scam though: people will try to lure you into their shops by looking at your bracelet to figure out which resort you're from, and pretending they know you. "Hey, remember me from ___? The waiter?" Don't fall for it!!
Great outing. We walked this area throughout (it's quite a walk but a nice one) and ate and shopped at various locations. We felt safe at all times and it was perfect for an afternoon trip.
Good Deals!. Some vendors were worth avoiding. But overall great shopping and even better food! Plus the beach is a 5 minute walk away.

Lots to see but harassed too much. I've always enjoyed 5th Ave. but the harassment of the vendors will make me stay elsewhere next vacation. I know they are all desperate to make money.... But enough is enough. I shouldn't have to say no 5 times to get you to leave me alone. If I am shopping I certainly don't need you following me around the store babbling in my face. Makes me NOT want to buy ANYTHING from you..... No matter what the price.
Shopping and drinking!. Excellent place for take a walk, go shopping and also, have a meal or a drink in one of its thousands restaurants. It is a large street full of life and a lot of diversity.

Very entertaining. Great fun wandering through fifth Avenue with its wide array of souvenir and big name designer shopping as well as numerous bars and restaurants suitable for all types of dining to fit all budgets. Be warned the avenue stretches for over 3kilometres so wear comfortable foot wear if you intend to walk the full street

Lots of great shops and restaurants. This is a great shopping avenue, you are constantly solicited by the many shop owners to come into their shop, restaurant, massage parlour, or tour company. Its typical of any Mexican tourist town and the prices are a little higher than some of the other cities that we have visited.

5th Ave. of the Mayan Riviera. I can't explain it in enough words about the experience you will have walking down this wonderful street. Suffice it to say you need to have lots of willpower and the energy to say 'no' to the many shopkeepers that will hawk you about their wares. From knick knacks, cigars, silver items to clothing etc. there are many choices and you will be inundated and enchanted at the same time. Just sit back and enjoy the stroll.
family night. nice to walk!! so many place to shop and eat!! ,safe, friendly people. a lots clubs for all ages! you can miss this place. VIVA MEXICO!!!I WILL COME BACKDG

Anything you want!. Well..almost anything. High end stores mixed in with the little local shows and stands. If you buy jewelry try to buy from a regular jewelry store unless you are an expert on authentic stones or silver. Many hawkers so don't be rude but don't be manipulated. A smile and No, gracias goes a long way. I must have said it fifty times. Lol..but its all part of the culture on the Avenue.

I thought it would be more international. There is a lot of shops, but mostly mexicans souvenir and really over prices ... I was expecting more designer brand... Walking there is still a pleasure time. Lot of restaurant, the view in perpendicular streets to the beach are cute.
For shoppers! . I'm not a shopper when it comes to vacation, I like local culture, not shop for brand names! The street is nice!

Nicer and Nicer. This is the heart of Playa and I was pleased to see many refurbished/newly decorated facades of buildings. There is a new Mall but all buildings are below 5 storeys which means Playa will not become Cancun. Definitely looking better with time, which is great to see. Plenty of restaurants and shops to choose from, try the croissants at Chez Celine, they are to dye for, well worth the walk there.
Best place to buy souvenirs . Very safe place to walk around and purchase souvenirs . This street is within walking distance from the Royal hotel . Coco bongo is also located here .
Overrated. . All bussiness, you can buy excursions cheap at the street Kiosks. Gelato is delicious. You can get a.cheap massage.
regular stuff, but not "trap". you find what you expect to find, and was not overvharged. Regular tourist wares. plenty of food (good one)

Interesting. They are all trying to get you to come into their shops or to buy something. Ignore them or say no thanks. If you go in most items are marked up 100% or more. Price items at Wal-mart or Mega first as some buy the items there in the souviner section. Be willing to haggle for everything. If they refuse walk. They usually will come down then. Which if they did I usually kept on walking. There is a million ways to spend your money here. Go several blocks West of 5th to the non pushy shops and you will find the same items far cheaper. You just have to look.

Beggers Banquet. OK, we all know the hustle..but this street takes it to a new level. Dishonest businesses abound, street hawkers over running the street, waiters padding bills and lots of overpriced items. It is a shame because once you get out in the county the people there are honest and kind.

Interesting view of Mexico!. Pass through the areas where locals live on the way here, then you see the locals mixed with the tourists with so many shops, your mind boggles! There are scammers trying to say they know you from ... and their cousin or mother or grandma opened this shop, let me show you... so just keep walking! The small shops deal if you are at all interested... but you should keep looking! Was too hot this time to get a massage, but usually it is very inexpensive to get massage for 2... they are all outside under tents or by fans, and not air conditioned, so in 98 degree weather, that's not a good option. Good Mexican food at 5th Ave. as well...

Beautiful downtown except for the street pushers!. This is a beautiful area filled with wonderful shops & delicious restaurants. However, the constant street "vendors/sellers" are annoying. You can't walk two feet without one of them trying to sell you "cheap/junk" (those are their words). I just wanna walk around & absorb the area not being pushed ever 5 mins to buy something from them. I will buy just not from you...ugh. Now back to this amazing downtown area!! Pretty, rustic with modern buildings, & foods to die for. Plus feels safe walking around. Eat at Aldea Corazon... Hidden gem!! Looks like a basic restaurant from outside. Once inside it sits atop a Cenote & is tropical w/palms, stones, & a cozy intimate setting!

Fun and Amazing place . Shopping, restaurants, clubs, this area is amazing if you are a tourist in this area. Its safe, police is always around and that makes you feel better I guess. People selling stuff are all over of course be ready to be approached by one of them every 5 seconds. Is in a way clean and nice. A must go place if you are in Playa del Carmen. We had a lot of fun, there was no incidents, everything was nice and fun.

Really Interesting!. I went with my friends to Playa del Carmen, and decided to go to the 5th Avenue, there you can find cashiers machine from differents banks, a lot of restaurants and bars of differents types.

Typical holiday gift avenue. Your typical shopping avenue, plenty of local gift shops mixed with your high street chains none of which are cheap, however there are bars and restaurants providing reasonable priced drinks and food. The avenue is busy but expect your usual pushy sales people. All that said its worth a visit especially if you like to people watch.

Fun place. Nice place to walk around. You can spend hours in this area shopping, dining and clubbing. The atmosphere here is very nice and lively. No visit is complete without going here where the locals & the tourists hang out.

Great time window shopping and fun dining area. We enjoyed a few breakfasts and lunches at various spots on Quinta Avenida. There are tons of people trying to attract you into their shops full of local jewelry, crafts and souvenir items. If you go in, be prepared to deal before you buy. Prices are very negotiable! My husband bought me a beautiful Mexican fire opal ring for about a fifth of the originally quoted price. I have been wearing it proudly ever since. Do be aware, however, that many sales people will approach you as if they know you from the resort you are staying in (and if you wear a bracelet, they can tell which one). If you aren't up for anything more than window shopping, best not to stop and chat. Just nod, smile and walk away.

terrible... salespeople wouldn't leave me alone!!. I walked with my wife on Quinta Avenida from 42nd street all the way to the ferry station. That's 2.0km (1.27miles) and I counted 12 guys offering me drugs - blow, pot, ecstasy. On the way back to 42nd, I did not bother counting anymore.I couldn't walk for 20 seconds without having some guy step almost directly in front of me to ask me if I wanted to buy cigars or other stuff. One of them made me laugh when he said "Same junk... only cheaper!"Not a peaceful place at all. The majority of the restaurants are mediocre. The "trendy" ones aren't THAT great (if you have been to New York ONCE you know what I mean).I'm not going back... what a pain!!

Family vacation 2016. Great place to visit and shop. Mixture of different stores to shop at and restaurants to eat at. The people were mostly friendly, however we were approached by 1 or 2 locals pretending to be our waiters at the hotel-to figure out that our bracelets were dead giveaways for anyone.I would recommend going but hide your bracelets yo not get hassled.

AV. 5 in Playa del Carmen - You WILL Be ripped in TEQUILA-shops!!. Just wanting to buy a bottle of tequila for the eventing, we went into a specialised tequila shop, this for the first time!Looking around, I found a bottle of Hernandez which I wanted.Then with a lot of overwhelming attention, I thought oké, I will try the suggested tequila (Atalaje Reposado).My wife did the payment.At home, it appeared we paid 2.050 Pesos, which is about €. 100,00!Whatever I did, but I could not find any information about this particular bottle.We went back with Mexican friends, and according to the law, they are obliged to ask any amount of money, when the price is visible.And ... yes it was, underneath every bottle there was a 1x1 cm sticker!!!To go short ....: 1. They have a pile of unknown brands of tequila and a few known original ones!2. They WILL sell you the unknown ones3. The prices you pay are excessive for ....4. DON'T GO THERETIP !! There is a great shop for Tequila, Mezcal and Deli's in one of the new shopping malls !! and they have understanding of the product!! and they have fair prices !!

What Americans expect to find in Mexico. This is a weird street, it definitely isn't a Mexican town street, it's not a hi end tourist street. It's a combination of a Mexican street trying to cater to American tourist expectations.

you will find everything you need !. souvenirs for family and friends, nice restaurants, bar, places where you can enjoy fish spa, or a fresh coconut for 2 go...i love this street ! a nice place for burgers or ice cream...the beach is super close..so you have always the chance to buy something in the supermarket instead of spending a lot of money in the restaurants at the beach... ther is a also a nike store !

Plenty of options. Nice shopping, however outdoor vendors are very pushy and can be a little off putting. There was a liquor store that had some massive bottles, which were great to take pictures with.

Cool and trendy spot. We went to La Quinta Avenida twice, and we wish we could have spent more time there. It's about 20 or more streets with lots of restaurants, bars, stores, street vendors, brand-name stores, etc. The night scene and atmosphere is pretty cool with live music and in some restaurants. There are also sport bars where you can watch football!!!

Greatest Salespeople In The World!. Shopping on 5th Avenue is a combination Yard Sale / Flea Market / Mall, with the best of all three. You will find small shops with vendors practically begging (or demanding) that you come in. Their prices will start high, so be prepared to negotiate at these shops. You will also find many shops that are more tourist oriented. They don't negotiate on price, but sell nicely priced souvenir items. There are also plenty of local restaurants here with good food and reasonable prices. I have visited Quinta Avenue in Playa del Carmen at least 8 times the past 4 years, and will continue to do so. I've only visited for shopping, but hear they have great night life also! Even if you just walk up and down the street, it is well worth a visit!
Beautiful place to visit!. This place is absolutely beautiful. The main street is surrounded by nice stores and restaurants. Very safe to take a walk.

Lots of Shops and Restaurants. You have to go at least once to see what it's all about. There are tons of restaurants, which are all basically the same. There are a few that are really good. Many will boast of having a/c to which you get in and it's only fans. We found it funny, others may get annoyed. There are a lot of places to change your money, but most people take dollars and credit cards. Some will prefer dollars, but make sure you ask their exchange rate because it might be a better deal to pay in pesos. There's a lot of people vying for your attention, don't get distracted by them..just say no thanks and keep moving if you're not interested. Please, go visit the Cigar Factory. There's an older man who rolls the cigars by hand, he's a very nice man. They have a mall now, which may appeal to the richer vacationers. Bathrooms in Mexico, as you are aware are hard to find. Most shops will say they don't have a bathroom and if they do they always want money, but this street it's a little easier to find one without having to pay. I found that Starbucks in the beginning of the mall has a great bathroom,although single stall: and there's a/c throughout the mall. I feel everything is way too expensive in this area, even the food. For some reason, they have restaurants that claim to be real Mexican food, but it's more like fancy food for the richer citizen. My husband is from Jalisco, and we go to Mexico often. We are used to street food (tacos, corn, tamales), sadly you won't find it on this street. Some of the roads which lead to the beach look sketchy and clubby. I'm sure if you're young, and you like that sort of thing, there are tons of bars to go to. I feel the beach/area has changed quite a bit since the last time we came (6 years ago). Seems extremely commercialized, with less beach and more businesses. Even though this seems like more of a bad review, it's not. Many will fall in love with this place, it's perfect for the younger crowd with plenty of hostels and hotels, and bars. Photographers- this is a great place for different backgrounds. You'll love it. Enjoy!
nice to strawl and find a few restaurants but full of turists traps. you must come to quinta avenida, but just be ware of not so great bargains. do you research and you will be fine

Annoying salesman. This place sucked....everyone sells the same things and get mad if you don't stop and see what they have to offer....restaurants sucked one salesman offered weed and got upset cuz I didn't want any...

Interesting place to visit. There are a lot of shops and bars on this street. Several night clubs are located on this street or are visible from this street. The stuff is a little expensive because this is where all the tourist go. You can walk 3-4 blocks away from the beach and get a better deal.
Birthday gateway. This place is so beautiful, you can walk, eat, shop or just have fun. Super safe, all the people is nice, enjoy !!

Mexico shopping strip . If you have been to Mexico before- pretty much same trinkets as you would get any where else. High pressure sales. But that being said had some good conversation and laughs with the shop promoters. Definitely worth checking out!

Worth Checking out. Lots of things to see and purchase. Very busy and happening area. I almost gave this 4 out of 5 but because of the aggressiveness of the locals trying to sell you things it kind of put a damper on things. Most would leave you alone after saying NO to them once. But the ones who didn't I totally messed with them and had fun with it! One asked if we wanted to buy cocaine lol. We are not into any drugs whatsoever but I think they were just trying to get us to pay attention to them and come into their shop. Don't worry, you're completely safe. We ended up buying things in a less aggressive area on fifth avenue (Near the Harley-Davidson outlet) for more money. If you've never been, you absolutely have to experience it. It was overall a nice walk if anything and lots of things to see.

Lots of Overpriced Souvenirs. We were entertained by the vast array of cheap tshirts, keychains, etc. There were also an amazing number of hawkers pressuring us to look in their shops, including some who also worked at our hotel and called to us, reminding us they worked at the hotel. We said hello and that we either weren't looking for whatever they were selling or didn't want to spend more than $25. To the other hawkers we just said "gracias, no." There were a few upscale jewelry and clothing shops, which I managed to get out of by offering $25-$30 for the items they were pushing for $100 or more. We really didn't see anything we wanted that was original, like pottery, or reasonably priced, like jewelry or leather goods. It's good for a visit and maybe lunch, but ask someone, such as your concierge or a native you take a tour with, where else you can find the items you want. We did and got ceramics for a reasonable price.

not what it wast. this is a fun place to hang out but quickly becoming very commercial and Americanized. Over the past several years we have watched as it has changed from a laid back place to eat, shop, and interact with locals to a commercial center with a big mall with Victoria's secret, Bath & Body Works, etc.A few Mexicans I've spoken with said they have trouble even using pesos at some of the stores.This has led to even more aggressive sales techniques from the local vendors to try to keep up.Not what I want to see when I go on vacation, but that's my opinion.
Loved it!. We went 2 days in a row, loved the shopping. We were there one night until after 7pm. Very safe place

lots of shops and bars. very busy with all the usual shops and bars, the Tequila Bar/sports bar is the best for people watching. Lots of waiters from hotels saying 'hey do you remmebr me, I am (name) from your hotel, cos they see the wrist band, don't be fooled !
It was alright . Not all that. Lots of sellers which I hated. Very crowded and everyone wants your attention. Stores were not anything special either.
Must See, Essential Playa. This is our version of a boardwalk, an entire street closed off to traffic, with bars, restaurants, and all sorts of shops are lined up for 20 city blocks.

5th Ave is Great for walking. Beware of drug dealers on 4th st and 6th st, they hang out in some bars like Jannah so be careful buying drugs since they are very bad for you and you never know who you are dealing with
5th ave. has a bunch of shops, bars and places to dine. you can also catch some street preformers. Very close to the beach.

Party hard!. This is famous street with a lot of shopping stores, clubs and restaurants. At the end is the beach and overthere you can find more restaurants and clubs. If your plan is lost your mind with a party hard night this is definitely the place. Before 11pm is more relax and you can have a few drinks or walk with your family but after midnight wait to see people dancing everywhere. Is the mexican style of Kaosan Road in Bangkok. I will recommend go to the beach eat there and come back to your hotel dress casual and go to the clubs! Check the Mandala and Blue Parrot by far the best ones! Pretty awesome I would say!

LOTS AND LOTS OF SHOPPING!!. This is a very very long street of shopping restaurants and bars. It gets very packed at night between 6-10PM. Most stores will close at around 10PM to begin the ramp up to the Playa night life. But it is a great place to shop for all your souvenir needs when going to Playa Del Carmen.
Great. Great shopping area. Amazing restaurant to eat. Had the best mexican taco. Playa del carmen is beautiful most see. People are so friendly and nice

Fun!. A must visit if in Playa del Carmen. Its just a very long street with lots of holiday type shops, bars and restaurants. Felt safe even with our two 11 year olds and it is fun. People were all friendly and you don't get hassled too much by the shop touts! We went a couple of times and enjoyed.

Cool Shopping Area. Love to shop on 5th Avenue. Lots of cool and unique stores. There is a multi floor air conditioned H&M. Minutes from most resorts. A cab from my resort cost $5 usd. Lots of security, pretty safe tourist area.

Club. Excellent to spend an evening, dining, open clubs.we went to the shops at night. The place was lit up and very safe to walk. You have many stores to choose from. Rolex, Cartier, H&M, and a lot of souvenir shops. Authentic dining , bars and music to cheer you up. The Taxi were reasonable.
Good times by all. Great food, amazing cocktails and awesome fun. Not for kids at night but the day time is ok. Something to do and see for all age groups.

Awesome, Must see !. Great place to visit. Many shops, bars restaurants and attractions. Stop in a restaurant to have some great local food and a cool drink, maybe some desert.
