The ferry to Cozumel is only steps away and there are many other excursions you can do nearby. I would definitely recommend people to go and check it out..

Great shopping. This is one place that my husband and I really enjoyed. We were able to walk from The Royal Playa del Carmen and we felt completely safe in this area. There's lots of options for shopping from cultural items, tshirts, upscale shopping, and stores you see back in the states!

Long Walk!. Along the "5 Avenida" you will find all the nice restaurants and stores. There are a lot of options ranging from local food to international cuisine, as any tourists place there are some restaurants that basically are tourist traps. Try to avoid the places that are obviously oriented for tourist, you will be better off looking a little harder to find a good restaurant. After walking all the street you will have seen stores like H&M, Zara, Quicksilver, etc. etc. and in the end you will find the public beach and ferry port to Cozumel.
Great for shopping and walking. Quinta Avenida is a must for anyone wanting to see the tourist shopping zone. It has great restaurants, and shops.
Shopping. Tons of vendors with 40+ streets to walk through. Be careful with vendors who will try to sell you anything from marijuana to hard drugs.
Nice to stroll. Local sellers may attempt to tell you they work at the hotel you stay at so buy souvenirs from them. Ignore unwanted sales pitch

A must see!. You can't go to Playa Del Carmen and not spend the day here. Yes, you will be aggressively harassed to buy stuff. It takes some time to get used to that. There are lots of bars and restaurants to try. Many different types of shopping, from little stands to mall stores. We stopped at a few places for beers, but didn't eat anywhere. It is right close to the beach so you can do both. Also this is where you can take the ferry to Cozumel. We spent one day here on our vacation...one was enough for us.

Great to find cheap souvenirs. We went here just to look around and see if we could find souvenirs a bit cheaper than the resorts and we sure did. The only thing I didn't like was that there were some stores where the vendors were a bit pushy, bit this is to be expected at almost every tourist shopping place. There were some guys performing a traditional show where one is dancing at the top of a pole and later the others hang from the same until they are down. It was nice to see.

Ate and shopped at different places every day. We ate different types of meals every day and went shopping for souvenirs and easily found and purchased items we forgot. Everything is reasonably priced, just check your receipts. You will constantly get asked to go on excursions, just smile and walk away.
Didn't feel safe. Be careful, it's shady and street business is ran by a cartel.Drugs offered, some people follow you around.Keep an eye and don't venture much.Overpriced as well.
Long walk. Love all the stores and restaurants. Long walk be prepared for all the hagglers. I ate at the Parilla restaurant, very good food at a good price.
Lots of things to see and buy, just be ware of prices.. never buy anything at the first price, walk away to the next stand for a better price or try to get a fair piece with the merchant

Amazing food and shopping but too much of the hard sell. Must visit when you are in Playa del carmen. Tons of incredible restaurants, nightclubs, stores and malls of everything you could possibly want and just a block west of the sand and ocean. Walk the whole thing and you will watch the neighborhoods change as you go with each section having its own little vibe. The only negative is all of the people trying to sell you things and constantly giving you the hard sell for tours, restaurants etc. Just keep walking and say No Gracias an you will be fine. they are mostly good people just trying to make a living and will not bother you.BEWARE when buying silver jewelry on the street, it quite often turns up to be fake, make sure you buy it from a reputable jewelry store.Check with your hotels and online for the best prices for tours and dont always buy the hard sell that the people on the streets give you for tours, they are all working on the same basic tours for the most part. Be safe, and have fun!! there is something for everyone on 5th ave.

The happening spot.. La Quinta Avenida, (5th Avenue) is Playa Del Carmen's happening spot. It runs parallel to the shore and you can see the ocean at every corner.The street is closed to traffic and it is lined with restaurants, hotels, souvenir and jewelry shops, and clothing boutiques. Definitely a shopper's paradise.The night life is mostly high class restaurants and bars frequented by European expats.
Gotta see it to believe it. Get better deals closer to the playa del carmen beach . It's uncomfortable being solicited to so aggressively but also part of the charm. Diverse stores n restaurants

a must go if you have time. This is comparable to Ocean Ave in Miami. Lots of great shopping like you would see in the US. For example, Victoria's Secret, Nike, Sephora, Mac, H&M, Zara Home etc. This was mixed in with local stores. I would suggest coming here at night around 7ish and going to dinner/bar and walking around. It was very safe and entertaining to people watch.

Not to be missed if you are in Playa del Carmen area.. Amazing steet with all kind of stores, large commercial shopping malls, restaurants, bars and entertainment. Not to be missed if you are in Playa del Carmen area. You will need at leat to days to go thru. plus the beach is just two blocks away. Great place to buy the best souvenirs. I would say is about 2 miles long.

Eateries and tourist gift shops. If you're not staying at an all inclusive, chances are you'll be coming here for dinner. This is where you'll find all the restaurants along with the usual US high street brands (Starbucks, McDonalds, H&M) along with seemingly hundreds of touristy gift shops. It's a looong street, starting at the ferry port. This is where the action is.
OMG!!. Beautiful...many restaurants to choose from, bars, stores, lots of lights at night, it was incredible.

Busy so busy. The shopping district of 5th was close to our hotel so we frequented it a lot during our August vacation. Theres mostly small local shops and good redtaursnts, buthe far too busy for us, I would not recommend going with kids unless it's really early.
Fun place to shop for souvenirs. "Almost free for you", lots of traditional and non-traditional stores to choose from. You could spend a couple hours or a day here.
Love 5th Avenue. 5th Avenue is where we walk every night. We love the atmosphere. So many little restaurants and bars.
Beautiful walking time. 5TH Avenue much better than 4 years ago.New shopping mall a little more secure to walk.New stores and smiling faces great pictures from Playa del Carmen
Nice place to hang out . You get to see many good bars and restaurants while walking there, so it is a good place to hang out and find a place to eat, have a drink or do some shopping

Typical tourist trap, but fun anyway.. My wife and I went there for souvenir shopping, figuring it was a bit "touristy". Did not disappoint in that respect. Lots of junk souvenirs, cheap tequila in expensive-looking bottles, and vendors inviting you into their stores. I must have run into at least a hundred waiters from my resort out there, because they all sure "remembered" us from the resort. The only downside was the relatively high number of guys selling drugs who approached us. Other than that, the beer's cheap and cold and you can find plenty of cheap souvenirs for your in-laws.

Nice avenue.. Nice street, full of things to buy, although I wouldn't recommend to buy there the souvenirs, because it's really expensive. They give you the price in dollars, and you think 'oh, that's only 3 dollars' but the truth is you can buy it in less then 1 dollar.For example, the cellphone bag you can take into the water- they sell it in 200 pesos, but if you walk 1 and a half blocks, you can find it in 29 pesos.

Great! . Quinta Avenida is not what it used to be. Now it is modern and with luxurious stores, yet it still has that at amazing vibe to it. It is now more expensive but it is nice for walk y around. Sip on ice cream ir evento window shop if you don't have The budget for shopping. There are lots of restaurantes to pic from for your dinning experience !

Great Trip!. It was perfect, we went at the end of the day. It was not too hot perfect for the walk. One thing I did not like it is that its too americanize. I was hoping to find more things to represent Mexican culture. I found there are too many stores that I can easily find here in New York. I was looking to see more stores that reflect the Mexican culture.

Shop around . I always take the shifter from the hotel to 5th ave to buy souvenir and stuff its cheaper than the hotel and its better deal for you money some store pay more for the dollar that the exchange place so shop atound for the best deal.

Not what I was expecting ;(. We went down here one evening, we got a taxi from our hotel the Grand Xcaret Resort, which was too pricey at all. There was a newish shopping centre with a few good stores newly built at the end of the Quinta Avenida, which was pleasant enough and my teens got a few T-shirts etc from Pull and Bear in the sale. We had a Starbucks Coffee sat outside ( I don't drink alcohol ) and had a walk down the main street, but I was pretty underwhelmed if honest. Lots of street vendors and it went from looking nice at the end we started at to a bit tacky if I am honest. Granted I am in my 40's, with a husband and two teens, def. not our scene.

Fun, but not the only option.. Quinta Avenida is where much of the action is in Playa. However, don't get stuck there. We found really great restaurants just a few blocks away, (Blue Pointe Grill, Oh Lala, La Coronela) that are well worth the effort. The shopping is nice and the night life exciting. And of course, the beach is only a block or two away.

Long street for shopping and Mexican Atmosphere . 5th Ave is most unlike its American namesake. It is a real mix of local souvenir shops next to high end designer shops. I liked starting at the Paseo del Carmen a high end open air shopping mall. Next to it are typical souvenir stores and loads of atmosphere. It's a perfect opportunity to soak up the local life at the Parque fundadores. Catch the local Mayan dancers do their dare daring descent down the 40ft pole!It's really worthwhile being on the look out for fabulous photo opportunities with the macabre statues or amazing wall art. You can haggle with the local vendors who were always friendly. I was happy walking along on my own and felt safe. There are plenty of police in the background but the locals seem to value the tourists. A real must do when in Playa del carmen or Playacar.
vendor vendor vendor. Too many people cat calling and inviting you into their store. Enticing people with drugs and alcohol in the middle of the day was odd.

Not worth it.... Tons of shops selling the same stuff, street merchants hassling you to stop and look at their items, people asking if you want to get high...really didn't enjoy our time in this spot. Also, there are people that say they recognize you from the hotel just so they can get you to go to their "uncle's jewelry shop", for example. We fell for the first one, and didn't realize it was a scam until several more tried after.

Great shopping area. Great selection of shops bars and restaurants with both a modern and authentic Mexican feel. We felt totally safe here in the daytime and equally so at night. We visited a few times during our holiday and enjoyed the relaxed vibe.Can't wait to go back!

Expencive. Hassle galore for over priced things we got half the price else where.the dream catchers were the biggest rip off,was asked how much I wanted to pay when told the guy (bearing in mind these were factory mass produced )he got really rude .told him my daughter had bought one at akumal for that he scoffed.man walking up and down selling trips ,when we said no he shouted well your gonna have a fun holiday,told him he was rude,then my friends who's hotel wrist band still clearly showed which hotel they were from,got conned into going to a Amber shop as the guy who approached them said he was a waiter at the hotel restaurant and come and see his shop.they felt very uncomfortable when they didn't buy anything got more hassle.some pretty restaurants ,expensive ,3of us had 3cokes two sandwiches and a bowl of soup £37 ,very average and much more than we would pay in London .gotta go to the place just to say you've been and don't want to go back

Mexico or USA. We were just overwhelmed by the amount of stores and people trying to sell you stuff.. The prices are ridiculously high, even for the cheapest souvenirs and it seems like people aren't even willing to go down in price. Nothing genuine about this street. Feels like American street in Mexico. You can shop at h&m, Sephora you name it. If you want a bit more Mexican food and people you leave this street and wander through one of their parallel streets...
Family trip. Loved the restaurants, the food, the bats and all the shopping stores. Super safe, clean and everything is near by. I felt like home and enjoyed our walks.

Good shopping experience !. Ready and set ! You will need to brush up your bargaining skills before heading out to this shopping trip ! Everything needs to bargain and bargain ! It is a fantastic experience if you relax and do not put your heart on any items ! You will find plenty of vendors selling the same stuffs with difference selling price ! Just go out , shop and enjoy the art of bargaining !

Great time but beware.. All in all we had a great time here. There are lots of great shops to get all sorts of authentic gifts, accessories, memorabilia and apparel at great prices. There is also a great view and access to the ocean. Be prepared to spend the day here because if you have a set few hours, you won't see it all. Especially if you are looking for name brand things. The other shops have pretty much the same stuff from shop to shop with some occasional uniqueness. It was nice going from place to place to get a good deal though. If you do go, understand that the prices are WAY better than at your hotel. But there are some things to beware of:1. Don't buy silver from the vendors that don't have a store with a register and receipt with their store name on it. Almost all of the silver on the street is plated. They will tell you it's real but most often it's not. It may last a couple of weeks but then your finger will turn green. This is true even if it has the stamp on the inside. (Learned this from our awesome taxi driver.2. Always negotiate prices down and buy at the third or 4th price. This will be a fair price for you and still allow them to make money. We bought my daughter a ring that three wanted $200 US for at first. By the time we left they were offering $60. (We didn't want to spend that much on a ring yaaaas she might lose) we went back later and got it for $25. Same thing happened with my hat.3. If you don't have a way to exit or feel bad about cutting people off, shop owners will keep you for 20, 30 40 minutes. Strangely enough, if you tell them you are leaving tomorrow they back off (not sure why).4. Lastly. Do not talk to the people that are everywhere with tour information. They are for Time Shares. And this is not like going to Orlando, Florida where you get tickets to Universal Studios or Disney World. They will tell you it is 90-120 minutes and never let you go. Waste a day of your vacation and some will even make you pay for your own taxi back of you don't buy. Not worth your time. It was fun and we made some nice purchases. Just go with the right expectations and enjoy the atmosphere.
It has everything . Restaurants (of different cuisines), clubs, bars, shopping, church, hotels and of course, the beach! My favorite place in the Riviera Maya. A very lively place! ❤️❤️❤️

DEFINITELY a must walk strip!. I walked down this strip about 4 times and it's always active and so many things and people to see. I definitely recommend you walk there and eat at some of the restaurants

Vibrant,noisy,safe,fun. We are staying just off Quint Avenida so we have walked around this very vibrant area for the last 2 weeks. We have enjoyed the "people watching" but have found it quite noisy and the shop keepers are quite " in your face". With regards to safety we have had no problems. Plenty of visible police patrol . Lots and lots of the typical souvenir shops. Plenty to see and do to while away the balmy evenings.

Plenty to do. "La Quinta" Avenue is a great 2 mile stretch of Shopping, restaurants, outside bars to just hang out and have a beer!When your tired of just being at the resort it's a great place for something different!

Blackpool away from home. We did this as a half day trip with Thomson at a cost of $25 each including transport.Its a busy area with the centre being 5 ave-Usual tourist shops, bars and restaurants trying to sell all the usual bits.Its cheap to eat here and amazing everyone recommends the Italian food which is lovely.Its here to get the sombreros, tequila shot glasses and odd bits.Worth s trip but keep hold of the wallets and purses especially in the late evening,We where also recommended to get and money from the bank cash points not the self standing atms as there had been issues in the past

Way too much hassling. You have to go in order to get food and drinks but the street vendors are beyond obnoxious. My sister had bracelets slammed in her face and when she walked away he hit her on the shoulder with them. There sales tactics are cheesy and unwanted. If you like to be heckled every 30 seconds definitely go.

Fun Walk!. The Quinta Avenida pedestrian mall is a fun and entertaining stroll through Playa del Carmen. Every imaginable kind of shop can be found here, from high-end names that everyone would know, to high-end names that were more local in flavour, to the tequila shops and silver stores and everything in between. Safe and friendly and not to be missed!
Great Shopping!. You have to visit this place if you want souvenirs. They even have large retail stores and restaurants.
Aggressive salesmen. What you'd expect in a Mexican tourist district. Stick to the bigger gift shops on the main street. The farther you get off the street, the more aggressive the sales pitches get.

SHOPPING!!!. A lot of stores, restaurants, bars and everything! I enjoyed walking around and stopping at stores all day long.I ate at one of the restaurants on the 5th ave but was not satisfied with the food at all and it was overpriced. everything on the 5th ave is over priced and for tourists. If you go a few blocks away, you will find better deals...
Tourist trap. . Little to recommend since most stores offer the same trinkets found in all tourist traps and airport souvenir shops. The fish tanks are a notable exception.

Being taken over by corporate moguls.. I'm sorry to see 5th avenue being slowly chipped away by corporate investors bringing in mega shops, etc. Part of the charm of this pedestrian thruway is all the mom and pop shops set up to entice you with their various wares. Unfortunately, these are being taken down, and larger companies are putting up their malls and shops. Most sadly, our favorite gelato place is now no longer, another victim of this takeover. Come and see it while you still can, and while there is still a bit of the original charm left.
Good place to go.. Good place to go , good to leave the hotel and have a better immersion on the Mexican culture. pay in pesos , go to banks to get money the have much better fees.
Great for an evening out. This is a great area to go for a walk and relax. Enjoy a drink at a bar, sit down for dinner or just dessert and shopping. Whatever you feel Iike doing is here.

Great strip-like feel. We walked the strip before stumbling across El Fogon, and bought a few souvenirs to take back home. Prices on most of the souvenirs are about what you would pay in US, so you must bargain to achieve any kind of value. Every shop my wife and I entered, we were offered shots of tequila on the house, as an enticement to spend money. All in all we had a great time here.
Mina. We enjoyed our stay in Playa del Carmen and walked, dined, and shopped on Quinta Avenida everyday. So full of life, color and great shops and restaurants.
One Street a million things to do! . Lots to do and lots going on, great food and drink, ignore the pushy guys....just smile and keep walking.
Too loud.. Charmless mall type atmosphere. Loud horrid the no music blaring from every corner. Not relaxing at all. No authenticity. Disappointed.

Love this part of Playa . This is exactly why we love Mexico. Great food everywhere. Lovely artisan shopping. The atmosphere is real welcoming. Next time we visit we will have to be in walking distance of the street. LOVE IT!On another note: as a parent of a young girl I would highly suggest that the vendors would raise the inappropriate knickknacks tshirts/photos away from young eyes. In my opinion this really makes me uncomfortable when shopping with my daughter.
Fun Day!. Great area to walk, eat, drink, & people watch! No vehicles! Even in the rain it was a good day. Lots of souvenir shops too.
Always busy. Long walking street chock-a-block with shops, restaurants, and bars. Usually always busy with plenty to keep you busy for a few hours.
Lovely to just walk around. Always enjoy a walk in Quinta Avenida, lots of places to shop or just look around, have dinner or ice cream. A must to visit.

Shopping heaven . Took my daughters shopping here, at the start of the shops which looks more like a market ALL the people touting for your custom "recognise you from the hotel" my daughter asked how do they all know us mum.... Then I explained it's a trick to get you talking so a little further down someone said it to her and she said "sure you do which hotel then" and her face was a picture when he gave the name of our hotel! Once you walk a little further you come across branded shops, Hurley, Victoria's Secret, Mac, H&M, Pandora to name a few my teenager was particularly pleased to see. There are an abundance of restaurants to choose from offering a variety of meals. There are ice cream parlours, delicious but expensive. The area is beautifully clean despite the lack of trash cans (probably lacking as they encourage vermin) Taxi are in abundance, and give you a price for your destination prior to getting into the car. Went a couple of times as an enjoyable shopping/lunch experience

Touristy place with no real character. There are certainly many restaurants, shops and bars on this street. But it gets tired after a while with all the shops seemingly selling the same stuff. It would probably be better if there are more unique shops with a greater variety of crafts for sale. I would recommend coming here only if you are staying in the area for more than 5 nights.

Love 5th Avenue!. If you come to Playa del Carmen, you have to walk 5th at least once. There's a great vibe here. Yes, the prices are for tourists, but there are many souvenirs and unique gifts to be found. My daughter and I love checking out the art that is displayed many evenings. My son loves to play in the water fountain. My mother loved shopping. There are many excellent restaurants. The south ends seems to be a lot louder than the north end. For this reason, we typically eat on the norther end. This is really an experience for people of all ages. Also, there's a nice little park and play area at the south end in front of the beach. My kids also enjoy this.

Vibrant commercial street!. The Quinta Avenida is the main commercial and entertainment street in Playa Del Carmen. It is about 2 kms long with shops, restaurants and bars on both sides. It can be a bit too loud. If you goto Playa del Carmen, you have to walk this street at least once.

Good Ride!. Hello Travellers, This is a nice place for shopping dont worry about cambio here you have a ton of houses for cambio at the best prices, dont forget if you buy expensive things with card to ask for the receipt beacuse you can have your money back(some of it) at the airport you ask at the vendors and they explain. You can eat, do shopping , go to the beach if you want, or just take a walk, its well crowded place.Best place to go there is taxi and you can arrange the departure at the same time you combine an hour and a meeting place and the taxi will be thereI think It worth at least a night to go there.Hope you like it.

Interesting Diversion. 5th Avenue is the heart of the tourist shopping, restaurant and bar scene in Playa del Carmen. There are many excellent restaurants and bars. The shopping requires much bargaining. It's fun and often crowded. Nice break from the beach.
Pleasant Shopping experience. Very nice vendors, great array of wares. Go in the evening on hot days. Lots of souvenirs and others.
Shopping. Shopping here was amazing. The people atr so nice. We will be returning with our children and next time I will bring more money to spend.
Beautiful new mall and stores.. Spend the day at Playa del Carmen and just walk through all the stores and new malls that they have. This is a most do
Absolutely fab. The place is full of shops and nice restaurants. It's really lovely but also very expensive. Any way worth to visit.

Always buzzing with activity . Right outside my hotel it was fun to walk this street and see all the action happening at night .During the day there were many pretty little restaurants to choose from as well as shops. I was surprised at the malls and major US stores that could be found here ( Sephora, H&M) etc. but it's an interesting mix with the Mexican stores as well.I never felt harassed or unsafe and I walked by myself several times at all hours day and night .The best part was that I could sit outside my hotel and people watch which is another way to pass the time as well.

busy busy lots to see.. we took a hotel cab and stayed 3 hours and then they came and picked us up. $14 per person round trip from where we stayed. if you take your own cab always ask how much before you get so they dont get u in then over charge you. shops and stand owners will always say the same thing. they saw u at whatever hotel. they can tell by your arm band at a distance. its a good experience even if u dont buy anything. people are pushy but its expected they rely on tourist. $1usd is 17mx. u can just wave your hand no or say no, or ignore them and they wont pursue u. it takes longer than 3 hours to see the whole strip. we went about half way down then went back to our pick up spot. it was a nice experience i recommend doing it at least once.
entertaining evening walks. I loved walking down 5th avenue in the evenings people watching and viewing all the activities on this pedestrian street.
Love this place!!. You can find everything and anything on this avenue, love it! Many restaurants, bars, stores and even the beach is 2 blocks away.
Great Shops. I loved walking along Quinta Avenida and shopping ! So many restaurants and the beach is just a few steps away. Definitely a must do when in Playa !

It is what it is.. Full of shops, restaurants, and clubs. The North and South ends carry a more upscale shopping scene, especially the North end where you'll find the ritzier establishments. Venture down the side streets for more ethnic flare and originality. You can travel the whole street as you wish but once you've seen half it begins to repeat itself.

Shopping! Very fun and we felt safe! The taxi cab ride charge was $10 one way from our hotel. (Paradisus La esmiralda. Highly recommend walking the street. It had such a fun atmosphere with so many people! Everyone was very nice and it's nice to shop for souvenirs! $10 cab ride each way for a family of 4!

Not pleasant. The vendors are very pushy and will use any tactic to get you into the store. They tell you they are from your hotel or saw you at some other point to get you to talk with them or come into store. It is not relaxing to stroll down the street for constantly being yelled at and solicited from all sides.

Too touristy and hard selling of cheap souveniers. Parts of 5th are great, but we did not appreciate to constant hard selling of souvenier stores. Very little local color. But if you are out for a dine and some takeaways from Mexico, its OK

Nice change from the beach!. I went to Playacar in July with my 5 year old daughter for a girl vacation. After beach-pool-beach-pool-and more pool, it's nice the put on dry clothes and walk a bit! My daughter enjoyed the colorful shops, and the overal ambiance which is very different from where we live! For me, well, it is what it is: touristic street for visiting tourists!I enjoyed the fact that the large souvenir shops have fixed prices, great aircon, and stock not only souvenirs, but also medicine and other items that are almost at the same price as Walmart (bought umbrellas there, which is the best way to beat the sun and heat imo). I ended up buying some ceramic souvenirs, while buying other stuff at Walmart. It's fun to walk up and down as there are no cars, it is well maintained, some shops and hotels are really pretty, shop people try to sell you things but will not insist too much, restaurants are good, some have great corner terraces with views of the beach. Safety: I felt safe being there alone with a young child, even in the evening. Most people there we families as well. Warning: some guys will spot your resort bracelet and come up to you and say very convincingly: 'Hi, I'm Juan from your resort, today is my day off, can I show you my (insert family member)'s shop?" I had read about this but only had it happen once in the few visits to this place. For fun, I just went along, it was broad daylight and nothing was dangerous. It was kind of funny to see how motivated the guy was, he spoke great English. I didn't buy anything at his aunt's (ahem) jewelry shop, nor his cousin's (!) leather shop! One thing puzzles me: how can all these shops survive???
Nice shopping, too many pushy street vendors. Nice touristy shopping, but way too many pushy street vendors who do not understand "no thanks" means we are not interested in seeing their items
Shopping. Nice place for Mexican artifacts. Up to American Standards lost its native touch but a very pleasant place to shop.

An extraordinary pedestrian zone. This place comes especially alive at night when it fills up with people and vendors and the hundreds of restaurants lights up. You will find whatever food you desire ranging from reasonable to expensive, from traditional Mexican to European fusion. If you go to south end of 5ta avenida you will reach a square where you can experience a traditional performance every night around 6.30 pm with 4 guys swivelling down from a high pole heads down.There is also a range of shops offering well-known brands like Nike, Victorias Secret and H&M as well as souvenir shops of all kinds.

Always a rush. Quinta Avenida is main street in Playa, and it is supercharged with energy during the evening. You can find some wonderful musicians entertaining; my absolute favorite was a mariachi band with two incredible trumpets and a singer who would have graced an opera. Expect frequent invitations to buy something, arrange a tour, or take a massage, but that is part of the fun.

Fun fun fun. It's a wonderful happening area. Lot and lots of shopping both upscale and not. Amazing mix. It's safe lots of tourists in the area and has a nice beach at the end of the strip. Amazing finds for bargain prices. Lots of walking though so wear comfy shoes.

ok. It has a lot of stores for teenagers the type of Zara, and others but nothing you would not find in the US and maybe cheaper. On the other hand, at the beginning of it there is a two stories drugstore where you can find almost anything you'll need.

Great time. My husband and I walked through Fifth Avenue two days ago and had a good time. They have some local stores and some western stores like old navy, Nike and etc. You can also catch a ferry to Cozumel if you espn down to the beach. I wanted to do that but we ran out of time but we will in our next visit! Be ready for people to get you to come into their stores we skipped those and went to the stores that have the prices US currency on the items. Overall great experience.
Nothing new. Just a normal avenue with shop. Better to stay on the beach and not loosing time. If you have a rent car it is imposible to find a parkin. Take taxi.

My wife loved this place . Awesome street and vibes! Lots of places to shop for souvenirs and mainstream stores! Many bars to choose from and our hotel was a walk away which is even better!! Always a good time in Playa del Carmen!
Street with shops. This is one of the main streets of Playa del Carmen. This street is full of small shops selling souvenirs.
You won't go hungry . Always lively and tonnes of good restaurants and bars to choose from, we stayed at the Grand Hyatt, brilliant hotel, which is very very close.

Souvenir shop and lot of food. Very nice place for souvenir shopping and lot of restaurants and bars. I wouldn't go here in the afternoon as it's very hot. Recommend to visit this place in the evening when the sun out.

Haggling with the locals. If you are in Playa Carmen you need to visit fifth avenue. It's approximately 2 miles long, filled with shops and restaurants. It's always fun to bargain with the locals. Many different shops with a wide variety of items to choose from. At night the street comes alive with music and entertainment. We stay in the Playa car area and feel very safe walking down to fifth avenue. At night I would recommend a taxi as in any city you need to be aware of your surroundings. Get out and have fun getting to know the locals..it's a wonderful experience.
Lots of fun!. Nice place for shopping, eating, and hanging out. The night life is great. Be warned, it's a popular are for locals and tourists. A lot of people.

Our evening out in Playa del Carmen. A lovely place to visit, full of shops for high end designer brands to the tacky souvenir shops. Something for everyone. Loads of bars and restaurants which all looked good

Shopping, nightlife, great food !. Walking this street is the best for shopping, nightlife and anything else you want. It super safe and you will always be surprised to find goodies and great places to relax. I loved it!
Great for people watching. Find a pub or cafe and just watch. There are people from all over the world to entertain you.The Euros wearing the Speedos are especially funny.
Fun. There is always something going on in 5th. There are so many great restaurants and bars to choose from or just walking along the street is great fun.

Typical tourist trap. Avenida Quinta (5th Avenue) is closed to traffic, making it a popular destination for tourist foot traffic in PDC. All of the typical tourist trap souvenirs are available along its length, along with (imo) over-priced drinks and treats. However it is tourist central, especially for those with limited Spanish language skills (Spanish is NOT necessary anywhere along Avenida Quinta).It was fun to do a little people watching along Avenida Quinta, but for my personal tastes and meals, I prefer to go inland a few blocks to where the locals are. Also I found the prices much better a few blocks inland too..... but you cannot be afraid to get off of the beaten path to uncover these local gems.

Street for tourists . Lots of suvenir shops and world brend stores. Every body is trying to sell you their products or excursions to lot of attractions . Very similar to main streets in other tourist destination. If you look for exchange office, on this street is bether price.
Quinta Linda. 5th avenue was lovely! From the restaurants to the local merchandise; it was beautify. Very busy and crowded but lovely.

Mexican Riverwalk or Waikiki equal. Alot of shops to include American stores like old Navy h&m, hang ten, forever 21 plus local Mexican artesian and restaurants and bars. Huge amount of Italian restaurants and pizzerias. Safe at all hours and great walk.

Shop and eat!. Great street to explore when in PDC. It starts from Calle 1 to 46... But the main action is around 6-16 with nicer stores to shop. There are a few unique stores/designers place that are worth seeing. The rest are just souvenirs stores that sells the same crap. It is better to buy these souvenirs items in the Grocery store off 5th (Chedraui, Mega, Walmart, Soriana). Same thing but cheaper: Tshirts, Ceramics, tequilla...Do shop around for tours and bargain when you are a bigger group. Also, if you are a family, some tours are not nescessary. Just take the collectivo or rent a car and pay your own entrance fee. It would be at least 1/5 of the tour price! If you want to explore more... Continue to walk on 5th when it is not commercial anymore (after 46th). You will find houses with beautiful Graffiti Artworks (see pics).If you are a good sport, keep walking on 5th til 112. Turn right... You will find the "secret beach" with a small lagoon of fresh water that goes into the ocean.Our favorites on 5th:Clothes: Psylo Fashion / designer clothing store corner of Calle 20. Betshka a sister company of Zara. Price is excellent! Great place to shop if you have teens! Food: Ambasciatta d'Italia / Douceurs de France/ Ahh Cacao

Good for shopping. We have spent an afternoon for sightseeing and shopping. We went to a shop in order to buy Mexican hats and the owner was so nice that gave us a good discount. A little bit further we bought a fresh coconut that was opened in front of us. From the sea shore we can see the buildings of the Cozumel island.

Good for souvenirs. It's a good area to walk around, souvenir shop, and grab a cerveza. There are a lot of American stores too like Forever21, Sunglasses Hut, and Billabong. Expect to have people calling out to you to get you to buy from them. This year people asked if we wanted to get high. We just walk by and ignore the "callers."

Just OK. Alot for stores and most are very pricey. Some will negotiate with you. But not all. I found this store selling a masage black rock for 1200 pesos and at the end offering it for 200 pesos. WTF are they stealing our money...... On my last night there were an expo of paintings on 5th Ave. That was great to see.
Close to our hotel. Close to our hotel ,walking distance, pretty good shopping for my wife, good prices and lots of dining a day drinking options.

Famous 5ta Avenida. La Quinta Avenida is truly wonderful. It seems like out of a European magazine combined with a flavor a Miami's infamous Lincoln Road; Mexican style, of course. Here you will find people from all over the world, colorful shops and an infinite variety of cuisine restaurants.
busy lots of walking. 5th avenue. so busy full of people and places to shop try the little restaurants we went to La Casa Grill , the best steak. just too bad stores close at 11 during the week..

The "Boardwalk" in Playa de Carmen. Everything is happening here. Just walk, shop, dine, drink, and watch people. Can stay all night if you want to. Felt very safe. It is just 2 blocks from the beach too.

A pleasant walk and people watching. Walking down fifth Avenue is very pleasant--and entertaining to do some people watching. it is extremely touristy though, and the establishments around it are way too overpriced. For this reason, I simply enjoy taking a stroll up and down it during the day and night, seeing how the pulse and heart of Playa move.For more authentic, delicious, cheaper dining, head toward the Central Plaza by the Palacio Gubernamental (government palace). Excellent Italian and Mexican eateries with great specials await, just a short walk from fifth!

Great shopping, restaurant and bars!!. No matter what you like there's an option for everyone at La Quinta Avenida.I thoroughly enjoyed walking up and down the almost 3 mile long street full of shops, bar and restaurants. If you are in Playa del Carmen it is a must!

Irritating. You are constantly being harassed by people trying to sell something that you really don't need in the first place that you could probably buy at the dollar store in the U.S. much cheaper. Also, when you are wearing a resort wrist band beware lots of peddlers claim that they know you because they work at your resort.

Great to walk here. I love that street, it's great to see so many stores and tour options in here, also, every street from here has access to the beach, so you can con down to see. Great restaurants, food, shopping malls and hotels.

Nice City. Very good night walk , good stores and where you can spend a great time meeting Mexico culture. A lot of good restaurants and souvenirs shopping . It's very secure place and close to my hotel .

Shopping for everyone. Absolutely loved walking up & down Quinta Avenida! This is the mainstreet for shopping for souvineers, textiles, ceramics, fine handmade items such as tapestries, purses, sandals, hammocks, blankets, beaded jewelry, silver jewelry, tequila etc. There blocks & blocks of native tiendas, mini store fronts & malls full of stores with some familiar brands like Nike, Old Navy, MAC, Starbucks. Of course "bargaining" is part of purchasing with some of the tiendas & I got great deals just by asking! A little spanish, even if broken is appreciated ! Of course the big name stores have set prices, so make sure to exchange your money. Having your money right sometimes gets you a better deal! Many of the stores accept major credit cards & US Dollars. Trust me, we enjoyed buying presents for our loved ones so much, we bought another suitcase just for all the trinkets from our travels . Also, wear comfortable shoes & be prepared to walk the whole avenue. Don't worry there are plenty of restaurants, eateries, bars, clubs along the way to grab a snack or drink (or two) as well.

Hassle city!. This is a long street full of tourist shops. From the minute you step onto this avenue you are continually harassed. I don't like that at all. Just leave me to meander about and I would come into the shop and look. I felt under pressure at all times while walking along and couldn't enjoy myself. However, I managed to escape into one of the malls which had a lovely rooftop restaurant. It was a heavenly and peaceful oasis amid the hubbub down below.

Nightlife. Nice place to go to get out of the resort, tons of shops and restaurants to choose from. Both times we visited were in the evening, most stores stayed open till at least 11pm. Lots of people and very fun atmosphere.
It's a amazing street . Any place you looking ..you will find out great places to go bars live music clubs restaurants .beach clubs brands stores h&m and more I'm recommending !!!

Most tourist street in the Riviera Maya. This street is the typical tourist/popular/party place to go if you want to buy souvenirs, go to bars, meet tourists or party hard. If you like the typical packed street with a lot of bars and people walking around, this is the place to be.

La avenida is nice... not quite the surroundings. I went there twice because I stayed at hardrock hotel, it was a 20- min taxi ride which cost more or less 40 dollars round trip. It was kind of confusing at first, then I found stores you can fnd in the US, it is like there is an area full of wellknown shops and there is this other part where you can find local businesses which sell souvenirs at really good prices. I even saw a small chapel/church with the front very similar to those Mexican style very beautiful. There are plenty of restaurants, my son tried the food of one of them and he liked it (we didnt eat cause we had already eaten) the prices were really good.what I didnt like was that if you kind of get out of ¨ la quinta avenida´ you see this other Mexico which is not very tourist.
Great place to shop and get local food!!. Great place to walk around and enjoy the local foods and especially the coco frio and homemade chips.
Good shopping. Bring your Walking shoes, lots of shopping. I good place spend the day and or evening. their some good eateries on 5th Avenue.

Good. Its a nice place to spend a day shopping and having some real authentic mexican food. They have a super big mall and many American stores to shop from.There is quite a bit of hassle from the locals still and the prices I noticed from 3 years ago have increased quite a bit so its not very cheap like some people think but it is still a good place to spend half a day to get out and about .I suggest going on a not so hot kinda day
Fun day of shopping.. You can get nice souvenirs but just ignore the calls from vendors. We took a cab from the hotel and back it was reasonably priced.

Great shopping lots of stores! But be aware...... This is a great shopping experience. But after several store and hundreds to go, it's clear they all carried the same stuff. Be aware of the cons...they look at your all inclusive waist band and try to convince you they served you at the bar the other day. Be prepared to be mobbed by them and others trying to you to buy they product. Recommend you look and price what you want then negotiate a good price. Lots of restaurants with a wide variety of food selection. A great experience just keep you eyes open. Enjoy.

Pushy vendors, still worth a look.. Bottom part of 5th avenue is good in small doses. The first large gift shop you come across on the corner had the best prices. Great shopping malls that were clean and well layed out. We did not enjoy the pushy vendors yelling at us to come into their stores, it was relentless. We were called everything from Mr Hollywood, honeymooners, sweet lady, etc. Towards the top of 5th avenue, the tone changed slightly, we were asked on more than one occasion if we wanted to get high. The bars further up charged extortionate prices and one place wouldn't give me the WiFi code but insisted on putting it in my phone himself! Good food spots at Ah Cacao, Mi Pueblo and Las Hijas de la Tostada.

Tourist trap heaven . If you want a place to buy souvenirs, come here... but back in the day there was variety and locally made items... now I find most stores have the ssme items, ssme prices and a lot is made elsewhere. Was a huge disappointment. Better off buying at roadside markets or authentic wares.

A little bit of everything.. The resort we stayed at had a small market but everything was suuuuuuuuper expensive and overpriced. We came here instead. They have everything ranging from flea market shops to trendy boutiques. Thank God someone told us about this place. Seemed safe. I never felt unsafe and that's because we were there at night. A taxi company is at every other block. They have a set price to locations and no one tries to rip you off.
GOOD SHOPPING. We ventured out and took a taxi into town to do shopping for souvenirs. Allot stores and great prices.

WHERE ALL THE ACTION IS!!!. You cannot visit the are without visiting 5th avenue or Quinta Avenida. It is truly where all the action is. Every store, retaurant, bar, jewellery, artisan, hostel or hotel is located. You can find mcdonald's all the way to luxury restaurants if you so desire. The streets running opposite to 5gth avenue all have numbers for names - it starts on 2nd and runs all the way to 34. There is michael Kors to the guy selling his wood work all beside each other. Starbucks to Swarski crystal to scotia bank and so many other stores/malls to name. American Eagle, H & M. the finest in silver, one attached to each other. At night it is the best, the music heard is infectious and with so much to look at, you will be sure to find more thatn you bargained for. A must see if in the area.

Shopping at the Comedy store. Just returned from Playa del Carmen and while there went shopping on 5th street. The vendors are so funny yet very respectful. The one guy was so funny I wanted to sit there and pay him yo keep talking as he was so funny. Had lunch a small place with great food and great salsa musicJoe C
Very Touristy. It's a nice place....great set up for tourists. If you, like me, prefer the authentic typical experience, then this is not for you.

Good food and interesting shopping.. It's an interesting place, but the large store on the 5th avenue and Calle 38 Norte was the best priced and had pretty much the same things that the other more expensive stores offered. We bought all of our souvenirs here. We browsed a few other places, but always returned back to the same store for any purchases. There were a few good restaurants there. Our favorite was Muy Salsa was our favorite. I included a pic of my tacos. Plus, the people there were so sweet and kind. The older lady who prepared her son and his girlfriend lunch gave me some for free when I commented how good it looked. His girlfriend saw us taking pictures and took a picture of us together and posed for a picture at the counter for me. Then during conversation, my boyfriend mentioned how he loved spicy foods and the waiter when in the back and returned a few minutes later with some homemade habanero sauce at no extra charge.

Family and friends - first visit in 6 yrs. . What have they done to my Playa del Carmen!? I first hit Quinta Avenida in 1996. Playa was like a sweet untouched paradise. Year after year, I watched 5th Avenue grow - brick by brick, shop by shop, one more street closed every year. NOW...instead of Italian food zone and Mexican food zone, all I noticed was everyday American stores! Why go all the way to Mexico and visit amazing Quinta Avenida just to find new "malls" featuring shops like "forever 21."
Busy street. Busy street with lots of restaurants and souvenir shops. Close to the pier that takes you to Cozumel.
shopping. a great street for shopping, people watching and manywonderful restaurants.and bars. A new adventure eachtime you go.

Nice walk while shopping. Its a lot of fun walking down the avenue while shopping for souvenirs. What makes it more fun is its allowed to drink while walking down the street just like in New Orleans. I found Cuban cigars and lots of different Tequila that is only found in Mexico and not exported to the United States. There was a lot of people from all over the world, listening to people in different languages trying to speak Spanish.
Cool place.... A nice place to hang out full of shops, bars and a wide variety of restaurants, tour offers and nice hotels.
Great variety. The variety of this street is great. You can find all sorts of restaurants, bars and nearby are all the clubs, so you can go a whole week without getting bored of it.

Amazing ambience . Main Street in Playa, great variety of shops, restaurants and bars...leads all the way down to the ferry terminal for cozumel. Lovely to walk along during the day or evening, friendly shop keepers, plenty of places to get a cooling drink and bite to eat and comes into its own at night.

5th avenue shopping. Great deals! But be careful ...don't buy the lie..."hey, I'm your server from..... They will look at your hotel bracelet that you have to wear while in stay and try to pawn off as one of your waiters. Don't buy the lie.

Everything you want and need at your finger tips!. Quinta Avenida has everything you need and didn't know you needed.Blocks and blocks of restaurants, bars, shops and things to do. You will never get bored.Store closed around midnight and restaurant and bars way later.There are lots of places with fish tanks full of little fish that will eat all the dead skin of your feet. I know it sounds nasty but it seems to be very popular and enjoyable.Any hotel around Quinta avenoda is a great location to stay.Quinta Avenida is simply the heart of playa Del Carmen and anyway you go customer service is excellent.
Very international. So much dining and shopping from all over the world. While it is Mexico the dining is international. Fun meeting people from all continents coverging on PDC

Fun Place! Everything you need and more. Awesome stores, cafes, restaurants, bars and great vibe.You are close to the beach, gyms, yoga studios and always fun people watching.Do go out and beyond the 5th though!

Fun to visit as long as you know what to expect. We spent an afternoon on Quinta Avenida. I didn't find the vendors as aggressive as previous years. Some of them were quite funny, saying things like "come in my store, let me sell you some things you don't need" and "come in my store, let me rip you off just a little bit". We didn't really buy anything, but we weren't looking for anything. It's just fun to look around. Most of the stores have the same things at varying prices. Most things do not have prices on them, I think they make it up as they go. And they always start out by saying they are giving you a deal. My son was looking at a statue of the Predator character, the guy was telling him it was $450 pesos, but he would give him a deal of $400 pesos. My son happened to flip the thing over and it had a price tag of $300 pesos on it!! Needless to say we walked away. I just laughed at the guy. Interestingly, as we walked down the street, 5 or 6 stores later a guy it front of his store called out to my son and said "you looking for a Predator"? So obviously they communicate with each other (the same people probably own all the stores!). This guy was more willing to do a deal. All in all, it's worth the trip, just don't go looking for quality merchandise and great deals. Lots of restaurants and places to stop for a drink.
Love going to 5th Avenue in Playa Del Carmen. I love the shopping, the atmosphere of the town, and the many restaurants you can visit for a lobster meal or just a cold cerveza

Cute Fancy Place . Honestly, one of the best parts of playa del Carmen. It was a bit crowded in july, but you can find a variety of restaurants (mainly mexican, italian and burgers), designer clothes shops, department and clubs are all nearby.

Surprised me. Man went to this stroll twice and still hasn't seen everything here plenty of Taxis , This place really impressed me very safe and fun a little too pricey though some of the shops were a bit outrageous i must say .

Fun times along the avenue but.... I do wish that shop workers badgered tourists less about shopping in their stores. Seriously, it's hard to walk 10 feet without someone trying to drag you into his store.

Quinta Avenida. Bueno para visitarlo pero antes de comprar cualquier cosa adentrese más a la avenida. Encontrará lo mismo por menos.
It's a place to visit but be careful. Compare prices before buying anything. The more you walk through the avenue, cheaper the prices. Always negotiate for a better price...

Perfect for walk and have a great time!. It’s the perfect place to walk, shop, dinner, and go to party!You can found a lot of things to do, if you are looking to buy some souvenirs this is the place, they are a lot of stores with all kind of Mexican souvenirs. Also you can have a great dinner, a nice cup of coffee, see a lot of people passing by.If you only want to walk its great to, is a place to go and relax, have a good time, ear some music, get tours information and if you want to party, one block away is tha Mandala club and coco bongo, great places to have fun.
Great food!!!. They have great food, shops and places to party!!! There's a lot to do with small children as well as with teens. You must try their fresh fruit by the small vendors its the best :)
Little touristy but have hidden gems. Ate at some great restaurants. Some stores were overpriced, so you have to look around to find cheaper prices.

Souvenir shopping . Great place to buy all your souvenirs. Find something you like and then keep walking, alot of the same things offered at different shops with different prices. Make sure to negotiate! !
Great shopping. if you stay on this street the shops do not deal like they do in the more authentic shops prices are more set and they do not come out and get you

Where everything happens in Playa. Before and after the day at the beach/diving/museum/archaeological site/ trip inland/waterpark, here is where everyone meets, where the good shopping, food and drinks are found in abundance. Great strip to stretch one's legs.

The Heartbeat. Quinta Av is just off the ocean and the principal street that runs through the Tourist Corridor of Playa del Carmen (PDC). It boasts several small malls scattered throughout - beginning with Paseo at the farthest southern point up to and beyond Calle Corazon and Quinta Allegria. This street is a fabulous place to grab a great cup of coffee (Starbucks or Cacao) or cocktail and people watch. Along the 5th AV is a mix of international shops, local shops, clothing, souvenirs, cosmetics, decor, shoes, household goods along with restaurants and bars. It is an extremely busy area, but safe. I have never been there later than 9pm so not sure how late the action continues or if the crowd changes.

Great Time!. Lots of variety of shopping and culture!!! The shops were very friendly!
A lot of different types of stands as well!
Good Shoping. Wonderful place to visit, eat, shop, drink and you are interested there are a few clubs in the area.
Nice. Nice tourist attraction with an abundance of shopping, restaurants, and beach access areas. A must see on your vacation.

Lots of changes. 5th Avenue is always interesting to walk. We were there in June and it was hot out. It was nice to walk past air conditioned stores with their doors open. There are many new, updated stores on 5th Ave and more "malls." The original "flea market" area remains near the dock but the rest of the Ave has new updated stores and restaurants opening. 5th Ave is also adding more stores and restaurants toward 39th street. Don't miss these.

Ripped off at jewelry store called Joy Aqua Silver 20' Avenue Norte. We went to Playa del Carmen to visit a museum and wound up running into "Carlos" whom we had met at a Cenote selling jewelry. He asked us to come to his "mother's store" and look at more jewelry. We went and picked out 3 beautiful rings. He had me fill out a receipt with my name and address for the credit card company and his brother distracted me with discussion of Mexican Tequila while Carlos wrote up a receipt charging me over $3000 for the rings and then handed me another hand written receipt for pesos, which he did not charge me for. I now have to spend time litigating it with the credit card company. So disappointed that I was scammed.

Lots of fun on a Monday night. My husband and I were in Playa after finishing up a tour and decided to have dinner and do some shopping before heading back to Cozumel. We were surprised at how lively it was for a Monday (as were a few shopkeepers we spoke to, lol). We had a really great time strolling along the street, doing some shopping - without a lot of pressure, which was great - talking to the locals and enjoying the scenery. I really liked the mix of stores too. I liked being able to look at the Nike store, an artisan leathers store and a store full of fridge magnets all within a block!

Lots of shops and Restaurants/Bar at 5th Ave. This is a narrow street intersected by roads some leading to the beach. Lots of activity here, vendors selling tours, trips etc; souvenirs, Tequilas, cigars, clothes. There is a mall which is nice. The whole stretch about 2.5km so you cash walk this during the day or at night. It comes alive from 5 pm to midnight. Lots of bars with music, live bands performing , lots of artists here. Just focus on your shopping generally safe and you can bargain sometimes. Very safe and lots of stores to choose from lots of money changers too- US$, Euro, GB Pound, Canadian$, Yen all can be converted to Mexican peso.

Worth the walk (in evening, when cooler). Definitely a place to stroll, find a restaurant, and look in many many shops. 50% of the shops are tourist traps, but the other 50% provide some unique opportunities to "shop local" and find a great souvenir for your trip. I have been here twice. I (nor my female companions) have never felt unsafe or scared, despite the crowds. There are some beggars for money. Ignore the many pharmacies offering to sell you various meds without a prescription; most of it is counterfeit and NOT what you think you're buying. And US Customs will seize it if found.
Relaxing. Nice way to spend an evening walking fifth ave.it's gotta be a mile long shops and resturants and even a few spots to stop and sit and see all the goings on.

lots of shopping with high prices.... We found a few good prices here, but in general prices for the same item are higher than in other parts of Yucatan or even than other neighbourhoods of Playa del Carmen. Of course a visit here is a must, you could visit Frida's restaurant to see 5th avenue from above.
Fun and Entertaining!. Great place to find food, entertainment and shopping. Perfect and safe for walking in the evenings after a meal.

Yes, yes, YES!!. I've been to Playa three times in three years. LOVE this place!! It's my second favorite destination right behind the BVI. Definitely spend some time on Quinta. I never did a tour, I prefer to hoof it on my own and chat with the locals. Look for the mariachi band after dark. ENJOY!

Energetic. Absolutely love Quinta Avenida. There are all kinds of shops available with gifts for everyone. There are people that try to offer packages for excursions but they aren't pushy. Fun to visit day and night.

Loved It!. I have stayed in Playa Del Carmen several times and I can't get enough of 5th Avenue. It has everything from upscale shopping to bargaining with vendors. Most of the vendors are good natured about their sales tactics. Just don't get your underwear in a wad and you can have a great time interacting with the vendors. And you can get some really good deals. The people watching on 5th Avenue is world class!!!! I can't say enough about it. Grab a giant margarita and just sit back and watch. If you like Tequila then this is a really good place to purchase it. Many of the shops will allow you to taste your Tequila before you buy. This is a real benefit if you are picky about your beverages. Sometimes you have to have thick skin because drugs and sex can be offered however if you firmly decline they will leave you alone. As a matter of fact they knew my face and they would joke "keep it clean around him". So we got along just fine. I highly recommend a few trips to 5th Avenue.
Too hot. In July it was just too hot. We tried but never managed more than 50 yards then we went back too our beach hut with perfect breeze and private pool.

Good for a rest from the sun and water. Fun, interesting. Not the best deals, but a beautiful walk. There were a few air conditioned shops that were a nice break from the heat. Walk up one of the side streets and you'll get a better price.

Great Mexican shopping experience--but not in the heat of the day!. I have been to Playa del Carmen a number of times and always go to 5th Avenue at least once a trip. Quinta Avenida I believe is the Spanish version. 5th Avenue is closed to vehicle traffic and is one and one half miles of shops, jewelry stores, cigar stores, clothing stores both very high end and low end, bars and restaurants. In the morning many of the tourists will do their exercise for the day before the shops open either walking or jogging. After the shops open, most around 10 am, it starts to get busy. Since there are so many large nearby resorts of US, Canadian and European tourists mixed in with small hotels on or near 5th avenue that cater to Mexican tourists, there is a great amount of walking traffic. In the daytime it is very warm or very hot--your choice depending on the time of year. Many tourists wait until the late afternoon to visit. In the early evening the restaurants get busy as do the bars. The streets are full of people and you will see strolling Mariachi bands playing for dollar contributions. Starting on the south end there is a large complex of high end shopping for clothing, watches, home goods and other items and of course a few dining spots. The ferry crossing to Cozumel is also located on the south end on the waterfront which is one block from 5th avenue. Also at this location is a small chapel and the central park with 5th Avenue on one side and the beach on the other. The souvenir shops start here. My favorite is the shop in the pink building across from the Chapel. Going north from there is the bus station and many, many shops, restaurants and bars. To get the real picture of the location, look up 5th Avenue, Playa del Carmen on Trip Advisor and see what others have posted or use the internet on U-Tube or on Google or Yahoo photos
Brash and in your face. Pleasant enough but full of punters trying to get you to buy their wares or eat at their restaurant.
Nice walk. The main artery of Playa del Carmen, where you can find anything you want. Best brands in modern shoppings. Can't miss!!

A place to be)). If you are looking for souvenirs, or you want to have some fun this is the place to be. A busiest, most touristic place in Playa. A lot of shops, restaurants and bars. The prices are higher here but still a great street. Very colourful, you can find a lot of interesting things. Go to the very beginning of the street to see the flying show, beautiful mermaids statue and a small pretty church. 5th avenue is definately a place to be on Halloween, New Year's eve and all kinds of other holidays. All the fun is here!

A must do if traveling to Playa del Carmen. . A must do if traveling to Playa del Carmen. From street vendors, local shops to name brand stores spanning across many many streets closed to vehicles and only a block from beautiful beaches. A lot to see and do. Once the night falls, you are in the middle of some great nightclubs.

A lot to see. Quinta avenida is a street where you can walk for hours looking the stores, eating at great places and also enjoying street performances. Shops close late so you can go in the afternoon just when it is not too hot.
5th Avenue...Playa. The downtown area of Playa...where its happening. The restaurants, souvenirs, bars, mariachis, street performers, etc. One block off the Beaches and Hotels.
Shopping paradise. This area is a great location to find all your souvenirs and trinkets. The place is close to Playacar Palace and there are many many stores.

Typical souvenir shops. 5th avenue is loaded with a bunch of local souvenir and handicraft shops. They are all pretty much the same and offer similar items like vanilla, tequila, t shirts, etc. Prepare to bargain and do not pay the 1st price offered. I actually bought a Dos Equis beer t shirt for $20 with the original price being $25. Later at my hotel, The Iberostar Paraiso Maya, I found the same shirt for $10!!!Also, if you are a male, and walking down 5th avenue by yourself, be prepared to be asked a million times if you would like to buy "weed". I would politely say "no gracias", but it got old after a while.
Great experience. Loved the town, the have everything you can hope for, great restaurants, Nice shops, and lovely boutiques for souvenirs .

Very Safe and Lively. Nice walk thru 5th avenue. We felt safe and relaxed. No disturbance. Lots of business and tourists. Great choice of shopping and restaurants. Very busy commercial area. We had drinks and danced at La Bodeguita del Medio, and took photos with the staff.

Fun spot for food and drinks- here are some tips!. Tons to see on this downtown "strip". They have everything you need especially if you want souvenirs. I was able to find plenty of 2 for 100 pesos deals on Mexican blankets (which was the only souvenir I wanted!)... Just be aware of a few things:1- tourist area so be careful with your bill to be sure they aren't ripping you off2- if you pay with pesos you will save money... ALWAYS. So find an atm that partners with your bank and get pesos out to be prepared! 3- lots of guys asking during the day and night if we were "tryin to get high"... They weren't pushy, just a bit surprising to see.4- better prices and authentic food can be found by just going North a street or two to 10th, 15th, and 20th Avenidas... all walking distance from Quinta Avenida.
Great place to spend the night. This Playa del Carmen street is full of restaurants, shops, hotels and night clubs. Its a must when in Playa del Carmen!

The most famous avenue of the City !. Everybody know the famous Cuinta Avenida in Playa del Carmen ! Pedestrains Street it's plenty of shops, restaurants and bar . It's parallel to the ocean so at every streets that it meet you can turn and reach the ocean in less than 3 minutes ! If you are around Playa del Carmen you can't miss a stroll on this avenue !

Nice stroll. The 5th Ave is where you'll find the most amount of restaurants and stores, but it might not be the cheapest. Many streets cross it which offer less expensive shops and restaurants. Look around for the best prices most of the shops carry the same merchandise.
Shopping and eating!. Buy your souvenirs here. You can negotiate at some stores and will find reasonably priced and unique items!
Great!. Great place to buy clothes and typical objects from there, t shirts, hats, plus more. There were a lot of international stores such as Zara, Pull and Bear, Tommy Hilfiger, Benetton,and others

Fun but constant harassment . We like to visit 5th Avenue in Playa every time we are in the area. It is filled with vendors constantly inviting people to visit and buy from their stores. We learned to tune them out. Simple 'no thank you' works also. It is fun place but very touristy. It seems to be growing with more commercial malls added every year. If you are looking to buy some souvenirs, this is definitely a place to visit.
Nice place. The Quinta Avenida is the reason you shouldn't get a all inclusive hotel in Paya! There is a lot of restaurants and shops in this avenue!

5ta avenida. 5ta avenida is great! We found just about everything we were looking for from restaurants, shops, bars/clubs and the list goes on. The only thing I was not too fond of was all the tour agencies who constantly harass you to buy a tour/package from them. Other than that the vibe was great and the people too. We were blessed enough to meet a bunch of interesting people from all walks of life. We shall return. :)
Nice Tourist Spot. We walked the Quinta Avenida at night and found ourselves visiting various eateries and bars along the path. Great place to people watch.

A little too pricey! . Overall there are tons of shops and eateries that have lots of cool stuff but you really need to haggle to get a good deal. You can walk a block or two down and get the same or similar items for a fraction of the cost.

A mile long shopping strip. A destination unto itself. This shopping strip is over a mile long with shops, restaurants, hotels, shopping malls, and other miscellaneous attractions. Shopkeepers hawking their wares and calling to you as you walk by. But it is all upscale and in good fun. A clean, neat, and fun experience. It is easy to spend a day on this strip. Make sure to haggle when shopping – for us $25 became $11 after some arm twisting . . .

Beautiful 5th avenue. Every vacation to Riviera Maya, we spend at least one day in Playa del Carmen, and usually focus on the 5th Avenue area. Great shopping if you are looking for unique gifts and locally made products. there are also lots of new "chain" stores available. We love walking the street, stopping for coffee and wifi at Starbucks, then off to Senor Frogs for lunch. A fun day!!

Fun to see. Fun to walk around and stroll for local crafts, very nice mall midway down
be careful of con men who pretend to work at your hotel as waiters and claim to know you just keep walking

Lovely Place !!!. We visited Quinta Avenida, a nice place to be. Shops everywhere and a great place to buy Silver. BE AWARE not to buy Silver from Street Vendors!!!!!. There are wonderful Jewelry stores, where you can Purchase good Silver. Plenty Restaurants, Massage Places to a good price. They have a lot good stores as here in The USA. The prices are a bit higher than here. There is public transportation everywhere. Good place to go.
The place to be. The street comes to life day and night for the enjoyment of everybody. Eat, drink, shop, dance, rest... you name it!
had a great time!. Loved the haggling! Lots of local flavor and charm. Would recommend staying on the North end, away from the Americanized malls.
Awesome place to be in the evening!. Great atmosphere. Great shopping options. Don't forget to negotiate and get the BEST deal when dealing with small shops/ streets vendors.

Safe and fun aera for the whole family. TIP: do some walking around and price compare before you buy.Its a safe and fun place to let the kids go and have some fun, eat some ice-cream. Most of the vendors we talked to have some basic understanding of English. To be afraid to negotiate a better price.

Best Place for Souvenirs and Good Food. We went downtown for a couple of hours in the late afternoon. Although vendors are trying to push their sales, just smile and keep walking until you see something you want. Prices are good and there is anything you could want. We had the most amazing shrimp tacos, but I cannot remember the name of the restaurant. Taxis are readily available when you are ready to go.

Great Shopping. We always take a cab ride here when we go to Playa del Carmen. It's well worth it. Authentic Mexican food, great shopping and still close to the gorgeous ocean. The shopping goes from true Mexican shops to high-end Rodeo Drive like shops. Something for everyone. Great night life as well. It feels very safe and has something to offer for everyone!

Like shopping?. Definitely the place to go if you like shopping! At least a mile walk full of shops and locals trying to make a living. I couldn't help reading the review cautioning visitors about potential rip offs. I'm sure this does happen on occasion however, my husband and I had no problems. We were charged what we were quoted. Yes, the hotel wristband is a give away and it's mostly males who will approach you & tell you they are so & so and they work at x hotel and invite you to their relative's shop, usually a jewelry store. However, we have no problem in thanking and nicely declining the invitation. When you do, they leave you alone.

Shopping, Eating, and Heat! La Vida Playa. The list of stores, restaurants, and tourist novelties runs the spectrum from Mom & Pop to Globally recognized centers of Luxury and Fashion. The convenience for my family vacation is knowing that pharmacies are abundant and prices are reasonable. Those who desire a shopping experience will not be disappointed. While big brand shopping is not my thing I do geek out for Mexican Surf brand Squalo which has 2 stores on this strip. I would encourage anyone seeking Mexican Cultural Art fused with Surfing images to visit Squalo or even better KukulCanvas off Quinta Avenida, they have the latest trend in pre-Colombian indigenous theme art with culture infused with modern twists.Craft Beers and Tequila are well supplied and available for the most discriminating taste on Quinta. Restaurants are diverse and range for fun-seeking to family friendly.The drawback is the Heat and some suspect appearances! Be prepared to perspire regardless of the time of day. Hydrate and just accept the fact that you are dealing with the elements. Shade and AC are deceptively available but surprisingly insufficient. There are some alarming vendors who will strike conversations, make comments, or ask a ton of questions to reel you in. They are most often trying to be friendly and make some business. Be wary of your surroundings and travel with company as much as possible. Quinta has so much to offer including hotels and hostels mixed with services, stores, restaurants, and just about anything a market or community can offer. Handle the heat & distractions and just get over it and enjoy your stay in Playa.

Nice ramble. Enjoyed a stroll along the Avenue after returning the hire car, browsing in various shops, admiring the colourful displays and partaking of some food and drink at Bar Fah... the place seems to cater to all tastes and ages, although the requests from the hawkers to come see their shop/come on their tour etc.. got a little too much at times.One tip - if you are staying at one of the AI resorts on the coast, either cover your wristband or try to turn it inside out lest you be accosted by "one of your waiters" trying to get you into his mothers shop LOL. Basically they can see what hotel you are from by the band..
Good for promenade. Good for promenade, but souvebirs are much expensive here. Save your shopping for Isla Mujeres or historical sites.

Good Shopping!. If you are looking to shop downtown, eat at a restaurant, etc., this is the place to go to. It is a nice stroll up and down this street, the only unfortunate aspect is that many shop owners constantly yell at you and try to get you to come into their store/restaurant.

Beware of getting ripped off. If you go shopping here you will be approached by people saying they are waiters at your hotel but it's their day off. If your hotel has a lot of staff I'm afraid it is very difficult to tell. You are then invited into their "Uncles" shop. You will be offered a very good deal, usually on jewellery. They will encourage you to pay by card. Mexican chip and pin machines do not show the value when you put in your number. You are then given a receipt to sign. Only then will you get a receipt that shows they have charged you 25%+ more than the quoted price. When you question this they get very aggressive and lots of their "friends" appear giving very little choice put to leave. You will then spend the next few days being really annoyed that despite the fact you are well-travelled you fell for this scam. By all means visit there, do a bit of shopping, enjoy the banter but please do not pay for anything by card.

Almost Endless. We have visited Quinta Avenida twice on trips to Mexico spending a couple of hours each time and still have not seen the entire length of the strip. LOTS of stores, restaurants and malls many of which attract attention for browsing. Some even have A/C.The walk is a gauntlet of hawkers vying for your attention. You learn to make this noise part of the background and not affect your shopping experience. The new call-out we heard this time was someone shouting that you should remember him because he was your waiter at the hotel. Your hotel wristband is the target for this ploy. None of the "noise" is anything more than that. You will feel safe along the Avenida.Starbuck's and Krispy Kreme bring familiarity to the area. The Mexican Outlet store was a great place for shopping many items in one location. There was a Cuban rum bar with rum-tasting that was a standout among all the tequila stores.List price should be considered a suggestion. You can work with a lot of the vendors to find a mutually agreeable actual price. You'll have an almost endless opportunity to practice this skill as you walk the length of the Avenida.
Chilling. Loved walking along this busy street with so much buzz and excitement happening all around. Haggle The vendors if you are buying . They are more than willing to make a sale
Fun to browse. Bit of a tourist trap but it's fun to look at. Shop for good deals and enjoy a Mayan show on the beach. There are cold cheap beers and snacks but not cheap food.
