The life of Playa. Lively street with lots of shopping and places to eat. Unfortunately we were only able to spend 2 hours in Playa del Carmen, including lunch, so we were not able to see the whole of Quinta Avenida. Everyone is your friend and wants to sell you something. Note: if you are wearing a wristband for a resort guys will come up to you saying "Hey amigo, remember me - I was your waiter at the ... resort" to create a familiarity so they can sell you something. Don't fall for it.

Quinta avenida. This place has no end, you could walk for hours, all stores carry same stuff, but I guess is the best to get a good souveniers, great restaurants...but very $$$$. But I guess thefe is something for everybody, if you like noice crowded places this is the place..

Fifth Avenue in Mexico!. Plenty to choose from, lots for everybody in all areas! Americanized Krispy Kreme & Starbucks on the Avenue and great value for the dollar - make a deal, they want your business!!

Great shopping and dining area.. I like this place. There is something special about it. They have nice little restaurants there. Shopping and dining prices are high,but you can find some special things in both. Jus choose not a weary hot day for walk- the area is large.

LOVE it!. We LOVE Playa and 5th Avenue. There are great restaurants and shops up and down the street. It has changed so much from the sleepy fishing town it used to be twenty years ago into a hustling bustling area with thousands of shops and big name stores. You can literally find anything you want on the strip. Its amazing and so mull of energy!

Quinta Avenida. Left our resort, Blue Diamond Riviera Maya to head to 5th Avenue. Found the usual souvenirs and food that you would expect in town. Was hoping to see something a little more authentic and less of the mass produced items. The $45 roundtrip cab fare would have been better spent elsewhere.

Long pedestrian walkway with many restaurants and shops. Use this avenue as a landmark and go further away from it for less expensive dining options and stores. Alcohol is not sold after 9pm so keep in mind if you need. People will always ask if u need information on excursions.

Walking along, browsing shops . Street vendors are very pushy, but otherwise there's plenty to look at and trinkets to buy. Wife liked the shopping mall area. No shortage of taxis to take you to your resort. Lots of bars and restaurants, quite pricey though. Seems that everyone has their hand out on this street !

Lively and fun part of town!. This is by far the most popular shopping and dining spot in Playa del Carmen! Quinta Avenida is a pedestrian-only street filled with restaurants, shops and entertainment that stretches for about 40 blocks. There are many types of ethnic restaurants, casual dining, fine dining, coffee houses, dessert stands and everything in between. There are local mom-and-pop stores, to large corporate chain malls. Personally, I like the character of the smaller merchants more than the H & M or Victoria's Secret of the malls. You can get those at home. Why come all the way to Playa del Carmen for corporate America? Hopefully, the large corporate chains and their malls don't take over what is otherwise the charm and draw of Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue.)The street is hustling and bustling day and night. Close to the beach just a couple of blocks from the water, you can stay at any number of hotels and be just steps away from some of the best restaurants in town. 5th Avenue is also steps away from the bus station and ferry dock, so no matter how you get there, it's convenient. Most stores take credit cards and there are plenty of places to exchange money. There are also side streets off 5th Avenue with more shops and restaurants, often with better prices, but nothing beats the liveliness and excitement of 5th Avenue. We were there in June and while it was hot and humid during the day, the nights were breezy and cool, which made strolling the avenue all the more enjoyable. The area is very safe and there are always people out and about.

Definitely visit town. There is a lot to see in Playa. There are some fancy shops mixed in with cheesy souvenir shops but that is part of the charm. Plus the food! Restaurants abound and the food is outstanding. Everyone is selling the same stuff so don't get caught up in the first storefront - really walk around and get a good feel before you begin your purchasing.

My favorite place on earth. Call me crazy but I just love wandering up and down fifth ave at all times of day or night. It is ever changing, I know some find the shop owners pushy, but I do not. They have a job to do and if you joke with them you will find that they are friendly happy people. It is fun to barter, there are very reasonable places to get a massage. Get off fifth and discover some hole in the wall eateries with the most tasty authentic foods.

A wonderful day in PDC. We decided to take the colectivo from our hotel in Akumal and were dropped about a 5 minute walk from 5th Avenue. I don't think there's anything you can't buy from this bustling strip. It's full of wonderful bars, restaurants and shops with a fantastic atmosphere. We had a really fun and memorable day here.

Playa del Carmen's Main Street. There are plenty of shops, bars, restaurants and places to stay for any length of time!The Avenue is filled with fun spirited people from all over the world. It's a block and a half away from beautiful beaches and Caribbean feed turquoise waters.It's family friendly and very safe. The questions are as follows: would I return? Yes I will again and again. Would I recommend it to family and friends? I most certainly would. It's a must do when in PlayaCar or Playa del Carmen!This review was done by: You, Me and The Dock - Travel SiteLove, Laugh & Travel Lots

Shopping !!!. We went to La Quinta on a late morning Sunday, after church, in July.. It was very HOT so it was a welcome relief to go inside air-conditioned shops to cool off and do some souvenir shopping.. We did not buy much as we planned to go back again but we never got a chance to.. Some vendors try to entice you to try their stuff but a simple 'No, thank you' is often enough and you keep walking.. Prices are quite reasonable and you do see a variety of things to buy.. Especially souvenir items..

Great Spot for Souvenirs. My wife and I took our two children (15 and 12) as we were looking for Mexican blankets. Dropped off by our hotel shuttle bus around 10:00 a.m. Most vendors and shops open. Got some good deals on Mexican blankets and yes you can barter some of the smaller shops down in price. The blankets we got were a lot less than what was offered for sale at our resort and at tour markets we visited. Yes the vendors try and get you to come into their shops as you pass by, but that is normal and a firm "no thanks" was all that was needed. We found the vendors polite and easy to deal with. Part way down there is a new mall with some nice stores in it and clean public washrooms on the second floor. There are also a few pharmacies, which provide better prices for suntan lotion, etc. Both my wife and I felt very safe in this area with our kids. We lasted till about 1:00 p.m. and left. Three hours is more than enough.

overwhelming.... I took my 18yr old daughter. We did get some good purchases, but may awkward moments. I hate to write something bad, because we love mexico and the culture. Its not a trip for 2 ladies to go. Many comments were made and it was just not appropriate. We went before lunch. It really enterfeared with even wanting to shop. We were glad to get back in our shuttle, even though when we arrived to playa on the shuttle our driver and a pedestrian got into a fight and the police came. It was just a odd trip for both of us.
Long street of shopping. Be prepared to walk as this is one long shopping street. The locals pester you to come into their shops but ignore them and keep walking. Take a hat and some water.
Hot hot hot!!. It was extremely hot so be prepared! Many shops and a mall. No "deals". Many choices for food and drink. We spent about 3 hours here and that was plenty!
Love Quinta Avenida. When visiting Playa del Carmen, you must walk Quinta Avenida!! We love it! Perfect for all ages. So much to see and so much to do!
Not a fan. If you're going with your family, this is definitely not the spot. It's too loud, too much of a party location. Its appeal is party and shopping.
A must see. We walked through quinta ave every day during our stay in Playa Del Carmen. You will find plenty of restaurants and gift shops on 5ts between calle 38 and calle 10

Once is Enough. The phrase been there done that would work for Quinta Avenida or 5th Avenue. Too many people are trying to entice you to go into their establishments. Be sure to have an Aldo's Gelato though!
Great shopping . We had heard the locals talk about it and decided to go ! It was great ! They had many shops from name brand stores to small locally owned stores ! Loved it !

Good place to people watch and buy souvenirs . Took a taxi twice to visit the shops. Felt safe during taxi ride to and from. Good prices on t-shirts and the like. Food smells awesome but we always went after dinner and weren't hungry. Some vendors are very pushy. Just say gracias no and it isn't too painful.
5th Avenue pedestrian shopping. Great pedestrian avenue for souvenir shopping, restaurants, bars, upscale shopping. Be prepared to be hassled, you will be entertained!

The smaller shops are disappearing.. We first started visiting Playa Del Carmen years ago. We really enjoyed the small shops and the goods they offered. Now glass shopping malls are replacing many of the small shops and offer the same retail chain stores we can find at home and in every tourist town in the world.

So fun!. We recently went to shop and play on 5th Avenue. It has been two years since we were here and it has grown so much. We love Playa del Carmen because it is such a great mix of quintessential Mexican charm and restaurants while still having state of the art shops and malls.
Can't miss it!. Walk the streets of La Quinta Avenida! It is surely fun, full of shops, restaurants and bars where you can safely spend a good amount of fun family time!
It's a must see!. This is a must see when in Playacar. There are so many things to see and eat. Love the stores, especially if you love shopping like me :)

Globalization victim. The quaint, old-time, small village atmosphere that everyone says is characteristic of 'la quinta avenida' has been lost to the dozens of global brands' stores and several big malls with stores that you can find anywhere else.

Convenient Shopping. Quinta Avenida or 5th avenue was just a few minutes walk from our hotel. The new part is very Americanized. I was very surprised to find a limited number edition Spurs watch there for less than what I would pay at home. Most of the stores have prices on the merchant and because they were already less than what I expected, I didn't bother bargaining. You can find pretty much any souvenir you're looking for and at good prices. There is a huge Nike store which came in very handy because we weren't originally planning on going zip lining and I needed a pair of sneakers. The prices there are a little better than in the States and there's no tax. Pharmacies are almost every 4 stores so don't worry if you forgot something. The ferry to Cozumel is there too. There's more than just shopping with there...there's a beautiful park with entertainment daily and each side street leads you down to the beach. There are two malls with very Americanized stores as well too, so if you forget anything, you're bound to be able to pick it up at an excellent price. The best thing: pedestrians only....no cars! Have fun shopping.
2nd honeymoon . Loved walking around the Quinta Avenida but start in the south side near the beach and the statue (photo included). I liked the south end much more than the north end.

Nice avenue to stroll. Take a stroll down the avenue, lots of opportunity to find a treasure you just have to have. Only bother are the vendors who approach you like mosquitoes. Overall a great experience. Vendors along here are willing to wheel and deal and respect those who do. Take a chance and bargain for your lowest price. Nothing is set in stone.

Fun experience but high pressure.. Visited 5th Avenue during the day on one of our stays. Shopping has expanded dramatically since the last time I visited in 2009. Lots of shops to explore but most with very pushy vendors who harass you to come into thir shops and even some asking if we wanted to "get high"... Glad we didn't have our kids with us or I would have gotten really upset by this. Didn't go into many shops because of the pushy atmosphere. One guy even made tge comment, "Give us the chance to rip you off"... Funny for sure, but speaks to the tone of our trip. I will note, prices are much better on 5th Avenue than at hotel shops or the plaza in Playacar so if you need something (sunscreen for example) it's cheaper to get it here.

All your souvenir requirements catered for. A good mix of high end and not so high end souvenirs available along with many bars and restaurants to rest your weary feet at after your shopping has been completed.
night time stroll. late afternoon and night when cooler in june and july. lots of shops restaurants and watering holes of all types and prices. now with upscale mall

Touristy, but still fun. Very touristy and busy street at night. Lots of shops to buy souvenirs and haggle with store owners. Kids had fun seeing all the stores, restaurants and shops. It is a long street hat you can walk on for a long time. Stores are same as we have in the states.....Billabong, Nike, Bath and body works, Victoria Secret, Hollister, Forever 21,etc. don't worry if you forget something, you can find it here!

Plenty to do. Stayed off of Quinta Avenida in a boutique for 6 days with my wife. We walked up and down Quinta Avenida almost every night. This street has so much to offer including restaurants of all types, bars, night clubs, stores, local shops, tour stands, random parades, performers, and much more including a mall with H&M and other stores.On the far end of Quinta Avenida is a ferry dock. You can take a ferry to Cozumel for $15USD to $16USD. I recommend buying a 1 way ticket when you leave. There are multiple companies and they have different times for departures. It costs a little more but, gives you more flexibility to pick a different company with the time you want to leave.On the other end (opposite) of the ferry is where the night clubs are. Most do not open u til 10pm and then stay open until 6am. These are worth checking out if you're in the party mood. There is something for everyone.Overall, if you're in Playa del Carmen you don't want to miss this street. I think it really makes the city.

Looked hard for good deals. Buyer beware. Most items are no bargain. Some pricing is okay. Some shops higher than U.S. Some very friendly shop people but just as many trying to scam you. Beware the ones who try to lure you into the stalls off the street. They seem so nice, will tell you they recognize you from your hotel and then get mean when you don't buy. Advice if looking for anything in particular, know the USD to pesos conversion, take your time and enjoy the food! Great restaurants at good prices.

Nice place to spend a few hours. We had great time walking and shopping for souvenirs. 5th ave is a long street, be parepared to walk a lot. You can eat, drink and watch people. They are some original guys over there! Be carefull, some seller can be very insistant! Don't be too polite and say NO cause they will bring you to their shop before you know it!!! The beach is just a few minutes away. Worth the visit.
Nice walking. It is a nice area to go for a walk, shopping and have a drink. There are a lot of nice bars and restaurants. I think it is better to go at night because of the weather.
Very active. nice stores and ambiance. close to the beach. perfect for group hangouts since its very active, reminds me of Miami.
local flavour. a lot of restaurants, bars and shops. Better to be visited at nigh for the colors and music coming from the clubs

Walking, shopping and dining!!! Awesome place to spend some afternoons!!!. This place is an avenue where you can walk through trendy shops, excellent restaurants with a big range of prices, gallerias, live music, nite life... And the beach one block away!!! Better to visit when sunset or night because of the hot weather!!!

Nice afternoon stroll. The Quinta Avenida makes for a really nice afternoon stroll. Make sure you grab an ice cream cone from Aldo's (there are several). The Plaza de los Fundadores at 2nd Street is a lovely place to hand out and people-watch.

Strolling down La quinta! . I love going for walks down 5th... there is so much to see and do! Restaurants Bars and many trendy cool hangouts! Only a 2 minute walk to the beach and if you ever needed to find something in a hurry! 5th has it all! I love Playa del Carmen!

Nice visit. We went to this street for our 2nd time. The street have changed, there's a lot of designer stores. However, there are still several Mexican shops and restaurants. We had a nice time walking and buying souvenirs. This is long street, so be prepared to walk a lot.
Food and drinks. Nice area to walk around , shop and eat. Find a restaurant or bar with a good view of the street and you can eat and people watch.

Too Americanized for me & if you've ever been to TJ or Ensenada, it's nothing new.. Lots of tourist souvenir shops with the same stuff in all of them. They prefer pesos to dollars and if you want to use dollars they give a dismal exchange rate. However, there are money exchange places here that are decent. Don't forget to bring your passport as rules require that you have a passport. The beach scene was nice. We saw a flying acrobat show for free and an Aztec/Mayan Indian show for free too (donations welcome).
constantly hassled by drug dealers near main square. Horrible pushy shop owners near ferry port and people selling drugs, also all bars at this end are over priced. much better further down.

Nothing good here . Hi the quinta avenida let tell you guys and friends tha this place have nothing to ofer to turistas everything its over price food and drinks and souvenirs puerto vallarta malecon its way better than this place

Good to see samething diferent. It is ok place, but you have to bee very careful. The souvenirs you have to know that they are over price but all you need to do is talk to them and you get better price in some of the stores.

Great walking and shopping and food. There's a Walmart close by. About 3 blocks from that center of the Playa del Carmen. The gifts within the miles of walking are better than Walmarts, but they do sale liquor in the Walmart.

Main Street - Playa Del Carmen. Only went in the daytime, in June, so could not comment on the atmosphere in the evening. Quite busy walkway parallel to the beachfront, but not visible from the street. Lots of opportunities for retail therapy, eating and drinking. Mixture of tack shops, tourist traps and modern shopping arcades. Only concern was the over-enthusiastic owners of some of the shops to coerce you into their shop. But a polite 'no' and they are no further bother (unlike other countries I could mention!).

Touristy, but has everything!. Shops, bars, restaurants. You name it, it's here. Very touristy place! The souvenirs are overpriced and a lot of "kitchy" things in my opinion. Still a fun way to spend the day exploring up and down.

Good to explore. Have variety of stores, including many United States branch stores. Lots of pushy salesperson trying to sell something or just get you in and visit their store. Many restaurants to choose from.
Lots to see and do. Fun street. Lots of shops and attractions/ people to watch. Is fun and super busy. A fun place to hang out for the whole family.

Nice place to stroll and stay. Although obviously touristic, Playa del Carmen has actual mexican flavour and is far friendlier and smaller than Cancun, besides being nearer most of the attractions in the area (Xcaret, Cozumel, Tulum and even Chichen Itza). It is an excellent alternative for staying in the Maya Riviera.

Too much for me. Too much of everything - shopping, people, over-priced restaurants. Nothing really authentic or interesting to see, I mean, Forever 21? Really? That said, I hear the nighlife is good....

Cool but expensive . Cool place to check out. It is however very expensive as far as places to eat. If you walk back a block there are amazing affordable places to eat. The shopping on the street is fun and the people are entertaining.

Great place to spend the day. Spent all day here during our vacation walking the streets with a lot of venders trying to get your business, some are pushy and others are very nice, purchased items for the kids, stopped off at a few bars for a cold drinks, purchased some cigars at Lauro's Cigars where they hand roll them. We ate lunch at the Tequila Barrel where they have the best Mojeto in town. You can also walk to the beach and rent paddle boards, catamarans, or take up some fishing or snorkeling. Great place to hang out for the day.
Interesting visit . Interesting place to people watch and shop. Strange mix of American stores and quaint Mexican shops. Was able to find some good souvenirs.

Something for everyone!. It is a great break from your resort to do a little shopping, eating or just people watch! There is always stuff going on - street actors, art shows, etc. There are name brand stores (Nike, H&M, Victoria Secret, Hurley) but there are several little unique shops too! However, be prepared that the street vendors will hassle you to come into their store but just either play along or just walk on past them! It is part of the fun & uniqueness! You also need to remember to haggle at the little stores on prices as they will negotiate. They always start out really high & you can get items quite a bit less than quoted. There is also several massage places available for 2 people for $50 for an hour!!! We have tried several & received numerous fantastic massages for a huge discount compared to the hotel spas. A lot of options to eat & drink, although a bit pricey! It is completely safe & something unique to venture out to see.

Walk down 5th Ave. Enjoyed taking a walk down 5th Ave. Many places to chose from for souvenirs purchases.
Recommended!!

A must for tourist! shopping, eating, nightlife. My husband and I took a mini vacation and we were very pleasantly surprised by all the shopping and restaurants. We literally divided the strip up over 3 nights. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes for sure! Our hotel was HM Playa Del Carmen which was within great walking distance to everything almost center in fact. The shop people weren't any more aggressive than what I would've expected or have experienced in Cozumel or Progressive. I just loved the whole strip and even joked with my husband about packing up, opening a shop and moving out there. There were kids dancing, restaurants galore.... I would definitely recommend Trip Advisor for food choices that's what we did and tons of shops local and big chain. There were places you could put your feet in and have the fish eat your feet $15. I personally didn't try it as I was too chicken but it was fun to watch people reactions. Maybe next time after a couple of drinks. Overall it was a safe place as we walked all hours of the day and night. The streets/alleys had tons of police patrolling. I would absolutely recommend this place if you like people watching, shopping and eating which who doesn't of course lol! The nightlife was equally exciting we enjoyed the club strip as well.
Buzzing. Great place to walk around, great atmosphere, plenty of local shops, things to see, good restaurants, best of which are on the north end.

Busy Street. Long street filled with bars, restaurants, and shops. Nice place to get cheap souvenirs, but don't believe a word they tell you...they just want you to spend money at their store. A must do one time thing if you are near Playa Del Carmen.

So many stores!. Our hotel (Gran Porto) was only 2 blocks away so we could just walk to Quinta Avenida. There are so many souvenir stores as well as stores w traditional Mexican items. The mall had all the stores you could possibly want from forever 21, to Sephora , H&M, and so many more stores. Most of the stores took visa and MasterCard and a few took American Express. It is super safe and there are many awesome restaurants to eat at as well. You can spend almost a whole day just going into stores and shooing around. Definitely a place to stop at. Everything is open and people are very friendly and there is plenty of security everywhere.

The place to be in playa del carmen. A large variety of restaurants, bars, pubs, shops gathered in just one avenue. Not so cheap though. You can find cheaper food and drinks in the center of playa del carmen.

Awesome shopping and eating street!. The amount of stores and restaurants is crazy! So many good options and things to do, 2 kilometers of shopping and good eating are definitely worth going to a couple of times during your stay.
Shopping . Many stores and they almost have to same thing. You just need to walk down the Avenue and look for the best products and best prices.

Good place to buy souvenirs. Spent a couple hours here after returning from Cozumel. A lot of good places to eat and drink. There are also several large souvenir stores with good prices. Guaranteed that you'll find something for everyone.

Persistence. Shop keepers are very persistent and will literally walk you into their establishment unless you are very firm in your "no". They can be put off politely if you try to retain your sense of humor. I do not like to be touched by strangers and have a 3' buffer zone so a few shopkeepers will never see me again but they are not all like that. Don't worry - be happy.

Very aggressive sellers. It's a nice place to walk and usually cooler than the very hot and sunny streets of Playa del Carmen but the sellers are very aggressive, which is very annoying. Still, it's the place we good every day searching for a place to have dinner and souvenirs for our family.

Shopping and eating. This isa convenient place to eat, shop and purchase tours. You can get better deals on tickets than through the hotels. They have high end shopping as well as small shops where you can negotiate and both small and larger restaurants.

Busy with much to see . Shops, sales people harassing u as always beach very close, souvenirs, people watching , and shows. Nice place to go shopping but can get pretty expensive since they sale in dollars n pesos the same.

FUN!. We took a taxi from our resort to 5th Ave. on our last day in Mexico, and I wish we would've went sooner. We had a blast!! There were so many places to eat and so many fun things to buy ( and way cheaper then the resort!). You have to keep in mind these guys are the " hustler" type- but this is how they're making a living. It reminds me of NYC in that way. The trip to 5th Ave. made my daughter want to move there. She fell in love with it. If you're staying in a resort I would highly recommended taking a break from there and visiting this part of town.

Nightmare. I really don't like quinta avenida. Everything is more expensive. Just go up to walmart and you will find same items for half the price or less. You got salesmen and excursion selling people up in your face everywhere you go. They will do anything to get your attention including try to fool you with different lies. But the thing I hate most are the drug sellers. I have been in Mexico for 4 monts now and everytime me and my husband walk quinta we get asked to but different drugs 15-20 times in a 15-20 minutes walk. And when you say no they follow you abit and just nagging you. Im not a violent person but on quinta there have been so many times that I have wanted to slap them. I remember two years ago when quinta was filled with police and you got maybe 1 question during a hole day. This is not a place a recommend at all!!
Great place to shop. Great place to walk and shop. This is a street close to vehicles and is full or restaurants and stores, including three malls!

it was fun. it was a relaxed environment and was nice to shop and eat delicious food :) there were many places to shop and buy cute things to remember our trip . it wasn't so good for the kids walking around so much but we still had a good time

Where to go for a few hours in Playa Del Carmen. I noticed when staying at the big resorts, that there is nowhere to get any souvenirs or anything like that without paying a huge mark-up. A $5-$10 cab ride from the resorts to 5th Ave is therefore worth it. A good place to spend a few hours walking around and seeing what the stores have to offer.So here are a few quick pros and cons.Pros:-Decent prices on items usually 5-6 times higher at the resorts such as sunscreen or diapers.-Many different types of stores to choose from. There are high end retailers and there are also street vendors.-Seems Credit Cards, Dollars, Pesos, whatever you got, they take.-Most of the people working the stores are on commission, yet none of them hassled me at all.-Starbucks and ice cream parlors everywhere to help ward off the sun.-It seemed that all the people we talked to spoke English.-There was a lot of usual trinket garbage, but also some very fine quality stuff at reasonable prices.-Many locally crafted items available.-Feels safe, you get the feeling that the locals keep trouble away so that tourists can shop in peace.-Finding a taxi to get back is easy as there are regulated taxi stands every two blocks.Cons:-Getting here is admittedly scary. Taxi's have to go down one lane roads littered with garbage and stray dogs, past run down buildings. More of a negative of the Mexican Gov than anything else. -A few underhanded "barkers" who try to get you into their store by saying that they were your waiter last night at your resort. Don't be fooled, they know where you are from because of the bracelet on your arm. Those stores are to be avoided.-A small gripe, but this is a long, and not flat street, so in the heat be prepared for a hike. Get plenty of water.Some tips I learned while there:-If you have a good no fee credit card, use that for purchases. Often the store would have a sign up that says a conversion of 17-1 for dollars, but on the credit card is was nearly 19-1 so you save money that way.-The store called Caravan has good stuff, as does Rosalita's. -Don't waste time getting hair braided here, it takes a long time and they will actually come to your resort beach to do it if you really want it done.-The white and turquoise cabs are the regulated cabs. Always take them.

Lively and colourful place . I really enjoyed this famous area in Playa. It's always animated and perfect for art addicts what I am.You find arts and crafts, good restaurants, small souvenir shops, art galleries and a must see. For instance I ate in one of the restaurants Karen's Seafood where there was wall paintings with Frieda Khalo (famous Mexican artist).A few steps from the beach. When going than the street towards the McDonald's, the church you end up in the Parque Fundadores where there's this impressive monument sculpture Portal Maya by Jose Arturo Tavarez Padillo. I also fell in love with the street art in all the little streets around Quinta Avenida. Memorable!

Food,shopping and fun along Quinta Avenida. Must see area in Playa del Carmen. Great area for evening stroll, dinner, drinks, clubs and lots of shopping. A surprising variety of food options available. Great area for people watching and relaxing

Great Shopping abd Fun!. My daughter and I spent Thursday June 16th shopping for souvenirs and other items to bring home. We started at the beginning "flea market" which had great prices on tees, sarongs as well as other touristy stuff. We worked our way all the way to the other end with several stops to shop jewelry- yes you have to haggle but it actually fun once you realize it's just a game. We ended up getting two really good deals on rings for ourselves. Stores seemed to open right about 10am and remember on Sunday you cannot buy liquor before noon! Great places to grab a snack or a cerveza including a really good stop Karens- table side guracamole YUM!!! Go, relax enjoy and wear comfortable shoes!
Must see!. Every time I visit the area, I have to go to Fifth Avenue. Some many fun shops and restaurants. Also, lots of two for one drink specials!
Pretty cool. This is definitely the tourist spot! The south end is definitely the better end. But you can find delicious food and great shopping all over

Tourist trap with lots of haggling. Loaded with Americanized restaurants, souvenirs, and handicrafts. I recommend if you're going to buy 'crap' atleast support the local economy and buy things that are made in Mexico. You can find better taxi prices here as opposed to your hotel. Haggling is a must in the smaller shops or you will pay twice as much or more.

Avoid at all costs. Unless you have no other options for shopping, give this place a body swerve. It has no sense of identity, with hideous tacky tourist shops alongside flashy brand name stores you can get downtown anywhere. Meanwhile it is impossible to browse any of the little craft stalls because of pushy salesmen yelling at you to view their wares. I suspected that if you showed any interest whatsoever, you'd never escape their clutches. I'd hoped for interesting quirky little shops but, no, nothing. You are constantly harassed, as I said, not just by shop owners, but people will try to entice you into their bar/restaurant, or sell you tours, cigars, taxi rides. Not an enjoyable experience at all. Couldn't wait to get out of the place. It's a shame be a use I had a bunch of pesos I would have been happy to spend on some tasteful Mexican art or crafts.

Shopping overload!. This is a great place to find whatever you are or are not looking for. Great shops, merchandise and variety. Only drawback was the strong sales tactics. We could not browse peacefully and when we didn't make a purchase staff was offended. I had to walk away several times because sales person was too aggressive. I left wanting to buy more but felt not worth hassle.
El Centro. El Centro was so much fun! A privilege to have visited this place! So many shops, restaurants stores. ..everything you can possibly imagine!
Last time shopping . Great location with to many famous brands. Great and secure for tourists. You would find everything that you want. Can't wait to visit Quinta Avenida again.

Fifth Ave....fair to good.... We are finding 5th Ave to be overwhelming....there are many restaurants, shops and bars but I see more and more big name stores appearing and am thinking the ambiance is slipping away...it is a take for sure if you haven't been and we have a couple of places we like but beyond that we don't view it as a destination...

Lovely little strip. Quinta Avenida is a lovely little strip with lots of little shops filled with not just tourist trinkets but genuinely interesting things as well as a lot of shops you'd find in the US or Canada. There are a host of very nice bars to grab a beer in a it feels very safe. It's a very long street so wear comfortable walking shoes if you're headed to take a look!

Everything is here!. What a neat street - pedestrian only and plenty wide. Tons of restaurants, lots of tourist shops, and a mall with every major store you could want: Sephora, American Eagle, Boss, etc! Bars all along the way. Our hotel was located right on the street, but we could not hear any noise at all. The street paralleling Quinta has cars and taxis so if you need that, it is available. Quinta dead ends at the main plaza where the Cozumel ferry takes off - really convenient! Great place to just amble along this street!

Visit before it is gone. . I have been coming to Playa Del Carmen for 6 years and love it here. I have seen 5th avenue change over that time though and it is definitely getting more commercial. Slow the mom and pop stores are being replaced by big chain stores. Come and see it before it is all big business.

Worth a visit . I spent parts of two days on 5th Avenue. Be prepared for shopkeepers to harass you about visiting their stores that have the same knock off souvenirs as the next one. Have fun with it. They will use any clue such as your resort wristband or any writing on your shirt to act like they know you. Just remember, they're trying to earn a living. There is also high end retailers and jewellery stores with armed guards. The mall on the strip is air conditioned and has clean toilets. Take the ferry to Cozumel if you have time. Take advantage of all the free tequila samples. You don't have to buy if you don't want to. Lots of cigar shops. I don't know what's real or not. The restaurants have cheap beer if you need a break. The beach looked great.
Nice town. Went to do some shopping and it was well worth the visit. Wall to wall bars and restaurants with plenty of different shops to peruse.

Avoid at all costs. Unless you enjoy being harassed by local merchants and the random "hey you want to buy some weed, some coke, or sex", avoid this area at all costs. The ferry area seemed fine. There were a couple nice bars and places to eat. Other than that, it is a pathetic street and not worth wasting any of your vacation time.
Quinta Avenida never sleeps!. We went to 5th avenue to walk the strip at around midnight and it was packed with people of all ages, shops were open, bars, restaurants. Very FUN!

Great for Browsing, Shopping & Strolling.. This my 5th time in Playa Del Carmen, and it had expanded quite a bit since my last trip in 2007. I always liked PDC and you can find all sorts of shopping on the streets, for different budgets and tastes. If food is your thing, you will yourself in heaven!

Great walk filed with shops and places for some eats . A good street to have a nice stroll through, lots of shops offer shirts, silver and food. It is a pedestrian only street which makes it even better. On quinta you will also find most of the nightlife that playa del carmen has to offer.

Shopping. Clean and easy to navigate the streets for shopping. Prices were a little high, but not unreasonable. Be careful of the store owner who claims he was your dining server last night (they see your resort wristband).
fun!. you can't miss this spot when you go to Riviera Maya! Plenty of shops, bars, restaurants and entertainment!

People openly try to sell you drugs. Walking down the 5th avenue can be quite a horrible experience sometimes. People will openly try to sell you drugs regardless of the time, you will often see exotic animals on leads and used to charge tourists for photo opportunities.

Small shopping mall. This is a tiny shopping mall right in the middle of the tourist area in Playa Del Carmen. Nothing unique or interesting there. If you need something specify from one of the few chain stores then it's worth a visit. If you are a mall rat this one is more of a mouse house

Expect to pay american prices. This felt more like being in the states with a side of Playa del Carmen. You'll feel at home with all the American big name shops and prices. Not a place for bargain hunting but it is well maintained and safe.

Ugghhh- way too touristy!!. I think this street could be really cool but its just way too touristy for me with all the hawkers constantly harassing you as you wander around. I love that it's a pedestrian street only but having vendor after vendor yelling at you and pointing at their shop is annoying. It's not effective at all. They need to just chill out.

Must go in Playa. This is the place to go out at night, have meals in a great variety of restaurants, listen to the "los mariates" playing traditional Mexican music or just enjoy the atmosphere. I recommend that you book a hotel near this road so you can easily walk around the city and visit the best places with no need to taking a taxi or renting a car.
Fun Night. Amazing place to eat, drink , walk, shop, see different people, make friends, dance, have ice creams, drink coffees etc...

Not a nice experience . Was looking forward to going to 5th Avenue as had read some good reviews. Unfortunately after setting foot for the 1st time on the street, I didn't want to go back, which is a shame as there were loads of shopping opportunities, varying shops old mixed with the new.We had been warned by our Thompson rep about the street vendors , who would offer timeshares and different goods, goods being drugs.Myself and my husband were offered drugs of every kind , almost every vendor offered drugs, although we didn't feel itimidated, it was really annoying, if they too no for an answer the 1st time it would hae been ok, but they would often crowd and keep on at you, to the point that on the second visit , instead of being my nice polite self , I ignored them all and would not look at anyone in case they spoke to me.It is a shame as I would have liked to spend more time there, and I'm sure others really like the area, but it wasn't for us.
Amazing. Was a great experience, lots of shops. It is a great experience and cheap to get to. Even if you aren't looking to spend money the walk along 5th Avenue is something to do!
nice place. bit touristic but nice. there are a lot of stands to arrange your trips. chichen itza costs around 70 euro's pp

Noisy yet cosy touristic attraction. Nice bars with wonderfull cocktails and deliciuos tapas and ceviche. Nice music too, one bar had Cuban salsa, the others played dance, and all this with temperatures around 30 degrees C at Night. Lots of shops with heeps of souvenirs too, if you like this, a real treat. Long stroll till the harbour where you can take the Ferry to the nearby Island of Cozumel. Ideal to catch a nightcap after diner! Don't try the ATMs though, they often don't function. Be sure to take Some cash with you!

Shopping---Shopping---Shopping. No matter what you are looking for you can find it here. Small shops or a modern mall. I would suggest that you start at one end and shop to the other end then buy on your return to the end where you started. You will find that the prices depend on how well you bargain. After shopping you can stop at one of the open air cafes and rest with a COLD drink.

La Quinta Avenida. Fifth Avenue is a three mile long pedestrian shopping street in Playa del Carmen, lots of restaurants, cafes, shops and more shops. I bought ceramics just off 5th ave. at Siete Detalles.

Explore the entire Avenue.. There's a lot happening when you go down 5th Ave. They have ultra chic restaurants and shops. Walking and cycling are the best ways to get around. The restaurants are a bit expensive but worth checking out.

Mildly Entertaining with Some Pesky Street Vendors. 5th Avenue is the shopping centerpiece of Playa Del Carmen and as such draws a lot of tourists. It is a rather long stretch of stores and restaurants, but as you will find it seems like every block is pretty much the same. The name brand stores you will recognize do not offer any kind of noticeable discount, so if you are heading there to save money you will quickly realize that you won't. There are a lot of restaurants off the avenue, so check with Tripadvisor restaurant reviews to see which ones are highly rated. You will also be interrupted by pesky street vendors, just ignore them and keep walking and they leave you alone. There are the typical t-shirt type stores that all seem about the same with prices the same, so if you are looking for some trinkets don't spend too much time shopping around as they all seemed to be similarly priced. We were there during the day and after dinner, and in either case we felt completely safe at both times, everyone seems well behaved and no one gets out of line, so don't be concerned about going there after dark. It was very crowded at night and a lot more comfortable temperature wise as well.

As expensive as US. This is just an average tourist town with lots of restaurants and some shops. We went there in the afternoon and stayed until the sunset. The restaurants are overpriced. We paid the same price per person if you go to a nice restaurant in DC. I do not recommend to go there more than once. We did get fish pedicure and the children had a blast. They say fish do not bite, but after we were done I realized that my husband's leg had small bleeding. I assume those tiny fishes liked his legs and glad that it was not one of the children.

shopping & sightseeing. lots to see, lots of stores. very Americanized but still has that Mexican feeling. cheap souvenirs, lots of places to have a great lunch/dinner, or just sit on sidewalk & have some drinks in a bar. overall great place.

Getting way too americanized. Truly astounding how americanized this street has become in just a few years. A few years ago we laughed because they had a Starbucks, now they have a HUGE mall with every store under the sun. Still it's fun and vibrant and a nice street to walk down and people watch. .. LOTS of restaurants!
5th avenue is easy & fun!. So many restaurants & bars - be ready for vendors trying to bring you into their facility -can be annoying! But they do accept 'no' graciously!

a magic walkway. when you walk all along the 5th it makes you feel like you are in some kind of magic village ,still you can find lots of restaurants , shopping malls and souvenirs , it is a good option if you want to just walk and relax , & at nght it is very safe to walk as well, so unique experience here in Playa del Carmen

The Life Of PDC. Playa Del Carmen's 5th Avenue is the pedestrian Street where most of the restaurants, clubs and bars are located. A great place to enjoy a meal, people watch and have a fun evening in PDC.
Everything close by with a short walk. Great. Minor harassment if you stand out as a tourist ...great food... Lots of shopping... Be polite and it's not an issue

Barter!. Time to barter!Skip the "name brand" stores and venture further into 5th Avenue to experience the negotiation process of Mexico!Stop at one of the restaurants ..... Get a cold beer and stroll along bargaining as you go! Great fun!I found good deals on silver jewelry...especially silver bangles and silver with Mexican opals!If you want to travel to Cozemel ferries run throughout the day for a minimal cost from 5th Ave.Be careful taking photos in stores ....I was approached by a worker in one store after taking a pic of cocoa display who not so politely informed me pictures were not allowed.Enjoy!

Went several times for a mooch. It's only a 20 minute walk from Playacar, and many shady areas on route. Lots of shops, one long street of cheap and tacky, the other very up market 5 th Avenue. To be honest the shops are all virtually the same, some cheaper than others. All souvenirs can be had, Tequila, t shirts, Nick knacks, bars, restaurants, pharmacy, supermarkets which are generally cheaper. 5 th avenue nice to walk down but unless you have a open credit card forget it. Plenty of quaint places to sit down and plenty of eateries. Was fed up with asking if we wanted drugs all the time, it appears to be worse than the previous 3 years when we visited. I usually stuck to supermarkets, you can buy almost everything here, otherwise you should haggle, although most is fake. Taxis are available all over and a bus station that goes all over

A good place to walk, eat and shopping!. This place is located close to any hotel in Playa del Carmen, easy to be here, you can came by taxi, or a regular collective bus, surrounded by different stores like if you were in your town, different types of Restaurants, you can find any kinf of excursions here, souvenirs, massages, you can take the sun in the beach or just simply came to walk!

Shopping! . Omg... Shop till you drop! Put on your kicks, trainers, sneakers cuz it's a long way... The fifth Avenue has shops on both sides of the street... Anything you want from souvenirs to good ole tequila.. Also entertainment & restaurants... So much fun

Nice to visit, wouldn't stay here. This is a really great place to go if you want to buy souvenirs or cocaine (I bought neither). My friend and I had dinner here and were a little disappointed with the options, they cater a lot to tourists from the US when we wanted authentic Mexican food. This is a good area to stay in if you want to be more rowdy, we opted for an airbnb in centro away from the crazy.

Alive. I visited 5th in 08 and was turned off by the pressure to buy "blow" or "dubbies". This year it still was present but more subtle. This visit, first week in June, the streets were packed (with gorgeous women, and maybe some men, but I didn't see them) and the scene was alive. I'm afraid that big names have replaced smaller ones, but it still had a good Mexican vibe. If you are one a budget venture off 5th. There are great restaurants on 10th, and all around. Plan a day to recover, even if you don't drink, as the food may not agree with you.
Fun. Had a great time. We felt safe and enjoyed the experience. Just make sure you practice "No Gracias" before you go!

Attack of the street vendors!. As in any tourist location there are those aggressive vendors the try to talk you into their shop or or to buy their over priced low quality junk. This is no different. There are some good shops with some good items, however they are few and they get a good price for their merchandise. It is a fun walk.

Lots of Shops and Local Foods. This is the main walking area of Playa Del Carmen. There are commercial businesses like the kind you see in the USA, and small mom and pop shops as well. For souvenirs and handcrafts, don't buy at the first shop you see. Don't be afraid to haggle (or negotiate, if you prefer) the price down to a more reasonable amount. Try buying 2 or more for a lower price, that seems to work often. Overall, a fun experience and worth the time. And it is one block from the ocean and the port and plaza is at the southern portion of Calle 5th.
main st Playa. ever lengthening street parallel to the beach 1 block in featuring shops, bars, restaurants, etc. 20 block long and northern end newer and nicer

Loved the shopping district. If you want to spend the day shopping, lunch and people watching, then this is the place to be. We had a great day browsing all the little shops and we had lunch in a little open area Mexican food place that was simply amazing. We didn't catch the name of the place but ask where all the locals eat and you will be pointed in the right direction.

Oh my God the harassment. Okay so we visited at the 5th Avenue area and all I can say is get away from me they will let you shop in peace you try to look around to see what you can get as souvenirs or just in general buy something nice and all they did was put everything on top of it wouldn't let you shop standing right behind you saying buy this take this buy this take this, then they have a trick do you tell you $1 special $10 special and you're thinking well hey a dollar special for $10 special the minute you get to the register they tell you $30 and you're like wait a minute you said a dollar and they're like no it's a dollar off be careful of what and where you go here the lights around people especially people that they don't think speak Spanish fortunately we're Puerto Ricans we speak Spanish please be careful also watch your items you have a lot of pickpockets out there

Same o same o. Fun the first time though, however if you have to get from point A to B take the beach (you can shop at home, a lot of junk) less people saying "hey Mister cheaper then K-Mart come take a look" however it's people watching at it's best, but if you shop off the main drag you can find the same products much cheaper and you get to deal with true locals...

Good shopping . There is loads of shops from your little independent ones selling handmade items to your big chain stores . There is also quite a few restaurants to choose from as well if you fancy a meal out. if you keep walking right to the end near the ferry port you will see street performers which are worth it, they will ask you for a tip for watching but are very grateful for anything you give them

Pedistrian mall (safe and popular with tourists and locals). I miss the small side streets off 5th avenue which now has two large malls instead. Great for shopping but it takes away from the lazy Mexican town feeling.

Not very impressed. If you walk down the entire street, you start to see the same stores again and again. We did get some great tequila buys that you won't find in the States. However, being bothered by the store merchants or the kiosk owners as you're walking down the street was annoying. And if you've rented a car, finding parking can be very challenging though the cost of parking is extremely cheap.As for shopping for brand names; we stopped in a couple of stores and their prices were pretty high compared to stores back home so there was no benefit for buying name brands there.The beach seemed nice, but we had gone for the shopping we were told about so we don't know what a day at the beach is like. Except for the tequila, we wouldn't go back.

busy, crazy street. don't be fooled...this street is ENORMOUS! takes forever to walk it. lots to see...everyone tries to sell you stuff. No Gracias usually is enough to stop them. great little restaurants along 5th.

Touristy Avenue that is more geared to visitors than locals.. If you want to shop, eat, drink or party - there is something here for everyone... but its not very Mexican at all... very commercial designed for visitors. Nothing wrong with this, but just don't expect a local feel. For that, just go a few blocks further inland and you'll discover a much more local experience.

Too expensive too touristy. I can go to H & M and Forever 21 at home. The main shopping center there is composed of American stores. I was hoping to get more of the artesanal feel and I felt like I was walking down a street in Los Angeles.

A wander down 5th Ave Playa Del Carmen. 5th ave is a must when in Playa Del Carmen. It has an amzing variety of shops , bars , lounges etc. There really is something for everyone here and it just keeps getting better. They have many small shops that still allow bartering but also have many large retailers now as well as some big malls. 5th ave keeps growing further and further to the North and keeps bringing us back time and time again. It is extremely safe and enjoyable for everyone and the nighttime visits when all is lit up is very nice.
Exceeded expectations. Very nice - very high quality food, great trees, nice shopping (Zara, Nike, Hurley, etc). Like Bourbon street but much, much safer and much, much cleaner.

Fun at first, after like 20 times, you want to start SHOOTING!!. TripAdvisor friends, This is a street in PDC, with out any cars. Just shops and restaurants. We had to walk down this street to do to just about every place to eat and every attraction. Our hotel was on this street. We started to walk the beach just to AVOID this street. after like 20 times being asked for the same thing from the same people. If you LOVE to shop, dont buy your first thing you see, hit it end to end, then go back and haggle. Some places give you even a small bonus if you pay in US dollars. of course you get a 5% bonus, but the prices are 10 % higher. Everyone has to do this street a few times, just for fun. But after a while avoid it if you can. I saw a guy with monkeys here like 2 years ago, but now I have not seen him. I guess they shut that down. Any prices it worth having a monkey sit on your shoulders. IMHO. Good luck keeping your money. dr Darrell of Michigan.

Day Trip to Shop. The shops here are all the same... pretty crappy stuff that the locals will peddle on you hardcore. It's basically like Canal Street in NYC except some of the venders here will grab a hold of you and pull you into their shops. If you are going down here to shop you better have your game face on or you'll lose all your pesos in a Mexican minute.
SHOPS, FOOD...YOU NAME IT. enjoyed the shops and the food was great. many good bars. this has something for everyone in your group

Too commercialized. I was there 5 years ago and went back again this year. Most of the little vendors have been moved out due to the bigger chains setting up shop. The new section of 5th Avenue has more condo buildings than I have ever seen. There are great little resturants like Texas Burger Co and 500 Gramos with great food. But the vendors on the street selling trinkets have gotten very aggressive at trying to get you to buy what they are selling. I really didn't enjoy going for a nightly walk as they would try to move you to where they were selling things. I enjoy the mariachi bandsmen the past but now they don't play unless you paid them first. They even come up to your table if you were eating asking you to pay for a song. A little to commercial for me.

A bit much but a must see and do. There is a lot to see and plenty of shopping here. Plenty of eateries too. It was also the place we were offered drugs most often so don't be shocked. There were people getting the fish pedicures on the street. Tons of eyeglass shops. It's a great place to find souvenirs. Found shark tooth necklaces and had my sons names put on them for quite cheap. The vendors can be quite aggressive but by the time you get there you should be used to it. Just ignore them.

Crazy, colourful, crowded. We were slightly taken aback by the Quinta, so many people, tourists and sellers alike! It made it somewhat easier not to make/keep eye contact with the more aggressive vendors and I always felt a little bit on guard. It felt a bit commercial to my tastes. Perhaps I am just not a big fan of crowds. In any case, it was a fun experience but I doubt we'll be doing it again, I much preferred the quieter streets of Tulum.

Scratch that souvenir shopping itch!. "Hey remember me, I'm your waiter from the Paradisus!" I read a review that the sellers would do this and they did, we all laughed.Walking along here is a fun stroll. Try not to do it in the middle of the day during the heat. Tons of things to look at. Small shops mixed with areas for 'American' stores like Forever 21. Great people watching. Take the time to walk up to Kaxapa to eat!This street is really long (30 blocks?) and ends on 1 side with the ferry plaza. Family was worn out half way down, did the other half another day. Got ice cream at Aldos and filled our bags with chotskies.

Souvenir shopping. If you are looking for those gifts to take back home for family and friends, this is the area to visit. $2pp for a cab ride where you can stock up on T-shirts, liquor, spices, etc. were the merchants are freely willing to haggle, just know when to say NO! Also, so many restaurant choices are in the area

Like a Mexican New Orleans. If you come to Playa you simply must visit 5th Avenue at least once. It's a trip. The reason my review is only 4 stars is simply because of all the hawkers. It can be annoying at times, as these folks are really relentless. Once you get used to telling people "no gracias" over and over you can have fun though. There are literally hundreds of bars and restaurants down this little street, so you can easily have fun and always find something to do. Plus the beautiful beach is only blocks away.
Shops and nightlife. Awesome shops and nightlife. We had our first fish pedicure which was amazing!! They have a variety of stores, restaurants with live music, karaoke bars and clubs.

blocks and blocks of entertainment and shopping. shopping drinking eating and entertainment all in one spot!! great restaurants...however, do not like when shop owners are pushy and want you in their store just keep walking

Evening walk. Have been here once before now at Gran Porto real it is a 5minute walk, to be in it. Lots of Artesians and shops. Repetitive. Lots of shops from home the same prices only US dollars. Nice walk at night ,safe ,no worrys.There is a bar /restaurant that has a live band. Would come here again.

Good experience. Lots of shops from high end to market stalls. Plenty of restaurants and bars. We went during the day and had a great time. It's a very long street and people are willing to haggle. We purchased all of our gifts for going home.

Watch out anyone who says Remember me, I am the waiter at your resort!. As soon as we got off the bus we were scammed by a local who claimed to be a waiter at our resort and ushered us into his brothers shop. I am ashamed to say we ended up buying some hugely overpriced silver. If you do respond buy a fridge magnet for 50 mexican pesos and leave.

Shopaholic Heaven @ Playa del Carmen. Need great shopping or restaurant options? This is the Place...From Benneton, Zahara Home to different Mexican outlets...you will find anything you are looking for. People are very friendly but they do tend to inflate prices for turists. Lots of great food options, silver, and mexican art buying options. After shopping, take a dip at Playa del Carmen Beach.

Great shopping just stay slightly switched on and no problems. Great shops and people running them, you can spot the rouge traders, and to be fair, they're not to bad, we went in many shops and had no problems at all, neither should you, two pieces of advice, cover your hotel wristband and they have no idea where you're from, no pop up "waiters" from your hotel, and take and spend Mexican peso, you get a far better deal than the USD, another great feature is the random Mexican traditional bands that's pop up out of nowhere, play and disappear again, fab!

La Quinta, 5th Avenue, in Playa del Carmen what makes Playa special. We've been coming to Playa for 25 years and it's always been about the beach and La Quinta. It's a pedestrian only street filled with shops and restaurants. It grows longer each year and is currently about 3 miles long. Seafood, Italian, and Mexican restaurants dominate, but you'll find Starbucks, Haagen Daz and other familiar names. It's most crowded at night as people stroll to dinner. You can sit at restaurants and people watch for hours. More and more high end stores (think Michael Kors) are locating on the 5th. It's the place to be.

Lively. Quinta Avenuda has a lot of hawkers, but once you get past the touristy feel, it is a great place to spend the evening after a day of diving or sight seeing. There are numerous restaurants, shops and even high end malls. close to the beach and stuff.

Great Shopping. Beware if you have a wristband from a resort the vendors will tell you that they work at your resort and they are just in town to help their families to make extra money and try to sell you jewelry some of which is priced right others not make sure you know pesos to dollars.

High end to flea market. You can find anything from luxury shops to flea markets. Buy sunblock before you get here as it has a tremendous markup. Good place to find souvenirs. Tequila shops offer samples too! There's a really cool statue as you're headed toward the Cozumel ferry.

A Stroll down 5th Avenue. The various facets of 5th Avenue are interesting as well as different. There are the hawkers for the various shops that one would expect and they are fun to jaw with. The restaurants are interesting and the food is always good. 5th Avenue is made for the tourist such as yours truly and is fun to visit, spend some pesos and enjoy the day at the park. If you need something quieter just step over to 10th Avenue and it is there. All in all 5th Avenue is an excellent experience to visit in Playa Del Carmen, MX.

Same as Barkers at a Carnival. Love Quinta Ave [5th avenue]. We stopped at a jewelry store and Valentino was great, not pushy, but very informative. He pointed out that most Barkers look for a bracelet that resorts issue to their residents. They know where you are staying and will remind you that they were Your Waiter. Please come in and help my uncle build his business, etc etc. Fun, everything you need and some that you don't need.We did not make it to the side streets, which are more local color. Every evening there is an indian show at the plaza near the small church. This is a must to see. Church has Mass in English on Sundays. Must try the Fish Pedicure. I could go on and on.

Great shopping. We love coming to Playa and walking up and down 5th ave. You can buy anything here and see all types of people. Lot's of great food and drink. A must see for anyone coming to the area.

ALOT ALOT ALOT. There was so much here so you have to go more than once. Do not buy from what you see at first, look around because again its just so much. Stay alert when you go out at night because it gets super packed.

Great to stroll around.. The main shopping street in PDL & well worth a visit.However be prepared to be hassled, a friendly 'No Gracias' usually is all it takes.If you are staying at an AI hotel turn your band inside out, that way you won't get anyone trying to tell you they work in your hotel as a ploy to get you to stop.Don't just stick to 5th ave, as there are other shops/restaurants in the side streets & they tend to be cheaper.It does get very hot so timing is everything, maybe go at night still hot but not quite as bad.

Busy, but interesting. Quinta Avenida is the consummate tourist area. All kinds of shops, restaurants, and bars.We ate at Karen's and bought jewelry at Mary's. We recommend them.Great for people watching.We visit Playa from our resort at least once a year.Don't be afraid to bargain. That said, if a price is too good to be true,it probably is.
Lots to see. Nice area for shopping and lunch. There is a beautiful park and if you are lucky you may catch the Mayan fliers.

busy street lots of shops. this was nice because you have all the stores you can think of there. Lots of bars and restaurants, we did the fish spa which was cool. and easy access to the beach from this street

Fantastic. What a amazing place, Love love love walking up and down this street just full of character the Mexican people are great , plenty of bars, restuarants and plenty of shopping if you have plenty of money could spend all day here and have the need to visit other days .
Plenty to choose from.. SO many shops to choose from, great environment and a long walk. The employees know several languages.

It's an okay shopping area.. As you would it expect, it is very touristy and quite a long street of stores from the usual cachis to luxury shops. We found a nice restaurant but if we didn't go I didn't feel like we would have missed anything

If you are young and want to party hearty!. Back in my carousing years I would have loved this people promenade with its parade of bars and joints and I could have ignored the come ons from the ropers as easily as I did as a kid on R&R in the Saigon of the 60's...but now the constant pestering had me off Quinta Avenida afetr 2 blocks.

A great place to go shopping in Playa del Carmen. I really liked Quinta Avenida in Playa del Carmen. We were staying far away from the city, so this was our only time in a shopping area. It was very nice. I liked the stores... there was a very nice mall (dont remember the name) with great stores and good prices.The only thing i didnt like is that the salespeople from the stores seemed too pushy. You almost pretend that you dont speak their language so you dont have to talk to them. They can be very obnoxious. But we still had a good time and did some great shopping there!

Find Anything You Need on Quinta Avenida. This major street in Playa has everything you need from food, clothes, make up to tours and taxis. Being a tourist it gets a little old being accosted to buy something every few feet but after a moment you learn how to decline as you pass by. Great time!
Mixed feelings. Love the area, great accomondations, great food, but the street vendors are annoying. Giorgio.The government really needs to address this

It has it all...hustle and bustle..love it!. This is a very safe and entertaining spot, which stretches out to many blocks. It has something for everyone. Music, culture and shopping. Loved the little white church on the pedestrian walk. We also saw the Mexican - Mayan dancers perform in the square. Great photo opportunities. Playa has it all and do enjoy when you visit. If you venture off to 10th Avenue, the area becomes more reasonable and less touristy - so my advice is - do it all.
our trip to 5th avenue. too Americanized! Sellers really hassle you. If you are Canadian, make sure you have pesos, as they want American $

Cheap trinkets and over priced restaurants. If you want to shop go off 5th Ave. You should totally visit 5th Ave while in PCD... for all about 5 minutes. I found the whole stretch more or less the same. over priced restaurants and mass produced trinkets. it's great if that's what you are in to.But this is what I suggest:Food: If you want good food without going too "local" (ie away from 5th Ave), head one streeet over to 10th Ave. Just as many choices there without the hype and the tourist tax.Shop: Don't just stay on 5th, many alleys that run perpendicular to 5th have boutique shops that sell unique handmade pieces by local artists.one thing I found really helpful was to do a little search online and just go to specific shops that I am interested in. this website everythingplaydelcarmen.com has a ton of info (not affiliated. I just found their site very helpful) Based on their suggestions I got a hammock at a local shop for 750 pesos instead of 2000 pesos on 5th Ave.

Typical tourist area. Nice shady street just up from the beach. Lots and lots of shops and restaurants but nothing charming or special about this stretch -- actually made me sad to see they even have the big American chain stores here too now.

5th avenue buying. The vendors do not haggle prices. The best prices can be found in the large tourist/souvenir stores. Most people are super friendly but a few are dishonest. If you have a resort bracelet they will say they know you from that resort and try to get you into their stores with all kind of stories. One vender was super rude when we wouldn't pay his price but he was the excepton....Stop at Micaela's for the beer and nacho special. It's a great price compared to the rest and it's friendly. On your walk if you see the fish pedicure place you so need to do it! Josie was amazing and so much fun even with a language barrier...she is sooooo worth a good tip too.. enjoy
Mexican Venice Beach. Just like a Mexican Venice Beach, lots of people trying to sell you their things and saying things in Spanish when you tell them no. It was fun.

ok. lots to see... however, this is a eclectic town built for tourists and not travelers seeking the true culture. You will enjoy sights and sounds for a change of escaping a trapped in all inclusive. At least you can eat a good meal that is not over processed and recycled from the resorts.
At least 1 night. For at least 1 night you need to take a cab out of your hotel and visit quinta avenida. It is full local ambience. There is a lot to see, eat and drink.

Vibrant street with "European" feel!. This is really the center of activity at Playa del Carmen - unless you're staying at a resort and never setting foot outside of it, you will run into the Quinta Avenida. Long street lined with shops and restaurants. Lots of hidden gems like great (extremely cheap) massage parlors too. Very colorful buildings, great for pictures and just looking around. At night, the bars and clubs come alive! Super fun, lots of choices for everyone, from the casual to the dressy.

Not worth the time. Unless you love to shop, enjoy crowds, and vendors that try every trick in the book to get your attention, no need to go here. Many shops sell the same thing with various prices. Unless you HAVE to go there, save your money and time.

Walking in the early morning. Visiting this busy street in the early morning is so nice, when you can really admire the locals opening their shops, preparing the first coffee and juice.Walk close to the ferry terminal to see the great sculpture work and to admire the beautiful turquoise beach side.
very colorful and picturesck. at 5th ave in playas u can purchase all kind of items national and international and many restaurants and bars welcome turist

shopping,shopping,shopping. Great experience, easy cab ride down and back, local merchants try to draw you in but just smile and wave and say no thank you because there is no way you can go into every one of them but haggle when you do...they are very pleasant people:) Restaurants, silver shops, local crafts and art work (especially Mexico Loco- Juarez Ave which is a restaurant but sells "nice quality" local art up near cruise ship docks) hotels ect. You can drink a cold beer that you can buy at any of the stores and drink it as you are shopping (not on Sunday though)

way to aggressive. People selling tours or working at restaurants are way to aggressive on the strip. We preferred to walk a street up because we were not hounded every 2 seconds to buy something or go in somewhere. I understand they have to make money but take no as an answer and the level of aggression was just annoying

Local feel, excellent time, but somewhat touristy. Quinta Avenida is a must if you visit Playa deal Carmen, a lot of shopping, dinning and interesting places to see along the streets. Make sure to try a fish taco and cervesa or margarita from one of the many food stands along the water. Fountains, statues and a Mayan festival pole will give you and enjoyable afternoon or evening "on the town". Where comfortable cloths and shoes and remember to negotiate on all,purchases!
Take a Walk. Taking a walk in the evening hours through Quinta Avenida was great. The streets were lit up and so many people walking around, shopping and enjoying the atmosphere

Tourist street in PDC. This street is full of bars, gift shops and restaurants. Hawkers constantly trying to get you into their stores, on their tours, and generally trying to get your money. They can be annoying, just remember "No gracias" you will use it a lot. Still worth a visit while in Playa. Can get pretty crazy at night as all the bars crank up their music.

Typical Tourist shopping street. Have been to 5th Avenue several times 2015 & 2016.It is probably a must go if you are in area and haven't been, but must ignore the street salespeople who try to lure you into their stores - they are probably the ones who want to rip off the tourists.Having said that, there are some good shops here and one can find some nice gifts. There is a new mall at 5th Avenue and 12th Street where you can find your name brand stores from the U.S. While there, don't miss Au Cacao at Constituyentes (I have reviewed it). Also worth a stop is Sol Jaguar around 4th Street (I also reviewed) for interesting gifts. Not reviewed by us but where we have purchased is International Diamonds for those with more expensive tastes for good quality jewelry - they have stores all around Caribbean.
Love to walk 5th avenue at night. Great place to find pretty much everything. Great restaurants, stores and jewelry. Night time is great there as the people watching is great fun.

The Old Avenida Ain't What She Used To Be.... ..but that don't necessarily make it a bad thing. Yet.Ya know, some ten years ago or more, this was a quiet sort of place. Quieter, anyway. Quaint, you might say. Some nights, it was just me, the wife, and a bunch of cigarette smoking Italians wandering around. Not a bad deal. Stroll the Avenida, find a place for a marg or two, check out some tourist traps. Now? Well, now you got some malls. Like, two or three. Probably more on the way. And Krispy Kreme. I'm not sure what Playa needs a Krispy Kreme for. A multi-level department store that sells everything. And a Burger King. Because nothing says "vacation" like eating all the same stuff you do at home, right?More higher-end restaurants, too, which ain't bad, but the locals...ask them what they think about the development. Some will say it's great. Others, they're worried. About closing. I know because I asked. Some of the places that have been in Playa for what seemed like forever...are gone now.I love 5th. It's one of my favorite places in the world. I hate to see the old 5th go. But, progress can't be stopped and they want Playa to be like Cancun, so then Tulum can be like Cancun and then it won't matter much where you go. As long as you go. And to that, I add, "Go now, check it all out while it's all mostly still there."

Beautiful shopping area. We loved the variety that 5th Avenida offers, the only thing I see as upsetting is how Americanized this avenue is becoming. I want to enjoy what the locals have to offer and not see stores that I can shop at here in the US. Please stop taking away the authenticity that Mexico has to offer! There was lots to see, but some vendors can be a bit pushy. The ones that we did buy from were less aggressive. Many restaurants...we were hoping to see the entertainment but missed most of it.
Walking by 5th avenue. Lot of thing to see most of them to expensive but if you walk a bit outside it you can find good food at reasonable prices

Brilliant.just ignore the sellers.. My fiance and I came for a day to get away from the hotel and see Mexico. First we went to a beach bar for food and drinks then we went shopping. The avenue itself is long and filled with allsorts of shops eateries and a mall.You can also haggle for prices here too.You get people who will know the colour wristband you wear and will say to you they work at your hotel and it's there day off do and you want to go look at their shop bla bla bla. A simple no will do or just completely ignore them.Anyway we really enjoyed coming here.

The nightlife hearth in Playa del Carmen. When we moved from Cancun to Playa del Carmen we were pleasantly surprised to discover the nightlife in Playa del Carmen was much better! Quinta Avenida is a really long street with lots of bars, good restaurants, shops and clubs but the atmosphere is more relaxing! And there's live music everyday which i really liked.
Shops catering to tourists. We went during the day and cannot comment on the nightlife. The stores cater to the tourists and seemed overpriced compared to other places we shopped.

5th Ave, better at night than during the day, way too hot. Lots of stores, some American style but mostly solo businesses and so many duplicate type stores. Walking down the Avenue you will be approached constantly to come to their store, so after a while it gets a bit tiresome. The latest PLOY is for a young man to come up to you and start talking to you, especially if you wear an all inclusive band on your wrist that gives away your hotel. The ploy is they say "you don't recognise me from the Prinses Hotel" (because the waiters wear hair nets now) " I was your waiter, I don't look the same, do I. I have a side business come and take a look at our store". The stores are off the main street, on one of the side streets. So be aware, they are NOT your waiter.If you love shopping and lots of people milling around and lots of choices for restaurants, then 5th Ave may be for you. As for us, not so much.
