An evening visit may have been better, lights, music and much cooler. 1 highlight though was the 4 men in colorful garb doing the Danza De Los Veladores, check it out at the south end of the Ave.

avenue shopping experience. shopped and got good gifts for family and ourselves, all store keepers friendly and accommodating to assist us in finding things we knew we wanted, earrings, shawl or scarf.
Great place to shop. . This Avenue has a little bit of everything. It has great shops for shopping. Fantastic restaurants with many variety of cuisines. Great place to spend the day or night.

Great place to get harassed by salesmen and pay for overpriced food. While I was in Playa del Carmen, I tried to avoid the Quinta Avenida as much as possible. The entire avenue is just huge, overpriced souvenir shops; relentless tour vendors; and overpriced, touristy restaurants. (Did I say overpriced?)You can't walk down the Quinta Avenida without being harassed every five seconds, and I mean harassment ranging from the simple annoying salesman to actual inappropriate and rude comments. I had endless men telling me to smile, asking if I wanted a Mexican boyfriend, and saying mean things if I just kept walking and ignored them altogether. (After about 5 long conversations with tour salesmen, who I clearly told there was no chance I would buy a tour, who insisted that they just wanted to have a conversation that ultimately ended with them trying to sell me a tour - no surprise there - or offering to be my Mexican boyfriend, I was just completely over trying to be nice/polite to anybody.)I want to note that I never felt unsafe during my time on the Quinta Avenida, just annoyed and harassed. It certainly put a damper on things.I also want to note that this is NOT how I was treated elsewhere on my trip to Mexico, including in the very touristy areas and souvenir shop areas of Tulum and Puerto Vallarta.That being said, the Quinta Avenida has a good variety of souvenirs if you're in the market. Plus, a lot of the main attractions are located on the avenue.I would recommend trying to get off the Quinta Avenida as much as possible, since you'll find better and less expensive food elsewhere. Plus, you can avoid being harassed incessantly by street vendors! Yay!
We were there every night. The strip is very clean and shopping is great. The prices were negotiable at all of the smaller shops. There are sooo many places to eat and they're all open late.

Review. Lots of stores but very touristy, not many local artists. Most of the stores have t shirts and souvenirs shipped in from China. The owners of the shops come out and try to get people to come in, which gets annoying. Only a few restaurants with local cuisine. Overall feel is like coming into a port on a cruise.
So many things to see. They have an amazing selection. So many stores! From super upscale to little stands. Def needed more time there.

loved 5th avenue!. Loved this place however there needs to be more parking!!! we paid 3$ at the museum of wonder which was very close between 8th and 10th in a parking garage. The amount of people that come up and ask you to buy drugs is a little ridiculous my husband was asked 5 times. But we loved it. So much going on so many stores, restaurants and bars. So much fun to be had!

Playa's Malecon. Busy walk with shops, bars, malls, music and diverse range of restaurants. Anything you want from Michael Kors to forever 21...tacos to filet mignon. Great place to buy pesos right next to a Starbucks. Dont miss the side streets and nightlife.

Walking on 5th Ave.. It was decent walking on the 5th Avenue. Mostly shops to buy things at a very expensive price,with shopkeepers heckling to sell their stuff. Overall in my opinion, the place is over-rated.
We found a decent coffee shop a block or two away from the Avenue. Their cold coffee (café frio) was good.

Fun!. Quinta avenida is fun and with a lot of restaurants! And shops! Be aware they are very expensive!!!
Nice street for families, couples, or just group of friends !

not to miss while in Playa del Carmen. To me this is the most charming thing about going to Playa del Carmen, you cam get great resorts anywhere but to walk in the Quinta Avenida is the best experience of all, you can walk trough a lit of blocks full of shops, bars, restaurants and easily spend a whole day exploring the best of Mexico. Make sure to eat at any of the restaurants they all provide an amazing service and great food!
A must. Day and night. A very nice ave to walk, shop, eat or just sit and watch people passing by. I enjoy very much and ice cream or coffee, I sit and relax.

I see Tourists. Fifth Ave was initially overwhelming. The sales people are aggressive and everywhere, but once you realize that, it's ok. Two pieces of advice: #1, if you're American, have them charge everything in Pesos! At dinner, the bill said it was $90 in USD and it actually was around $74 once it posted. #2, don't ignore the sales people-acknowledge either with a smile and "no, gracias" if not interested or get ready to haggle! And per a locals advice, don't "get into with" the taxi drivers, but be sure to negotiate price before you get in. If you're a woman with a man, be prepared to be ignored unless you help with a sales pitch. It's a very male dominated society, but no one was at all rude and we never felt unsafe. The selection for food, drink, shops, excursions, massages, etc are endless. After 3 days visiting 5th Ave, I really loved it. We highly recommend La Fisheria and Puerto Cocina Urbana for food and drink.
Cute!. Playa del Carmen is wonderful! It's away from the masses in Cancun and you have a variety of restaurants to choose from!

Nice day trip. We went to 5th Ave for a day in Playa Del Carmen. Beware that they are very pushy and harrass you constantly while shopping. I have bartered and shopped in many places including Mexico, Jamaica,Haiti and Chile but this one was annoying. Most will not barter at all and are harrassing.Beware of scam if you have a resort bracelet on....they will say "they are your waiter from last night" to get you to buy from them. They say very rude things if you keep walking. I'm glad we went, but it's not a must see for me in the future.

Lively street all hours of the day.. There is something for everyone in this street. Shops and more shops. Arcades of shops. Restaurants, bars, music and the beach bars and clubs until the early hours of the morning
Lots of bars with live music!. Bars, restaurants and storefronts. If you walk up some of the side streets to the restaurants and bars there, the prices drop dramatically.

5th Avenue. This strip of shopping and restaurants is a good glimpse of the Mexican culture. Lots of street vendors, all of which try to sell you their product. Be sure to negotiate the prices! We ate a couple different restaurants down there too and they were all welcoming and very tasty.

Great place to eat, shop and have fun. We stayed at the Royal so we were in walking distance to 5th Avenue. So many restaurants, bars and shopping. It's also a great place to walk in the early morning. Felt very safe

Comes alive at night. If there is a place that you must be in Playa Del Carmen, it is most certainly Quinta Avenida. By day, it is not too much more than pesky shops trying to sell you stuff that you have seen too much of already at "almost free" prices. When the sun goes down, the Avenida comes alive. From the ADO bus station at one end, you can walk north for over a mile and in addition to the pesky shops, you will find one fine restaurant after another, attempting to seduce you with their street side menus. Interspersed between all of this are many liquor bars with live entertainment. A good description of this Avenida would be "Bourbon Street South".

Its ok, but prepare to be bombarded.. The avenue is nice enough, but with every step you have vendors and restaurenteurs calling you to visit their establishment. We've had a few people (when we say we're not interested) say "don't you remember me - I work in your hotel" which is strange as we've rented a condo! Also if you eat in some of the places, especially tables near the street you will likely have kids trying to sell you sweets and bracelets and such whilst eating. Not good.On the upside, there's plenty of choice as there's everyrhing here and it's good for people watching.

Typical port street. Quinta Ave is your typical port street with stalls and souvenirs trinkets. It's a long street with clothes, things to buy and food. Felt very safe walking around. Around 6pm or so local people performed near the ferry.
Exploring 5th avenue . Had a wonderful time walking around and visiting all the shops. Different things to see and great place just to kick back and relax! Definitely a must!!

Food and Entertainment Surround You. 5th Avenue is filled with great restaurants, bars, live music, and clubs. I recommend Coco Bongo. It's a little expensive but includes drinks and all night long entertainment.

It's Fifth Avenue South of the Border!. High end shops, designer clothes and Starbucks! Pretty much what you come to Mexico for right?? A many blocks long pedestrian walkway with little eateries, tacky souvenir stands, lovely restaurants, open air bars, boutique hotels and even a first class mall!! Something for everyone - great people watching and always a shady spot for that cerveza or frosty margarita!

This Is It!. Avenida Quinta IS Playa del Carmen. This is where you go for almost anything. Everything you want to do can be found here. Book your tours, great restaurants, great bars, shopping, and even a sports betting place.When we first got to this area, my wife and I were staying in a small hotel about 5 blocks away. we would walk down to the Avenida every morning strolling with our dog looking for somewhere to eat breakfast (lots of choices). We would do the same for dinner. Everyone loved our dog (Astro). The restaurants are pet friendly since you sit outside at most of them.
Fun fun fun. Amazing a must go. Night tine here was awesome. We felt safe. Drinks are cheap and food was above average

You have to come here twice to really enjoy it!. We stayed outside of Playa. We came here twice and really enjoyed the walk and the people watching. There is a lot of great unique women's shopping and excellent people watching.

Eh.... Just a bunch of cheap shops and poor excuses for bars (Fat Tuesday's? Really?) if you like people constantly yelling at you to try to sell you something, including drugs, then this is for you. If Disney World put up a section called Mexicoland, it would look something like this.

Good Vibes. It is what it is ! Lots to sell and they all have the cheapest or best , just go along don;t make eye contact if you don't want dialog with sales people or they love to talk and sell,sell. We always have a good time and the beers on the street when its so hot !OMG!

Would not go back.... The hotel staff seemed a little skeptical when we announced we were going to check out Quinta Avenida in Playa del Carmen, and we soon discovered why they practically discouraged us from going. Two women walking along the avenue here apparently invited an astonishing amount of catcalling and aggressive sales pitches from street vendors. Not just men yelling at us from the side of the street, no, they frequently came right up to us and stood in our path flirting, trying to entice us to try some restaurant or bar, etc. Not pleasant. We really came here to check out a store called Sol Jaguar, which was very small but had some terrific handcrafted items from Quintana Roo and really all over Mexico. We bought a couple of special things and quickly flagged a taxi to take us back to the hotel. I'm fairly sure he was gouging us a little on the price based on what we paid the taxi that the hotel staff place us in, but at that point, I was too happy to be back at the hotel to argue.

Mixed feelings. Many high end stores and some hawking. The hawkers left us alone as we said "no, thank you" and kept walking. We found the vendors in the middle of the street to generally be helpful. We should have tried to bargain more!

People watching paradise.. Of course while in Playa Del Carmen you cant avoid strolling down Quinta (5th avenue) Avenida and of course it fun.So many shops and restaurants and so much better in the evening.Like so many popular tourist spots its a must do but like so many others its not the heart of Playa, do yourself a favor and venture a few blocks further off the beach and see the real playa. So many small local restaurants and shops to balance out the Quinta Avenida experience.

Vacation . Lots of shops and restaurants if you are looking for family oriented activities this is ideal. If you want clubs you could get to can Cun in about 45 minutes which I believe is close enough to party but you can go back and relax in playa which has better beach fronts. Enjoy

Great!!!. Great place to spend the end of your days in Playa del Carmen. There are plenty of shops, bars and restaurants (from handcraft shops, silver shops and internationally renowned brands) that don´t close before 10 PM. Make sure to visit even if you´re staying at a all inclusive hotel.
Great fun to watch the twirling acrobats!. We always enjoy 5th Avenue. Playa del Carmen is a fun place to visit. The food is always good, and there are so many things to see.

Hassle. If only the vendors didn't hassle so much they would , they would attract more business . Went 5 times in 4 years and ended up just walking down the middle every time avoiding the lookee lookee brigades

An ok place to visit. Be sure to keep your money and valuables close as there are some dodgy looking characters. We got asked 4 times if we wanted to buy drugs! Also don't be fooled by a man saying he is the waiter from your hotel. They can tell by your wristband which hotel you are from and they will try and convince you to buy jewellery from a new shop they have just opened!!
A must if you are in the region. Very nice environment at thr end of the afternoon/night. Very colourful , amazing restaurants, and a huge amount of shops! Really worth to visit!
Great shopping. 5th Avenue has many high-end shops souvenir shops Point Loma restaurants it was a very fun afternoon I must see if you're in the Playa Del Carmen area

Beautiful but expensive. It is a long road with a lot of big stores and some local ones. You can find Apple, H&M, Forever 21, Michael Kors, Guess, Sunglasses Hut, Victoria Secrets and others but with more expensive prices than normal. There are plenty restaurants availables for different styles: mexican, italian, seafood, brazilian, Sushi, etc.

Shopping trip to Quinta Avenida. This is a must do for shoppers. Lots of local vendors selling typical souvenirs as well as high end retailers. If you want great food try Yaxche at the corner of 5th and 22nd! Excellent Mayan inspired cuisine.
Tourist trap. Very long road with vendors trying to get your business. Very good restaurants and pubs. Do not take any trips 1/2 price they include a 3 hour visit to a time share.
Ughhh. Not my type of place. Its full of touristic stuff like shops or pubs , nothing local, dirty vibe. You don't feel you're in mexico at all.

Nothing special. We found 5th Avenue disappointing. Lots of shopping (much poor) and not very inspiring restaurants.Worth a short visit but use TripAdvisor to find the best restaurants off the main street.
Something for everyone. If at first you don't see what your looking for...keep walking!!! You'll find it or someone will find it for you!!! Or turn around & look on the other side of the street.

What an experience. Where do you start?! So many shops you can't visit them all. The end closest to the pier has high end open aired mall. Walking north are the smaller shops. I have never seen so many silver stores! How can they possibly all stay open? We had the sales approach of..."Hey senor..I remember serving you at your resort! My brother owns the shop on the corner so I can get you a good deal" Maybe he did, my husband fell for it as I smirked. I would love to poke through the endless shops with a girlfriend because this was simply a path to the bar for by hubby. It's a real experience off the resort.

Disappointed with changes to 5th, lost its charm. While 5th Ave used to be fun, unique, adventurous, it's now like walking into the mall in my hometown. We once came and spent an evening in a jewelry store being serenaded, brought tequila and laughing at jokes. Now it seems all the small unique shops have been pushed out by Sunglass Hut (I counted 3 stores) and Victoria Secret. The charm is gone. I don't need Forever 21, Bath & Body Works and all the other stores I can easily find in the US! The further north you walk 5th Ave some of the old style shows up, more with quaint individually owned shops. I'm searching off 5th avenue now - I can't stand the way 5th has commercialized.

Overrated, overpriced, and the vendors hassle you and make stupid comments.. Irritating people are stressing me out on this avenue. When you try and ignore the vendors, they say stupid things like, "Hey, do you want to meet uncle Charlie" (cocaine), or, "Let me show you my sister; happy ending." Stupid people! This is the only place of the 6 that I have been in Mexico where people are bugging me. Food and drink are expensive here as well: 175 pesos( 7 Quid ) for a frozen Margarita, in Fat Tuesdays bar. Add a 25 pesos tip to that as well. Drunken git that I was, I had two of them. So, while the beach is beautiful; Quinta Avenida, as the main tourist strip here, comes with hassles.
Shopping. 5th Avenue vreat for shopping, Coco Bongo can be found here, bars , restaurants etc . Best to go here in the evening , a cab is cheap enough about 120 pesos .

Not as bad as people say. We arrived knowing we would be approached by sellers and they are fine with a polite 'no thank you' Yes there are people who ask u if you want to buy drugs etc but again, we didn't feel pressured or under threat at any timeMany shops allowed you to browse hassle free or offered you free tequila with no obligation to buy. Great place to grab a bargain, souvenir or duty free.
Fun shopping experience.... Hundreds of shops and vendors...high end to street sellers. Close to the beach so quite a parade of folks.

Only ok. Not much to say, it was ok a lot of shopping really nothing spectacular. I just wanted to been able to say I 've been there but if I go back to Playa del Carmen will not visit 5th Avenue. I think the Plaza was a lot better and cheaper.
Walked arounf Playa del Carmen. Had a great couple of hours walking on 5 th avenue, shopping and wondering around. i recommand going at end of day as the temperature gets quite hot during the day.
Shopping!!. It's a nice street to go shopping or eat at local restaurants. Some items can be pricy. It could get super hot in the sun, not much shade as you walk unless you go inside the stores.

Over hyped Avenue. We walked the entire length of Quinta Avenida hoping to find something good. Most of the places all sell the same thing but if your looking for silver, check the prices carefully. We saved over $100USD by going to several silver stores and finding the exact bracelet for much, much cheaper. A lot of Mexicans trying to get you into their store and not someone else's. I guess we were expecting something more. Worth a visit but we wouldn't spend an entire day there.
Great place. Best place to stay, to dinner, and to buy things from México. It´s the heart of Playa del Carmen. Very cute
Good shopping street . Can do a mix of picking up some bargain souvenirs here and also clothes shopping. No hassle and plenty of interesting shops.

High-end to local shops!. I spent about 4 hours walking up and down this lively street on Wednesday night and it was so much fun. The street is lined with shops, restaurants, and bars. I loved the variety of stores that range from very high-end to the local artisan shops. It is a great place for the whole family or for a romantic stroll with your significant other. Most restaurants have tables outside so you can pass the time "people-watching" as you sip on a cocktail. The street is also located about 2 blocks down from the beach. Next time I go, I will be ready to head to the beach after a day of shopping.

Everything is very expensive walk five blocks north for better prices . La Quinta avenida is a fun place at playa. There's lots of people trying to sell you things. They want your money. But for food and gifts walk a few blocks away and you will find better prices. They want about $60 per day for car rentals and food is like if you are eating In the us. People here are really friendly. They are willing to help and explain where to go. The beaches are the best beaches probably in the world. Take lots of sun block beaches being close to the equator you get burned really fast. Not tanned but burn. Your skin will be red. Eating out. Try going outside the touristy area because you will pay a lot of money. Go further away from the main streets. Prices are three times less than what you will pay for in the main area. We learned the hard way. We spent about $100 in just two days just in food and beer for two. You will be paying about $30 a person. Take public transportation the ADO Is about sixty pesos which is about $5. It will take you to cancun and most destinations there like Xcaret xelha and xplorer but if you will be doing that I recommend the collectivo which is the common taxi will be about $35 peso one way. It's about $2. But all in all going to tulum they wanted $79 a person but we paid $20 for two with transportation taking the collectivo. The collectivo taxi is located off 20th street I believe. If you ask people they will tell you exactly where to go. The collectivo will take you to all of the cenotes. I recommend the cenote Eden, and Azul and also the cenote in Tulum called the main cenote. Very beautiful. The beaches in tulum are way better so try to go there. Expect people wanting tips for everything expect to have to pay and take extra change. All the sightseeing and everything is money there. Alcohol stops selling at 5pm outside the tourists spots because they double it on 5th Ave. so if you will be there for a while go to Walmart which is about 7 blocks from the main avenida and buy yourself food and lots of alcohol to take to the beach if that's your thing. If not water snacks and food to keep going. I recommend you bring a small ice chest those plastic ones so you can take to the beach and bring an umbrella as you will need it for when you go to the beach and to chichen itza and tulum. The sun is hard on you then you will have to buy it there. This way you can have it and be ready.
Great shopping!. 5th avenue is great for shopping, and restaurants.Great venues for cigars, trinkets, clothing, and just about everything under the sun!

A little bit of everything. Fifth Ave is a great place to blow some time and do some shopping but you will get hounded a little from local shop owners wanting you to check out their wares and some other things. There are also many shops that are very similar and you may find the same exact shop three to four times from one end of fifth to the other. But there are also some good shopping that can be done with good deals if you know how to haggle.

Nice place to visit. I enjoyed a couple of days here, there are a lot of restaurants, bars, shopping centers and so on.In general it is nice to walk around and get some drinks and souvenirs for a good price.
playa del carmens highlight. a wonderful long road which is car free and loaded with restaurants, shopping centres, souvenir shops and tourist centres to book activites.
Great place to shop and eat!. Playa has awesome shopping. Quaint and deals for bargain hunters. If you're hungry, make sure to eat at Aldea Cortozone.

Great place to stoll. Lots of shops and little family run restaurants. Unique little shops besides all of the junk stores. I love to sit and watch all the different tourists and local that are drawn here.

Interesting mix. Was expecting all US style malls but really surprised to find such a huge variety of different types of shops, bars and restaurants. Shopping ranges from cheap souvenirs and t-shirts to high end US fashion chains. Essentially it is one long street so you can wander as far as you want. Be prepared for vendors calling you to come into their stores as you walk past, and trying to sell you tours, messages and other things, but if you just say no thank you they won't hassle you. It felt safe and was an interesting and fun experience.

I Love Walking This. Call me a tourist, because I am. Just get past the hard sell around the bus station and ferry dock and take your time. Look at the smaller shops, friendly people and an occasional different find. Go down the side streets.You will find small local taco or pastry shops and bars if you are so inclined. The higher up you go the better. Have Fun! You are on vacation after all.

Hassled.... Lots of guys out there trying to hustle you. Amusing, if it were not so irritating. It is like walking a gauntlet, if you are not with a man, and if you are a man, they offer you women and drugs. It was actually a sad reflection on tourism in Playa del Carmen.
Very nice but wouldn't choose it. Really nice spot for a coffee! but it really don't like crowded places. I'd rather go to the beach, that is very close to quinta avenida btw.

Stroll along with pleasure!. So many times you end up at your destination with a "shopping" district which has you craving for more. More shops please, more restaurants, more people to watch please. That won't be the case with Playa Del Carmen's 5th Avenue. Tree lined, even streets, clean and plenty of shops/restaurants and more. The new blended in with the local flare, it goes on and on and was totally enjoyable!

Lots to see on La Quinta. La Quinta is a great mix of shopping, dining and people-watching on the pedestrian only area which stretches for many blocks now Early in the morning, it's quiet and cooler, then gets busier & hotter as the day progresses. We enjoy it most in the evenings when it starts to cool off again, and for those interested in late night bar activity, there is plenty to do. Although many of the shops are somewhat repetitive, there are still some with unique items. Lots of good choices for a meal, snack or a drink - many places with outdoor seating where you can watch families couples and groups of all ages enjoying La Quinta.

Lots to do!. This Avenue is for everybody. It has everything you want: huge and small souvenir stores, cheap & expensive restaurants, cheap & expensive bars, clubs , clothing, shoes & accessories stores like H&M , but also Michael Kors. Hair salons, spa's etc. Store and restaurants are open till 11-11.30 pm. Bar and clubs all night. Me and hubby enjoyed it for 3 days in a row.
It's all here!!!. So it is pretty touristy but with that you get a ton of great food options and great people watching !!!! Many shops are US chain shops. Others are pretty pricey Mexican goods.

Eclectic mix of old and new, tradition and tourist. We booked our hotel right off the avenue. Loved taking a walk down this long street especially in the evening when it's busy and alive with a great atmosphere. All sort of shops and restaurants are down this street from a new shopping area down one end with Zara, Rolex, berska, and tourist shops to forever 21, h&m and plenty more down the other, there are plenty of restaurants, a beautiful old Catholic Church where we saw a wedding one evening and nuns sell there wears outside, bands playing and more. If your hotel is in the area go have a wander.

fun street blocked off from traffic. lots of shops and restaurants. very clean. could rent bikes if you wanted... people were not too pushy trying to sell you things or get you into their store as bad as other places I have been....

Such a great area. If you are going to Mexico, especially the Caribbean coast, you want to visit Quinta Avenida. Countless shops and vendors and amazing food. The people are so nice and you can find exactly what you are looking for. If you stay in Playa del Carmen, try to get a hotel on this street!

Great shopping!. My husband and I had a blast in and out of the shops. He bought a pair of leather cowboy boots and the shop keeper even came out with the bottom (knee down) from a pair of jeans to see how they would look (he of course was in shorts). Watch the tequila tasting - we ended up with a $125 bottle but it was fun!
Where the action is. Great for everything, food ,shopping and entertainment. No car necessary.You also can find massage and body treatments in many places.

Fun day trip!. We decided to venture out of our resort and visit Quinta Avenida, it was definitely fun! It is true, you will get hassled by almost every shop asking you to come and purchase their items but it did not phase us. If you like to shop, this is the place to go. We did not buy much as we found the further you got from PDC, the better deals you got on authentic souvenirs.
hide your wristband. The sellers will recognise your all inclusive wristband and then claim to be the waiter/bartender that served you recently. Don't believe them.

A little bit of everything!. I've been here a couple times now, and still enjoy it There are all kinds of shops here, international ones, as well as authentic Mexican shops. Lots of good restaurants, too! You can spend hours here.

Fun shopping and people watching. A must when in Playa! Locals call it a tourist trap but that isn't always such a bad thing! Tons of souvenirs, shopping for every budget, food for every budget or taste. All lit up at night and music playing everywhere. We love it!
The epicenter of Playa Del Carmen . Always something new to visit and see Great spots to eat shop. Definitely a big crowd of European and South American travelers
Shopping and entertainment. . After a few blocks the shops are all the same. The restaurant and bars change and there are some public parks just off the Avenue. Fun to barter with the shops.
Loved the restaurant choices. I loved all the choices of places to eat. We spent most of our nights here even though we had an all inclusive deal at our resort.

Great. Great for shopping . Lots of top names including a Michael Kors Vibrant atmosphere . Lively bars great day and night . Highly recommend . Very safe walking into playa del Carmen day and night from hotels in Playacar . Worth a visit or two .

Trendy Playa. Quinta Avenida certainly provides bright lights and action to PDC. Lots of souvenir shops selling the same mass produced souvenirs, your Americanized high end stores and overpriced "Cuban" cigars. There are some shops that offer some value but you do have to search for them. Beware the tour stands as they may offer you a deal if you attend a hotel presentation which will likely be a timeshare offer. We got roped into one and cancelled the following day. There are legitimate tour operators typically operating out of an office or store.It is a busy and fun spot though. Find a chair and people watch. There are some good restaurants and we found the FAH which offers live music at night as well so that was fun. Food is good but try and explore out of 5th and 10th to find some local joints that offer very flavorful meals at a lower cost as well.

A must stroll down pedistrain-only Fifth Ave. 20 block long pedestrian-only avenue with shops, bars, galleries and restaurants. As you go north, it gets newer and nicer with few upscale malls along the way. Great people watching

See and be seen fashion, eating and shopping strip for PdC. The ~mile-long street is a mix of cheap tourist knickknacks, overpriced convenience stores, some higher-end handicraft & goods, & intermittent touts for massages, restaurants, other services and products. Not a bad place for gift shopping. Food quality is good and the vibe is distinctly international, worthy of a visit and imo much more appealing than Cancun (city or hotel zone).

A splash of vibrant colour. Loads to see and do in 5th Ave with a great variety of shops, stalls,restaurants & bars. Some of the stall owners cab be a bit pushy but if you say no thanks they leave you alone.

Everything you could need. Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) is the place to be in Playa Del Carmen. Not only can you buy nearly everything from the local stores, there are also some bigger chain stores (H&M, Hollister, Forever 21), loads of pharmacy's and loads of places to eat and drink no matter what you fancy and what your price range is. We spent a lot of time just strolling up and down and soaking up the atmosphere. Locals from their shops will shout hello and ask you to come into their shops, a simple no thank you works. I found the mexicans to be extremely accommodating. If you need a taxi, you can get one here... Massage? No problem. Tequila Tasting? come on in! There was everything.
Worth a visit. Good for a wander and a meal. Lots of branded shops mixed with souvenir shops. We went early evening and there was lots of entertainment going on around main square and beach area.
Great massages. We had great massages at Sabai by Esther and Nory. We always felt great after one of their massages. Eddie was always helpful in arranging our appointments.

Worth visiting!. I stayed at a hotel in the area and found myself walking Quinta Avenida everyday to go shopping, eat breakfast/lunch/dinner or watching the entertainment along the street. There are so many restaurants you can't go wrong. Tip: Go to the French restaurant Chez Celine early for a fantastic breakfast. I guarantee you will enjoy the atmosphere and the fresh food.

Walk down Quinta . We got dropped off by our taxi on 38th. There's lots of souvenir shops and restaurants even a mall with big name stores. The souvenirs were priced at American prices so it's not really cheap like if you go to a small village. You can find the best tequila in these shops. You will be approached by many people selling tours so if that's what your looking for you can negotiate a good rate since competition is high.

this should be called La Gringoria. This is the usual tourist strip for Playa. To really experience the town and setting any of the streets that run parallel to this gringo strip and find you will find yourself some real gems that will be real nice to your pocket as well.

5th Avenue Playa del Carmen, Q.R. Mx.. Excellent shopping and more. Safe and beautiful especially at night. Highly recommended! Plenty of cigar shops for cigar officionados. Pharmacies every where and too many shops and.store to count. There are restaurants and bars to the Pontiac that you don't know which one to choose as they almost all look so inviting! Visit the Plaza by the quaint Catholic Church near the south end of 5th Ave.

Great shopping when not on the beach.. every night take a walk up or down 5th avenue and see the restaurants and the fabulous shops. If you forget anything from home, you can find it here. Super fun!!!
Haggle Haggle Haggle. Put your hagglin' shoes on! This is a poppin' avenue best times to shop are before noon or after 6. Vendors are vocal but not aggressive.

Love the hustle and bustle. . I took my sister and husband here. Really loved the busy nature atmosphere and so many shops to buy gifts for our friends and family at home. It's got at least 2 malls that have everything you would want. But be prepared to walk away from vendors. Otherwise you will be broke by the time you get to the other side.

A nice walk. Great area to enjoy a local dish, and of course a cold beer, the beach is 2 blocks away if you get tired of shopping, but overall is a nice walk, prices are negotiable, don't be afraid to rummage ,
Fifth Avenue. Lots to see, had our feet nibbled by fishes. $15 for 15 min. Great restaurants, bars, stores, gorgeous beach. We took bus from resort on way down and taxi $20 on way back.

Everthing your tourist heart can desire. Eat, drink, dress Mexican...it's all on avenue 5. The are some excellent quality shops in amongst the tourist haunts and no-one but the jewellers hassle you to buy.

Always A Hit... Although most of the shops sell the same stuff, it's still fun to wander and people watch.. There are also some new higher end stores, but I can shop all of that at home, kind of takes the fun out of shopping in Mexico.. Wayan Village is my favorite for clothing.. There was a store named Caravan that was really nice for assessories.. At times you get harassed to "look at my store". But a small little no Gracis is enough to stop.
Lots of things to see and do.. Always barter especially in the jewellery shops. Expect to pay around 30% of the first quoted price.
A fun place to explore. Lots to see and do on 5th Ave. Many excellent places to eat or just sit and sip on a cerveza while you watch the crowd go by.

Too short a visit. We stopped briefly on our way to and from other destinations. There is so much to see and lots of territory to cover. My son likened it to being on the Amazing Race as we ended up racing to find our Resort Shuttle which was hidden behind some jewelry store. Our cab happened to drop us off over a mile away at the wrong store. That was an adventure. We found a great all purpose store for water shoes that were half the price of our resort. Same brand/quality. Cab drivers will negotiate and are friendly. Yes, I was approached by the "guy that works at my resort". Threw it back at him and we both ended up having a good laugh over it. Turned out to be a nice guy. Can't wait to return and spend more time.
Always something to see!. We winter in PDC and there is always something happening on 5th. Music, art shopping or just people watching. Definitely the place to be.

The Avenue, Nothing More Needs To Be Said. If you're in Playa, you will no doubt come across 5th Avenue. Everything you might want is here. From shopping to dining to drinking to simply taking in the sights and sounds of all that is Playa, 5th Avenida is your destination. Restaurants from all over the world are represented as well as Mexico's best. There is shopping from souvenir and trinkets to art and jewelry. Fashion from t-shirts to tuxedos, it all depends on what your looking for. If you visit the Riviera Maya, you owe it to yourself to visit 5th Avenida, if not to shop, then just to see.

El Capitan visits 5th Ave - Quinta Avenida. This is a must visit for all people that visit the Mayan Riviera. A blend of restaurants, shops, cafe's, bars, patio bars. specialty shops and high end plazas, The street has changed immensely in the five years since I first visited - it is amazing with some of the best restaurants in the Mayan Riviera located there.5th Ave has it all. Go at night - the street comes alive with mariachi bands, local acts - the street is alive. You can walk for miles. There are vendors trying to sell you the typical tourist stuff - but that is part of the charm of being in Mexico. The sellers right on 5th Ave. will barter - but not much. They get thousands of visitors a day and won't move a lot on their prices. Overall, the prices at all stores and restaurants are more than outlying areas - so be careful when buying since you can get it cheaper a few feet down a side street. All in all - a great way to spend a night taking in some of the sights of Mexico.

Shopping. Very long avenue for shopping. You and pick up tequila ,souvenirs, silver and art.Be aware of wering you resort bands down there. The peddlers recenize that you are from a certain resort and will say that they are a waiter at that resort and that they remember you. Then they will asked you to go in there Mothers shop to buy something.
What you can expect for a tourist street.. Vendors try to sell everything from tours, to massages, to souvenirs. Priced more than Plaza las Americas.
Interesting shops. Things to remember, don't fall for the "Hey amigo, remember me I am the waiter at whatever resort", to get you into their shops, but overall a great value

Shopping on 5th. If you want souvenirs that are the typical cheap stuff your better off to goto Walmart. Prices are so inflated here. But if your looking to shop at boutiques or retail stores then they do have a lot of good things that are decently priced. One guy quoted me $80us for a silver bangle. I walked away.
Great Shopping and Restaurants !. I hadn't been to Playa deal Carmen on 5th Avenue in a few years, it has really changed . Lots of great places to eat and great shopping !
Noche and safe. It has everything for every budget, from nice restaurants to affordable souvenir shops, very safe, language is not a problem, all the business have English speaking personnel

5th avenue . The 5th avenue if one of the beautiful places in "Playa Del Carmen". It has many restaurants (delicious by the way), many shops, and is a great place to be with your family and friends! The beach is really close to it and you can do many things besides shopping and eating jajaj👍🏾

wow. I didn't like the changes they have been making. they build a new mall, its like been in the U.S. they removed those beautiful restaurants and little stores that make it so special. I love to feel im in Mexico with their culture, not US...Besides that 5ta Av is magical

Becoming more Americanized. Love the vibe and just wondering about 5th Ave - over the past 15 + years this street is becoming more of a big store meca rather than the little town with great authentic stores. You can still find the little shops and those one of a kind items but you have to travel farther and wonder a little off 5th at times. Still love the vibe of 5th the restaurants, entertainment and coffee shops - sitting people watching - but it is definitely loosing that authentic Mexican small town vibe from years past

RIP OFF CENTER OF PLAYA DEL CARMEN. Beware of the hawks on this street...this is the biggest rip off street in Playa del Carmen.If you buy silver beware it might not be silver but alpaca. Just everything you buy from the phony Cuban Cigars are a rip off....I can't say anything good about the hawks that insult you as you pass and the gimmicks they use to get you ninth shop. Some put the dollar at a higher exchange rate so the stupid tourists think they are getting value after the mark everything up 40 %... Most people enjoy being ripped off.

A Browsers Paradise. If you want to spend a lazy day in Playa del Carmen, Quinta Avenida is the place to be. Do what ever your heart dictates: Window shop in Quinta Alegria Mall, dine on seafood, sip coffee and eat local pastries at a cafe, or enjoy a few drinks with friends at one of the many bars. If shopping, you will find shops with standard tourist souvenirs as well as those with serious local art and crafts. If you are tired of walking, there is always the beach to cool off and relax. Quinta Avenida is the portal to "something for everyone." No trip to Playa del Carmen is complete without the better part of a day spent at this destination.

The place to be, if you like action.. Famous Quinta avenida, we walk from our hotel to here, it have everything you want or need, from restaurants to stores, suveniers, even a shopping Mall, with lots of American brands.Walking in Quinta avenida is a MUST at least once if you are in Playa, during the evening and night is more fun, more people, more everything.
Nice Day Visit. Spent an early morning here had a good time , lots to see and do , had to leave early because of heavy rain but still a good day in Mexico.

Good energy, fun place. Quinta Avenida is a long pedestrian area with tons of restaurants, bars and stores. It is teeming with people and a lot of fun. Over the years, it has begun to lose its Mexican feel--there are many international stores (Victoria Secret, Nike, etc), but grabbing a bite to eat and walking the avenue is an enjoyable way to spend an evening.

Great place to stroll, eat and shop. Nice quiet friendly area to stroll through. There is shopping and some great food in many of the abundant restaurants.One time while there we experienced rain, but it was no problem as we sat at the front of a restaurant and watched the rain while we ate. The street flooded and went down quickly, the sun came back out, and everyone went about as before.
Lovely atmosphere. This a really lovely place to walk and watch ( yes watch) the beautiful shops. My advice, buy your souvenir in chichen itza!

Bars and Shops. This is the area where you find all the Bars, Restaurants and shops in Playa Del Carmen. Well worth the visit in the day for the shops and to visit in the evening for a night out in the bars and restaurants.
super fun to walk around!. Loved walking up and down Quinta Avenida! So many great boutique shops and restaurants! Loved Ah Cacao!

A very interesting long walk. Came here with my husband to playa del carmen. We walked up this street for over an hour. It goes on forever. It is a very interesting street. Alot of souvenir stores with a mix of American stores. Most stores repeated over and over. Kind of silly. The further you walk down 5th Ave the cheaper the souvenirs will be. But remember you can bargain with locals. We were staying at a resort and had wristbands on. We noticed the locals knew where we were staying and approached us saying they were there come see their moms store. We decided to turn the wristband inside out and no one could tell where we were staying! The locals will approach you all over trying to get you in their stores. Don't go unless you want to. There are so many options for eating. We decided to go off 5th and found some very affordable restaurants. An fyi. There are clean public washrooms in the quinta mall. It is halfway up 5th Ave.

Monoculture comes to Playa del Carmen. Walking along this street is reminiscent of strolling the fairgrounds. Everyone is hawking something. It's nice not to worry about traffic but everything is so hyper-commercialized. Did you really travel all this way to buy brand name swim trunks available at any North American mall? Beware of many overpriced and mediocre restaurants. Visited Playa 11 years ago and can't believe the changes -- not for the better.

Tourists Delight. If you go to PDC, you have to visit 5th Ave at night. Tequilla tasting in almost every souvenier shop. More t-shirts than you can count. Guys in Authentic Mayan dress for pictures along with the silver/gold dudes that stand still. Most of the restaurants are very good and I haven't had to have a reservation anywhere because there are so many. Just stroll along and you can pick your spot. I am told, though I dont participate any longer, that the Clubbing is good in town also. I have been going to PDC for 10 years and I have always felt safe, even when my kids were 5-10 yrs. old. Have fun.
Love to Shop!. Soooooo many stores! You will find what you are looking for. Tip: understand money denomination. Lots of places to eat and drink. Do at your own risk. Had an enjoyable day.

Fun!. Love visiting the locals! Yes they try to get you in their store, yes they say they've seen you at your resort, and yes we still love doing it. Its their livelihood. Just say no, gracias and keep walking. We enjoy it! We are a little sad by how commercialized its becoming but the little shops are worth checking out. We've been at all hours and always felt safe. Cannot wait to go back!

Quinta Avenida...Fabulous,fabulous. My husband and I have been going to Playa del Carmen for our winters for 12 years.5th Ave is one of the attractions for us.We can walk it everyday and not stop anywhere or we will walk it,stop for coffee,and meet people,walk again,stop for lunch,and meet more people and continue our stroll..Its lined with Shops,cafés,bars,restaurants and boutique hotels..Just lovely.Over the 12 years we have seen it grow from 10 blocks long to 35 blocks lone.Strickly pedestrian ,no vehicles or bikes.. Even after 12 years we will still spot something somewhere we havnt spotted before.Sure there are more modern changes happening over the years,but no complaints from us..It is what it is and we love it...

LOTS of shopping and restaurants. 5th is a great place for people watching and picking up the shot glass you promised your neighbor for keeping an eye on your house. While some of the unique charater has disappeared as Starbucks and Sunglasses hut appeared, you can still find the Mom and Pop trinket shops if you keep looking. Stop at one of the local restaurants, sit near the street as you drink a well desearved cold one and just enjoy the view as tourists from all over the world march past. It was 10 years since my last trip to Playa and I would not have recognized the place had I not been there myself. A part of me mourns for the Playa of old but time marches on....

surprising experience!!! People are not to pushing. People are not to pushing, what make it a great stroll down in the evening. All kind of restaurantes and stores along it, and we can even see some local shows around!

Nice. This is theMain Street in Playa Del Carmen. You can find everything here!
I hope that Playa Del Carmen stop or control the expansion of the city, if not, this will be the next superficial Cancun...
Always fun. We love to stroll down 5th -it's always a bustle of activity, color & sounds. The vendors can be a little obnoxious though. Politeness goes a long way.

South Beach USA in Mexico. Wow! We have not visited Playa Del Carmen in 3 years and were absolutely flabbergasted by how many changes have taken place. Actually ventured down the avenue with a friend from Playa and even she was amazed by the expansive growth!Must admit I was disappointed by the changes. The huge American style mall was not anything that interested us so we just wandered by in favour of smaller Mexican type retail establishments.

Vendors are too much!!!. 5th Avenue was definitely something to see. Tons of shops and great restaurants and bars but getting constantly hassled by the vendors got to be too much at times. 8 have no problem spending my money in local businesses but when I am almost harassed to go into a shop it makes me not want to go near it no matter what they are selling. I found some of the prices of the shops we did go into rather expensive and the vendors were not willing to haggle.

Great place to walk, run, have drinks and good eats!. Love it here! Such a big variety of food to try and great shops! Avoid eye contact if you don't want the shop owners to try to get in their store! !

Cancun's version of NYC's 5th Ave. If you love to shop and are in Cancun area this is a nice place to spend a morning shopping, buying souveniers, and having lunch or drinks. Recommend small restaurants on beach rather than expensive one on street.
Fun. fun to walk around but get used to saying "non gracias" . Lots of vendors all selling the same things.

Morning visit. Nice long walk, pleasant little shops and big name stores (meh). In your face too as as you'd expect. Vendors recognize the color of your bracelet and know what resort your from and make it seem like they know you cause they're waitstaff there......really?

Best place to spend some time.. So much to see and buy eat and play. Fun for all the family the beach here is clean just a little choppy. They now have shows here to like xcaret. The whole day is nice but better in the evening,beautiful place to see the sunset or to get married in the Chapel.

Kinda fun, really touristy. This shopping street in Playa Del Carmen, is just what you would expect. A very touristy place to buy trinkets, booze and eat western style Mexican food. I'm sure there are good restaurants along this strip and that some of the shops have interesting, authentic Mexican art, but it's few and far between. Still, if you are staying Playa, it's worth a stroll, just for the spectacle.

Best place to eat. La Quinta Venida is the best place to eat! You don't go wrong! So many Restaurants to choose from.
Italian, seafood, Cuban, Mexican,

can be fun for a walk. There are lots of bars, restaurants and shops for all tastes. The street is buzzing, full of tourists and of course locals who try to sell their crafts and invite you to their restaurants - typical tourist street.

Tourists Trap. Boutiques are overpriced and its the same crap over and over, some decent restaurant, 70 pesos for a beer is too much, go up two blocks and that same beer is at 24 pesos.
That said its amusing to walk at night

busy tourist spot!!. popular with tourists ! full of stores ,restaurants and bars. You can also take ferry to Cozumel here!There is also a big modern shopping center with all brand stores .Explore the side streets away from 5th ave so you can get a better bargain and less touristy. Great to find good eats ! Have a beer and a taco too!!bring good shoes !!

I did not enjoyed it!. We go to the Riviera Maya every year but we never visited the 5th Avenue.We went for the first time on Sunday, April 3, 2016. Some friends keep talking about it so we decided to go.I find the place full of stores but except the international lines, all the other places were not too good. I was desssapointed. I will not go back. I bought better quality souvenirs at Tulum downtown

Busy tourist street . It's the main area in Playa del Carmen. It's a long street full of stores , restaurants bars.jewelry stores pharmacies and souvenirs , there is a big modern shopping center with stores such as Victoria Secrets Mac and HM .You can also take the ferry from here to Cozumel .Bring good walking shoes. And prepare to beat the crowds .You might want to explore the side streets away from 5th Ave Cheaper stores and less crowded

Can't miss attraction if near Playa del Carmen!. Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) is a can't miss attraction if you're anywhere close to Playa! This is especially true if you know a little bit about why things are the way they are there. Mainly, the biggest complaint about 5th is the constant barrage of vendors trying to get you into their stores by any means necessary. While admittedly, this can be a bit bothersome at first, I have learned to actually enjoy it and usually get a good laugh or 2 every time I walk a portion of 5th.I have been to Playa around 10 times total and 5-6 times in the last 2+ years. So, I have walked portions of 5th all the way to the ever-expanding end (currently around 38th) literally hundreds of times. Businesses come and go but there are pretty much 2 constants: 1- things change here a lot more than average. this means businesses closing and new ones opening up, as well as the northward expansion of the "tourist zone", and 2- you WILL get propositioned or enticed multiple times and in a variety of manners on your walk here!There are a variety of different shops here... mostly in 2 main categories: 1- tourist shops with souvenirs, etc and Spa/Massage places. You will not get "bugged" to enter the big tourist stores because those are under a much different ownership model. These employ multiple people who get paid by the hour, so there is no incentive for them to try to pluck you off of 5th. By contrast, the smaller shops are usually run by their owner or have an employee who works directly for commission. This is why you will see many people approach you while walking down 5th... because these people make nothing unless you buy something from their store. Also, you should be aware these people will use a variety of tricks to entice you into their store. Many of these guys are quite smart and I have seen them fool dozens of tourists first hand. However, there is no fowl play afoot... they are simply trying to get you to enter their store in the hopes you will buy something. The most common trick continues to be the "I was your waiter at your hotel/restaurant the other night" one. In this scenario, the guys typical look for an all-inclusive bracelet. They seem to have most of them memorized so don't be fooled into believing them just because they know your hotel. They typically tell you that they were your waiter a few nights ago and that today is their day off so they're helping out in their uncle's store. They play on the fact that many people will feel guilty about not remembering the guy (but of course you don't remember since he never was your waiter lol) and this guilt trip works a stunning % of times that I have seen. They have also expanded it to include non-resort restaurants but this doesn't work nearly as often since by default, they have to speak in much more general terms, meaning more people catch onto the scam. Bottom line is, just be aware of it and buy something only if you want it, not because you are falsely guilted into it.The other main type of businesses (other than restaurants of course) are Spas. Most of these are massage only, but a few (like Magic Moments Spa near Constituyentes) also offer pedicure and manicure. These services are very cheap compared to prices in the USA at least. Most of them offer 1 hour massages for between $20-$30, which is well below the average of $50-$100 in the US. The big problem now though is that there are so many of these places (probably over 20 now just on the main part of 5th). This is not necessarily bad for tourists but it's bad for the girls (and some guys) who work there because they do not get paid anything unless they actually give a massage. A good portion of these places are also now using girls with no technical training. I have visited most of these places and the general rule of thumb is this... the farther north you go on 5th, the better your chances of getting a really good massage are. Some places that I know require all of their girls to be certified are: Magic Moments Spa (5th & Const - Aura is the best but all the girls are good. this is probably the best place currently in Playa), Magic Hands (2 locations: between 6th and 8th & between 10th & 12th). Also, Sabai, Zen & Be are good quality, but management here is poor towards employees.5th also has a distinctly different vibe between day and night, so both are recommended (I personally prefer night). For the most part, day activity is higher from Constituyents south and that mostly dies down by around 9pm. The night vibe kicks in usually after sundown from 10th/12th northwards, so this is a good time to explore the area north of Const, which includes a ton of new trendy restaurants.Overall, it's a really great experience, especially if you are into shopping, eating, or people watching.
Great way to spend a day. 5th Avenue has so much to offer....the restaurant scene is amazing - stick with the authentic Mexican restaurants as they are the best.

People Watch, Talk, Dine and Shop. This street is an important part of the Playa del Carmen experience. So much fun in such a great location. Music, Mariachi bands, entertainment, street vendors, hair braiding, artwork, sombreros, pharmacies selling (Z-Paks! WOW! Couldn't believe it!), Great dining, surf shops and so much more. Day or night. Shops stay open until at least 10, some 11 p.m. Great fun to walk after dinner. NEVER PAY FULL PRICE. When they say a hat is $85 it's not... Maybe $25 at most! Have fun, bargain and don't miss all the fun on this street!

Honky Tonk. A mix of souvenir places with owners try to get you and and some higher end stores. We had bracelets from our resort and so many of the hagglers approached us and said remember me I'm your waiter from the other night. Come in my store. A bit annoying Fantastic people watching

Fifth Avenue. Very much like Bourbon Street in New Orleans, but minus the passed out drunks and panhandlers. The biggest drawback is the relentless solicitations for business from street peddlers and shop employees. It was very tiresome to be solicited every ten steps.

Good place to chill. We came here at night time usually and it was good. There is lots here - lots of shopping with all kinds of variety. Lots of restaurants. Tons of people and a good vibe. Great place to come and watch your sports teams. We found a lot of Winnipeg Jets NHL faithful at EZ Sports bar.

Fun Time. I rode the shuttle from my hotel for free and spent a couple of hours shopping. Most of the shops are duplicates (hair braids, jewelry, knick-knacks) but you can find some good food and unique items. Fun day.

Food, drinks and people watching galore.. Now doubled in size from just a few years ago, Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) in the scene in Playa. The new end is north of Constituentes and the older end us south. Fun bars of all descriptions include sports, free tequila for girls who dance on the bar and cool places on rooftops with beds to relcline on while you imbibe. There is also every kind of restaurant you could hope for including real Yucatecan and a happening Cuban place with great food and salsa music. You can buy anthing from Mexican tourist stuff to Birkenstocks. This is the way to get to the world-famous Blue Parrot - a wild, late-night club on the beach. It is tourisy but everything you want us there if you look.

Carnival Atmosphere. I love wondering the streets , just looking around, playing the games with the vendors,stopping for a cold drink. Interesting walks everyday discovereing new shops, from a coffee roaster on 10th to a fabulous leather shop just off 5th. There is always something new , venture off 5th explore , fun Martini bar on 1st, Dirty Martini .
Medianamemte bueno.. If you want to know about mexican culture and local real mexican food this is not the right place. This is not our culture, is just like a little street of USA in Mexico.

Shopping! Shopping! . 5th Ave is a strip full of department stores Michael Kors, Mac, Victoria Secrets, Nine West Ect...there are also vendors that sell souvenirs.Taxi ride is 10 minute ride for $7 from playa del carmen, Walking distance is about 30 minute but it can get pretty hot .

Be prepared to use a stiff arm and move forward!. The avenue was a unique experience. Probably not one Ill do again. Tons of street vendors and stores with all kinds of souvenirs. Great for souvenirs, bad if you don't like to haggle.

Main pedestrian thoroughfare. Gotta go! La Quinta is the main pedestrian thoroughfare with hundreds of shops, stores, restaurants, bodegas, liquor stores, and money exchange kiosks. Two blocks from a high-end mall with a Starbucks. Everything is within walking distance. Expect to be bothered by vendors, but this is the Mexican way.

Bugged, bartered and bought. 5th avenue is great, if you take all that bugging in stride. As long as you remember that they are all out there trying to make a living too - you'll get through just fine. Never take a price at face value. If you have a max price in mind, just barter with them. If you don't get it for that price, move on, you'll get another chance next door!Visiting 5th ave actually made us want to get a hotel and stay there next time. Go a bit off the ave and you'll be able to find some great things. The beach is beautiful around there also!

Busy street. Certainly the street to be on in playa deal carmen. It's quite long and plenty of options to shop from local crafts and "tack" to high end stores. Also many bars and restaurants, so you should find something you like here. It feels different at day time to night time.

People Watchers Delight. 5th Avenue (Quinta Avenida) in Playa del Carmen is a must visit if you are staying anywhere in or near the city. Of course there are stores galore from top end to souvenir palaces to wander through. But the unending parade of people up and down the many blocks of 5th Avenue of people from all over the world is the top attraction for me. Early evening on is the best time to enjoy this fascinating and safe spectacle. Be aware that there are not many places just to sit and enjoy unless you decided to take a table at one of the many street-side restaurants.
shopping on vacation. love the atmosphere! Shopping is great! I love being around all the action! Street performers are awesome.
Love it. I Love the 5th. Sadly that they have torn down the Old stores and bild up in concrete and glas so it have soon lost the magic.

Great day on 5th Avenue. You can walk for miles & miles. Great shopping for small items up to name brand stores. Also wonderful restaurants to enjoy as well. Definitely worth the trip if you have not visited before.

Loved walking down 5th at night. So much activity, so many restaurants and such great people watching! The whole family enjoyed walking around, finding a great spot for dinner, and enjoying the perfect weather. I preferred the area closer to 38th, while other members of my family like the area closer to Juarez. Very different feel.

may as well be in the US. It's pretty much a tourist zone. The mall is full of American stores so I just went in to see it, didn't shop anywhere. Many of the local places I thought were overpriced but that's what happens in the tourist zone. If you walk up a few more blocks you get more authentic but they were not as densely populated.

Just ok. There are a lot of shops here, but the people constant bugging you to buy heir goods is sooooo annoying. I just want to walk and shop without being harassed. It made it so that I didn't want to go down there to shop and just stay at my resort.

Time Share Scam Nightmare. Many of these guys that approach you are dishonest! Don't waste your time. You are likely to spend upwards of 5 hours subject to a heaving bombardment by sales people and receive absolutely nothing for your time. These guys a crocks! Beware! Their office is located just off of Fifth Avenue and 14Norte.

Sensory Overload. This was our first trip to Playa del Carmen, and we were very happy we stopped to eat, drink, shop and take in the very cool town of PdC! This street has it all, without being overly commercialized. I felt like I could have been in any quaint Mexican town and our family enjoyed lunch and drinks on a beautiful day. It is a great place to simply watch people from many countries, walk about and enjoy what the area has to offer. Plenty of shops, restaurants and bars, so regardless of your interests, you ought to find something you enjoy. It is also just a short walk from the beach.

Playa Del Carmen must. It is a place that you should experience. It has become a lot more commercial over the years, but it still has a fun vibe, and there are some interesting shops and restaurants mixed in along the street. It is like the boardwalk at the beach - no trip is complete without it.

Tons to do. 5th avenue is the vessel that connects everything in the tourist area of PDC. Tons of restaurants, bars, shops and more. You can spend a full day/night exploring along this walking street and has something for everyone.

Not much to see other than souvenir shops and overpriced high end shops. Not worth the trip. We were approached by several people on the street trying to sell drugs. There are many souvenir shops with overpriced goods and liquor. The Mall on 5th avenue is very expensive and priced 50%-100% over comparable goods in the US and online. We didn't try any of the restaurants which were not overly expensive, but not cheap either.

A Stroll almost every night is just wonderful. I have been enjoying Playa for many, many years,...before the streets were paved.....always wonderful...just concerned about thenew taller buildings going up to replace the quaint,little shops that gave a feel to this wonderful little town.....Happy to see somany more people now enjoying Playa.....They even keep the street clean, like Europe.John, long time visitor and now resident

Worth the walk. We got to go for a boo, and the trek was long from beginning to end. A lot of the same if your shopping but every shop has their greeters to invite you in. I tried to stay to the centre and not make a lot of eye contact otherwise I was constantly apologizing for not wanting to go in the shop. Lots to see sit on the bench and just watch people haggling for a better price. That part was even more fun.
tons to see and buy. lots of variety american and mexican shops youll be able to find something for everyone on your souvenir list
Love Playa del Carmen. Tucked away amid the typical souvenir shops are some beautiful shops with beautiful art - not to mention Cenote Azul just off 5th!

You have to visit come!. It's a great street to hangout, it's a long walk from the start to the end but it's totally worth it.You can find all kinds of restaurants, from the classy ones to pizzas for $3. Some stores are great, other ones are the same one every 5 streets or so. It is definitely a really important stop in your trip.Good look!

Tacky commercial strip. If you like this sort of thing, stay at home and go to a mall. Loud and annoying. Why travel to visit H&M? Food is Mexican and in name only. Go to a side street and find a restaurant like La Perla with the most wonderful real food and drink.. not to mention fine music.

Long - commercial - a tad tacky. The main drag has lost its soul over the years. It now sports more shopping centres and large fridge open market markets peddling the usual mass produced tourist offerings.
Had to go shopping. Be prepared to haggle and say no lots to buy but go wicked low! Lots of walking but plenty of places to stop and have a drink at while someone window shops

A good way to pass a few hours during a lazy afternoon. Typical tourist strip: souvenirs, food, Starbucks, etc. Crowded and hot, but that should be expected. Nothing must see or do, but a change of scenery from the pool for a little bit.
Always Fun!. Fun place to visit! Tons of restaurants, bars. No cars so great with kids. Ice cream at every corner. Good browsing and shopping! If you like people watching this is a great place!

Always fun to stroll. So interesting to stroll and watch the people. Day or night there is always something going on. The street was packed solid around 9 pm when we were there end of March. Every kind of restaurant to choose from but like a lot of tourist streets some are a ripoff. Read reviews first. Tacky souvenir shops up to expensive designer clothing, there is definitely something for everyone

best shopping ever. best shopping ever. anything you want from cheap trinkets to handmade jewelry. Haggle in the flea market places, the prices are jacked up! Good way to pass the time, much to look at and plenty of places to eat.
Fifth Ave. Quick, easy $8 taxi ride to tourist area with bars, shops, souvenir shops and the ferry pier to Cozumel.

My favorite place in playa. I loved it here! It was my favorite place! Lots of restaurants and small shops, music in the streets, nightlife and fun! Stores close at 10-11pm so it gives you chance to have dinner and to do some shopping. The ambience here is just the perfect way to end your day!

Good trip. Be careful what to buy since they raise the prices for Americans, specially silver shops.Great restaurants every where, felt safe being there day or night.This was the third trip to that region and I will come back to Playa Del Carmen.

Super touristy and overpriced. Tourist area of 5th Ave is full of shops, restaurants and people trying to sell you tours. Nothing you can't see or find in Miami Beach or other places, especially with the influx of mainstream brand-name stores and shops. Nothing unique or Mexican about this area of PDC, so if you're looking for a real experience, just walk a couple blocks west of from 5th Ave for much cheaper and more authentic local food and drink.

Fun day.... Spent the day here and it was a wonderful experience. We took our resort shuttle to and got a taxi back... it was very reasonable and so worth it. Great little shops with so much to see. Would love to come back and spend more time here.. hopefully can return soon!

Always different each visit. We love 5th avenue. There are always new things to see. People watching is fun,. Having happy hour mojitos or margaritas is always fun. And it's always happy hour, somewhere on 5th Ave.. Spend a little or spend at lot, or just stroll along for free.
Shopping heaven. Lots of designer shops. Loads of bars/restaurant to sample the local delights, ferry terminal to Cozumel and all feels very safe.

Quinta Avenida. Downtown Playa Del Carmen has really grown up in the last 15 years. Quinta Avenida is a fun pedestrian friendly street to spend an afternoon/evening with lots of stores and restaurants. Not only the Main Street, but the side streets as well have plenty of stores to explore.
5th Avenue Playa. Fun auto-free zone. Lots of Restaurants and Shops. Easy to get to and from with a Taxi. Tequila and Cerveza for everyone!

Dinner . Very crowded at Easter week!! But with trendy restaurants. Difficulty finding parking lots this time of the year. Some of them close before midnight! Visited Frida Kalo restaurant and The Catch. The Catch has an incredible view of the island of Cozumel.

This is the place to be!!!!!. sPEND TIME HERE TO EAT SHOP OR JUST LOOK AT ALL THE ACTIVITIES. Its safe and fun. shop owners will ask you to go in their store but you just no thanks and get on your way. It gets frustrating some times but that's their job, just trying to make a buck. FOOD BOOZE ATMOSPHERE

A must do if you go yo playa. I guess if you are in the area, you must visit, as it is the main town attraction. But for us, top much touristic, noisy, pack with people and bunch of solicitors trying to lure you in a restaurant or to sell you something. Fine for young people to party, but if you need quiet, avoid

Vacation. Lots of stores comes alive at sunset. Very safe and friendly people. Taxi service has established prices no gouging. Shop around for excursions. Sad to say hotels have independent companies no real value.

Lots of repetitive shops, lots of variety in Eateries. Easy strolling , brick or smooth road--always something going on. Eateries range the full gamut of fast food to 5 Star. Be sure to check out Sur for a nice el fresco experience. Karen's is always great for Fajitas and their coconut shrimp was especially yummy. Lots of photo ops over dozens & dozens of blocks. Attire is Casual bathing suits to dresses. Anything goes. Seems all perfectly safe although have never been out strolling after 11:30pm

Can't skip this place . If you happen to be in Quintana Roo Mexico you Must visit the Quinta Avenida it's a charming walk thru store with lots of colorful shops and restaurants and boutique hotels. Great prices to buy silver jewelry and artisanal goodies, souvenirs, etcetera,the Playa Del Carmen Beach is on the other side of the street with a huge variety of beach clubs and bars, you also get to see the locals and take a closer view of this Mexican culture. Simply loved our visit here.

AMAZING PLACE TO WALK, SHOP, EAT, AND DRINK !!!. I remember coming here almost 50 years ago and the few restaurants in the area did not even have indoor rest rooms. Yes, really. I had to use a communal restroom outback being used by several businesses and using a water bucket to flush afterwards. Now this place is amazing. The transformation has been magnificent. It really is a pleasure to come here now.

The Main Street . A lot of shops, restaurants, bars , at evening something happens at every corner but you feel safe. Great vibes , people not too agressive to sell something.It was a spring break so tourists from US did their part of entertainment.

Amazing atmosphere!. First time we went to town during the day and almost melted. Most of the shops and restaurants and just getting opened us so its pretty quiet. The second time we went in at about 5 and it was hopping! All of the side bars and restaurants were open and they were alive! The vendors were out in full force! The street was lit up! Lights, music and action every where! We dined at a little bar off to the side...it was awesome a bucket of corona and food for 4 was $40!! amazing food!!

Tourist Shops Galore. I've been here several times in the past, and there has always been a focus on 'tourist shops', but now there is also a huge mall. Most of the little artisan shops are gone. So its restaurant row and very average tourist shops.

Wear Comfy Shoes. A pretentious-free environment made infinitely more spectacular with colours, textures and time travel. You enter a modern shop with beautiful clay and wood designs then walk directly through the shop to an open air restaurant complete with natural palms and mangroves. Worth the experience.

A ZOO!!!!!!!!. Yes its just a series of shops and the same souvenirs but it makes for an interesting walk.Just a great place to spend a few hours........you never know you just might meet someone you know......we did.

I liked it better 15 yrs ago,,,. The street had changed a lot in the last 15 years... Still, I cannot imagine vacationing on the Riviera Maya without a few visits to 5-th avenue in PDC...What to do there? Just walking the street it is an experiene itself... Having lunch or dinner in the restaurant of your choice could be a great experience. Shopping in PDC? This is the place! At least, I would have a Margarita on one of the teraces....

You have to go enjoy shopping and food. lot's to do and eat great food.Don't forget to take a shot and have some great drinks. Shopping is great they have everything you could ever want Rolex's to straw hats.

Don't miss this !!!. 5th ave.is a great place to visit! If you like shopping and eating, you'll be in heaven. They have shops in all price ranges, from high to low. The little boutique shops are the best. The high end shops are taking over and I think takes away from the quaintness of 5th ave. You can also go on the side streets to get good prices and food. Don't forget to get a Freida souveneir!!
What happened!. Just a few years ago this Ave. was a pleasant walking area. It is now just a series of souvenir shops, bars and eateries. Over development gone tourist mad, disappointing.
Lovely and Lively. The 5th Avenue is great during the day or at night. the atmosphere was nice and they are plenty food and shopping options

A bit of everything. This street was far longer than we thought it would be,as the first time we went, we walked to Calle 26(The Calle's cross the Avenues) which took well over half an hour. The Avenues numbers go up in 5's, so there is 5th Avenue, then 10th Avenue, then 15th. We Later found out that the Calle's go up to 38, so we hadn't reached the top as we thought.There is every kind of shop on 5th Avenue. There are the usual souvenir shops which are nearly all the same except the prices vary slightly. There are some great bars and restaurants, a few of them have live music, be it traditional or rock/pop. If you like rock/pop there is Kitxen which is 3/4 of the way up on the right and Hotel Siesta Fiesta, also known as Fah on the left about half way up. If you turn down one of the streets on the right, I can't remember which one, there is the Wah Wah bar, which has the best live music in town. It has music during some of the days and on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights. The bands were brilliant and very,very talented.There are some fabulous clothes shops and also handbag and shoe shops (various price ranges) There are lots and lots of jewellers, most of which sell beautiful silver items. If you get a taxi, there are three prices, depending on whether you wish to be at the top, middle or bottom. The first stop was never more than 90 pesos, the others varied between 100 - 140 pesos.If you cut down some of the Calle's the are more local bars which have good vibes about them.
