If you are a churchgoer there is a lovely small white church on the right which does 4 masses on a Sunday - 10.00 12.00. 17.00. 19.00.My husband and I had some really good nights in the 5th Avenue area. Even if you are All Inclusive don't go home without visiting it.

Fun vibe, but watch out for con artists. Loved the colors, activities, restaurants and vibe. Most stores close early (10 or 11 pm). Watch out for con artists who invite you "in" to see their store, down an alley of little stores. Also, another caution is when someone (native) comes up to you and welcomes you as a friend ("remember, I met you on the beach") they are probably trying to sell you something. Have fun on this pedestrian strip..just be aware!
just crowded. u just feel the tourism and everything is adjusted. Many restaurants and prices are higher than cancun.

Colorful street . Very famous street, very colorful, nice to have a walk. There are a lot of stores and restaurants, some quite expensive, others not that much. But anyway, is a must when visiting Playa and is very near the beach

Great People Watching. This is a great place to grab a beer and people watch. There are many stores you can walk in an grab a beer. A lot of restaurants and nightclubs are located either on 5th Ave. or right off it.

Too Kitschy For Me!. It is very disheartening as you're walking down the middle of 5th Avenue and you have vendors trying to heckle you into their stores or sell you an adventure package! Our tween age kiddos were a bit frightened, and it was just plain uncomfortable.Most of the shops along the way have the same trinkets and not very authentic items. A few gems in the mix, but mostly kitschy type items. They do offer a Starbucks & a few eateries along the way. However, the coolest part is having coconut water right from the coconut and watching a guy cut it open right in front of you-highlight of the Avenue! Take a stroll down by the beach and watch fisherman cut up th catch of the day or hop on a ferry to Cozumel-the action down by the beach is much more authentic! Also, there is a fashion mall located across 5th Avenue similar to those you'd see in the states. I feel that the airport had fun gifts to suit anyone-a few quaint shops with jewelry, t-shirts and unique gifts at reasonable prices and good quality!

Lots of things to see. You can shop, eat and drink. Everything you need is right on 5ta avenida. Nice colorful little town, liked it better than Cancun because it is not as big yet. Enjoy it while it lasts.

Fun adventute. Quinta Avenida has many great options for shopping and restaurants. This area will not disappoint, there is shopping for everyone. Find mall type stores (Forever 21, H&M, Hollister, Boss, Guess), and Mexican souvenir shops all in the same location. Excellent restaurants many to choose from.

Watch the scammers. A very nice street to take a walk and look around but definitely not to buy something especially at the Fabriqua Tequilla Mexico I'm not proud of myself but I have to tell my experience to help you avoid being ripped off After tasting of their Tequilla I choose one of their best bottle after a rough negotiation from 9000 pesos to 3000 pesos (for Tequilla imagine?) I accept the deal in cash afterward I was discussing with my friend and during my lack of attention he wrap up a cheapest bottle and I left with the wrong bottle after paying.BE CAREFULTHE BEST PLACE FOR TEQUILLA or what so ever IS TO WALMART on 30 avenue and 12 nte it worth the walk ex Don Julio 70 $500 pesos at the airport $980 pesos

Great tourist attraction. We visited the avenue two days in a row. Purchased some cigars and gifts, ate lunch, and did a little bit of shopping. There are great stores there (big box style and local fun things). A few blocks off the avenue will take you to more varied restaurants and shopping - including Walmart!

Best street for People Watching.. Every time we visit Playa Del Carmen we have been lucky enough to stay close to Quinta Avenida. There's so much to do on this street, shopping centers, tons of store, restaurants, there's always something new going on. For us, it's the best place for my husband because he can ride his electric scooter without the danger of cars around. Some places have ramps and he can shop with me as well.

Saturday Evening on Fifth Avenue. Great place to visit early on a Saturday evening as you get chance to shop before enjoying the activities of the local entertainers.Expect some hassle from the street vendors, excursion reps and taxi hawkers although once you have said 'no thanks' they leave you alone until you hit the next bunch a few yards down the road .A really enjoyable few hours though that you should experience if you are in the area.Also, getting the 'collectivo' back to you hotel is far less daunting than you might expect - give if a go!

Walking at 5th Avenue. Long strip full of small, medium and large set of locals where you can find stores of souvenirs, restaurants, clothes and mostly everything, very crowed all the moments specially at night with lateral streets with bars, discos and nigh entertainment for all tastes. Most things are overpriced but you have most options of city entertainment in dense space.

Good for souvenir shopping. This is a fun area for shopping for souvenirs if you are in the Playa Del Carmen area. Be aware that you will need to negotiate prices at some of the shops, as the shop owners have flexible prices. Other shops have prices clearly marked. There is a nice mall and there are restaurants in the vicinity. Taxis are plentiful.

fun shopping and strolling area. Walked here along the beach from our hotel in Playacar. It is just what you expect from a tourist town so you have to take that into account but there are many interesting bars and small shops if you bother to look.
Afternoon day trip. Interesting for a couple hours. Strolled, had coffee, lunch at the beach, and a pedicure. Worth a short afternoon away from the resort.

Awesome place!. Many people are worried to get off their resorts, but this is the place to be! There are so many things to do here! My friends and I came here on our first night in Playa del Carmen. We got dinner which was amazing! The food was so authentic! We even had a mariachi band play for us while eating. After we went to the clubs which was also a great time! If you're not into clubbing there are hookah places, more quiet bars. The shopping are is great too!

Tourist Paradise!!. This is area is lined with plenty of restaurants, souvenir shops and a wide variety of shopping ranging from typical mall stores like Forever 21, H&M, tour bookings, etc. This is basically a place full of tourists and you rarely see any locals. It's a nice place to purchase gifts for family and friends, but I would avoid shopping at any other stores and the restaurants overcharge. I would avoid this place and go somewhere off this avenue.

5th Avenue is interesting . We loved walking 5th Avenue every day. There are a ton of people, interesting blend of souvenir stores, galleries, high end shops and everything in between. The shop keepers wanting you to look in their shops gets a bit annoying but they aren't aggressive, just plentiful. Excellent restaurants are everywhere.

Fun, fun, fun. 5th Street is just plain fun with a capital F!! Much to see and experience, not to mention just people watching. Your typical Mexican street hawkers are present but all are very friendly. Lots to do including having a "fish pedicure". Did I mention Fun?
Noisy and unpleasant. The street is filled with shops selling overpriced crap. When you walk it, hawkers from both sides are trying to get your attention so that you would buy from them.

Interesting experience. We stayed just off of 5th avenue for a week. We enjoyed being so close to the restaurants, shops and action, but quickly grew tired of the repetition - same shops selling the same tourist trinkets, same restaurants serving the same food, and being continually pressured by the vendors. Obviously, not all of the shops and restaurants were like that, but enough were that it became tiresome.

A smorgasbord of every kind of food and sights!. This is a very interesting and fun Ave in Playa del Carmen. You will find all types of restaurants and bars, clothing stores and vendors... My only suggestion ( unless you LOVE the hot hot sun) is to go later in the day. It gets very hot there even though the beach is only a few blocks away.

You'll spend a lot of time here. I was pleasantly surprised by the shopping and dining options on Quinta Avenida. Its a nice mix of modern (H&M, Sephora, F21, MAC) and souvenir shops. The dining varies from Mexican cuisine to Italian. Playa Del Carmen specializes in seafood so you wont go wrong ordering that. I especially enjoyed Carboncitos (Mex) and Ula-Gula (Italian) On calle 12 off of Quinta you'll find the nightlife. The clubs definitely compete with each other in terms of who can bump the loudest. You can walk up and down the street and pop into which ever appeals to you. The crowds from bars sometimes spills out into the streets since open containers are no big deal here. I felt very safe walking through town. There is a police presence but unlike what you see on tv they were not there looking to harass travelers. Just maintain order. I truly cant wait to come back.

A lot to see, buy and dine!. Great walkway, lots of restaurants with a variety of cuisines, from casual breakfast to sophisticated dinning you can find it here! Lots of shopping to do, an lots of nothing to do, chill out and relax on any of the open bars along the street! Don't miss it!
You'll be bringing back home an additional lugguge with you :). EVERYTHING you might need, want or experience is there!! Just be prepared to be attacked by the locals trying to sell you things.
Fun. Having gun on THE strip rating and drinking with A lot alif louty american people, what else you want on spring Brake!Go party drink and use To much everyting is svaileble

Token visit. We like to spend some time in Playa del Carmen each time we come but over the past few years we are finding that is is becoming almost too commercialized as it has taken away from the uniqueness of 5th Avenue just off the beach area. Great place for people watching and if you like to shop lots of shops to fulfill almost everything you may be looking for. Bars are fun and watch for true Mexicans in restaurants for the authentic and good food.

BEAUTIFUL WALK STREET. This is the best street for take a walk, shop and eat in playa del Carmen, big name stores and great restaurants for all the budgets, many good hotels also in the sides of the streets and a lot of bars also.
souvenirs. fun shopping area. very friendly people. Its a tourist attraction you can pick up all your souvenirs here. Go early otherwise too hot. Or go on a cloudy day.
Charming nite walk. We walk a that street at night.We were two couples and we really enjoy it. girls were shopping an we were drinking ;) we had fun.
Love this area. Very nice to have so close to the resort where we stayed to easily spend some time off resort. Great mix of restaurants/bars and shopping.
main street in Playa del Carmen. Nice shopping and eating every day. A lot of people walking around, nice to observe the tourists and having a drink at some bar.

Love the night walks. The art was amazing at night, all the artists come out to display all their work. People happy and pleasant, totally safe to walk all night! People here don't pressure you into buying anything. They are just happy you are here to look and check out what they offer! Totally amazing atmosphere! Can't wait to go back!!

Toursity. This is one of the famous place everyone in Playa del Carmen tell you to go. However is a tourist trap. There are plenty of shops with very high prices on things that are worth 5 dollars. There are restaurants as well but nothing that is ethnic from the area. Many tacos are with store bought tortillas instead of home made ones. Not a place to find interesting souvenirs or "deals" that is for sure.

good shopping. nice shopping but the heat will catch you out by midday as the street is a heat trap shops are well stocked and the staff are very helpfull and the prices can be a bit steep just remember to haggle and you will get a good deal.

beware of being pestered . fifth avenue is along strip and is brilliant for shopping the only snag is that your being constantly nagged to go into shops by their workers and believe me they hate being told no
Perfect. Super Fun, great street vendors, restaurants, people watching, drinks, clubs, EVERYTHING! For way better deals, go up a block to 10 Avenida, but 5th is a perfect tourist spot!

Quinta Avenida is fun for a day or two. Quinta Avenida is the main drag in Playa del Carmen, there are souvenir shops, restaurants, cafes, etc. DO NOT GET THE CHURROS ON QUINTA AVENIDA - they were gross.
Great Experience. Good shopping, beginning to see the Malls take over which is disappointing. But still a great place to people watch to if that is your thing

It's lovable . Not that long to walk around but it's cheap and easy to negotiate with people over there, you can get any famous brand without spending tons.
It shows really well what Mexico has on it's whole. Culture, that includes, food, wardrobes, traditions, and souvenirs.. Who doesn't want to get some souvenirs.. Really beautiful.
Don't miss it
tourist mecca. tourist street, lots of souvenir shops and pricey restaurants. Not the real Mexico. only heard English spoken

More of the same. Lots of shops selling the usual tourist crap and american clothing and restaurants serving the usual food. Ganga and blow offered by street trawlers. Very few places selling quality arts and crafts but asking absorbent prices. Great for people watching as this strip is always busy.

5th Avenue. Have an outdoor/indoor mall - very impressive including Starbucks!
Outdoor vendors bit pushy, politely decline or just keep walking.

Food for the eyes and the restaurants are good too!. Very busy and very competitive among the merchants with the flurry of tourists. This is a fun place to visit and culturally appetizing but it doesn't offer as much of a bargain as one may think. It is a very safe area, no crime and clean --- buyer beware not to get pressured to buy that unique item.....that everyone else has 1+ as well. It's a street game - no harm, just gets old quick.
Walk in town. Nice and different boutiques and restaurants. Had a nice time with the fish therapy, little fishes that clean you feet and you have such a good relaxing feeling when it's over.

Touristy But Nice. There is more English spoken on this street than Spanish. Interesting for people-watching. The shops are mostly cheap souvenirs, much of it made in China. Compared to nearby areas, the restaurants are a bit pricey.

Lots of shops and restaurants . A must if in playa del carmen, cancun or riveria maya. There are a lot of fun specialty ahops and quite a variety of restaurants too. There is an area where the loud bars are also if you are into the loud techno bar scene.
Great restaurants and shopping. Worth visiting and spend some time having a drink or dinner. Great restaurants for any type of taste.

From A to Z you can find it all at Quinta Avenida. Hand rolled Cigars, lots of restaurants, Street performers, clubs, pubs, cigar shops,tequila shops,street vendors,american clothing stores, you can find it all at la quinta avenida..Don't be afraid to walk the well secured streets at this fabolous place, explore and dine in at one of its many restaurants and enjoy a little bit of Mexico.We visited this place on our way back to Cancun from Tulum, my wife told me to stop and quite frankly I wasn't feeling it since I was tired from snorkeling and walking the Tulum ruins, I'm glad we stopped and that we saw how vivid this place is, it almost reminded me of the Promenade at Santa Monica, California but a bit better..Where else can you find shops, souvenirs, close to a beautiful beach with Mariachis singing and top restaurants in the state? Well, visit Quinta Avenida and find out everything that this place has to offer...
Great ambiance. There were shops/bars/restaurants for all types/ages of people. We ate at a Camelia's - great Mexican food.
Fun night . WeLoved walking down fifth Ave and watching street performances.Playa keepsGrowing. WeHad dinner at Agua, overlooking the street. Wonderful service.

One bright spot. We stayed nearby for 3 weeks so it got old pretty fast. While humorous & fascinating at times, if you are tired or going from point A to point B, or trying to browse peacefully, it's definitely not happening! Some lines from vendors were pretty funny and a bit more original but mostly just repetitive & exhausting. Even training your gaze straight ahead is minimally successful & at times left me wanting to scream "leave me alone!" If you are foolish enough to actually look at something you leave yourself open to being hounded as you walk down the street. We Canadians are used to acknowledging people who address us, but we quickly learned to simply keep walking. There are occasional shops with something a bit different but it's an adventure just finding them & you are never free to enjoy browsing the street-side offerings. Many countries we've been to use similar vendor tactics as this but never have I seen so much of this squashed into one place where you must 'run the gauntlet' every time. Also, I have to ask, "why travel to a different country, only to shop in stores exactly like the ones at home?" because there were plenty of those too. The one bright spot was that it is an amazingly tolerant and unbiased place that seems to welcome everyone regardless of culture, ethnicity, lifestyle, etc. For that alone, it should be applauded.

Lots of fun, shops, and good restaurants. Fifth Avenue is the heart of the tourist district of Playa and is a must visit for anyone in Playa Del Carmen. It's a walking street full of restaurants and shops, and while the shop owners might be a bit of a pain hustling for your attention, it is a lively and fun atmosphere!

Delightful street to stroll. Even after numerous visits to Playa Del Carmen, it is always fun to stroll Quinta Avenida. The pedestrian street, not far from the beach, is filled with local shops, restaurants and lots of local vendors. It has great people watching and local color. We bought a beautifully made hammock at a very good price after bartering.

Don't stop unless you are seriously interested!. If you stop at one shop everyone else that sees you expects you to stop at their shop too. And they will be persistent as this is probably their livelihood. Expect to barter with the street vendors but many of the 'boutiques we found to be priced exorbitantly. ($80 USD best price for a simple cotton swimsuit coverup just 1 example). Though the prices in town for food, vanilla, and alcohol were considerably less in town than at our resort.

Interesting place. Quinta Avenida is a long street in Playa that is filled with bars, restaurants, clubs, souvenir shops and annoying men that insist they know you from your resort because they see a resort bracelet on your wrist. I did enjoy my visit there except for those overzealous shop workers
Fun but expensive. Just walking down the street it seems that every store owner wants you to come into their store. Sometimes they can be just a bit too pushy.

Excellent.. 5th avenue, as its also known has is about one and a half miles of shops, bars, cafes, boutique hotels and restaurants. It is very attractive and you can spend a very pleasant day/half day just browsing, and soaking up the ambience.There is a nice little church at the top, and from here you can watch the pretty impressive show where half a dozen men swing about 40 foot above the ground from ropes attached to a steel pole.However if intending to buy anything, please take note that the further inland you are away from "5th" the cheaper things are!!

It Has Everything You May Need. You want it? Quinta Avenida has it and more. Plenty of restaurants and shops. Hawkers trying to get you into their shops and using very creative lines to get your attention.Don't be fooled by "hey, remember me, I was your waiter at the resort" It is also great to see 5th Ave area north of Constituyenes developing and offering a different experience.

5th Ave Street Mall. The 5th Ave street Mall has really changed. Very modern now with all the big name US stores like Forever 21, Sephora, Great American Eagle etc. Unfortunately lost some of the old Mexico charm that it once had.

American shops taking over. This is a great place to find American items at American prices. There are also several Mexican shops - watch prices as they all sell pretty much the same thing at vastly differing cost. Mexican 'salesmen' are pretty pushy and over the top but that can be expected. This felt like a very safe area, and is an easy walk from any of the Playacar resorts.
Very Americanized. It has been 5 years since our last visit here and I was a bit surprised at the change in 5th Ave. I prefer the old 5th Ave.

Busy. Great spot to spend an afternoon,very busy though,the locals all want you in their shops,a polite no thank you and they will generally leave you alone,many spots to stop for a rest and drink.You can get the prices down from what they show,overall an interesting experience.

Lives up to its name - Famous!. Most refer to Quinta Avenida as the Famous 5th Avenue and the name doesn't disappoint! The mile long pedestrian walkway is now expanding even further north! Even though some of the large trinket shops repeat themselves there are still many gems to be found along 5th with bars restaurants, shops of all types (clothing, linens, boots, t-shirts, silver and many local handicrafts) . Don't be afraid to interact with the locals tempting you into their store - they are harmless and fun! My all time favorite is 2-4-1 cocktail place is Bip Bip (5th and Constituyentes)- great local dishes, soups and pizza. Sit at the bar and tell them Holly sent you and look for my picture! Also, there are many fun and good eateries on all the other side streets - step out of your comfort zone and try something new! For those who haven't visited Playa del Carmen in awhile there have been some changes - a new Americanized type mall went up a few years ago and Calle Corazon has changed completely. These changes have diminished the quaint sleepy little fishing town that Playa has been known for, but don't let that prevent you from returning or going for the first time! Playa del Carmen is still a jewel in the Mayan Riviera!
Great town!. The shop owners do call out to you to try to get you to come in to their store. Very safe town. Great night life!!
Great street to spend the time. The best street in Playa is the 5th avenue. Shops, restaurants, bars, music, everything! A few chilometers long to walk.

Interesting Shops. The town offers both unique & high-end shops. Silver is a "biggie" in Mexico. Look for pure silver(925) & be sure to "deal" with the vendors. Many of the quaint restaurants offer excellent tableside prepared food & delicious drinks.
Safe Stroll Day & Night. Food options in every price point and whether early morn or late into the evening felt safe....solo female traveler.

Great deals to be found.. Great Deal! You just have to pretend you don't see or hear those who yell at you to come into their shops. If you're Canadian, don't pay in US funds, pay in Pesos, you'll save on exchange.

Lots to see. There is always something happening on 5th Ave. Lots of deals but vendors can be pushy, you need to learn to say Gracias and continue walking. There are some unique opportunities to take pictures. Definitely a must see on your trip to Playa de Carmen.
Shopping. Got a lot of good deals. Some of the store owners get kind of obnoxious wanting you to buy from them but if you just keep walking they eventually stop.
Loving 5th. Fun had all week on 5th avenue!!!! Shopping though prices are not as negotiable as in Puerto Morales or other Places we've been in Mexico. Lots of Bars, nice happy hours, & restraunts.
All the clubs near. Nice road all the clubs are here. Do not buy your souvenirs here they will aske 10x the normal resell price.

Really good people watching. Great place to walk around, people watch and eat, drink beers/cocktails.
Was a little disappointed to see all the name brand shops slowly taking over the avenue, but there's still a healthy mix of local shops sprinkled in.

The soppe'rs dream. All kinds of restaurants and shops, we can shop just about anything, the price depends on how much pacience you have to bargain. It is almost overwhelming to shop, due to so much offer.

5th Avenue Tourist Area. Very busy shopping area with lots and lots of vendors selling jewellery, embroidered shirts, trips (snorkeling, scuba, turtles, Mayan ruins and more) and more. Lots of restaurants and bars. Good selection and friendly people - just a few blocks from the beach. A tourist area, very different from the rest of Playa del Carmen.
fun!. Fun afternoon shopping and eating. The beach is also justa short walk away. You really get a feel of Playa del Carmen.

A good place to walk, eat and drink. I liked Quinta Avenida for sitting on a terrace and watch people walking by. The stores in general have not very high quality goods. You will find better away from the strip.

Cheesy but Fun. This is a street that has blocked traffic and allows pedestrians to roam. And the do. Tons of them. The shops are overwhelmingly overpriced souvenirs. There were a few stores that had artwork but not enough of the handcrafts of the Mayan people. There were some good restaurants and lively bars. A great street for people watching.

By the end of the week I wanted to scream "leave me alone!". During the first part of our stay we were at a resort. During the second half of the week we stayed at a hotel on Quinta Avenida. At first it wasn't so bad. People wanting you to come inside their shops. Asking if my husband wants to spoil me with jewelry, asking if we want Cuban cigars or weed. One day we were walking along and a guy walked up to us and said, "hi! I'm Jose your waiter from last night. Do you remember me?" I picked up on this scam quickly but my husband said "yes." The guy said, "I'm at my mother's shop here come in and take a look." I said no. We walked maybe 20 feet and another guy said the SAME thing to us. Beware! They talk so loud to you and follow you. It's sometimes hard to have a conversation walking down the street. And they won't take no for an answer. Then sometimes will make nasty remarks after you walk by. After a week of this it got old and I got so tired of it. I was on vacation. I just wanted to walk down the street in peace and have an uninterrupted conversation with my husband. I would definitely not recommend staying on Quinta Avenida because when you walk out your hotel door you're confronted with it immediately. There are some nice shops along the way but for me all of the other shop owners made it frustrating to walk down the street.

nightly9. 5th Ave Stretches from two blocks south of Juarez to 36th street. Streets in Playa by by twos, ie 2nd north, 4th, 6th etc an Avenues by 5. 5th, 10th, a 15th. Information, Walmart is on 30th Ave and 12th st. No vehicles allowed on 5th tho they can cross it on the streets. It is the malecon of Playa a day is strolled nightly by almost all who stay in playa, the locals, and tourists from the Rivera. Restaurants and bars abound, Mexican craft stores, silver shops, two new American style malls, street very does and musicians, artists, and about everything you can imagine. Information, restaurant prices go down as the Avenue number goes up. Cheaper on a quiet 15th then on 5th and cheaper yet on either 30th or 40th then on 15th. We were there this time for 15 nights and walked it nightly but only partial on the one rainy night. Always stopped at McDonald's down by Juarez c or ice cream cones or sundaes. You might think it is to much, UT each night you will discover a new something. For sure.

Amazingly clean and looked after,. Cabs at every corner...very polished white with Aqua blue trim and posted fares. Great by day different by night...every kind of restaurant you could want...and now shopping centers with big name labels.

Tourist area only. This is not the real Mexico nor what I like to see. The avenue was crowded, busy and pricey compared to all other areas in PDC. But the restaurant selection is great, food and drinks pricey , but if you are here for a week why not. Go one book to 10 Ave, food and drink about 2/3rds the price.

Very aggressive vendors and the high end shops are expensive. It has changed a lot in ten years! There are lots of high end shps. There are stll the locals flogging their goods but they are very aggressive. You have to be rude and ignore them completely.

Ok, not impressed. . Don't recommend it. Basically a zoo of high pressure shopping. If you want trinkets and souvenirs, then ok, but beware. Shop at opposite ends of street and side streets for best prices.

Just go with the flow and prepare to bargain. Fifth Ave. in Playa del Carmen is filled with tourist shops, bars and restaurants. Some of the shops will bargain with you and others stick to their posted prices; generally if the prices are posted they are less likely to bargain. There are also a few upscale stores such as Hugo Boss, Swarovski, and Victoria's Secret some of which are in very modern three story mall type building. The restaurants range from taco shops to some nice Mexican style food and obviously sea food being only a block from the beach. There's even a Krispy Kreme at the south end.The vendors are generally friendly and upbeat and there spiels range from "Come in, we have the cheapest prices" to Come on in and let me rip you off." True, that was one of the pitches we heard.All in all a typical shopping area you might find in any Mexican tourist area. Or for that matter in Jamaica, Bali, even some European cities.

Keep a Cheerful Attitude. Like most places, it is all in what you make of it. Personally, I like to haggle, enjoy browsing and looking and I loved it! I wish there was more variety in the "local" shops as there certainly was a lot of repetition in what was offered. Evening was great as the lights, music, etc. seemed to be amplified. If you get tired of looking and buying(?) you can always stop for a gelato or meal and enjoy the people watching. I'm ready to go back. :-)

A treat for the Senses. Strolling down 5th avenue is a treat for your senses, there are so many beautiful, exoctic, local and colourful things to see or buy. And there are also many, many restaurants, cantinas and pubs so the smell of wonderful food is everywhere. Shopping or just strolling you do not want to miss this pleasant experience.
Shopping Mexico style. Just a quaint shop in an area that has similar places to explore and slowly browse. A good out of the sun activity.
Typical commercial street. Rather boring row blocks long of stores selling tourist chachtzkes. I did not care for it as they were all the same and tourist trappy.

Most Charming street ever! . This foot traffic only street goes for miles and offers everything you could be looking for. The ONLY downfall is that the sales people are very pushy so you have to be able to say no (I loathe pushy salesmen!) Also, don't be shocked when you're offered drugs many many times "Hey man, wanna get high? Weed, blow, something else maybe"....they all say the same thing. With that being said, we felt very safe there though!

Fun experience!. Block after block of shops, restaurants, galleries. Pedestrian avenue. Great for a stroll in the evening. Be ready for the "barkers" out front of the stores hawking their wares! All part of the fun!

Turistic, crowded, mainly souvenir shops and restaurants. Lot of souvenir shops, selfie sticks sellers, excursion sellers, hair braiding, massage offerings, resturants and cafes. Typical tourist street / area. If you want to have neon-colour plastic sombrero, t-shirt with text or some "mayan culture" inspired souvenier, you probably find it from here. Large choise of different restaurants, take your time and check menues and atmosphere, there is really good ones and extremely bad ones, great service and lousy service.

LOVE!. UGH! You MUST go!! This place is super live. You must go to Fat Tuesdays the staff is awesome. We had such a blast. Eat at Karens, super yummy. Music is Americanized sad to say but if you ask them to change it, they will.

Great place to walk!. This is basically like a little downtown area.. there are plenty of shops and little cafe style restaurants.. there's a starbucks somewhere there and also high end restaurants.. this is a great place to come on a non activity day.

Choices!. Fifth avenue CAN be overwhelming and annoying, but it's awesome to have the choice of walking and shopping it when you're in the mood for such things. Many destinations have little or no opportunity to shop, dine and club and can be BORING. Not in Playa...fifth ave offers such a variety of wonderful restaurants, clubs, pubs, bars and shopping outlets. We love it.

We were hungry so we ate!. We at this taco place. First we were seated then we waited and waited and waited and Finally a waiter came to see if we wanted to order food which we did and we ordered our drinks as well because they hadn't come before to ask if we wanted anything. then the food and drinks came lots of food on platters and brought guacamole and chips which was really good. Not a bad place, just getting food and drinks was very slow.Wasn't busy in there either so can't blame it on other tourists!
Go place to stay. It is nice to walk and sit and take a coffee...there are a lot od options to eat o drink. We recommend casa del agua...casa mediterranea

Long pedestrian street full of shops, restaurants and tourists. Long pedestrian street full of shops, restaurants and tourists near the beach. Worth visiting at least 1 time. After that, it's more of the same. There are many excellent restaurants to sample, including Mayan cuisine such as the Yaxche. You should also visit the 10th Avenue (one block away - avenues are numbered in multiples of 5).

Getting busier every year. Queens Avenida is a lot of fun miss getting busier and busier every year. We enjoyed getting off the beaten path a little bit and some of the better restaurants are not located on fifth Avenue

La Quinta avenida. I love la Quinta avenida lots of shops and little restaurants they also have a huge mall. The area felt really safe, and also very convenient since it was a 2 minute walk from my hotel.

Touristy yet quaint. One of the main reasons we purchased a timeshare in Playa del Carmen. Shops, restaurants, etc. Also a great place to people watch! Don't forget the side streets as well as there are shops and restaurants located on those streets as well.
Nice day shopping.. We spent a good 4 hours walking and shopping. They have everything one might need: restaurants, bars, souvenirs, shoes, clothing, sunglasses and jewelry.

What choice do you have?. When in Playa del Carmen, you HAVE to visit 5th Avenue! I mean it's THE place for shopping, whether for local hand-made items or high-end stores like Michael Kors, they've got it all. Not to mention restaurants and the beach just a block away.We hadn't been to Playa in 10 years and wow it has surely grown to almost 40 blocks on 5th Avenue alone. So be prepared for lots and lots of walking! Unfortunately, we didn't find much in the way of good food and service at most restaurants. The best food was off the beaten path, off of 5th Avenue on the side streets going into the old town. I would suggest exploring those streets instead for authentic food that's cheaper priced and so much more flavorful.And after almost a week walking 5th Avenue, we were exhausted from the constant "harrassment" from the shop owners to get us to buy something. It's very wearing and starts to get on your nerves after awhile. A good place to relax is in the Plaza where you can watch Mayan shows going on nearly night and day but expect them to walk around with a hat looking for tips.

Busy, interesting street . We knew when we were going to Playa Del Carmen that one of the must do things is a day spent on 5th Ave. It was a fun, interesting day to see how Mexico has become Americanized. Lots of different people and places to see. Great shopping for everything from souvenirs to brand name outlet shopping. If you are looking for a deal get a little further away on a back street as the further from 5th you are the better the prices. All the haggling gets a bit much after a while but if that's your thing it's totally the place to be. I wish I had kept count of how many times I heard "almost free" lol

5th Ave Playa Del Carmen. You become immersed in the Mexican life. Bartering for goods, great restaurants, people watching, high end stores to the small market stalls. All kinds of goods to barter for. Just know what you are looking for to get your best bargain. Walked on 5th Ave every night. Just grand!!!

Fun shopping experience. We spent and afternoon shopping on 5th Avenue on one of the days that wasn't great weather wise. There a ton of cute shops and we found great souvenirs for our family. Ate a great restaurant. Very fun atmosphere!

Great place to eat and drink. I like the vibe of the street lined up with shops, bars, restaurants, touts, souvenir shops and tour kiosks.You'll find any cuisine you desire, lots of places to enjoy drinks and generally great touristy vibe.

people watching 101. love the strip for the people watching. always something going on as there are hundreds of shops an eats. if your into people watching grab a cervaza an watch the show. I will admit some of the merchants do get in your face at times. go enjoy.

Buzz. Only if you enjoy buzz
Streets, stores and very good restaurants...
Good if you need to buy something or wants to see people
But if you are looking for relaxation, this is not the place

So many new stores. We've been coming to Playa del Carmen for many years now and have always enjoyed strolling down the 5th avenue to see all of the local stores and vendors however this year we noticed a big difference. There are hardly any small handicraft stores, instead they have been replaced by huge mega malls and modern designer stores. It may attract a younger crown but for us it has ruined the authentic mexican atmosphere that the 5th avenue used to have!

Everything from Foot Sucking Fish to Winter Coats !!. Always entertaining, especially if you like people watching.We like to walk to the web cam, call our Kids and Grandkids and have a little video chat.Almost to many Restaurants, Lots of things to buy, and right now the exchange rate makes everything cheap.We've been to Mexico about 17 Times Mostly Cozumel. This time we stayed in Playa, right off 5th.We will definitely return.

Always a lot of fun!. Every day we "wobble" up and down Quinta Avenida. There is always so much to see. Many shops selling the usual stuff but also many places where you can find that perfect, unique, something special. Watch out for the "I know you" hahaha...we just get creative and play along with the guys. They work long hours every day, so they need to be creative. It's actually a lot of fun.

Not to be missed. Firth Avenue provides an experience for everyone. Quaint shops are interspersed with name brand stores. If you are not interested in shopping, the people watching is facinating. Quality dining abounds, The beach off of 5th Avenue Is a beautiful. Allow plenty of time to soak in the cultural experience. I never tire of the 5th Avenue experience. PS. Wear comfy shoes to allow for walking on uneven pavement.

Full Of Culture Avenue . Sincerely I do enjoy long walks around the Quinta, the smell of the food of the restaurants is in every street and is constantly changing, with about everything to shop for every taste and need. There's always people showing their costumes or artistic skills.
Tequila plus wife = silver purchase . Always an entertaining walk for us down any part of this street. Good places to eat, drink, shop and enjoy the playa vibe either at night or during the day.
Relaxed walk without cars.. Nice pleasant walk. If you like trinkets and shopping this will get you out of your resort for a short diversion.

A great place to people watch!. Love walking early in the morning before all the people start coming out. You see all the locals going to work and the starting. Gives you a different perspective on the hustle and bustle of the afternoon and evening hours. Still fun to sit and watch the crowds walk the street and shop the shops.
For every day walk!. We love La Quinta Avenida, we walk up and down all the time, you can find almost everything, gelato, great food, amazing shopping, long walks...

Not Impressed with Playa del Carmen. Dirty and Poor Town, and very congested.
Cozumel seemed cleaner and more sedate, if that is what you want?

Otherwise known as Fifth Avenue - Great shopping & Dining. Lots of unique places to shop and dine. This district has changed a lot since 2014, the strip has become very modern with many state side shops and many of the traditional stores are gone. This was saddening to us. We also missed not having all the street artists. I wish this feature would be brought back.
Night life. If your looking for night life options in Playa del Carmen this is it. There are so many options to choose from as to where to dine, have a drink or simply dance.

Good vibe. Enjoy the walks down 5th ave. great place to people watch and get those souvenirs. Higher end merchant also available. It does get tiresome getting asked for a taxi, tour,massage or entering a store but I get the highly competitive market. The bartering is fun too and a good lesson for the kids.

Growing . When we started coming to 5th Ave it was about 10-12 blocks but now you will be able to spend the entire day on 5th. Vendors can be aggressive but don't let that stop you, once you are past Calle 6 they really scale it back.

Disappointed in how Americanized and Commercialized it has become. I was charmed by la Quinta Avenida as I breezed through it on my way to visit the Mayan Ruins in 2002. I was very eager to visit it at leisure on our recent January 2016 trip to the Mayan Riviera. I was looking forward to strolling the Avenue and admiring the quaint wares from the shopkeepers in this little fishing village.Needless to say, I was EXTREMELY disappointed by how commercialized and Americanized this area has become. It has lost its charm and pull. I'm sure there is a fun and active nightlife here, but I had no interest in sticking around to find out. The restaurant where we ate was okay, but nothing to remember. I was horrified to see the giant flashy two story shopping area featuring Sephora, BCBG, etc. We were screamed at and accosted from every direction by merchants trying to get us to visit their shops. The charm of Playa del Carmen is gone and I am truly sad that it has turned into such a place.

Must do. 5th Avenue has a little of everything - food, shopping, entertainment, culture. From small souvenir shops, corner taco stands, chain restaurants, commercial merchandise, dance clubs, laid-back bars - cheesie or not - there's something for everyone. The scene offers something different during the day and again at night, as the atmosphere changes. Like it or not, it's still one of those places you should experience at least once.

Fun shops and great restaurants with an up tempo. The Quinta Avenida is the mainstay feature of Playa del Carmen.The vibe here is really up beat and you can find great shops with virtually anything you might want to buy as well as countless interesting restaurants and bars. At the end of ther Quinta Avenida (which is pedestrian only) you come to the beach and many additional beach clubs and restaurants.Quinta Avenida is the signature location in "Playa" and best of all--very safe--even (e.g.) on A Friday night 8 to midnight!

Anything you want!. If you are staying near the Playa Del Carmen area you will want to take the opportunity to spend a day on 5th Ave. You will find anything you want here - food, clothes, souvenirs, tours, car rentals, great people watching and a fantastic stretch of beach running a block away from, and parallel to, 5th Ave.
good for shopping. If you don't like to be called Mr. Wiskers or Mr Harley this may not be the place for you. There is high end shopping and low end souvenier shopping.

Good soup. I have been here twice. I have had the beef dinner and the bean soup. Very good food. The service is excellent and the Mexican band was great. There was nothing overwhelming, it was quite comfortable.
Fun stroll with shops, cafes, kiosks. Fifth Avenue is a wonderful way to get some exercise while perusing dozens of shops and restaurants.
Love the vibe!. We love staying so close to 5th Avenue. Great for walking, people watching, getting a latte or gelato ir a Mexucan meal.

A strolling tour. We enjoyed the wide variety of dining and shopping options on "Fifth Avenue" in Playa Del Carmen on this visit. We soaked in the local flavor and dined one night at Blue Lobster (delicious!).

Downtown of Playa de Carmen. Im not a huge fan of nightlife or shopping - the two main atractions of Quinta Avenida, but these blocks can have its charm. I found one amazing Art Gallery specialized in Catrinas and other traditional form or traditional arts that worth been seen - or even bought if you have the money for. Run, but really run from the super souvenirs market it can be minimum 2x more expensive to my last count 28x more than traditional stores. Is a place where you can find restaurantes from all over, including Canada. My friends went to los Tabarnacos and loved to eat poutine. They have one good vegetarian restaurant - 100% natural - and the falafels are incredible.Quinta Avenida is good and is sunny and raining, is near the crowded beach and beach clubs.... Walking on the beach you will certainly find a wedding going on...

Fun street of shopping on the water!. Enjoyed this popular street. Full of traditional Mexican souvenir stores plus restaurants and higher-end boutiques. Shop keepers can be pushy verbally so be prepared to ignore them. Wish they had more street food vendors-they only had dessert ones. Bartering ok on street purchases but not on store items. Beach is 1 block away. ATM's conveniently located. Parking lot not too hard to find. You'll pay for this but it is inexpensive.

So commercislized now - not fun anymore!. Since the cruise shipos started to come to Playa, 5th Avenue (Quinta Avenida) is not the same. It used to be small mom-n-pop store on top of each other - now it is all commercial - Diamond International, H&M, Aeropostale, and other "chain" places. The charm is gone!!!! There are a few mom-n-pop places, and they are worth the trip, but the whole street is now just one chain on top of the next. Playamart is still the place to check out - but their deals are not the same anymore!

Just Say "No Thanks" And Smile. We love Fifth Ave and each time we visit Playa Del Carmen the shops have changed and the streets have grown and become busier. If you don't want to go into a shop just say "no thanks' but stop and chat and get to know some of the local people who run the shops, they are all lovely!There are so many places to eat and drink and lots of places you can sit on the beach. The locals have there own version of Fifth Ave but we've not been to it.

Loosing it's charm. Love walking 5th avenue in the evenings. It's one of the reasons we stay in Playacar, the fact that we can walk to 5th in the evening and go for a drink or just people watch is a bonus to our vacation. However, we have noticed over the last 2 years that 5th avenue is slowly loosing it's charm to ultra modern high end boutiques that sprout high fashion shops that we have at home. Why would I shop at Zaxe in Mexico when I have one 5 minutes from home. I go on vacation to see something different and 5th is slowly loosing it.

Great variety. A very fun shopping experience. Not as hard sell as some other places we've been in Mexico. Go in the evening after its cooled down. Lots of bars and restaurants to choose from and tons of shopping opportunities from made in Mexico hand crafted to made in China tourist junk.
Great stroll through avenue. Lots of fun strolling down the avenue taking in the colorful sights and people at night. Safe, no trouble with begging, etc.

Good place to people watch. Okay it is a tourist trap and you won’t see many local people but grab a seat on a bench with a drink and food bought from a shop from outside the area and watch the world go by.

Was OK to me... just OK.. Beware of people approaching you and telling you that they were your waiter last night, and then using that to sell you something. The guy got our hotel completely wrong. You will be harassed numerous times walking down the street. That all being said, we ventured there twice and just kept saying "no thanks".

Fantastic. Lovely, lively street with shops, restaurants, bars... You can find everything here, delicious food, authentic Mexican handcraft, souvenirs and well known brands too. This is the heart of Playa del Carmen.

second trip to 5th. So this was our second trip to 5th ave. Once again you have to deal with people barking at you all day but that's part of the deal, we like to go to playa mart and buy there its a little more money but its a less hassle. Good food and drinks lots of interesting things to see and buy just be careful everything in mexico is a gamble and most of the silver is fake just like most of the "Cuban" cigars are junk. The beach here is beautiful. Its easy to find a cab to go anywhere from here too. Worth a visit

Great street for eat, drink and shopping. We stayed in quinta avenida, it is excellent because you can any type of food you want there, a lot of bars and restaurants. You can also do some shopping, souvenirs, clothing, pharmacies, one big nice mall.It is a long pedestrian avenue.If you stayed around there make sure there is no club close to your hotel or apartment since it can be very loud.
Amazing experience !!!. Absolute MUST is Playa Del Carmen. Big or small, they have it all on 5th Avenue in Playa Del Carmen.

Not the same as it used to be. We visited this area in Playa Del Carmen for an afternoon/evening to see some of the sights we visited 10 years ago and do some shopping. It is amazing how much this area has changed and became loud and crowded. It used to be enjoyable to wander around the street and visit the shops before heading to the beach. Maybe it is because I have gotten older, but I found it too commercialized and people everywhere trying to sell all the same things for prices that seemed unreasonable. After finding this disappointing, we headed to the beach and found it to be crowded and not in the best shape. Likely damaged in a past storm. We were eager to leave Playa Del Carmen this time as any remaining charm appears to be gone.

Fun for all times of day. . Quinta avenida was perfect my fur as a solo traveler. I was able to stroll, shop, eat and drink safely every day of my stay. It is always busy and bright. Yes thee are annoying vendors but they just ask questions and if you can't be bothered you keep going - no big deal. Each part of the avenue has a different flair so you can vary your experience, from traditional to trendy. Make sure to start out by senior frogs. I missed that section and didn't find it until I was leaving. That's the area with the cool beachy vibe.

Place to go if you like being hassled. You cannot walk a few feet without shop vendors hounding you to come into their store, look at their items, etc. You have to keep saying no over and over again. If you should venture into one of the shops they hound you to no end and you can't wait to get out. Not my cup of tea.
Zoo Parade. Quinta is a combination of bars, tacky shops, and now huge American shopping malls. There are still a couple of good restaurants stuck in here and there, but this is Spring Break central.

Shop till you drop . This is a long long strip of shops and restaurants some good some bad every few feet you will be hounded and whistled at hollered at joked at anything to get your attention and once you make eye contact they try to sucker you in to there scams and there shop been here 2 weeks and the same people same places every day still try and ask you the same thing over and over and over they dont give up not at all
I LOVE this street. When I think of Playa, I think of the Mamitas, the Blue Lobster and 5th Ave. I can't wait to go back! This one street has it all... shopping, bars, restaurants...

Great artwalk CAMINARTE on Thursday. Walking on the 5th avenue on Thursday is amazing. You can have dinner and at the same time enjoy the artwalk between 24 and 35 street ...dont miss the oportunity to see local art.

Watch your wallet!!. Quinta Avenida has everything you can image. Everything from high-end stores to dumpy little stores, bars, restaurants. Money exchanges are on every corner. Everybody is selling Cuban cigars but buyer beware. And everyone wants YOUR MONEY!!! I was offered "weed", cocaine and even hookers!! Not once but a few times and so were my sons and son-in-law!!

Something you MUST do when in the Playa del Carmen area!. 5th Avenue is a lively fun walk that is approximately 3 miles filled with eateries, bars, shops and color! Wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to but something. There are great inexpensive shops and lively high end shops. Almost every food cuisine is available and of coarse, Authentic Mexican. Without doubt it is something every visitor must do. Go early afternoon, grab lunch, lay on the beach, then walk 5th Avenue for dinner or Margaritas and nachos. Enjoy!

Fifth Avenue has it all. Fifth has it all. Great restaurants and bars. Shopping for anything you desire (legal or otherwise), scam artists and pickpockets. You'll generally pay about twice what you'd pay a bluck away. Have fun, but be careful.

Make sure to experience it!. We walked 5th Ave on a Saturday afternoon and it was very nice! Never felt uneasy or unsafe! Very safe!!!! Lots of places to eat, shop, and drink at! Lots of local things as well!

Rodeo Drive Meets Cancun. I LOVE Quinta Avenida. It's the only place you can go to find World-Class shopping right next to WILD night clubs and local souvenir shops. You definitely have to keep your wits about you here because everyone knows everyone and they all want the same thing: your money.Keep your friends close and walk confidently wherever you want. You'll have to ignore everyone calling to you. If you can handle it, you will find THE best shopping - truly unique things to commemorate your trip, great food and some of the most insane night clubs on the planet.I definitely think of this place as a party scene after dark... but it can be more low-key and family friendly during the day. It's busy and it's getting more and more modern (sadly)... but I still think it's worth the trip.

Just ok. Not what I expected. Thought it would be a bit more quaint from pictures and travel guides. "Quiet fishing town"... it is not! It was very Americanized in some areas, crowded and everyone is a salesmen looking to make a $. Glad I went but if I were to go back to Playa del Carmen I would like to wonder a few blocks off Quinta Avenida and avoid the tourist traps.

Great for shopping. Lots of trinkets to buy, some good finds and good restaurants. Expect vendors to call out to you from time to time, trying to get you into their stores. Runs parallel to the ocean so you can just pop over if you like.
long, long walk with much to see. such a colourful area of Playa, stores, people, food, nightlife, a casual way to spend a day when you dont want to do anything...

Fun day trip. There are definitely some places along the strip that are better than others. We were dropped off by our shuttle bus at 5th and 30th. We made the mistake of going north first, where we were overwhelmed by the amount of people approaching us to buy things from them. On our way back however, to the south of this intersection it is much nicer! We were approached by far less people and the atmosphere was much cleaner and enjoyable. If you are looking to go shopping, this is a good place to go, but don't expect to find any great deals here. It's a touristy area and you will pay prices according to that. The beach here is gorgeous though and definitely worth checking out!
Walk it. No mattet what. When in Playa, one must walk/stroll this street. The best time is around 7pm. This is where most of the restaurants and night life is at.

Overwhelming but will meet every need. This was my first time to Playa deal Carmen and I had read much about Quinta Avenida so we had to check it out. Be ready to ignore people or just be really good at saying no. Because I speak both Spanish and English fluently this was a little easier for me, but if you can't say no - you should not shop here. There was a LOT to choose from, from cute boutiques, specialty coffee/tea shops to jewelry stores and "artesanias" which are Mexican souvenir shops. The nice thing is that most of the shops are open until 10:45 p.m. We didn't eat dinner here - we went off the beaten path to an authentic taco restaurant - but it seems there are plenty of choices here. We did stop at a tea shop for coffee and cookies in the afternoon and then went to the chocolate cafe for dessert.
Center of PDC. Shopping, eating, drinking, people watching, it's a hubbub of activity from morning till after midnight. The place to go, see, and be seen!

Anything but a quiet shopping street.. After spending time in a quiet fishing village it came as a shock to walk this street. You can hardly take two steps without someone asking you to go in their store, take a massage, buy gold and silver, take a trip,step in their restaurant. It is the not the kind of place you can take a quiet stroll and look in the window of a shop or wander around a store. Everybody is out to make a dollar and they will not leave you alone. The trick is not to look anyone in the eyes and don't talk to anyone then they will leave you to continue your walk. There are many restaurants and bars and even more stores selling everything from tequila to t- shirts. If you are in Playa it is a must even if you don't buy anything.

Great shopping and bargains. Went parasailing as well.. Yes everyone will bug to shop with them or do this or that tour but you eventually get used to it and ignore them. The more modern look stores I would avoid as the prices seem to be higher and they would haggle. You would get your best deals on the little shops and side streets where they will haggle with you. Always have pesos as you will get on average about 20% more for your money. Or if they accept credit card so that because you will get top exchange rate. If you want to go parasailing I just walked up to someone soliciting some tour and asked where I could parasail they walked me to beach and within 20 mins I was in the air after they took me out to a boat on a jet ski. Even haggled them down to 55.00 per person to parasail which I thought was a decent deal.
Packed open air shopping mall. Not a very Mexican experience at all. Has that Can-Cun / Miami feeing some might enjoy but that has definitely set the track for the town to sink it's own greed.
Quinta Avenida. Wide avenue lined with shops and restaurants and a thousand things more, enjoying walking and looking, very good places, great spot to barter.

great shopping area. great little place where you could find all that you want. with the exchange of the dollar, there wasn't any great deals to be found. lots of sunglass huts, starbucks, and other local vendors. the cigar peddlers are also your local contraband dealers, so beware.
Awesome!. Great atmosphere, fun waiters, great food, on our this of top spots in Playa. We live here 3 months a year and this is a new treasure for us !

Always something happening.. 5th Ave....where there is always something going on. Would definitely recommend going here. We went in the daytime for shopping and souvenirs. Very safe. At nightime we had drinks and food and listened to the music. A lot of fun.

Lots of Shops. You know those cartoons where the scenery repeats behind a running character? Quinta Avenida reminded me of this. You'd think the local merchants might strive for unique identities, but every three blocks or so, everything tends to repeat. You'll see the same statue, the same ceramic Mayan calendar, the same beaded horse in a nearly identical shop three blocks away. Don't get me wrong... I wouldn't call it 'bad', but how many dust collectors can you stuff in your suitcase? The restaurants and shops we liked best tended to be a block or two off of the Avenida. At least it seemed reasonably safe.

Fave Spot. We have been here a few times, and while it is "touristy" it's such a great place to grab a drink and people watch, we always visit at least once! There is great shopping from tourist trinkets to high end name brands and everything in between. Restaurants galore and spas in between for massages. The best price we found was $50 for 2 x 70min down beside the ferry terminal. We were there this month when the carnavale parade came thru and then had dinner at Senor Frogs. Had waffles/crepes at a vendor which were delish and bought some overpriced clothes at a surf shop but it's all part of the experience! You should not miss out on an afternoon/evening here. The lights everywhere in the evening are beautiful!!

Everyone is hustling! . Fun to walk and people watch and shop. Lots of excellent restaurants to enjoy. We were there for Carnival and that was a blast! Shop owners all want you to come in but a simple no gracias will suffice.
Nice place. 5th ave is a very nice place to spend your day and night (till 11:00 pm). There is a lot of restaurants and stores.If you like to shop it will be a good place to visit.

Lively and fun. The only street in playa del Carmen with bars, restaurants and shops. It is much better than cancun, here at least you can have a drink on a terrace or walk on a pedestrian street. Though playa del Carmen is getting build up and has several towers under construction. And the water used to be turquoise...
Feb in carribean. Entertaining walk with lots of shops, typical Mexican things as well as upscale American shops. Food is much much less expensive the further away you are from here.

All those shoppings centers destroyed playa. It is something really personal.Some people would love, me not.The beach in Playa del Carmen is awful as it is completely full with buildings.The city is full of pleaces to do shopping so maybe your wives would love it
lots of hagglers. be aware.. Just be prepared to ignore a lot of people. They are relentless. Its pretty mainstream now. Not authentic Mexico.

A place to show off. This avenue is full of restaurants and shops. Its very charming to the point I just wanted to go up and down just watching people passing by or the buildings. The atmosphere is so relaxed you can be whoever you want. Nobody seems to be paying attention .

Good to see. If u have gone so far then might as well go here once. It is all high end designer stores bunched together. If you are looking for local stuff this is not the best place. But yes experience it once for sure.

Be prepared to spend $$$. You're walking down the most tourist area in playa Del Carmen so prices for restaurants will be more expensive in this area. If you want to dine at a cheaper place, then walk 2-3 blocks away from this place. There's endless shops and tourist stands so you will be bombarded with sales every five seconds. People there are trying there to sell, sell, sell and they will bargain with you all day if they have to. Fun place to walk around but it gets old.

Good shopping and strolling. First time in the area and were advised to check out this area. Lots of shops and restaurants to choose from all down this avenue. It was a little redundant after awhile and very touristy, but we enjoyed window shopping. Quick taxi ride from any of the resorts.

Lots to see and do. The shopping trip has lots to see and do. But, a lot of the shops carry the same thing as another shop down the street. So, don't be in a hurry when shopping - take your time and find a deal. Also, make sure you take some of the side streets - there are some amazing little shops just off the main shopping strip.
Loved the shopping and dining!. So much to see and do here! Shopping and dining is great! We could easily spend three days here and still not see everything!

Nice shopping and walking street in Playa Del Carmen. It is nice shopping district with shops of different kinds - from big mall high end to little boutique and gift shops. The environment is joyful. Great place to shop or just to relax and watch people and life.

Great shopping . Great shopping and nightlife and day life on the wonderful Fifth Avenue I felt like a celebrity just like everyone else being pestered to buy things but it was fun and we bought a lot

Bustling gem in Playa. While extremely touristy, and lots of US shopping chains, this avenue was quite fun to explore and go out in on Superbowl Sunday. I was actually quite surprised to see this place, after driving through Playa a few times. I didn't realize it had a walkable street with lots of good shopping and fun things to explore.

Fun place to be!. We travelled to Playa del Carmen for a few days on February 4, 2016. This was our first time there. We enjoyed strolling up and down Quinta Avenida and browsing the many shops along the way. Some of the vendors are a little pushy trying to get you to come into their store, but if you just say no gracias (no thank you) they generally don't bother you any more. There are also some great restaurants with delicious food at reasonable prices. La Vagabunda and Micaleas were the ones we liked.
Awful. Avoid, avoid, avoid. Tacky, terrible, the shops and the food not interesting. Go two blocks further north and the food improves drastically.

Something for everyone. A trip here is worth your time if you haven't experienced it yet. Even if it is just to accomplish a specific task like replace a lost phone charger or get some pesos. You will probably find it entertaining in other ways too.

tourist trap. Please dont come here thinking you will see the real mexico outside your hotel. This is a typical tourist trap that gets worse each year. Lots of restaurants, but in my experience food at the hotels I stayed in has been better, so not even worth a venture for that reason. If you absolutely need to bring back a souvenir this street may fit the bill though

Playa del Carmen Shopping on Fifth Avenue. A must for PdC visitors who like to shop. Twenty+ blocks of shops, both large commercial properties (ie Victoria's Secret :-) ) and small Mom & Pop operations. Something for everyone and most will bargain with you, something my wife loves! There are some places that get a bit "pushy" to try to get you into their establishment but a "no-thanks" usually works. There are also some great eating places. Recommend a visit late morning to early afternoon, and it will take that long if you want to see it all...

Noisy fun. Except in early morning,when it's a peaceful,pleasant walk.We happened to be here for Carnevale parades each evening.Fun to watch from our balcony.made me want to toss beaded necklaces.The shop/information stand owners can be a bit much (trying to be nice.I heard "Let me rip you off"and"Hey,Mr Clean/Mr Whiskers" more than I ever needed/wanted to.really)
Beautiful traditional art. Definitely a must!!! It was like a beautiful market set up. Lots of shops and friendly people. Great place for souvenirs

Fun and Entertaining. There is lots of walking here, with many sites to see along the way! Lots of bar and restaurant options await you here, along with many shopping locales (which are rather pricey considering the state of the current Canadian dollar). We felt very safe here and enjoyed soaking in the sites and local atmosphere!

A must do, but prepare for the onslaught . Good for souvenir shopping and eating but little else. If you're staying at an all inclusive, hide your band under a watch or bracelet. Many guys will try to convince you that they were your waiter at the hotel.

Must stroll at least once every visit to Playa.. The only reason this review is not rated a 5, is the constant and sometimes aggressive pedlars, making the walk sometimes feel like walking a gauntlet. That aside, this 2 km stretch of partially shaded pedestrian-only street of shops and restaurants is a lot of fun to explore. It DOES NOT feel at all dangerous or creepy, and generally everyone is friendly. Great selection of restaurants, but restaurant prices drop dramatically only a few blocks west of this strip, like at Papa Charlies and Cafe Orange near Avenida 25 & Calle 30, which have equally good quality food.

Great shopping and food. This is definitely the hub of Playa Del Carmen. We found terrific shopping and excellent food. My only negative comment is about the vendors along 5th pushing tours. They are rude, don't take no for an answer and make cat calls. My daughter is only 16 and it was disgusting the way the men treated her. A few even came up and touched her and asked for hugs - in front of me!

Americanized Shopping. Did some shopping here; however, I felt as though I was shopping in the USA. It is connected to the famous 5th Ave shopping, which has everything from your basic souvenir shirts, mugs, shot glasses to homemade goods. There are restaurants up and down the street. The people are very pushy at many of the places and they try very, very hard to lure you into their shops. However, it's a fun experience.

Lovely people all around . Gorgeous downtown to stroll for hours!Super safe with police officers at every corner and smiley faces all around. Quinta avenuda has everything you need: food, bars, clubs, gift shops, music, atm, currency exchange, publuc beach... I'm so coming back to Playacar!
My favorite place in the world. My husband and I love to walk here with our dog. The street is full of life, sounds, art, food, people and fun
Local shopping. Long stretch of great shopping, mix of local artisans and chain stores. There are also lots of food choices. Very clean and safe.

Two different places. If you like to shop go to the avenue in the afternoon. It is sunny and bright and the traffic is moving right along. Night is different. Well-lit, but the crowds have slowed to a crawl. Hawkers are more persistent in the evening. Some of my favorite shops are here. Several new large mall-like stores have torn down small shops and have built mega stores. It is destroying the 5th Avenue feeling. Although the current 5th Avenue destroyed the tiny fishing village that was the beginning of Playa del Carmen and its charm.
Too american . It doesn't look like Mexico, it looks like a US mall or outlet in open spaces which I can visit in other places that are not Mexican beaches

A little too pushy but fun anyway. This is a great place to hang out and people watch, have a great dinner, and get your shopping done. I found you were approached far too many times but politely say no thank you and mostly they would leave it at that. This is a great place to practice your bargaining skills. I suggest going in the late afternoon and staying in to the evening because it gets quite active at night.

The streets were so crowded we went in here and enjoyed the food.. All I can remember was the food was very good and we were on a second floor looking over a balcony to the crowded street below. We saw dancers in the streets and people everywhere having a good time.

Fun. Did some shopping here. It's got everything from your basic souvenir shirts, mugs, shot glasses to homemade goods. There are restaurants up and down the street. The people are very pushy at many of the places and they try very, very hard to lure you into their shops. However, It's a fun experience.

Shopping mecca. 5th Avenue...not quite like New York tho!! Great fun place to shop and get anything you want...but bring pesos...they'll negotiate if you have cash versus credit card. Some are fixed price shops...but who needs that...the fun of Mexico is the negotiations on price!

Amazing. So many shops from local shops to international ones. I was very tired by the end of the walk but it was well worth it. I highly recommend Yaxche for delicious mayan food and maya-xel where you can find lots of beautiful seashells

A Little Bit of Everything. Quinta Avenida is an eclectic mix of stores, restaurants, bars and everything in between. We loved walking down the street and taking in all the sites and sounds. The street seemed very safe and there were always plenty of people walking around. Several bars have entertainment and each night offered something different. Strolling the street after a day at the beach was a great way to end the day. Must see!

Fun Evenings Walking the 5th Ave. Pedestrian Walk. Evening walks along 5th Avenue are very fun and magical. Evenings are cooler and the street performers are out creating a magical evening. Eat street side and people watch - it is a BLAST!

Vendors saw my wrist band from my resort, and would try to get me to buy saying "remember me? I was your waiter ". Best to always use pesos...even though you can use USA dollars. If you use dollars, they will give you a low exchange rate and not give you the correct change. The atm on 5th avenue was a total ripoff. It cost me $42 to get $300 (US dollars).
Shopping. TONS of shopping and food! Of course u will be approached by each vendor telling to to come into their shop.. but if your are looking to shop u should find everything your looking for here!

Underwhelming. We drove into Playa del Carmen on a rainy day to explore a little and found nothing of interest. I did wander into a store that had, without dickering, some good buys and bought a few things.Parking was difficult so we imagined going into town for dinner it would be even more so and decided that one afternoon of walking this main thoroughfare, seeing the same shops, selling the same stuff, at inflated prices was enough. There was nothing I wanted enough to bother with bargaining for. There seemed to be a lot of fairly reasonable restaurants that had the same lunch specials, as wellI'm giving it an average rating because I know some people like this familiar, touristy, atmosphere and I don't believe it much worse or better than most similar towns.
Fascinating. This is by far the most interesting pedestrian street I have seen in a long tim. It is full of people of all ages and origins, dozens of restaurants, stores, etc...
Pez Vela is the best!. We love returning to Pez Vela each year for drinks and sometimes lunch. Great bartenders and service!!
Great nightlife and decent restaurants. Lot's to see and do on 5th Avenue. Interesting restaurants, shopping, and nightlife. Demanding salespeople

Ok. This is your typical tourist shopping strip. Everything is negotiable. Just remember that they usually start by tripling the price of whatever you want so haggle haggle haggle. Also at some point some there will most likely say that they know you from the hotel..and that its their day off so they are working at their family owned shop. They do not know you you. They only recognize the resort bracelet you're wearing .. So don't fall for it..On a brighter note, we had the best, authentic shrimp tacos, nachos and Margaritas at a restaurant here. I can't recall the name but you'll see large margarita glasses right out front. Do yourself a favor and stop in. I went twice just for the tacos.

Street festival extrodinare!. If you are visiting the Cancun area you should get to Playa del Carmen for an exciting adventure. Without a doubt this is a tourist trap! However, we had fun walking up and down this mile long street. Shops on either side selling souvenirs, clothing, trinkets. There are the everyday shops, chains (Starbucks, Senior Frog), and unique (handmade clothing from native Aztecs). There were also kiosks mostly offering tours. We usually avid them as they usually are timeshare sale. This time we were curious and stopped to chat with a saleswoman. Told her we were interested in snorkeling and she offered a couple of suggestions. After negotiating, we did in fact, buy a tour. That turned out to be the best tour for our stay! At the end of the street is the ferry that will take you to Cozumel. And we took advantage of that on another day. Near the ferry port there were some street performers showing Mayan or Aztec cultural dances. On the day that we returned from Cozumel, we stayed latter in the evening and there were several other street performers. Yes, this is a tourist trap and yes it is very noisy. But it made for a fun day. And we did find a nice restaurant, Micaela's for a filling snack. Their Stone Bowl appetizer was enough for our dinner! And they prepared a wonderful Banana Flambe, all for under $30! Go! Enjoy! Buy or don't buy, you should have fun. Something for EVERYONE!

The heart of Playa Del Carmen!. Do not miss walking Fifth Avenue when you are in the area. You will need to return numerous times to explore all the little nooks and crannies this street offers and if you can only make it in once, spend the day in shops, restaurants and bars. Whether it's people watching, shopping or being serenaded by real Mariachi muscians, it is a must do!!

Good for souvenir shopping, big shopping and dinning area. Quinta Avenida is a long shopping street. It is a very alive area, very touristic though, so quite pricey. Mexican silver is know for the quality and this is a good place to buy some. Souvenir shops are also quite good and have good offers in the area. It is nice to walk around a see the place, but it is nothing special.

It has it all. A pedestrian street about a mile long filled with restaurants and shopping opportunities. Local vendors hawk their goods and many restaurants offer specials,posted outside. Two story building are the rule in Playa. The ferry terminal is located next to the main square and the shops go north from there. You can negotiate prices at many stores. Active night life, massage opportunities and only one block from the beach make this a fun place to visit.

Tourist trap. Ok, yes you have to go and experience it. Lots of tourists and can get noisy.Do yourself a favour and don't eat there. Everything is twice the price and fast food quality. Go off one of the side streets. Better food and prices. The souvenir shops are a rip off and the booze is almost twice the price... Go to Walmart on 30th for alcohol. Keep in mind that the further you go north on fifth, the cheaper it gets.

Okay if you lower your IQ by half.. Overpriced, with no respect for any semblance to Mexican culture. A great example of mass unsustainable tourism. Geared towards wealthier older people to lazy to experience anything other than Quinta Avendia and young people getting booked up..Joke is 2 streets up you can.start to experience some "normal" Mexican life.

Good mexican food.. Quinta Avenida is like a eating and shopping street everywhere else but here you can have a lot of different mexican food and it is well done. Thumps up for mexican food. I love it with a cold Corona.
