Souvenirs x 1000000. The street is endless and so are the options for buying a souvenir. Except from some bars, quite some restaurants, a few jewelleries, sun glass shops, ice cream sellers and some fashion stores, almost all the others sell the same colourful stuff. Everything looks very appealing to me, but what to do with the 101st table cloth, tea mug or photo frame?It's a nice street to wander around, but all the sales men and women trying to get you into their store are a little annoying.

You have to experience it!. 5th Avenue in Playa del Carmen is like a Mexican Iowa State Fair midway! You have to experience it! It's a shoppers paradise for sure, and the many restaurants will have your head spinning. So lively and colorful! Just Go!
Place is fun to walk and shop. Lots to see and visit, all types of shops! Can be tiring if hot! Some shops are over- priced! Shop around and bargain!

Something for everyone!. A lot of restaurants, bars, shops with Mexican wares as well as Sephora, Zara, Victoria Secret, Tommy Hilfiger, Forever 21 and more. It can be busy in the afternoon and evenings. Close to the beach, the ferries to Cozumel and a park at the south end.

Mexico Shopping on Steroids. My wife and I have visited PDC probably 15 times over the past 25 years, and have seen it change dramatically during that time, some good & some not so good. If you visit PDC & don't spend some time downtown & on 5th Avenue, you are missing a lot of the experience. South of Avenida Constituyentes, the shops & restaurants range from still some local flavor to very pushy (it is Mexico) and now very upscale like a top end mall in any large cosmopolitan city. In fact, there is a new mall open now that was being built several years ago that is full of upper end stores that I feel really hurts the quaintness of the place that used to exist. We don't like that change, and the influx of cruise ships has likely caused a lot of it, but regardless, the experience of walking up & down the pedestrian street is still fun. North of Avenida Constituyentes is the latest development, and if you look hard enough, you can still find some shops & restaurants that are more like PDC was years ago. Not perfect, but more fun to me than the hardcore tourist traps and high end stores.

Lots to do, Lots of fun!. Over the years, we have stayed in Cancun and at some resorts on the riviera maya. But the past few years, we have truly enjoyed the intimate and entertaining experiences that staying in Playa Del Carmen offers. Quinta Avenida is the heart of Playa Del Carmen. If you are not staying in Playa Del Carmen, take a cab and have them drop you off by the bus station. Enjoy that immediate area and then head up fifth avenue to explore all of the shops, bars and restuarnats. Avenida Quinta is mostly flat, and well lit at night. It can get crowded later in the day and at night. The cross streets are easily laid out allowing you to navigate the several mile area with ease. Dont forget the there is a beautiful beach just a couple of.blocks away. There are also lots of fun shops and restuarants within a few blocks of either side of fifh avenue. This is a pedestrian only avenue, so wear comfortable shoes. Cabs are easy to find up and down the area. I would set aside either a half day or at least an evening to get a good feel for the area. This is worth the stop.
Lots of fun. There are options for everyone, if you want to just have a quiet dinner, go shopping or party you should go.
Fun. This is a fun Avenue to Visit. Go into the little shops and you could find something that you would love to have.

Streeet Hustlers, Massage Girls and obnoxious Cab Drivers. I've been going to Playa Del Carmen for 25+ years and now attempt to walk down 1st or 10th. avenues. to get around town. The food is over priced and by no means the best of this city's culinary scene.. The street hustling is now untenable.Watch your pockets when approached by someone saying they're your "waiter"!! The cab drivers charge you double or triple the tarrif if you catch a cab along 5th and, a good majority of the "massage girls" are hookers nowadays. Note, the further south you go, the seedier the experience will be. If you want a good massage, pay a little more and go to Veronica's on 1st. Even just 10 years ago, 5th Ave was quaint but now, it's just the three mile long loved child from the sordid tryst between a middle class America shopping mall and a bad Mexican mercado. Neither are typically considered quaint or charming.

Tired from constantly saying "no thank you"!. We stayed in Akumal because we like areas that are less touristy but we stopped into Playa del Carmen on our last day on our way to the airport to catch our evening flight. We walked down Quinta Avenida and honestly got very tired of saying no to people! There are lots of shops and everyone wants you to go into their shop. We had no interest in shopping and found it very tiring to be constantly bombarded by shop owners and people trying to sell us tours and tickets. Our sons remarked many times how happy they were that we didn't stay in Playa del Carmen. It is also a bit difficult to find parking which is quite expensive. All of the restaurants we looked at were easily 3 to 4 times the price of the restaurants in Akumal and Tulum!

Shops and restaurants. This was a nice long avenue filled with shops and restaurants. Although it was for tourists, I found it was fun and convenient although expensive. Since this was the last leg of our trip, it was easy to pick up souvenirs. There was an art gallery that had handmade mayan pictures out of paper; a great place and unique!

Great after dinner walk. This is a friendly street. We enjoy walking & shopping after dinner each night. You can find any type of food you want. Shopping is outstanding. There are local "Mom & Pop" shops to retail chain stores. People watching is fun too.

Fifth avenue has exploded!. We were shocked when we arrived at how much the 5th avenue has changed in 5 years. More and more American stores. But there is still some of the local cool that made us love the place . Use TripAdvisor to find great restaurants

Shopping and restaurants. If you like to see people this is the place. Everyone tourist and local wander 5th ave. It goes on forever, pedestrians only. Stores from the usual tourist junk to high end. Everything is there even just people watching. There are an umber of reallfine restaurants all along 5th with every type of cuisine. Just a fun outing but wear your walking shoes
Busy. Lots of shops and restaurants. Quite busy in the evenings. New premium shopping centres have been built which have free toilets.

Overpriced tourist trap!. Started off feeling quite excited at the huge amounts of shops, cafes etc. to explore.Does not take long to see that all the shops are selling the same stuff with just a few more costly exceptions.Walked from one end to the other hoping to find reasonably priced cigars but although they have the selection the prices are way over the top.Apart from a couple of drinks and a taxi back to the hotel, unfortunately we did not help the local economy!

T Shirt needed. No silver for me thanks.. Great fun street. All kinds of places to eat drink and have fun. There is a little circle bar right by Starbucks that is cool. Italian eateries well worth a go. You will be harassed the whole way , not bad but you will need the 'No Silver and Gold for me thank you' t shirt.

Must do!. La Quinta is an absolutely beautiful street lined with shop after shop and restaurant after restaurant. It's an absolute must do if you go anywhere near Playa del Carmen. We usually stay in a condo or hotel right on the beach and go into town every night to a different restaurant. There are so many fabulous options! Many restaurants have a sample plate of their best dish on the street for you to see before you decide. Everybody has menus on the street to peruse as well. There are lots of wonderful, fresh Mexican restaurants, of course, but there are a ton of Italian restaurants as well, plus a little bit of about everything else.The street itself is beautiful and full of life. It is paved in bricks and many of the trees have lights in them. There are always lots of people and lots to see. There's always a mariachi band or two roaming around in the evenings and sometimes even some xylophone players. Its totally safe too wander the streets in the wee hours of the night too--we have done it many times. It's among my favorite places to go, anywhere!
Love the shopping. You must go there lots of shopping and beach close by, amazing little restaurant.. It's a must to do

Nice and clean street. Nice for shopping, eating or drinking. A lot of different things to buy, from cheap souvenirs to expencive american brands. Very busy and a lot of sellers trying to talk you into their stores. A little too much for my taste, but nice to walk in the evenings. Everything is more expencive at the 5th Avenue.

5th Avenue was awesome!. It was the perfect little escape, even coming from an all-inclusive resort...just to walk along the beach, stop in at a small local bar and chat with the waitress, watch cigars being rolled in the tobacco shop...we went to a couple of little outdoor bars and just ordered a beer, listened to the local music, and enjoyed the breezes off the Caribbean...people-watching in Playa Del Carmen was fun, too!

Very disappointing and commercialized. Quinta Avendia as I once knew it back in the early 2000's has changed dramatically. Every year for the past 15 years we have noticed the growth and progress and IMO it has lost it's charm. Gone are the cute palapa roofs with restaurants, shops and bars. Now replaced by Americanized chain stores and malls that are all overpriced.  The atmosphere used to be charming and it was very enjoyable to stroll both during the day and at night and take it all in. Stopping along the way to relax on the benches that were provided and listen to the strolling Mariachi bands and local musicians that were playing live. Now gone are the benches and there is only one group of Mariachi bands that will only play for a tip. There is no more strolling on 5th ave, the pace is so hectic and crazy and so many people. The only places now to sit and relax are the high end Starbucks and other coffee or bars along the avenue and even then you can't hear yourself think because of the loud music pumping out of the bars on the corner of 5th and calle 10. I looked forward to the evening strolls along the avenue to people watch but now avoid it like the plague......Lost is the" local" feel, like the fruit ladies and the food stands, now more designer stores and high end boutiques are what you will see.

Plenty of shopping for all budgets. The street is closed to automobiles and is pedestrian only, which made the shopping experience more enjoyable. There was great shopping for any type of budget and plenty of variety. Plus there were restaurants, salons and other services available. My only complaint was that you are constantly being approached by sales people, but that is pretty much the norm in Mexico.

Michigan Ave of Playa. Need to exchange your money for pesos? Go to 5th Av. Hungry? 5th Av. Wanna drink? 5th Av. Heard about that new Frida Khalo restaurant? Check it out, it's on...5th Av. Anything you need you can get it there. However, I do suggest buying your souvenirs off of 5th simply bc the prices drop significantly.

Always an adventure!. There is something for everyone along 5th ave.The experience can be a lot of fun. Everything from authentic Mexican shops to high end malls! Lots of great food along the ave. as well.

Jewels galore. We had a great time shopping and enjoying our walk up and down the Ave. We ate at several places with entertainment and reasonable prices. Many, many jewelry shops so anyone can find that special keepsake. We visited the ave 3 times during our stay and enjoyed each visit.
Something for everyone. A fantastic mix of old n new, slow pace n fast pace, markets to malls and super food options - love mexican food !!

Love Quinta!. I love this street! I've visited Playa four times and every time, we spend a lot of time on Quinta. Tons of unique shops, great people watching, great restaurants and bars. I wouldn't recommend buying jewelry at the shops on Quinta though, as it's not always authentic. For example, shop workers will tell you that the opal jewelry is "Mexican/harvested in Mexico," but most of it is man-made from plastic (though it looks real) and it's NOT a bargain. There is however a lot of local art for sale, which is a good deal if it is authentic. Some of it is, some of it is made in China, you just have to research it a bit before you buy and don't be afraid to haggle over prices; they seem to expect it and don't mind "negotiating." I recommend just walking this street to take in all of the wonderful Playa/Mexican culture; it's a great experience! Just don't let yourself be bothered by heckling shop workers; it's just part of the tourist-oriented culture and they are fun to talk with if you have an easy going attitude/don't take it personally. I've found that the locals are friendly, fun people and this street is a safe, great place to interact with just about anyone. Of course, watch your purse, backpack, etc., just like you would in any tourist-oriented location, but really, I feel safer in Playa than I've felt in many other tourist locales, such as Paris or Rome.

It's too much. Okay. I'm spoiled since I used to hang out here years ago when it was low key and mostly Mexican. Today this place is so full of upscale boutiques and designer stores that I'm floored that Neiman Marcus isn't there. Really! You go to Mexico to shop the GAP, Victoria's Secret, etc? The only reason I give it 3 points is because car traffic is prohibited, and there is a good variety of restaurants and bars.
Souvenirs galore. Fun shopping experience. Restaurants, fast food, ice cream! Plenty of cash changing places available. Can pick up the ferry to Cozumel at this point.

Must Visit. First - very safe. Great place to stroll, shop, eat, drink and people-watch! Goes for at least mile and a half. Pedestrian only. Lots of families. Seemingly hundreds of restaurants and bars - with all kinds of shopping.
Good shopping place. There were so many shopping there. I saw a lot of high end stores. But hope to see more of the normal or local people shopping stores.

Busy Bustling Freindly.. Practically every night we would venture into Quinta Avenia. Fantastic friendly atmosphere not really hassled at all other than people trying to get you to go on tours. Great selection of food and shopping at great prices.

great food. We stopped here for a relaxing lunch. The food was great and the beverages were very good. You can get healthy drinks that don't have booze in them. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who is looking for good food

Take Me Back!!!. I loved this little town. I wish I was there on a "off-season" but nonetheless it was fun. I felt like I was in Mexico but I also felt safe (which is a big concern to tourists). I went into several pharmacies looking for allergy medicine and found some. I didn't eat very much around here but next time I will. Also, get a fish pedicure!!!

Okay- touristy. I would spend the day doing something else I think. Unless, you wanted to buy the usual tourist items to bring home. There are street vendors and shops up and down 5th Avenue. I saw very few items that I wanted to bring home or could not purchase the hotel gift shop. I would rather spend the day on the beach I think.
Good fun to see. Traditional, and easy going for all. Drinks while you walk, good restaurant choices and 7 / 11's everywhere. Even the kids got a treat !

Interesting street. We are staying nearby and have visited everyday. Many kinds of restaurants, some just a sandwich, some very fancy. Lots of souvenir shops but also a few beautiful more authentic Mexican craft stores.

Great place to shop!. Quinta Avenida has a lot of stores to choose from and places to eat too. It's modern, clean and something for everyone. It's also a great place to people watch while have coffee from Starbucks or some Ice Cream from Haagan-Dazs

Honeymoon. Fifth avenue caters for people with different budgets. Just beware of small boutiques that offer you a Mexican minute! They are lovely local people wanted to sell you their products.The Mexicans are lovely, friendly people.
Beautiful . Nice place to walk, restaurants, bars. Is the main street in playa del carmen, 30 min far from cancun, playa del carmen, and 5th avenue is the beat way to get the beach
NICE STROLL - great deals!. We spent a few hours here getting souvenirs to bring back . you can find great deals here but you must look around and haggle!
It was a cute place with much needed convenience . Convenience stores, souvenirs, restaurants, close to Walmart, and walking distance to the beach. Aaahhhhh, Starbucks is here!

***Wonderful***. If you book a stay in Playa del Carmen, Mexico consider yourself very lucky. You can find any and everything on 5th avenue. Plenty of restaurants and shops all within walking distance. Make sure that you walk the entire 5th avenue, you won't be disappointed!

Touristy as it gets. There are definitely some spots worth visiting individually on Quinta Avenida. But if you're not into touristy spots, you'll want to spend as little time as you can walking this street.

Downtown. I have been coming yearly to this area for at least 10 years now. It is sad how it has changed to a very touristic, ungenuine,and americanized town. Hardly any Mexican goods to be found. Stores are almost the same as home. Shopping is not a fun experience any more. I do still enjoy talking to the locals and watching the interactions.

Nice place to walk around!. Nice place to walk around. I always visit Playa del Carmen every time I am in Mexico. Lots of shops and restaurants. If you want to get out of the resorts and go somewhere close this would be a great place. The shops pretty much have the same items and the prices generally the same.

Must see!. 5th Ave is such a must see if you're headed to Playa. Be prepared to be harassed by the local vendors when you make your way down. I found a simple "no gracias" and a smile usually did the trick to shut them down. Try to remember that these people are hustling to make a living.. Don't take it personally. There are sooo many places to check out and the food options are endless. There is one Italian place on the "new" end of 5th that is especially good. Best pizza we've ever had! The owner and chef is Italian. The beaches are great and you can find about any souvenir from beach bags to jewelry, hot sauce, tequila and Mexican vanilla. Tons of silver --- barter when it comes to the silver, but don't assume that can get away with it everywhere.

Main shopping area. Lots of shops but you have seen them all before. Many sell the same stuff as the shop two doors down. No cheaper than at home really. Walmart is close by for those looking for a local supermarket

Nice - but too expensive. An interesting mixture of Mexican and American cultures. Some of the places were fine but pay for most items in the local currency, this case pesos. The exchange rate at establishments for foreign currency is abysmal. Also be careful of the street ATMs as some of them go against your credit card and at terrible rates. One is better to go to a bank ATM and make a large Peso withdrawl. Be careful not to go on the first and the fifteenth of the month as the machines tend to run out of cash on these Mexican paydays.On the way home buy your "duty free" stuff around here as the Airport shop depends on desperate tourists that have left over Pesos. You're better off taking out a reasonable amount of Pesos at the bank ATM, for your stay, and at the end of your trip go to "currency exchange booth" . Don't worry there are plenty around.

Touristy & Over Priced. 5th Avenue is a tourist trap, overpriced and there is nothing Mexican about this street. If you want to feel and experience Mexico, you need to walk away from 5th Avenue and onto 10th, 20th streets. The bars are too noisy. The only good thing about this street is you can dress casually and walk down to the beach for a walk, swim, snorkel or diving.

Tourist strip. There is nothing Mexican about this very long strip of bars restaurants and shops. If you like buying touristy trinkets this is the place. You will be constantly harassed to look in shops or book tours. It was entertaining to hear the banter and tricks used. Good vibe. Seems very safe.

Some good shopping, but hot, hot, hot!. Go at night! We went in the morning and it was just too hot to shop! Who wants to try on clothes when you're hot n' sticky?Some nice clothing shops and a variety ot crafts, knick knacks, you name it. Worth wandering out for a few hours and just a short walk from many of the hotels. 20 minutes from the Royal Hideaway and the walk is lovely!

Fifth Avenue not too impressive, at least during the day. Just a disclaimer that this review does not address the nightlife on Fifth Avenue in Playa del Carmen. However, during the day this commercial strip is too North American and definitely too high priced to be enjoyable. Street vendors constantly accost all passersby, frequently offering prices that are "almost free" and "Cheaper than Walmart" and if that fails to interest the pitch frequently ends with "Wanna get high?" This contrasts with retail establishments and restaurants, many with names familiar to Americans and Canadians from home, offering prices that are inflated by North American standards and exorbitant by Mexican standards. It's worth a visit for a few hours and to stop a one of the more local restaurants which are often on side streets just to experience but over-priced and uncomfortable for a leisurely visit to town by a vacationer.

A bit touristy for my taste. Quinta Avenida, Playa del Carmen is a nice place to visit to purchase trinkets, goods, and great Mexican food! You can get great access to off-the-beaten path to sandy beaches for fun in the sun. Adult visits at night is great for night life partying and exploring authentic Mexican tasty food delights. Be careful to travel using the buddy system as one or two streets off the beat can be dangerous day or night. Otherwise, have fun and take plenty of pictures.
Awesome Time SHopping!. Be ready to haggle and get a good deal. Don't be afraid to ask the vendors if they will take less, because 99% of the time they will.
shopping..... very pleasant avenue to shop...during raining day.. a lot of choice for souvenirs.cheap prices and good italien restaurants.
Main Strip. Great people watching with shops, restaurants, bars, clubs and hotels. Must stroll while you're in Playa del Carmen.
Overpriced. Much better value on 10th and 30th Ave.OK to walk down, particularly early in the morning. Check out the NAU restaurant on 15th Ave between 8 and 10.
Fun and safe. Really enjoyed. Vendors a bit insistent.Lot of choice, and prices OK.Lack of spots to sit and rest for tourists. It is hot there.

Cool busy shopping street.. Nice for a walk. Definitely super touristy. It's basically shops and restaurants. A lot of the same stuff but its a fun walk on a nice sunny day. People will ask you to come in their shops give you tequila samples and such but in my opinion the best prices were at La Europea in the Quinta Alegria Mall. The bottles in the tourist shops were marked up quiet a bit. But for little nick nacks and that, those shops are fine. Most of the stuff is made in China now anyway. There is the odd sketchy person asking 'weed/blow', but a simple head shake and no and its no problem. I was also there during BPM festival (not attending it) so that may have had something to do with that.It's really close to the beach (1 block up) so bring your swimsuit if you fancy a swim!

Great people watching. We walked the length of 5th Ave and did a little shopping. You need a little foresight going in, especially if you are coming from one of the resorts. They know the bracelets and will try to draw you in. We sought out the places that didn't have people offering "almost free" stuff. There are some great hidden gems among the cheap stuff, such at La Troupe near Calle 24. Hundreds of restaurants to choose from too.

Awesome vacation. Best place to visit in mexico hands down plenty of places to have fun different restaurants everybody is friendly just beware of so called posada hotels have crazy policies wnd rude staff do not recommend them at all especially if your witha large family
Atmosphere like no other. An array of food, drink and entertainment with a dash of shopping inbetween. This is a must experience for Mexico.

Quinta Avenida. This is a great place to go to at night. There are plenty of places to eat at as well as a street with all the bars and clubs. There are also brand name stores as well as souvenir shops.

A good place to spend a couple hours exploring. Shopping here gets hot, but it's a must, especially if you're at all AI resort. Get out and explore some mexican charm! You can shop high-end retail, or cheap mexican souvenirs.

Cool and safe spot. Don't be afraid of negotiate prices. Definately pay attention when you are paying for your stuff so you don't get charge more. And if they y do, do not be afraid of saying something If you don't want to be bother as much by the people that call out for trips, stores and such do no wear any piece of clothing that says were you are from I felt very safe here .it's a great spot to people watch, it a fairly cheap to seat down and have a few beers most places have WiFi just ask for the password

Great food and fun. There are plenty of options for good food and good times, my husband and I walked this street several times and it's full of very touristy stores, but also cooler, more interesting places, bars, restaurants. There is also something for every budget. Very elegant restaurants and also street food type of places.
excellent energy. Went here strolling/dining and shopping every night. Always busy and full of positive energy, Excellent place to stroll after diner.
To shop. We went to Play del Carmen to shop and stopped at a store call Ruby and bought some jewelry we were ripped off if looking for jewelry please avoid this store it is on 5th Ave & 2nd street.
Good bye charm. Out with the local charm in with the chain stores and shopping malls. Remember the charm of this quaint fishing village with its family businesses? Gone taken over by corporate USA.

Fun place to shop and dine :). There are LOTS of stores and restaurants at La Quinta Avenida, you will never run out of options. It's a fun place to walk around, specially at night because you hear the music coming out of the restaurants, cafés and people walking around. If you like handcrafts this is also the place to go if you don't have a chance to go to Market 28 in Cancun.
All the world in just a street. Here you can find people from all around the world, sharing drinks and hearing music. Shopping and window shopping are also main attractions
Busy Tourist Shopping Street. very popular and safe shopping for tourists with plenty of bars and restaurants. You will be pestered by the shop and tour operating staff but they're really no problem

Don't miss it.. I kept reading the reviews about how touristy this place is and that kind of made my expectations lower. Is it touristy? Yes. Is it still awesome? Yes! They have everything on this street from high end fashion and dining to cheap bargain t-shirts and walk up hot dog stands. There really is something for everyone.

Tourist Shopping. Typical touristy shopping street. Tacky gift shops galore. But the people watching is great and there are some interesting restaurants and bars just off the main drag. You have to go at least one time if you are in the area and stay until night when it really comes alive.

Fun walk at night. Quinta Avenida is the main shopping and restaurant area geared for tourists. You'll find countless local shops where you can get souvenirs, snacks, etc (many US store chains as well). As for dining, be prepared to overpay for subpar food, with the exception being La Parilla Playa (located right by the Quinta Alegria Shopping Mall). La Parilla has absolutely amazing, authentic food and Margaritas. In the evening, it's fun to walk La Quinta and people watch and take in the ocean air (which is a stone's throw away). Also, you'll feel very safe and secure, as there is an emphasis on making tourists feel welcome and protected.

American shopping. I know there are probably plenty of people who love to shop while on vacation, I do too, but I like shops I can't find at home. While there are street vendors and some local shops, I was overwhelmed by the number of US chains that have retail fronts along this strip. We walked the length of Quinta Avenida, abandoned it once we reached the ferry terminal and went off in search of some street tacos instead. I had a much better time just wandering some of the other streets rather than being inundated with heavy traffic and many hagglers on this main strip.

Good but .... It's a nice place to walk. However if you have your little ones is not very for them loads of night life but nothing to enjoy as a family..Look around before you get your souvenirs as prices are quite high...Nice place for one day ..

Tourist trap. Relatively crowded, lots of people and many street vendors. Not really my thing. But if you are after souvenirs, people-watching and that sort of thing, then I guess this is the place for you. Quinta offers also many bars and restaurants of varying quality - and rest assured: some of those restaurants are actually really, really good.

Be careful!. I love playa and 5th avenue. It's a great place to shop around and meet other travellers. I caution people though as the store owners/salesmen are aggressive and will use your resort bracelet as a sales pitch. They try to pretend they work in your resort as waiters, ground staff etc but they don't. They know all the various resort bracelets and try play on that. They will try charge you double but if you know your prices or how to barter them you should be fine. Keep your money close as I have heard of handsy salesmen or their companions helping themselves to your cash. I love the massive variety of stores and shops and the busy atmosphere. It's definitely not something we see often at home. I recommend checking it out, simply for the experience is nothing else. The beach here is also amazing if you decide to bring your suit and towel. A must visit, and visit again if I go back to Mexico as I didn't get through the entire strip.

shopping. great shopping good prices lots to look at really good food a lot to choose from. Prices vary depending on what you want. The taco wagon food was great very cheap the Italian food was my favorite.

Worth the time. Visiting 5th avenue in playa del carmen was awesome. Grest restaurants (to be a little different then the usual buffet at the resort) really safe, most taxi drivers speak english or somewhat english. Great for souvenirs and nice summer dress or cigars as your can easily bargain and enjoy a nice ice crea while walking for hours looking aroung. Go as a couple or group of friends and take the time to visit the little places, boutiques and sit on one of the nice patios :)
Shopping. I found that every store sold pretty much the same items. The further down the street you go the better the deals.

Vibrant shopping and nightlife. 5th Avenue has changed dramatically over the past 20 years. While there are still souvenir shops and cheap watering holes, there are also nice, upscale shopping and eating establishments up and down the avenue.
Nice shopingstreet. A rather okay shopingstreet in Playa. The only thing that bothered me was that young Mexicans kept asking me if I wanted to get high or by drugs!

My adventure walk. I loved this street, We stayed close and walked to town every day just to see what we could see, and there is something different to see ever day. .We were only asked to buy drug 3 times in 14 days so I feel the street had cleaned up it's act from 4 years ago. New years night was like been in time square , what a blast. There is a beautiful new mall that is a must see. But the best was the restaurants , we had great food at all the restaurants we tried and even better service. Cheers hope this helps .

Gotta walk 5th ave. We always love 5th ave but remember that the "most" of the things sold there are cheap crap and you will be hassled when you walk down the street. There are some great bars and restaurants. be very careful on what ever you buy to make sure it is authentic (cigars or liquor) and never pay full price. counter offer at 1/3 of the asking price and never pay more than half. If you do you will kick yourself because you will find it cheaper somewhere else than 5th ave!!! Never make eye contact with the sales people unless you want to be harassed and berated. On the up side, I bought a box of real Cohiba cigars only to find afterwards that they were infested with tobacco beetles. i took them back and the store owner fully refunded me.

Pretty standard . Definitely worth going for cheaper souvenirs than the resorts. Expect to be mildly hassled by street vendors, but they're pretty polite overall. Lots of restaurant options and a pretty nice beach, modern mall, but you can see it all in one afternoon /evening. From our resort, the cab was about 14 dollars each way.

Improving. Some of the vendors used to be really rude when you walk by their shops when you wouldn't stop to shop. This attitude has improved a lot. We didn't hear any rude comments directed towards us in Spanish. Some tourists can speak Spanish.You still get the "Hey Senor(ita), remember me? George from the hotel? Come see what my Grandma sells in her shop." Maybe this adds to the quaintness of the street vendors, maybe not. There are a lot of new more upscale fashion shops now. But plenty of small and medium Tourist Trinket shops. If you need a t-shirt or shot glass type of gift, go for it and shop here.

Crazy at Playa del Carmen. I used to love going to Playa del Carmen and not its so commercialized. I don't want to go shopping for Guess or HMV, we have this here at home don't need to see it on my vacation. If you go to Playa del Carmen you need to go to Coco Bongo. You won't regret it.We ate at this place called El Pirate and I tell you its the best Burrito I have had, and the fish tacos are amazing. The service was great.Lots of walking at Playa and everyone wants to call you to see their store. Its crazy. If you want to exchange money you need to bring your passport with you if not they will not exchange the money. They do have ATM machines that charge and arm and a leg and it give you Cdn currency or Mexican.

The best of high end shopping and local crafts. Street is blocked off and there is so much to see. We never made it to the south end. There are so many stores and vendors to suit all tastes and budgets. Many different cuisines to select from--be it a sit down meal, or a quick snack on the move.
Fun, lots of activity, good shops. Lots of things to do around here, great food selection. A lot of insistent vendors but they were easily avoidable. great place to hang out
Really nice. If you need to buy souvenirs and breathe a little, just wander for a while, it is the perfect place. Very lively.
Pretty. Pretty place. It was nice going around. Many stores, restaurants, music and people. Nice place to visit
Shopping. This is a fun area to shop. Anything you could possibly want. Be ready to haggle! Also some wonderful places to stop for a drink or a meal!

Fun to walk, eat & shop. Whatever else you might say, it's pretty well all on 5th Avenue: shops selling anything from tat to expensive jewellery, cheap T-shirts to designer clothes, whilst the restaurants cover all tastes and price-ranges and it's just good to wander up and down and watch the world and his selfy-stick go by.

Always fun! Just laugh with the shop owners. Fifth Avenue is always a fun and exciting place. We always visit here when in this part of Mexico. Remember as a tourist, however, these shops live from the goods they sell. The sales people are aggressive as it is their livelihood. We always return, no negative experiences and many many shops and restaurants in the area.
Fun! Great for strolling!. Long walk but plenty to see for everyone! Bars, cafes, restaurants, fast food, souveniers, high end shopping, you name it!

5th avenue Visit. This was a nice distraction during our 10 day stay.
Lots of shops with great restaurants
The shop owners and sales people are a little aggressive so be prepared

Lots of fun if you like Key West.. What used to be quaint and kindly playful has moved to mainstream and a bit overwhelming. I used to stay in town and troll these streets for live music and a good value meal. Now, it's lost it's charm with a few exceptions...
You might be better off staying at a big property and making a day visit...

5th Avenue. This was a fun experience. Lots of shops to go through and trinkets to buy. It was fun walking through and seeing the people. Just be cautious of some of the shop owners trying to make you enter under duress. We had one unfortunate incident where one owner tried to convince us that we had met him on the resort and he became somewhat belligerent when we did not buy anything from him. He had seen our wristbands and tried to con us.Other than that, an overall pleasant experience!

Love 5th Ave. Love the atmosphere of 5th ave.Very safe and the back street taco stands are unreal . YumThey have baby lion, panthers, tigers that you can pet and take pictures while holding them but of course you have to pay Great shops and restaurants.

So so. A long stretch of shops, most of which you can find in any big city in Canada or the states but with inflated prices as opposed to back home. We even found a lot of the souvenir stores to be priced fairly high, almost double what you pay for the exact same thing on the pacific side. Much of it seems very comercialized which isn't what I am into when I go to Mexico, I don't need a Starbucks or Nike store but that is just me. You are constantly being harassed by vendors to see their goods, was asked if I was looking for drugs at least a dozen times. Usually a quick no gracias is all that is required although some of them were a little more pushy which you get accustomed to in Mexico. I have experienced it so would probably not go again, not really for me. The one nice thing is the amount of bars to enjoy a cold drink in while the wives shop!

Shoppers Delight. There are tons of options for shopping all within walking distance several local tourist stores and several mass chain stores spend the day here walking shopping and eating until your heart is content!

Must visit - Safe for Family. We love to shop in countries we visit. My wife and our 2 kids (7 and 22) loved to visit and shop in Quinta Avenida. We where worried with several comments regarding safety issues, drugs and too much preassure from sellers. Well what we found was very different, lots of nice sellers, working with education and a very safe location to buy with police in several corners.
Nice place for tourist. You have everything in this street. If you like shopping or you just want to eat and rest...Full of people all day and night. Main street in Playa.
One of the world's great resort "strips". Whatever you want, you can find it on Fifth Avenue! It's really what makes Playa such a special destination.

Not to be missed. La Quinta Avenida is the main shopping street of Playa and just the place to buy gifts for loved ones and then sit in a bar and watch the world go by. We were firm with enthusiastic traders who quickly backed off when we declined to be dragged into their shops

Too Touristy. I would have enjoyed this a little more had we not been offered drugs on every corner. I was a little taken aback by this, and didn't expect it. This strip really has only junky souvenir shops, overpriced (and dirty) bars/restaurants, and drug dealers. You have to seek out the good restaurants, and there definitely are some good places to eat. I was not impressed. Further, those that say the shopping is good - not true. Just another American shopping mall experience. Nothing unique at all.

Fun Fun, but a lot of hustle.. Great little tourist trap with a lot of bars, restaurants, and souvenirs for purchase. Beware, many stores don't price their merchandise, and the vendors will try to hustle you hard if you're white. Get ready to negotiate!
crowed. cheap shops, lots our tourists, ugly tourisic restaurants and drug dealers trying to sell their staff.

Fun shopping and dining. You will find many of the merchants approach you to invite you into their stores you quickly get used to it and a no thank you goes a long way. There is a real variety of shops and certainly bargaining in most of them is expected.

The best people watching. We really enjoyed sitting at one of the streets many cafes and just watching the runway show that is continuous and always surprising. There is no such place in the world I have enjoyed people watching quite as much as on 5th ave.

La Quinta is transforming.... ...and is replacing the traditional Mexican village with an alignment of Starbucks Victoria Secrets Nike and tourist shops.
80% of the restaurant on Quinta are now Italian (read: pizza pasta and burger...).
You can now even find 4 shopping malls.

Day excursion to Playa del Carmen. La Quinta Avenida is a very characteristic street down town Playa del Carmen. Just a couple of blocks from the sea, (you can actually see it), the street is quite long and is filled with little restaurants and shops. The Mexicans there are very kind and helpful.

Love exploring!!. Definitely don't miss out on a wander down this strip!! So many cool bars and restaurants!! The constant hassling from shop owners to visit does get annoying but such is life! Definitely make sure you have some meals down here but if you do check the restaurant's exchange rate first as they are often a lot less than the official one but the food and atmosphere make up for it.

AN EVENING GET-AWAY. Quinta Avenida is the place to go. Get away from the all-inclusive and enjoy the evening strolling blocks and blocks of interesting shops and great restrauants. Except for a few shops you can still negotiate for that "great bargain".

Awesome place to get souvenires. Spent the day shopping it was so much fun to look at all the stores but it can get a bit annoying cause all the vendors are persistant about u visiting their stores especially if they see u bought stuffTip for next time - there is a beach so next time I'd bring my bathing suit and make use of the public beachThe best deal is to take the bus from your hotel if they do that it was $6 pesos each for each way worth it

Plenty to see and not nearly as pushy as places in Cancun. I thought the mix of small shops and independent places was better than other spots in Cancun. We picked up nice things and it was easy to grab food and find a place to people watch.
Busy and fun. Very americanized and be very careful not to get scammed buying jewellery.Overall fun and full of action

Constant harrassment - and scam alerts!. The good: There's plenty of restaurants to choose from. The bad: OMG - nonstop harassment from shop employees and tour operators in kiosks. You literally can't walk 10 feet without someone trying to sell you... hair braiding... massages... junky and wildly overpriced trinkets... and - worst of all - tours and activities from the ubiquitous kiosks. These kiosks are the worst - they're populated with pushy sales people who will lie to you at every opportunity - promising tours and experiences that sound great - until you actually get there and find out you've been sold a "tour" that doesn't deliver nearly what was promised. At least at the price you've paid. And getting your money back from these thieves requires the Tourist Police - if you're lucky. My advice is to get tours through the larger hotels - you may (or may not) pay a bit more, but these hotels have leverage that a lone traveler simply doesn't - and crooks are less likely to scam people coming through a major hotel because they don't want to get blacklisted. Just walk past the kiosks and save yourself some grief.

Great expirience. So colorful, cheerful, full of smiley people, great dinning options, phenomenal souvenirs shops.... Like you are in a different world and the best thing is everything is reachable by walking distance. What do you need more?
Get off the beaten path. . Not real Mexico. Overpriced and pushy. Get off 5th Ave. go to the market on Sunday up the road it's safe! Anything we ate on 5th ave wasn't any good.

Nice break from the Resort. Our resort was awesome, but we didn't feel like we were in Mexico. We jumped in a cab and went "downtown". Just what we expected for a tourist street in Mexico! We got some great deals after haggling and interacting with bad Spanish!We felt very safe, had a great meal and there were plenty of "real" taxi's available to get back to our resort with our bags of gifts! Shop around and have some fun!
expensive. No bargains, American shops, more expensive than in America. Food very average. Crazy place. Will for sure NEVER go back to Playa del Carmen

Good opportunity to people watch and have a little fun!. We went to 5th Ave with one major goal - get our daughter's hair braided. We also stopped in a few shops and saw some interesting stuff but mostly overpriced and/or poor quality. We ended up paying $25US for full braids with beads at a street corner cart - way better than the $60+US we were first offered. I also went to the nearest small convenience store to buy beer for about $1US while we waited. As others have noted, if you want deals, travel up and down the side streets a bit rather than just staying on the main drag. Also, I'd say the big tourist stores have the worst prices in general so look for smaller places if they have what you're looking for.

Our Fav place!!!. We've been going to playa since 1996 - its the best kept secret ...well, not for long. LOL. Its mostly europeans and laid back hippie style hipsters!! Most people a cruising around barefoot - bikini ready! Lots of options for relaxing with a cafe, shopping or fine dining. YOU CHOOSE! Cobblestone streets - lots of fun street vendors and performers - fun for people of all ages. Streets are smooth enough if you need a wheelchair ...plenty of parking if you rent a car on all side streets. The 5ht ave goes on for about 2-3 miles and is expanding every year as they build new hotels...cant wait to go back ( as we do every year ) WE LOVE PLAYA!!!!

Definitely way too touristic . Just few quality shop and lots tourists, definitely a crowd place with lots average quality restaurants. Playa del Carmen from a small village it's turning to a big city and first victim it's the atmosphere of 5th Ave.

Shopping, Food, Drinks.. Its easy to take a taxi here to enjoy few hours of walking, shopping, eating local foods, hanging out at the bars and buying souvenirs. You can also find people offering deals on excursions.

Wear good walking shoes!. I love Quinta Avenida! I enjoy walking the strip from one end to the other. Great place to eat, drink, shop and people watch! Tons of variety from name brands to local arts and crafts. If you like massages they run about $33/hour and there are dozens of little massage studios all up and down the strip. The street is one block off the ocean. No cars allowed which makes is great for walking and taking in all of the sites.
Very entertaining . La quinta avenida is a must to see and walk. You will find everything there from Soveniers ,restsuranrs, nightlife and more. Everyone is friendly and very helpful.

Shopping Trip, enjoy the scenery. We went here to do some shopping. There were a lot of people that walked up and down 5th Ave, along with some police as well. I did enjoy the bigger stores that allow you to shop at your own leisure, but do not enjoy the people on the street trying to get us to come in. I was also asked by two different people on the road if I wanted to buy weed or get high.
Fifth Avenue. All the night life is going on here every night. A lot of restaurants, bars, clubs. I felt a lot of pleasure to walk there every evening during our stay in Playa del Carmen
View. Great views of the stores as well as pubs along the routes our trips out were interesting as we stopped at pubs along the way

Vibrant, alive. It was great to come back to Quinta Avenida after 20 years or so, this street has a personality, beyond the stores and restaurants, it's about the people. It's well organised, a wide option of places to eat or do shopping. I don't think theres something similar anywhere.
Lively. Great street for shopping, eating, or just soaking up the atmosphere. Very hot place to be during the day but amazing at night.

Ummm, it's a street!. Just like any other main street. Bars, tourists, drunks, vendors trying to sell you fake cigars and sunglasses, shops, etc. Not a bad place to sit down and get a few cold ones and watch the crowd.

Quinta Avenida. We walked to Quinta Avenida,12/20-12/25/2015, every day/ evening from our Gran Porto Real Resort which was a 8 minute walk uphill. It was a lot different from when we were there in 5/2006. It is a must if you visit Playa Del Carmen, Riviera Maya, Playa Pariso,MX. Since we were there before and after Christmas it was extremely crowded with International Tourists. Quinta Avenida, a Pedestrian area, is in downtown Play Del Carmen and is a very long street with shops, restaurants, farmacias, a Western Shopping Mall with Designer brands, Bars and Night Clubs. The Night Clubs open at 11pm and Street Vendors have packages for Coco Bongos etc.We shopped during the day for Souveniors and possible Excursions to participate in. We went inside a Jewelry Store and we looked at various stones and necklaces. We do not think the silver is real Sterling Silver it was too light and shiny. We couldn't find the stamp of 925 for Sterling silver. We looked at Gold necklaces and bracelets were not stamped with a number of real quality gold. It was difficult to tell if the stones were natural or man-made. Most of the Vendors and store Sales people speak English and most speak Spanish. Beware,the Store Sales people will say "Remember me, I'm the waiter at the restaurant at your resort" to try to get you into their store because they know the Resort wrist bands. The store Sales people say "Almost Free", which made me laugh I said "No Gracias" to 20 people and kept walking. You see some Mexican culture and International culture. There are Street performers to watch.

Typical tourist street. Extremely crowded over the holidays. Overpriced restaurants, cheap souvenirs, hawkers, bars, and everything else that comes with it. Really didn't want to spend much time there.

It's a must! . La Quinta has changed drastically through the years, it used to be a small and quaint little street, now it's HUGE and it even hosts a shopping mall, I preferred the original version, but it's probably nostalgia, it's still the heart of Playa Del Carmen, and an absolute must if you are in town!
shop to drop. Lots to see and buy. Alot of the same from store to store, and if you can handle the harassing you will be fine and enjoy the experience if not don't go lol

Great stroll - have fun!. We didn't do a lot of shopping, but a great combination of a vital international street scene, local flavor, people watching, restaurants, bar and street food. We returned again and again. One of the locations that makes Playa del Carmen so special - enjoy.
Great massages. We had several great massages at Sabai with Patty Moreno and Esther. Eddie was very helpful in arranging our appointments.
Not NY's Fifth Avenue. A long row of small shops & boutiques line up this street intended for tourists looking for mostly souvenir items and a taste for local food and entertainment.

Typical tourist area. If you are looking for Playa souvenirs like shirts, pottery, etc - head here. Don't forget to haggle, and be ready for LOTS of people trying to get your business. Be extremely careful if buying silver jewelry as much is plated (not real). Lots of tourist-trap bars and restaurants with so-so food. Oh, and expect to hear "I work at your hotel, remember me?" every few stores - they see your wrist bands and know where you are from. Don't feel obligated to say anything or stop, it's just a ploy.
Shopping-street.. Very looong shopping-street. Nice to walk along, but the selling-people are very nagging and want to sell thing to you every second meter.
Overpriced fakes. Not to bash all of the vendors but most of it either gouges or is fake. Especially the cigar shops. Decent pricing is found anywhere off the strip.

Hub of Playa feel Carmen. Dinning, shopping, everything you need. This is the heart of the tourist area. Always busy (except if you get up early it is a great place to run before the crowds wake up!).Be smart with bags and valuables, there are a lot of people around. Ignore the touts, find a nice place to dine and watch the crowds go by.

A lot of variety, but pricey. This place is pretty sweet. There is alot to check out in here. All kinds of stores, bars, and restaurants. The only downside is that most places are more expensive and the amount of sales people desperate for your attention. The nightlife is very vibrant.

Fun but crowded. Lovely to walk down. Full of bars and restaurants by the beach.Also great for gift shopping.A little bit crowded but no biggie.Worth going to both sitting the day, with family -and at night, with friends. Aimed only at night.
FUN walk. Quinta avenida is very long. You can get the typical tourist spots and further you get any american store there is. Also food and great drinks. It's a fun walk.

Fun Street but ..... We enjoyed an interesting walk here with my wife and kids but be prepared to be constantly harassed by the street vendors. There are plenty of interesting restaurants I shops here.

Quinta Avenida is slowly turning into shopping mall. We've been coming to Playa for the last seven years or so and it's somewhat sad to witness the ever increasing pace of development in Playa which is ruining what used to be fun laid-back experience. Prices are going up and variety is going down. Do you really need all your "western" stores here? Or 5 of the same shop on one mile of the street?

For Quinta Avenida and PDC as such - be sure this is how you want to spend your vacation. 5th av and PDC as such is geared towards "gringo turists" and prices are hicked an extra because of this.Was surprised how poor and narrow the beach was, packed to last sq feet. Having travelled round Yukutan before and been Tulum just before, this was a bit overwhelming. Going to Cozumet helps, but only barely. If your priorities are shopping and partying maybe this may be ok for you.

Beware!. Been in PDC in 2009. So we wanted to see if it changed! Indeed but not in a good way. There are more fancy stores, restaurants, shopping centers and so on. But the feeling/glimpse we got after 2 hours there make us return to our hotel! I really didn't expect that. My wife and I been offered cocaine and weed 10 times !!! We were like tourist meat for sellers even if we know that they are pushy but this time too much pushy! Police nowhere to be seen! People almost nude walking in the middle of the steets.Actually, as I said even if there are nice stores and restaurants...I found the place dirty and unsafe. I was very suprised of the turn out of the place.

High pressure sales. This place is a horrible place to go. The vendors hassle you relentlessly and are actually very rude and mean if you don't buy from them. We had a better time shopping at the cancun airport.

Entertaining place to stroll. We have been here a few times and always love the stroll down this street to see what's happening. There are lots of pubs, restaurants, shops, and entertainers. Many shops are big name chains and many are single owned stores with souvenirs of Mexico.

Too crowded, too much shopping. I came to this area for the beach, not the shopping. It's extremely crowded and a constant stream of people hawking their wares/ restaurants or stores. Nothing here feels genuine or honest.
Nice Walk. Its a very nice street to walk and grab something to eat and drink. I love its lively atmosphere and its people.

The night of playa.. La quinta avenida, is where to go at night time in playa del carmen. My wife and I went there every night in our stay in playa. It is a fun, cool place to go. You will find souvenirs shops, fancy shops, restaurants, bars.You can walk up and down and you will see lots of different things.
5th ave. 5th ave is the heart of playa with nice restaurants and little shops , bar and clubs it's we're everyone in playa takes a stroll down its the place to be and be seen and meet up with friends

Nice shopping both local and international shops!. Very nice street with shops, restaurants and bars at both sides. You can find souvenirs and local shops, as well as international brand stores. There is also an indoor shopping center.

Cool Avenue . Because tourists stay at resorts when at Mexico, for that reason I recommend a walk on Quinta Avenida, you will kind of get a Mexican experience. It is beautiful full of people, full of laughter, vendors, and so much more. I strongly recommend a visit at this avenue. You get to see how hard these people work to make living. I loved it.
Heart of Playa. In the middle of all the holiday festivities! Playa is very exciting at this special time of the year and Quinta Avenida is the best place to experience all that Playa has to offer!

Typical Pedestrian Plaza. Quinta Avenida is a very colorful but ultimately average pedestrians plaza. Many restaurants and shops with all kinds of overpriced goods. Go up to 10th or 15th Avenue and you can find many of the same items cheaper. Tulum also has better prices and more character. It is a fun place to people watch.

Mexican/Italian/Seafood/Icecream/Massage/Tour/Souveneir Shop. THIS IS IT! The entire boardwalk, 1 of 7 things. . . And along your nice stroll, no less than 100 people yell at you as if you are a walking dollar sign. It´s frustrating to look like a rich tourist when you are a humble local that doesn´t want to be swindled by shopkeepers and their gringo taxes and exorbitant fees!!!!!! And some of these people are somewhat rude at times to women, catcalling and such, or gawking, as if you are on parade for them. PS, shouting: ¨Lady! Lady!¨ is considered RUDE to an English speaker! ´Miss´ (like señorita) is the polite way of catching a female´s attention. ´Excuse me Miss´ is the best way.

Walked down everyday. Crass capitalism run amok! Also, those manholes overflowing? Smells like sewage. Problem is that greedy over development has overwhelmed any sense of responsible city planning. This place will be unvisitable soon.

Worth the visit!. We stayed at The Royal and were just a block of 5th ave. It was a great spot to walk around and catch the local scene! Felt very safe and lots of great stores: chain stores, local stores, bars and restaurants. Check it out!
Great concept. I like the idea of a walk only avenue, The hagglers were a pain in the butt but just be polite and turn them down and they go away

Lots of shopping, food, and fun. Traditional Mexican shops mixed with modern options as well. Good for every budget and taste. Be ready for lots of people offering you their wares and services. Bring your best bargaining skills!
Shopping duty free . Great brands, lovely restaurants, friendly shopkeepers, if you take your passport and ticket details you can pay for gifts less duty paid.

Way to crazy. Drugs drugs and drugs... walking down this road you get the question at least 10 times which is around 10 times to much as I've never had or will use drugs! Just because I've got my arms covered in tattoos and I've got a surfer look it doesn't necessarily mean that I'm a drug addict. Sad story of Mexico....Good shopping though..
Fun for all ages. Traveled with our young daughter and we loved walking down Quinta avenida! Lots of shops and restaurants. Always felt safe and never threatened by anyone!
Too touristy . I have always loved playa, I got married there! Sadly it is way too touristy and way too hip. I loved it for its little town, authentic spirit a d it is gone.
Lots of shops around. 15 blocks of shoping and eateries...if ir with family ...its good place to visit..convienient location
Very touristy place, but lots of different restaurants. Restaurants are great, but vendors bugging you during your meal is just too much.... Fun to explore the first night, but gets old afterwards

Too much of everything. VERY touristic,VERY expensive,VERY non worthy visiting.I felt the walk in the fifth like i was walking at an american road,non a mexican one.Did not know the place was sooooooo touristic...if you wanna feel Mexico do not go there..If you want to empty your pockets in the heart bit,paying money for nothing,go.Not my kind of travelling at all.

Not so quaint any longer.... My husband and I have been going to Playa del Carmen for over 20 years now. Then, it was a sleepy fishing village and slowly became a quaint town with 5th Avenue being one of the highlights of our trip. Even staying at an all-inclusive resort, we walk 5th every evening. Our latest trip was in the beginning of this month, December.Over the past year or so, 5th Avenue has become way too commercialized, thereby pushing the small local store owners out of the area due to rents being so high. We know many of the shop owners and, unfortunately, they had to close their stores due to the higher rents. There are very upscale stores there now including a full-blown mall to include Forever 21 and even Michael Kors. Starbucks is even there now.Please, don't get me wrong, we still enjoy going to 5th but seeing all the new development is truly a turn off. We will always walk 5th but not as often.

Great Walk About. Don't let anyone put you off walking down 5th avenue. The traders try to get you into there shops but they are really very friendly and do not offend in any way. You can't help but be amused at some of the sales pitches that they have like " I don't know what your looking for but I have for you" There are also some good buys to be had.
a shoppers dream.. Something for everyone lots of shops, stalls , restaurants and bars.Go down in the evening there is live music in lots of bars and all the shops and stalls are open late.
hustled. be careful... men will come up to you & tell you that they are your waiter or bellboy from the hotel..they see your wristband. THEY AREN'T!!! Just overly aggressive..not harmful!

Must see in the area. Took a day trip here just to shop for souvenirs and boy did we find them! On the cheap too! Price haggling is what these people live for. Word of advise though, I do not suggest the back alley or upstairs tattoo parlors they try so hard to sell. Yikes! Fun place if you like shopping and restaurants though!

Lots of shopping and places to eat.. Over the past few years that I have been coming back, 5th avenue has grown and changed, with big influxes of foreign money and foreign outlets. The place is now packed with Victoria's secret, Sephora, and all the other stores I could find in any mall back home. Step a few blocks either side, however, and the charm returns.

It could be a fantastic experience. it is the local PRI political party which has totally missed the final thing of what a pedestrian streets is for, comercial is fine but it is a complete disaster to have only one street conctrating all the income of a great city, vendors have really bad impact but in stead local government SHOULD CREATE OTHER NEW SPACES and more equal oportinities for the complete city not just LA QUINTA

Fun to walk with friends, family or as a couple!. Whether you are by yourself or with someone, Fifth Avenue has something to offer for everyone. Great walk to help digestion and great shopping on the way.

Waste of time.. Took a cab from our all inclusive on a grey morning, just for some quick shopping. Nothing there you can't get.anywhere else, including the airport gift shops, and for the same prices. Very bothersome salespeople, as stated by others here. Ended up at a small mall about 5-6 blocks up from where we started and shopped at a couple of boutiques and a forever 21. Nothing I couldn't have done back home. Altogether spent about two hours there, and felt like it was wasted time.

Bargain shopping paradise. Don't pay full price for anything! The places very often are able to negotiate prices for many of the products! Especially when it comes to jewelry, if you go to brand names store then forget it they have fixed prices and rates you can't change, but try the street dealers mom and pap stores and you can get great deals! Definitely a great place to do some shopping !

Nice very commercial too much souvenirs. It's a long way full of shops, restaurants, posada and bars. It looks very nice green with low houses maybe too much souvenirs shops, they sells always same things.
Great atmosphere. Great for shopping and the best margaritas!!! The closer you are to the pier you find better prices and better exchange rate for your $1.

A Place for a Stroll. Quinta Avendia . aka 5th Ave used to be a great place to hang out. Not it reminds me of Cancun with big American style malls. I thought I came to Mexico, not Miami. Old Playa del Carmen is gone. Sad to see her go.

Easy strolling street. Great pedestrian street - with many 'tourist' shops, but fun to experience the local, remember to bargain in any shop, you'd be amazed at how low they'll go on prices. Good restaurants and always a place to stop for a drink!

A FUN SHOPPING AREA. Whether you are shopping for souvenirs or quality clothing, Quinta Avenida, or Fifth Avenue is the place to go in Playa del Carmen. There are also restaurants, bars and agents selling tours. Fifth Avenue is a pedestrian street and there is often entertainment and/or photo ops. The shopping area is convenient to hotels, the ferry and bus station.

The best!!!. If you like walking, seeing turists, eating in great restaurants, going to clubs, doing some window shopping (or real shopping) o just enyoing a great ambience, this is the place to go. Playa del Carmen's 5th avenune has a great vibe, there is a lot to do and a lot to see. My friends and I walked so much (it's really long) and didn't even realized it until later. At night you can do club/bar hopping. Everyone there (turists and locals alike) is very nice and happy

Fun street. Fun place in PDC to eat, shop, drink, get spa treatments, anything really! Lots of options and can keep coming back. Minus one star for all the people that keep trying desperately to sell you tours and other random crap.

Best place to visit. Oh my, this is the busiest street ever in Playa, especially at night. you can find anything you really need from food, attractions, souveneirs, brand stores. I fell in love with this street.
Go shopping. All kinds of things to find, Restaurants, take the ferry to Cozumel for the day… Always determine taxi price before you get in. Loved the experience!

Almost perfect. I totally loved the atmosphere here, especially in the nights, lots of international people, lights, music, people with costumes, etc. I could walk trough this avenue every day of my life and not getting bored. The only "but" are the stupid vendors that try to sell you things agressively and sometimes they could be rude, it's really annoying how they want you to walk in their stores and they are abusive with their prices, especially with foreign people. I hope there will be something or someone to regulate this annoying sellers because it really leaves a bad experience to some of us.

Busy spot, lots of night life!. If you are looking for endless shopping opportunities, or night life options Avenida Quinta is the place to be. The street goes on forever, with nothing but stores, restaurants, hotels and bars for as far as you can walk.One word of caution - this is an extremely poor place to get a decent night's sleep, because of the music and partying that goes until at least 2 in the morning, every day! Great place to visit, but make your hotel selections away from 5th Avenue!

The Magic of La Quinta. Great place to shop and eat...It's really the heart of Playa Del Carmen, MX. The high light of La Quinta, was being serenaded by a group of singers playing the guitar. It was romantic and unforgettable. Defiantly go in the Evening!!

Good way to spend a couple of hours. Caters to tourist which the prices show, Good place to eat as the prices a re comparable to home.They have Starbucks for good coffee.Ice cream shops and souvenir shops. Prices for excursions are much more reasonable.

No, I don't want to buy Drugs. I used to Love Playa, my wife has been visiting for over 25 years when there was only the Blue Parrot and over the years we've watched it grow - sometimes for the better - sometimes for the worse. Don't get me wrong - if you've never been to Playa - visit - it's great, but year after year the vendors get more aggressive with their selling tactics, bordering on occasion on plain rudeness and if by chance you look like I do (long hair and tattoos) be prepared to be constantly approached for drugs in all shapes sizes and varieties. This isn't the Playa I want to visit any more. I'll be back next year to visit old friends and play some golf at the great Hard Rock golfcourse, have a few beers and laughs but we'll stay in Tulum and take the Collectivo back and forth and, then go back to Isla Holbox which is what Playa used to be, quiet, laid back, polite and where you can still kick up your heels but without the hard sell from the vendors and certainly without the drug dealers.
Shopping. Fun place to shop n walk around the little town of Playa Del Carmen. Or take a short ferry ride to Cozamel

Amazing people. If your looking for something for family members is the perfect place to shop. The people are friendly and very helpful....we will be going back! Was very easy to get around and have a little bit of everything. They are adding more shops in the next year also.

A must do for us.... We always visit 5th Avenue at least once on each of our yearly trips to the Mayan. There are many fantastic beach clubs along the main beach and some great restaurants along the streets. I find prices for souvenirs are cheaper at the PlayaMart than we are able to barter for at the shops most of the time, but I have found some great prices on silver in some of the shops along 5th.

Nice concept, but annoying experience. The street is a great idea and it stretches over a very long road. I like the concept very much and it could have been an awesome experience. The problem is all the people working in the shops. We lived in Playa for 18 days and EVERY time we walked up and down the street we got contacted in average around 20 times each way. Normally you can ignore them or just say "no thank you" but there are a few of them who went way to far, calling us names when we didn't react, yelling at us for not responding and being really rude. The first times you get asked if you want a massage or if you want to look in a store, it's no problem being kind and say no. But the 20th time in 10 minutes you get asked, you don't want to respond anymore. It's exhausting. It's also very hard to have a conversation with your partner, as you are constantly interrupted by these salesmen. The worst part however, are the drug dealers. We get contacted 3-4 times each way from Calle 2 to Calle 20... Weed, cocaine, wanna get high, wanna wake up... The same people are asking you over and over again... A no is usually enough, but we've been followed, yelled after, called different nasty things. If at least the drug deals would leave us alone it would have been bearable, but after 18 days with the same crap, you get really annoyed in the end and it ruins the great experience that it could have been.

Nice shopping street. Nice and very long shopping street, but you have to be patient with all the shop owners who want you to visit their shops. Also to mention is the drug dealers along the street that offers a lot of drugs, I have to mention that it's annoying but they only ask and then let you go.

Great street shopping experience. Lots of high pressure sales, and a lot of the wares repeat themselves (silver, wrestling masks, blankets, etc), but prices are reasonable and you can bargain and get better deals. A fun experience and lots of people watching!

Shopping street for tourists - overpriced. Good street for a walk, but do not buy there anything. It is better to take a taxi and go to centro maya shopping mall which is close to playa center and the prices of tequilla and all other goods are 1/2 sometimes 1/3! Or choose any other street that is a bit away from 5th ave to get much much better prices for food, drinks, souveniers etc.
5th Avenue - PDC. Love 5th Avenue. Lots going on. Didn't like the people shouting at you to come into their store, though. Other than that, a great experience.
Average. Ok shopping trip, seem pricy for what they sell and not open to bargaining. Nice beach area and the street performers were good. Same things in the shops but was good for an afternoon out

The good and the bad. I definitely preferred Quinta (5th) Ave between Calle 26 and 38. The crowds are less, the shops and restaurants are nicer, but mostly I prefer it because the shop attendants do not try to badger and con you into their stores. The first day in Playa we made the mistake of taking 5th Ave from Calle 26 to Calle 16. There was constant harassment from store workers, even very bad cons. It was not fun. The next day we turned the different direction on the street (from calle 26 to 38) and it was a different story. No cons, no harassment. Lots of small restaurants and shops. We even did some decent tourist shopping without being badgered. The other end of 5th Avenida should learn a lesson from this. We may be tourists but we are not stupid. (BTW, if a store keeper stops you in the street and says, "Hey, it's so good to see you!! I'm the waiter from your resort, remember? I'm Roberto! So good to see you again!" just flip him off. What a stupid con.

Amazing!!. Went we the family eat churros mmmm super delicious enjoyed the beach and had some drinks, we bought cool souvenirs for friends a family at night, this place it's magical and safe, Riviera Maya it's a place that you have to come in order to experience all the feelings at the same time, love the Mexican caribean, see you in april, again.

Good shopping and fun day!. If you are in the Playa del Carmen area, don't miss this shopping and sightseeing chance. We had a blast just walking the street and taking in the culture, eating local cuisine, and shopping. It's lots of fun! The ferry to Cozumel is located just off this street too.

Shopping trip.. Quinta Avenida was interesting. Overall it was crowded with people who are a little too pushy to try to either get you in their stores or trying to sell you an excursion. My wife, daughter and I really only went into the stores that we were interested in or got invited into by the less pushy people. I think this needs to be cleaned up a bit in order to make it a little more inviting. By the time we walked up and down the whole avenue once I was done with the pushiness.....

Amazing avenue if you like very touristic places. If you like shopping and if you need to buy some souvenirs Quinta Avenida (5th avenue) is the place to go. It's the main touristic street in Playa del Carmen and it very nice and crowded.Tons of shops and restaurants to cater for all your souvenirs and food needs.It's also worth visiting the beach by the West side of the avenue. It's a very nice place to chill out and get some sun.Totally recommend.

Wonderful walk. Lots of the same stores selling the same things. Lots of restaurants. Lots of ice cream.But, we loved walking it very night. People watching is great, and it's alive!We discovered the area north of Constitution. More trees, less crowded, less stores more restaurants, narrower street.We had visited twice before as tourists from Cancun, for the night. Living there for a week made it feel like it was ours.
Nachos & Cerveza!. We did a bucket of cerveza and plate of nachos and it was great! Sat on the street. Delicious authentic flavors. Great service.

sellers shouting and to get your attention. Street vendors the practically screams and begs to have your attention and your purchase.I not enjoyed this tour, and honestly, I find it very uncomfortable and lack of respect this with the tourist.

Great place to shop!. If you want touristy things to buy, this would be the place. A lot of people are turned off by the sales people trying to get your business, but really just a wave of your hand is understandable to them. Some get a little pushy but noting like a little no thank you will do. Great place to people watch, easy to get taxi around here. The farther end of the Avenida is more westernized (they now have 2 malls with all the stores found in any US mall-disappointing) but we prefer to go to the little shops that are a few blocks away from the main Avenida.

Livelly and very Internationalized.. Walking the "quinta avenida" (5th street) is a livelly experience. You will see a lot of international tourists. Shops, restaurants, local souvenirs, boutique hotels, bars and nightlife. Kid friendly.

Mostly Tourist Junk. After all the hype I was given about 5th Avenue in Playa Del Carmen, I was disappointed. You are harassed on the street by numerous people selling either the same junk or tours that are better booked through your hotel. Thankfully I followed my policy of never going in to a store that begs for my business on the street and found a few deals and a few gems. I recommend sticking to the gallery and art shops for unique and fun items and the less busy tourist traps.

Fabulous shopping, great prices!. We (6 in our group) traveled into town on an overcast day. The shops were fun. Lots of fashions that we don't have in Colorado. Really liked all of the local crafts. The bummer were all of the vendors, excursion sellers, and hawkers of other sorts that bugged us as was tried to stroll along.

Awesome art work! . 5ta avenida was fun and very close to our resort. Lots of venders selling the same thing though and bugging you to come into their store when you walk by. There's a smaller street with some incredible art work. We actually bought 4 of Hugo Curiel paintings. His art work was seriously incredible and could be sold for thousands if he wanted to. He's been in magazines and traveled all over the world selling his art (Paris, New York, LA, Denmark, etc). It is a must to go visit his station.

A "Must Visit" if you're at any of the resorts within 30 minutes either direction. When we were in Playa del Carmen almost 20 years ago, this was a two block restaurant area. Now about 50 blocks and two miles long, this is a great destination for a daytime "change of pace" or lively nightlife.Sure there is an element of "tourist trap" to the gift shops, but there is some high end shopping, unique items and the prices are reasonable.
