Additionally, there are restaurants of all types, bars from lame to wild and music, including live acts regularly. On our five day trip to the area, we spent parts of two days in this venue and think we might increase that on our next visit.
So loud !!. A little but really amazing city !! It's possible find a lot of thing like restaurant, souvenir shop, tattoo and more.. Let have a walk. The beach itsn't beautiful better try in Tulum

Love this place :) all day experience and close to the beach. Soooo many stores and things to see, places to eat and drink of course! If you cant find the gift to take home here you are in trouble, make sure to check out the side street stores also, they can be even cheaper!

Fantastic place to shop. Not much has changed with Quinta Avenida in the past two years. Paseo Del Carmen now has a new building in the spot where all the taxis used to park. This area is now well shaded and cool in the heat. Which is nice with young kids. Many spots to chill with a treat. The main avenue is still great to shop. Make sure you wheel and deal with the vendors. Many restaurants line the streets.It cost us $30 from our hotel, twice as much as there were 6 of us.In general, great place to buy stuff before you spend money at your hotel with the vendors. $200 pesos for a Lucha Libre mask in playa vs $500 at the hotel... Enough said.

Lively place!. We loved hanging around here, and we were here on Halloween night! The place was buzzing with people from all age groups dressed up for Halloween! The colors, the energy..ohh you have to be here!!

Quinta Avenida is the place to be.... If you are looking to buy some nice upperscale stuff or your basic cultural souvenirs, go to none other than Quinta Avenida (5th avenue) Playa del Carmen. The nightlife is even wilder. The hottest clubs from CocoBongo to Palazzo to La Vaquita to Bar El Hidden to the Blue Parrot club, you will have the time of your life!
Shopping and food.... Great place to people watch, shop and eat a variety of different food. Always a good place to explore.

Crowded. All about the sales . Obviously my perspective at this time of my life
I would expect of such destination a more quite town
People is very nice but I suggest make plans ahead and get informed well, so you don't have to rely on their suggestions which tend to be over optimistic in time management and you end up wasting lots of money

Hussle Bussel. Bit of a crazy gauntlet like walk down the Avenue. We wonder, does anyone actually go into the shops when they are stalked by the owners? Generally found it quite amusing and not at all intimidating, Just odd. From honeymooner to Mr Muscles (My husband) to Do you want a shot, all very entertaining and completely harmless

North end of 5th too up-scaled. 5th Ave has been the busy strip of PDC, due to the quick access to the ferry dock. First stop for ferry goers from Cozumel. It is evident that the old ma-pa family run souvenir shop is becoming a thing of the past. More franchise establishments and expensive shops. New modern constructed buildings are replacing the quaint old rustic Mexican buildings. Progress I guess. There are still shop owners/venders chatting you as you walk and there is much of the rustic Mexico a couple of blocks off the beaten path. The North end of 5th is like in a N.A. city.

Lacking local flavour.. Having been here numerous times before, we noticed a lack of Mexican flavour. Everything is geared towards the tourists with mass produced souvenirs. It was extremely hard to find local handicrafts. Being a collector of Tequila, we found prices to be quite high here and noticed that the airport had an an amazing selection and the prices were a bit more reasonable. More American style eateries are popping up and it was hard to find traditional Mexican cuisine. Lovely walk and very safe. Be careful of buying silver as it may not be actual silver.

Becoming a bit samey. This is the main street in Playa, and a few years ago when we visited it had a very Mexican atmosphere however quite a few new shopping centres with multinationals have now arrived and it is really detrimental to the feel of the, you have to wander to the furthest ends for the best atmosphere
Great People Watching. Make Sure to see 5th Avenue at least once during your trip to this area. I was here every night during my stay

Nice to see, but...... A great place to shop while in Playa. The continuous street with a variety of shops is nice, but the constant sales people trying to get you into their store grows old pretty fast.

everything you can imagine,. This 5th Ave experience hives a taste of all that Quintana Roo has to offer, falafel, tacos, and even a Macdonald s for the faint of heart. And then there is the hour show of May as doing their 200 for high spinning experience.  Or will the drumming and dancing catch your eye.A nice walk while you wait for the a ferry to a Cozumel, unless of course you stop by Dan for a beer.

Fun, happening and super safe. The Quinta AV is several miles long full of bars, restaurants and shops. It's always fun and there is never a slow season that's why Playa is much better than any Caribbean island In playa besides of the Caribbean waters there is a lot of the Mayan culture you can visit and amazing Eco water parks and Cenote lagoons. Must visit Playa del Carmen.

Lots to see and buy. We stayed at the Royal and love being so close to town. There are so many shops and malls... Very commercialized but still nice to have around. Lots of places to sit and drink and eat, people watch and buy all those little trinkets. Love all the lights being set up now that Christmas is getting closer... And yeah, lots of people trying to get you in their shop to buy what they have
Very expensive souvenirs!. Great place to look around but very expensive to buy! Walk 2 streets to the sides and you'll find cheaper taxis food and souvenirs.

The place to go in Playa. After going to Playa for 10 years, this was my first trip back in 4 years....BIG changes! Big fancy malls have been built. And it's been built up to the north extensively. I walked it several times a day. Get off t he beaten path to experience more local flavor.

Go there, you will not be disapointed.. One of the coolest areas in Playa del Carmen. Very lively with great restaurants. Only negative is the constant pressure to check out the individual shops but that comes with the territory.

5th avenue. Fun place to shop! The vendors will heckle you to death but you pretty much just dont make eye contact and keep walking and they leave you alone. When you go in the shops they pretty much just try and sell you weed and other drugs so just stick on the main path! Haggle with the vendors unless there is a set price, one shop tried to sell us a souvenir sombrero for $45 dollars and we got her down to $15. Super fun day!
Great shopping. Great place to stroll, stop for food and lpeople watch or even shop but the hawkers get a little annoying after a while.

best Fagitas and Margaritas. La Parilla is the best for authentic margaritas( frosted of course)and Fagitas ever. It is about half down Fifth Avenue, by the dip in the road. yum, we visit there every time we go.

It is the thing to do in Playa del Carmen. So I give this a 5 out of 5 because it is the main thing to do in Playa. Tripadvisor is meant to help people decide what to do when they travel. So if you are close to town, it would be silly not to take a stroll down the avenue. There are a lot of people trying to sell you things but at least they are easily brushed off. The disadvantage of staying in an all inclusive is that when you go to a place like this, you do not want to stop for a beverage or snack, so what else is there to do? I liked the one guy who said, and maybe it was a mistake, "I have all sorts of things to sell that you do not need!"

So much change. It has been 16 months since my last visit to Playa's Fifth Ave. It is sad to see a Victoria's Secret,Sephora, Bath and Bodyworks, Michael Kors, H &M all in a span of a few blocks.Progress I guess but not a fan of this trend.

Overpriced shopping. The local shops are way over priced or are the same stores as any mall in the USA (H&M, etc.). The vendors will block your stroll down the middle of the pedestrian only street trying to get you into the stores. Restaurants are good, but for both shopping and restaurants you are better off on 10th Avenue or Constitution avenue farther from 5th avenue. The pharmacies are much lower than the USA.

Who needs Cancun when you have 5th!. I originally wasn't really planning on a full day of shopping at 5th because I didn't think there would be much but boy was I wrong! What was supposed to be only a hour long trip to walmart to grab some sun screen (because the resorts and street shops will overcharge you like hell), turned into a 7 hour shopping spree! They have pretty much anything and everything you need: high end clothing and jewelry stores to local street vendors. If you plan on buying from street vendors, beware, you go into one shop and you might get stuck there for a while. Also, to get the most bang for your buck, barter with them. If you don't feel comfortable with that, check out a couple of stores, scope out the prices and then make your selection.If you're lucky you can catch the "dance of the flyers". It's a performance by 5 men in bright traditional outfits. The men all sit atop of a tall pole and are harnessed around the waist and while one plays the flute, the others ascend as they spin upside down. It's really amazing. There's also the most amazing archways that welcome you to the beach which are 2 giant mermaids reaching out to each other. There's also fancy restaurants, pubs to street food. Make sure to buy a Nutella filled churro while you're out!

Lots of shopping and dining.. We had a great time people watching, dining and shopping Quinta Avenida. We really enjoyed the food and staff at La Adela. Food was affordable, delicious and the staff very accommodating to our large group.
Shopping. This avenue has good restaurants and shopping. the sellers can be a bit overwhelming though so you have to be careful.

A must in Playa. A trip to Playa del Carmen will never be complete without visiting 5a Av. Whether you are willing to buy the sometimes pricey stuff offered by luxury shops or dine in a fancy restaurant, the place deserves to walk across the streets at a relaxed pace and feel the Playa's charm.As a note of caution, beware the pushy sellers. They will try to sell everything, ranging from a tour, to creams, and handicrafts.

Shopping in Mexico, wonderful place to visit. Many shops with so much to see. I visited this any several times over the years and all ways found things to take home. Silver and gold, ceramics, to wood carvings and many other items
FOOD, BARS, NIGHTLIFE. 5th ave is food, shopping, bars, and a few streets with clubs going all nite. did i say shopping? over 40 blocks of one long extravaganza. be prepaid to walk and gawk

Souvenir shopping. Interesting place to visit. Souvenirs are plentiful. Bartering is a must. They start the prices about double what they will actually take. They are also very aggresive calling you to come in their shop. If you can say no, then you would have no problem.

Great shops, great food. Great shopping experience. It's a really long street full of shops, cafes, bistros and restaurants. You'll find from jewelry to souvenirs, shoes, you name it! Price? Meh! If you walk a little bit more you'll find better prices. Food is very affordable though. It's very safe at any time of day and night. There is always a lot of people walking and shops and restaurant close late so you'll never feel ackward.

We go to Playa for the Italian food!!. Quinta Avenaida is THE place for Italian food and now Argentinean too! As people retire to Playa they open restaurants so you get real international food. For under $15, typically, you get a $50 meal!

Walking up and down. Very touristy. All big brands. No point in buying all the overpriced stuff. I didn't even begin to haggle for souvenirs as what cost $5 in Chichen Itza will cost $80 here. Worth walking up and down a few times, but its not Mexico.

A lot of shopping experiences. Lot of stores to buy souvenirs and restaurants whit different types of foods, bad? The activiti s seller are a pain in the neck there are hundreds and is a little bit annoying but the place is clean and good to walk and have a nice tIme.
Love the Place. Every day I walk down 5th avenue. I enjoy the atmosphere where tourists and locals can enjoy fine food and shopping. There is everything from small shops to large modern malls.

Tons of shops. This street had a ton of shopping (shopping mall as well as souvenir shops). But with all the souvenir shops you continually saw the same things so I would recommend visiting a few to find the best prices. Walking down the street a lot of store workers will try and do everything they can to get you inside the stores. Another negative, you have to be careful with the really small shops- they follow you around pushing you to buy items, and then offer services and claim the price doesn't change but then when you're checking it out it does (and they don't give you a receipt). I learned my lesson real quick and decided to stick to the larger souvenir shops!

Great place to walk and shop!. Many shops and malls, tourists and places to take pictures. You can find many places to buy souvenirs at great prices, many things to see... the beach is not a great place though so dont waste time. But very close is a beautiful chapel made by things in the sea, its very peacefull. The bad part is that there are many people trying to sell you trip packages and they wont leave you alone easy... just pass by and say thank you.
Walking around w beer . Love the shopping little stores, walking while enjoying a beer, relax and chill. Music everywhere, people from all over the world, yet not to loud or crazy. I liked it a lot.
Great tourist spot! . The shopping is amazing here. Or if you are looking for a great place to sit and have a drink and people watch, la Quinta is the place to go!

A lot of the same things. Pretty at night with the lights, but busy. Lots of shops and some variety, however there were a lot of the same type of souvenirs at the multiple shops. I understand that many of the merchants rely on tourist to buy their products to make their living, but it got a little overwhelming and annoying that I couldn't just browse. If I even looked at an item, I was being somewhat berated with "why not buy?" I did buy some souvenirs but leaned towards the shops where people were more polite and subtle. It did look to have several beautiful restaurants and even big, modern mall. If I was there with my sister or girlfriends, I could have easily spent longer there... The streets got pretty crowded at towards the evening. Easy to find a taxi back to your resort (if you are staying at one, so don't feel like you have to go back to the same spot. We were dropped off at one end and took a return taxi at the end of 5th Ave).

Be Smart!. I've spend many hours shopping in border town markets. If I can offer you any advice it would be this:1. Shop around. Unless you don't mind spending 3x the price for the same jewelry just around the corner, shop around. The rest of the vendors aren't going to pack up and leave in a mysterious hurry and neither will your money if you're patient.2. The man in front of the shop yelling at you "Remember me? I was your bartender at xxx resort last night." He was not your bartender. Ever. Trust me on this. Sure, you'll feel bad that you don't recognize him - but he recognized the resort bracelet your wearing. You've never seen that man in your life. I swear.3. Don't drink the free tequila in the back of the jewelry store. Even if it's the almond flavored one and the most delicious thing you've ever tasted. Don't do it. When is the last time you made a good decision while drinking tequila? Never. And you know it.4. Unless you are looking for a few good blank c.d.'s without the music you think you are purchasing on it, don't buy any from the sweet young lady selling them at her booth. I've never heard such a quiet Mariachi band. Ever. Nobody has. 5. Unless you are looking to make a donation to a charity of the shop owners choosing, I wouldn't use a credit card for purchases. Chances are that shop owner is the charity. Chances are that I was that stupid. Chances are that I got ripped off. Chances are that I went back to ask about it. Chances are the guy got right in my face and yelled something about the exchange rate somehow changing in the pesos favor at the exact minute I made the purchase. Chances are I left quickly. Chances are....you shouldn't take the chance. That is all. Just don't. 6. Was it fun? Sure. If you don't mind being a sucker, re-meeting every bartender from every bar you've ever been to, drinking tequila likely made in someone's bathroom (although....I must say it's delicious and depending on your stomach strength and immunizations, worth the risk), and having stories to tell your friends. I'd go again. For reals. Only I'd leave my credit card at home, stop feeling guilty about not recognizing someone I've never met, I'd still drink the tequila and enjoy the walk.

Good Area to Shop or Eat. If you don't mind the aggressive sales push from some of the local shops, this street is a pleasant location to walk, shop or stop to eat. You can find everything from local trinkets to high end clothing stores. There are coffee and ice cream shops and a number of restaurants with outdoor, or open air seating. You are only about a block from the ocean. If you need a taxi to return to your hotel, there are taxi stands at several of the cross streets. Fun place to visit if you want to check out Playa Del Carmen.

Beautiful, typical but so chaotic. Hello,I pulled that I liked very much is very evocative as vision. we in Milan paraganare can it to our crammed full buenos aires courses from 50 years ago… of places that sell all the same things, bar, chioeschetti products homemade and a lot more… the only thing he is an annoying little and the attitude of the sellers are very insistent on after all

Love the Carnival Midway experience!. Be prepared for VERY aggressive sales people; they go from imploring/encouraging you to visit, to harassment and insults. It's usually all in good fun, and they're willing to negotiate price on everything. Plenty of food options as well - we love Sur Steakhouse and Casa Adela - go there every year.
Loved 5th avenue. Lots of shops for every taste. Including bars and restaurants by the dozen, even had a McDonald's bought some lovely keepsakes.
Nothing special other then the ocean. No great deals to be made unless you want to take a chance on a cheap massage. Interesting statues along the way

tourists beware. if glitz is what you are looking for, this is it. Total tourist trap stuff, way to many people. I was in Playa when it jad less then 3000 people and now it is pushing 200K. Progress?? Not in my book, but if this is your 1st trip, it is a must see as it does have some very interesting places.. Just no longer my cup of tea.

Shopping Galore. A fun place to have a drink and people watch. It gets annoying to be constantly bothered by the shop owners though. They would likely sell more if they left people alone. I usually don't shop very much in Playa because it is annoying to be on 5th Ave.

check out all the stores -- I bought some amazing jewelry -- I wish I would have bought more. this is a great street to stroll and look for souvenirs, gifts and eat. we shopped for hours but it is rather warm in the summer!!!
So mexico. it is a lovely place a must when you are here just dont trust in the sellers when they say they know you from the hotel.

Beware. Cuidado. Warning.. We were duped into buying fake jewelry. Shortly thereafter, we stopped for lunch and researched the "rare" stone we had purchased only to find it was not mined by the Mayans...it is only found in Turkey. Needless to say, we went back for a refund and we got rejected. The guy told us we could come back the next day if we wanted our money back. Instead, we are disputing the credit card charge.Lesson learned (and we read that several others had this same experience)...if you opt to shop on 5th Avenue in Playa and someone approaches you and claims to be the waiter who served you at your hotel the day before, it's a scam. It's a scam to make you feel like he's this great guy who is personal enough to remember you and invite you into his "mom's" store...(he is just working there on his one day off). Then, he'll give you this great deal, but "you better remember him and tip him well when he serves you at the hotel the next day." Whatever...don't buy jewelry in Mexico. If you do, only pay what you would be comfortable paying if you knew it was fake!
expensive. same as everywhere else you get hassled to go into the shops. couldnt beleive how expensive things are here to buy.

Worth it if you're staying in PDC. We stopped in the evening on the way back from XCaret. Like everyone says, it's full of expensive souvenir places and a ton of restaurants--- a LOT of Italian, and many Mexican, some with an ok array of veg options.Good place for a stroll but I wouln't go out of my way to go there.
Extremely expensive. We walked through this area while visiting Playa. All of the shops were extremely expensive - $30 for a thin beach towel. After seeing it once, I'm not sure I would go back.
great place to walk around. this street is only used by pedestrian and it is great to walk around, many stores, bars, restaurants, malls. Crowded and very alive

Crappy touristic sales. "My friend come look at my store, do cheap almost free."
I hate these kinds of places. All that they have on this street is cheap touristic crap. Not authentic at all.
Very nice. It's great to go by yourself, friends, date or even kids. There are many many shops and it's a very nice place to walk around at night. It's also very nice for food.

Great shopping. Loved staying so close to 5th avenue. It is great fun just to walk the streets and see all the street vendors try to sell their wares. Also saw some great entertainment like a Michael Jackson impersonator and mariachi bands. Great shopping for souvenirs and sundries. Lots of great places to eat and drink.

Wonderful experience to see the local side of Playa del Carmen. Aggressive shop owners are outnumbered by respectful, professional shop owners. A lot of choices and opportunities to buy souvenirs and small forgotten necessities.
Shopping street. I don't know what else to say. There are high end shops and guys hawking crap. It is a pretty stroll with lots of trees in sections. It is safe and just blocks from the beach.

Not that long but nice. I expected to see something spectacular but it was just normal at least for me wasn't that great as I read before going there
You should go for sure because it is an touristic place but just for that
Quirky. A melting pot of restaurants, shops, bars, ice-cream places. Very noisy and lots of touters inviting you to try their place.
Too much garbage. there is too much garbage on the street to enjoy what was once a beautiful place, seems the city is more interested in the people who park wrong than keeping the streets clean

Good walking street but so commercial. Loved that you can walk this street day & night without any cars/bikes. Good for shopping but it's so commercial & many stores are selling American items with a big price tag. Shop at the Mexican markets only. Massages were on average $50 US per/hour & not worth it. Many great restaurants both north & south on 5th ave. I preferred the south end as not as busy & pushy.

Love the North End!. We stayed in the north end just off 5th and loved it there. Much quieter than the busier section of 5th, and several great restaurants as well. Aventure Mexicana is one of the many boutique hotels located there we would recommend.

Two visits and had a blast!. If you're in the area, you should definitely check this out! Its very safe with all kinds of shops and restaurants. We went to a few restaurants and they were both good and inexpensive. I will say we saw a purse snatching and the guy didn't make it 50ft. Security and police are everywhere so if anything goes down, they are on it in a heartbeat! Have fun!
The heart of Playa del Carmen. Definitely a must visit! its the main street in playa with many bars, souvenir shopping, restaurants, stores and desserts! Full of life no matter which day of the week!

Need something to do?. It's a long strip of a bunch of overpriced restaurants and a lot of souvenir shops and stores like H & M, forever 21. Fun to people watch but coming from the US the last thing I want to do is emerse myself in that. We walked off these paths and found other places to each much cheaper and better.
Touristy commercial fun street. Gotta go at least one time during your trip to Playa. Quinta is a pedestrian only street filled with restaurants, shops and more shops and restaurants.

Walking downtown Playa del Carmen, take off your wristband!. Your hotel wristband is your calling card. One look at it and no one will leave you alone. You cannot just look around, you cannot take a step without being haggled. We could have skipped this all together. It was much more fun shopping the stands at Chichen Itza than it was heading to Playa del Carmen. We just wanted to leave. There are plenty of stores from Mexican souveniers to H&M and department stores, but you won't have a moment to even think about going to one, because everyone will be beckoning you in and throwing out prices.

Lovely to walk down and to shop but.... It was lovely to walk around and grab a few bargains and some last minute souvenirs but do be ready to be constantly pestered to buy items from shops as well as getting asked if you would like to buy any weed or coke. We got asked about 4 times and I was ready to tell someone where to go by the end of the walk!
it improved a lot. We were downtown for a walk and saw that they made improving to the 5th avenue , it looks really nice

Quinta Avenida is the main shopping area in Playa del Carmen and is a pedestrian shopping district. I have shopped here and eaten at a number of restaurants here. There are quality goods available here but you need to be willing to bargain and know what you want to buy. They recognize the marks by the all-inclusive/resort wrist bands, in part. I have purchased leather goods here and my wife has purchased jewelry and clothes and I also got a simple hammock. No major complaints other than the harassment. I think it gets better in some spots. So enjoy, bargain and eat well.

Get ready to get annoyed!. While this is the main area to shop be prepared to get asked to come into each and every store along the way. Not any great bargains to be had and be sure to know your silver if you want to buy any. Go to the MEGA to buy tequila if you are staying for a bit as the prices are incredible.
Great walk. you will visit many stores and restaurants with variety of food, be careful during rainy days, they get little rivers with the downpour.

It's a trap!!!. 5th Avenida is just a simple rip off and a trap for the turists as cruisers who do not have enough time to discover more of Playa. It is basically a huge market with items that appear to be "local" but are actually made in China :D Loads of people will bother you with "hey guys, check the store, almost free..." and other pick lines... Be cautious though. One example speaks for all. I was searching for some bracelet made of blue stones that are Yucatan's typical jewelery. Saw one on the table in front of the shop. Asked what the price was (as there were no price tags). The seller took me to the shop, showed me other stuff and said that the price was usually 700 MXN, but just for me it is only 675 MXN. I said I did not have that much money on me and that I might come back for it later on. As I was leaving the store, he offered me gradually price of 400 MXN, 300 MXN, and when I was outside, he said that if I really liked it, he could give it to me for 200 MXN. What a scam.... If you do wish to purchase items here, on Avenida 5th, DO NOT accept the price they say as the first one. Pretend to leave, see what you can negotiate. And generally, just don't go for the items without the price tags. As far as the restaurants go, the prices there are aproximately 3 times higher than in usual restaurants, a bit further from the sea, but that's kinda expected.
Love the walk. Plenty of shops, restaurants, people from all over the world walking there. I felt safe all the time.
Nice walk!. Good restaurants, there are several good options. watch out for "semi deals" they will promise the moon!!Nice,safe envitonment to walk around even with kids!!

Tourist trap. Clearly one doesn't go to Playa Del Carmen seeking a true Mexican experience and 5th Avenue is the expected tourist trap. This pedestrian only street is lined with shops and restaurants - some local and some large American chains. Be prepared to be bombarded by shopkeepers trying to persuade you into their store. Most are polite about it, but some not so much. We found that a simple no gracias worked fine most of the time, as long as you kept moving. I didn't end up buying anything and my husband wasn't too impressed with being offered drugs and women by a few men lining the street. I'd skip this area and check out the streets further east, away from the beach.

Interesting Shopping Experience. PDC 5th Avenue has high end stores combined with Mexican street shops/vendors. Just be aware that they will do everything that they can to get you into their shops even pretending to recognize you for your resort. If you like to negotiate prices, then this is the place for you to shop!

Honeymooners. Many stores, mexican commerciants but happy and friendly people! We loved it! We really enjoyed our holiday in Mexico and we were happy to discover hiddens cenotes And beaches from Quintana Roo!

Great place to shop!. This strip is a great place to shop. There were plenty of options and shops willing to strike a deal so I didn't feel like I overpaid what so ever. There is everything from food trucks, to ice cream shops, souvenir stores and even high-end shopping. There were also neat statues and plenty of colorful buildings so bring a camera as we got great pictures!

Nice place for a stroll. This street has shops and restaurants that look wonderful. We stopped in many of the shops and checked out all the items. Nice variety of local items to chose from and the vendors are all very nice.

Don't listen to the salty reviewers!. As a tourist you have to know you will stand out in Mexico bracelet or no bracelet. It was raining the days I went so I took the resort umbrella which had their moniker stamped on the canvas lol. As a single woman travelling alone I did get the persistent vendors trying to lure me in. Even got the "hey I work at Princess I was your waiter remember me" line. You just have to politely say no thanks and keep it moving. I never felt in danger or threatened walking fifth avenue alone. While most shops are bulk generic souvenir joints there are jems hidden in between like the corazon shop which sells handmade treasures. Further down the road you will find less outdoor vendors and more mid to high end shops. I actually went back a second time! Loved it!WARNING there is a restaurant at the corner of 5th and 20th on the west side of the road do not eat there, the food was so bland it was the worst 300 pesos spent on my trip.

Just for fun. We took a cab from Paradisus La Perla, as a way to get out of our hotel and see some of the local sites. It was overall an enjoyable time, however the people selling their merchandise, were extremely pushy and would not take no for an answer. We just got to the point where we ignored them, unless there was something in their store that looks interesting. I must have had at least a dozen people try to sell me drugs. But I also have a lot of tattoos, so I MUST look like I was interested in that.

Disappointed. I remember coming here 9 years ago, and it was a slightly more authentic experience. Obviously it's all very touristy, tchotchke stuff, but sometimes that's what you want when you're on vacation. Sadly, it is being overtaken with Bath & Body Works, Forever 21, and American Eagle stores. Many of the cute, Mexican shops I remember are gone.
Busy Shopping. All the vendors are extremely friendly; however, they will not bargain with you if you have pesos. I found out the hard way. If I used my USD, yet, but with pesos, nope.

Overpriced junk and rude vendors. 5th Ave in PDC certainly looks interesting in pictures, and definitely has a large selection of decent restaurants (if you're willing to pay the 20-30% price increase over restaurants on 10th Ave). However for shopping, it is a gauntlet of overpriced junk sold by rude vendors who will try every trick in the book to sell you their junk at the very highest price possible. They will lie to you and pretend you've met before, and they will tell you their stuff is hand-made when you can see by looking at it that it was machine-made. Just stay away. Cruise through on your way to the beach.
Once is enough. Great. for people watching. I enjoyed seeing the ladies trying. To walk the cobble. stones in their. elevated. Highheels. One walk through is enough

Fun shopping and delicious lunch. I could do without all the hassle. This was our second trip to Playa del Carmen and also our second trip to 5th Avenue. A few lessons learned that made this experience much more enjoyable than the last. Rule #1, if you are wearing a resort bracelet, turn it inside out or cover it. The first time we went a lot of people kept asking us if we remembered them because "I was your waiter at (insert resort name here) last night. Once they couldn't read the bracelet, this nearly eliminated the harassment. Then it was a lovely stroll down the avenue. We shopped mostly at the large stores, where we discovered that the prices for most items were only slightly less than our resort gift shop, but it was fun and there is some beautiful Mexican artisanship
Picturesque and main attraction.. Many souveneir shops, restaurants and bars. Nice ambience. Fun at night. Must go to if in Playa del Carmen.

Nothing worth seeing.. A lot of the vendors harass passerbys as they walk down Fifth Ave. The stores don't carry any specialty items and the items are usually marked up because tourists don't know the actual cost of the items. I can't tell you how many times I was approached by young men asking if I would like to buy hard drugs, which I found a little frightening. 3/10 would not go again.

A lot of "puestos". This place was okay. There was nothing more than what I have already seen here at a flea market in Houston. The strip goes on for what seems like forever. If I could reverse time, I would totally skip this place. Not worth the 72 dollar cab ride from and back to the resort.

Love It or Hate It Type Of Place. 5th Avenue is a love it or hate it type of place..You can spend as little or as much as you want and take a few hours or all day about it. There are budget souvenir shops and supermarkets and newer malls with high end stores. Lots of ,bars and restaurants of varying price and quality.The biggest problem is being hassled by the souvenir and silver jewellry shop owners. You just have to grow a thick skin and employ selective hearing. We got a shuttle bus from our hotel for 50 pesos per person and it was worth for the experience although I could not say it was spectacularly better than other tourist streets we have visited.
Interesting city.. The city was interesting, but we were approached by a man trying to sell drugs. Good restaurants and shopping.
Lots of Shops. I found an awesome store here, bought some silver accessories, loose tea, and ate a great lunch at a cafe. It is worth a visit to browse and stroll through.

Nice at night. It's full of restaurants and small shops, but at daytime I think the sales men just make it annoying to walk there. So go there in the evening, and make sure you go further than Mamitas (calle 28-ish). There are some really nice places around calle 38.

Neverending Treasure of Stores!. Oh my goodness, it just goes on and on and on! I had great fun and laughed off the numerous ways the vendors and shopkeepers try to lure you in. Very entertaining and not to be taken seriously. And never, ever never pay what they are asking! Make a game of it and have fun!

Eh.... Eh- went solo for shopping. If I had to do it again, I would skip it. Not much different goods than what was offered on the resort. And since I was alone- the shop keepers were pushy. One keeper even acted like he knew me from the resort when he clearly saw my resort bracelet, and physically tried to guide me into his shop. The area was beautiful to explore, but that can be done without traveling into the shopping district. Expensive, and not many deals. Sorry, wanted this to be more fun than it was.
Free entertainment. This avenida foul of entertainment,restaurants bars New buildings with high quality of stores,foul of musicians,you find diferents caracters of peoples
Neat place. Ver nice to explore downtown but the shop owners will drive you nuts. Everyone wants you in their shop..Other than that it's a fun day of shopping.

Touristic, fun, relaxing . Went to playa del Carmen and stayed next to Quinta. We loved it! Even though our baby daughter was with us, we went t restaurants and bars. Quinta avenida has it all plus it is super close by the beach. Totally enjoyed it! We really enjoyed having margaritas there, in several places all great !
Love it here !!! Best party experience ever.. Best party experience ever. i went to coco bongo and stayed out all night on 5th ave. Many local mexs they were awesome and the food was great.

Shop and bars street. La Quinta avenida was right next to our hotel (paradisus la perks) , so we decided to go for a walk and do a little gift shopping. Was pretty nice to walk over there. There is all kind of shops (gift shops, clothes shops like desigual, h&m, forever 21... Etc) and bars and restaurants. There is this famous club called "coco bongo" in the area too. The beach is right there with some nice places to have a drink or a snack. The only thing that I didn't like is this vendors trying to convince you alllll the time, so I kind of felt a little overwhelmed. Also the ones that offer you weed and cocaine like they are selling candy ... Over all I liked the walk and the environment itself. Was cool.

tourist meca. If you want to walk down almost two miles of shops, restaurants, jewelry stores, tour hawkers, bars, street vendors, money changers, condo sales, hotels, coffee shops, T-shirt stores, leather goods, ect; ect; This is where to go. Some are good, some not so much. A great place to pick up those last minute gifts, or find some real nice artisan goods. Did I say 2 miles of it?
Great shopping. Great shopping with high end stores and tourist shops. There are also lots of spots along the way to stop for food and drinks.
LOTS to DO!!!. Wow!!! Amazing strip! Lots of places to see, eat, sit down, and chit chat with people. There is an excellent selection of restaurants to eat at. There's alot of shopping to do!

Singular atmosphere!. Day or night, this is the spot to be!From handcrafted items to fancy shopping you can find everything here.Get a sorbet on Aldo's, enjoy a beer on any bar available or hit a night club,ENJOY hand made fresh cigars from Lauro's, get a tattoo at any tatto shop, listen to jazz or a group of electric violins interpreting "Metallica" or "Nirvana" in the corners of the various streets.Hire some tours to eco-friendly activities and parks or hire an archeological tour visiting great prehispanic mayan pyramids.The bus leaves you right from the airport here, then you can walk a couple of blocks to your hotel or restaurant.!The only "wierd" thing is there are several "local" promoters offering "a smoke" or " something for the party" (if you know what I mean.....yes, I'm talking about drugs) and NO POLICE is getting rid of them. They're safe and you just answer "No, thanks", but it is hard to believe that in a country fighting druglords as Mexico does, they offer drug to tourists just like that.

Variety walk at Quinta Avenida. You can walk and shop and relax, eat, drink and simply have fun. Close to the beach. Though if you want a great white and lovely beach you have to go to Tulum. There at the beach of Playa del Carmen you can have massages. Loved it and very relaxing.

5th Avenue - it's ok but nothing special. We visited the much hyped 5th Avenue in Playa Del Carmen when we decided that we should go and see what the fuss was aboutTo be honest it isn't, IMHO, that special, lots & lots of stores selling the usual tourist tat, a nice Senor Frogs merchandise store, a Tequila museum, some very good designer stores. a few malls and the rest is bars & restaurantsThe biggest issue we had was the store owners constantly harassing you to come into their store - if we wanted to come in we would - stop with the shouting at usAlso their laughable attempts to tell us that they work in the hotel we were staying in - we made a hotel up & the shop owner proceeded to tell us how he had served us the evening before in hotel restaurant - really!!!!Also please be aware that you will be asked several times if you wanted illegal substances - a firm no thank you or naw (in broad Scots accent) in enough for them to go awaySo as they Romans might say - we went, we saw but we won't be back - we have seen better shopping areas in other Caribbean islands

The main shopping street. Heaps of shops along this street plus vendors selling tours and shows etc. Most places take pesos or dollars... and everything on this street is quite expensive ! Tourist prices! !

Hecklers. I enjoyed the atmosphere of the crowds but the shop owners were such bad hecklers that it made me uncomfortable at times. Most stores had the same merchandise. I only found a few stores to be really cheap. Got some souviners for family and friends. Would I go again? Probably.. but at least I know what to expect next time.
Fun to walk around and check out the shops. This is a good area to get out and buy some gifts to bring back home and grab a bite to eat. There is a beach close by that is worth checking out!

Shopping and sun...who could ask for more?. Shopping on 5th Avenue is anything but boring. Looking for souvenirs and locals to banter with? Youve come to the right place. The main shopping area is well maintained and clean. There is even a Starbucks for a refreshing piece of home.If you are not good at saying no I would not recommend going to the street vendor area as they can be persistent.

Touristy. This is a decent place for sightseeing, but not authentic Mexico. Same doodads of questionable quality for sale in every other shop, and you will constantly be harassed by proprietors. Reasonable prices and decent food can be had. Don't miss the ferry area, there are dancers and a very cool large sculpture.
Decent Excursion. Ok, a few unique stores to check. Liquor can be cheap. Pick up a return taxi off this street as the taxi is traveling. Pay in pesos and you will save a bunch!

Great tourist/shopping/fun area. Everything one might want to buy eat or enjoy in a great promenade environment. Old buildings and sparkling new shopping malls, clubs & bars, dancing and plenty of great food.

Awesome. So many shops and restaurants/bars. Even more fun at night! I went to the Blue Parrot and Mandala night clubs on two different nights. There was a foam party at the Blue Parrot that was so much fun. Had bottle service at both clubs. All the little shops pretty much have the same merchandise. There is a big shopping mall there too but I did not venture in. Have most of those stores in my hometown so I was not interested.

Tourist Trap. Your typical Mexican tourist trap complete with hecklers. A 'pedestrian only' main strip with shops, shops, and more shops. Plus, more restaurants, cafes and eateries than you can count. If you go off the strip away from the beach to 10th or 15th, you will be able to eat or shop at half the cost, but you will sacrifice the flair, fun and action of being on 5th.

The main attraction in Playa. Stayed 6 days at Playacar hotel which is situated at the begining of the quinta, we had three rainy days so we spent most of our time walking this magnificent streetLots of nice mexican bars, clothing and silver jewelry wich their sellers are the most anoying sellers on the street, just egnore them if you do not plan of buying.  The south side where the street begins is nicest one if you like brand namesOverall if you stay in Playa, you will spend a lot of time in the "Quinta"

Nice walk but annoyed. We decided to take a walk and go shopping, the shops were nice but some of the vendors got annoying. They would say hey we were your waitors last night at our resort to try to get us to come look at there merchandise, but they were not our waitors. We probably would have looked at there stuff but after bothering us we just ignored them and walk on by.

Ave. 5th in Playa. Your trip would not be complete without going to 5th Ave and seeing the many shops. I wore my shirt the is red and has Georgia written on it, that made it lots of fun as shop owners would make note of me coming. BE AWARE on any merchant who says, hey remember me, I was your waiter last night...liar. also if you like hand rolled cigars you will be in heaven if not you will be told its a great time to start about 20 times. most shop owners were in fun.
Charming. Prices are more reasonable then in the shopping malls. If you want to take a taxi, negotiate the price before you enter. They accept bartering.

Must-do if in area.. This touristy shopping district still has enough local flare to be fascinating. There are many local eateries here, too. The high-end mall is at the far end nearest the ferry stop. Cabs are handy a few spots along the avenida. Ice cream. Starbucks. Pharmacies, etc. Many silver shops. Pop into the old Catholic church near the ferry, as well. Darling. (Nuestra Senora del Carmen)

AMAZING SHOPPING. Just be careful when in the small shops. They are narrow and not easy to move around it. I also picked on item to get a better look at it and it was greasy and slippery. it slipped out of my hand and it fell to the floor. I paid for it. but not sure if the greasiness was a coincidence or not.
nice Shopping plaza. A log street with many stores bars coffe shops restaurants and clubs, the only drawback is the constant hounding by shop assistants.
Great morning out. Good for buying those souvenirs, having a coffee and seeing how the Mexicans live. Shop keepers very friendly and never felt intimidated or threatened.
Nice evening walk. It was a good evening spent walking down the 5th Avenue. There was Mariachi playing Mexican music on the street, very nice.

a trip down 5th Avenue in Playa !!. Always a thrill to spend the day on 5th avenue, although going at night presents a totally different view as the sun sets the lights go on and it takes on a different persona ! The "hawking" is still the same ie: lady, come into my shop and let me rip you off" or " we are cheaper than walmart" !! can be lots of fun .You can walk as far as you want, probably 4 miles long. We try to get to Constitution Avenue but that's a long way. LaParilla, one of our favorite restaurants moved down there so maybe worth the taxi ride there and walk as far back as you can until you want to get a taxi back to your hotel! The new mall ( a couple years old now) is right there too, (bathrooms up the escalator) gorgeous mall but I think all the improvements, like the NEW upscale stores sort of ruin the downtown flavor of old Playa, which I liked better. but there must be money being spent there.

Good for half a day . 5th Avenue has changed a lot since our last visit in 2011, lots more shops especially high end and chain stores. Great for us Brits as we don't have many of the U.S. Stores like Victoria's Secret, sephora and forever 21 at home. The Michael Kors store was cheaper than in England. Yes, the owners of the touristy type shops try and encourage you to come in but just saying 'no thanks' they didn't pursue you. Some of them were actually quite funny! Make sure you go down the side streets and the road that runs parallel too, we found nicer bars and restaurants than the ones on the Main Street. Id recommend El Tapas and Company - 2 streets back. Drinks were very cheap in all 3 bars we tried and they all had good wifi. This is a good trip for a half day or half day plus time for a meal, when you're up for a change of scenery from the hotel. You can get a taxi at a lot of places along the road and ask the price back to your hotel before you get in if you're worried. We got a cab for $25 back from here to the Valentin hotel to give you an idea of fare, it was $30 from the hotel to here!
To pushie at the shops but restaurants good.. OK for a quick visit but sometimes the hassle from the shops can grate and tended to be expensive.Although the bars and restaurants were good.

Anchor of Playa delCarmen. 5th Avenue is filled with small street side vendors and the inevitable invasion of American retailers. The Avenue is under constant renovation with shopping mall areas replacing older restaurants and vendors. We only hope it doesn't lose its charm in all this renovation. Great people watching with a mix of cruise ship folks, land bound tourists and locals. At night the lights come on north of 10 street creating a beautiful street scene. Lots of fun bars on the side streets.

Street vendors galore. Lots of people trying to sell a variety of touristy things. Some are really good deals, but as always, buyer beware. Don't be scared to negotiate. Never pay the first price they give you, you can bargain with them. If you like bargain hunting, you will love it.

Great for shopping and fun!. Lot of stores to shop for souvenirs, clothes, jewelry, etc. Places to eat for any taste - Mexican, French, Italian, Asian. Got tired - get a massage @ $50 for 2, or get to the shore which is one or two blocks away. Great place to talk to people and make new friends. Money Exchange are all along the avenue and are at a descent rate - be aware that paying/bargaining in peso will save you a significant amount.

Buzzing. Anyone who has ever been to 5th Avenue will agree that this is as good as it gets.You can spend as little or as much as you want and be all day about it. There are budget shops and high end stores,bars and restaurants.There is only one problem and that is being hassled by the souvenir shop owners.It is however a must do experience.
Our honeymoon. We like the quinta avenida you can find a lot of stuff we got some tacos and Starbucks with free WiFi lol ;)

Best Pedestrian Walk Street Ever!. I lived in Playa for 5 years, walked this street MANY times. It's lined with shops, bars, cafes, restaurants, nightclubs, beach clubs, and locals and tourists walking up and down all times of day and night! So much to see and do. You will pay tourists prices on this street that's for sure. For the "neighborhood/local Playense" deals, best to go up towards 30 Ave. But if you like the hustle and bustle and lively walk, you will never be disappointed walking 5th Ave "Quinta Avenida"

Shopping and Drinking. I love La Quinta it's so hip and fun. You can find everything in this lively strip, from souvenir shops, malls, hippie bars, delicious restaurants and more. I can't wait to return.

Unprecedented harrasment!. I suppose everyone should visit "5h Avenue" at least once. It is a unique and often mentioned highlight in Playa del Carmen. Lots of shops, restaurants, and hotels. However, the amount of confrontation that takes place by overly aggressive sales people just makes it exhausting. If they would at least stay within their shops and wait to see if there is any interest in their wares, it wouldn't be so bad. But they come out into the street, cut you off, shake your hand (whether you like it or not), and basically ruin the experience. We went through this a few years ago, and it didn't seem so bad then, but it is a trying experience that may put a black mark on your vacation. There is a lot of merchandise to see, but the prices are, for the most part, not competitive. We will skip this attraction the next time around.

Persisent Harrassment!. On the optimistic side for my friend & I, Plenty of reasonable bargains/gifts to be had. If you enjoy being constantly harrassed by virtually every single shop/stand owner, & some can be very arrogant, then you will have a ballOn the pessimistic side, My friend & I are not In the slightest bit interested In any of this.That said, It is an experience. Nothing like I've EVER experienced before.No doubt there will be many thousands of travellers around the world who are familiar with this sort of experience. I am NEW to this afterall Ha Ha!

Shopping over load!!!. If you walk away from 5th Avenue without buying something......you have will power!! Night life is truly an experience. Shops, restaurants, bars for a mile & 1/2 ...no traffic just cobblestones and people.

Unique shopping experience. Although we enjoyed shopping here, it is not for the faint hearted. It can be very difficult to just browse through some shops as some of the shop keepers can be very pushy and aggressive. They constantly call out to you or wave in front of you to get you into their shop/stall/restaurant. Beware they try to tell you that they work in your hotel to engage you in conversation and act like they are terribly offended when you say you are not interested in an item you have been looking at. Only ask prices of stall or small shops if you are really interested. It is hard to shop around. I understand they really need the business but it doesn't hurt to be polite. We have travelled in Asia and have never had this sort of pressure to buy.We bought a lot of silver, pottery, t-shirts etc. Can't say they were huge bargains but we liked what we bought and it is definitely an interesting experience.

Typical tourist and cruise ship location. It is a long street starts near where the passengers disembark from the cruise ships typical mix of pricey bars restaurants and souvenirs. Interesting performances from some of the Mayan descendants there. Had some good prices on medication that you would need a prescription for in the US Good place to sit and people watch.
Shopping. Not too much hassle just be polite+say no.everyone is your waiter at hotel so turn your all inclusive band round so they don't know where your from.
Very good to waste time. The attitude of sellers is very agresiv, but you can find anything you need, the prices are expensives and have no the best at playa del Carmen. But... Is good to waste time
Cute Town. I love this little town. It's still Mexican style town with cute Mexican shops, open air bars, open air restaurants and it has a Starbucks.
Loved it!. Great shopping stretch, many stores and restaurants. Felt very safe, and a simple "no thanks" took care of the vendors. Can't wait to go back.

Constant harassment . Full of tacky souvenir shops with not much else to look at. You will find better souvenir ideas at chichen itza or on other excursions where the bus driver will drop you off at a shop in a village. Vendors in 5th avenue will harass u to no end even if u give them slight eye contact

Nice trip. Nice place to visit with lots of tourists, little shops and restaurants. It was hot in August when we went but there are so many places that you can cool down. Nice view on that ocean. Nice place to go and visit.

fun evening. This street (closed to auto traffic) is good for a fun afternoon/evening shopping, eating, etc. The street must be at least 2 miles long with many bars, restaurants, and stores selling just about anything.

5 th avenue!!. This venue was a short walk from our resort. Once arrived through the guard gates you stumble upon a hidden shopping center. There were a few stores that caught my eye such as Zara , sunglass hut and Liverpool. The locals are extremely pushy just keep on walking is the best advice I can give . There are plenty of touristy restaurants available however we found a small park and ate tacos where the locals eat ! These were the best tacos I've ever eaten . They ferry to Cozumel is also available here !
Shopping experience.. Quinta Avenida is the longest open air mall in the area. You can find local and international wares. The souvenir shops are well stocked and relatively inexpensive.
Plenty of shopping!!. There were designer shops as well as small souvenir shops. I can't imagine anyone not finding what they were looking for in this neighborhood.

Best visitor shopping in Mexico. A short walk from the Playacar area. Miles of shopping and entertainment on 5th Avenue. Make yourself a peso to dollar cheat sheet before you go. $10 is 150 pesos and makes sense to write out different increments. When using taxis paying in peso will save you money.

Horrendous, no fun shopping. Having visited a few years ago, we went into the town eith the friends we had travelled with. Every shop, every bar we were hassled and badgered to look/eat/drink.We offered massages and drugs on many occasions.  I try to be polite and enjoy the banter with people but this was way over the top. We gave up half way down and went back to the hotel. When we return to the area will avoid the Main Street like the plague.

NICE STREET TO SPEND TIME FOR A CHANGE. 5th Avenue in Playa del Carmen is the most frequented street by the tourists than the locals, for shopping, though the prices are high, tourist have to haggle a lot for what they want. Sometime it is fun to go through this experience.

Rambling, cool street, tons of restaurants, bars. A great way to spend an afternoon, or better, an evening, walking from restaurant to restaurant, and bar to bar and maybe a little shopping along the way. We really enjoyed finding all the little hole in the wall places just waiting to be discovered. Choose wisely, as many offer only adequate drinks and food, but there are plenty of great places as well. We had a good experience in Playa Del Carmen, but overall, still like Puerto Vallarta better.

shopping and food. vultures!!!! you will be hounded from one end of the ave to the other end. the prices are high, the locals do not shop here, only tourists, the restaurants are for everyone. we were trying to get to the ferry to cozumel, had to fend off all shop people

Your average tourist shop/restaurant area. Lots of stores and restaurants most selling the same things. There is a new mall by Los constituyentes that has stores the same as or similar to those found in American malls. A good alternative to hotel food. pedestrians only.

Stimulating to all of the senses--something for everyone!. Love walking the mall daily end to end. But, as mega-malls take over traditional thatched roofs and bad, blaring recorded music replaces wandering minstrels, I worry Playa is quickly losing unique character. Hope city planners preserve some of what was original, affordable and real. Love the LIVE music, dancing, performers and parades in the streets and hope that continues. Could use modern, safe public bathrooms and re-cycling stations.

I will say .... The miracle avenue. I say miracle because you can find anything food, souvenirs, jewelry, all the clothing and shoes stores we have hear, hotels,restaurants, cigars, spas and much more....,Ahhhh Walmart!!!!The people is very nice and helpful we feel very safe around.You can pay in US dollars or in Mexican pesos, most of the times the tour agent will offer a free tour then you don't have to go on your own if this is your case get a taxi from your hotel usually the lobby people will call then and tell you the price for each way, if you pay in Mexican pesos it will be shipper.If you are looking for some jewelry don't buy it in the hotel witch is much more expensive.Take enough money as I said you'll find anything every where you look you'll see beautiful stuff.
Tourist trap. Everything is over priced. You can get 50% discount if you negotiate well. There is not much variety, Almost every store have the same items.

Go nuts at shopping!!. This street is designed to walk the whole time, you will see lots of people and the best shops. If you love to go nuts at shopping this is a perfect place. It's more beatiful at the afternoon so you can see all the lights of the stores and all the people walking by. Be careful with your stuff cause there are a lot of people so you never know.

Crowded, expensive and touristy. I was so looking forward to visiting this area but when I did get there I couldn't wait to get out. Food expensive, drinks expensive, vendors rude. I spend lots of time in Cabo so I am used to vendors and folks trying to get you to buy. I usually have fun with them and buy if and when i have some interest. I am not at all bothered by good natured comments,but some of these people were downright rude. Then there were the big, trendy high ticket stores, Was I in Mexico???? Prada really?

5th is the place. You will find the obvious tourist and souvenir stores. However there are some good restaurants and Mexican arts and crafts along the way. Walk to the end of the Avenue to the beach. The store persons like to barter. Be careful of the fake silver!

Shopping experience . If you love shopping this is the place from pharmacy to cowboy boots they have everything including the mall but I preferred the authentic Mexican shops which are located on the side streets about 1/2 mile down 5th Avenue beautiful handmade leather bags and shoes prices are always negotiable especially offering American dollars instead of pesos

Lovely place to shop.. We shopped on 5 the avenue a few evenings during our two week stay and it's a lovely place with a great variety of shops and eating places.There are some things to be aware of though: The vendors try to get you into their shops by saying they are a waiter from your hotel (they recognise your wristband).We loved shopping and if you say no vendors they leave you alone.which is nice.Overall a great evening out.
Its great part of Playa del Carmem.. Its great on day time for shoppings, some really high end stores/brands - great and wild at night :)

Great if you can say "no". There are some great bars and restaurants to choose from. All of the shops have pretty much the same items, but if you're looking for something specific, haggle with them and say "I saw the same thing down the street for half the price!
Plenty of shops and bars to suit all pockets.. Look at prices in bars and restaurants before you buy. A beer and nachos can be bought for 25 pesos (£1) and a good meal for £6

Great street to walk. Quinta Avenida in Playa del Carmen its a huge street full with restaurants, local shops as well as big stores. Its full of life and color. I love to walk on this street during the day and at night its full of life also thanks to all the bars and nightclubs they offer. If you are in Playa del Carmen you can not miss visiting Quinta Avenida during the day and night.

A huge tourist trap. I’ve been told 5 Avenida was the best part of Playa del Carmen, now I understand why I didn’t like at all this place, Cancun is way better.It’s impossible to walk 2 meters without being harassed by the vendors, taxi drivers, tour operators and waiters, they are so annoying!And of course everything is incredibly overpriced. We went to a couple of restaurants and food quality was inversely proportional to its price. Just move to another Avenida and you’ll find cheaper places with better food.There is nothing Mexican in this place.

Verrry touristy and limited selection. We didn't enjoy shopping here. Although we knew to expect to be accosted by eager store owners trying to get you into their shops, it was still just unpleasant. Everyone seemed to have very similar items for the most part, and prices weren't much cheaper than at the airport. But if you like to haggle, you might do better here than we did. We ended up just walking to the beach.

Variety of activities for everyone. Quinta Avenida has a combination of stores from the US like Zara, H&M, etc., Starbucks, and Mexican restaurants. There are also many souvenir shops and pharmacies. I thought the items were a little pricey, but some shops had some beautiful, unique pieces. However, if you go on any tours, you can get souvenirs for cheaper. One thing I didn't enjoy was all the hassling and yelling my friend and I received as we were walking. It was a little annoying, especially when you're trying to enjoy shopping and the town.

Good place to spend an evening. Great choice of bars, restaurants, shops, massage parlours. Shop owners not pushy, but do speak to you as you pass.
Just a great place for an evening out.
Fun Shopping Experience. Fun afternoon shopping but I found myself being acutely aware of my surrounding at all times. Be wary of people trying to offer "other" services!

February 2015. I found everything here so expensive--it made me sad. It has changed a lot in the last 6 years. Their new mall makes it feel like any North American city. However, I was desperate for flip flops and did find a nice pair in one of the shops. If I had more money to spend, I would have loved to try one of the high-end restaurants on the strip.

Great food, drinks, shopping. 5th ave is a great place for meals, drinks, and shopping all in one place. Expect food and drinks to be much more expensive than if you venture off into the neighboring area.

Super fun and Very Safe!. Wife and I spent most of our time here. We stayed at an all inclusive resort however we found the food here to be much more tasty. Plenty of shopping for the Mrs., and plenty of hand-made cigars and cerveza's for myself. Cant wait to go back.

busy, crowded and colorful. fun street but noisy, crowded. Don't choose a hotel on this street. We almost chose a hotel on this street, thinking it was the center of Playa, but I'm so glad we didn't. Great restaurants and stores however

Quinta Avenida. My husband and I like to rent condos when we visit playa for 6 weeks in the winter, we love renting directly on fifth avenue, always lively. Most of the vendors recognize us after a week and don't bother us while we are walking on 5th, but when we don't want to be bothered at all we walk on15th or 20th Avenue and we are good.
a place to enjoy. nice environment, safety, clean, all kind of restaurant, shopping and beautiful beaches with block of where you are staying

Wisconsin Dells on Steroids. Went for a day and it felt like Wisconsin Dells on Steroids. It was interesting seeing all the different stores, but after awhile they all seems to blend together. I probably would have bought more souvenirs, but the shop owners or people working for them can be quite bother some. If they would just back off a little, I bet they would be able to sell a lot more. If you keep walking and don't make eye contact with them it's not so bad, but once you give them interest they fly over you like vultures. I brought a small cooler from home, and filled it with water from the resort I was staying on. I'm happy I did because it does get hot, and water can be a few bucks more then in the US. Make sure to see the beach, and eat at a restaurant so you can take in the atmosphere around you.
Must see 5th Ave.. What a great place for shopping, dining, and people watching! We also were able to run in the morning with no traffic to navigate!

Great place, rude and disgruntled local shop keepers. I love quinta avenida as its beautiful and has so much going on. You walk walk for hours nipping in and out of shops and then stop for a drink or bite. The downside is that shopkeepeers are all very tired and down right grumpy. The only place on the yucatan peninsula where people aren't warm and friendly.

Good way to spend an afternoon.. Do not be fooled by the gentleman calling out "hey it's me from your hotel" it's really just a way to get you into their shop. It's such a shame too because some of them really do have lovely things inside but this pressured environment just makes you walk on by.The street has a lot of shops selling various things from tequila to magnets to masks and so on. On the right hand side it is very much tourist mementos but on the right hand side there are lots of name brand shops for you to do your shopping including: Body Shop, Forever 21, American Eagle, Sephora, Mac and more. As with everywhere in the world there is a Starbucks every few paces as well. If you're having a grey day in Playa and want to spend some time it's a good place to wander if you're good at saying no thank you and moving on.

Main shopping street in Playa Del Carmen. Lots of little shops - a good bargain can be had if you have the time. Problem is there are too many ppl trying to convince you to look at their shop/stall. Some will see your hotel wristband and pretend to be a member of staff from there. One guy pretended to be Hector when we first walked past him, then Carlos on our return trip.
Great for an afternoon shopping. Very hot (what else?) when we went, but enjoyed 5th Avenue. Stopped at a couple of bars and also had lunch here. Nice place to visit.

Busy and lots of shops and restaurants. This is the main strip in Playa del Carmen; it's quite touristy so be prepared to have shop keepers hassling you to come into their stores. It's also becoming a bit more mainstream here (this was the 3rd time I've been here) - Most recent trip was Oct 2015. There are lots of nice little shops however and if you walk the side streets you'll see a bit more. There are larger, shopping centre like spaces now too. Overall if you're in the area you should visit :)

Worth a brief visit but not something to go out of your way to do. This is a shopping area which is set for walking tourists, it has a large volume of visitors from the cruise ships which dock nearby. The area includes everything from high end jewelry and clothing stores to tiny stands with tourist "trinkets." Restaurants, bars, and tour operators abound.

Busy, busy, busy. 5th Avenue is very touristy. Lots and lots of shopping from a high end mall to little local shops. You can barter in the shops and really it is a must. This area is very crowded, busy and a bit overwhelming. The shop owners are very agressive and some will just about chase you down the road trying to get you to come in their shop. BEWARE- We had a man approach us saying he was our waiter from the day before at our restaurant. We asked what hotel thinking we were being smart and he replied with the hotel we were staying at. He wanted us to follow him down a side street to a shop that his mother supposedly owned and had just opened. At the last minute it dawned on me that he could read our all inclusive bracelets that we were wearing! I have no ideas what his plan was but we were a bit unnerved by this.

Downhill. This use to be a great place to hang out an enjoy. Now it is all US shops so the local Mom and Pop stalls have been pushed out. I didn't come to Playa Del Carmen to have a Starbucks on every corner, a Victoria Secrets, Aldo , Seforai, Forever 21 etc. IF I wanted those I would of stayed home or just gone to Texas. Commercialization has completely destroyed the charm of this place.

Interesting, but no longer authentic. Overall, this is a good place to go if it is your first visit to mexico, or if you're into high prices. There is little room to barter anymore as the shops grow bigger and bigger. Food is generally a rip off, I would suggest going a few blocks over and find a good little food cart. The people that yell at you saying they were your waiters at the resort last night or whatever... just ignore and walk right past them. They were not your waiter last night. Fat Tuesday is an awesome time, we did pay to get our picture on the overpriced bottle of tequila. Make sure to try the eye candy drink! Senor frogs was good too, but the food wasn't that great. Cabs are cheap, and generally, everyone is nice. I got my hair braided (just one strand) and it has stayed over a month! Try to bargain all you can if you go, the lady was trying to charge me $12 USD for a hair braid, but after walking away she yelled and asked if I could do $5. I took her up on that, and had her add in a gold temporary tattoo for $3USD. Don't do the tattoos, they will rub off immediately in the beach.

nice place to visit ... very crowded, kinda pricy. we visited in september and it was a fun time, lots to do, but seemed pricey for the area. lots of shops, nice food, close to the beach, shop owners not aggressive. nice way to spend a lazy afternoon, or dance

A nice walk. Playa del Carmen's 5th Avenue is a fun walk. There are a variety of stores to choose from. A lot of vendors who claim they know you by looking at tour wrist band. Make sure to bring a hat with you because the sun can be brutal and wear lots of sunblock. I also suggest going to Haggen Dazs for some ice cream when the heat gets too intense.

Beautiful . Absolutely loved going to playa and found it much more enjoyable than Cancun, Cozumel, Costa Maya, etc. 5th ave is great and you can find everything you want here: restaurants, clothing, bars, etc. One down side are people CONSTANTLY trying to sell things to you...I understand that these people need to make a living but it can become a bit much after walking up and down for an hour+

Great Area. Playa del Carmen has grown over the years but this part is still where you need to visit while there. The first time we went they had mostly dirt roads. After going every year for several years we've seen it grow and is fun

Buy a wide bracelet . Some great shopping, but if you're staying at one of the resorts cover your wristband, vendors know which resort you're at, they will claim they know you from the resort, apparently I had about forty waiters in two days, once I covered it they still tried same line but they had to guess which resort
Shopping and restaurants. Lots of shopping and restaurants. At the end of the avenue there is a ferry that goes to Cozumel Island.
5th Avenue Mall. This is a street filled of lots of stores that u need a whole day to go to all the stores. The prices are reasonable and great foods .

A great visit. 5th Avenue is an amazing place, with a vibrant atmosphere and shops, restaurants, bars and more. As you stroll along you will find yourself hollered at from all directions, with comments such as 'Don't you remember me I'm your Waiter from' and they will name your hotel after checking out your armband. There are some comedians amongst the stall holders and you her some funny lines trying to get you into their shops. We loved the atmosphere and bought a lot of t shirts and jewellery, sunglasses and beach shoes. They sell everything you could want here and the shops range from traditional mayan art shops to Malls with Forever 21, American Eagle etc.There is a lot of bartering to be done if you purchase from the stalls and I found I would decide what I was prepared to pay and then bartered down. I bought some necklaces with Abalone pendants and they started at 30 dollars each and I got the two for £20. Still don't know if this was the right price but it was what I was happy to pay.Off 5th Avenue are lots of more local shops selling goods at cheaper prices including sunglasses, shoes, jewellery etc and local food carts. There is also a huge Walmart which is air conditioned and great to walk into on a boiling hot day. We got bottles of Appleton Jamaica rum for £4 and Captain Morgan for just under £6 here, which was cheaper than the airport.For a wonderful taste of electric atmosphere and fun I would recommend Fifth Avenue
La Quinta Avenida. Nice area for tourists to walk through. Lots of shops, restaurants and bars. I felt very safe there.
Touristic. For shopping I prefer the smaller villages, more authentic, less touristic and most important, you do not get vendors almost harassing you

Shopping in Playa de Carmen. Great day of shopping and walking in 5th Avenue. There are some bargains to be had if you shop and compare. They will adjust their prices if you talk about other shops. May require several visits back and forth but well worth it for larger items.

Great Place for a Shopaholic. 5th avenue is a great place to walk. After dinner each night part of our routine is to walk and shop. Lots of people and every kind of jewelry,souviners, tobacco you name it.
they have built modern shopping mall and a new one under construction. Food is everywhere and places to have a drink, dance or whatever.
Great Shopping and fabulous food!. So glad we decided to go. This was an amazing experience and a lot of fun. Great tourist shopping and phenomenal food.

Good for shopping, if you are looking to eat mexican food or any other type, it's a bit pricey.. Anything you can possibly imagine... Every shop and restaurant, they are all in the 5th Avenue. Shops were great, as I said there is something for every taste, maybe if you are looking for a truly mexican dinner by just going one street behind you can get any type of food in small mexican shops, a lot cheaper that by the 5th and would allow you to see how they really life away from the tourist side. Definitely a place to visit! Can't wait to go back there next time.

Great Place to visit . First time visiting MX and 1st international trip and I really enjoyed. Spending time around Quinta Avenida will make your experience more interesting, you'll have time to share with the locals, learn about the Mayans at the Portal Maya and do some souvenir shopping. The restaurants are great, the prices are very reasonable and the beach is right next to the corner. Four days are not enough, there's so many things to do at the Riviera Maya.

go for the party. you will never forget this great experience on the fifth avenue at playa, full of great malls and also litlle stores, you can find drugstores, art crafts, bars good restaurants, bus station, the most interesting , i discover that for the first time you can do a very good and cheap shopping at playa, stores like forever 21, stradivarius if you look for something diferent, thay are making a huge difference on a place only to visit, you will see everybody with their bags , if 5th avenue decides to sell cheaper than the rest of the country where you can buy the cheapest original rolex, i would take a flight to playa as an excuse but rolex are more expensive than in NYcity, hope they read me, and make this place the greats attraction more than las vegas... playa if you are looking for party , girls, boys, this is the best place ever, you only need to stay awake... to enjoy...

Another fun stroll!. Quinta Avenida has had some amazing changes in the past couple of months and it's just getting better and better! The restaurants, shops and shopping malls that are popping up on the Avenue are improving the whole experience. Can't wait to see what's next.
People won't leave you alone. We could not even enjoy the shops as the high pressure sales tactics were so annoying that we just left within an hour of being here.
BRING MONEY. Great deals or just window shopping, we spent a day away from Cancun, girlfriends a local, I said no she said you'll like, I loved it!
