Awesome time!!!!. We have a great time there you can find anything you want for souvenirs a lot of good restaurants like I said awesome time
Good place to watch people walk by.. Nice street to walk. Lots of restaurants and touristy shops. Good for people-watching. Becomes pretty noisy late evening.
Shopping!. I liked to walk around. good shopping! The vendors are a little bit agressive. You can take a taxi from you ressort, it's about 200 pesos from Sandos Caracol.

Great to get out of hotel, good bargains and lovely restaurants. So we went on a rainy day, best option I would say otherwise it would have been heaving and hot. Did lots of walking all the way from one end of 5th Ave to the other, then took the back streets through the local areas to Walmart. We had lunch in a Mexican restaurant which was lovely, had couple of coffee stops and dinner in an Argentinian restaurant. All great and very good price. One of our coffee stops was at Au Cocolate, where we bought some 100% and 70% dark chocolate to bring home. Yes you will get asked constantly to come into shops at one point it was like walking through a gauntlet of traders. But we just said hola, no thanks and laughed at some of their comments.Some nice designer shops, covered malls, bars and restaurants along the avenue along with lots tacky souvenir shops, however some have lots of good stuff in them to take back for family and kids etc.Due to the rain we didn't see the street acts at the far but we are going to go back one evening again for dinner so hoping to catch that experience then.Walk to Walmart was experience through some local shops and markets but good to see. Felt safe and with the streets being a square grid pattern, you can't really get lost, but take a map anyway. We took a taxi from Walmart back to 5th Avenue due to being shattered and carrying a few bags of bargains we picked up in the store. (£6 for a bottle of Kraken Spiced rum).Take money as you will spend it. Wear good walking comfy shoes/trainers. Take a sense of humour. Expect to be hassled but not physically. Try your best at haggling as you will get things cheaper (although I was told off by my partner for even suggesting to haggle in the Swaroski shop). Look out for the silver and leather shops for genuine goods and savings. If you are just not satisfied with everything going on, then you can even get a McDonald's to remind you of home!For a short trip in a taxi or bus (from our hotel it was $5) it is well worth doing on one or two of your days here.

Something for everyone. Very cool street. You'll get hassled by the many vendors but don't let them get to you. There not too bad. There's no way you won't find something you like. Food, jewelry, massages, souvenirs, tattoos, tours, and much more.

Must go and see. Not much to comment, you are pretty much secured, but dont forget you are outside, meaning dont drink to much, dont talk to strange looking or weird acting people do not argue with some one local especialy at night time and if he is not a local buissness owner.Do not wonder how much is cocane or other drugs, it will bring you into trobble becouse all dealers there is a police.How ever if you want to buy something dont be afraid to bargue.Visit a very unic shop of aquamarine candles it is by Haggen dazs ice cream shop.Most of jewerly there are fake!!You be lucky if you get low sort of silver.if you want jewerly there one or two stores who carring it and they easy to find - there 3-4 fully armed man inside .Change your money at airport of your country you will save Some $.And ofcourse dont forget that in MX life level is poor, so no jewerly on you ,no large chunks of money in public. Besides almost every shop takes Visa and Master Card. Good luck

How many ways can you say "No, Thank you".. You can't walk 10 feet without barkers trying to guide you into their store and they won't take "no" for an answer. As soon as you clear one, another is on you. There are some nice stores: clothing, grocery, trinkets. jewelry, etc., worth exploring, but the hassle is overwhelming. Restaurants abound.
Explore Playa. Nice to get out for evening stroll. plenty of shops, bars and local "flavor"great location close to most beach resorts.

Fun to visit, but don't spend your entire trip here. Filled with lots of stores, restaurants, and cafes, there is a lot to explore here but it gets a bit touristy and the prices aren't great. It's fun for a night out and a long walk though. Vendors like to holler at everyone walking along the streets and they can be quite aggressive, just be pleasant and ignore them. I say only 1 visit to this avenue is necessary as there are a whole lot more enjoyable, local places to see and better food to eat elsewhere.

Amazing blend of local culture great value and high end shops . I have to say 5th ave is my favorite avenue in the world!! Walking from playacar or right out of our resort at The Royal we love taking the walk. 5th ave has it all amazing food great little shops and plenty of beautiful boutique hotels to look at. If your resort is close to this location it is well worth at least taking a half day visit to check it out. So much culture so much fun so laid back. Great place to get a good deal on excursions as well. Enjoy

Fun times. Great time just strolling along. Great stores and restaurants. Can find almost anything you need. They have done a very nice job of upgrading stores. Very safe. Be warned that the locals like to holler at you, and haggling is expected at most shops.
Great stores. There is endless entertainment and great stores to peruse all along the avenue. Lots to buy, see, enjoy.
fun to explore. Fun place to eat and shop. Lots of shops and retail outlets. Great for people watching too. It is a great place to just walk and find a place to have a drink and food. Doug (ut)

a MUST GO!!. if you are in the playa del carmen area you definitely need to check this out! There are a lot of great restaurants and shops here. Do not mind if people are pushy just keep walking and ignore them! enjoy your time!!!

Fun to walk around and shop.. It was our third time walking Quinta Avenida. Still learning though. If you stay at an all inclusive resort, wear a bracelet or a watch over your wrist band as the vendors know the colours of the bands and some will say that they were your waiter from the other night. Then when you look all confused that gives them the opening to start talking and trying to herd you towards where they want to sell you something. We were smart though, we caught the vendor out on his lie because at the resorts the men must be clean shaven, no beards or goatees and this guy had a small beard. Still fun to look and walk around and have a meal at a restaurant.

Touristy and tourist prices but fun regardless. Playa's tourist Avenida is a bustling (and surprisingly lengthy) lane of boutiques, t-shirt shops, and restaurants. It's not where the best food is, nor are the prices that great, but it's fun and entertaining. Start your visit here, then start working your way away from the Avenida (using TripAdvisor of course) to find other restaurants. Either way, this place is a lot of fun--we loved Playa.
shopping on 5th ave. there is alot of deals and great food shops on 5th ave. you can exchange your money there , but shop around for best deal. that includes when shopping foe souveneirs too.

One visit here is enough. If all the people who worked at the stores on this Avenue just left the tourist alone, they might actually make some sales. But all they do is call out to you as your walking by. Your afraid to even look at anything. Its really a bummer. It ruins the whole shopping experience. There are also restaraunts and bars along this Avenue, but even the restaurant people try to get you in by calling out to you. One time here to experience it is enough.

If you like shopping, dining, and cocktails you are in luck.. Other than some aggressive vendors, take a stroll down the avenue and enjoy people watching as you peruse the many shops, cafe's and dining that is available. During the day the beach clubs are great, and at night the area is bustling with activity!

Playa del Carmen. Great shopping with a lot of vendors don't forget you can barter with the prices. It is very safe and you are by a beautiful beach and you can sit at a bar and watch the ferry going to Cozemel or for a few dollars more take the ferry and shop at Cozemel
Quaint. It is such a nice place to go. Shops, local art, bars, restaurants etc. A walking street no cars allowed.

Tennessee girls. Didn't spend long enough on 5th Avenue. This is an all day excursion if you are a shopper like me. I felt harassed by shop owners leading up to 5th Ave. We just ignored them. Authentic show was good but they asked for tips before we knew what was going to happen. Must try fish spa but only if your not ticklish.

Lots of people; be cautious about "deals". The Fifth Avenue experience is something that every visitor to Playa del Carmen should try. There are just a few things to remember:1. Not everything is a good deal. In fact, some things are downright overpriced. It's hard to find good deals right on Fifth Avenue itself. Your better buys are often a block or so off the main drag.2. It's Mexico. That means you need to barter for goods. NEVER take the marked price as the final price. Make an offer that you want to pay. If the business owner doesn't want the offer, walk away.3. Everybody wants you to stop in his/her shop. If you aren't interested, just keep walking.4. Don't wear shirts with sayings on them. If you wear that Nebraska Husker t-shirt so you can run into more people from Omaha, be prepared to have every person in every shop yell, "Hey, Husker. Come over here, Hooosker!"5. Go, walk and have a good time. There are many fun stores, bars and restaurants. There's also pretty much a Haagen-Dasz on every corner.

SHOP AWAY. Great for shopping, strolling,and also lots of food if your hungry. Only watch as a lot of people always on the side asking if you want other things. (illegal substance) but once you say no they don't bother you.

Shop shop shop then eat!. Great shopping to be had and bargains too! A very friendly safe place - felt very comfortable walking around with my 2 young girls. Huge choice of eating places & on every corner you can see the beach.

Mainly for Tourist. There are lot's of shopping opportunities on Quinta Avenida. You will have multiple shop owners calling out to you. Just smile and wave them off or stop to see what they are selling. Keep a positive attitude. I was called a derogatory name in Spanish once and it surprised the "barker" when I turned around and gave him a raised eyebrow and a scowl. It helps to know a few of the Spanish "dirty" words. There are lots of international chain restaurants on the avenue. But, you'll find some local eateries with great food. Great place to find those inexpensive souvenirs. We felt safe day and night on the entire avenue and even ventured off to some of the side streets.

Really just for shopping. Overall this is a place to shop, there are stores from really well known (and expensive in my opinion) brands as well as a couple of bars and small stores were you can buy the classic t-shirt or any other souvenir ... There are a lot of night clubs around too.Not really the place to go if you're interested in the more cultural aspect of Playa del Carmen

5th Avenue, good for a quick visit. Visited 5th Avenue last week in order to get away from our resort for a bit. It's definitely a touristy spot. Lots of bars, restaurants and shopping. Everything from Mexican crafts to fine clothing. A few one off hotels and hostels too. Starbucks, Sephora and then stalls selling Mexican blankets and sombreros. It's all over the map.You'll find lots of bank ATMs and pharmacies too which is handy.If you get sick of the hustle and bustle you can pop down to the beach which is only a block away.We enjoyed wandering around there for a couple of hours but there's no way we could have spent an entire day.
Playa del Carmen my favourite town!!. Love the cobblestone streets and no traffic allowed. Lots of shopping, very high end to the locals bartering their treasures.

Must Visit. If you're staying in Playa Del Carmen make sure you have a trip to 5th Avenue, either early in the morning,or early evening. Soak up the atmosphere . If you don't want to buy just say No politely when asked and you won't be bothered any further. A mixture of drainer shops, bars and trinket shops

a christmas gift for my 24 year old daughter who had no ideal she was going. fith avenue has a little of everything you want brand name shopping stores to American resturants to mexican markets restaurants cafes and it is very safe no worries you might have some people asking you to come look at their things to buy but no thank you and its all good

Fifth avenue.playa del carmen. What a place.hundreds of shops and bars.absolutely spoilt for choice.we went in a few times in the evening.it was packed full of people all the way down fifth avenue.the only thing we didn't like was all the shopkeepers trying to get you to go into their shops.even though it was packed with shoppers we always felt safe.great fun to sit in a bar watching all the people go by.

Fun. Super fun. No problems. Great shopping. lots of night life if thats what your are in to.
I felt safe

Tourist Only. Its the typical drag. Very much like South Beach but a little more hustle from the vendors. Some unique restaurants but also alot of the Senor Frog et al. Bargain with the vendors otherwise you're getting ripped off. Venture off the strip just a few blocks north for a more genuine experience.

Great shopping!!!. Excellent variety of souvenirs, t-shirts, dresses etc! You will find better prices towards the middle of the strip. Shop around a bit because prices vary for the same item. Also...haggle!!!!! We bought a woven blanket for $40 that started at $120.!!Enjoy the tequila barrel if you like to try different flavors of tequila. Its a bit expensive, the the tequila is premium!!!Choose restaurants that look clean (check out the bathrooms).:)
Interesting shopping district. Nice walkway with shopping from Mexican tourist shops to some boutiques.Beware of sellers trying to sell even the shoes off your feet.Good to pass by and have a drink.

Always use pesos. Good deals to be had if you are willing to negotiate. Seemed like there were 100 vendors, so take a good look around before you buy. Expect to pay about half of what they ask for. Of course some stuff is still junk no matter what kind of deal you make. Always use pesos and never cards or the ATM. If you are an American and use dollars you better know the exchange rate or these people will screw you, but that is the same almost all across Mexico.

Touristy but fun. Typical Mexican shopping district. It can be fun if you can brave all the barkers calling to you. Lots of options for dining. La Bodeguita del Medio has great Cuban food. Loved just sitting enjoying a drink and people watching.

Walk this way...Talk this way......... Wait until dark to go there, too hot otherwise. Lots of shops and stands and bars. My wife's name is Karen so we had to stop at a bar/ restaurant of the same name. Also stopped at one called El Ranchero". Both very nice. You get propositioned almost every step by the "outside" street vendors. Kind of cruel but you have to just ignore them, their pitch and walk on by.Got some nice jewelry.

A great place for having fun, drink, eat and shopping.. There are a lot of handcraft stores from local manufacturers, a lot of bars and restaurants with interesting concepts and dessert shops (Ah Cacao, Tepoznieves). Quinta Alegria has a lot of international brand stores.

5th Avenue. Many great values on these streets - better than the flea markets of Cancun. I always look for the jellyfish lamps! Souvenirs were much cheaper than in Cancun. Many great bars & restaurants.

Fun day, just pay attention!. We enjoyed Quinta Avenida, but beware of the store owners asking you if you would like cigars, or something better, like marijuana or cocaine! That threw us for a loop. They are quite aggressive when you pass by their shops. Also, they will try to hike up the prices on items, so set a limit on what you will spend for an item and don't go over it. Chances are, you will find it in another shop down the road,

Great.. but sellers become annoying.. Me and my husband stayed in the area for 4 days. Great for couples and solo. 5th ave is great with nice little shops and authentic Mexican culture. Its a nice strip to walk on from when sun goes up till when it goes down. The liveliness starts at night and lots of people come out. Friendly vacationers and lots of nice locals. It's pretty safe since there's police everywhere. You may even find a nice restaurant to fall in love with. But be careful with some restaurants because some will leave you with heartburn and empty pockets. There's a lot of restaurants we didn't get a chance to check out. We mainly preferred theme restaurants or organic Mexican food.. Some great restaurants are hidden on side streets so don't be afraid to explore. Bike rentals are a must try. Car rentals and taxis are everywhere. Cons: There's hagglers EVERYWHERE!! I don't know how many times I heard "Take a look my friend" "Nice silver for you" "check it out" Special deal" "Do you want to have fun.. cocaine, weed" "Massage" "TAXI"!! Yikes!! oh my gosh.. annoyed beyond words at times and it never stops.. especially those mornings you wake up on the wrong side of the bed.. They don't care!! at least 15 hustlers is guarantee to convince you to buy something within a two block radius. When you say no thank you, some get hugely disappointed .. some usually talk about you to their peers in Spanish. Some smile and say no problem.. But understand most Mexican men are silly with a burst of personality. Try not to take things too personal and understand that's their hustle. Once you overcome the harassment and know what to expect the experience gets better.Also everything shuts down at a certain time. Trying to find food on a hungry stomach after the club lets out is nearly non existent ...unless you really know where to go.. I walked for blocks and found nothing!! I thought it would've been a 24 hour area. Guess my expectations were too high. Overall me and my husband will return in the near future. I just want to share some personal tips I learned but to each it's own.. 5th ave is great for maybe a day or two to explore then go back to your all-inclusive resort. The hotels around 5th ave are nice and small but I'm not sure if these smaller hotels offer all inclusive. It's a headache digging in your pockets trying to figure out pesos for breakfast, lunch and dinner. I highly suggest converting your money as well. We kept our American money but were robbed a lot and it adds up. Next time we will book an all-inclusive and just get a car rental to go to 5th avenue. I don't need to stay in the area. Some mornings and afternoons are dead. I notice the area doesn't pick up till about 4:00 p.m

Shopping and restaurant row. This is a pedestrian Street which is sidelined with shopping malls with the trendients brands, small shops selling all kind of local souvenirs, restaurants and bars, most of them open to the street. You can get your picture taken with Batman, Spiderman or The Mask. At any time of day it is bustling with people, both tourists and locals. It's worth a visit.

great bargains. Great bargains to be had but don'think be afraid of bartering. Stall holders do tend to hassle you as you pass by but a no queiro will not offend them. Go for it and enjoy. Watch the heat!!

Shopping downtown . Hubby and I went here to do a lil shopping 4 the kids. 5th ave is a long 3 mile walk. Be prepared to walk in the heat. Wear comfy shoes. Same items that are sold in the hotel shops, you can buy it here for less. Besides that where can you get whiskey in a can !

Too Touristy. Quinta has really changed from the last time I was here. It has dozens of restaurants which are ok with decent prices, but it has many more souvenir shops which are over priced and very aggressive sales people that most places will not haggle over prices which is the custom in Mexico. If you want a deal, try the little kiosks that will haggle with you. Remember, when you ask how much, the price will always be way too high. Counter with about 1/3what they asked and if they counter then go up to about 1/2 what they said. Don't go any higher and be willing to walk away.

Boardwalk . A must see when your in Playa del Carmen. If your looking for things to do, resturants, bars, shopping or just want to people watch. 5th avenue has it all! It starts on the Playacar boarder with Playa del Carmen and continues for 40 blocks or so. I believe it stops around Calle 46 norte. The beach also runs parallel with 5th Avenue and is only one block between each other.

Shopping trip. Great place to pick up some fab souvenirs too.Beware though, there are so many people that `apparently work at your hotel, also had this in Tunisia last year, so we were a bit wiser this timeGreat street entertainment and shopping malls either end of the street and some fab restaurants too.Worth a visit for bargains

About 10 blocks of Commerce. This street started a few years ago with only a couple of blocks, now there are more than 10 streets, where you may find from a local Maya shops, gourmet restaurants, fast food, bars, nightclubs and even shopping malls with international brands. If you are at the Rivera Maya is a must.

Nightmare on 5th Avenue. We were excited to visit the Playa Del Carmen 5th Avenue but ran back to our bus stop and hour early. I understand that the local residents are trying to earn a living but the pressure every step to "buy" and trying to trick you by noticing your name on your coffee cup and calling you by name or telling you that they waited on you at the resort is just too much. I would have enjoyed shopping but the bus driver's joke about them ripping you off was no joke. If you need something like sunscreen or snorkel stuff go to the "wonderful American Walmart" about 4 roads down ... you can buy everything on the street a a much reduced rate. I would have spent money if they had not been so aggressive. Sorry, but I will NOT do this trip again.

Not the same as it use to be.. The strip is not the same as it use to be.Get there quick as it is becoming very commercialized very fast. Some sections are more like U. S. traditional shopping malls than the traditional Mexican small shops and bars as it use to be.

Exhausting Shopping and Eating!. From 1st street all the way to 40th street, you can find great shopping, great eateries and art galleries. Stock up on souvenirs. Eat at a variety of great restaurants and check out the artists in the streets and the galleries showing some of the local artists' works. A lot of the shops carry the same items...so shop around and don't be afraid to haggle. You can usually do better than the original asking price for virtually any item in any store. The "barkers" (owners of the shops) can be a little intimidating as you stroll up and down the avenue trying to get you into their store. But most are polite when you just tell them "no thank you" as you walk by. We never get tired of Avenida 5 when we visit Playa del Carmen. A great place to stock up on essentials you may have left home or just to stroll.

Nice walking district and gateway to most restaurants. This street is bright and exciting, lots to see and do. It is blocked off for pedestrians although cars cross it at the intersections. In every block you will find Tshirt and gift shops, restaurants, small convenience stores, and handcraft shops. Every few blocks you will find jewelry stores, an art gallery or fine clothing boutique. Also massage, pedicure and other personal services. Now there are two major malls as well, including high-end chains as in every other major city. It is easy to use this corridor for all your dining and shopping. Watch for the time share and tourist operators, as they can get your attention and monopolize your time easily; also the scams by guys (and gals) who introduce themselves as "your waiter from the hotel" and offer to show you their friend's (or family's) shop or restaurant. If you stop to talk to everyone, you will never get to dinner! When you are finished, you can easily catch a taxi to go home, but verify the fare with the driver before you get in.

So many things to see!. The 5th avenue in "Playa" is always full of life and open to the visitors, lot of restaurants, shops, souvenirs and entertainment; really like the idea by feeling still in a Mexican town while you walk the streets, is touristy but not to crowded and commercial like CUN! When you go to Playa del Carmen, don't miss the opportunity to stop and walk exploring this nice part of the city!

An oasis in the desert!. Very nice bars with very friendly people around! And you must try and drink the best Mexican beer, Corona! And if you need to buy something to give to your family and friends it´s the right place to go!

5th Avenue. The 5th Avenue. You must visit this particular avenue. You will find every thing you want to buy . Do not Forget to négociat price.You will also find free and interesting Mayàs traditionals dancing and other amazing things to see

just FUN!. What a great few weeks we spent here ,If you have dollars your in for a treat, the dollar is at 17.20 now and your buck buys a big bang, cute boutique hotels and more girl ration to guys than anywhere I've been! be ready for none stop party!, couples have a million thing to do, great honey moon spot!

A Mexican Mardi Gras . It's like a New Orleans vibe, BUT family oriented.... shopping (from upscale American shops to the small local markets), music, art, street musicians, bars and restaurants galore! Definitely a great place to sip on some drinks, relax and watch people.

Don't miss this place when you go to playa del carmen. Always a busy place, you need to check the other stores because there are tons out there but it's worth coming for, and just in case if you are wondering how they know your hotel? its because of the wrist band color, i think they're able to memorize it.

Strolling around at sunset. Excellent area to stroll around every afternoon.Good shopping and restaurants. It is quiet during the day but colorful and a live at evenings. Great place to visit at sunset.
Touristy. Very cozy and cute. Lots of deals. Best gelato at Aldo's. Would definitely go back. Bought tons of stuff and enjoyed all the scenary.
Quinta is primero. 20 plus blocks of restaurants, kiosks & bars. Central location pretty much 3 blocks from anything you need or want. Vendors friendly & helpful. Great paseo.

Better to avoid some guys. Our hotel is based on 5th ave and cannot complain about it. U always have a choice to go wherever u want as u can find basically everything in that street. Only one disapointing thing is that after sunset all the wierd guys appearing from the hell trying to sell u blow and weed what could be quiet annoyin for family goin to have a dinner with their kids.

Love - Hate relationship... If you are visiting Playa del Carmen it is a must go to, for the experience alone. South end starts with High End and Mid Level Shops. Followed by Local Merchants and Toursit Nik Naks, this area is more aggressive for your attention and money. Next is my facorite part, Just after the iStore heading North are more interesting Boutique style shops, many different types of restauraunts, cuisine, artists. This area is where I like to met friends for beverages, people watch revealing in the fact I live here and don't have to go back at the end of the week. Side Note*** Many of the side streets off either side of Quinta Avenida have the coolest little shops, Little Hotels, amazing Restuaraunts, Yoga, Spas, Natural and Health Food and so much more.

Take A Stroll. Fun pedestrian only street that runs for a mile or two through downtown Playa Del Carmen. Lot of restaurants, vendors and street performers, worth a visit. Lots of vendors trying to draw you into their shops, but a simple "no gracias" will suffice if you're not interested.

What a walk :). Endless restaurants, bars, shops ... a lifetime of food and bliss. Evening hours are the way to go. Right after the beach and shower. Love to have dinner in one place. Desert in another and a drink even in another place ....
Always a pleasure. My wife and I come ro Playa about 3 times a year a yet we have not stop loving the atmosphere on 5th ave mainly ar night. A must visit
Fun Street. Fun Street, lots of choices to see and have drinks and shop. Would say was worthy to go every day and walk around. Nice shops and restaurants
My experience . Really nice but a bit over priced but fun to walk and have a couple drinks. Only complaint was that there's not enough authentic Mexican food on the strip. Great night life

Fun people watching, lousy shopping. We walked part of the southern end one night and a bit of the middle sections another night. There were lots of stores similar to what we have at malls in the US (especially at the southern end) mixed with little stores selling tourist trinkets. The sellers are very aggressive and it gets old fast. We were looking for slightly better quality "Mexican" style pottery/leather/jewelry and this is not the spot. However, there are great restaurants and the people watching was a lot of fun.

Not great.. We did walk fifth ave, there are many restaurants and shops. However we avoided it every time we were in town because of the heckling. It was much more expensive for the same things you can get at walmart or shops a few blocks up for much cheaper. We bought souveniers for about 70% less by going to the local stores about 4 blocks up from fifth.

Don't waste your time. Not worth the cab fare if you are going to shop - you will be hassled by every store owner to come into their store. Saw quite a few interesting restaurants but did not try them. If you are taking a cab, be aware of a few things - they will claim to have no change and they will give you awful exchange rates in USD.

Fun street full of attractive hotels, shops and bars. Well worth a few walks down with lots of little shops and lovely restaurants/bars to pick from. The prices are slightly cheaper than the UK for plenty of items though some shops can be just as expensive if not more expensive! The only real negative is the constant calling from shop owners and workers to come in to their shop selling exactly the same goods as half the shops on the street but that's no different from most tourist destinations that I've been to. Lovely to roam down during the day and bustling during the night, Sundays though are a no go at night as most bars will close slightly earlier.
Nice variety, super expenssive. There was lots to choose from, from syores to restaurants. I felt like all was really expenssive for the products but also found lots of wonderful souvenirs.
Fun place to walk around.. Great place to walk around. Tons of shops and tons of restaurants.... but be aware the souvenir shops here are over priced.
Mandatory walk and shopping !!!. Great place to shop if you're in the mood for bargaining ... Lots of stores, restaurants, and som annoying sellers...Allround beautiful place...

Great shopping! . Recently went to Playa del Carmen and heard about Quinta Avenida "5th Ave" so I had to go and check it out. I spent over 3 hours walking down this street, great place to go shopping and spend the day, eat, have a drink. I enjoyed it so much that I went back the next day for more shopping!
Great night life . It's a great place for adults ,nice ambiance.The food is ok, margaritas are ok,the micheladas awesome

my vacation to playa del Carmen,. I stay at Hyatt playa thel Carmen this august and it was the best, at night we went to la quinta avenida and we loved it, it was full of shops, and nice restaurants,and icecream, it was very nice to have a walk in all la quinta avenida

Beware of getting hassled. It was nice to get to see a bit of Mexico, however this place is filled with people hassling you to get into their shops and buy their wares. As long as you don't mind saying non gracias regularly, it's not too bad.

Quinta Avenida - Playa del Carmen. Pretty horrific to be honest!The main street in the main tourist town in the area is pretty much as you would imagine it to be. Tourist shops selling everything you would regret buying upon returning home, and a ridiculous number of tour companies trying to sell excursions to just about everywhere.The invasiveness and insistence of the hawkers is quite intense especially in around 40º heat - and the fact one is following you while others are trying to get you into their shops made the whole experience irritating to say the least.We went in once knowing which agency we wanted to find to reserve excursions and find out about ferry tickets to Cozumel. The second and last time we went in was to buy ferry tickets to Cozumel, and upon our return, didn't even stop for a drink in PdC and especially not Quinta Avenida, as we couldn't deal with the constant attention - on a par with Morocco for being unchilled

Shopping day. Fifth Ave in Playa is a great way to spend an afternoon. Many little shops to explore with everything you could want and more. Great local cuisine and the beach is just steps away. Shop,eat,drink,enjoy the local sights and wonderful people. As a woman I walked around during the day on my own and felt very comfortable. Although other travellers said to cover my resort wrist band with bangles or ribbon etc. There are people that will try to convince you that they met you at your resort on a previous night as your server or whatever after they spot the wristband. Probably not a good idea to trust that ruse. However I did cover my band as a precaution and had no issues. I would highly recommend an afternoon there and will go again next trip. Great day!

Never a dull moment . Nightclubs, bars, restaurants and much more. We went to the 5th Ave almost every afternoon or night. It was always full of people. We met people from every where. I can't wait to go back

Love/Hate relationship. Strolling Quinta at twilight into the evening is one our favorite things to do, but sometimes we walk on 1st or 10th just to avoid it. I would recommend trying the streets west of 10th to get more of a real feel for Playa.

A Playa Soho -- A Must to Visit!. The best time to go to Quinta Avenida is between 5 to 10pm when it's cooler and the night life begins, that's when the street comes alive. There is Part 1 and Part 2 to the Avenida, and you may begin at either end. Part I begins near the pier to Cozumel and has lots of American franchaises, such as Starbucks, Haagan Daaz, Sephora, Forever 21, and soon to be a 3 story H&M super store. Part 2 has more of a Mexican feel to it. Pretty much, the same merchandise can be found throughout the entire avenida. There is no bargaining at the Fiesta Market which is a chain store with at least 3 to 4 locations. You can find a nice selection of souvenirs, Mexican vanilla essense and tequilla there. Expect to pay a hefty sum for sunscreen which runs at USD$24.00 each at the local pharmacies. Find good bargaining at the mom and pop stores, and off the beaten paths. Bring cash in either USD or pesos. They want to see your money when making a deal, although you can ignore their request. Dress comfortably as it gets really hot in the summer. Plan on at least 3 hours minimum to get through the entire street. The local Tour kiosks have very competitive prices. There are also Taxi kiosks in between Part 1 and 2 for your convenience. The shopkeepers are bargain experts and are not easily swayed. Some vendors will call out to get your attention esp. the Tour Vendors, but most vendors will not harrass you. Whether you are in the mood for shopping or not, it is still a nice stroll.

Sights of 5th. We have been travelling to Mexico for many years, and love the vibe of Playa Del Carmen and 5th Avenue. Over the years the street has become more Americanized with malls and box stores but you can still find authentic crafts, clothing, art etc .. and restaurants with authentic flavours ... love just watching people and street performers, wondering in and out of shops or the beach .. or wondering deeper into the center of Playa finding the one off store or food cart off the beaten path.

A must to visit. A must to go if you're staying in Mayan Rivera. We travelled 7 times to the MR staying at four different resorts. Each time we taxi from and to the Resort to the Quinta Avenida, Playa Del Carmen. The longest taxi ride taken sonfar were from the Grand Bahia Principe Tulum. We generally deal with the Reaort's concierge to negociate round trip with same taxi.
Average tourist shopping and restaurants. Just an average tourist shopping and restaurant area. Its a nice walk, but don't expect a real cultural experience. The adjacent beach is also just average.

truly amazing!. best off so far! lovely place! all the streets, the restaurants, the green and the beaches are amazing! people are nice too, is a dream come true! we've been there in August 2013 and we are still dreaming of that place

Be prepared to be pestered at every shop and restaurant. I was excited that our resort was so close to this area but I was not impressed. The gift shops all have the same items and as I walked down the streets I was approached at almost every single store and restaurant practically pushed inside. I understand the need for the hard sell as their living depends on getting tourists to buy but honestly they should tone it down. I found I avoided browsing in shops because they just wouldn't leave me alone.

Shopping in Playa De Carmen. Interesting shopping experience...Be ready to bargin and walk away if they don't agree because there are 100 other stores with exactly the same thing..Also be cautious of the scam to get you in their door, all the sales people are doing it and it goes like this " Hi, do you remember me, I am the waiter at your hotel , come see my Mom's new store"

Every store is the same typical souvenir theme. We went there last night and the first block of stores was new and exciting to be there. Then as we kept walking it was the same magnet store. Same beach clothes, same wind chime. Lots of senior frog shops. Nothing amazing but I guess something to do if you want to shop around town.

Quinta Avenida. Great place to stroll and savor and shop. Right off the beach. Super casual. Family friendly. Beware of hawkers trying to get tourists to buy stuff and tours. Use your common sense. Be polite. Say no. Enjoy the ice-cream. People watching. Just a fun place to be.

Good fun (and food) at night, but nicer during the day. After 5 years from my first visit to Playa, I found Quinta Avenida to be almost the same... nightlife is quite alive, with mostly the same places but much louder and too city-like for my taste of a beach-town party scene. The music at the most large clubs is way too commercial but I guess that's what works for them. Some exceptions like Diablito make it worthwhile to go out and listen to good music. And for fine dining in a fun atmosphere, go one block from Fifth to PLANK (in front of Acanto Hotel & Suites) which is truly spectacular!Now, during the day it's a different story... the street is nice to walk under the sun and it's wonderful to sit outside at the restaurants and cafe-bars, or inside some that offer patio or garden sitting, like Aldea Corazón which I recommend for breakfast (early or late). You can grab a beer or margarita and keep walking, drink-in-hand of course!Quinta Avenida is enjoyable night or day, just make sure you know where to go and which places to stop by... Salud!

Typical tourist trap!. Most people will know what they are up against when they come to a place like PDC and in particular 5th Avenue. For food, there are MUCH better places even only a few avenues away from 5th and which cost a fraction of the price. There are also plenty of touts hassling you as you walk down the road, which can get tiresome. But I guess no visit to PDC is complete without walking down 5th, and for a few drinks it can be quite a fun place to hang out, although for food, I would definitely go elsewhere.
Shopping. Local colorFunOverzealous shopkeepers But polite .Good to try outside restaurants or pubs after a day at the the beach..

Definitely worth a walk down the 5th. Pleasant street full of nice restaurants, bars and stores. It's lively and full of people. It's definitely worth a walk down the 5th and the other streets that cross the 5th (if you are looking for a party, look out for the 12nd/5th, there are a lot of nice clubs over there).
Fun place to shop. So much to see and do at 5th Avenue. There was something for everyone and it was an easy walk from the hotel to the ave.

Mix With Locals. Quinta Avenida in Playa Del Carmen has it all! Great food, shopping, night clubs & bars, with a healthy mix of tourists and locals. Hopefully, it will maintain it's real Mexican flavour, and not become another Cancun.
Awesome Experience:). OMG they have everything there. Great souveniers, Restaurants, etc.. You can even enjoy the Beach there. Great shopping experience!
A worthwhile visit. Many restaurants and shops along the street. If you are not good with haggling over prices you will end up paying much more. I always felt safe while there. Prices are in dollars!
Same old crap.. We're from LA and recognized the same stuff we see on venice beach. Mass- produced, nothing handmade, all overpriced. Fun to walk, mostly not worth buying.

Prices are in Dollars!. Yes, there are really many stores. But stores are selling basically the same things! Very touristy! I expected more and after few minutes of walking I realized we made a mistake by wasting our day in here.

Constant harassment . I love the look of 5th Avenue but being constantly harassed by the vendors, drivers and tour operators makes it very unpleasant. The prices in almost every store, I've gone into were way overpriced. I read about the silver jewelry not being real silver. So far while in pdc, I've bought absolutely nothing. My rental is very near 5th Avenue and I deliberately walk on 10th just to avoid the catcalls, harassment and whistles. If I wanted to buy an item, or take a tour, im certainly not going to buy anything after being treated poorly and spoken to rudely. I'm also not going to buy overpriced trinkets in a tourist trap. Very disappointed!

Expensive but worth going. ..don't do drugs. Lol. There is a $5 shuttle from the hotels si dont get roped into a "free tour" to a jewelry store (that was day one for us and even though we got 2 cool Mayan pendants for free. ..it sucked 3 hours of wasted time from us! And it is not a tour. ..they just drop you off at a jewelry store hoping you'll spend money)Anyway. ..back to 5th Ave. ..go up a couple streets and you'll save money. On 5th ave We had couples massages...deep tissue...was amazing. ..she even kneeled on the back of my legs while massaging! Way better and cheaper than the resorts! And hope you don't mind being asked "senor...would you like to buy some jewelry? ...no. ..hokay...how about some cocaine, ecstasy, morphine, weed. ..you look like you need to relax"And make sure to get the fish eating the dead skin from your feet! Feels like bubbles! And again cheaper than the resorts!

Pedestrian Shopping Zone. Worth a walk/visit if on holiday on the Mayan Riviera. Busy vibe with street performers, hustlers ( watch your purse), liquor store ( beer, wine, etc.), groceries at Mega a few blocks up, high end and tourist shoos and plenty of restaurants and bars. Taxi stand is very organized but fixed rates are pricey. 250 pesos or $25.00US was our rate from Mayacoba to 5th Avenue. Pay in pesos, much cheaper with exchange rate. We enjoyed dining at Aldea Corazon which is in a cenote, very cool. An upscale Mexican experience.
Love 5th Avenue!. A trip to Playa del Carmen would not be complete without a stroll down 5th Avenue. Over the years I have seen the area grow by leaps and bounds, but still enjoy it!
Nice place. There are very good restaurants, a lot of places to have a drink, it is very safe You can do many things like dancing , drinking or just walk around

Great shopping fun!. We stayed at The Royal. I feel like the closer you are to Constituentes Ave. the more expensive things are and the further you are willing to go, the prices drop. I really enjoyed shopping with my wife at the Wayan store, he is a great designer with shockingly fantastic prices. I did get the fish feet soak treatment, it felt great and seemed to help with my dry heels. Another gem I found, the liquor store in the high end mall on Constitutienetes had some great prices.

Lots of activity. A pedestrian only street for many blocks. Many souvenir shops, restaurants of all types and styles. Lots of people offering tour deals. Also a surprising number of people offering short massages. At night costumed Mayan warriors are at various places along the Avenida. And, as you walk along, you are occasionally cooled by air conditioned air which is refreshing.

Great place for an evening walk. This street in Playa del Carmen has many shops from high end to low end. Good place to buy souvenirs, have dinner or just people watch. There is also the Portal Maya (Mayan Gateway) bronze arch where you can see a mayan warrior dance or sit and watch the waves roll in on the beach.

Great place. You got to go into to playa in doing shopping I bought some hats and some dresses for my granddaughter great place to go
Very safe with a variety of places to also eat

Decent Shopping. This was a very long street filled with varying stores with similar items. It's a nice day-trip if you want to just get away from your hotel. There's nothing spectacular here that you HAVE to see but it's nice if you just want to get away for an afternoon.

Great for buying souvenirs!. This is a nice street so much to see and buy. The problem was that we went at mid day and it was very quiet. We still enjoy it and did some shopping.but I'm sure It must be a lot of fun during the night.
Nice street. Nice and small place. Great bars and restaurants. Safe area. Excellent place to shop, nice restaurants, just have to be firm when saying " No Gracias" vendors will try to sell.

Has everything you need!!!. From shopping, eating to dancing!! Great place to check out. Sometimes can be tough due to so much to choose from as far as eating and or dancing. Great shopping but remember to negotiate!!!
5th Avenue. Really just went here to get to other places. Area felt safe. Didn't really check it out though.....
Fifth Avenue Playa Del Carmen. Excellent place to shop, nice restaurants, just have to be firm when saying " No Gracias" vendors will try to sell.

Aggressive salespeople. Everyone is trying to sell you something, specially anything belonging to the company "Experiencias Xcaret" It is so horribly annoying that we did not feel like we could ask anyone about anything because an immediate sales pitch would ensue.

Fun way to pass some time. I enjoy shopping for souvenirs and such, so for me it was great. Be ready to walk away if you're haggling. We got some good deals I felt by just telling them what we'd spend or what the last guy was willing to do.Our hotel was off 8th street north so we mostly wandered south toward Juarez...a lot of bartering "come see my shop" "hey honeymooners!"...however, the last night we walked up into the 20-30 blocks north and the shops, restaurants and stands got a bit classier and less "in your face"---we didn't shop that night though so could've been pricier too as I believe maybe some of the more expensive resorts were up that way.Money....had to use an ATM and there was a $10 fee + $3.50 & highest we could get out was $100 USD. You can pay in USD and get change in pesos...I tried to avoid doing this because I was terrible figuring out the exchange rate.

Be careful. Not a bad place to get some souvenirs. Remember the price were marked up by 10x, at the least. Sellers are Very Aggressive, they will say "I was your server last night, remember me?" "Today is my day off, this is my mama shop". It gets old and annoying very quickly, you will hear these statements for the whole stretch of the Avenue. I have learned from staff at the resort I stayed as he used to work on the Avenue that, as sellers they have to learn each bracelet on your hand and color coded because it tells level of possible spending. Nonetheless, there are some off beaten path shops that you can get a good stuff including food from. Tips:1. If you exchange money at the Avenue, avoid those that buying less than 15 pesos per USD (you buying pesos). They will put 16 on windows and those are for selling price (they selling USD back for your pesos). 2. You can use USD or your currency at street vendors, my experience the exchange rate is 10 pesos to 1 USD.3. Haggle to death. I got a nice ring for 400 USD, which I know if I have time and knowledge, I can get it down to 200 or lower.
Amazing. Great place to party and shop love it completely lots of new modern shops as well as the quaint local fare makes for a great day or night out
Shop Street. Nice street to go shopping and to hang around, so many people and it is really entertaining because there are so many shops.

Fun!. Fun place to be and hang out but everything is very expensive on this street! If you just get out a bit prices drop by half and usually not at the expense of quality! If you want to discover the real playa don't be afraid to step out of la Quinta!

Tourist trap but a must. This is a straight up tourist trap in Playa del Carmen. With that being said, if you go into this experience with that in mind, you will come out on top. It really is a must when visiting Playa del Carmen. There are tons and tons of stores and restaurants that line this avenue with people standing outside trying to get you to come in. They will yell for your attention and tell you of their great discounts and merchandise. Some will be funny, some will be crude. It really is quite the experience. As you walk, you might catch some performers closer to the ferry dock and the pier. It's a lot of fun. It's a good place to buy souvenirs as well.

Shopping!. You can find lots of shops and places to eat on Quinta avenida. The only thing did not like is how aggressive these vendors are. I get they have to make a living, but it really was a turn off. For the most part, lots of shops have the same products, but different prices. For the most part they will lower the price. This place is full of history and make the experience one to remember.

Fun street to watch people. We rode the city bus several times from the Fiesta Americana to Quinta Avenida to look around the shops and people watch! There is a nice assortment of restaurants bars and shops. Did not go to the famous Coco Bongo. Maybe next time! Always felt safe!
A good place for hanging out . I thought 5th Ave was a bit overrated. It's cool for hanging out,eating and people watching. There are better bargains to be had on side streets.

Beautiful street with much to offer. 5th Avenue is a great place for shopping and dining and entertainment. There are many restaurants to choose from. It is very safe from mourning until late into the evening. Just be prepared to be stopped by every vendor, food, retail, jewelry, local gifts, excursions, etc to buy-buy-buy. It can get annoying. They work solely for commissions so they need to sell. Also be careful that not everything they say is 100% true. They can be very convincing.
Great experience. You can do everything from shop, eat, drink, party, get spa services, and enjoy the beach here in this safe and lively location. A must see if going to Playa del Carmen.

About the experience. This is the tourist area, so you will be approached by every vendor on the street. Not overwhelming...but was a different vibe than expected. After 20-30 minutes, I became more familiar with the surroundings and the vendors, and I enjoyed it. Was able to visit many local stores and did all our souvenir shopping. Actually sat in a Mexican Cafe, and had a cold beer and relaxed quite nicely. While this area may not be ideal for every tourist, it is definitely a safe area to get the feeling of a Mexican town for families.

Nice street. Excellent street where you can stroll and find many restaurants, shops and interesting people. Very good for Mexican food restaurants specially seafood. Don't forget to bargain at the shops.
Be wary on scams.. Safe, fun and touristy. But be sure to ask for specific prices beforehand. A $3 bracelet with your name on it could cost $20

Can't beat 5th Street Shopping! It's a must!. Great prices and restaurants were really good! Close to our hotel at the Mahekal, so we loved that! Loved the pottery and bautiful embrodered pillows. You can talk the vendors down on their prices too.

If you want to escape mass tourism don't go there. Don't get me wrong, there is nothing "wrong" with the 5th Avenue of Playa. Lots of shops and restaurants. Just nothing for people who do not want to party (but to dive). Facts are: plenty o shopping and restaurants, for party seekers a good vibeAlthough, be aware as you might be overcharged (the USD ATM charges a 7% fee on top of the usual bank fees). Every ten meters a street vendor tries to sell you souvenirs or overpriced tours (you can do Chichen on your own for about 40 USD incl lunch, no need to pay 140 USD). We left Playa after two days of diving and escaped to quieter places down south.

not to impress. Too busy for our taste, be aware of the scammers, specially the ones of the corner of the Constituyentes and Quinta Avenida(Fifth Ave), they will try to sell you fishing trips or snorkeling, do not buy it.

Be prepared to be harassed by virtually every shops keeper and street sales person.. This is the tourist shopping hotspot in Playa del Carmen. I was quite stunned by how expensive it was. Many shops posted signs that prices were fixed. Seeing this place once was enough for me.

Shopping Mecca in the Caribbean. Great shopping mecca. However, be prepared to be "pitched" by vendors every few steps. Watch out for friendly locals who claim to "know you from the hotel" where they work a second job, and then try to get you to go to their "mom's jewelry shop" off the main drag. Beautiful Mexican and Mayan craftsman products can be pricey, but you are sure to find affordable souvenirs well worth the money. I bought a jellyfish lamp that I just love, and some pretty woven table runners, etc. They lend color to my home and are sweet reminders of our time in Playa del Carmen.

You will find a bit of everything here.... You will find EVERYTHING on 5th avenue, from restaurants, bars, shops lots of local art, boutique hotels, street vendors and more... I really enjoyed walking up and down 5th Ave!

Very cool place to walk around.. Bunch of stores, restaurants and people to see. You can easily spend at least 2 hours just trying to see everything. You can also buy all the handcrafted art from the locals here.

I love this place with all the restaurants, and the people watching. Walk the entire strip of Quinta Avenue. It is a blast! As I said, I love checking out all the restaurants and watching all the people. You can enter the shops you don't like and pass the ones that are not interesting. Vendors here are not that pushy. If you aren't interested there are so many people they ignore you very quickly. That is the bottomline. I have been in Egypt where political problems have left few tourists. There the vendors will harass the few tourists on and on and on to the point where you need a personal guide to fight them off. You will be ready to get violent it's so bad. And some of you think this is bad? Give me a break! Think again. You barely notice the street vendors on Quinta Avenue.
Busy area for shopping. A lot of shops and restaurants .A great place to walk around.Ate at Muelle and it was just so great.service and food and drinks were very good.

Vegas in Mexico!! You decide if that's a good or bad thing.. My husband and I traveled here in 2007 and had an amazing time. It was far less touristy. The hustle and bustle of a "Fremont Street - style Mexican Strip" was non-existent. Gone are the days of free tequila shots at happy hour, barefoot walkup beach bars, $1 beers, and $2 burritos. Not that we didn't have fun...it's just that seeing a shopping mall with Victoria Secret and American Eagle Outfitters, kind of depressed me. I don't go to Mexico to shop for MAC make-up or $40 Havainas. I go there to get a little dirty, a lot sweaty, occasionally drunk, and just have an all- around laid back good time. Sadly, the only thing really "dirty" about Playa Del Carmen now, is the shoreline. 2 foot high mounds of dead-fish smelling, rotting seaweed made the ocean disgusting and not swimmable, from any beach. Even in front of Zenzi Beach Club!!--- which is supposedly one of the highest TripAdvisor rated beach clubs in PDC. Hey Zenzi...maybe you could use some of that $125 USD I spent on a bucket of beers and chips and salsa, to clean up your beachfront. Ugh.Anyways...If you like nature, being far away from the "shopping" crowd, and are looking for a spot in the Riviera Maya where you can just go and chill on a beach like a hippie...take the ferry to Cozumel, rent a scooter or car, and drive to the other side of the island. It's pretty desolate over there, on the opposite side from where the cruise ships come into port. If I had our recent trip to do over again, we would've just spent 9 days over there in Cozumel, and skipped PDC altogether. If I want all that glittery nonsense, I can just drive 30 min down the freeway from where I live, and go to the Las Vegas Strip. I guess it just all depends on what kind of vacation you are looking for. My husband and I like to rough it a bit on vacation. We're not the "backpacker, stay-in-a-hostel type"...but in the same breath, we don't necessarily need to stay anywhere fancy, just somewhere clean and hospitable. We hardly spend anytime in our room, and set out to seek either adventure, or somewhere to chill, every day. Finding a nightclub to wander into and dance the night away is fun to do on occasion, but I'm not big on staying at a hotel right next door to nonstop, pulse-pounding music either....which seems to be the norm no matter where you stay on 5th Avenue. We are in our mid thirties and early forties. I hope giving you a little description of us helps you to decide if this is the right kind of vacation for you, or not.
Quinta Avenida. Very quaint area. Many shops but commercialized. Found a few bars that were quite fun and many many small restaurants. Very good food.
Awesome!. I was afraid for our safety at first. I was so glad we went. I was awesome and so safe. We walked around and did shopping and had a great safe time.

Fun Shopping on Quinta Avenida in Playa Del Carmen. We had a fun morning exploring Quinta Avenida in Playa Del Carmen. We took the collectivo from the Bahia Principe in Akumal for less than $3.00 each and took it back again for same. Very easy to do. They drop you off very close to Quinta Avenida. Our favorite stores were La Troupe for fantastic embroidered clothing and pillows and Ah Cacao for everything chocolate. But it was fun to explore the shops and pick up little treasures. Felt very safe and didn't worry about the vendors who tried to get our attention. Most were nice. Just avoid the jewelry stores - they have a bad reputation.
Nice walk. You can find anything in here! Restaurants, bars, shops, tours, ATMs, all kinds of nice things to look at.

Tourist trap??!!. I remembered a "small", charming, Playa del Carmen from 14 years ago so for me seeing it now was a bit of a shock. What happend to all the native charm?? It's now a huge strip mall with hundreds and hundreds shop, bars restaurants and tourists. If that's what you are into then you will definitely love this place.

Must Visit, But Don't Spend a lot of time here. Another must see destination in Riviera Maya...the vendors are very annoying ..always pitching something and in your face, but there are some interesting boutiques and restaurants. Many of the stores are cheap t-shirt stores. mall is nice

First class shops and restaurants. Wow this is a very long street with lots of shops, restaurants etc. If you cannot find anything of interest then you must be very picky. Definitely worth a visit but remember to bring your money!
vacation. is very nice lots of stores and restaurants , one con no public bathrooms.very hot,but over all very nice experience

Family Friendly!!!!!!. This was my first trip to Mexico and for my daughter to leave the states! What an experience! We went several times in the evenings, and always felt safe! We had such a great time walking up and down 5th Ave. The food was awesome, the people were very friendly, and it was great people watching. Yes, People will ask you to shop in their stores, but they live off tourism! If you kindly say no, they do not hound you.
playita del carmen asi la llaman los locales. nice place for walk and shopping very safety and colorfully and the night life soo wild and crazy the mexican people are fantastic

shopping. great for shopping and eating, best time to go in july is After 4pm as it is far too hot ,walk down to La Bodeguita Del Medio great Cuban eating place and live music from Tues-Sunday Best Mojitos in town. If you still have life in you stay around and go to Coco Bongo best night club ever we were a mixed aged group starting from 21 to 70 we left 3.30am
5th Avenue. Many great shops and a lot to see. A lot of stores both local and many that I see here in the US. A lot of places to eat and drink.
5th Ave is excellent!!!!!!!. Excellent for nightlife, bars, restaurants and shopping.best bars are near the Coco Bongo club (a must visit)

amazing place!!. It is definitively the heart of P del Carmen. It is amazing how many restaurants and attractions are in this area .Coming from NY I love the fact that you dont have to wait to be seated . I love the fact that there are many choices for food .Most of the stores are nicely decorated.I highly recommend to visit this place I will definitively go back to Playa .
Safe area. What they call 5th Avenue was a walking distance from the hotel that we stayed at. This is a very safe area even during the night time. Area full of stores, restaurants, cafe's, bars, etc.
downtown review. great for buying souvenirs at a decent price, and great local food. You can also find tours for all the major attractions probably at a better price then at the hotels.
shopping!!. great shopping and plenty of food places to pick from. very safe and friendly. not expensive at all.
Good place to walk, shop, and eat.. Great for strolling and people watching. Lots of restaurants, shops, and Mayan street performers. A nice change from being at the resort.

Lots of live music, shopping and plenty of restaurants.. 5th avenue has lots of nightlife - plenty of restaurants and live music. Of course there are lots of people trying to solicit your business, but that is pretty normal for this type of area.
Good for strolling. It's great for walking around and looking but overly priced. The vendors constantly try to get your business no matter what.

Our Favourite Place in Mexico!. We love strolling on 5th Ave in Playa. We always feel safe and enjoy the relaxed atmosphere with all of the shops , bars and restaurants. Silver jewellery heaven! Cheap Coronos!
Main Street. Everything you need in Playa del Carmen is here. From the handcrafted souvenir to famous cloths shops, cafe, restaurant, bars, etc...

Very commercial - very little Mexican feeling left. Tourist shops, American style restaurants, ATM machines on every corner, Mariachi bands and flower Sellers all over The place. Not to mention The poppers for clubs, disco and similar places...
This street could Just as well be located in Benidorm or Miami. Nothing typical Mexican about it. No thx.

Nice afternoon shopping. We headed here for an afternoon of shopping. Most of the souvenir shops are the same but if you paid attention some were definitely cheaper than others. Be wary if you are staying at an all inclusive. EVERYONE works at your hotel so stay away from those folks. Also be warned some vendors will try and sell you drugs. We had a fun day and grabbed a drink at one of the local bars. We didn't get to cover the whole strip but we saw was enough. Would definitely recommend just keep your guard up.

WELL........ I am not writing this review because Quinta Avenida is unique.So, why am I writing this review?When I was planning our trip, I read reviews that made Quinta Avenida sound like Thunderdome. A horrible, dirty place with pushy street people chasing you everywhere. This WAS NOT what we experienced!As a result of these reviews, we decided not to visit. On a whim, we changed our minds and made a last-minute decision to do a little shopping. I'm glad we did. What we experienced was an enjoyable sunny afternoon with local folks in a pleasant seaside town. Right up front, Quinta Avenida is not really much different from any other mercado. Seen one, seen 'em all. Street stalls and small shops, all selling souvenirs, interspersed with bars, restaurants and high end retailers. Playa del Carmen is a pretty town, and the avenue is a tree-shaded, attractive pedestrian promenade in the heart of the tourist district. Prices are fair and the selection is not bad.Yes, you will be approached by peddlers, some more assertive than others, but all with a friendly attitude. You can banter with them and they will continue to engage you, but we never had anyone keep pushing if we gave them a firm "No". For instance, one guy approached me and tried to get me into his shop. I said, "I'm good". He replied, "but you could be better..." I laughed and said "No thanks" and he gave me a smile and a wave. We felt safe the entire time, and even found a few gifts for family and friends.I guess my point is that, if you go to another country, meet the people. It may be a little outside your comfort zone, but don't stay barricaded in your resort, afraid to experience the local culture. You're going to deprive yourself of those unique experiences that make foreign travel special.

Gotta see it. You have to visit the market and go all the way to the end by the park. There was free entertainment going on when we were there. The markets are typical trashy Mexican markets, but you should at least go in and bargain a little for the experience. Remember, start cheap...real cheap ($1) and go up because you can't come down.
Nice stroll after pool-overload. Fun little boardwalk with reasonable prices, fun shops, and plenty of armed security (felt very safe).

Good place to walk around. Fun and lively avenue to spend an evening bar hopping and looking at touristy stuff. Pretty entertaining walk. Everyone is trying to sell you something, just smile and nod and say 'no gracias' and should be fun. We stop at the little pharmacy stores and buy a can of beer or two and enjoy the ambiance walking with a cold one at hand. The kids liked all the stores as well. Super touristy.

Be wise and you'll have fun. Very safe, don't get pulled in by guys who say they work in your hotel and have a good deal for you... I got suckered in but I can haggle pretty well! If you take a cab, make sure they are wearing uniforms and get one from your hotel and take the same service back;they rely on the hotels for work and always ask how much they are going to charge.

Walk the entire avenue. This is where all locals and tourist meet. This place is also know as the 5th avenue. Everything you need in one street. Food, shopping and much more. You will not be disappointed

We loved it!! It's what you make it!. Reading reviews on here - true it is very touristy like souviner shops and people collaring you into thier shops - but isnt it like there in most tourist destinationsGreat food, mexican street food, high street shops (zara,forever 21, aldo) and traditional shops. We had a fab day :) and even went back for an evening (GO TO SENIOR FROGS - drinks and atmosphere is brill!!!)
Sea under the Stars. Hola Mexico,Very cool, bubbly street! Restaurants were varied and wonderful. Ambiance was fun. The beach at night was breathtaking. So great. Ciao, Reese & Yvannia

Parking Lot. We just wanted to stop by the beach before heading back to Cancun. It was awful. We only had less than one hour, so we decided to park near the beach. ( I believe it is closet one to the beach) The guy told me 15peso per hour. I confirmed with them many times, just in case we are going to be ripped off. Of course, the wrote the time as soon as we got in the parking gate before parking the car. ( that is okay) We came back after taking photos at the beach 10 mins before one hour. They didn't let us pay until we move the car from the parking lot. (that is okay too) We moved the car and tried to pay. They told me $50 instead of $15. I complained lots showing the sign at their shop. They asked me $5 more. I didn't understand the beginning. We paid $10 + $5 coins. During the conversation, they swap the coins to $5 + $5 coins. I saw how my husband paid. It was very obvious to say that, but they didn't have any shame. I know it is so cheap to ague. I think many people will give up for it. We knew many people trick in Mexico, I really wanted to fight for it as well as my husband. We really compline for a long time and asked for calling police. Finally let us go. We could pay for extra money since so so small, however all experiences are awful. I wanted to write here. If you are parking the place. You should video tape the conversation, and make sure how much you have to pay. When you pay, do not leave your eyes off from the money. Even you can pay money counting at loud. I can't find this parking address, but the parking is near the big bus stain (20 Av. Nte 77710 Playa del Carmen, Q.R.)
Fun street. Fun place. Sure, it's touristy, but I wouldn't suggest finding out what's behind the scenes. If you're staying at one of the local all inclusives I'd suggest taking off the bracelet.
Great place to visit. I happen to live here for over 11 years. Please visit La Quinta Avenida teres always something new. If you are an investor now is the time to invest in P.D.C.
Great shopping!. Great shopping avenue for souvenirs! Lots of options and good food too. Some places will bargain with you as well.

5th Ave - shopping paradise. Fun, busy, lives up to its name- 5th Ave... This is the place where you can buy all of your souvenirs, eat breakfast, lunch and dinner...If you are driving - be prepare to look for the parking... There are two small parking lots that fill up pretty fast...

Pretty typical tourist trap. lots of small shops selling tourist stuff, and a few bigger stores and mall. You can find some good deals compared to resort shops, and some good food and drink, but watch out for sellers claiming to know you from the resort, as they can tell from your wrist band. For better deals and less hustlers, go a few blocks further inland.

Tourist trap.. For shopping like you do at home... or for paying twice what it will cost you for food that you can find way better and way cheaper if you only make the effort to go on the 10th or upward avenues... then this is your place.But for a little authenthicity of what Mexico really is... then avoid it like the pest.Playa del Carmen is SO MUCH MORE than this "Quinta" avenida.Please make the effort to look elsewhere... you will not be disappointed.

Meh!. Quinta Avenita was just a place I wanted to visit to say "I was there". However, I do not think I'll return. It's just too touristy for me. I feel like I'm back home with the North American brand name stores and restaurants. There is definintely plenty to see and do and eat, I guess it give visitors some comfort seeing some familiar stores like MAC, Coach, Forever 21... however, when I'm in Mexico, I'd like to experience Mexican culture. That's just my opinion. It is absolutely a lively and busy place to visit. We parked indoor at the mall for 15 pesos per hour.

love it, but things are changing. let's face it - progress in many parts of the world is inevitable. Playa Del Carmen is no exception. What I Love About Quinta Avenida: the local shops, the flavor, the sights and soundsWhat I Don't Love About Quinta Avenida: The constant questions about whether or not I'd like to buy drugs. OH - and there are now multi-story shopping malls just like in America. So, remember when you travel to Playa and take that stroll down Quinta Avenida, you're going to see lots of cool stuff, you're going to get asked if you'd like to buy some drugs and you're going to see a Bath and Body Works. You can decide for yourself if that's a good thing or not.
shopping. very good but sellers very pushi, very good bargins to be had, food and drink good choice and not over priced
This place is overrated!. Overpriced and not a good value. Cancun has better and less expensive markets than 5th avenue. Never going to waste my time there again.
Worthwhile spending a morning here.. We rode bikes here from our Resort. A very lively street with plenty of places to eat and drink. A little too touristy for me but a definite place to visit.

One of the best streets in the world. One of the coolest streets in the World. Bars, Restaurants, Shops and tons of great people watching! It has a very European feel and is shut off to vehicle traffic.

Go north for better experience. the salesmen on fifth are getting quite aggressive. Avoid the south end particularly during the day, like if you have to go to the bus station walk on 10th instead. Much nicer in the evening, temps are nice, good people watching. The area starting to go north from around 14th is where we liked the best
Nice shopping. There is a lot of shops to look in. The prices were good on lots of items. Lots of places that want your money. Nice place to stroll down.

Very touristy. Once you walk down the Quinta Avenida, you can notice that all the shops appear to look the same, since most of the shops carry the same merchandise. Did not like the fact that everyone tries to approach you trying to sell you something. Watch out when the seller says that they work at the hotel you are from (Sandos) and do you remember them and he helps the family business on weekends, another marketing techinque. There is some excellent restaurants on the avenue.

Harassment, Lies, and Cheaters! Don't shop here!. I knew to expect vendors bothering me, but it is tiresome to be yelled at when we just want to walk down the street. Avoid this street if you are just trying to get somewhere. I leaned a game the men do to get you to come over. They lie and say do you remember me from last night? I'm the waiter from dinner, or I'm the hotel clerk or some other lie to pull you in. The whole point is to extract money from you by selling junk. I made the horrible mistake of buying "silver" bracelets. They were marked 925 and the vendor swore up and down about authenticity, oh no, I would not cheat you. He even used religion to placate me. What a liar. I had the bracelets tested at home and they are worthless metal. Also don't go out at night. It seems dangerous. There's cops patrolling everywhere to protect tourists but ha just don't know who is truly friendly and who wants to take advantage. Btw, the aggressive vendors are everywhere. We even found them, or rather they found us, at the Walmart and tried to sell us day trips to Cancun.
Wow. I was so impressed with the Quinta avenida, have nothing to say but if you go to cancun or riviera maya and you don't go to "la Quinta avenida" you missed the good stuff
The Playa Magnificent Mile. We enjoy the walk from one side to the other end and after a couple of days we were very pleased with the variety of shps and restaurants
Just ok. Very touristy. Lots of shopping, but all over priced and low quality. Some good restaurants to visit.
Best shopping experience . Best shops..we loved it!! The only bad thing is the heat and humidity that kills us. They also have a 3 floor mall..has a lot of nice shops and stores.

Market Place and bars. You have everything there. Great for shoppers. It's the 'happening' area. You can walk onto the public beach, dine at one of the many restaurants, or party at one of the many bars or shop for souvenirs there

My favorite "5th Avenue". One of our family's favorite activities is meandering down 5th Avenue in Playa. We start at the very beginning of the street, with the high-end shops and fountains and just keep going. There are some overly-enthusiastic vendors, but on a whole, the experience is great! We love people watching and browsing the shops. And if you get hungry or thirsty, there is a bar or restaurant every few feet!

a tourist street. A pedestrian street lined with shops and restaurants with tourist pricing. The street has many souvenir shops selling overpriced items. There is a new 3-story mall at Av. Constituyentes called Quinta Alegria with familiar international brand name shops and restaurants. There is another mall under construction just a few blocks away. At night, there are artists selling their works on the street.

Otherwise known as 5th Ave. 5th Avenue was fun, but even more enjoyable visiting at night. There was actually more going on at night than during the day. In the evening, there would be people dressed up or painted to look like statues. There would be more little shows to watch and enjoy. My friend and I visited during the day, and on the advice of our hotel conseaire, went back in the evening. One thing we did enjoy was a pedicure where little fish ate the dead skin off of your feet. I had read about this in a spa magazine, so I was eager to try it. I will say that you can barter and try to get a good deal if you see something you really want to buy. In fact, you might even be chased somewhat to try and get you to buy their goods. A little hassling is okay, but I did tire of it quickly.
Great place. Nice place to go for a walk, dinner and shopping ! Great atmosphere and many nice places to have a drink at and enjoy nice music as well!
Touristy. Very touristy area with lots of souvenir shops with some bars and restaurants. Not a life changing experience but worth a walk down if you are in the area.

A mix of Key West & Miami Beach a la Mexico. Quinta Avenida or 5th Ave is the main tourist drag / shopping street / pedestrian thoroughfare of Playa del Carmen. Pretty much everything you expect to find in a touristy beach town you'll stroll pass here: bars, Starbucks, restaurants, McD's, shop after shop of cheap tourist trinkets with aggressive sales people. There are countless places to stop for a place to rest or drink. We enjoyed strolling down the street and back up on the beach after turning at the little white Catholic Church - Nuestra Senora del Carmen.

Annoying people asking for American dollars . I was really annoyed by the shopkeepers asking me to pay in U.S. Dollars , excuse me I'm not American I'm Canadian so stop asking me for US dollars , i got so fed up , everything is super overpriced and in U.S. Dollars , even the junk is expensive .
