Quinta Avenida. Excellent place to walk and eat dinner after an exciting day in Xel-ha and Xplore. I recommend walking for the Quinta Avenida.

A Good Way to Spend a Few Hours. A leisurely walk down 5th Avenue is a great way to spend an afternoon or evening. During the day it can get very hot, though. Most of the same shops have numerous locations, either with the same name or a variation, but there are the occasional gems tucked in. The best deals can be found on the streets and avenues just off 5th. It appeared that a lot of these shops were locally owned and family-run.

A walk at 5ta avenida. We went to this ave just to check how it was and we liked it. Prices vary a lot so my advice is to ask for prices and keep on walking, you can always do better if you are into saving a little money here and there. Silver is a little higher than other places like chichenitza. But you can always bargain too. Sont go with your first. Keep looking but in general is a good place to spend an afternoon, food is great too..
Night time fun. 5th Avenue has expanded and rebuilt a lot during the last few years. Nights are the best, as the day can be very hot. Every kind of food you could imagine is available.
Shopping!. Love it! Great for shopping! It has all kinds of restaurants , local shopping and good prices ...the enviroment is very friendly...

Entertaining. It's the place to shop and eat. All kinds of shops that you would find at a typical mall in the USA and a lot of little shops from local vendors. Also street performers are out to entertain you, working for tips. Lots of bars and restaurants.

Mexico is Not Fun. 12 years ago this was a pleasant experience. During the recent excursion it was sad to see how the commercialization has destroyed the charm of this city. Basically the Cancun experience has absorbed the entire Maya Riviera. Shop owners ceaselessly hound you until you can't stand it. There is no peace. "Gringo, spend money or go home" is the reception you can expect. It was awful. And nothing to see or buy except the same crap in every shop. Absolutely nothing of interest. Buy some made in mexico trinket at your local Wal-Mart and you will have the same thing for less money. And we were robbed by the police at a traffic checkpoint. All the advice about what to do when the cops try to extort money is just jibberish when you are confronted by a sweaty cop with a machine gun on his shoulder telling you that you can not leave until you give him $50.00. Stay Away!!

Shopping mood.. I`ve known la quinta since it was two blocks long and the only attractions on it were a t-shirt shop, the Quiam family store where you could buy a cold beer or a bag of chips and the Pez Vela restaurant.. Today, it`s hard to recognize the old laid back place, as now impressive commercial centers with expensive condos on top are sprouting in every corner. All I can say is: impressive. Bring your shopping mood and your thick wallet.

Tourist Trap. I'm staying with my family out of town, but I came in to town to address a rental car issue. I decided I would walk around a bit to see the town. Finding parking was a real challenge, but I finally found a spot near the zocalo. I walked along the beach and along Quinta Avenida. "Sir!", "Hey, guy!", "You dropped something", "Senor!" - the only difference between this street and tourist traps around the world is the slightly higher incidence of Spanish. I guess the silver lining was that only one person asked if I wanted smoke or girls. The street has an odd mix, with high-end boutiques next to mass-produced souvenirs.I don't ever need to return.

Great People Watching. This is a vibrant area with lots of people watching. Sure, the locals try to sell, and pitch and persuade. But that's part of the fun. You might just find something you like. Otherwise, sit and watch them pitch everything from vacations, to tours to products.

Good place to have a walk. It is a place which is good for shopping and you can also find restaurants and bars but generally I noticed that the prices are very high in comparison with Mexico city and its surroundings areas. So, If you intend to shop and you have programed to visit Mexico before or after, make your shopping there. Prices in Cancun are 3 times higher.

Our Cancun Honeymoon. This downtown Cancun (flea market ) locals shopping center is somewhat cheaper than other centers. But as with other Mexican shops you have to bargain down the price to get a good deal!! So do not settle and don't act too interest or they will not bargain. Good Luck.

Shopping heaven. Great area with lots of shopping. Pure tourist area. Many vendors selling all kinds of souvenirs. Many choices to eat. Lots of cantinas for you to sip on a drink. Can't miss area with red brick road
Loved it!!. Great place for shopping! You can find everything there! The cheapest place are in the middle of the street. Great for a night walking! On May stores closed around 10-11pm.Very charm!!

Touristville. Playa Del Carmen is a nice town. But 5th Avenue is like being in a giant sales pitch center. Everyone wants to be your friend. Everyone invites you into their shop. And I mean everyone. It's non stop. And sometimes it gets to be too much. Okay. We're gringos. We get it. The street is jammed with restaurants and shops and people are nice, but everyone is trying to sell you something every minute you're there. So it got so tiresome we started to use the other streets where people leave you alone. Nice town. Lots to do. Over the top street: Quinta Avenida

Great promenard. Nice shopping area.Very turistic.Regular mexican stalls for tourists from handcrafts cigars and more Many coffee shops and wxcellent restaurants.Eat only on this avenue...prices might be for tourists but quality and service are great. Eating off the avenue at a local restaurant even if it is one street off can be disasterous.Best time is at night when the restaurants and bars are full and alive.Enjoy

Don't miss it. It is closed to cars and is great fun for people watching, shopping and some restaurants. I suggest walking early in the day, or early evening during hot weather, to avoid the mid-day heat.

Perfect for strolling, people watching or souvenir shopping. Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) is a lovely walk through Playa del Carmen offering a variety of shops, bars, lounges, boutique hotels, restaurants, and souvenir stores. Our family likes to stroll down 5th Avenue (foot traffic only), stop for an ice cream or buy one of the artisan souvenirs. It can be whatever you want it to be...a place to chill out in a jazz bar, or enjoy dinner on the balcony of a second floor restaurant and people watch. Also, lots of places to exchange currency.I recommend starting about 1 hour before sundown so that you can watch the vibe of the street change.

Buy the souvenirs for those who stayed back at home. Many shops & all selling the same kind of stuff: tequila, vials filled with sand, mexican chocolate, corona beer T shirts, ornaments, magnets, the usual stuff (but with Playa del Carmen written on them). The guys will try to catch your attention with the line: "Hey I am your waiter"). Drugstores on almost every block (ideal for sun screen or other stuff not usually sold OTC in many countries). Bars and places to eat or drink. A nice pedestrian street with a mall at its southern tip next to the pier of the Cozumel ferry. Starbucks too.Nice for a stroll and to buy a souvenir for those who stayed back at home.

Very busy and you will get pestered to buy something!. After visiting here I was so glad we weren't staying in PDC. Walking down this street you will get harassed to buy something and they will keep on as they do not understand a polite no thank you. Drugs were openly offered, which made you feel uncomfortable and I was glad I was there in daylight as I can imagine it worse at night.

You MUST spend some time here. We love quinta avenida. It is one giant market where you can find anything. Great restaurants and bars also abound. The hustle and bustle can be a little noisy at times but all you have to do is go a few metres off of the street and all is quiet again.

calle Quinta. I liked the abundance of shops and food, however, i did not enjoy the heckling from tours personnel. it seem like every step you took, somebody was bugging your walk by selling various tours, especially those to Cozumel, a famous attraction nearby.

Great atmosphere and really cool restaurants and shops !. Quinta Avenida is one our favourite things to do once in Playa . We really like to go for a dinner and drinks every night on Fifth Ave. This street has such a good atmosphere and vibe that is true pleasure going there walking around , checking some stores , bars ,restaurants etc . Its very few places in the Caribbean that I've seen with such a great place and atmosphere with so many things to do .We truly enjoy walking the street and all the cool stuff there .

Nice Experience but Make Sure to Bargain. We took a taxi by going outside of our resort. This is recommended as the taxis at the resort charge much more. They have to pay the hotel a hefty commission. Just go outside of the hotel grounds and bargain with the driver. It cost us almost the same as taking the collectivo and the driver waited for us for a few hours while we went shopping. The shopping itself was nice. Do not buy for the price marked (unless the prices are fixed, which is clearly marked) and do not buy at the first store you see. This is the only thing that was annoying. The same sombrero cost 400 pesos in one store and 150 pesos in another. So, walk around first and BARGAIN. If you are buying silver, go to an actual jewelry store, as the ones on the street might be fake (advice of our tour guide). Even at the jewelry store, ask for 40% off right away. That seems to be the standard in all the stores we visited. If you are looking for genuine crafts, go to an art gallery store. Those usually have fixed prices but the pieces are absolutely beautiful. My favorite were the wood, carved, and beautifully painted, locally found animals, such as coatis, iguanas, etc. We also bought some hand made blankets and cotton pants and dresses all made in Mexico. For the not so genuine trinkets, there are hundreds of stores you can go to. And it is a good place to have your daughter's hair braided, if you have time. The prices are much better than at the hotel spas. Unfortunately, we did not have the time to wait and had to settle for the hotel spa. There are also tons of places to buy cigars, and we have seen so many as my husband and his friend are really into them. Again, bargain and see a few places before you buy. Ask which ones you can bring across the border if you are planning to bring them back. The people selling them will know. Our entire family is vegan and we could not find a single place to eat, unfortunately. All the restaurants seem to be stake and seafood and meat, meat, meat. And they push the kids menu (chicken fingers, fries, etc.). We do not eat any of that stuff. So, if you are into healthy eating you might want to eat before you go as there is not much there that's healthy.I heard that you can see pretty awful stuff on Quinta Avenida, like baby lions, which are obviously kept in captivity. We did not see any of that. If you do, do not take pictures as that only promotes exploitation of these poor animals.
Busy street. Felt kind of trashy in a Niagara Falls ways ...lots of souvenirs if that's your thing.Other parts of city nicer.
A pleasant atmosphere, shops bars and restaurants. A pleasant atmosphere, shops bars and restaurants.Lots of souvenir shops You should bargain for everything People are really nice

Better than anywhere USA. This area is why you come to a place like this. Anything you need, you can get for a much better price. The people are friendly and willing to help you in getting anything you want, but you much be able to negotiate. Aside from that, there's food, drinks, fun to be had all up and down the whole street.

Awesome for relaxing walks. This place is Long, we could not walt tyyowards the end, but saw many things , storfes , resstaurants and even a dancing club. Saw it during day and at night, felt safe walking thru it.

Bargains can be found. It was fun to walk among the stores and you will have to bargain or pretend to walk away at some locations in order to get a better price. If you are staying at an all inclusive resort you will be wearing wrist bands and most of the shops have hawkers who ask if you remember them in order to get you to stop and try to get you into their stores, be careful!
Colorful, vivid and noisy. Very nice place to take a stroll day or night. Lots of restaurants, tour kiosks and cafes. Always alive any time of the day.

Anywhere USA. We came to Playa three years ago, and loved the atmosphere on 5th. We got a big shock on arriving back this year, as Playa has changed almost beyond recognition. What used to be a pretty street is now rammed with shops selling practically the same thing, with vastly inflated prices, and there's nobody buying. That would be bad in itself, but what has ruined the town is the arrival of several new malls, with bigger ones being built on 5th, which has turned the street into a homogenised version of anytown USA. The shops are the same old same old, Victoria's Secret, Nike, Sunglasses Hut, Forever 21. It's horrible, and the arrival of the malls has clearly driven up the prices of all the other shops along the street, because there are no bargains and no decent shops left. There are clearly a lot of people making a lot of money out of Playa, but They have torn the heart out of the place and we won't be coming back.

STRESSFUL SHOPPING.. There are a lot of stores and street vendors with a variety of items. Some of them are very persistent in tourists purchasing their products. Once shop owner even came outside of the store and followed us down the street constantly lowering the price for the item. We were not interested and kept walking, but this was just too stressful so we left.

Fun Place to Shop. Our taxista took us to this amazing store that sells hand painted plates. It was to die for. Found souvineers for everyone. There were fun shops and places to eat. I loved it! Definitely a must see!!!
Love this street. Love, love Quinta avenida. All the restaurants, all the stores, the atmosphere. This is an unbelievable place to visit outside the hotels.

Interesting to walk through - too pushy. Shops are interesting to look at, especially ones with local goods. Lots of touristy ones, most prices are the same. Lots of people selling day excursions, also shops selling silver and cigars. People selling day excursions were the pushiest. They were all pleasant, nobody was rude or mean, just pushy. Some shoppers liked this, I didn't even though I know it's the custom in this area. Some shop keepers are willing to bargain, my husband and kids did get some good deals.

where to get your souvenirs. very nice avenue, kept clean, just be aware you can buy certain things if you haggle at different places, and some places in those general stores are pretty reasonable. I never paid attention to the vendors. I would however, not recommend eating at the bigger places there as they're expensive, we made the mistake of doing this and highly regretted it. You can find some not so flashy restaurants that are moderately priced. Be prepared to do a ton of walking!
Local Flavor. Loved walking the avenue, people very friendly not pushy. Lots of local shops and eateries to explore

Cute shops . Lots of cute shops from cheap little souvenir stands to pricier designer stores. Personally we enjoyed the local shops as you get a better feel of the culture instead of air conditioned European/American designer stores (you can get those at home). Our only complain was all the shop owners yelling out to shoppers trying to entice themTo go into their shops

Quinta Avenida just ok. We visited quinta avenida because we heard it was a good place to shop at. Many of the stores you can find at home like TAG, MK, etc. There is a very nice small church "nuestra señora del Carmen" to visit.
Divas on Deck Vacation 2015. Nice long walk. Lots and Lots of shops for shopping. Restaurants! Bars! Mall!A must visit when in Playa Del Carmen.
Start here in this Avenue. A street with a very nice ambience and where you can find lots of place to have a delicious meal in Playa del Carmen.

Too much pressure. The 5th Avenue strip is a typical tourist trap. Most of what was available for sale is junky and over priced. The sales guys are annoying, and they will try to tell you that they work in whatever hotel you're staying, and that they are off today working in their family business. Don't buy it and enjoy the experience, but keep your wallet in your pocket.

Fifth avenue hard sell. Nice walk . Lots of sunglass shops, plenty of cheap tchotchke shops very aggressive annoying vendors who ask you over and over again to buy. Hey senior massage Is something you hear over and over. Swim wear clothes expensive you have to expect that in a tourist area.Everyone in the resort has family that sell things on the street when you walk they say don't you remember me from the hotel? Come in and look it doesn't cost anything then the hard sell comes.Prices are similar in all the shops. Beautiful old church worth seeing.

Absolutely the place to go while staying close to Playa del Carmen, a pedestrian only mile of shops, bars and food.. 5th Avenue or Quinta Avenida in Playa del Carmen is a destination by itself. One caveat--if you are there in the summertime, go late in the afternoon as the heat will make the visit memorable--but for the wrong reason. Four of us walked 5th avenue one afternoon and by the time we were at Constituents Avenue we were drenched in sweat. We had to sit under a tree with some cold refreshments for quite a while to cool down so we could walk back to the south end.5th Avenue is a pleasant destination free of vehicles for North American, European and Mexican tourists full of various shops, restaurants, bars and motels. For those that are concerned about safety--it is very safe and if you ever asked anyone who has been there you will get the same response. You read this correctly--it is pedestrian traffic only. And if you have a burning desire to go to WalMart while there, it is a short 4 block walk from 5th Avenue.In the late afternoon and early evening is the time to walk the avenue. They have strolling Mariachi bands for your enjoyment and the afternoon shade of the buildings makes for a pleasant walk. Many of the restaurants have eating available alongside the avenue at street-side tables. We stopped for beer and pizza one of those locations and enjoyed people watching while we ate.It is somewhat amazing to see what is in the shops. They have the normal shops that sell the t-shirts, hats, masks and ceramic items and they also have the jewelry shops. What is not expected is the high end shops that exist on the south end of 5th Avenue and those near Constituents Avenue (Avenida Constituyentes).Near the south end is the public beach and the ferry crossing to Cozumel. It is a very friendly place with a very diverse business structure. They only annoying issue is the same issue facing tourists in the Caribbean. When things are a little slow, the shop owners become a nuisance by trying to get you into their shop. Once you get past that issue--it is an enjoyable experience.

Agressive vendors. We were dropped there by our cab driver and gave us 3 hours to spare but we ended up having enough with just 2.It is a commercial street where you can buy very pricey souvenirs mostly made in China and the likes. The street is very charming but not the guys trying to sell you everything (yes, everything). The best part where the little white Catholic chapel and the fish pedicures offered at a very zen store almost at the beginning of the strip by a very bubbling Venezuelan girl and her helper, don't remember the name of the place but it shares the entrance with a little hotel. $20 for 20 minutes fish pedicure + 5 minutes foot massage.

typical holiday street. bars,restuarants,shops,drug dealersbars and restuarants,can get some good deals if you look about on beer and food,everything from local food to mcdonalds,some designer shops but mostly tourist tack shopsi have tattoo sleeves so seemed like that was a sign for everyone coming over asking if i wanted to buy a selection of drugs,a no was all it took but did get boring time after time
So many stores, so little time. Shopping to your hearts content, plus bars and restaurants for miles. Don't buy at the shops closest to the beach, the prices are better further in.

30 blocks of a pedestrian only on 5TH Avenue. Hundreds of bars, restaurants, cafes, discos, cigar lounges, and anything to have fun under the sun and moon all day and all night long. Very secure anytime

You can find everything here!. Playa del Carmen is such a nice mexican town. I love la quinta avenida, specially in the evenings when is lively and you get to have a nice drink with a nice mexican meal. They have all kinds of restaurants from what I saw but when in Mexico I prefer to go for the traditional fare. The street is colorful and a nice playa to walk around and see some shops or get some ice cream and people watch.

Fun to shop and browse!. Great place to stroll and bargain for souvenirs, as long as you don't mind the hawkers and the come-ons like "hey I was your waiter last night at your hotel, don't you remember me!" We just laughed and enjoyed the "game"!

Come on! You love it or leave it, but there is definitely nothing like it!!!. I have recommended it many, many times. Many people I know have come here and loved it as well. It's like this, sure people call you over to try to sell you cheap trinkets. But where can you go, walk miles of cobblestone streets, with no cars to worry over, and everybody comes here to eat, laugh, shop a little, see and be seen, and just play with your family? This is it. Finally a real place, way too big to see one day off a cruise ship. Playa Del Carmen and Fifth Avenue are a special, family old Mexico place, away from the party Cancun scene. The reef is about 50'yards away from Fifth Avenue, and you can see it as you lounge around in an outdoor seating restaurant, with mariachi bands wandering by, playing. Really, believe me, if you like people and casual dining nights, this is the place to be. I cannot tell you how many times I have talked to shop owners there that have said, "I came here to visit, and never left!" I wish I didn't have to leave too!

Busy street. This street was amazing for getting around. You can walk from end to end. There are plenty of shops and amazing restaurants. Taxis are always at your service, but we chose to walk until we couldn't walk anymore.

It's OK to blink. We probably ate at restaurants here about 7 times, never at the same place twice, and always had excellent service and great food. The shopping opportunities are hard to describe. There are many, many places to purchase common (mass-produced) items. Go ahead and blink; if you miss something, you'll see something similar within a block. If haggling is your thing, go for it because you will probably be successful. At least once, I had every intention of moving along until the seller made a discounted offer I couldn't refuse. (My kids love those hammocks!). Sellers consistently try to draw you in, but rarely get "ugly" when you decline. And, by the way, there are little markets and pharmacies along the avenue, so don't worry if you forgot your toothbrush or have an urgent need for a coconut!

5th at night. 5th Ave is a great place to walk along at night. The lights and open air feeling are great. Try to stop at the smaller venues for a clod drink and a bit to eat. Do go off some of the side streets to find the interesting shops. There are some local artists that set up on some of the week nights

Cool street to stroll, grab a cold drink, and people watch.. Fun place for a stroll, a drink and good people watching. This was my first trip to Playa. I have stayed in smaller places like Akumal and Puerto Morelos over the years. This made 5th Ave seems forever long to me! I enjoyed myself and thought it was clean and the people were friendly. We did not go into many shops so I cannot speak to the pushy. The bar/restaurant staff were nice enough. The street is long, were good shoes! I do agree it is super touristy but you are staying in Playa, which is super touristy by nature. I went here with one of my girlfriends one night and then with a big group the next night and can tell you Friday nights are hoping maybe too much. The Thursday night adventure was quieter but perhaps even more fun--no pressure from anyone and several free drinks!

Very family oriented and so much to do. The weather is always great in Playa.. Playa del Carmen is one of the many cultural experiences of Mexico you will get along the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico. You have it all in one place and reason it has made the charts as on of the top 10 destinations to visit only hours from the US coast.

Shop til you drop. Lots to be seen here, from jewellery stores to souvenirs. The steer is quiet vibrant and substantially long so you can browse at your leisure. Quiet a few restaurants along here too which were yummy. A must to go to. Checkout the nightlife also, lots to do!

Walking, shoppin, eating, drinking... what else?. You have to go there during the day, in the afternoon or night will be better; fresh. Not too much sun. This is better than a shopping mall; you will love to buy Mexican Hand Crafts and will love to walk there.

I must have seen this before. This pedestrian street is similar to many others I have seen in different locations, tourist shops, small restaurants, bars and tourist souvenir shops mixed and available all day to the crowds of tourists. It has nothing to do with Mexico, it could be anywhere.

Tourist trap. We were staying just off 5th avenue, so unfortunately had to walk down this street every day. It got busier throughout the day, ending in every evening being full of drunk and loud people. Numerous shops geared up purely for the tourists selling tacky Mexican souvenirs. Just not my idea of fun.

Fun street with a touch of seedy. This road has some interesting shops and is mostly fun but there is quite a bit of peddlers with unsavory wares so keep that in mind. You will not have a problem unless you go out looking for it or you are incredibly prudish.

Bars, restaurants and shops. Beautiful restaurants,nice bars, ovesome night life, in stores prices are a little high and there is not a real mexican typical market outthere. I'm use to visit a lot of handcraft and little markets in Mexico and you will not find this kind of handcrafts here. But overall is fun to walk around the avenue.
Much Fun. Lovely Walk down this avenue, loaded with restaurants, shopping, bartering suggested, but not always appreciated.
Everything you need. Nice restaurants and a lot of shops. You can find everything you need. Nice walk until de main "plaza".
Overrated. The days of 5th avenue being hip are over. It's over developed and now populated by cheesy shops owned by pushy salesmen and aggressive drug dealers. Avoid.

Must see....once.. We spent two nights in Playa just a few steps from 5th Ave on calle 2. Quinta is sort of like Disneyland. Everyone should see it once, but that's probably enough. Unfortunately, most of the restaurants are located on or near it. The prices in the shops are inflated. I found much better deals and nicer people in Tulum and Akumal. One store on la quinta wanted 450 pesos for a piece of Mayan art the same size as one I purchased in Tulum for 180 pesos. The vendors in Playa aren't necessarily rude, just relentless. If you are a relatively young male and not with family expect to be constantly offered all sorts of illegal substances.

If you like night life you are in the right spot.. 5th is very Mexican typical, crowded, noisy, vibrant, and pushy vendors. The Ave. if full of bars and places to eat and way over priced shops.If you want good food and a more authentic old mexico get off of 5th and explore the town.
shopping and eating galore.. another year in quinta.this place gets better and better as every year goes by.cannot wait till 2016 make sure you visit the amber store.

A wild place. Be prepared for walking down fifth avenue. We were advised to go in the evening to avoid the heat of the day. That was a great piece of advice, cause it is still hot in the evening. There are lots of shops, that pretty much all carry the same things. We didn't shop for jewelry at all, so I cannot comment on whether those are a good deal. I bought a really nice leather and embroidery backpack from a vendor that I will treasure, but I don't think it is one of a kind..and honestly had I known how much it was in America dollars I probably wouldn't have bought it. Sometimes ignorance is bliss. Every vendor is talking to you and trying to lure you into his store. It was a bit overwhelming for me the first time, but not so much by our second and third trip out. Go get something to eat and a Mexican treasure to take home with you.

Fun shopping strip. I didn't realize how extensive this area was. Almost 3/4 miles of shops, restaurants and bars. It's fun to stroll. Don't settle on the 1st shop or price. These vendors expect haggling. The street food is safe and delicious.

Shoping in Playa del Carmen. The variety of what is on sale and the prices of even designer goods is excellent. There are the usual vendors trying to entice you in to their shops but they are all good humored and never pushy.

Best at night. It was extremely hot during our visit so daytime strolling was very uncomfortable, but the lights and milder temps made evening visits interesting. I can't imagine anything you might need that you could find somewhere on Quinta Avenida.
5th avenue. Vibrant, overpriced and touristy. Though should be experienced if in the area. A lot of construction when we where there

Shop, Shop, Shop!. Great avenue for shopping. Lots of restaurants also for delicious food. And Starbucks which I craved for for 4 days before finally coming here, and we saw 4 of them. I was so delighted...loll. Great stores for souvenirs. A Senor Frog's also.

Great shopping. This area of town is extremely shady. If you just stay on the main street it is very secure and safe. There are tons of vendors and shopping from budget to high class. We were there for 3 hrs and didn't even see half of the shops.

Exploring Cancun. It's a very touristic area, but prices are in dlls n pricy, lots of stores, bars n restaurantsJust really not for me. A block away i found a little restaurant with good food n reasonable prices, no need to pay mire than what us worth.LAS BRISAS REST
Dinna R B. Enjoyed walking down this ave. felt safe and comfortable. Was surprised to see US stores. Looked forward to bargaining for the best price. Lots of local handicraft.
Love it!. Love this street! it's perfect at night. Bars, restaurants Shops all you can have in one place! Just perfect!

Retail therapy. 5th Avenue is a box of delights. A very long street with masses of souvenir shops, interspersed with restaurants, bars, jewellery shops, pharmacies, perfume shops, and massage parlours. A great atmosphere, especially in the afternoon, when you may find entertainment on the street, especially near the park. Only problem is the vendors who try to entice you into their shops, especially if you happen to just browse the windows. Still, they are very friendly, and a no usually suffices. Certainly worth a visit, and if you have time, a ferry trip to Cozumel is worth the trip.

Underwhelming. Oh, 5th Avenue. 10 minutes of walking down a portion of this (very long) shop-lined street made my husband and I go out of our way to avoid it when possible for the remainder of our stay (with the exception of when we purposely went back for souvenirs). You can find any souvenir possible, but hardly any of the shops are unique in what they sell. The vendors will harass you to no end, however, most will drop it the moment you say "no, thank you." We only had a few people that had a hard time taking "no" for an answer. We also got very blunt offers for many types of drugs--something that caught us off guard the first time we were asked.Once inside a store, sometimes the staff would follow you around while you browsed. Super uncomfortable. We left quickly when that was the case.In addition to shopping, there are plenty of restaurants and bars but we never visited any of them, except for Ah Cacao Chocolate Cafe, which is a must for any chocolate lovers out there.Overall, 5th Avenue is worth checking out for souvenirs for but I would keep my distance otherwise. The constant harassment can be draining!
Tons of choices. Lots of restaurants and stores for all budgets. Very safe feeling any time of day.Pay by Peso's as US prices at locations is far less than at ATM's or exchange booths

Good shopping-street for all you needs. The main street for food, shopping, nightlife and tours. The shops and restaurants are pricier than a few blocks to the west and up to twice as expensive as in other less touristy places in Mexico. But there's plenty of options to chose from and you can buy stuff and equipment that you can't find in less up-scale places.The street is also only one block from the beach, though when I was there the beach was covered with sea-weed and odor was bad. There are a few places right on the beach with a beautiful view.Sometimes there are street-artists (pirates etc.) performing in front of the big shopping-mall. Definitely worth checking out. The further north you go the smaller the shops tend to be.

Great walk to 5th avenue. We left our hotel on 95th street and decided to walk into town. Didn't take to long to get to the first of the 5th avenue shops. We visited a couple and did some browsing to decided what we wanted to take back. Stopped in one of two Starbucks for a frappacino and a bathroom break. We continued our walk and were approached by a guy who 'recognized' us ... Just be aware that the sale guys on 5th avenue are very slick. They know the various hotel bracelets and will greet you as if they work at that hotel. They are usually pretending to be one of the bartenders or waiters from your specific hotel. All they want to do is to take you to one of 'their' relatives stores nearby and offer to give you the best price because you are staying at the hotel which they supposedly work at. The shop keepers give these guys a commission or percentage of whatever you purchase to bring you into the shop. They are not dangerous just can be a bit annoying. The guy who stopped us tried to sell us Cozumel magic stone earrings .. Started at 473.00 then went to 261.00 ... Then got down to 150.00 before we just told him that we were not interested. Anyway we continued walking and window shopping untill tropical storm bill decided to produce some very heavy rain. So we decided to get a taxi back to the hotel. On a personal note - If you decide to buy anything it might benefit you to change dollars into pesos because you get a better exchange rate 14.3 rather then some vendors calculating 10 pesos to the U.S. Dollar. We used our credit card which does not have a foreign Transaction fee for most of our purchases.

Loads of shops!. This is a very long street full of shops. Most are touristy shops with the occasional shops for locals such as pharmacy, fruit shop, and . There are loads of bars, restaurants and clubs and no shortage of taxi ranks. Thestreet is kept very clean and the people are lovely. They ask you to visit their shops but they dont harrass you and they do accept "no" for an answer. The atmospheres lovely with the odd mexican band playing to the crowd. An excellent place to visit .for souvenirs

Nice walk early in the morning. Avendia Cinco awakens around 7AM with Ah Cacao's several locations. It's a great place to walk, but PDC's best food is found further west. La Bamba Jarrocha on 30 Ave; El Fagon, Kaxache, etc.
Have fun, shop, dine and enjoy the scenery!. It is completely what you make of it. Enjoy the vendors. Ignore them if you wish. Enjoy the food and most of all enjoy the culture.

Loved the Shopping. Many stores to shop at, lots of little shops with souvenirs (don't forget to bargain) I got souvenirs for all my family at a great price.quinta Avenida has lots of restautants and bars. My husband and I walked around and enjoyed the beach, we had a chance to see the ritual ceremony of the Voladores.

Favorite activity on every trip. This is the place to be in the evening, as people gather in chic patios of restaurants and the music from clubs adds excitement to the air. Fun to drink or just watch people. Daytime for shopping but be aware you will need a hat and bottled water as it gets super hot walking around in the sun.

Great pedestrian street. From upscale stores to local shops you can find pretty much anything here for perfect trip souvenirs to Playa del Carmen. From Starbucks to local taquerias. Highly recommended!!!

Touristy area of PDC, but fun to walk along. Quinta Avenida is the main strip (for tourists) in PDC, there are a lot of restaurants and bars, each with their own bit of flare. It's fun to walk along and people watch, but I recommend also exploring 1st Avenue and 10th Avenue (only one block each way- they go in increments of 5), lots of interesting restaurants and bars along those streets as well

Everything we expected. Lots of stores-small and large. Always haggle. Stores werent too pushy; didnt keep trying after you told them no. Lots of fun lots of food and if you ate not into the whole small stores and bargaining, there's a mall with stores from Forever 21 to Harley Davidson.

Fifth Avenue Shopping was great!. Visited this shopping area with a group of friends - our tour operator, Sunquest, offered this excursion free of charge so we went. It was a lot of fun - air conditioned van picked us up at our resort, then we visited a silver factory, and finally went on to Fifth Avenue. Lots of shops offering the regular tourist fare. Lots of great ice cream and coffee places too (including Starbucks! lol). The street is very long (something like 13 kms) so we didn't dawdle too long in any one spot. There is a great little "mall" with a Harley Davidson shop for you bikers. In short, our couple of hours on the street went way too fast! Thoroughly enjoyed popping in and out of all the little shops! You will too - don't forget your camera and a bag for your purchases!

very nice, but too much. Initially a shopping walhalla: loads of shops, restaurants, bars, music. Never a dull moment. New shopping malls are built right now for upgrading the atmosphere. However , we got irritated by dozens of guys who (every day again) try to "seduce" you for visiting their shabby shops or services by saying: "hey, I'm the nice waiter of your hotel". This was even more pathetic then the salesmen in cheap Egyptian areas. Get rid of them or the brand stores will regret this in the near future.
Great place to Walk, eat and drink !. we love it ! not only can you walk , eat and drink ! but great place to by souvinors! cant wait to go back again!

Great walk dowtown it is a must. Recently just got refurbish and looks amazing a must when you come to the riviera maya for shopping take a long walk and get involve with many people from all over the world

I gotta say...didn't excite me at all.... With all the hype this place got, it was a total let down once we got there. It's just one of the few things to do in the area, short of an excursion, beach, or hotel pool. All the shops had the same stuff and the merchants scream at you to come into their shops or buy excursions from them. The pro is if you want to go to a bar or have dinner outside of your hotel, there are many different options. Plenty of taxis to take you here or there if you don't feel like walking on a hot day. You can catch the ferry to Cozumel from here too, which is very convenient. Soon there will be more big box stores in addition to the ones already there (Sunglass Hut, Zara, Starbucks, Hagen Daz, Lacoste, Tommy Hilfiger, Beneton, are already there). Mostly local merchants though, which is cool if that's what you like. Wal-Mart is a few blocks off 5th Avenue as an fyi...Another thing, although Quinta Avenida is expensive, it's cheaper than shopping over in Cozumel. Because the cruise ships come in to Cozumel, the prices increase until 3pm. After 3pm, the prices decrease once the cruise ships leave. Overall though, it's cheaper to shop on Quinta Avenida.
Ripped off. Be careful of the exchange rate. We we quoted one price in dollars and charged much more when the credit bill came

Losing its Appeal. It has been 4 years since we last visited Playa del Carmen. The aspect that bothered me the most about 5th Ave. were the malls containing European and North American stores. I could go to a mall in the US if I wanted to shop for those items. There are still a few stores located on 5th Ave. that are worth checking out. This area is also great for people watching. ATM fraud is a huge problem on 5th Ave. We walked up 5th Ave. towards 38th Calle and found several ATM machines with cameras facing the keypad. DO NOT USE ATM MACHINES ON 5TH AVE. The problem was worse than I expected. My bank even stopped the use of my card until I contacted them even though I let them know ahead of time. I was told ATM fraud was a severe problem in the area.
So, So.. Too many people stopping you asking to buy their services or items. The strip was really long. Many, many stores to chose from.

Local style. I love 5th shopping, BUT, go up a couple blocks to 20th and grab a street taco from a local vendor. They're more authentic, and the food and drinks are cheaper. Get away from the tourist area, dont panic, it's safe save lots of money shopping where the locals shop.

5th Avenue. Walking 5th Ave. is a fun way to spend a few hours in Playa Del Carmen. You can shop and interact with vendors. Be prepared for insults if you bargain too hard with some shop owners, but just walk away. There is always someone down the street willing to negotiate and you'll find the bargain you were seeking.

beautiful nice atmosphere and Picturesque. Great people watching, like music, bars, shops, street performers! good shopping, local vendors to high end boutiques. Lots of beautiful and unique restaurants Its very safe and people are friendly! . good night life as well!
Awesome stores!. Great place to walk, relax and shop. Very nice stores. Pretty close to all resorts. Make sure you take your wallet, not only pesos.

Colorful and Picturesque!. Great fun for people watching and souvenir shopping! From high end luxury goods, to souvenir T shirt vendors. Beware! shady tour organizers are very aggressive , but a firm "no thank you" and keep walking, will do the trick. Overall a fun way to spend an afternoon. Wear plenty of sunblock and comfy shoes!

Mexico gone European,. 5th Avenue is the center of the universe in Playa. Great people watching, like music, bars, shops, street performers. Cobblestone streets and very safe. As a female I feel completely safe walking alone until 2 am or later and at the same time I often wake at 6 am and walk the entuire 3 mile round trip stretch to enjoy the peacefulness.Yes, people are going to try to get you into their shops, yes you will be offered illegal items, yes a monkey might hop on your shoulder for a picture,but thats all part of the fun. Just remember people are just trying to make a living and a simple "no thanks", have a good day, or I'm going to the beach are always responded to with kindness

Endless shops. This is the touristy part of Playa del Carmen. The shops here, with the exception of a few, sell pretty much the same stuff but the prices may differ so it pays to shop around and bargain. The south end has some high end stores. If the shopkeeper is rude, move on and you'll find the same thing at cheaper prices. There are 2 very interesting shops selling shells made into lamps. They are both at the north end of the shopping strip. The one further south has a display case with the owner's private shell collection - some wonderful things in there. I have never seen such large sea biscuits - not for sale of course! There is also a shop with some wonderful hand made items from India. There are lots of restaurants, bars and cafes on this shopping strip. We went down to the beach and ate at one of the seafood restaurants lining the beach. Reasonable but not cheap but it's great to have sand between your toes while you eat.

Loved this street!. It was one of the best time in my life. I lived 4 month in Playa del Carmen and it was great time to go Quinta Avenida to see many people from different countries to speak with them and sure only to spent time there near the beach.
Decent walking area. It was a nice place to walk most nights but we found cheaper, better food on 20th or 30th avenue. Also, the constant barrage of merchants got old at some point.
Cosy. Cosy , must see when you're in Playa del Carmen, lots of places to eat and drink.. It's always busy and the store owners try to sell you anything if they can tell you're a tourist....

Don't be an idiot!. If you are the type who comes to Mexico and you only speak English and like to stick with your Starbucks and get hassled by hawkers in the street and eat mediocre expensive food.... Then Quinta is definitely YOUR kinda place! If you want to taste and experience a part of Playa that is more authentic then just cross 5th to get to and from the beach. It gets really annoying to have people continually prodding you to spend your money on crafts that have been made in a village by hardworking families who only get about 10% of the price you pay. For example, I bought a gourd lamp in a small village on the road to Coba. I paid 18$ to the guy who made it. On 5th the same one sold for $65. How much do you think that family got if any? Wanna come to Mexico to just get drunk and stupid and poorly represent the USA? Then just stay in Cancun and stop making the rest of us look bad. Playa has changed much in the 15 years I've been coming here. Not all of it good. But you can still see and taste true Mexico if you avoid 5th.

Rude. After visiting Playa de Carmen for close to eight years I was very disappointed with the vendors on Quinta avenue. Took friends for their first visit and I was so embarrassed by the disparaging comments vendors made if we just looked and did not buy. Calling us cheapskates and yelling that we were not needed there. These few vendors will surely give all others a bad rap and cut tourism for them.

Endless Shopping and Eating. This strip has numerous eateries and places to shop you think it doesn't end. It seems to go for miles but not really. Anything you could want to buy and eat is found here. Not only can you eat genuine Mexican food but all types from Italian, American Chinese etc. The shops are numerous, with authentic Mexican creations as well as name brands from all over. You could spent the whole day here and not go any where else. This area is great for people watching not only for the tourists but for the locals also.

Cute shopping area but very expensive. We really enjoyed Quinta Avenida. We were able to find some great stuff but had to negotiate hard. we alsways paid less than half of what they wanted. In a few stores, vendors tried to sell us real silver items that were fakes. Make sure you see the 925 etching on the product or else don't buy.The best deal we got was on leather good at a store at the end of the strip near the tequila museum. Beautiful handmade saddle leather that ages beautifully. I bought a very large satchel which would have cost me upwards of $300 CDN for $80 US. People constantly stop me to ask where I got the bag. The tequila museum also had great prices on tequila but not as cheap as the airport duty free. Note that duty free does not have a large variety.It is definitely worth spending a day on Qinta Avenida. Grab some chocolate from the high end chocolate boutique and roam around. It's really quaint but make sure you are ready to haggle and check the item before you buy it.
Great Place. Nice place to shop, walk, and have a Michelada Margarita across from Starbucks there is an outside bar.

Nice entertainment, good restaurants, fun atmosphere and great shopping.. Nice entertainment, good restaurants, fun atmosphere, and great shopping. Downside would be that there's a lot of harassment from vendors of various services such as cruises to Cozumel or souvenir stores. If you like to shop luxury watches when in vacation I recommend "Ultra Jewels" their stuff is genuine and they are authorized dealers. Be alert of all kind of little tricks from street sellers to attract your attention, they look at your hotel bracelet and all kind of stuff to lure you to buy stuff. Don't encourage people who want to take pictures of you with baby animals such as monkeys or baby tigers.

Nothing special!. Fifth Avenue is a 'must do' when in Playa del Carmen; however it is nothing special. There are some good international and designer shops at the one end and after that, most shops are much of a muchness.The usual gift and tourist shops, bars and eateries.It's quite an experience and takes on a different feel at night. The walk along the avenue is spoilt by the hawkers and men pretending to be a waiters from your hotel, to gain your confidence. They look out for your wristband!We also found it irritating being to spoken like we were from USA; though this isn't surprising, as most people are from the USA!I would rather not be negative; however without the irritating people trying to get you in their shops, it would be a much nicer experience. The ironic thing is, we would have gone into some of the shops if we hadn't been pestered!
Overrated. Visited several times during our break, both day and evening. I found it very busy and experienced a lot of hassle from shop keepers trying to entice you into their premises.

Really Crowded. This is completely a question of preference, but if you have come to Mexico to relax in a peaceful paradise then 5th Avenue is really not for you. Heaving with drunk crowds and shop-owners who are seriously pushy, it was really not an experience I will be repeating. All of the high-end shops are American or European - so if you come from one of those places then they aren’t selling anything you cant get in your local mall anyway.

The Busy Quinta Avenida. It is a fun place to visit! At this place, one can see people from all over the world! I guess we all want the same thing, a fun place to go walking at all hours, feeling quite safe, with plenty of restaurants and shops, gorgeous surroundings, warm clear turquoise waters just a couple of blocks away from the Quinta Avenida to swim in or go snorkeling or diving!! We had our family reunion there!!We had a blast!! It was a group of 12, ages from 66 years old to almost 5 years old. An unforgettable experience, so glad we did it. It was my dream come true!!!

Good place for shopping. This is our 2nd time back to Playa del Carmen & to 5th Avenue for the shopping. Throughout our day we found the shopping to be irritating at times because some of the vendors tend to be pushy about selling their products. So be prepared for pushy vendors. There are several stores that sell the same items, so make sure you never settle for whatever initial price is given to you on an item as the price will be lowered if you ask. If you're looking for souvenirs,shopping & bar hoping this is a good place to go for the day. The beach is very close to 5th Ave & it's beautiful. I'd suggest 5th Ave.

Must go!. This street has everything for everyone! Restaurants, local shops, international shops, bars, nightclubs, and street performers. Of the 7 days my boyfriend and I were staying in Playa del Carmen, we came here 3 times! You cannot walk the entire street amd see/do as much as you'd like in just one visit.

Cliché. Unless you're looking for cheap souvenirs, drugs and what seems to be rip-off jewelers, I would recommend you stay away.There seems to be decent restaurants and fun bars but the crowd vibe quickly turned us off.

Great Shopping to explore. Fifth has it's good and it's bad. Everything from great little mom and pop shops, expensive shopping, handmade items and cheap tourist junk as well as street entertainers. It is fun to go through, some salesman are more aggressive than others trying to get you into their shop, just remember a smile and a no gracias go a long ways.

Good place to pick up your souvenirs. I spent a few hours shopping for souvenirs here. Tons of options for eating and shopping. Some vendors are aggressive but its easy to say no and walk away. I love the Riviera Maya for its beaches and snorkelling and like to avoid crowds in general but this is the place to go if you want some mementos of your trip.

Quinta Avenida. Honestly it was too touristy for me, but I did enjoy the area. There are many restaurants, souvenier shops, and many opportunities to sign up for different tours. There is even a mall with Victoria Secret, Starbucks, and Forever 21. If you chocolate and chocolate drinks theres a little shop called Ah Coacoa. I went there to get a Spicy Chocolate cold drink to relax and use the wifi for a bit. The best part though was the club strip. We went club hopping there and even came across a small lingerie parade that was leading people into one of the night clubs.

Fun to people watch. I like taking early morning walks down 5a ave. Getting busier with new constrction :( but still appealing. Vendors will ask you to approach their booth but they are never overly aggressive which we liked. They take no for an answer... Good variety of shops and restaurants.
Awesome bars and drinks!. My buddy and I were just looking to get drunk in Playa del Carmen. The drinks are good and the girls look better! Look for the mayan ambulance sign and get one!

Great for all your sovenir shopping. Great shopping, both designer shop and the usual souvenirs. Expect to approached to be asked to look in the shops, but polite but firm no thank you, is usually enough, no one really bothers you to be a nuisance. Some good bars and restaurants too. In the evening this place really comes alive, and there is a real buzz. You can easily spend a couple of hours just walking around.

"Love 5ta Avenida". Like to walk, shop and dine? Than this is for you. A great place to go shopping for those souvenirs for your family and friends. Lots of great and delicious places to eat. And most important, many places you can have a drink to cool off. The night life is great if you go with friends. People are so friendly. If you travel with family explore all it's rich culture. Go visit all the Eco Parks. My Favorite places are Excaret, Xel-Ha, Tulúm, Cobá, the Cenotes, Playa Mamitas, Fusión Beach Hotel Bar and Grill, La Bodeguita del Medio, Ah Cacao Chocolate Café, Babe's Noodles and Bar, and other places I don't remember it's name. But you will never get bored there. Excelent time in Quinta Avenida.
Love all the shopping!. So many stores and restaurants great atmosphere! Only minus side is to many tourist hawkers but other than that it's wonderful
Beautiful. Downtown playa del carmen was a wonderful time the food and all the great shops made for a great day..

Highlight of our trip. It seems like this street never ends. Lots of shops, restaurants and dessert places. Love the people that are all over this area, everyone seems to be friendly and willing to share their WiFi. They have everything here, including convenient stores for anything you may need, money exchange everywhere as well as ATM. You can book excursions here from different agencies, dive shops are everywhere, hotels, you name it. Very nice place, you can seriously come to Playa Del Carmen with no luggage and you will find everything here, even things you don't need. Love it !

Shopping in Playa del Carmen. Quinta Avenida was a ball. You have to be able to ignore all the people trying to sell you, but for the most part they are respectful. Their favorite line is "hey, remember me? I was your waiter at your resort last night. My family has a store I want you to see" If we believed them we would have had 300 waiters in our 4 day stay. The stores are fun and the scenery is beautiful. There is a large police presence so you feel safe.
Souvenir Shoppers Paradise!. Great choice of restaurants and cafes! There are little Mexican Shops everywhere, and you are just a few steps away from some beautiful beaches!

Nice for shopping and just sightseeing. nice for shOpping and sightseeing, every time we go it seems to be getting bigger and more people, A little too crowded sometimes. But it does not take away from the place.

Awesome Shopping Experience... Be Prepared to Walk. First of all, Quinta Avenida (Fifth Avenue) is very touristy. With that, there are literally every kind of shop, bar, restaurant, hotel, etc imaginable here as far as the eye can see. It's divided into sections, split by Av Constituyentes that runs perpendicular to it. Almost every street intersection has a map you can look at to see where you are. It is so vast, we only got to see half of it due to a timeline (our hotel's shuttle was leaving in an hour & a half). My wife and I went from Ave Constitutyentes all the way up to N 4th Street, but then we had to head back to the hotel shuttle. We never got to visit the opposite side, going from N 20th Avenue and up.The time we did spend though, we were pleasantly surprised at how busy it was (it was the afternoon) and how many shops there were. Of course, there are tons of shops that are similar, we still had a good time. There's currently a lot of commercial construction going on there, as they are putting in some shopping malls along the avenue.I heard it gets even busier at night. Next time we go to Mexico, I'll be sure to allot more time, as I really want to try the Mexican restaurants outside of our resort.Last suggestion, WEAR COMFORTABLE SHOES. You'll be walking your feet off.
meh. Lots of shops many selling the same stuff. Got to imagine there are better deals slightly off the strip.

The best spot. This is the street where everything happens in Playa del Carmen. There you will find the best restaurants, nightclubs (including Coco Bongo), shops and hotels (if you take a resort you probably will be far from it). The best time to go there is at night. We spent a week in Playa and our hotel was in this street, so we had fun every night. I strongly recomend to stay in this área if you like nightlife.

Fun place to shop. 5th Avenue is a fun place to shop, eat and drink. With lots of bars, cafes and a few clubs.There are supermarket style shops rubbing shoulders with high end stores, and all the usual tourist shops as well.The ferry to Cozamel is located here as is the local bus station, as well as taxi ranks at both end of the long avenue.

Fun to walk and people watch. I really enjoy walking down this avenida and chat with the vendors. As soon as you show them that you want to converse in Spanish they are more interested in finding out about where you come from and what it is like there than selling you stuff. I am here to learn Spanish and they really appreciate when you just simply try to converse with them in their language

jewel heaven. This was actually my daughter & my, third trip to Riviera MayaEach time we go to Playa del Carmen so we have gotten to know it. At least we think that we know the good jewelry stores. Vendorsseem to be honest. Very patient as most Mexicans are. Expect to bargain, it is part to the enjoyment

Not what its cracked up to be. Visited 5th avenue in the evening , didn't think too much to it and only spent an hour or so in the vicinity, it was very busy in the evening so maybe went at the wrong time .Next time I will try in the daytime and do a bit more exploring . Just go and look for yourself as it was just not my scene .......

5th Ave. The tourist board walk in Playa del Carmen where everything is located. Bars, Restaurants, malls, tatoos, ferry, massage, rentals and only one block from the beach. After dark when all the lights come on 5th ave is a site to see! Some of the locals can be pushy trying to get you into there shops to look at there stuff. Just ignore or say no gracias and continue walking.

Fun, but...... Very cute street with both touristy type shops and high end retailers. Lots of cute bars and restaurants. My biggest issue was that my daughter and I (2 females) were harassed non stop while walking down the street. Not scary but annoying and disrespectful. Also beware of men who hail you in the street and pretend they are employees at your resort. Basically they will profess to know you, then proceed to lead you into their shop. We fell for it once but got out without buying anything. Don't fall for it, it is a scam.

My favorite street in the world !. So full of life and different cultures from all over the world. So many great restaurants and bars. All of the night clubs are conveniently located together on one street. Walk or taxi. No car needed in Playa.

Quinta Avenida Did Not Disappoint. Quinta Avenida in Playa Del Carmen did not disappoint. With miles of shops, bars, restaurants, and stores all in a pedestrian atmosphere, 5th Avenue provides a peaceful way to shop, drink, and dine in comfort. Taxi Cabs are available every few blocks for when you want to go back to your hotel. The people are nice and it's fun to return again and again. If you dig the nightlife, you can book a hotel right on the avenue and party right outside of your hotel.
it was ok. Liked the spa and facial that we had there, great price and felt wonderful afterward. Would visit again.

Repetitive shops, not as good as advertised. We visited the beginning of May 2015.We were told by our holiday rep that 5th Avenue was one of the best places to go for shopping, but it was a let down when we go there.There were a few up market shops, but the remaining 90% of the Avenue is just the same old touristy shops. There are only so many magnets in the world that can be seen in the repetitive shops.The owners of the shops, are to be frank, a pain in the rear end. What should be an enjoyable stroll on your holiday becomes a constant aggressive sales technique, everyone wants you in their shops. One tip, don't wear a t shirt that has an identifying logo on it. My t-shirt had Chicago written across it and all I heard over and over again was "Chicago, Chicago, Chicago, come look at my store."Some of the store keepers had a great sense of humour with their sales pitches, saying "come look at my store, let me try and sell you something you don't want.'Beware of various tactics, they will try and say "remember me, your waiter from the Palladium," obviously catching your eye, but then you realise he has just looked at your wrist band but by that time they are in front of you! I think I could have come away from there as high as a kite too, probably near 10 times we were asked if we wanted any tobacco or cigars, when we said no, they asked if we wanted something stronger, any weed or crack. Strange this happens so openly considering the amount of Police parked up there.One highlight was a mexican meal at Tropical on 5th Avenue, very nice food and good to sit down on the front seating area and able to site back, relax and take in the surrounding rather than someone in your face all the time.

Bunch of things to do!. There is a lot of restaurants and so on. Great nightlife too! Just make sure to don't get annoyed by all the vendors on the way. They will try to show you everything, just answer "NO, GRACIAS" and they will stop lol

The Fifth. Every other winter we come to Playa del Carmen for one to two months. Fifth Avenue has to be one of the reasons. Every year it gets longer and more colorful. Now there is a huge US/Canada class shopping center right in the midpoint. Shops, restaurants, etc. and even FREE INTERNET on the street!

Fun place to hang out and try your haggling skills. Pretty, fun, but can be very expensive if you do not haggle. Everything is marked up almost 50%, but the good news is that you can haggle almost everything well under a fair price.

Tourists Beware. As one would expect, tourist traps everywhere! While I would recommend a quick stroll down the strip of 5th avenue, please be prepared to deal with a lot of aggressive people trying to lure you into their businesses. The place is dirty, crowded and, at times it can feel a little unsafe.You're better off eating and drinking at your hotel!

5th Avenue is why I moved to Mexico!!. I have lived in Mexico for 12 years on a half time basis. I never tire of La Quinta.. and love to bring my visitors down for a look-see. The beauty of 5th Avenue is that is it always changing!! You will hear languages from every continent if you sit at a sidewalk cafe and people watch!Countless restaurants of every type of cuisine, bars, cafes, night time musicians ..mariachis..plenty to see , eat and do!!

Great restaurants and shopping on Quinta Avenida!. A great place for Oeople watching, restaurants, bars and shopping. A wide variety of restaurants including Italian, Asian, Mexican, American and others. Many great shops for beach gear and other clothes.

Fun evening in Playa!. A very pleasant evening exploring pedestrian only Quinta Avenida! Lots of nice open air restaurants, souvenir shops, upscale stores and a pretty ocean side park. Very clean, safe and family friendly.
Heart of Playa. Many nice restaurants, bars and shops.. different style and price range. Bit crowdy at night, but always fun.

Nice easy relaxing place. La Quinta it's a place with lots of restaurants, night clubs, souvenirs stores and actually all kind of shops. It's not a shopping trendy area, but it's fun to walk around have a drink or diner. Great restaurants are around. The best time to go it's at night. Be sure to go with comfortable walking shoes. Lots to walk. It's safe and clean ( precaution as always is safer) Taxi cabs in almost every street. Very touristic area.
Nice and trendy. It is a nice place to walk, shop, eat and dance! I liked the nice weather and the people. There are so many restaurants and night life.

So touristy. I'd heard that Playa del Carmen was a fishing village. And I heard that there was good shopping in this area. I was disappointed to find that neither is really true. There were maybe two or three places along Quinta Avenida that are genuinely regional, but almost everything else was a tourist shop selling t-shirts, shot glasses, and other assorted knick knacks. I found it very disappointing. We did pick up a few gifts to take home, and we added to our shot glass collection, but I definitely would not call this "good shopping."

Wear comfortable shoes, lots of walking, stay hydrated.... We went twice to Playas del Carmen and enjoyed both trips. There are numerous shops and restaurants in what seems to be a two mile stretch. The beach is accessible from the Avenida at different spots. The locals are friendly, look out for the timeshare vendors--just say no thanks and keep on walking. Compare prices between vendors and since most of them are in a store, little bartering is done. If you speak Spanish give them the courtesy of speaking Spanish with them, although a lot of them speak English. There are lots of money exchange locations along the Avenida and are exchanging the current money exchange rates. They exchange dollars and some exchange Euros. Be sure and try "El Fogon" restaurant (across from the Mega Commercial). It is only a few blocks from the Quinta Avenida (ask for directions). They are open 1 p.m. to 5 a.m. The local transportation "collectivos" are on the main road between Cancun and Playas is reliable and inexpensive. Just wait by the main road, drivers will flash their lights and you hail them down. We stayed at the Grand Mayan, fares to travel to either Cancun or Playas del Carmen were 25 to 30 pesos per person. They come by every 10 to 15 minutes. After 11 p.m. they run about every half hour, running 24 hours a day. We caught a Mayan bus-line bus at 4:00 a.m. on our way to Vallodalid

Upscale but beware. The shopping and variety of stores is awesome. But many of the "barkers" can be rude. Just ignore and go where you like. It is a great place to walk around an buy a few things. It's like a promenade, no cars.
a bit touristy. Tacky shops, limited luxury brands, a much more authentic experience can be found in either Tulum or Vallidolid

No Gracias. Our family started out strolling along Quinta Avenida cheerfully greeting all the friendly faces that stepped out towards us hoping to entice us into their shops, stalls or just sell something there and then. After an hour of this we were exhausted of politely saying "No Gracias" every few steps. There are many interesting shops to visit, but most are selling cheap goods for tourists and unfortunately not much of it was made in Mexico. In fact the cap I bought was made in China and the other more interesting articles purchased came from India or Thailand. One trip was enough.

Safe and upscale. Great shops and restaurants! Very upscale - yes there are small shops with locals that are trying to get you to come in and shop - but thats to be expected and it was not overwhelming. We found the restaurants and nightlife to be excellent. A cool mix of old and new ( Modern shopping mall with Starbucks next to some local market stores) great stroll after dinner
Fun!. Here is where everything happens! Many restaurants, shops and clubs! You will have tons to choose from!

One Week in Playa DelCarmen. Not as cozy as it was years ago, it seems to be going towards all modern. In the late eighties it was so calm and laid back and every time we have returned in the last 10 years they are replacing old warm Quinta Avenida in Playa with more glitz & glamor...........Bright lights and now multi level glass buildings that reminds me more of 5th avenue in New York City. Above Av Constituyentes (18th N.) it will remind you more of years gone past or try Ave's 10,15,20,25,30 or further west, lots of local restaurants and small businesses (very safe, but watch were you're feet are). Still a great place with great beach's and gracious locals.

Always fun and entertaining. Well is not as pretty and charming as it was 6-8 years ago, but is still something nice to visit, walk around, drink a beer and hit a nice restaurant (try la fisheria). They are building it up and urbanizing it cancun style so that's not great but still a nice area to see to eat, walk, drink and shop.

One of the most fun resort Main Drags on Earth. If you're one of those who hates Cancun, Quinta Avenida is the perfect antidote. But hurry, American and European chains are starting to gobble up the shops and restaurants.

Shopping and Services. Loved 5th avenue. Lots of different things to see , buy experience. Just be open to them and take the time. Initially it may seem just like everyone wants your business, but after the opening most people just want to chat..

Shoppers paradise. Only visited during the day but it was busy enough then. Every kind of shop you can think of, but dont expect anything too cheap as i found it roughly the same price as at home. One thing i definetely recommend is booking your excursions at one of the shops,(not stalls) found trips 1/2 the price than at the hotel.

This is the "It" Place. We spent many evenings here - strolling, eating, shopping - and I don't think we saw it all. We loved the International flair and of course the friendly locals. Fun shops from high end to low. Starbucks and Haagen Dasz too. So many good restaurants. Live music wafting onto the street from several restaurants - all of it harmonious and within a very reasonable decibel level. A really fun beach scene and people-watching hangout.

Great evening walks. Love to walk 5th ave. In the evening when it cools down a d all the lights come on. Great places to stop for a drink and plenty of restaurants to choose from. Also further down the ave. Some unique shops.

A must visit!. Fun, lots of little shops (as yes, most are geared towards tourists). Walk from one end to the next and you will come across some wonderful little shops and all kids of boutique hotels and restaurants.

A lot to see. The first day we arrived we went to 5th avenue, it was about 2 blocks from our resort. Here we did a little shopping and enjoyed seeing all the entertainment around. We also went to Coco Bongo at night, it was the best night club I have ever been too! Definetly a must see and experience! Very fun!

What a source of entertainment!!!. Well it certainly is entertaining... the first section is filled with "5th Avenue" style high end boutiques, than you're into the local shop keepers with many merchants on either side of the road claiming to have something you need, must have, or that they just have to show you inside their stores. Being friendly and politely saying no with a smile worked perfectly for us. There are many bars and restaurants to choose from. Heads up should anyone claim to want to take your picture either to put up on a their bar wall or their FB page. Within minutes they return with that picture labeled onto a tequila bottle which they'll sell to you for $20 or less, mine ended up costing $15. Quite resourceful if you ask me. Once bitten, twice shy.

Definitely a cool spot, everchanging. I've been going to Playa del Carmen for the past 10 years now. I think I've been there about 20 times now, for business and pleasure. Yes, the area has changed a lot in the past decade and continues to do so. After all, it has a soul of its own. It's a place where people from all over the world mix with the locals. It's situated on one of the coolest beaches in the world. Shopping, food, entertainment, there's so much to do and see. I am not sure if I like it less now, now that the area has grown. It has changed for sure but I still enjoy it and everytime I am there, I find something new or meet someone new and that makes it all worthwhile. It's definitely a place you have to see and experience at least once.

fun time...just be careful. Shopping here is fun and exciting, but......The sales people can be very aggressive and if you don't decline with a smile they can get very mean. And you will be asked if you want to buy...illegal things!actual conversation:On 5th Ave in Mexico Playa Del Carmen:1st Salesman: hello my friends...Come into my store? Me: no thank you 1st Salesman: I have girls for you... Me: NO 1st Salesman: you want my sister, you can have my sister! 2nd salesman: tattoos, piercings? Me: no thanks. 2nd salesman: cocaine? Me to my friend: do I look like the type of person who wants to f¥€k your sister and snort cocaine!?!?Also just avoid the silver shops unless you are ready to haggle prices down on shiny metal that is 99% most likely not silver.Go down all the shops find stuff you like and find the cheapest price and go back and haggle at other shops that had the higher price; a lot of times they will try to beat the price.Food is good, but service can border on pushy and aggressive at times.Beach is fun and happening, there are also cultural shows and local street vendors. DO NOT try to rent a car here, takes forever (us almost 3 hours) and they will try to rip you off.Also, there are sales people trained to recognize your hotel's wristband; so do not fall for their sneaky sales tactics. example:salesman: hey you guys!! Do you remember me??us: nosalesman: I was your server at the buffet at paradisus.us: the buffet we ate at this morning?salesman: yeah that one!us: we did not eat at a buffet this morning!salesman: *turned and walked awaydon't fall for it!

shops, restaurants, bars, tour pitches I want the old PDC. We first came to PDC 13 years ago when there was virtually nothing here but local craft shops and a few hotels. We loved it. 7 years ago there were more souvenir shops, a few more restaurants and bars and more stations wanting to sell you a tour. This visit we were here 11 nights. 11 days of walking past these same people multiple times a day... they did everything but try and drag us in. Nothing unique, and many non-mexican. We only went into a few of the shops who weren't grabbing us, and 1 restaurant here our last night. No bars. If you like that kind of scene, you can have it. We want the unadulterated places and will have to find a new place to go for our next beach/snorkel vacation. Too many tourists, too loud, and the local craftsmen and shops we loved are gone. In case you are thinking it, this was not spring break and previous visits were summer. Another big thing I noticed. Dogs. I love dogs, but had never seen one here before. Dogs were everywhere, mostly on leashes, but when the pets are coming here on vacation, we know we are in the wrong place.

Average....... Many places didn't take dollars, so plan accordingly. Fun just to walk around. They have a lot of silver jewelry, little souvenirs, etc. 1-2hours is plenty of time to window shop and look around.

My favorite shopping area. You don't have to by looking to buy, just looking is fun. This street has everything. Jewellery, clothes, cigars, even a shopping mall at the end. If you can't find what you want here, you didn't look hard enough. I always stop at the Tequila Barrel, a little cafe on the street for lunch.ba great place to have a rest and reorg.

Not interesting to us. Walked several hours on Fifth Avenue and after 15 minutes every shop started to look the same. Same type of t-shirts, tourist trinkets, etc. Some of the shop people had funny come-ons while others were just rude. Best part of the walk was the people watching. We won't be back.
nice city. i love it good shopping nice staff during the day very hot.Will be back next year for sure.I dont mind the vendors.
not cool anymore. it used to be local and cozy now it is becoming crowded and an extension of american malls full of american stores and less of the local sweetness and originallity

Watch Out!. Be careful here. You will be approached (up close and personal) by almost every street vendor in the area. You will be lied to and, if you don't look out, ripped off by the copious jewelry stores who will fabricate all kinds of stories about their wares. There are some decent restaurants, but the street is packed with tourists most of the time. You're better off going to see the Mayan pyramids and the archeology rather than submitting yourself to this infamous tourist trap.
nice street. perfect for walk within playa del carmen, lots of shopping, retail and restaurants, best place to be seen in riviera maya
magic at night. Love fifth avenue. Pedestrian only. Bars, restaurants and shopping. It's busy and exciting. Can't miss a trip Herr!!!

Livin'la vida loca. This street is alive day and night!!!! I was mesmerized by it's beauty and diversity.I felt safe at all time,given the fact that police men patrol the street day and night.Be careful tho' when you try to hail a cab. If they see u white they will overcharge....big time!!!The street is quite long and has many restaurants, bars, shops, souvenirs, cigar shops(where they make you your own cigar) and clubs.
