Shopping=minor harassments. Spent a Wednesday morning shopping with other relatives once we got off the resort. Was okay but I did not find much more than a T-shirt. Lots of shops with same old, same old but sometimes varied in prices. Shop workers, tour guides, massage ladies, etc. would mildly hassle you as you walked down the street but nothing that was aggressive or unfriendly. We just walked down the middle of the street, nodded and smiled, and went into places we wanted to go to. Will take your a 2-4 hours to go from one end to the other end. Best to take pesos as I feel that the calculations from pesos to US dollars are a bit sketchy. Actually, pesos worked best for my whole trip.

Good to visit during the day. Some good restaurants on or near. Babe's Noodles was excellent, El Fagon was good stay away from the Pork though. Boston Grill was excellent, a little pricey but worth it

Amazing!. 1st: Understand 5th ave. is about 10 miles long. Start in the area near Ave. Constituyentes, and explore out from there from Calle 10 or so to Calle 32... or don't bother. Some of the most amazing, eclectic mixes of shopping/dining/etc. I've ever seen. Totally safe. Great crowds. It's like an upscale Bourbon St.!

a beach like feeling. love walking through the quinta avenida a bar or restaurant every 20 meters love the laid back feeling and at night is even better coz the place is alive! Worth a night out there once in a weeks trip might be too much for every night.

Crear ethnic street to walk. If you go to Riviera Maya this street is a must!! You will find some souvenir stores and also popular ones as Victorias secret, adidas,Zara, Starbucks and more also several bars with nice atmosfere,restaurantes, and discoteques!!, you must walk it till The end, and you will fondo a really nice mall with live music and great places to take a cofee and shop
shopping. Nice shopping & food. Nothing big, Merchants will negotiate w/ u so dont settle on the first price they gave you.

Overpriced. I live in San Francisco, and this was like the Fisherman's Wharf where food is expensive and a trap for tourists! If you walk literally 1 block away from the strip, onto like 10th ave, (it goes from 5th to 10th, I dont know why) there are local and authentic food carts, food stands, and cheaper hand made crafts that the stripe sells for 10x the price. What the heezy?Don't be afraid, wander a little. You'll have the best cheese waffle, I promise.

Variety & good deals. Great for shopping! Playa del Carmen is fun & the place to be. Lots of things to do & very long to do your walks. We kept walking & walking with no end in sight. Very bright at night. Loved it! Wasn't there too late but there's lots of bars & places to eat. I only shopped but it was lots of fun.

People & Action. Quinta Avenida or 5th Avenue is the heart of Playa del Carmen, which runs for a few miles from the Park at the South End to the new area on the Northern End. The more north you go, the less busy it will be if you want to avoid the crowds; but this is where you will see plenty stores, restaurants and bars. No matter the season it is always very busy and you will see people from all over the world in all different kinds of clothing: well dressed, casual, and scantily dressed. You will be bothered by many shop keepers; but the best response is to just ignore them and keep walking if you are not interested. If you are claustrophobic, this is not your street. If you like action, this is your street; but certainly a must visit when in Playa.

All Happening. My wife and I were staying at a nearby hotel, the Sandos Caracol and took the opportunity to visit 5th Avenue in Playa del Carmen. It is a lively street with lots of cafes and bars as well as shops. At one end there is a ferry terminal that plies back and forth to the island of Cozumel bringing in many tourists. It is a busy place.You need to have your wits about you though. One favourite trick they use is to use the fact that many tourists are wearing wrist bands issued by the various hotels, to come up to you pretending they know you because they work at your hotels. It is just a hoax to talk you in to entering their store or whatever. So dont fall for it.

Busy Busy Busy. 5th Ave is great for a stroll & people watching after a meal at one of the many wonderful restaurants in the area. Been going to the Mayan Riv for about 20yrs so I'm used to the vendors harassment but it's easy to ignore them & they're just trying to make a living.

Enjoyable night time stroll . At night this is a pedestrian zone avenue that is blocked off to cars. There are a lot of stores, restaurants and bars however you will get better deals on everything if you go a block or two off of 5th avenue (10th or 15th avenue). On Monday and Thursday nights there is an art show featuring several different local artist displaying and selling their artwork. Really nice artwork for not a lot of money.

Interesting!. Our hotel offered a shopping trip to Playa Del Carmen with Diamonds International who provided the free shuttle service. We listened about the Diamond Store during our drive, we arrived at 5th Ave and we were guided into the store. We were served a glass of wine and looked at a few diamonds, after twenty minutes and a drawing for a pair of free earrings we were free to shop.Fifth Avenue goes for blocks and is lined with high end stores, flea market type store, boutiques, hotels, lots of restaurants and bars. The avenue is very busy and the vendors constantly harass you. We got tired of being harassed and walked one block over to the beach. It was very beautiful beach, but very crowded. After two hours I was ready to return to our shuttle and back to our resort. It was an experience to see 5th ave but doubt it I would return.

A very good & nice place!. Everything there´s awesome but the streets sellers; they will disturb you every moment you pass in front of them. It´s a very good place if you´re single, married or searching for somebody.

Stayed on 5th Avenue. Stayed on 5th Av between 4&6 streets. Its the pedestrianised high street. It's a great Central location. It's lively and safe to walk up and down day and night. Your a minute from the beach. You can buy almost anything even puppies in boxes . It's expensive though you only have to walk to the next Av up and things get cheaper. 5 th Av and 12th St is bar street for all you youngens it's party central and worth a walk through if your a bit older like myself just to have a look. It's alive early in the morning with joggers and strollers and it's noisy until about 4 am. Bring your ear plugs if your staying on or off 5th.

The "Times Square" of Playa Del Carmen............. A pedestrian zone dedicated to trendy and colorful shops, restaurants and bars is the highlight of staying in Playa Del Carmen. At night it is magical with people, sounds and excitement. A true joy to experience. Reminds me of Times Square or the River walk in San Antonio.
Strolling on 5th ave.. If the vendor would leave you alone and not harass you they might sell more & make more $$. It's very frustrating and kinda ruins your visit!!

Fascinating at night!. The pushy salesmen are not as bad at night, and the visual sights are much more interesting then as well. We took a $7 taxi ride from our Playacar resort and were there in 5 minutes. It was so interesting, and we only toured 1/3 of it. Lots of fun souvenir and artsy shops to check out along with fancy American clothing stores (that we didn't bother with), and crazy amounts of restaurants to choose from if you are hungry. Yes, there are a few pushy salesmen, but I've heard it's far worse (and hotter!) in the day time, so go at night. After we walked around 5th Avenue a bit, we decided to walk back to our resort, and it was only about a 20 to 25 minute walk. Very safe and very relaxing walk in Playacar. I highly recommend!

If you look at anything they will try to get you to buy it. "Quinta" as it is called by Playa del Carmen locals, is the sidewalk shopping area blocked off to cars along 5th Avenue. This commercialized Mexican tourist attraction can be fun, especially at night when the street lights and brightly colored signs and decorations make the place look magical. It's time to loosen up and have some fun! Everyone here wants to help you have a good time on your vacation. By the way, they would also really appreciate it if you spent some of your money in their shop or restaurant!La Quinta is sometimes packed with people walking up and down the street soaking in the sights and sounds (Jan-Jun), and other times not so busy (October). There are souvenir shops, bars, restaurants, jewelry and clothing stores, tequila stores, etc. Prices are generally inflated compared to a couple blocks off this street but most shopkeepers will at least discuss the price if you think it's too much, and consider your offer at a reasonable discount (expect them to accept about half what they asked at first). Remember, they want to move their inventory so don't be taken in by stories about needing money to buy tacos to feed the family. There are so many shops the employees come right up and start walking with you as you pass by and try to persuade you to come into their store. This is very annoying to me after the second or third one in a row. I don't mind the bantering back and forth in conversation with passersby, but when business is slow they can get more aggressive. Don't be a sucker and try to keep a good sense of humor as you say no thank you and walk away while people are still talking to you.The core tourist area runs North/South between Constituyeyes Ave. and Ave. Benito Juarez. There are many, many choices for restaurants with all kinds of International foods. There is a huge variety of vendors in a range of quality from cheap trinkets manufactured in China to high end rock and gem jewelry stores selling very high quality items, which are priced at their top value. If you're buying t-shirts and cheap souvenirs to take back home it helps to speak some Spanish and bargain for everything together to get a better price. Check reviews on Trip Advisor and plan before you go and you will have a better experience. Most places accept credit cards but in my opinion, part of the fun is learning how to negotiate prices in pesos. Most sales people on this street will appreciate your having made the attempt to learn their custom of negotiating. Many vendors can be extremely overbearing. This isn't always the case, but more often than not, if you so much as take a double glance at an item, they are immediately all over you wanting to start the negotiating process.Step 1So you see an item that you want or are interested in. You will next and most obviously ask "how much?" The vendor will now give you the inflated price of the item. When you balk, then the vendor will then ask "how much will you give me?" DO NOT ANSWER THIS QUESTION!. You are now playing verbal/mental chess with the vendor and if you put any value whatsoever to the object, you are now playing right into the negotiating game to the vendor's advantage. He has set the HIGH and you have set the LOW. Your LOW might also be 30 percent or more than you might be able to get the item for by using my technique. Here is the response that you will keep using (even if you have to say it 20 times)...."IS THAT YOUR LOWEST PRICE?" No matter what the response by the vendor, it is important that you NEVER-EVER set a price that you are willing to pay. Step 2Now you need to back up the above statement with a little bit of acting, by looking as if you are only lukewarm to the item and couldn't care less if you get it or not. No matter what price he (or she) gives you, put the item back on the shelf or hand it back to the vendor and say that's more than I wanted to pay/I've seen the item for less (not saying how much)/wow/I am going to have to think about it/etc. No matter what, you are leaving because this is when the price starts to seriously drop. Here's a scenario. You have found an item that the vendor say is $50.00. You ask if that is his lowest price. He then asks how much will you offer. You reiterate that you want the lowest price. You go to leave. He says would you give me $30.00. You ask if that is your lowest price. You go to leave. He now asks if you will give him $25.00. If you want to be argumentative at this stage, you could reply...I thought $30.00 was your lowest price (doesn't really matter because you are already beating him up mentally), but generally at this point you can say that you want to cut through the chase and just want to know what the lowest price is and will then make a decision..."can you do that so that I am not stuck here?" At this point he might say that the $25.00 is his lowest price or maybe he will make another drop. No matter what, the only way you will find the true rock bottom price is by continually repeating the above steps until finally when you are leaving he is no longer dropping the price. You might even go into the shop next door, then try doing a "walk by" of the vendor to see if there is another price drop.Vendors sometimes sell a $50.00 item for under $10.00. If you had countered on that same item with an offer of $20.00, you surely never would have paid under $10.00. Never, and I mean NEVER SET THE PRICE or answer the question "How much are you willing to pay" as these are both negotiating disasters.If you try this technique you will be astonished at how low some of the vendors will go. By the way, Vendors hate this technique.
First visit. Nothing special, just a lot stores with Mexican crafts. A lot of nice restaurants.Close to Playa del Carmen beaches.

where the action is. full of restaurants and shopping...just steps from the beach clubs.
it goes for about 40streets.
all kinds of restaurants and bars to check all kinds of food

GREAT PLACE TO HANG OUT.... After a great day at the beach, it is not a bad idea to hang out, enjoy some drinks and some shopping in Quinta Avenida. Here you will find Starbucks, Forever21, Surf Shops, Columbia Outdoor Shop.....great places to enjoy some drinks and have something to eat.
5 avenida. Walk entire 5th avenue. Lots to do and see. End up at 5th avenue and juarez. Bring your swimsuit and go to the beach.

The best street of Mexico. This is a great place to spend the day in Playa Del Carmen, all the nice bars and restaurants make a great setting to hang out with friends. It is just a few steps from the beach so it is very well located.

Excellent Place for Shopping. I lived a couple of years in Playa del Carmen before; but always loved their art expos over the Quinta avenida street. Lots of good restaurants (local and foreign). Get your camera, and go for it.

Much more expansive from 10 years ago. We travelled to Playa del Carment right before a hurricane damaged the town. 10 years later, Quinta Avenida is grown more commercial. It's still a nice excursion to take while there.

Had a walk down 5th avenue. Had a walk down 5th avenue having got a taxi from Ocean Maya Royale. We went at 10am which is a good time because it gets really hit and humid. It will take you about an hour to walk from one end to the other depending how many shops you look in. The shop owners can be a pain trying constantly to get you into their shops. If you wear an all inclusive wrist band be careful because a couple of the owners know which resort you are staying at and will tell you that they are a waiter at the resort as a way of getting you into their shops. Some good bargains can be had. Always half the price they first offer you. They always sell you it at that price. All in all a good experience. If on the hot side.

DREAMY. Stroll - window shop - stop for a crepe or waffle made right in front of you - walk some more - stop - look around - smell some grilled food - stop at restaurant - sit on the patio right on the pedestrian street - drink a Miami Vice or some tequila cocktail - sip - relax - do some serious people watching - discuss what you see with your mate - eat the food - order dessert - watch more people - get up - stroll some more - notice a nice Panama hat in a store - NEGOTIATE the price with the shop guy - buy the hat and wear it right away - Find out the same hat was 20% cheaper at the shop next door - laugh it off because you're in vibrant Playa del Carmen - stroll back to hotel - repeat the next evening... That's Quinta Avenida (5th Av)

Lots of shopping, fantastic restaurants. I don't like shopping but my wife and kids loved it. There are tons of stores. I do like to eat at good restaurants and there were plenty of those. Try La Parilla --- OUTSTANDING! Also, La Fisheria was good. Lastly, just down the street from the hotel, La Vaca Gaucha for good solid Argentinian steaks. Our family really liked the deserts there, so we went back several time for desert. All the restaurants above are within 5 minutes walk of the Soho Playa. There are many more, those were just the good ones that we liked.

Whoa!. My friends and I went to 12th Street just off of fifth avenue and wow what an experience! Clubs and bars to your left and right, loud music and a ton of people walking around. It was definitely a lot to take it with all your senses. It was definitely a one of a kind experience. We went there twice because it was so much fun. Talk about bar/club crawl.

Loads of shops. You could walk up and down 5th Ave every night for a week and do something different each time.
Lots of eating and drinking places if required.
If you are in this area it's nice to visit.

Romance. We stayed near Quinta Avenida. There is so much shopping to do! You will enjoy the many Mexican artifacts for sale. There is also a vast amount of restaurants and lounges.
We enjoyed the entire avenue, just strolling and browsing through the shops, and stopping for a beer now and again. The area is beautiful.
Always entertaining!. Always fun to go to 5th Ave. The bands and singers are always fun. Shops are inviting and restaurants are good. Never found a bad one yet.

shopping in 5 avenida. A lot of merchandise from China, not a lot of Mexican real handicrafts, so everything is "Made in China" and they stick something that shows "Mexico"
Plenty of options to buy tequilas and hot souces
Different stores that you can buy gifts and products

Pintoresco y shopping oriented. Impossible to be in Playa del Carmen and not visit Quinta Avenida. It is very nice to experience. Lots of shopping opportunities and bargain. There are from international brands to local crafts and souvenirs.

Ridiculous fun day or night!. I'll start by saying a Playa Del Carmen is my favorite place in Mexico to visit. We completely fell in love. Wandering 5th Ave is one of the best part of holidays for me. Food. Drinks. Trinkets. Artwork. Clothing from traditional Mexican to brand names from home. Street performers. Coffee shops. Ice cream shops. Pubs. Bars. Something for everyone. From mellow to crazy. My "must do" ~ hot wings and a bucket of beer on the street patio at the Tequila Barrell. If you're feeling really loose girls can dance on the bar for a free shot. Enjoy!

Just not my thing.... I'll start by saying I'm not a big vacation shopper. I especially don't like crowded shopping. And I definitely don't like being yelled at constantly (sometimes rudely) to come buy something. There are restaurants and jewelry stores and leather shops and tattoo shops and travel agencies and tour operators and snack shops and smoothie bars and money exchanges and fruit stands... and then it starts over... all the while every store operator is standing in front of their particular store front yelling that they have the best price and the best stuff... (shhhh.... it's all the same stuff) We did eat at two of the restaurants on 5th and I'll review them separately but it was not as good tasting or as good a value as the food on 10th or any of the other streets just off 5th. My recommendation: do it once. Take the walk down 5th in the evening. During the morning nothing is fully open and set up until 8:30-9 ish. It can be very hot during the lunch time hours with a ton of cruise ship tourists from Cozumel coming in non stop and the sun bearing down.

Get out and walk!. Walk on Quinta Avenida and the intersecting calles and discover many secrets - especially good places to eat and welcoming proprietors. Great atmosphere and good break from the beach. Quinta Avenida is an experience, not just a walk.

Little bit of everything. Stayed at a AI in Playacar but 5th ave. was close enough that we went 3 times during our week stay. One trip was for shopping, every kind of store available. 2nd trip was to have lunch and ended up at Wah Wahs. 3rd trip was for dinner. Found a great spot on 5th that had a unexpected entry that opened into a courtyard with several shops around. Afterwards walking 5th ave. after dark is the best time to do it. Cooled off and people wandering around. Felt very safe the whole time.
Nice walking street. You have all there, restaurants, bars, shops, brand stores and small hotels.Lady's get comfy shoes to walk!

The center of Playa action. Go for a stroll to drink, eat and shop but be prepared to say "no" to the street-hawkers. Plenty of restaurants to choose from at all price levels. Bars of all types, some with live music. Stores from kitschy to high-end boutiques and artisan markets. Can get crowded on weekend nights but just plan on wandering with the flow.

Entertaining!. If you are staying in PDC, you will inevitably visit La Quinta Avenida. It's busy with something for everyone. There are tons of restaurants (many overpriced and not very authentic), shops (from designer to local), and entertainment venues (especially the intersection with all of the clubs). It's an entertaining stroll if you are looking to get off of the beach for a few hours. Great places to enjoy a drink and people watch. Many of the stands selling tours will be aggressive. Our hotel concierge told us stories of many of those places ripping people off (either with no shoes or inaccurate tours). So we completely avoided them. Beware: I was approached SEVERAL times by locals trying to sell things that are definitely illegal in the US. There wasn't any harassment but I was surprised by its abundance. Overall, a fun place to stroll and enjoy the heart of the city.
5th ave.. 5th avenue is where it's all at!. bars, restaurants, spas, you name it. it's like walking in the heart of your home city in just a few short blocks.
good shopping. Lots of stores with ok prices and tons of great restaurants. Went during the day but I am sure it is great at night too.

Cute little shopping area.. There are so many shops with inexpensive souvenirs. Also you can buy a beer at one shop, return the empty bottle at the next shop and the next beer is cheaper. Instant CRV! There's also a guy that shows up in late afternoon in full costume, feathers and all.. Fun place, just beware of the occasional pushy salesman.

Always growing ans always busy. Thats the charm of "La Quinta! or 5TH Ave" however you call it it is always growing and always busy.There are new stores opening all the time, a new mall with high end stores and more restaurants.

Nice street. A busy and happy street. Nice place to hang out in the afternoon. Good shops, bars and restaurants.The mall has nice shops but we prefered the little shops in the street. The souvenir shops are very expensive. Better to buy crafts to the locals.

Awesome Strip!. While staying in Cancun, we drove to Playa del Carmen. The ambiance and service at the center is amazing. Great food, bars, and shops. You are able to walk done the strip and do it all. Amazing place! Must visit again!

Can be overwhelming, need to be strong willed!. We had so much fun tourist shopping in a market in the hotel zone of Cancun last year. Making deals and bringing home some neat things and the stories to go with it.I expected the same in Play del Carmen on 5th avenue. For sure you can have the same experience but at a much larger scale, block upon block of stores.If you are ready to shop they are ready to sell, but if you are ready to just get to your destination it is slow and painful. Solicitations to shop or eat are non-stop. Ahh, and don't touch me. One sales person tried a gimmick that was insulting to both of us, "don't you remember me? I was your waiter!" and then he touched me. Really? Who is this funny to? Do I look that dumb? Do you not care how you look?I really thought I wouldn't care but this was the main pathway from our place to anywhere else. We did often go up a block to avoid the crowds.But on a good note, there is no lack of things to look at and buy. We had fun tequila tasting and haggling for a few items. Going just off 5th will get you better deals. The further north you went seemed to have many more, newer looking restaurants. It was fun for me to tour and look at the buildings. So many interesting places and buildings.We stumbled on more things, as I said, just off 5th - a bakery called bacana, babes noodle bar, ah Cacao and Tepoznieves ice cream and a store with some cheaper souvenirs we bought. It is also fun to hang out near the main plaza near the ferry dock. There are often shows there and the chapel is very picturesque.As an additional note, we walked to the other side (south) of the ferry dock and walked around Playacar. There are ruins scattered all over the grounds and we walked through this park area and it was peaceful and fun. It was also fun to walk around the vacation homes there - so unique and really interesting. I think I saw a sign for Xaman Ha condos when there, too, just to help place it. I highly recommend this area for a walk or run.
Very interesting and colorful. many options for delicious food. Great shopping. If you lioke crowds this is the place to go. Great night life. People are friendly.

Wonderful. But still one problem.. I love walking along the avenue especially at night when the weather is so beautiful. It is often crowded, but never filled with noisy drunks. It is peaceful kind of a dog walking crowd . the jungle animals, such as monkeys snakes and lemurs and even a baby tiger have been removed from the streets and that is very good. Handlers used to be there holding them out for tourists to take pictures of and handle. My only sadness here, is that one does remain. There is a little baby monkey at the end of 5th Avenue toward Playacar. He's in a high end mall. He is shamelessly promoted by his handler for tourist photo taking. At the end of the day the handler takes home in a little kennel. It's very sad. All that monkey gets to do all day is sit on top of tourists heads, and be handled by strangers.
Mixed. Some really nice shops & restaurants , but also a lot of tatt , so a mixed bag. We were here a few years ago also, and it has been getting better.

A very different experience. Lots of shopping and restaurants. Fairly high pressure to buy jewelry as this is their livelihood and they are very good at it. It doesn't hurt hat the silver is good quality and the designs are unique. Just be prepared to bargain and you will do well. If you pay asking price, you will pay50% too much, in my opinion. If you try to get items for a song, those deals just don't exist. For dinner, I found the food okay and prices med-high. After, I noticed many more restaurants off the beaten path and wished I had waited as I believe the food and experience would have been better..

Not exactly "Fifth Avenue". Not a whole lot to see. Not even particularly quaint. Some prices OK but you have to watch. Go there to buy a few souvenirs, hot sauce, etc, but head to the beach rather. Much nicer.

Shop until you drop!. Spent an entire afternoon shopping here, spent too much money, but had a great time. You can find a little bit of everything here. Some of the vendors can be pretty aggressive if they mark you as a tourist

Fun!. Lots of variety! My husband got a tattoo, my daughter swam at the beach while we waited for him. Got a good deal on Mexican blankets seriously got price down. We watched the Mayan show and also ate some Haagen-Dazs. If you stay in the center of the street vendors can't come up to you, keep that in mind if you just want to walk around. All in all it was a fun experience. We were actually staying in Cozumel and took the ferry over.
Busling!. Use the bus station to and from the Cancun Airport! It costs way less than the shuttle or taxi services.

Cute cobble street with shops and restaurants. I liked the dining here, especially in this restaurant which has a ceynote and a garden (forgot the name). The shopping was ok I guess, i didn't come to Playa to shop. But love that there are no vehicles allowed here. I came here almost everyday of our 4 day trip. The stretch towards where you get the ferry to cozumel is very touristy so avoid that patch. Seeing the big plaza mall with forever 21 etc made it look like south beach though.
Fifth Avenue. Great mix of shops, bars and restaurants, well worth a visit if you are in Playa. Just ignore the locals trying to sell you anything!

Destroying the atmosphere. Build more, and you'll destroy it more. The quaint atmosphere is disappearing. Some who believe we go to Playa del Carmen to shop at Tommy Hilfiger or Victoria Secret. Personally I hope they go broke. Leave the street to the small restaurants and street vendors. I love hearing" Come in senor, it's almost free"

I could not imagine the 5th avenue was that long. We tried to walk the entire 5th avenue but could not. The place is filled with stores, restaurants, malls, etc. Good place to see people, shop, eat and make some exercise. You can not go to Playa and don't visit the 5th avenue.

not mexican stile, but a mix of shops, cofee bar, restaurants music, shows in the street. To spend some hours in this funny Street may be a pleausure. But Remamber: Mexico is something totally different from playa del Carmen and Maya riviera.All the fashion shops of V avenida are not mexican. This is an ugly copy of Miami, funny to see, but please see something more of mexico.At least to to Merida and San cristobal, not so far!!!

Overpriced and underwhelming. Not worth the time. I saw many of the same shops I go to in the States. The jewelry and food is overpriced. Our lunch of sloppy tacos cost $75 and we didn't even have any alcohol. One guy tried to sell us a leather bracelet my kid could have made at summer camp for $40. The shop owners don't do much haggling anymore. No fun.

A fun evening!. We took the collectivo from our resort to Fifth Avenue late in the afternoon. It was very easy and the collectivo was brand new, very clean and air conditioned. It cost $35 pesos each from Akumal to Playa del Carmen. We were dropped off two blocks from Fifth Avenue. There wasn't a problem walking through the streets, we felt perfectly safe. I'd highly recommend taking the collectivo to Fifth Avenue, but perhaps consider taking a cab back to your resort, especially if you plan to stay later in the evening as we did. I had made arrangements with our private guide to take us back, and it was 350 pesos for the two of us to return to the Grand Palladium resort.I'd read about being hassled to come into the shops, and yes, we were bothered somewhat, and did hear the usual 'Don't you remember me? I was your waiter last night at your resort!' comments. However, these do lessen after it gets dark, and Fifth Avenue is much more attractive by night, although it does tend to get busy. No one gave us a hard time once it was dark, so perhaps that's the best way to do your browsing/shopping. All of the shops are usually open until 10 pm.There are tons of shops, so much that it became overwhelming at times, as there is so much repetition of articles, and you have to keep looking to find the cheapest prices, as they certainly vary from place to place. So many restaurants as well, with beautifully decorated interiors. There are a few really nice ladies' shops - I found good deals and nice items at a store called 'Crush', near 2nd Street, where we came in from the collectivo street. There was also a nice handcraft store farther down with many things made in Mexico by craftsmen near the end, approximately at 38th Street.Look for the street performers and mariachis as well. We went for dinner at 'Oh lala' a few blocks up on 14 North Street. Be sure to make a reservation first, there weren't any empty tables and I made my reservation 3 weeks in advance. It's the #1 restaurant in Playa, and we certainly enjoyed our meal there.A fun evening, don't miss this trip to Playa del Carmen for something different!

Lots to see!. We were there 3 times in the 10 days we spent in playa del Carmen...what can I say ...the wife loves to shop..all in all a pretty good experience. Food was good..you really have to haggle for any kind of deals...most of the vendors weren't to pushy, but some were really bad....lots of the same stuff in many stores...lots to see and do here!

Brash, tacky, a strip mall like any other. The street has no character any more, it sold out entirely. There are three "Watch my Watch" shops in just a few blocks, then there are the usual glasses shops, jewelry stores, Zara, Birkenstock, overpriced bad restaurants, t shirt shops with vulgar messages, and very crowded with people who seem to think Prohibition is starting tomorrow. We were offered drugs four times in one evening and it just didn't feel like Mexico at all. A real shame, as Playa used to be a lovely little town. Quite frankly, you could be in any mall anywhere.

Not my thing. Love Mexico, but you do get the good with the bad. Great food, nice people, beautiful crafts, a fabulous margarita - and then the slightly desperate hawkers begging/cajoling/yelling? At you to shop or dine in their establishment. Not really my thing.

Nice,restaurants beaufiful shops, everything for free time in holyday. A very long Street of many beautiful shops, restaurants, music, dico music, shows in yhe Street, all what makes holyday!You have to spend at least 1 evennight here!

Great mix of people, goods for sale, and restaurants.... My family visited Playa del Carmen for 7 nights and there wasn't a single day that went by that we didn't walk up and down 5th Avenue. The restaurants pricing and quality of food varied. Many of the typical souvenir shops had the same stuff and if you walked long enough, there were sometimes two of the same shop. Although I was disappointed there wasn't more true artisan items for sale, I really enjoyed the liveliness and vibe of the street. It felt like a relatively safe place and although the shop owners frequently call out to get your attention to go into their shop, they were not obnoxious or harassing - you just keep walking.

Awesome good fun.. Get ready to spend some $ and do some walking. Be sure to stop along the way to enjoy some of the locally owned restaurants. We ate a Miceala's and LOVED IT. We also enjoyed the Fish Spa Therapy (twice!) and had a blast. We've been here many times over the years and can't believe how much it's changed. There is truly something for everyone here.
The Fifth Avenue of Playa Del Carmen!. If you want to do some shopping this is the place to be altough you are cheaper of for some things such as Salsa Habanera if you go to the local super market.
Great walking tour. Sights and sounds, great food, nightlife, it has it all. Fun walk, lots to see and do.Super crowded over Easter weekend.

Nice place to walk at night. our resort was walking distance to Quinta Avenida so we would walk there every night after dinner. Nice walk to see all the vendors. Sometimes they can be a bit pushy but a simple "no thank you" will get them off your back. Lots of restaurants and shops they even have what it looked like a mall with a Forever 21 store and other American stores.

Great shopping stroll.. Withing walking distance of the resorts (about 40mins for us), along beach or via the sidewalks. Spent only day hours there, but I was told the nightlife is worth checking out.

A Nice place to visit. This was a very nice place to visit, it was very clean and taken care of and lots of different things to see. Many, many stores to shop at and places to eat or just sit and have a brew. They were also very friendly. What I especially liked was the mixture of area stores and high end stores.

All day and night full of tourists and local gift shop sellers. I lived on this street and it not quiet because there is a lot of shops, restaurants and services so you may see there whole day and night tourists and gift shop sellers until late night. People who like shopping will like it because you will probably find there all shops that are also in your home country.

Nice to walk around. 5th avenue it's a nice place for a stroll after dinner . The traditional Mexican commerce mixes with modern stores and food & drink . You might get stopped by locals trying to sell you all different type of merchandise , but it's a fun place to go .Usually safe , but keep an eye on your wallet on the back pocket

Night on the town. "5th Avenue" is the place to be if you don't want to call it a night just yet. This strip is packed with bars/lounges, hostels, restaurants, gift shops and tourists from all over. The owners of these establishments are so down to earth, they'll even sit right down and have a chat with you and you can't help but notice the beautiful live music. If you are looking for a casual and laid back night on the town, visit "5th Avenue"

Lots to see and do. Took a cab from our resort and walked '5th Avenue' lots of little shops with great characters.Don't be afraid to haggle. But stick together! My friend and I were dragged away from each other by vendors on a couple of occassions which made me nervous. Also beware of 'real silver' My bracelet was not!

A bit too touristy for me. If you like to shop and feel like you are most anywhere in the US, this street will make you happy and comfortable. I had fun walking around for one evening, but would not spend much time there. I did jog along this street in the morning before it got too hot.
all in one place. there are plenty of restaurants, night clubs, pubs, brand shopping and local shops where you can get a variety of souvenirs and local products

Loud and crowded. Quinta Avenida is loud and crowed, WHICH is to be expected in a tourist area like Playa del Carmen. If you are able to fight off shop owners and slower tourists, the food is usually worth it.

Great Shopping. Don't let the locals sell you anything without bartering with them. The restaurants are good, the silver on the street is probably not real even if they have the logo on... they stamp it on a single piece of silver. The shopping mall and higher end stores only take credit cards or pesos.. no Canadian or US cash.

Watch out for rip offs!!. Be aware of scammers and drug dealers,every shop will try to short change you or gouge you on the prices,every second shop someone will offer drugs to not only you but your children,stay in groups and make sure you know the exchange rates before you go!!

Lots to see and lots of fun. My husband and I spent 2 hours wandering Fifth Avenue and loved it! There's so many shops and vendors selling all sorts of souvenirs. We didn't find anyone to be too pushy, more funny while yelling out their pitches to you.

A tourist haven. If you just want to do the normal tourist stuff at the prices you would pay back in your home country then this is the place for you. Nothing bad or wrong about 5th Avenue just not my cup of tea.
5th Avenue. Fun to visit - very touristy (to be expected). Most of the shopping was either local junk, lots of silver, or US chain stores.

Love the new Fifth Ave!. We really enjoyed our quick trip to Fifth Avenue. It has been years since we'd been there, and we really liked the "street festival" vibe we found. Certainly it was more "authentic" in the past, but I'm good with less slummy and fewer people accosting me. We found fun sculptures and street buskers for photo ops, and our daughter loved finding Forever 21 and Starbucks.

Complete Tourist Trap. Was only in Playa for a day so I can't really speak to the town as a whole. But La Quinta Avenida is the typical tourist trap of a street that you would expect a tourist city like Playa to have. I have traveled many places in lived in South America and if you really want to know a city and it's people then get outside of areas such as these. Walk the street to say you've done it, make your rounds and leave. sure there are lots of restaurants and bars but they are all Americanized... to the point where I heard Def Leppard playing.. to the point where you look around and everyone is from Middle America with a fanny pack or Cancun shirt on. If that's your thing then hey, go for it........ but it's not mine. Also the beach wasn't so nice. I'm sure there are more beautiful beaches as you leave the main area.

Just one touristy shop after another. I walked the whole street twice and could never find one shop selling contemporary Mexican high quality arts and crafts. There was one in front of the Lol Ha restaurant at Akumal Beach but why not in Carmen
best street. We found everything on this strip. Stay right off the strip if you can and you will not need a car. We walked to all the best restaurants and beach and clubs.

The best place ever with something for everybody. Shopping out of this world, cuisine to die for and unlike no other, spectacular beaches, the friendliest people and service, ultra trendy night clubs right around the corner. There is something for everybody in la quinta avenida. Here is a place that once you visit you will never want to leave- you will want to make this your permanent home!

Impressive. A seemingly endless street of Bars, Restaurants, Malls and individual shops. We walked along it every evening, not only for 'Retail Therapy' but for the live music including wandering Mariachi bands. It has a pretty unique atmosphere of shopping and entertainment and well worth a visit.....or many.
A little bit of everything. Many shops to choose from including local and international shops. Worth walking around and checking out
A feast for the eyes. Walk, shop, stroll, eat or drink your way along the blocks of shops and cafes, bars, and restaurants. Take time to sit and watch the world go by.

One of my favorite places in the world - one trip is NEVER enough. Fifth Avenue in Playa is one of my favorite places in the world.A mile plus of a street with fabulous shopping and restaurants to stroll at your leisure. The atmosphere is exciting and the weather is 95% of the time spectacular for evening strolls.Vendors calling out to you with their best honed sales pitches "Hey Movie Star" or "Everything almost Free" adds to the ambianceI have never heard one person that has been there not fall in love with itGo there!

Always enjoyable. I love going for a stroll on 5th Avenue when in PDC.There is always good banter with the shopkeepers and a fun atmosphere. I love the silly things the shopkeepers shout out to get your attention. My personal favourite 'Are you English? Come in here - my shop is cheaper than Primark!'. The Brits who read this review will get this reference! It worked though as we did go in and bought something!There are plenty of restaurants and bars to frequent or walk down one of the side streets to get to the beach. Be sure not to miss the Voladores in the town square by the beach. Very entertaining and crazy at the same time!

Fun street, lots of vendors, restaurants, etc.... Lots of typical souvenirs from high end jewelry to local crafts. Nice restaurants. Beware of vendors who claim to be the waiter from your hotel. They look for your wristband and claim they waited on you the night before. But, if you joke with them, they leave you alone.
Great shopping. Not only is it great for shopping but it's great for people watch. There are some great restaurants albeit American prices. There are also some great handicrafts places.

Hard to enjoy in the afternoon.. Love the town but hate the salespeople constantly trying to drag you into their stores. They try to make you feel guilty if you won't come in or won't buy. I'm a shopper, but it makes me not even want to look. It is not as bad at night, but the afternoons are awful.

Some of its charm lost. The quaint atmosphere with it special charm is giving way to the upscale and modern as new buildings rise along the busy little avenue. Great little watering holes and shops, but they are getting squeezed by the big modern stores.
Great shopping. The restaurants and shopping was great. The shop people were a bit pushy and annoying but to be expected. great food.

People Watch. This is a street which is a little longer then a mile. It has lots of shopping and things to eat. There are currency exchanges and people trying to sell you things like tour excursions. Hair braiding and massages too. Very sunny street. Nice to people watch.

swimming with the sharks.... You need to be prepared. Some sellers will not take no for an answer. if there is a price sticker on a object, it is usually not negociable. If there is none, try to get at least a 50% discount.
Nice place to hand out. restaurants, bars, shops....all in a same street. This is the place to go if you need something ! Very safe night and day.

long power walk of all options and meeting point. the runway and catwalk on playa occurs at 6 or 7 pm where you take a walk back to your hotel and try to search something suitable for looking hot at nigth . .. meet people take a pick of great looking girls.

Go to the beach instead. If you love overpriced souvenirs ,this is the place for you.The restaurants are overpriced and not all that great.I tried to find some possitve things to off set the negative and could not.Tips:1) if you take a cab, make sure you have enough pesos vs US to pay for your ride.the reason being if they charge you 300 pesos and you pay in US they will not give you a good exchange rate.Just an example when we were there the exchange rate was 15 pesos to 1 US,what they do they will only give you 10 pesos for 1 US.They will later take the US dollars to the bank and get the 15 to 1 rate.2)The other trick they use is when they say that they know you from the so and so resort that they work here part time.The way they know is by looking at your wrist band from your resort.3)Real Cuban cigars @ $40 dollars for 5 in the case.The packaging looks great but trust me they are FAKES .

After almost 20 years, still my favorite Avenida!. It's changed a lot.....paved with cobble stones to calle 10 ( street) and lined with small shops full of local artisans ware and great food, it's now extended past calle 50 and lots of expensive brand name shops. But it's still a fun place to go! After window shopping you can do some serious looking for reasonable priced restaurants and shops west of 5t Ave. (toward hwy 307). Just about everyone speaks English now. Some of my favorites are Las Brisas, calle 4 (w. of 5th) great fresh fish, inexpensive; Fusion, calle 6, on the beach, best burgers, live music, fun atmosphere, reasonable; Carboncitos, calle 4, between 5th and 10th. Reasonably priced for the great food and atmosphere!

A smorgasbord of shops, restaurants, hawkers and people watching.. From new malls to old style shops and street vendors, there's something for everyone. Plenty of restaurants and watering holes too. Remember to wear comfortable walking shoes and give yourself plenty of time...it's a very long street!Watch out for con artists pretending to be waiters at your hotel (trying to gain your confidence).

What a lively street!. You can find anything and everything here. The best place to go shopping and tasting local cuisines. Very friendly vendors but could get quite annoying after a while. Just ignore and walk away. (Visited March 2013)

Beware of the twin old ladys on quinta avenida!. The twins!! Quinta avenida is GREAT, tons of food and shopping to do here!My whole reason to come was to visit coba and show my 22yr old son a great time. I tried to book my trip with these 2 twin sisters but they quick turned and convinced me to help them since they get paid commission from people they refer to do a timeshare presentation. I hate presentation and had previously done 2 a few yrs ago. I did the presentation 3 hrs and was then given a receipt of completion which alst stated the time and place I would be picked up for my tulum and coba trip...they never came so I called wilberto the man who gave me the receipt, he answered put me on hold and never came back to the phone, waited 35 minutes! Went looking for the blond short haired twins. As I approach them they ask you didnt go? I went on to tell them what happened all they said was did u pay them $48 u had to pay and when I said I had no problem paying they said the bus got in to an accident imagin if you were in the bus! Thank god u weren't! I was livid!! At the end they said you can take the colectivo 2 blocks down. Never again!!! Beware the blond twins in quinta avenida!!

Great shops and restaurants if you do your homework.. I will review individual shops and restaurants on separate posts but as this is about the street atmosphere itself I'll address that- it's a really cool cobblestone walk with some great shops and great restaurants just do your homework in advance. Also, there is some great nightlife but we were usually asleep by 1030 so we didn't take advantage of it. We were too busy having amazing time and early wake ups to waste the night away in the nightlife so I can't address that specifically. But the store "Amber" who not only taught us about how to find real vs fake amber by a charming shop worker Ernesto was awesome and there items gorgeous! I bought a heart pendant which I will post in pic. You can geocache on the avenida- the Canadian place was a blast- if you've never done that you SHOULD! Great for singles, families or couples and free to do. Just download the geocache app or Google search it and start having fun. We've done it as a couple and as a family all around the world and always super fun. The restaurant Carboncitos was FABULOUS and the restaurant Tierra Madre was expensive and adequate at best. The bar Mannes was so fun! Bottom line was that if you tripadvisor the places you will spend less and have a great time and if you don't you'll spend more and have a good time but no matter what you'll enjoy it. Don't forget to tip well like in America 15-20%. And don't be surprised if people offer you illegal substances on the street but be smart and don't take any ;-). Very family friendly place during the day and party friendly at night. And Aconto boutique hotel is right In the middle of it and a great place to stay too! Look for their groupon for added savings :-)

Main tourist street. The main street in Playa here is where all tourist walk to shop and to eat if you would like to walk out of the beaten path step off 5ta agenda and hear to 10th and upward. You will find the prices drop a lot and you will also find the real playa and even better food.

Touristy but nice. Plus: the security, variety and some stores of this street.Minus: prices, feels kinda like a street out of a massive amusement park.It is a nice street, but I would be crushed If this was all Playa del Carmen had to offer. It's good for light shopping (haggle away with the artisans!), but you'll get much better prices anywhere else.

Shopper's Paradise. I visited 5th Avenue one afternoon for a couple of hours and found it to be pretty enjoyable. It's a seemingly endless array of shops, restaurants and other services being sold by the local people. The atmosphere is rather fun and festive. The only drawback I found was the sometimes annoying merchants trying a little too hard to sell their stuff. Most were not that way, however. The ones that were I simply told them firmly but politely "No thank you, sir." That was usually enough and I would just walk on by. If you're staying in the area, I would definitely recommend a visit to 5th Avenue. If you love to shop, it's heaven. Even if you don't, it's still fun.
Great Atmosphere. Great place to spend a night !The restaraunts are amazing with lots of choice.Good place for shopping.
Good but pricey.. Prices very high. They had all name brand stores but more expensive than what you can get them in California

Quinta avenida..... For sure is tourist oriented but you can find there whatever you want:,shopping, exchange, bars, restaurants, cigar makers, breach dancers, maya shows... Very intriguing at sunset, ferries coming back from Cozumel...the Caribbean in all its charme

Expensive, crassly commercialized, and usually overcrowded.. Everything is so commercialized that one can walk from one end to the other and see nothing of much architectural or esthetic interest. And there appear to be relatively few stores or restaurants which are reasonably priced. The many pushy sellers of various items, and inviters into restaurants and bars don't help either.

Something to do?. I would not put this on my must do. It does have some shopping, we only stayed for a couple hours in the morning. Picked up a few trinkets and left. If you don't like the heat and the vendors stay put. If you are looking for local restaurants, this is NOT the street. We brought the son and husband, they would of rather stayed back.
Playa del Carmen worth a visit. Mostly restaurants a souvenir shops. Go to Coco Bongo, disco and show place. Crazy Party and fun.....

Great place for evening walk. I like this place with all native stores with hammocks, ceramics, cigars, ... and Mayan people in costumes - and of course store with gorgeous cowboy boots.
I don't like how this wonderful street starts to be commercial.

You Either Love it or Hate It. 5th Ave in Playa is the main tourist destination. It has all the tacky souvenir shops and overpriced restaurants. It also has the shops with the guys trying to drag you in to take a look. they are non-stop annoying. but I guess that's their job.From the Ferry block to Constituyentes is the worst. Walk up to 10th Ave if you want to avoid the hassle. We do! You'll find better food at better prices. If you must visit 5th Ave., the daytime is best as long as a cruise ship has not dropped off it's passengers.

A must see in Playa. Fifth avenue is all about the shopping and the food. If you don't want either, don't go, you will be bombarded by people selling from their shops. Or just be firm and say no and not engage in conversation and you'll be fine. It's lovely at night and much cooler but day is usually more empty as everybody is on the beach.

Too many tacky stores!. I wouldn't advise people not to check out Quinta Avenida, but go there knowing you're going to be harassed to go into the stores. They constantly use the phrase "just 1 Mexican minute" to try and lure you in. There are a few unique, artistic Mexican stores, but they're in the minority. If you're looking for cheap, tacky souvenirs then this is the place to find them. Beware that some of the Mexican souvenirs are really made in China!There are definitely plenty of bars and restaurants to enjoy the experience and the beach.
This is the action area. Lots of cafe, stores and bars and fun!!!! Noisy at night if you have a hotel near to there. Great night life and cheap massages

Always a great time!. My husband and I spent an evening here and once again we had a great time. Plenty to see and do. Like other reviewers have said--I really did not care for all the American stores and the new mall but it does help their economy I suppose. I can pick and choose where to go and what to see. Everyone in this area definitely needs to spend some time here. Too much fun!!

The greatest tourist strip in playa del carmen!. I've made 6 trips to Playa del Carmen now.Late into my first trip I discovered 5th Avenue and fell in love with the area. All of my following trips I stayed at hotels right on 5th avenue. My 5th and 6th stay there was with Hotel Delfin. I will always go back to this hotel because of the location, price and friendly staff!!
Great Place to walk. A good place for walk and shop after spending the day on the Beach. Shop and eat local, avoid the Chain food and stores, go there when home :P

Why avenue 5 when you can have avenue 30. Avenue number five (Quinta Avenida) is the main attraction for most tourists visiting Playa Del Carmen.Some will say it is what tickles their taste buds the most and that it is the highlight of the trip to Mexico, while others are less impressed by the long stretch of road that runs parallel to the coast of the city.This avenue is crammed, packed to the rafters with everything that can squeeze a dime or a dollar out of a tourist. There are salespeople literally grabbing hold of ladies, in their effort to make a sale. It seems as the salesmen believe that tourists, who have been able to make enough decisions to get there, now are incapable of finding our way into their stores without help.It is not okay in my part of the world, to grab hold of people! I take it as an invasion of my private space and I will not only defend myself vigorously, but also do anything but follow that salesperson into a store.Americans tend to enjoy the atmosphere of Fifth Avenue, and they happily spend hours, as well as dollars, in the trendy stores along the route, while myself, and most Europeans I talked to, think it is tacky and overpriced pretty much everywhere along the street.Should you decide that you are ready to rumble with the crowd, bring a water bottle, sensible walking shoes and prepare to elbow your way through the thousands of people who mill around here. The funniest time is in the late evening, when the crowds from the cruise ships are herded around the area, and the most quiet is in the mornings when the street sweepers and shop keepers are preparing for a new day.Best thing about the Fifth Avenue is that it is the only area in Playa Del Carmen where one can go with a wheel chair without too much problem. All other areas in the city are close to impossible for all but the most hardened chair veterans.For a more genuine Mexican shopping experience, I would recommend Avenue 30. It is full of stores where the locals shop, and restaurants where they eat, at prices that you will never ever find on Fifth Avenue.

Nice mall. There is so much to see on Quinta avedina. There is lots of restaurants and stores, but what I didn't expect was the mall and all the American stores.
It's a nice busy street to see.

Over a mile of bars, shops & restaurants right in the heart of things and with quick access to the beach and ferry termi. We spent many happy hours in bars & restaurants here, enjoying live music, traditional Mexican food and far too many Mojitos. always lots going on at night and the place to be seen if that's your bag.

built up!. we had visited Quinta Avenida about 10 years ago and I was sad to see not only Starbucks but a big modern mall with Victorias Secret and Champion and such crappy american stores, all but a few were charming local stores! fun and lively and worth an evening stroll.

Great Shops and LOTS of vendors.... We went into Playa del Carmen 1 day and spent the day on 5th avenue as West Jet provided a free shuttle and lunch there when we booked with them. There are lots of different shops varying from the typical tourist to coffee/chocolate shops, boutiques, etc. We did also end up finding a Mega store (very much like a large Walmart) that was off the beaten path of 5th Ave as my husband wanted to find a memory card for his GoPro and didn't want to pay a fortune for it. There is also a mall and one end of the Avenue if you are looking for more Americanized shops.
A normal place for souvenir shopping and several interesting stops .. This was a fun afternoon with good shopping for souvenirs and some interesting and different things not seen often

Still a major draw for tourists. Over the 10 years we have been coming here, we've seen the growth of some pretty major shopping malls (under construction as well as completed) so 5th Avenue is changing. In many ways, though, many things have remained the same. You can still buy a hammock swing, t-shirts, souvenirs, brightly colored ceramics, and tours from the vendors hawking their wares. Lots of bars and gelato shops offer wonderful treats to anyone wishing to stop for a bit.The rainbow of colors of the buildings are typically Mexican and always excite even the most tired eyeballs. Fifth Avenue has a lot of its area dedicated to pedestrian traffic only and it does transverse many different types of communities.

Choose what you want to do and go to 5th avenue. Many people, restaurants, art galeries, hotels, hostels, hotel boutique and a lot of small shops.The 5th avenue is the best place to buy souvenirs, to drink and try diferent kinds of cuisines (cuban, italian, brasilian, caribean, mexican, greek, arabic...).There are a good place to buy tequila with a fair price called Europea, in the same building that Forever XXI, they have a lot of brands and is cheapier than Duty Free.

Eat and Shop. It's packed full of shops and all kinds of places to eat. There is something for everyone here but it's not the real Mexico. I like to troll through the neighborhoods and find where the locals shop and eat. The tourist zone at american prices is packed with foreign investors willing to take your money. Upscale shops replace the mom and pops. It feels like the worlds largest cruise port with many shops having multiple locations. Good people watching and street performers sometimes. I love this town and I love the people but I liked it better 20 years ago.

shops, bars, restaurants. There are plenty of things to see and many places to eat. The shops pretty much all have the same sort of things. The best place to buy silver is in a jewlry shop and not the little vendors. Lots of places to buy trinkets. YoU can also catch the ferry to Cozumel down here.

Was fun for awhile. 2 couples, took a cab to town, 5th Ave. it was nice, picked up a bunch of souvenirs. Found that after the first hour or so everything was pretty much the same. Was disappointed that there were really no great deals to be had. And the shop owners were VERY persistent in trying to get you to view and purchase their goods, which was somewhat off putting. Overall a good experience and would do it again.
Shop til you drop. Lots and lots of stores to look at. Lots of food choices. Most of the street blocked to traffic so makes it better for walking.
A great place to shop and window shopping. It is getting better every day. New upscale shops opening every day. Nice church and plaza to watch people.
changing. 5th ave is getting commercialized, not as charming as it was 3-5 years ago. who really needs to go to American Eagle in Mexico?

Great Shopping - Lots of new things to see. Shopping is great here. I remember coming 10 years ago and none of this existed. There are lots of your typical souvenir shops, but if you head west until the end of 5th Ave you'll hit a really nice mall area with European fast fashion/higher end stores such as Zara, Bershka, Stradivarius, Oysho, Pull and Bear, Onda De Mar, Tommy Bahama, Zingara, Starbucks, etc. There are no obnoxious store owners in this area, and clean public restrooms.And I have never seen so many sunglasses stores in one place. Sunglass Huts galore!There are also several gelato shops which I really enjoyed and reminded me of being in Italy.

Good place to hang out. The avenue is still expanding, so we explore new areas every time we do. There is a big variety of activities there. Restaurant, massage, live band bar, night club, souvenir shop, art gallery, street art performance, brand stores, and so many more.

Expensive shops and food, obnoxious hawkers. Fifth Avenue is a must visit street in Playa with tons of shops and restaurants. It's like walking through a gauntlet of shop owners screaming at you and begging for you to come into their shop or come in and eat their food, or buy their tours. As you keep walking, you will notice that the shops start to repeat themselves. It's not my favorite, but it's part of visiting Playa and I have come to accept that. But veer out past fifth ave whenever you can, there is so much more to see, eat, and do!

Icky Sticky. You'll need to practice your "NO, GRACIAS" before you embark on this pedestrian thoroughfare because the vendors are voracious. I never encountered the 'in your face' rude kind like some other countries, but their tactics are relentless. There were times where I literally wished I had ear plugs to block out the constant push to sell you things from the street vendors, the stand alone kiosks and the shop owners as well and this happens literally every three feet you're walking. The four offerings you will be bombarded with are tours, taxi service, massages and "icky sticky" (Mexican marijuana) especially from the guys pretending to hawk their Cuban cigars. (I also received offers for "a wh*rehouse" and cocaine, I think it was a package deal!) Other than that, it was a lot of fun with an endless supply of bars, restaurants and shopping and people watching options! Make sure and walk all the way down to the ferry dock; theres a really nice open town square overlooking the beach to just sit back and take in humanity....and rest up for more vendors on the way back!!

Lots of restaurants. No problem to find a restaurant. Many touristshops and some small shoppingmalls. Did not like that some people sell drugs like it was candy and others having animals on leash (monkeys, lemurs etc.)
Has something for everyone, bars, restaurants, shops, markets. live music, ice cream, good cafes, sports bars, all kinds of restaurants, close to beach, lively, the tour people will hassle though.

Shopping and Restaurants. You could be anywhere. There is not much "flavor" of Mexico. It looks like a big shopping mall and it is a big shopping mall. The prices are way over what they should be. I know this because I live in Mexico for part of every year. The tourists are being ripped off.

Too Loud, Busy & Crowded. Local merchants hound you constantly for your business; loud music from competing restaurants/bars; wall to wall people. If you want a quiet, peaceful vacation, stay clear of 5th Avenue.

Just be patient the censors will almost dragg you to the store. I understand this is a culture aggressiveness haggling but if you really want to by something interesting go to the side stores galleries. Be careful the silver sold on 5 will wear off quickly a lot of stuff just from china cheap and ugly. Venture away much better merchandised

Going to look like can understand soon.. Playa has become the day stop for cruise people too cheap to take a tour. The town is more and more becoming a drinking and eating and big box America place. We noticed more old building destroyed to build big American shopping centres. Don't get it, you can shop at home. Your on holiday, enjoy the sun, have a drink, smile, but shopping at Walmart on vacation, nuts....
shopping. shopping shopping shopping, and more shopping,nothing really interesting to buy anyways...just tourist souvenirs
Avoid this if you can. Between the crowds and obnoxious salesman this is the opposite of a peaceful relaxing vacation on the beach. Go a couple blocks away to have a much better experience.
A spending paradise. Lots of ways to spend your cash in this area. Both tourist and fashion shops. McDonalds with free wifi.Saw a demonstration of the flying men in the square, amazing.
great ambience!. great place to stroll and find all kinds of fun trinkets and deals. It's pretty expensive if you don't negotiate a deal. Restaurants are cheaper the further away from centre you get

Free entertainment and stroll. Definitely an interesting place to explore. Yes, the vendors will call out to you, but a simple "no thank you" is enough to turn most of them away. Similar to an Ocean City Boardwalk adventure with lots of shops, bars and restaurants. Fun to do some "comparison" shopping for gifts, gadgets, etc. We went once on a Sunday and once on a weekday, and found the weekday visit less crowded. The further north you get, the less people. Interesting to see the newer construction on the north end. Definitely will include a visit to Quinta Avenida on our next visit to Playa del Carmen.Modern bathroom facilities available beyond 20th Street (can't remember the exact location, but they are in a modern 2-story mall-like structure on the left side going north.)

Strolling 5th Avenue, Playa del Carmen. Something that I do recommend when there, is taking a leisurely stroll on Quinta Avenida. Lots of shops and things to see. The people encouraging you to come in and take a look gets a little old, but there are some beautiful handmade things like leather goods and pottery that are really worth a look. What I do recommend, is wandering up the side streets to get food, local food, the really good stuff! Be warned, lots of people recognized our wrist bands from the resort and would tell us they were our waiter-total lie! Called a few on it and they backed down. Do not fall for that!

TOO MANY PEOPLE. never seen so many people in one place in my life. Like Time Square in New York city....as someone else put it. Crazy crazy place and so many bars, restaurants, shops - continuous - but very glad to have seen it. Would recommend that people should see this place if they get a chance.

Greatttt hangout!. Its a huge boulevard, you feel safe at all times, there are plenty of bars, restaurants, hotels and shops. You cannot miss this place! If you visit the priciest bar, get a bottle is better if you are not going to be barhopping

Glad I went, but no intention on going back.. We took a bike tour from our resort, through Playacar, to 5th Ave. We were left to explore, shop and make our way home when we were ready.As with any street vendors, they all try to get you into their shops by calling out to you and basically harassing you, but generally accept a 'no gracias' and leave it at that; a few will say things, under their breath, as you leave... The worst are the people at the tour kiosks; one man actually came out to us and held on to our bike, not letting it go, trying to make us follow him, and then had the audacity to call after us (even though we repeatedly, yet politely, refused to hear about his offers) with derogatory remarks, as we walked away.The majority of the vendors were helpful. I even had one gentleman (Fernando) go and search his neighboring, competing, shops for what I was looking for, because he didn't have it himself!I'm glad I went, it was definitely an experience, but because of the few rotten apples, spoiling it for the rest, I won't go back.To the vendors, if you see this:If we were left alone to come and go to browse, as we wished, without harassment, I would have spent a lot more money. But your tactics to try to lure us into your store feels uncomfortable and sometimes threatening, and is a huge turn off!
Ze street of PDC !. If your traveling for the first time or not, La Quinta is undeniably a must ! Have fun ! Enjoy the restaurants, shops, people, drinks and all the fun of the 5th AVE !

Good for a stoll... but that's about it. This was my second time here. The first was years ago. The street has built up... a major walkway that's lined with shops and restaurants. It's become an odd combination of shops selling cheap knick - knacks and souvenirs that are initially very overpriced (bartering is expected and necessary) alongside brand name American stores. You'll find yourself dodging the continual barrage of "hey pretty lady" and "come in and look... good deals" comments, as well as the relentless approach by salesman trying to push (yes, I mean push) their wares on you. In some ways, it's a part of this street's carnival-esque charm. Be smart if it bothers you...keep your eyes straight ahead and keep on walking. Or have some fun and haggle your way through some touristy purchases. If you're willing to say no and walk away, even a few feet away, it's amazing how fast the price can drop. Some quality restaurants and good deals on drinks, particularly on the side streets. Evening is quirky and fun as the street comes alive with lights. It's worth a wander once or twice but then you'll likely find better places to be and things to do in PDC to occupy your time.

Very Touristy, but worth a look. 5th Avenue used to be so quaint, now it is overrun with franchises instead of mom-and-pop stores. However, it's fun to walk down the street, looking at the surroundings. DON"T LET FOKLS TALK YOU INTO anything "free" - they will entice you with free goodies, even swimming with dolphins, but the truth is that you have to do the time-share thing, and they are relentless. Just keep walking and say "no gracias". Off the main drag, there are side streets with wonderful mom-and-pop stores, but all things are more expensive than they were even 6 months ago...it's nice that the area is getting attention and is economically improving, but it's sad that pricing is becoming outrageous.

fun and funky. We always make sure we get a visit in to 5th avenue here in Playa. We love to bargain with different shop owners for everything from silver to blankets to bags. People watching however is the high point!

Early evening promenade. This was our second visit to Fifth Street and it was a lot of fun. The energy is palpable as you stroll along the pedestrian roadway while checking out the shops, bars and restaurants. Late afternoon, early evening is our favorite time to go. Great entertainment on the street and singers in the little bars begin as the sun goes down. My husband bargained for a cool tropical shirt and we enjoyed drinks and dinner while we were there. Our hotel helped us with transportation which worked out well.

Insulting at times. The street side vendors (not the stores) will ask ridiculous prices like $50 for a $5 item and then act as if you are causing their family to starve to death. Get off of 5 (even a half block) and things will get better.

24hs stepway. Uncountable restaurants, live shows, shoppings, and to muco people walking and enjoying the PDC way of turist. The prices are a little high, to fish americans rich guys. Dont forget to bargain

Nice walk. A nice break from the resort. Lots of shops and restos to check out. For those interested in enjoying a fine cigar while walking the strip, there are 2 places that have quality, legit cigars stored in appropriately humidified humidors. La Casa Del Habano on 5th around calle 28. The other is La Casa Paratagas on 5th at calle 5 near the south end. Both shops have legit Cuban cigars. LCDH also makes a nice Mojito for your stroll. Prices at both shops are insanely expensive, so don't plan on getting a bargain. The quality cigar plus the experience is worth the $20-$40USD you will spend on a Cuban cigar. Don't buy cigars anywhere else.Lots of street side places to stop for a few cocktails to people watch. We found most of the Mexican souvenirs to be priced pretty high. We negotiated on most clothing items down about $20-$30USD at the small shops.

5th Avenue Excitement. Every time we walk down 5th Avenue it is an exciting time. There is so much to see and do on 5th Avenue it is almost overwhelming. It is a shopping paradise and there are so many choices to choose from in restaurants. It is always a lively place to be with lots of energy in the air. Add that to all the colors from the shops and buildings and it is a fun place to visit. At night 5th Avenue takes on a different look as the lights give it another look which is in itself very impressive. One of the aspects of 5th Avenue that we always look forward to and enjoy is the people watching. Grab a seat somewhere and take in the sights and sounds of the street and then watch all the people from all over the world walking up and down enjoying themselves. One word of caution...the time share folks are alive and well on 5th Avenue so beware of a seemingly friendly voice that will lead into a time share presentation. All in all,, 5th Avenue is a place not to miss in Playa del Carmen so be sure and take the walk down the avenue when you are there. You won't regret it!

Carnaval Extravaganza. We watched the Fat Tuesday parade from a prime seat on Quinta Avenida and can't wait to come back. Quinta is magical any time but the regional dance groups and mardi gras atmosphere made it even more interesting and exciting for everyone in our family, from the 2 year old to the grandparents.

A long walk. Brilliant vaiety and mix of the old and new - new malls look good but not too many as they will spoil the atmosphere. Maybe not the place to go too late in the evning on the street off 5th Avenue

walk on the fifth avenue. Interesting to see the little shops and restaurants, however there is a drastic change . Older buildings are being tore down and replaced with very modern stores. Maybe for the population and cruise people , this can be good, but for me it is a change in atmosphere.

Playa de Carmen has it All!. We were walking distance to Quinta Avenida so we made 2 visits to shop and browse. It was a nice feature to have nearby. We usually took a cab back for $5.00. There are many shops ranging from your high end international favorites to the basic souvenir shops. One shop sold gladiator sandals with interchangeable laces and accessories - a Mexican product/design which I've never seen before. I loved the Mexican lamp shops and there were many of them, just couldn't see traveling back home with one of those lamps. There were many choices of restarurants too and street vendors selling nicely cut and packed fruit cups - I had some and I didn't get sick. There are also some night spots that we heard others talk about back at our resort. I got to learn a bit about the native tribal communtiy in that area - most dressed in traditional attire and most are vendors and shop owners. Just be aware of the pushy salesmen in the streets and near the ferry terminal trying to sell excursions etc....but otherwise a very nice area to visit.
5th avenue is the spot. If you want to spend a cloudy day it `s the space to be, lots of store restaurant entertement, lots of store souvenir could spend the day by the beach....

Avenida de Tourista....... Quinta Avenida is a must for 1st time visitors, even for us that have been many many times. A great place to people watch. Any kind of tourist gift you need you can probably find here. Some of the places to eat are good, but it's much better to eat off of 5th. I will return many more times!

DEPENDS WHAT YOU ARE LOOKING FOR. I love Playa Del Carmen and always go to 5th street. I love to go up and down the street people watching, buying some souvenirs, and have a few drinks at street bars. It is a great place where you can find a fine designer store and next door a Mexican trinket store. The prices are not all that great but I find a great selection of shirts and caps that I want. Also bought a new pair of Maui Jim sunglasses for about the same price I could buy them back home but no sales tax so that was pretty good. I love to stop at street bars to sit in the shade sipping a rum and coke just watching the people go by. So if you are looking for a big bargain price on something you want you probably will not find it but if you want to enjoy the day soaking up kind of a festival atmosphere this is the place to go. Of course the store hawkers are out front trying every way to get you inside but that is the culture there and I enjoy it.
