If it bothers you just keep walking and they will pick up on the next person.

Busy, hassle, but a decent experience. Let me be upfront about it: you will get hussled to purchase goods and services by a lot of the vendors. They stand outside the shops and stores and really hassle you to make purchases. You may even get a few attempts at scams...just be aware. It is not dangerous, just a nuisance. It was nice to get off the resort and see a little bit more "real" mexico. It is still touristy, but it is cool to see. There are good Mexican restaurants here that vary in price and level of food. You can also grab coffee, gelato, and find cheap booze and souvenirs. Always try and barter down for prices on stuff. I would never go with the first price offered.

Loud and brash. The 5th is overly expensive and far too loud, all the bars and restaurants are in competition with each other, no not in quality of food or service just in plain old whose speakers are the loudest. Between the touts selling timeshare or excursions and the shop owners calling you into their stores it feels like a chore rather than a relaxing stroll and that's not to mention the "you wanna get high?" guys, so be prepared ! I would recommend a walk up some of the other smaller streets which offer quieter and and more reasonably priced establishments,

Fun, Fun and More Fun. I have visited Fifth Avenue numerous times. Lots of shopping options from trash and trinkets to art galleries and high end shopping. Dining runs the gamut from taco stands to 5 star. I love the vibe and the people watching. Fifth Avenue is must when visiting Playa.

Too Commercial. Where did the mom and pop shops go?. I used to enjoy walking down fifth avenue once or twice a year. Now it is getting way to commercial. Do we really need 12 sunglass Huts and 14 watch my watch stores? I really do miss the small local merchants selling stuff and bargaining up a storm with them. Now it doesn't feel the same anymore, now more with the new complex on the corner of 5th and constituyentes Ave. Big box stores ruined this street.
A waste of time. Just shop after shop selling the same things over and over. We really weren't not impressed with the general area.
The heart of Playa a block from the Caribbean beach. Twenty blocks for pedestrians to stroll at ease and find tourist trinkets to international luxury shops and all types of food or drink.

Just like Greatie!. Busy street with every single waiter from your hotel saying don't you remember me? I am Juan or Carlos or whoever from whatever hotel wristband you are wearing. Don't be fooled! Some nice bars and Diamonds International is here, heavily guarded of course. Enjoy!

A shadow of itself. Been here 4 times and the desperation , hassling is too much.5 th Avenue did have charm but it appears long gone. Too much of the same stuff in each shop.Sell things new, unique and wanted.

Walking 5th Avenuein Playa. This is like no other place in Mexico. Walking down this street is a shoppers paradise. Anything you want, need, or don't is here. Restaurants for every taste can be found, some of which are very good. The best is having a margarita and watching people from every corner of the world.

Always something new to see!. Fifth Avenue or Quinta Avenida, is always full of surprises...every few weeks...it seems a changeover offers new & exciting shops, venues and restaurants! I simply love the new sausage guy located in a little hole in the wall just steps onto 5th off Constituents, heading North. Or the lady that will weave beautiful feathers into your hair for a small amount of money...5th Avenue is ever changing and growing....with a little less "come & buy my junk" sellers and a more relaxed feel! Come ... take a stroll and find that special little treasure to take home!

This is Mexico..!!. Have been on 5th Ave. a 100 times. We live down here. A special bit of Mexico. Vendors selling EVERYTHING you can imagine. Everything is "almost free". One guy who spoke pretty good English, I asked, "Did you live in the USA?" '"No, he says, lots of hours watching Sesame Street."You have to Love the humor of the Mexicans.!! All of them have a sense of humor we Americans should learn. 5th Ave. is very busy. Some folks hate it. I love the vibrant upbeat atmosphere.

Tourist junk. I accompanied my wife and daughter on a walk down the beach from Paridisus Playa del Carmen Le Perla to Playa for some shopping. The beach walk was fun and nice to see the other beach resorts.However, the Quinta Avenida was a disappointment. Great for sunglasses, T shirts, massages and beer. Nothing really interesting or authentic to get excited about. Ended up buying a couple of things from the resort gift shop.

too much cheap mexican souvenirs made in japan.. A lot too much expensive. I dont want to pay 10 time thing i can easely get at my place. There is always soemeone hanging to your shirt to sell his things.

Fifth Ave is such a great touch!. I've been to a few all inclusive resorts in Mexico now but none of them offered something like 5th ave right out the front steps of the hotel! We stayed at The Royal PDC and were so pleased to have Fifth Ave in walking distance outside of our hotel. From restaurants to shopping to an air conditioned mall with many name brand stores, 5th Ave offers nightlife, dining, massages at great pirces and overall just a different feel to your vacation. We were also able to walk to Coco Bongo's which was awesome as well! I highly recommend visiting this area!

Very nice but expensive. Went to Avenida Quinta while staying in Tulum. The prices for artesanias or local wares was very expensive. Pay 400 pesos for un craneo or skull. They sell them around 99 pesos in other places outside of Tulum. Beware that this place will jack prices up to all tourists. Not recommended to purchase local wares. Go other places to purchase souvenirs.

Good base to venture out from. This street is what most will remember about Playa, after the beaches and weather. It is the heart of the restaurant, shopping, and club scene. Be prepared to be asked about needing a taxi or planning an excursion every 2nd block or so. The "hawkers" are good-natured at least. If you want to experience a more local experience, you will have to head inland from Ave. 5th.

Expensive street. It's very nice avenue, but everything here is very expensive, food, drinks, clothes, gifts and souvenirs... But you can try to ask for a better price, and maybe you can pay 50-60% less than the first offer... If you want cheaper food, drinks and everything I can recommend you, 30th or 50th Avenue and Calles (streets) near by...

Made our nightlife!. We shopped and ate some of the best food in the cutest restaurants. Casual and fine dining, massages for next to nothing, fish that eat the callouses off your feet...it was awesome.

Great way to spend a day. I've been going to Playa for many years and always enjoy spending a day on 5th Avenue. Pick a restaurant, order a couple of beers and do some people watching. Also worth it to get a massage and of course there is tons of shopping.

Great people watching. Love this street. It is easy to walk with only foot traffic. Great shopping and restaurants with small hotels mixed in. Very clean and friendly with views of the ocean down many Calle. At night it is more alive with music and dancing. Great people watching.
Great for people watching. Great for people watching from any bar or restaurant to visit. Everyone tries to get you in their shop/bar/restaurant.

Colorful pedestrian mall goes in for miles. You will see all types at this couple mile long car-free strip. Will be offered drugs, massage, sombrero or all the cheap Mexican chotskys you can imagine....also some fun bars and restaurants...beach only block away.
wonderful nightlife. The most beautiful street in the world for the fun, Latin dance and nightlife. I will never forget the nights spent in this famous street of Playa del Carmen!!!

Built up more each day. but still nice! Lots of fun and great places to eat ..lots to see, music everywhere. Little hotels, cafes..bistros. Haggling merchants. All adds to the fun and glitz of 5th aveCan walk too along the beach for best deals on massages. Everyone can be talked down. East access from anywhere on ADO bus plus ferry to Cozumel. Been coming here since it was a fishing village.

Worth a Visit. This shopping and restaurant avenue is near many of the resorts, and is, as you might expect, filled with tourists. As such, there are hawkers and retailers who will come out on the street, politely and then some not-so-politely telling you to come into their stores. It was a bit much in some cases. The stores vary in quality: some sell cheap souvenirs, and others more quality items. Be careful to check for "Made in India" stickers on the bottom of shell, coconut and other handmade jewelry. I was excited to buy a necklace until I turned it over and saw that sticker remaining. Oops. No sale made. Prices are somewhat steep (again, touristy), and while some sellers are willing to bargain, the prices don't drop by very much. I enjoyed walking down the street for the entertainment of it all and for the feeling of being in the action. Overall it was interesting, but be cautious.
Beach Lover. 20 blocks of entertainment. Beach by day, 5th ave by night. Never a boing moment in Playa. It is not the humdrum of an all inclusive.

Ground Zero for the Party Crowd. Pedestrian walkway offering shops, bars, hotels and dead ends at the world famous Senor Frogs. Tons of t-shirt shops selling party animal style stuff, cuban cigars, street barkers selling tours, pharmaceuticals and pot. I liked the shopping and disliked the party animal atmosphere and the people hawking cigars and WEED.

Not what used to be. For me that I been a traveler to this town for many many years, its very sad to see how the neighborhood is loosing its character. Every time is getting more commercialized and the big brand companies are taking control of all the charming that used to be. Its a shame that in short, this town will become a small Cancun instead of being an alternative for travelers as me that wanted something much more relaxed.

Gets old fast. Well known Pedestrian street downtown PDC. Even better known for the many vendors trying to sell pretty much anything tacky you can think of as well as a few decent items at prices that would be reasonable in the US or Canada but are inflated for Mexico. Everyone is trying to make a living but the starting prices seem to be very random and based on the vendors best guess at what you will pay. Can't say we didn't buy anything but paid waaaay less than asking and passed on the "Cuban" cigars, the wrestling masks, the myriad made in china foolishness, the "doobies" and even the sexy girlfriend who was "almost a virgin" There are some good bucket of beer deals if that's your thing and many excellent restaurants on or nearby 5th that are much more expensive than a couple blocks away but still pretty affordable compared to any city you might find yourself in. Had no security concerns.

Dai in Playa Del Carmen. There is a few nest shops and boutiques but most of the merchandise is cheap and overpriced. There are many pushy vendors which is a real turnoff for me. There are also quite a few restaurants to choose from for a snack or a cocktail.

Our shopping experience.. We enjoyed walking around and seeing the sights but I found it a little overwhelming with the venders coming out at me trying to get me to go into their store. I prefer to pick my own to enter and they would just scare me away instead of going in.

Great pedestrian street. 5th avenue is the backbone of playa del Carmen . It's great for walking & people watching & the beach is just a short block away (try marmite club) great restaurants and cafes too!
Nice. Had a very pleasant time: walking / shopping / eating there. A lot of souvenirs, even fancy stores, good food and drinks. Visit it! No dislikes .

40 block walking avenue. Great walking avenue that is very safe and worth the visit. The area around 1st is mall-like, 2-13th or so is typical Mexico, 14-28 or so is the trendy/restaurant area, and 29-40 is the up and coming area.

They are trying to rip off. 5th ave is a great place to take a walk do some shopping and have a bite to eat, but you will pay top dollar for everything! The street venders are quite aggressive and will not take no for an answer. After 2 weeks they still bothered us every time we walked by and it gets old fast! The food is very good and you can find everything from pasta and pizza to lobster and Mexican food. The resturants are great but very expensive. If you venture off 5th to some of the other streets it becomes much more authentic and much cheaper prices. 5th is fun to see but after you have been up and down the street once it gets old quick! Check out the other streets and you won't be disappointed!

Wow!!! Lots to look if you like shopping. Wow I haven't been to downtown Playa Del Carmen in over 13 years and to say the least it was changed a great deal. We spent a couple of hours while it was raining in the Tequila Bar on 5th Avenue. We had nachos and drinks - great people watching place. Will look forward to going back again.

Lots of changes. This year we went down here on an evening , our rule is never to be outside of the resort at night time. Well all was fine , with all the lights on it looks totally different then the day timeLots have changed here in the last couple of years. Lots of small vendors are gone and massive stores are opened up , so much for old Mexico. We ate Las Parrillas Rest ., nice view from the second floor, food was good . Our favorite is still Playamart , This is a complete store with everything in it including a full drug store This is a must if your close to Play del carmen
Fun but overpriced. Fun to walk down 5th Avenue but everything was very overpriced. We found the same items at the airport for a lesser price.

5th Avenue - Playa del Carmen. Runs from about 2nd. Street to about 40th Street....we did from 2nd to 16th....very vibrant...people enjoying the restaurants and bars....we were at an all-inclusive resort so didn't go for a meal....went in the early evening until 9:10pm....stopped at a yogurt-ice cream type of store and it was very good...looked in a few stores.....most of them are all selling the same type of souvenirs, but the shops are numerous and you can pick and choose....we found the shop around 2nd - 3rd St. called BEST MARKET, I believe, to be the best in overall prices and they do offer you samples of liquor to help you with your purchase....!!! People looked like they were enjoying the food, bars, various restaurants, etc. so do go...you won't be disappointed...!!!

THE shopping street in Playa. The fifth avenue avenue has a little bit of everything.At the south end you have the port, the ferries of which take you to Cozumel. You also have the shopping block called Paseo del Carmen, with e.g. Martí sport, Tequila/Farmacy, Starbucks and Tommy Hilfiger and Pull & Bear.The fifth goes on forever but I would say that up to street 40 is basically it. Half way up (fifth and av.Constituyentes) you have a mall called Quinta Alegría (="fifth joy", a wordplay with "quinta avenida"=fifth ave). Here you have Aldo, Victoria's Secret and much more.Along the way you will find a church, the bus station, banks, hotels, souvenir stores, farmacies, restaurants and bars. You will also pass a couple of Liverpool (mini department stores), häagen dazs, Subway, McDonald's, Burger King and Aldo's. There are a lot of nice dinner restaurants on and around 5th. You will also find a lot of tattoo parlours, dive shops and exchange booths above and under 5th.Night time the bar life is concentrated some blocks north, south, west and east of 5th ave. and 12th street. The biggest clubs are on 12th street, between first and 10th ave.You have not been in playa if you have not been on Fifth!
Lovely atmosphere.. Vibrant, colourful and safe. A pleasure to take a stroll down at ant time. A variety of shops from stalls to department stores.

lots of interesting shops and restaurants. Very close to the beach, lots of interesting shops and restaurants but you are Constantlybugged and harassed by merchats. It just goygot to be too much, so we had lunchand left. Very colorful!
Great place to visit.. Highlights would be 5 th avenue shopping, walking the long beaches, snorkeling the Morales reef, touring around Cozumel and visiting Tulum.
plenty of shopping. Did the 5th ave experience several times.There are many sights & shops to see,restaurants,bars.There are no cars on the street,just pedestrians

Nice area. Quinta Avenida is a must visit if yo go to Playa del Carmen. There are a lot of good bars and dining options for those who are not staying at an all inclusive resort, or for those who are tired of the same food from all inclusive resorts.

Use other streets to avoid endless sales pitches. Quintana Avenida sounded nice from other reviews, but vendors are constantly hounding tourists with corny sales pitches and pushing Cuban cigars and mostly tacky trinkets, sometimes aggressively. It's worse the closer you get to the ferry terminal. We found better places to eat on other streets, and avoided walking down Quintana Avenida after the first night there.

Great for sights. Go for the great walk, a bit of a cultural experience, and to people watch but don't go for bargains. This is their high end shopping. I especially enjoyed the free Mayan (esque) performance at Parque (park) Fundadores at B. Juarez (0 street). They did pass the "hat" (coconut?) which I happily contributed to. The show was going when we got there sometime after nine pm.

Worth a walk, shopping fun. We always take a walk along Fifth Avenue when staying near Playa del Carmen. There are lots of big and small, reasonable and expensive shops and restaurants. Lots of fun, just remember the phrase, "No gracias."

Fun Interaction with Loco Locals. Playa's 5th Avenue is a fun spot for people watching and interacting with the interesting people that live and work there. It is always interesting to hear the latest 'barker' phrase from the folks trying to sell you some service or get you into their shop. Last year's favorite ("Hey, remember me? I am the waiter from your hotel!") gave way to this year's ("Hey, we were in high school together." or "Are you looking for my sister?"). They don't make much money, and their survival depends on separating you from a little dinero. Have fun with and throw a little back at them ("I do remember you, and the service could have been better!" drew a smile and "Oh, I see how you are now!"). All in good fun, and a traditional part of the Mexican banter.My favorite places along the pedestrian way are the numerous massage spots such as my favorite - Sabai Spa - or the shop selling liquor and generics of US pharmaceuticals at bargain prices. And of course some of the craziest T-shirts you can imagine (Does someone actually wear these in public?). It is all there from the cheap traditional Mexican crapola to high end jewelry and many bars and eateries. And all the while it maintains a safe, and laid back atmosphere. There is a great, eclectic mix of people from attractive young people to families to couples. It is a good time, though pretty hot even at night in the summer!

This is what's wrong with tourism. Poor restaurants and bars probably owned by foreigners, plus the regular souvenir shops. Lots of solicitation from store and restaurant ayudantes.Mostly dead after the sun goes down.

Ok if you like that kind of thing. Quinta avenida is very vibrant and busy. There are plenty of places to eat and plenty of shops to spend your money in.... However.... Be very cautious. Understand the currency rate of exchange or you will be ripped off. Bargaining is a huge thing in Mexico and if you know how to do it well you will get a deal ... Especially on silver ... However ... Make sure it's actually silver! I was fortunate to stay at a resort with plenty of shopping opportunities and less hassle! Quinta is fun but a little aggressive when it comes to shopping!

Busy tourist street. I'm going to exagerate but I felt a bit like in Kuta beach in Bali. Now, it's not as bad, and maybe I overreacted because I didn't expect Playa del Carmen to be like that, but it's very touristy and you got a lot of stores/stands calling for your attention.Prices are high and the gringo should not expect any good deal in that street. But there are restaurants and souvenir shops, and it's a s safe as can be, so overall I gave it a 3 star score.

Same Main Street, different city. It seems that wherever we find ourselves, we find a 5th Avenue. Bourbon Street in New Orleans, 6th Street in Austin, etc. shopping by day, drinking by night, eating in between. You are sure to find souvenirs, cold cerveza and plenty of people who are willing to "help" you out. Cool place to spend money and take in people watching.

Nice place for a stroll. Nice to walk down the avenue and take in the sights. Lots of stores to look around in and buy some souvenirs. After awhile all the stores look alike. Lots of quaint local restaurants to stop and have a cerveza or two and a bite to eat. Recommend a restaurant called The Blue Lobster. You can also head down a side street and head to have a look at the beautiful beach! Definitely worth a trip to see!
great shopping mile. great to shop and having fun, full of life and people, have fun with bargaining, feels safe, just don't fall for all the "very good deals"
Same old, same old. There are endless shops all selling the same overpriced toot. You also get quite a lot of hassle from shopkeepers and hawkers.
Ok if you like kish deco. It's a shame to have such a nice street with such raunchy stores, I guess for some Americans this is a typical Mexican Town. Far from it!

So nice!. Besides the beautiful beaches of Playa del Carmen, Quinta Avenida is also a great place to know. Many stores, many restaurants, art galleries, culture, different people..everything in one place. I totally recommend the walk during the day and at night.

A safe, fun time on Fifth Avenue. Go stroll the Avenue for a taste of authentic Mexico and feel totally safe doing so. Great Mexican Restaurants and see a and barder with the locals in their street shops.

World's largest outdoor American Mall?. Over the past few years, Quinta Avenida has transformed from a destination of mostly family-owned Mexican businesses to a commercial shopping mecca with large glass American storefronts. People-watching is still good but if you want a more authentic Mexican experience, go west one block to 10th Avenue. It's still well-traveled but does not feel like such a tourist trap.
nightlife. I like the night life, music and shopping. Dining is more expensive there then other places in town.

The hearth of Playa del Carmen. You cannot stay in Playa or in any hotel on the Riviera Maya, without taking some time to stroll down the fifth avenue. The beauty of Playa is that this Main Street exclusively for pedestrians , is at a stones throw from the Caribbean sea. Restaurants, bars, shops, everything can be found there. You must at least spend a day/night there during your stay.

Fifth Avenue is quite the experience. If you are going to be in the Playa del Carmen area, take some time out from the beach to hit Fifth Avenue. It is colourful and entertaining, to say the least. There are some real characters trying to entice you into their stores and restaurants. A word of advice would be to hide your resort bracelet under your watchband if you can -- otherwise you look like an easy mark. A lot of the stores are a bit junky, but there are some gems along the way. Lots of great places to eat and drink. For those on the younger side, the clubs just off Fifth on 12th look interesting.

Quinta Avenida. It is was a tough decision to take some time away from our wonderful resort, the Iberostar Grand Paraiso, to visit the Quinta Avenida. It is an opportunity to do a little shopping and see a bit of the area around all of the resorts. One suggestion - buy some "pure" Mexican vanilla to take home to your friends if you are looking for inexpensive gifts. It is excellent and well know.

Nice but what's the point?. So this place is a well-developed area with lots of nightlife, tons of restaurants, and plenty of places to spend your money. What it isn't is Mexico. This is where people who are afraid to leave a resort go to, not anyone who has any interest whatsoever in seeing how real people live. It's a sad, extravagant strip of commercialism that could be anywhere in the world. There is no Chom, no authenticity, and no local culture. Well you will find plenty of here is selling drugs, prostitution and plenty of taxi rides. It's done mostly discreetly, but they nag you at every chance to buy drugs and it gets very annoying, especially after you say no and they continue to offer you different types of drugs and different women for prostitution.

A classic tourist path. It is the typical tourist street in any beach destination. Many local stores everywhere selling souvenirs. You will also find plenty of restaurants and bars. I would recommend to eat octopus chips at la fisheria as an appetizer.

Fifth Ave is very interesting. Fifth Ave is a pedestrian only stretch. It has fantastic restaurants, shops and night clubs. If you know where to eat you can do so reasonable. Some of the restaurants are over priced but we have not really had a bad meal in any of them. Wrote reviews on quite a few. The tourist shops are like those in any tourist town and most of the items are pricy but if you do not have a car to go out of the area most tourists buy what they need there. The night clubs are fun lots of energy and excitement. On New Years Eve it reminded me of Times Square. I read one of the other reviews and they stated Mexican coffee is not worth drinking. I am a coffee drinker at least six cups a day and the coffee here both packages and restaurant is excellent. Like any place else you can go to a place that makes a bad cup of coffee. This would be the exception not the rule.Once the vendors find out you are a local you are treated differently more like a friend not a tourist just a greeting and they do not try to sell you anything. The chapel at the end is beautiful and the beach with the Mayan sculpture is well worth seeing. Fifth Ave.is a interesting street filled with energy and great food and nightclubs.
not like being in Mexico. Too many OVERPRICED Mexican handicrafts and too many American stores.the only advantage I found was 3 Starbucks. Mexican coffee is not worth drinking.
Night, bars and restaurants. I liked Quinta Avenida since this street is enjoyable at nights because there are very good bars, restaurants and cafes
WHAT HAPPENED TO PLAYA?. 1995 - 5 STARS2005 - 5 STARS2015 - 2 STARSWhen did Playa turn into Cancun Jr?"Show me the money""Money Money Money"Very sad and very disappointing
Have Fun!. Just get comfortable dancing shoes and make sure you eat before going out, tequila takes you away!If you are a woman, you probably will get in to places for free!
Quinta Avenida. too busy, too many people trying to sell their stuff! It is sometimes annoying to avoid the sales people.

Lively, hip and expensive!. Very clean for Mexico. Great shops w big N. American prices. Lovely for a stroll if u don't mind being hasselled by locals to come spend ur $ on their overpriced ummm stuff.
Wow have fifth ave changed. as you walk down fifth ave now you will find a three story mall of high end shops, there is a starbucks on every corner and it is just not the way it was.

No way. Pushy, annoying vendors line the street and I did not feel safe with my kids at all. After a pretty short time I made the executive decision to flee to our hotel. Really an awful experience. Nothing worth seeing or buying. Also, I love how the exchange rate is remarkably different in each store. Scandalous.
Comercial. Very comercialized place, but you can find anything in that road, starting from restaurants to bars and souvenir shops, etc.

Tourist trap deluxe. Everything you've read about 5:th Avenue on Tripadviser is true. You will be offered drugs, you will be confronted by people who claim to work at your hotel and you will walk into countless stores with the same wares. It is however a bit cheaper than the same products found in Playacar hotel shops. There was one store that we liked though, namely Wayan Natural Wear. It can be found in several places along the avenue.Fortunately it's easy to find a cab to go back to your hotel when you're tired of the unwanted attention from all the sellers.

It was commercialized.. It have been to market places in other places and this was very commercialized. We could not haggle or bargain the prices were set. The most interesting this was a tobacco shop rolling there own cigars. Hitting the end of the street and seeing the ocean. I could buy the stuff they were selling at the resort. I wanted different. More authentic. More artistic. Would have been willing it pay for original work etc. but did not see any of that.
So much fun!!!. So colorful and busy...lots of fabulous shops,restaurants,bars and sights. YOU MUST WALK DOWN THIS AVENUE!!!

Changing. I was here about 16 years ago and it has changed monumentally. The popularity of this area in Mexico has led not only to the development of resorts but to the town of Playa del Carmen as well. It has added brand name shops for those who can't do without them or their Starbucks. Little shops selling local crafts are going extinct and those that are left are fronted by aggressive hawkers begging you to come into their shops. If that's what you are into this is the place for you. The beach is still beautiful and you can always take the ferry to Cozumel.

Interesting touristy street with thousands of shops & restaurants. Interesting touristy street with thousands of shops & restaurants. spans 30 or more blocks and there is a lot to see and a lot to eat. usually has lots of people walking around.

It's ok for souvenirs. We did a 1/2 day trip to Quinta Avenida from our resort. The shuttle is "free", but first they took us to a jewelry store where you are stuck for an hour as they try to sell you upscale jewelry. Your salesperson also follows you from room to room which is a bit annoying. Quinta Avenida is a collection of tchotchke shops, restaurants, and other various stores. The sellers are a bit aggressive, but either ignoring them or just a firm" No Thanks" works. It did appear that the restaurants were at various price points, so you should be able to find something to eat that doesn't break the bank. In a lot of the souvenir shops US Dollars were a better deal than using pesos. We did get gouged when we stopped for ice cream at a Haagen dazs. Ice cream for 4 people wound up being like $40 US, should have looked at the prices before we ordered, I think there was cheaper treats to be had on the Avenida. Overall it was an ok 1/2 day, and if you are looking for cheap souvenirs rather than buying things from a resort gift shop it's a good place to go.
Beautiful shopping district!. You can find a lot of handcrafted objects, as well as regular tourist stuff like caps and T-shirts... A lot of very good restaurant there too...
Great shopping!!. Lots to see and do, good food, cafes, entertainment, stores everywhere.liked the variety of shops! Nice to see the mariachi ands singing for restaurant patrons.

Great walk. 5th Avenue is where all the action is in PDC. There are a wide variety of restaurants, shops and bars to suit any taste and pocketbook. You can eat, drink and shop your way down the street. Don't let the vendors worry you...it is just the way its done in Mexico. A polite "no thanks" is all it take to stop them. Everyone is out to make a buck as we all are.

Once is more than enough. Like the old Atlantic City boardwalk, lined with shops, hustlers, and hotels while being stifling crowded. We are glad we went just so we know to never book a vacation in Playa de Carmen!In fairness there were some quality merchants but the prices were astronomical. I guess if you a young party animal this might be a great place to party and do tequila shots though. To each their own......

THE place to be!. Read anything about Playa del Carmen and 5th Avenue will surely be mentioned. Ideally you'd want to stay at a location where you can easily walk here because trust me, you will be here every night. Eateries, places to drink, people watch or shop. You can shop for everything from junky trinkets to high end merchandise. Musicians stroll the streets and they will stop to play for you for for a few bucks.Be aware of the store barkers who constantly call out to you... "Cheapy, cheapy". You get used to it and simply ignore them. Barter hard to get the best deal. Decide what you are willing to pay and don't pay more than that. If you can't get your price, move on because you can find the same stuff at many stores.5th Ave people watching is great. Grab a spot, have a beer, get some guacamole and relax. Everything will walk by you! When you go, wear comfortable footwear as most of it is cobblestones and skinny heels won't work well. Also be aware everything is really open air so it will be warm. Go and enjoy.

Shopping and people watching. Over a mile long. On 5th Avenue there a probably 100 restaurants ranging from dumpy taco stands to gourmet restaurants where dinner for two can cost $100. You can buy everything on this street...3 t-shirts for $10 to Rolex watches. Its a pedestrian street which makes it even better.

Don't miss it!. This is just a great place for an evening stroll/dinner/drinks. Over the years 5th has changed and grown, but it remains such a cool place. Lots of people, lots of places to eat and drink. Sights, sounds, smells, - love it. Easy to find a cab. Lots of shops. Some fantastic food. If you travel to Playa del Carmen area, 5th Avenue is a "don't miss". A very international scene. Despite the occasional bad press about Mexico being dangerous, in our probably 20 something trips to the area, we have not had any problems. Many of the vendors are a little pushy but this is a pretty upbeat, welcoming and relaxed place and your courtesy and friendliness will likely be returned. Relax, enjoy!

Busy but fun place to shop, eat, and walk. We love walking along 5th Avenue at night, when the vendors don't bother you as much (especially if you walk your dog, as we do). It's fun to see all the little shops and cafes, the city lights, and all the people. Such a vibrant, fun place to be! It's also a good place to jog in the morning while most everyone else is still asleep.

Fun to visit - once. This last trip to PDC, we went to 5th Avenue. What a zoo. Lots of people, and lots of high priced shops. There are a few local shops and goods, but way more high-end to luxury goods and shops. What a tourist trap. You are not going to find local Mexican handcrafts here. I remember when 5th Avenue was a small path. The whole area is becoming to 1st World. Sad to see.

Its busy and exciting. you can definately find afforable trips and food here.. Its a fun place to visit. good shopping - and you can negotiate trip prices.. One couple we met paid 60 per person for a trip that travel companies were charging 160 per person.you can even bargain for meal prices and of course, all sorts of everything else from blankets to pottery to tequilla...some stores have fixed prices, but many are open to bargain.be careful of the street silver. much of it is not real.

Where are the quality local handicraft items?. This is a great place to people watch, eat food, and get drinks. However, if you're really looking for local, quality, handicraft items that are reasonably priced, this is not the place.We went to Quinta Avenida to see it at day and night, so we went late afternoon. Many stores sold tchotchkes/souvenirs. Many stores are also found in the U.S. Many stores are local stores selling high end (and therefore expensive) fashions. None of these are bad if that's what we were trying to find.What we couldn't find were reasonably priced, quality, locally made, handmade or hand tooled, items. Examples would be quality leather items, woven shirts and blankets, etc.These stores, for the most part, just didn't exist. Ironically, we found the items we were looking for at the store in our resort.

Shopping for the day. This is a great place to find pretty much anything for the gifts back home. Fun things to see, food to eat and interesting people to talk to. I always go here when I am in the area.

Janet's Birthday Week. We took a shuttle from Iberostar Paraiso Lindo into Playa Del Carmen one day at a cost of US$6 per person. They dropped us off at the usual high priced silver shop. We walked back from 20th St to the Cozumel ferry landing checking out the wares for sale. We enjoyed the banter with the venders as we walked along. We checked out the upscale shops at the end like Harley Davidson and we ended up buying t-shirts and souvenirs at the Maya Mart. We had a beer on the beach at US$4 a piece. Noticed that massages were advertised for US$20 per hour in town vs US$100 at our resort. We returned in a cab for $30 for the 4 of us.

Fun for all. After reading a lot of reviews talking about the bombardment from shop-keepers we almost didn't come to playa all together. Maybe we just didn't look the bill but for three full days we walked the 5th and other than the casual mentioning of coming in their shop we never got harassed and really enjoyed the people watching. Maybe the shop keepers figured out this would ruin there towns reputation and send tourist elsewhere? We really enjoyed walking, shopping and eating on the 5th although restaurants generally cost more here but are more accommodating to non-spanish speakers so i guess you get what you pay for. With the exception of one restaurant everywhere we ate was good. We really enjoyed staying in town.

Cool place to hang out. Love this place! Yeah the shop keepers can get a little annoying after a week of going to dinner there but then again no one is physically aggressive and some of them are pretty creative in their barker antics. Tons of great restaurants and bars. Walk it from end to end. The souvenirs are very generic and repetitive though. If you want something authentic or special you will have to dig deep or get off the main drag. There is a young couple that own a shop that specializes in hand painted "Katrina" or "Dias de los muertos" dolls on the southern end of the Ave that is outstanding for authentic arts and crafts. They are located just off the Ave, next to the Parque Fundadores and the ferry to Cozumel. If you just want to relax there are a dozen shops offering massages, cigar shops or bars to watch the "big game" or the masses of people moving through. Looking forward to going back again.

Better than I expected. Visited 5th Av several tines over a one week stay in PDC. Yes the vendors a tab pushy - so what... Usually cool shopping and people watching. Stuff better priced a block away or in one of the supermarkets west of 5th but the overall experience is very cool. Goes all the way from Playacar to north of Ave Constituyentes, good mile long....

Stay Rip-Off of Quinta Avenida. I must admit the Americans have once again Killed another Mexican beautiful place. I stoppedto person buy Evian water in a store on Quinta that were paying $8.00 for the water. In Walmart in Playa its $3.00. The people who upset me most are the tourists that pay 200 peso to take a picture with a baby monkey. The restaurants will rip you off by padding the bill by putting 20% on bill and not telling you the tip was included. Quinta Avenida unless you are a fool with money to throw away is the biggest rip off streets in the Yucatan Peninsula.I also suggest you don't flash a Rolex or Cartier since you will lose it for sure after 11PM.Dis you ever wonder why there are so many Police on the streets of Playa. The have lots of problems there with robberies and kidnapping.The water in the Ocean is not clean. The new Malls have killed the old charm of a simple fishing village.Enjoy your stay but dont be a Gringo Stupido and pay the check on your food without checkingor spend $20 to take a picture with a small monkey. The more you help these animal abusersthe more they will be there, They take home thousands of dollars each night. Enjoy your stay in this rip off avenue and beware of the so called travel tours they are all time share scams.

Worth visiting it a couple of times. 5th Avenida is the main tourist (and "pedestrian only") street in Playa del Carmen. Plenty of shops and restaurants (and some hotels). Quite safe to venture around. After walking around a couple of times you see the same stuff again and again. Excellent restaurants all along the Avenida. Try the Yaxche for a unique experience!

Lively, but full of cat-calls and Italian joints!. My friend and I went to 5th off of a recommendation from our neighbor, and it was great. Lots of different shops to stop in, lots of different people, and very safe. We were taken back by the number of "western" shops (think Victoria's secret, Forever21, etc.) and TONS of Italian restaurants. We wanted authentic shops and Mexican food, which were available, but far more sparse than the other, more commercial options.Also, we were 2 girls traveling alone and were cat-called nearly everywhere we walked down the street... from vendors, men walking down the street, hosts at restaurants; it was overwhelming. However, we never felt threatened or unsafe.

5th Avenuje is growing up. 5th Avenue is becoming a mini Cancun, which is okay if you like the hustle and bustle and brand name stores. I prefer the Playa of 10 years ago, when it was more flavorful. Having said that will I return you betcha'!

very lively. I liked a lot. it's a long avenue full of shopping and restaurants for all tastes and budgets. There are local mexican restaurants, italian, argentinian, brazilian, french bakeries, subway sandwich stores, starbucks... really a lot of choices.
The same goes to the stores: from souvenir shops to upscale malls.

Far too blandly international in its commercial style. Aside from the odd tourist tat shop and abundance of silver jewellers, the remaining shops could be on any high street of any city in any country. Sadly, there is little in terms of cultural distinctiveness. There are some nice bars along the route - Santanera and a roof terrace bar closer to the port. The bars of 12th are trashy in a student gap year sense - possibly fun but again generic. Don't expect much in terms of gay scene... This is straight territory.

Otherwise known as Fifth Ave. Main strip in Playa for shopping, people watching, eating, drinking, walking the list goes on. This street runs east and west. You will see a variety of shops and eateries and bars. There is definitely not a shortage of things to do or see. Very safe to walk at night or during the day. Be prepared though this strip is HOT with the sun during the day. Pesos or US funds accepted. Barter Barter. Shop owners will try to call you in to buy their goods- this is their livelihood do not be alarmed or taken back; smile and say no gracias if no interest- remember if you have a armband from the cruise ships or hotels you are walking marketing as a newbie to Playa looking to purchase. I love the feel of this strip in the evening when the sun goes down- lots of places with music.

It is what you expect. Going to La Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) is an adventure. Go with an open mind and when the vendors get a little pushy, just say, ‘No, gracias.’ There are some bargains, but you have to know what you are looking for and willing to negotiate. Taxi to La Quinta from Playacar resorts is about 90 pesos, or $7 USD. Pay in Pesos, otherwise the cab drivers can set their own exchange rate. Have exact pesos was very helpful.

Fun place to walk around. Whenever my husband and I come to Playa, we purposefully pick a place that's close to 5th avenue. There are a ton of restaurants and shops and it's fun to just walk around and look at everything. The street is closed off to cars which makes it really easy to get around with a stroller. When you're off of 5th ave, it's much harder to get around with one. It's great to be able to walk off the calories that you'll surely consume at the great restaurants! I will say though that prices are more expensive on 5th. You can get and awesome meal for much less by leaving this street.

Overrated. if you are looking for the real Mexican experience stay away from la 5ta ave. this is just an other Americanized overrated shopping street wit bunch of expensive restaurants and gift shops offering nothing but the same you can find anywhere else for half the price. It's a nice place to visit if you feel like you miss the U.S. And want to stay away from locals, which I belive is not what most people travel for. I was very disappointed after walking all across la 5ta. Ave feeling like I was anywhere but Mexico. don't take me wrong, it's a nice place to visit, just not what I was expecting to be.
Nice place to visit, but wouldn't want to live there. Nice shopping area with lots of restaraunts and shops, outdoor cafes, and bars. Beach is only a block away.

Fun place to walk around. Went here for a day trip, loads of things to see, people are friendly and cheerful but they try to get you to go into their store, restaurant etc by calling out as you walk by. Just say no gracias and they leave you alone. You have to haggle with them if you want a fair price as the prices marked are beyond astronomical. Don't be shy they expect it but keep it within reason and don't be rude. Have fun and practice a reasonable degree of caution.

Have fun. What a great experience to wander along, shop, have a bite and enjoy the merchants trying to sell you everything and I mean everything at up to 100% off. It is fun and non harassing. Beware of the fake cigars, almost all are labeled as name brands but are not. Do not buy alcohol there, it is way over priced. Go to the Walmart and a Mega grocery store a few streets over where everything is more reasonably priced. There is a large shopping mall nearby, but a car or cab is necessary. Some very nice crafts, good quality but market priced. Food was good, but expensive too. Police with big guns are everywhere and our waiter told us the place is very safe, even at night. But like anywhere, you need to be careful where you go late at night. Worth the experience.

5th Avenue Playa Del Carmen. What a blast!! Although be prepared to say NO THANK YOU a lot!! Vendors from all stores desperately want your business and have some creative ways to get your attention! Thankfully they aren't touching are pressing you too hard! We went the week of New Years, there were SO MANY PEOPLE.... but so much fun.

Tourist Trap. Playa Del Carmen used to be a nice calm quiet place to visit & really soak up Mexican culture, food & ambience. Not any more - chain stores everywhere, constant harassment by people trying to sell things, chained monkeys & drugged lion cubs paraded around for picture ops, offers to buy drugs (only made to the men in our group) several times daily. We won't be back.

Practice your negotiating skills and have fun. 5th Avenue strolling is not for the faint of heart. The current " line" being used to lure you into their shops is " remember me, I'm your waiter from your hotel." It didn't take long to catch on as they could not possibly all work at the hotel. There's a vast array of trinket shops, t-shirt stores, jewelry , Tequila and even Tommy Bahama and Victoria's Secret, something for everyone. The most fun was browsing and seeing how low the merchants would go. Some shops clearly state "fixed prices". I always buy vanilla, but do your homework on vanilla and read the labels as I found some that said pure Mexican Vanilla but had artificial flavouring. The beach wraps and Mexican blankets are reasonable but be cautious on the jewelry and be sure silver is stamped "925". There are plenty of restaurants and most are good. Walk al, the way down to the Cozumel ferry and down to the public beach. I wouldn't try to walk it all in one day in the heat, spread out over at least 2 or 3 days, and be sure to go at night and have a Marguerita at the Tequila Barrel.
must in playa del carmen. wonderful atmosphere, special stroll, nice restaurantsnear to the beach, near to the discosunforgetable
Super nice to visit.. It is no way to go to Playa del Carmen and not to take a cab and get to Fifth Ave, lots of shopping and great restaurants.

be carefull. when they see your resort bracelet, they will tell you that they were at your resort, at the restaurant just to make you feel like you need to buy with them. Don't be shy to negociate the price with them. You will be surprised the difference.

Nice Place to visit. Quinta Avenida is a place to visit if you just want to hang out and shop around. It is full of shops ranging from all prices but we did see that some are more expensive than others. My wife and I decided to visit the mall and some of the prices were a lot more than in the States for the same department store.. Aside from the prices, you can still have a good time and enjoy the modern and the traditional atmosphere. Although we did not go, I heard that you will get a much better deal coming to Quinta Avenida to obtain a pass for Coco Bongo instead of getting it from your resort.
Having fun!. The Street is full of stores and restaurants, it is fun going during the day or even for dinner time. It is difficult to park.

Tourist area - fun time. This of course is the main tourist area of Playa del Carmen so don't be surprised to find yourself being somewhat harassed by the vendors and shop owners to come in and check out their stuff. It's only one block off the beach which is beautiful. There's also the ferry terminal over to Cozumel. The entire area probably runs at least 10 city blocks long so you can end up being there for some time if you don't get tired of walking. The entire street is all shops and vendors, small boutique hotels, bars and restaurants, pharmacies, cambios (banks/currency exchange) and there's also a new mall. We personally don't like to be harassed by what are usually extremely pushy shop owners so when we want to actually shop, we stick to the big box stores (you'll recognize them as soon as you see them - some are so big that they are two stories high and look like a large department store you would find at home). These larger stores have fixed prices for everything so you can browse at your leisure, not be followed constantly by someone offering you a "deal" and not have to haggle (mind you, some people enjoy the thrill of the haggling so whatever you're into I guess). There are high end shops as well but don't expect any better pricing than you would find at the same store at home. We ate at some of the locals places on the ave a few times and although expensive, the food was spectacular!There are some locals with baby jaguars or leopards or spider monkeys that charge you money to take photos of yourself holding them. As tempting as this may be to some, don't fall prey to this. I did once a couple of years ago and felt so horrible for this animal, it was so lethargic from the heat that it barely moved - it's really sad. There are also street performers who dress up in full traditional Mayan clothing or as Michael Jackson or things of the sort, again for money to take photos with them. It's definitely a sight to see and in my opinion, not something you should miss out if you are in the area, even if just for a short visit!

Shops, swim, street shows. If you'd like to buy a quality Mexican guayabera shirt - 5th Avenue is the place to buy it. The poll acrobats are simply amazing, and so are the drum dancers - in the beach square.

If it feels like a tourist trap.... ...then it probably is. I live in a touristy area of Florida, and this reminds me very much of the local tourist traps. The shops are mildly interesting, and perhaps a good place to pick up a few cheesy gift items for the folks at home (most of which have "Playa del Carmen" scrawled on them somewhere). Street performers rely on their questionable Mayan heritage to dress in outrageous feathered costumes and play traditional instruments to get their cut of the tourist pie. Some fellows even resort to using small monkeys. Shopkeepers are aggressive, and the competition for dollars/pesos is fierce. I enjoyed going down to the beach and people watching much more than looking in the shops. If you are in Playa del Carmen anyway, it's worth a look, but otherwise it's very skip-able.

Take It For What It Is. If you are staying in Playa, Del Carmen, you really cannot help but find yourself on 5th Avenue. As many others have remarked, this is a very typically pedestrian shopping street. It's really not much different from similar areas in major cities around the world. Here in Boston, it would be comparable to Faneuil Hall Marketplace, although the vendors are perhaps a bit more aggressive at getting your attention. But no one is getting in your face to force you to come inside. We found them all pretty nice and laid back, actually. There are high-end luxury boutiques, middle-of-the-road sorts of places, places to buy cheap chintzy touristy stuff, etc. The vendors are harmless - simply smile and say "no thanks" if you are not interested. If you are planning a tour in the area, there are several booths set up selling the same trips throughout the area. You can play one off the other to get the best price. They all seem to be booking for EasyTours which has an office around the corner. I don't know, but the prices might be better booking direct. There are many excellent restaurants and eateries on and near 5th. Just run a "search nearby" on TripAdvisor and you will know what to expect.

nothing else to say. equal to al shopping areas not good not bad; what is the idea of havig young baby monkies enslave to a chain for tourists to get a pictureI do not understand the uselessnes of such an activity
Typical Tourist Trap. Did not enjoy the constant harassment of the vendors trying to pull you into to their shops and because of this only went to the 'warehouse' shops.

Interesting. We walked 5th Ave but must admit it was a little challenging. Shop owners try desperately to get you into their stores. We bought our souveniers for grandkids at the market place store around 40th street. They held our purchases for us until we were done so we didn't have to carry bags with us. Great service! They have a bench out front with a stone mexican bandito! Didn't appreciate being offered drugs from a vendor on the street and I am surprised that this happens here especially as we are seniors!

Shoppers Paradise. One mile of boutiques on both sides with numerous restaurants in between. Have re-visited several times and always impressed with the area growth. Not only boutiques now, but US franchises like Forever 21, Guess, Hugo Boss, Nautica, Krispy Kreme, McDonalds, Subway and Burger King.In the evening numerous talented street entertainers perform for tips.The Mexican storefronts not unlike most of Mexico with rude in-your-face "almost free" duplicate offerings.After residing in tiny Belize for the past two years, my wife was in heaven to find a 24 hour Walmart.

Typical Tourist Street. The typical tourist shops, restaurants, bars, etc. walking street. It is fairly lengthy though if you want to take a break away from the shopping, the beach is just a half block over. Otherwise, a couple hours of walking and may be a lunch here is good enough unless you’re a big shopper.
5th Ave. Bars,Restaurants & Tac, repeat ad infinitum, just be prepared to say no to all requests to venture into establishments you don't fancy, usual holiday Main Street area!

Not much to see. People can get very pushy.. The souvenirs are not appealing. People get crazy trying to sell whatever they have, from hats made in China to touristic packages that you can arrange on your own (especially to Cozumel). It can get very inconvenient.

awesome, love it.. This was awesome, close and within walking distance from the resort. Lots of restaurants and shops. some of the vendors could be pushy, but after a few days, we learned not to make eye contact....

Fun for a little while. It's your run of the mill Mexican shopping stall experience! The prices were decent, lots of vendors with tequila and other trinkets. If your hotel makes you wear a bracelet, they'll zero in on you with "don't you remember me? I was your waiter last night." We got that at least 10 times in the few hours we were walking around. Also, we got offered drugs several times, you just have to keep walking. Overall, the shops were a fun experience.

Everyone is a waiter at your complex!. Quinta Avenida is an experience but it becomes weary after a while. Everyone reads your wrist band and says they are a waiter at your hotel. BUT we were at a private condo so since we don't have waiters I often took them on in an argument. It became very irritating. You are assaulted with people trying to sell you something. I was called Barbie, told to come give a kiss, called gringo and amigo and I found this rude., Not sure there are even any good deals! Go off 5th Avenue and you find amazing restaurants and shopping far better than the crazy pushiness of 5th.
too many mean vendors. not all it is cracked up to be..lots to see but tough to do with all of the hastle the vendors give you each one telling you they have stuff to sell you
Shopping. Fifth avenue is a shopping avenue with many vendors,it is pedestrian friendly and got many restaurants,ice cream parlors ,coffee shops,a new shopping mall,etc
Not all that.... Meh. Would never go again. Vendors are annoying and the beach is nothing special. Shopped for some souvenirs and the restos looked good.

Great place to visit. We took multiple trips up and down Quinta Avenida on our vacation in Playa. There were many shops, restaurants and lots of people watching. This is a very safe place - night or day for walking and shopping. I never felt uncertain at all.

Slice of everything. A cross pollination of restaurants, boutique hotels, bodegas, and tourist shops, and now even a mall. Some of the best food in any cuisine can be food while also some conveniences. Long stretch of walking parallel to beach only 2 blocks away.

Playa Del Carmen. The shopping is great. 5th Avenue is a wonderful place to just walk around and look at all the wonderful items on sale. Even if you are not in the mood to buy the atmosphere is wonderful.
Great for walking, shopping, eating and people watching. Lots of places for all tastes and budgets. Safe to walk at all hours. We reccomend eating at Divinos.

Many shops, Bars & Restaurants. This was our second visit to 5th Avenue, first time we went during the day, this time we spent an evening here. We took a collectivo from our hotel and it cost us around 3 dollars each so very cheap indeed and well with taking a look. This place is full of shops, bars & restaurants. We stopped for a drink & had a meal here too. It's got plenty of souvenir shops plus a shopping mall. It's nothing spectacular but well worth a look if you have a couple of hours to spare. Both times we have been here we were offered drugs whilst walking around, it's uncomfortable but you have to politely say no & walk away. Also, avoid photographs with the animals as I've read lots of stories about animal cruelty. The bars and restaurants aren't cheap but it is a busy tourist town so things will vary in price from shops and restaurants. Have a look around before buying anything to get to grips with the average price for things. It is nice to stop at a bar & have a drink and a look around around so definitely worth a trip here. Also, when getting the collectivo home you have to walk away from 5th Avenue to get to the stop, it's about 3 blocks away and you can easily take a wrong turn. Make sure you remember exactly where you were dropped off especially if its late at night. We actually got lost and ended up down a back street away from the crowds. Taxis are a lot easier as they are all over 5th Avenue. At night time I would of preferred using a private taxi rather than the collectivo.

Great place to people watch and some good resturants. Great place to people watch and some good restaurants. Great place to people watch. Better massages down at the beach though. Be sure and try Fusion restaurant also

Get ready to be harassed. Just walking to get to a restaurant is total harassment. We got asked to follow them they had something to show us in the alley?!! If we wanted Cocain, weed, pain killers! oooofff. Ignor and walk fast! If you can. We did eat at SUR. It's a steak house on the 5th. We ate fish, it was delicious. I highly recommend it. The service was great and so was the food. Can't go wrong.

North end is quieter. Our first night in Playa, we only walked the northern end of Quinta, and loved it. On the second night, we walked farther south, and I couldn't get out of there fast enough. A Nike store? No thanks, I can do that at my local wall if I really wanted to. Also, restaurants farther south seemed more interested in selling you crap than giving a good dining experience. We stayed around 46th, and I was glad we were close to the north end.

Muy Bueno. Its a Great walking street, you can find people from all over The world, Stores that Sell everything from Silver to DESIGN clothingRestaurants from many different cuisines and overall a very interesting walk

wear sunscreen and light clothes, it is damn hot. do your homework on your bank machines and carry pesos!!! if you are Canadian, bring your passport to the bank of nova scotia and use your visa for a cash advance...
Fun night out. It was nice to walk along 5th ave and look at all the shops and restaurants! The shop owners were very friendly! The area was clean and decorated nicely for the holidays!
Good day of shopping and sight seeing. Spend a day on 5th Ave, good for shopping, stop for drinks and food, random people with animals for pictures.

It's changed a lot. 5th ave has always been tourist central, but now it looks more like union square than Mexico. They built a couple big shopping malls with all the American staples. Why do we have to ruin everything? There's still plenty of great things to do in Playa, but most of them are off 5th.

5th Avenyue. It's a mile long of shops, food and drink. It certainly has changed over the past 15 years from the sleepy little avenue to the hustling high end shops mixed with the ma and pa shops now. Can get everything from purses to minnows eating the dead skin off your feet. Obviously all the souvenirs all in one place. Only downside is the small shop owners have become highly aggressive and have alot of lines to get you in their shop. Have fun but beware of the "almost free" deals.

Go for the people watching and some restaurants, not for the shopping.. Yes, Quinta Avenida has gotten much more tourisy and overpriced in recent years. Yes, if you look like an easy mark you will be harassed to no end. But if you are staying at the resorts, all you have to do when you want some serious shopping and cheap authentic Mexican food is to leave the tourist street and just walk a few blocks inland. (The much less touristy area begins at 15th Ave, only 2 blocks inland!) As far as Quinta Avenida itself, it's great for people watching, very limited shopping, and a handful of good restaurants. Here are some tips for our friends from across the pond:-Some of the larger souvenir shops have fixed prices and are not unreasonable for tourist areas. I would look in these and avoid completely the little shops where you are heckled to come in. -The same goes for the restaurants. There are some excellent bars and restaurants on Quinta Avenida. They are all overpriced by Mexican standards. Do your research beforehand and know where you want to go before you arrive on Quinta Avenida. Though there is usually someone standing outside to greet anyone who shows an interest in dining there, as a general rule, a good restaurant does not need to have someone in the street actively soliciting passers-by to come and eat there.-Walmart and Mega are two large supermarkets a five block walking distance from Quinta Avenida, at 30th Av.-The stranger you meet in the street was not your waiter the night before at the hotel. -Non-gringo priced food and shopping start at about 15th Av, especially along Avenida Juarez where you can get cheap bathing suits, sandals, flip flops, etc. There are loads of restaurants where you can get breakfast for 35-50 pesos, stuff your face with 5 tacos and a drink for 50 pesos, and shop in a much more local and cheaper atmosphere.-If you want a large mall go to Plaza las Americas in the residential area of Playa. There are lots of great stores for relatively inexpensive clothes, shoes, as well as a nice movie theater and a huge supermarket. You will need a taxi to get there. It's only 35 pesos from the center, but DO NOT TAKE THE TAXIS FROM THE TAXI RANKS ALONG QUINTA AVENIDA These stands rip off tourists and charge them whatever they want. Hail a moving taxi on the street instead. -It helps if you speak at least some real Spanish and not just a token amount with a bad accent.-The taxi fare to and from Playacar has recently been raised from 70 to 90 pesos. (which is currently about $6.) If you ask how much beforehand, you will be charged as much as you look like they can get away with charging you. The 90 pesos covers all of the Center of Playa Del Carmen, including Mega and Walmart and Quinta Avenida all the way as far north as 34th Street. Again, hail a passing taxi a block inland from 5th, and pay 90 pesos when you are back at your resort in Playacar. -Have fun.

typical boring overpriced tourist street. Instead of going to the beach we decided to go to town. We said we would be back by 12, we were back by 11. Instead of eating or drinking anything there, risking horrible toilets and rip-off prices we just got a taxi back to the hotel where everything was clean and free. Why do they ask such absurd prices for things? More than in London? Surely if they rip off one person then they lose 20 others which maybe explains why they all look so bored in their empty shops. Like others have said people pretend to know you, they don't. I was interested in going to a normal mexican supermarket to pay normal mexican prices, I couldn't find one, again, why hide the real prices away? All the tourist stuff was cheaper at Chichen Itza.

Where the magic happens!. Is the "must go" destination at PDC, full of typical souvenir shops, restaurants, hotels, snack stores, and all you can look for to make your beach vacation the best. (Wear comfortable shoes).
mexican flavor. Sampling typical foods at local street vendors and Mexican restaurants. I did not like the European side of the beach where they are half naked.

Tourist trap. We walked through this street and it had the usual shops and restaurants you see in every city that caters to tourists. The usual sales pitch and of course, the old line "I was your waiter last night at so and so resort ". It was amusing and fun but got old after several of them said the same . Even one salesman anldmitted the price is high and you'd pay less if you went up one block.We walked several blocks and felt very safe while walking back to our resort on the north end of PDC.

Great Shopping for souveneirs. Lots of different shops for different tastes. Dont be afraid to haggle over a price in smaller shops. Its fun and if you start to walk away, the price magically drops. Felt very safe even at night. Plenty of police floating around. Can take a taxi from resorts for around $10.

Mexican Fair. The Mexican version of the PNE or CNE. Lots of people wanting your money but make sure you compare prices since they can vary quite a bit. It is strictly for tourists, locals don't buy here, they cannot afford it.
A must see. The 5th ave area is must when you get in this area. A great place to walk, shop and eat. Great prices and selection and great day in Playa

A good place to buy souvenirs.. As you walk by they will try to sell you everything. And their first price is always ridiculous, specially if you go for the silver stores. But if you really want to buy something Bargain. It works with most of them, and its worth it. I wanted to buy something, asked for the price and he said : 50 dollars. I ended up getting it for 15. But this place is filled with tourists.

Best walk in the area. If you are not diving and not taking day trips, Quinta Agenda is the next best thing you have got to do when in Playa Del Carmen. Good shopping and dining is offered, all you have to do is to make the right choice...Not easy though cause there are places they are not worth your visit and some vendors are going over the limit sometime....The rule if you are not on buying is to avoid eye contact and use the word gracias as much as you can. You can have a lot of fun too though with some of the people working in the shops, most of them are in a good mood and understand jokes very well. Some of my favourite restaurants are on this street, easy I guess for you to find yours...
Tourist Trap. Some nice shops,somewhat pricey and some pushy vendors.Nice restaurants and bars and an overall enjoyable way to spend a few hours looking around.

Everything in One street. Very nice street, you can find everything . It is excellent if you want to eat or drink something , there are tons of bars and restaurants. You can find all kinds of food and very cool decorated places. It's nice to walk it all you find tons of shops with interesting stuff and also fashionable boutiques. After a long day at the beach this is a good place to enjoy the afternoon

great place to shop!. This is a long strip of litle stores and boutiques, malls, restaurants,Is located in playa del Carmen , go to the litle stores ,, they cheaper and most of the time they go down on the price, I found the prices of souvenirs and clothes cheaper compared to the resorts price, the only downside was that people always calling you and harrasing you to shop with them, but other than that , great place, great people!

Annoying. There are many shops and restaurants on 5th avenue, however the vendors are very annoying. When walking on 5th Avenue you are constantly harassed by vendors, tour companies and waiters trying to get your business. If you answer them they follow you and if you don't answer them they yell insults at you. We would have gladly browsed in the shops or stopped for a bite to eat, but we just avoided it all together as it was stressful and not at all enjoyable!

Hearth of Playa del Carmen. This avenida unic,they cold 5-th avenue,full of shops brand names,big shoping mall very soon will be another shoping mall.Lots of good restaurants bars,small local vendors ofering their products,you have to bargain.The avenue good place for walk nicely decorated for Cristmas.You can miss this place

Touristy!. So, this one is tough for me as I met my wife here 14 years ago and Playa was still a relatively quiet fishing village. What a transformation: Quinta Avenida is basically a long road packed full of restaurants, bars, souvenir shops, cigar shops, large malls, basically everything you can think of crammed in one street. It's overwhelming, feels touristy and has none of the charm of the real Mexico. You'll see people with Monkeys and Snakes trying to put them on you for a picture, for which you'll have to pay for of course. I was more concerned about the animal being in such a place, chained to the 'owner'. There are some decent restaurants and bars around, mainly nearer to 5th Avenue and Calle 30, which is quieter and seems more upscale. It's definitely a great place to people watch and just meander around, but it became too much after the 2nd day.

Pros & Cons. Pros: Great exercise walking up & down the long street. A few nice, unique shops. A lot of restaurants to choose from & some very good ones at that. Very easy to get a cab almost anywhere along the road. (Be sure to finalize a price before you get into a cab!)Cons: Most of the stores sell the same things & we were constantly accosted by local vendors as we passed by. Their tactics were amusing at first but became annoying very quickly. (We were told that if you are carrying a plastic shopping bag, they will harass you more as that shows them that you are actually spending money.)It is worth walking the Avenida at least once - if only for the exercise!

Very fun place. Quinta Avenida is a great place to walk. The European influence of this area is evident everywhere and it is an interesting phenomenon. There are a lot of cool lounges, bars, and shops to see here. I did not like to see the animal exploitation taking place here however. I would give Quinta Avenida a 5 star if the Government addressed this. I am referring to a baby lion that appears sedated and close to death. People ask for money to have their picture taken with it. There are also monkeys being used to generate tourist revenue here.

Two worlds in one. Perfect combo between home and local customs. You can find American stores and franchises also local stores with handcrafted jewelry.Local vendors can be little bit pushy but always respectful. Look around for best prices.If you are staying in a all inclusive hotel, I recommend that you eat there since in la Quinta prices are high.Also here you can buy ferry tickets for Cozumel, just go straight to the ticket stand and avoid buying packages from street vendors.
Nice walking mall.. Lots of small local shops and a great atmosphere.Had lots of locals try to approach you to sell you stuff, didn't really care for this, but you get that anywhere.

Overwhelmingly Touristy. This is the main "tourist" road in Playa Del Carmen. I knew it before I came but was still unprepared for the onslaught from the local vendors and restaurant owners. We have met a great tour company and found lots of great ways to leave town. Even enjoyed our outing to buy some groceries at the local grocery store. As my profile says, I am a budget traveler. I have found very little of that here. I will say that there are some interesting looking restaurants here on the Avenida, but I prefer to hunt out the less pricey options a little off the beaten path. There are some good stores on the street, but as soon as I look right or left, the vendors are using their worn scripts on me to try to get me to come into their shop.

A place to shop but you feel like you're in a big city with lots of hustling.. First went to 5th Ave almost 3 years ago now and went again this past week... it has grown a lot in just that time. Unfortunately there is still lots of hustling and now a mall with stores you would see at home (if you're from Canada or the US). It's great to shop and find things for a decent price but shopper beware of the vendors approaching you/calling out to you and being very persistent. It is just how it is so be prepared and be comfortable saying, "no" or just walking away if you need to. Aside from that... you generally will get a good price and you should be comfortable negotiating as they are more than willing to do that. So go with an open mind and enjoy the experience just remember to wear your big girl panties on that day.

Souvenir heaven. if you want a souvenir or two from your holiday, this is the place to go. Store after store of tat to choose from, plus a couple of more upmarket places keen to help you empty your bank account. Also lots of bars and eateries. Other reviewers complain about getting lots of hassle from shop owners trying to drag you in but we didn't experience that, certainly nothing to compare with experiences in Egypt or most European tourist hotspots. A good place to spend an evening if you want to shop, or simply have a change of scene from your hotel

Gone downhill, hate to see the changes.. First traveled here 27 years ago and have been going back to this area every year, it has changed to much it is not the quaint little town that it used to be. It is a must see for people wanting to do a little shopping and to pick up some souvenirs. they built a mall on 5th. and it is full of high end American stores, not what I want to see when I'm in Mexico. They are tearing down all the older hotels and stores and building American/European stores pushing out the small stores and venders. I like to have fun and enjoy my walk along 5th. ave but it has been taken over by drug dealers, you can't walk 5 feet without someone trying to sell you drugs one of the nice old hotels on 5th. is now a Brothel. Hate to say it but things are going downhill, I guess that's progress. Time to find a new place to travel. Not to say it is not safe but it has changed.The people I have met over the years that work there are still some of the best people I know and there not happy about it but can do nothing about it.Stay safe and have a good time.

hustlers. nice to have a pedestrian plaza. colorful. but you have to ignore the people yelling to sell you something. show a second of interest and they're following you, etc. I always chose a place that didn't hassle me to give my business. Many times you can find a place yourself instead of paying someone to get you your tickets, take you places. Walk! other parallel streets are calmer I certainly would not choose a hotel along this avenue.

Shopping Center. This is a new multilevel shopping mall that open in the last year. It is located on the 5th Ave. walkway. It has many high end shops one which is Sanborns which occupies half of the top floor. I was visiting it to pick up a t-shirt at the Harley Davidson store. Do wish it had more run of the mill type shops but it is surrounded by those kind of stores up and down 5th Ave. Well decorated and has security personnel visible on all floors.
Loved 5th Avenue. it was loaded with shops, bars and restaurants, its a must do while you visit Playa del Carmen, we went for breakfast and dinner and some shopping
hustlers galore. Timeshare barkers are the worst but everyone has an angle. Lots of shopping, restaurants and nightclubs. We thought the best food was off the avenue.

Gross. To some people this type of place/vibe night appeal but really it's just full of tourists and people wanting to make a quick buck - not that I blame them. But if you did not come to mexico to eat a burger or buy a pair of Nike shoes then I would avoid.

Has a Mexican feel to it.I like it.. Go to this pedestrian street in the evening and you will see many local families out for a stroll.Hundreds of restaurants to choose from.Some good some bad.A great place for people watching.Has many Farmacias and small shops as well as higher end shopping.Be prepared to bargain.Don't expect too much and you will have a great time.Has a Catholic church by the bus station as well as a larger one 2 blocks off of the main street.

Love 5th Avenue.
