Its so neat to walk 5th Avenue,to see all the Mexican wares,the neat little restaurants & now its changing,now we are seeing high end shopping centers,expensive restaurants ...........the small fishing village that it was,is no longer.But its still a great place to walk as no traffic,except people traffic to worry about.If you feel like stopping anywhere you are usually treated very friendly & others are really trying hard to sell you something.....but its still a great walk!Stop at Tropical restaurant between 8th & 10th & have a great healthy smoothy or a beer,cocktail & some great food!Best coffee in town unless you are a Starbucks fan....but most Canucks will like the coffee there.
Great Street for Everyone. Great food, bars and shopping and you don't need a taxi !!!! Live Quality Music in most of the drinking establishments.
Pleasant Surprise. The kind of thing that absolutely makes people like us smile from ear to ear. It actually has nice shops.

Don't miss out!!!. We were on 20th ave between calle 2 and 4. Every morning we'd go down to Quinta to get to beach. We'd head back to hotel to get changed for dinner and evening and back down on Quinta at night! For 2 weeks!!!! Pez Vola swing bar, Tequila Barrel, Fat Tuesday's, Star Bucks, Scotiabank, just to name a few favorite stops, and hundreds of small shops, pharmacies, jewellers, souvenir shops, Playa Mart, ATMs, money exchange outlets, cops, taxi guys, cops, taxi guys, and then hundreds of restaurants, bars, McDonald's, ice cream outlets, cops, taxi guys, and people...lots of people!! Women, don't get pulled in to little shops if you're alone!! They are very persistant and you might not like what they offer in exchange of their products when you don't wish to spend your pesos!! :o Guys, whatever you look like, you will be offered cigars, little something to relax, wanna have a good time, free sample for you.... Lol. You just have to say no, get into there game, be a little witty, but not rude, and have fun with them. They are all very nice and have to make a living. They will try to pull you in every, I mean every buisness there is on the street! After a few days walking up and down many times a day, many start to recognize you and that's when I started having more fun! Felt like a local!! It's a must to walk Quinta Ave more than once if you really want to enjoy it's full value!! Don't miss out!!

THE BUSIEST STREET IN PLAYA DEL CARMEN. During my last visit to Playa del Carmen in 2012, I saw a lot of construction going at that time. However, Playa del Carmen was still that little beach town outisde of Cancun. However, in 2014 all of that has changed and Playa del Carmen is no longer that little beach town we probably all loved. It is now a commercially attractive beach town with many coporate luxury hotels similar to what Cancun has been a while and Quinta Avenida (5th avenue) is the center of all of this consisting of blocks with stores, cafes, and restaurants. Everything is priced above market value. All the restaurants are quite pricey (i.e. expensive) and you will find Starbucks, McDonalds and Burger King: things I thought the average traveler or tourist wanted to get away from when they went on vacation in the first the place. However, it gets at excellent anyway because I'm impressed with the beautification and cleanliness of this street in Playa del Carmen. It is just entertaining to walking of up and down being harassed by vendors for tours, photo ops with animals, souvenirs, and massages. This is not the street to be on if you want to to enjoy the Mexican culture and have a peaceful vacation. Get out and explore real Mexico and use Quinta Avenida for what is worth. Happy Travels!!!!
Some good stuff here. Tatty shops and bazaar-like southern end, though some exceptions. It gets better as you go northwards, mostly beyond Avenida Constituyentes.

Great shopping!. Great shopping! I wish we would've left our "resort" much sooner to experience this! Their shopping includes Victoria's Secret, American Eagle, MAC, and many other places. Great scenery and atmosphere!

Interesting but too touristy. We spent a couple afternoons wandering Quinta Avenida because we had some spare time (were staying in Puerto Morelos) and it is a "must see" attraction when you've never been before. There is certainly no end to the variety of stores and restaurants available along the many blocks of Quinta and sitting and people watching can be very entertaining. But we found it far too crowded and much more expensive than the many little shops in Puerto Morelos. On our next to last day in Mexico friends took us to Don Chendo on 30 Avenida for supper and we drove along 30 Avenida Norte on our way out of Playa. I was surprised at the numerous unending small stores and restaurants along this road. We didn't have the time to stop and check them out but if you want to experience "the real Mexico" head a few blocks away from 5th and explore! We will head here first next time we're in Playa.

Happening Place. Must visit and walk the entire avenue like 2-3 kmsLike all tourist places, will be constantly invited to look at different products. For any photos pls. discuss before.Good restaurants
Fun for all. Nice place to walk off all that beer and food away, great place to just watch the people stroll along with friends and family.

Shopping, drinking & dancing on the beach.... Return to PDC every year and stay at the Royal Hideaway (adult only, quieter hotel just outside the city). However, having 5th Ave to go to within a $7 cab ride away is part of the reason why we continue to return. One night we'll go and just walk & shop (I think stores were open close to midnight one night we were there), another night we'll stop into a lounge/bar/club (there are some right on the beach) and have a drink and/or dance a little. The street is alive and full of color. Almost all restaurants & bars have this open concept idea where there are no walls and therefore you can see in from the street. Window shopping or window bar hopping, your choice, we usually opt for a little gelato and do both!
a total rip off. Over priced and a joke to negociate...tourist trap. beautiful park with entertainment at the end of street.

A must see!. Restaurants, cantinas, nite-clubs, shopping, bars, boutiques, so much to see..
You do not need money to enjoy this street, but it is nice to stop in a cantina and grab a drink.
This street has an amazing atmosphere.
I cannot even explain Halloween night, 1000's of costumes and people having fun.
I will go back every year for it.

Outstanding avenue. 5th Avenue has it all, all kind of restaurants, bars, boutiques, souvenirs stores and a lot of nice people working there.
Get a hotel at the 5th Avenue and enjoy.
Alex Espejo

When will it stop!?. 5th Avenue continues to grow longer and higher and 'deeper'. Pretty non-stop (south to north) all the way to 42nd street (note streets are even numbered - 2,4,6.....38,40,42 and Avenues (east to west - 5, 10 15th). Hard to fathom the range of worldwide cuisine offered and how consistently good it is. I am not much of a shopper so that part all looks the same after awhile but have noticed a lot more upscale and chic shopping venues in the last few years.Great for people watching: from shop owners readying and opening stores in am to restaurants filling from 5-9 pm and nightlife after that. A very cosmopolitan range of people in a safe and entertaining environment.Make sure to wonder down to 1st Ave/beach and out to 10th and 15th to get a little more of a local flavor and in most places reduced prices, including taxis.

USA-ed but still amazing. After going to the delicious "El diablito Cha Cha Cha" (5th with 12) me and my family walked in the amazing 5th avenue that has lots of little stores, mexican shopping, restaurants, bars. All these create an unique atmosphere, that you can ONLY find there. If you keep walking you can see a mall that includes USA stores like "forever 21" "victoria's secret" "starbucks coffee" and so more, which broke the mexican, and a tottally new-place-to-visit but the mall kind of broke the special "thing" about the 5th. Even tho, the mall is very nice and has nice stores but they should've placed it in another place, not the 5th. The little stores, little coffee shops, bars with loud music, innovating restaurants, etc... are beautiful amazing and the atmosphere and everything is spectacular, i can't put it into words, TOTTALY WORTH IT, a new nice place to go, and if you're traveling to Cancun/Playa del Carmen you NEED to go. It's really impresive and a new experience that you can't miss!

Too big!. We went down 5th Avenue a couple of times only to be dissapointed with how much it has grow, and how most of the smaller shops have gone and been replaced by large "designer" shops with price tags to match. Sorry, but you've spoiled it in the name of greed.

Lots to see, eat and buy!. Nice to walk down day or night. Pretty much if you're in Playa del Carmen, you literally cannot avoid walking on this street at some point or another.There are TONS of restaurants and shops. Pretty much it all starts looking identical when you go from one end to the next, but good to people watch and pick up some foods and clothes along the way.
It's always fun.. It's always fun to visit 5a Avenida. I liked the arts and crafts and the street store with really interesting products.

Just wonderful. This is just one of the most lovely places to walk on the riviera, you can find everything here and is just beautiful, from a slice of pizza to the finest restaurants, from the Mexican souvenirs to the most elite boutiques, hotels, discotheques and everything you can imagine...
5th avenue. You can find anything on avenida cinco. It leads you everywhere as a pedestrian mall. Side streets offer more local restaurants and artisan shops.

Typical tourist zone. This is a typical tourist zone with over-priced restaurants, souvenir shops, and a large number of stores from the US. One authentic shop I liked was Jellyfish lamps. Brought 3 home, quite pretty.

Very alive street. We really like this avenue, but I would prefer if it stop being modernized. It change a lot since the last time I was there and not sure if for better, but still great place to visit with a lot of options to eat, shop and drink.

5th Avenue. Good variety and prices. I bought silver jewelry at what I thought was a good price but found same thing at the airport at a lower price. Vendors on 5th Avenue were not overly pushy, which was good.
nice walk. a very big street where you can walk and explore turist nights in mexico with everything,shopping,food,drinks!!!i loved it!!

5th Avenue. If you're in Playa del Carmen, you will likely be seeing Quinta Avenida. It's a very long street. I found the southern end near the shopping mall the worst. Everyone wants you to shop in there store. At least some vendors had a sense of humor. Shouting, "I have nothing. Nothing you need." If you don't mind the stress of bartering for your wares and are looking for tourist trinkets to take home, this is the place to be. I was surprised to find that many of the souveniors were cheaper at Chichen Itza then on this street. I had to be in the right mood to tolerate this street. Saying that, we did find some great restaurants on 5th Ave. Yaxche, La Casa del Agua and La Bodeguita del Medio were my favourite restaurants.

love love. I loveed 5th avenue. i started walking all of it, because yo can walk a lot and is everything beautiful. I stoped in a place named el gallinero du chocolat and ate a crepe and some chocolate. It was perfect for me because i saw a lot of people walking from a lot of places
Shops. The shop owners are way to pushy!!! If they wouldn't lie about knowing you and making rude comments I would be more inclined to enter their shops.
Touristy. Nice shops and you can find some good food and deals on souvenirs. Do NOT buy "Cuban" cigars as they are NOT genuine, regardless of what they say!

Be ready to bargain!. It's a nice long street full of shops, restaurants, street vendors. The stores do have prices good ones too. The street venders and street stores no prices. You bargain over 50% of the cost they started at LOL.

For tourists. The place is crowded with people and stores selling souvenirs and "touristic" items, and they say the price in dolars already. A guy offered to us marihuana and cocaine, it was a little bit strange.

Always something going on!. Monkeys, boa constrictors, hawkers and shops, shops separated by restaurant after restaurant---some simple, some spectacularly beautiful and tropical---all overpriced, but you can't say it's not interesting. You'll probably have your fill if you stroll up and down over a couple of days, but for a short time it's enjoyable. Mix it with some beach time and an excursion or two and it all makes a great week in Playa.

It's so touristy, not my cup of tea.. If you are into this, be my guest. A visit for a night is worth the experience, but having visited Playa yearly for over ten years, things have changed a lot!I feel developers at Quinta Avenida are trying to please a specific sector of tourism, losing it's natural essence. Prices have sky rocketed in that area, overpopulated with loud bars and tourist shops. New plazas (shop malls) with American stores are sprouting in what once was a street with a nice town feel. Starbucks killed the local coffee shops, and Häagen Dazs can be found every few corners, as well as Burger King. What happened to the real thing?The nice thing of this street is that it's a pedestrian strip and a few good hotels and restaurants have survived.

You will not get bored. You can find anything you can ever imagine in here. From delicious food, to animals to take pictures with (like monkeys). And there's a lot of people from many countries to talk with!

Not our thing. Expensive restaurants, loud bars and tacky tourist shops. Maybe some people's idea of tourist heaven but not mine. If you want something that is more local, you only need to go a couple of blocks back. That's where you will find me.

Lovely street. Very lively place. It's always somethting to do and see here. Plenty of restaurants and food choises. Many shops with art crafts and small turistic items. I don't recommend it for people who want a quiet walk.

Street that have all... We were lucky to have Quinta Avenida( Fifth Avenue) close to the hotel, is a pedestrian strip that runs for about 2km parallel to the amazing beach. The avenue is full of restaurants, cafes, bars and shops catering to the visitors needs, so if you want to go shopping, this is a place for you there are plenty of souvenirs and also you can catch the Ferry to the nearby island of Cozumel or take a bus at the ADO station to Cancun. The place felt safe and had a relaxed atmosphere all day long.For us that we had so much food and drinks during our vacation, our stomach was very upset and like a miracle we found very close to Fifth Avenue a Farmacia Similar (drugstore) that have a Doctor who charge for service $ 35.00 pesos and gave you the order for the prescription so we finish our vacation without any complains

Mucho Fun. Pedestrianized main tourist street of PDC. Better prices than at 'Mexican Street' in Playacar in the stores but the restaurants seemed expensive. We had read of horror stories of people being charged $10 for a beer there, so were reluctant to go in, sit down and have a beer. Had a confrontation with one of the 'pitchmen' outside one of the restaurants, when I made a comment about their prices, but mainly the razzing was good natured.

Too Americanized. Great restaurants. Becoming so Americanized now though. A big outdoor name brand mall is not there and they are in the process of building another one. The quaintness of Playa is gone.

Fun Trip. If staying in Playa take a short cab ride to Fifth Avenue; some great authentic restaurants, cobblestone streets, and some good bargains...At least stop and have a drink in one of the quaint street fronts.It can be crowded but that is some of the fun. Take a walk down to beach and you can see the pier to board the ferry to Cozumel.

A day full of fun. Lots of people and things to see. You can get your picture taken with animals or people dressed up. Soooo many stores and places to eat and bars......wonderful Shops and shops!! Totally safe day and night.the sellers are always trying to get you to come in their shops but they are harmless, just say no gracias and keep walking :)the funny ones are the ones who say they are from your hotel....99% of the time they are not! lolJust smile wave and keep going.If you are at an all inclusive try to wear something over your wristband or take it off if you can.Haggling over prices is a way of life here so feel free to join in!Bringing pesos with you for purchases makes it easier, no trying to figure out the conversion rate!It is a long walk from one end to the other so wear comfy shoes.

Quite the site. Very different place lots of nice shops to get things from but wow do the locals hassle you if there not trying to drag you into there shops there trying to sell you drugs and don't take no for a answer even if you've told them 5 times a day for 2 weeks, Lots of good bars clubs and restaurants all pretty high priced but is still a really good place to be if you can put the harassing locals out of your mind.
La Quinta. nice break from resort. Pretty at night. Souvenir city, but if you walk down a block to 10th avenue the prices are less than half than on 5th.
Typical tourist trap. I think Quinta Avenida is a nice place to check out once if you have the time and enjoy shopping. However, it is very crowded and the sellers are very pushy at times.
Nice Shopping and Eating. This is the place to go, it has a huge selection of places to eat and shopping. It also have night life.

Nice pedestrian only shopping. Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) - not to be confused with super high end luxury shopping in New York, is a long stroll down a street with pretty much anything for sale, from souvenirs to sandals. A new indoor mall even has stores like American Eagle and Forever 21 for the younger crowd. However, that should also clue you in as to the creeping Americanization of an otherwise pleasant shopping experience...if shopping is what you are looking for. There are also many nice places to grab a bite to eat, bars if that is your scene, and plenty to see. There seemed to be people offering cheap massages on almost every corner, as well as the occasional offer of marijuana and other things. Be aware you will suffer the typical vendor mob as you walk down the avenue. Take my advice, just stroll along and ignore them all, but keep an eye out for what you want. Once you are done walking to the end, turn around, walk back to the places you saw what you wanted, and go directly there. Don't forget that bargaining is, for the most part, expected, and you will get taken to the cleaners if you don't have the stomach to play hard to get. Overall, it was a nice place to find some things for the kids, some souvenir shirts, and some jewelry, had a nice lunch, and enjoyed the sunshine.

The tourist trap you think it is. We found a few nice spots to grab a beer and some souvenirs, but we were also offered blow probably a dozen times, and each and every vendor WILL attempt to get you to look at their wares. It gets old after a few minutes...

The centre of it all. Playa del Carmen's main attraction Fifth Avenue (Quinta Avenida) is the social centre of this amazing resort town. Shop many of the fine artisan boutiques, Enjoy a meal at one of Playa's fabulous restaurants. Offering an array of flavours sure to please your palette,with a variety of local and international cuisine, you're sure to enjoy. Street performers, including Mariachi, perform helping make your experience along Fifth Avenue memorable.
Not much stuff. I hated to see that the town has lost the uniqueness with too many stores, and too Americanized. Do tourist really need fancy and expensive stores?
Safe and Fun. Great shopping, eating and local flavor with a hometown feel. From high end shops to local art, there is everything on 5th Avenue.

5th Avenue. Been going there for 12 yrs, so much fun. The vendors do call out to you as you pass by, all part of the Mexican experience, and some are truly funny and creative, some occas. rude but that's rare. Fa bar has great live music; The Minerali store has awesome jewelry put together right there for great prices; I could go on and on, just have to go there and walk around. Each time you go you'll find something different.

Lots of shops/restaurants. was good to see 5th avenue, very long strip and lots of bustling shops and restaurants. Wouldn't class it as an attraction but was lots to see and made a change from the beaches and other trips. The walk from playa car beach hotels is a pleasant one and takes you past the ferry to cozumel

what a hassle!. as someone who speaks both spanish and english this is a real hassle!
People just wont leave you alone trying to sell you stuff! And when they´re not talking AT you they´re talking about you...what a drag! I

North of Constituyentes. There are a few shops between Constituyentes and the ferry that aren't selling the same tourist kitsch and even fewer decent restaurants. Constantly being asked to go into shops, restaurants, buy tours or drugs gets old. The northern end has better restaurants, shops and less aggressive sales. I would give the northern end 4 stars.

Depends on the person..... it was my first time visiting Playa. We stayed at an all inclusive, so I wasn't consideringing one particular factor.,..my girlfriend... She's quite the shopaholic. I am the kind of person that visits all crack and crevices of town and and I like trying different foods, not neccesartily on the strip. I may buy something here or there, but it really has to catch my eye, not just another bathing suit. Had we spent our 9 days in a boutique hotel in town, Someone would be taking out a loan to pay another loan off... Other than that....LUVZ IT!

Fifth Avenue. This street was a couple blocks behind our hotel and had everything you could possible need or want in mexico. There was shopping, restaurants of every type, hotels, bars and discos. Use TripAdvisor as a guide to know what is good or not good. The staff will work the street trying to get you to come in and try their restaurant or visit their store. Some may be pushy but if you just say no thank you and keep walking, they leave you alone. Don't be afraid to price around a bit because not all shops are the same and have different prices. We enjoyed walking the street at night to people watch or have a drink or a coffee. There is even a mall on the street. Wear comfortable flat shoes as parts of the street are cobblestones and hard to walk in heels. We felt very safe here in and out of the shops as there is a good police presence in the area. Enjoyable and love the variety it had to offer.

For shopholics, this is the place!. If you are bored by sun , sea and sand, then try walking along (part of) 5th Avenue. It's a shopper's paradise! Whatever the vendor says is the price, halve it in your mind before you begin!If you are tempted into jewellery shops, check that the items you like have the 925 stamp on it. The mark 'sterling silver' doesn't exist in Mexico's jewellery making, so if it says that - give it a miss. It's fake!We found some of the best souvenirs were to be found in the bigger shops where prices were fixed and you didn't haggle. Not such fun but better value!!

3kms of shops, haggling, and food.. I liked that the day we chose to go was sunny and hot. It wouldn't be pleasant in the rain. We ate a couple of different places, bought our excursion here too. Drinks in a sidewalk café with street performers strolling past every few minutes.

I Just Love Walking on 5th!!. It is an experience that everyone should partake in. I love people watching, eating, shopping and listening to music. We start at one end and walk miles at a time. Stop and eat at restaurants- there are many to choose from- it all depends what you are craving that day. I also recommend walking to the beach and stopping by the beach clubs during the day. I like Mamitas!!

Playa del Carmen. We weren't happy with this trip in. If you like to shop, this is the place to go. Because we were staying at an all inclusive, we weren't looking for restaurants to eat at, although there were many. Wearing your all inclusive resort bracelet makes you a bit of a magnet for the vendors, who spot them readily and come up and say that they are on days off from the resort, that they recognize you and please come and see their relative's shop that they are working at on their day off. Having said that, nobody was overly pushy if you said no. The beach was nothing special. Wouldn't recommend the free bus tours in, since there are stops that are out of your control, and also return times are out of your control. Would suggest finding another couple and cab sharing.

Hustling and bustling. Visited La Quinta Avenida the first week of November after deciding that we wanted to venture into Playa del Carmen. The cab ride was only $14 US from the Sandos Caracol and we made arrangements with our nice cab driver to pick us up again in about 4 hours. The outskirts driving in didn't look as busy or as safe, so we stuck to Quinta.There are quite a few restaurants to try and shops to see - they even have a mall with larger brand name stores like Victoria Secret, Nike, etc. However, we spent about a good hour of our time at one of those booths where they sell excursions. They waved us over and we just wanted to compare prices with our hotel (btw, shop around because there are many excursion booths and prices may vary) but they took up a great deal of our browsing time because they were pretty aggressive about closing a sale and kept talking every time we tried to say we would come back later. They were nice, but it was a little annoying to have so much of our time taken up. In the end, we did purchase an excursion to Isla Mujeres, which I will review later.There's quite a bit to see on the street from restaurants to shops, massage places, and sports bars. The reason I only give it an average rating is because of all of the hustlers trying to get you to come over and talk to them or sell you something every few steps. We had one guy try to tell us he was our waiter from our resort the night before and to come talk to him and shake his hand. I've read in other posts that this is one of the scams they use to get you to talk to them. They look at the AI bands from your resort and automatically know you're a tourist and sometimes know which resort. If you don't go up to them, some of them will even go so far as to walk up to you. We even had one guy ask us if we wanted to buy cigars and when we said we didn't smoke, he offered us drugs or "nose candy". I understand these guys have to make a living, but these aggressive hustlers became pretty tiring and annoying to deal with after a while and that's why we never made a second trip to Quinta.Had dinner at Yaxche Mayan cuisine which was decent but overpriced. The prices on Quinta are only slightly lower than hotel prices for souvenirs and food wasn't cheap. Peeked at the massage prices and they were definitely lower than at the resorts, but the places looked a bit sketchy from the outside. If you have a chance, try the fish spa located at the front of the Wayan store across from Victoria Secret. It's actually just a couple of foot tubs at the entrance of the store, so don't look for a spa like we did. It's a neat experience and your feet feel so soft after :)It was pretty average experience, so unless I had a reason to come back to Quinta Avenida like partying at nightclubs or was accompanied by a local to show us around, I probably wouldnt' come back.
A bit overwhelming for a non shopper. If you are a shopper, you are sure to find something here. The prices though are a bit high compared to the rest of town.

Touristy but interesting. Fifth Avenue in Playa del Carmen is a typical touristy area. All the usual tourist shops interspersed with some high end boutiques. Just ignore all the vendors shouting at you from the sidelines and enjoy just being a tourist.

If you are looking for real Mexico this is not. My my the changes are drastic here on 5th ave in PDC. Now steel and glass malls, very few non tourist sights. We always avoided cruise ship ports because of that and now you have all of that and more here. If you read Trip Advisor you will find numerous places off of 5th ave that are tremendous value and excellent in quality. That means you may have to step out of your comfort level and explore off the beaten track but if you're reading this then there's a chance that you have it in you to do that.

THE OTHER FIFTH AVENUE. That is the title of a t-shirt i bought years agoHave down this street a thousand times in past 15 yearsIt is the heart of playa.......everything is available...........i mean EVERYTHING.......from fine dining to jewelry to cuban cigars(real and fake) to French bakery to Hugo Boss to NikeOk for family with kids, OK for the clubbing setI mean where else can you get this?

A complete tourist rip off!. We walked here one day from our hotel, it was about a 20 minute walk. The entire street is lined on both sides with kitschy souvenir shops selling pretty much the same things. The prices are over the top. The shop owners and staff are very aggressive. They see you wearing a hotel bracelet and bid you to come inside and browse. They hound you without mercy to buy, buy, BUY something! I hated it.The street also has a very seedy side to it as well. I lost count of the number of "massage parlors" we passed. We were approached on 2 occasions by men who told us they could offer us "drugs, women or anything illegal". Many shady characters are seen lurking in doorways and alleys, the police are every where.One can only imagine what this street is like at night!?The place was a nightmare and I felt very uncomfortable, constantly looking over my shoulder. Our visit was cut short after we had had enough, hoped into a taxi and went back to our hotel. One word of advice: Don't allow this tourist trap to prejudice your view of Mexico.

Exhilarating to say the least!. When you are on the Mayan Riviera and visiting Playa del Carmen, an integral part of your visit is to have a walk down 5th Avenue! You will encounter characters of all sort like Mayan warriors, fire dancers. You will hear a vast number of different languages as vacationers from around the world come to play. All the shop owners will vie for your attention "hey remember me? I'm your waiter at..." "I've got what you are looking for" "it's my turn to show you..." Pure entertainment!!

A very nice walk. 5th is a long pedestrian street in downtown "Playa". It's a must-see for all tourists. Actually it might be kind of difficult to avoid because that's where everything is (restaurants, clubs, art galleries). It's a nice walk with buildings that are not too tall and you can see the ocean from every corner (it's 2 blocks away from the avenue). It might be a little too-touristy for some, and after around 45 I minutes of everyone trying to sell me something, I got annoyed.

El Capitan Visits 5th Ave - Again. Oh yea - if you are in the Mayan Riviera, jump in a cab and head down to 5th Ave - at night. The street is lit up like Christmas every night with miles of shopping, outdoor cafes, bars, restaurants and some of the finest dining anywhere. Want a sports bar - try the End Zone. Are you a Habs fan - try La Tabernacos. Italian, Mexican, pizza, burgs - you name it you will find it on the Fabulous 5th Ave. For you night crawlers - try Coco Bongo. $50 bucks all you can drink and shows - a tremendous night out. DO NOT MISS 5th Ave.

so so. Typical sales street I guess. There are some really great restaurants there, and lots of the same old peddler shops. Beware that it's illegal to walk with a beer there--- I guess I'm just used to Cabo...

if you like to be hassled My friend this is the place for you!!. on the second day of our honeymoon, my wife and I decided to leave the resort and take in some of the scenery of the city. The cab ride was awesome into town, Cabbie drove like he stole it, not quite sure if it wasn't! My wife sat in the back with another couple as we drove down the busy streets. Once we stepped out of the cab, we went into one of the open stores to see what gifts we could bring back. I loved it my wife, on the other hand, felt overwhelmed with all the vendors. Walked down to the beach and everyone and their mother was offering to give massages. Enjoyed the scenic views and loved interacting with the people. Crossed one thing off my bucket list, I live in Texas and I listen to Big Al Mack on 106.1 Kiss fm, so I had to stop in and have a beer at Big Al's Beer Bucket.

Touristy and not to be missed!. Yes, this avenue is lined with tourist-traps. Yes, it is crowded and people call out to you to come look at the things they are selling. But there are also many amazing things to see, eat and watch. You shouldn't miss it! We went in the evenings and got to see a costumed Mayan dance troupe performing (with fire!) at the "beach stage" at the end of Avenida Quinta, another Mayan troupe swinging high overhead head-first on what looked like a giant "top" in the plaza, a man with a lemur on a leash (as my son said, "Just like King Julian from Madagascar!"), a number of monkeys on leashes, roaming mariachi bands, breakdancers - it's like an open-air carnival all night long on a huge pedestrian avenue (closed to cars)! The vendors we encountered were all very friendly and other than the usual precautions you'd take in any crowded place, we felt very safe and had a great time. Be sure to check out some of the shops as we found some lovely artisan shops "tucked in between" the many shops selling t-shirts and mini sombreros. You'll love it!

Fun. We enjoyed walking Fifth Avenue for the shopping and restaurants. While everyone asks you to enter their stores or restaurants, we did not get harassed when we said no. We've been to other shopping areas in Mexico where they would grab us or follow us to get us to change our minds. We felt very safe and relaxed as we walked. Because this street is app 4km long, we broke our walking into multiple days.

Safe any time of day...or night!. We have visited Playa several times and have enjoyed strolling down 5th Avenue at various times of the day and night. Even when there are no crowds, you can feel safe and enjoy the many shopping opportunities. While there are MANY bars and restaurants on the strip, choose wisely, as some will serve you only mediocre food, but charge you 5 star rates. Make sure at least one of your visits is at night, as the street comes alive when the sun goes down!!

Fifth Avenue: A Place for Dining, BarHopping, Shopping, and People-Watching. Fun, fun, fun!!! No visit to the Riviera Maya is complete without a night out on Fifth Avenue. Skip it during the stay; play at the beach. At night, play on Fifth Avenue. And be sure to dine at PLANK Restaurant just 1/2 block off Fifth Avenue on Calle 14, at Chez Celine Bakery on Fifth Avenue near Calle 28, and at Diez (Argentine Steakhouse in the Italian Zone on Fifth).

"Fun Street". I love the Quinta Avenida, its a great place to spend all day. You can go shopping, eat and drink at the nice restaurants, go to the famous beach Mamitas, and later in the nigh enjoy the fun night life.

Fun, busy, great shopping!. My husband and I really had fun shopping on 5th Avenue. We stayed at The Reef resort and we were able to walk to 5th down the beach (it's about 20-30 minutes). We felt safe there and there were many different stores. We even saw a native Mayan dance in the square! Just be prepared to say "No" many times because everyone wants you to visit their shop, buy their excursion, etc. and that part we did not care for. However, overall it was a great experience and we were able to purchase just about all our souvenirs from one shop! Some advice: if you can go after sunset because many places lower the prices after the cruise tourists leave!

Nice!. I love the Idea that is close to cars to allow pedestrians walk more confortable. Plenty of shops, restaurants, cafes, Ice-cream shops and massage spots. Also Is also easy to get a taxi in every corner.
Tacky. Characterless and full of shops selling tacky souvenirs. You get hassled by the traders as you walk past. I hated it.

Fun place to spend some time. took a walk on 5th avenue during one of our days on vacation. Fun place with lots to look at, some good places to eat (see other reviews), close to the beach. If you are looking for some souvenirs, this is the place to stop.Interesting I guess what I would call street performers in the square near the end by the ferry. These guys put on performance a few times a day and I'm not sure I would get used to doing what they do. See the pictures Recommended for something different.

Halloween a Blast. We were there a couple times but Halloween night was like a festival! Awesome! There is everything you could want to buy there- from tequila and t-shirts to bathing suits and high end makeup. Even a Victoria Secret! Some quaint little restaurants and bars. Great people watching!
Ready to walk. Just great to go after the beach. If you want a beer, a snack, souvenirs and some fun... Go to Quinta Avenida!!

Fabulous 5th Ave. Fabulous 5th Ave, the heart of Playa Del Carmen. It's so much to stroll 5th, enjoy a glass of wine and people watch plus great restaurants and shops on 5th avenue.... A must do when vacationing in playa.

Everything for everyone. From the most posh to the most casual. Careful of what we term the street whisperers...they offer everything illegal by USA standards in most places. Just say no thanks when approached, otherwise it's a risk.

Fifth Avenue a Huge Open Mall. There is so much to see and do in and around Playa del Carmen. But 5th Avenue is a must when staying in the Riviera Maya or in Playa del Carmen. If you ever need something or just want to go people or window watching, then 5th Ave is the right place for it. Fifth Avenue is a long pedestrian street that extends like a huge open Mall, along 20 street blocks in parallel to Playa del Carmen´s Central Beach. Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue) is an evening must for walking about for the finest shopping and activities throughout the Riviera Maya. You get a countless variety of restaurants, coffee shops, jewelries, Duty Free perfumes, apparel stores, beach wear, Arts and crafts and more. Additionally you can also access Bars and night clubs

What a great place!. Stroll in the evening for blocks! Stumble upon some fantastic meals, bars, shops, people!! Even though we stayed at an "all inclusive" we ate here almost every night. How could we resist - GREAT dining on 5th Avenue. We walked down the Avenue Halloween night - oh my gosh - the cutest little kids you've ever seen all decked out in costume and painted face 'trick or treating' - so fun! This Avenue has the 'feel' of a Bourbon Street in Nola or the strip in Las Vegas WITHOUT the nasty part. Was very family friendly and I liked that. Don't miss! Go in the day AND in the evening so you can see the lights - completely different during the day and night.

Lively and Entertaining. I like Quinta Avenida because it has a lot of different restaurants and I could choose a fancy restaurant or a taqueria. It offers a lot options for entertaining or shopping. There are a lot of good night clubs too. People could simply go for a walk ... it is a long avenue. It is also very safe.
Tourists trap with boom-boom music. Perfect for those who are not interested into local experience but are into mainstream nightlife and western shops.

Well.... It's the only place to go (after the beach) in Playa... Good for strolling and eating, but the gift shops are very very poor, offering only items of bad taste and low quality. And I hated the way they try to "grab" you on the street ....very "pushy"....the vendors should really reconsider this way of imposing themselves over people. It's very disagreable. I think they underestimate the kind of tourists they receive (people with higher standards, not used to this way of abordage)

worth visiting for the interesting experience in spite of pushy vendors. Whether you are out for serious shopping or not, this is a worthwhile street to spend some time on. The vendors are pushy. If you are prepared for that, however, that shouldn't ruin the experience. We really enjoyed seeing the overwhelming variety of goods for sale as well as the incredible people watching. There are things to do besides shopping as there are many restaurants. We can't speak to the authenticity or value of the goods offered for sale because we didn't buy anything here. We also went during the day and while apparently, there is great energy at night, the energy and atmosphere during the day was pretty high as well. If we're in Playa del Carmen again, we would probably choose to visit again.
Shopping zone. Quinta Avenida, it's the shopping area, you can find great places to eat, bars, coffee shops, buy tours and many things more!

Pushy but Lots to Choose From. During our stay in Playa we checked out 5th Avenue daily. There are so many fun things to see and eat and buy. My big complaint is that many vendors are very pushy. I would rather browse on my own time and not be subjected to the pushiness.
shopping. variety of shops, something for everyone, places to eat and get drinks everywhere, easily accessible

Just not my thing.... If you like constantly being accosted as you walk past each and every store, and each and every vendor, then this is the place for you. We were told we could find mariachi music, but we only saw three men dressed in mariachi outfits, and they were walking, not playing. The street is lined with stores offering cheap and cheesy merchandise. Had I known, I would have skipped it.

Don't go. Buy at the airport or hotel. Couldn't walk 5 feet without being accosted. Everyone worked at your hotel, or so they said. We didn't have to wear bracelets so it was a little harder. Don't be fooled. Stay away and shop at the airport or hotel

Shoppers paradise. loved 5th avenue, had shops for everyone.You have to know how to barter in the smaller shops or you will pay a very high price for your items, can feel a bit intimidated as we are not used to this. Loved all the different bars and restaurants, the general feel of the place. Came alive at night and was nice to sit at a bar and people watch, from the young girls wearing shoes that they could not walk in, to thelocals walking their dogs.For those of you who miss 'junk food' there is even a Macdonalds

Joyeria Ruby is a rip-off. My son purchased a "silver" chain and my husband got a "gold" crucifx. Each purchase was a little over $200.00. When we got home we noticed that both were fake. There are several jewelry stores on the 5a. On our AMEX statement, it only read Joyeria Ruby as the merchant. Be careful. If you want jewelry go to reputable jeweler. You just never know.

Quinta Avenida - Go at night. We liked the people-watching, the shopping and we drank at a bar that had swings instead of chairs. The only disappointment are the barkers trying to get you to buy their time-shares, as well as the prices for trinkets and drinks aren't what they used to be in Mexico.

Oldies enjoying themselves. 5th Avenue is 2 minutes walk from Playacar Palace Hotel. Worth a visit for a walk and window shop. The hassle you get is quite tame compared to Turkey or Tunisia. Just tell them NO Gracias politely and keep walking.

Fun and Local. Don't walk here alone ladies, unless you love to be approached constantly. But it's really fun and lively, there are lots of people around and I always felt safe, but yes you will be approached a lot to buy or try or sign up for tours- can get old but the shops are really fun to see and the variety is excellent. If you need souvenirs or want to get away from your squeaky clean hotel bar, check this place out!

Great fun - day or night!. Traveled with my husband and 20 year old daughter. Street was clean and safe feeling, day or night. Yes, we were harassed by vendors constantly, but we just smiled and laughed and had fun with it. We said "no gracias" a million times, but it was all good. There were so many great restaurants to choose from, we never ran out of options. We also loved stopping by Ah Cacao (incredible chocolate mousse!) and Chez Celine (delicious dessert crepes!) for dessert after dinner in the evenings.We were saddened and disappointed by the numerous vendors exploiting small animals (usually monkeys) by trying to get people to take pictures with them for tips. So wrong for these poor animals to be subjected to spending hours on end being used in that way. The best way to put an end to it is for people to refuse to support it and by not paying these people.On the other hand, we enjoyed seeing the local dog rescue people out walking adoptable dogs each night and raising awareness for their great cause.All in all, 5th avenue is great fun!

Shopping, Food, Fun. There is a little bit of everything at La Quinta Avenida. I was only two miles from the RIU Yucatan and had local shops as well as international chains. There were many local restaurants to choose from and also a Senor Frogs, McDonald's and Burger King. There were shopping malls and local market stands. If you haven't found it yet, keep walking and you will. There are taxi's available on every corner to take you back to your hotel when you're ready. Never felt unsafe.
Tourist Area, but nice. Gets expensive, but is fun. Lots of shops and restaurants/bars to choose from. Good deals can be found if you look.

Great to walk without fear of traffic. What a nice walk to experience not only local culture, but also many great little restaurants like 100% Natural, or Green Box. Dessert and coffee joints line up the whole stretch. It stretches to almost 40 little blocks, and hence takes at least an hour of leisurely stroll. Apparently the most visited street in Mexico.
Bad place to visit. Lots of people that want to make you buy. They treat everyone like they are rich and think you can buy anything.
Meh. It wasn't anything special to my boyfriend and I. A lot of the same types of shops selling souvenirs. I did get to take a picture with a monkey though! That alone was worth it.
A can't miss!. This long strip of shops and bar and restaurants are very lively. We were lucky to have seen a wedding procession with mariachi.

Souvenir Nightmare. This town lost its charm in the last 6 years. I assume Mexico's difficult economic situation continues to turn many locals into desperados, visitors are pestered step by step as one strolls through this souvenir haven.
Villages further down the coast are in development. If you enjoy quaint village settings head to those before its too late.
Nice street to stroll and shop.. About 8-10 blocks of restaurants, shops, bars. Some pretty good restaurants and a few good crafts shops too.

New scam. Be aware of the new scam. While we were walking down the street, a local approached us and greeted us friendly. Said that he worked at the resort where we were staying and that day was his day off. He took us to his "family business" which turned out to be a jewelry store off the main street. None of our friends had met this guy before, though he had made us believe we had. Be aware!

5th Avenue. Lot's of shopping, and restaurants. Lot's of people trying to separate you from your money! Be careful of the time share scams, and people trying to steer you into stores. Overall, enjoyable! See it during the day, and then at night for a totally different perspective (FIESTA at night).
5ta Avenida!. 5ta Avenida in Playa del Carmen. Great selections of restaurants, bars, shopping,beach.... highly recomended!!!!

5th ave. La Quinta Avenida or 5th Ave was a small and comfortable strip where tourist visiting near by can safely explore and grab Mexican souvenirs or a quick bite to eat/drink. We were able to cheaply get a taxi ride there a few times on our trip to buy trinkets or get food. The food was decent and ranged in all types and prices. What I would say is if you look like a tourist locals may be subject to change or edit pricing for you. Either way some of the handmade crafts or items they sell might be worth it depending on what you are looking for. The only reason I am not giving this area the 5th star is because the sales people can become overwhelming at times and lose track of realizing when no means no. Overall a great area to visit if you want to feel like exploring Mexico and mingling with the people.
Great people watching. Good bargains to be had. Many, many restaurants. upscale shops as well as bargain shops. I have bought much jewelry through out the last few years.

Go slightly off the main street. Aggressive peddlers. Go off the Main Street for local shops w/o pressure. Riviera May art shop was great and no pressure. Siette detalles was great for hand made pottery

Busy fun and plenty haggling to be done. We we're up here quite a bit.. everyone trying to get you into the shops sell you anything.. literally.Always try there luck with prices etc but always room too haggle. Fun street very busy ;)

No use in being rude!. I've been to Playa del Carmen for the past 5 years. Last year for 3 weeks and this year, we'll be staying a month! Got to say that we live away from the 5th, generally around the 38th and 46th street north close to the beach. There are lots of good restaurants before you hit the pedestrian hassle. If you do want to get to the other side, take to the 1st avenue by the 32nd street that gets you all the way to the 10th street. A peaceful and quite walk that may even bring surprises... a great wine store, a few nice restaurants, Impreviste, just to name one, but most of all, no hassling vendors! There is also the 10th avenue that is parallel to the 5th all the way long. It is a bit dark at places and you have to watch your step a few places. But you can find nice spots also.The fifth avenue does get to be quite nerve racking after a few days but that's where the people are. It is an endless venue of identical shops and restaurants. You've seen one you've seen them all. A bit of diversity would be welcome! But it is useless in being rude to these people who are just trying to make a living for their families. It is easier to just smile and say no gracias and continue on your way without stopping. If you do stop, well that opens a door to more insisting and hassling! Smile, wave, that's all it takes! Think of your next day at the beautiful beach!

Tourist traps and chain stores. It took us a lot of stores filled with similar goods, probably produced in China and stamped Made in Mexico, to find a handful of authentic Mexican artistry. It was a lot of fun bargaining though, and I ended up getting pretty good at it! My advice is buy a few collector pieces instead of a bunch of junk. Haggle hard and stick to your price, yet show genuine interest in both the goods and the seller. Have fun, but don't get trapped!

It is OK. I liked the diversity of people visiting the place and restaurants around the area along with the shopping plazas. I did not like that the Jewellery merchants try to scam you by selling you non genuine silver as genuine silver. Be careful with that, if you decide to buy on the streets for silver; make sure the merchant test the jewel before you so you can see if it is genuine. If you are not convinced; DON'T BUY IT.

Touristy downtown. There are some nice things to be purchased at decent prices if you have the patience to go through lots of stores and the sales pitches and haggling. It's a nice walk with a mix of local flavor and international chains - you just need to accept the active recruting into the stores and the haggling as part of the local culture!
Must not miss.... Shopping of all types, all prices,good food sometimes expensive. You can just sit and watch...take one or two trips around to choose your restaurant and store.

Be Prepared to get Bombarded by Vendors. What a shame that the ministry of tourism can't control the continuous bombardment of these people trying to sell you stuff. It was such a turn off in such a nice looking place. Some of these guys were following my wife and I from store to store, even though we told them in english and spanish no thank you....we must have said those words what seemed to be at least 200 times a day. Had a couple of them follow us a block and a half trying to sell Time Shares and Tours. I will never come back here again because of that problem and also that the prices on all of the stuff they were selling was WAY TOO HIGH....Started off the day we arrived at the bus station on 5th ave.I needed a pair of sun glasses and when i was told $20 USD that's when i knew we were in for a bumpy ride.I can get these same glasses at the Dollar Tree for 1.00 I know these people need to make some money but it's Crazy with the extreme mark up's. They should lower them down since it's the slow season.
5th avenue the main street. nice place to chill and watch folks. food is better in the other streets. also better shops past 22nd street.
good for shopping. a stroll on 5th is also a must , great for buying those memories for the loved ones , have to stop at coco bongo for the shows

Nice time but haggle. Shops were fun and colorful and full of anything you could want. Workers will ask absurdly high amounts to settle for a lot lower prices, except the bigger stores they are like the walmarts of 5th ave.

Great shopping and fun!. My family and I spent the early part of the day exploring and shopping on 5th Avenue. For the most part the stores all sell the same thing, price difference minimal. If you are there in the daytime and are just looking to buy some souvenirs and grab a bite then this is the place for you. The only downside is the constant sound of people trying to offer you the "best deal" which is actually way overpriced. As long as you say no thank you and keep walking they will move on to the next group of people. I only spent one evening on 5th and it is quite lively. They were offering free salsa lessons at one of the restaurants. There is music and fun all around. If you want something more quite and laid back it suggest coming in the early morning or afternoon.

Good for suvenires. Full of life, bars, restaurants, shops and travel agencies but it's very hard to pass quitely and take your time as every single seller is trying to grab your attention and sell you anything.

not so great. Souvenir shops all have the same merchandise, at the same price. Yes, a bit cheaper than your resort shopping center, but if you don't buy much, and add taxi fare, you don't get any discount. Ice cream parlor charging ice cream by weight (!!!) so we ended up paying $16 for 2 ice cream cones, that's a joke. Very busy, timeshare vendors all the way. Nice buildings for a photo opportunity.

Annoying and fake. This street is terrible. You can't walk two yards without some barker trying to get your attention... sometimes in a very rude way. E.g. Barker: "hey, why don't you buy your girlfriend XYZ?!" My reponse: "no, thanks." Barker: "oh, she isn't worth it huh." Every other store is the same, selling trinkets, booze, and the same fridge magnets you saw 500 times. The rest is just bars which you can find in any city in the US. The beach isn't great either, with the water much murkier than the less busy beaches.There's nothing here that interested me at all.

horrible place. i went here with my 2 daughters 24 and 15. we went in at night because it is too hot by day. we could not go into any shops as the vendors were so harrassing. they would shadow you in the shop so you had no peace whatsoever. also guys on the street asking did we want a mexican boyfriend for the night, so that was it, we left. i would go back to mexico but never to quinta avenida.

Recommended. You really can't go to Playa del Carmen and not visit the famous Quinta Avenida. There are so many stores, local and foreign. Make sure you take Bargaining 101 before you visit though! You can easily get cheated as store owners will sell you something for double the price.

Trip to. I like shopping in Quinta Avenida because you can find from jewelry stores to artcraft stores and also restaurants. If you go at night there are Mariachis on the street ready to take a picture with the tourists.

Annoying at times. Mainly residents at times their walking dogs are overwhelm. Way too manny. Wish there was a rule against it. Although very nice the newly constructed shopping mall (told belongs to the riches men "Mr Slim) extremely expensive. There is no bargains that all any place in whole Mexico. Very very expensive. All parks. Very high. So much x vacations here in Mexico.

Must see. Really colourful and fun but a tad overpriced. It's nice to walk and see, you'll find a cigar shop where you can see the maestro making and rolling the cigars in front of you or people painting and making jewellery, you can buy a coconut to drink as you stroll down the many shops. Some good shopping and lots of bars and restaurants also lots of people soliciting and trying to sell you all sorts of stuff. If you need less touristy stuff stick to the 30 or the 10
Loved It. loved this street, everything you need is here, shopping, dinning entertainment, accommodations very good vibe

The border between good and bad. A very interesting avenue that lies on the crossroads of east, west, north and south of Playa del Carmen. When you cross the road going west, you will find many artisinal shops, small restaurants and the biggest attraction: Raines, a restaurant with Cuban live music, performed by Cubans only. They are so good that really get hooked on it.

A nice place for evening stroll. We've gradually watched this place change. Shopkeepers didn't used to harass customers but they seem to do that now. Just a firm no thank you and avoid eye contact seems to do the trick. It's got a great atmosphere in the evenings and if you can catch a day when locals are doing sand sculptures or have some kind of celebration it makes for great photography opportunities! Yes it has got a lot more westernised, but still has some interesting little shops and it's a good place to buy those holiday gifts to take home. I've never felt threatened there and have always enjoyed trying the various bars and cafés. Much better than the huge shopping centres in cancun.

Nice walk in town. Nice walk in town. Lots of shopping and restaurants. Please note the shop owners heckle you to visit their store, just say no thanks and keep walking. We stopped at Kool Beach for the day, this was a lot of fun.

Shopping, lunch and massages. My girlfriend and I spent half a day on Quinta Avenida (I wish we could've spent more time). Treat yourself to a massage ($30 USD for an hour). We had lunch at La Vagabunda. Two appetizers shared will make a great lunch for two people. We found an amazing Mexican Fire Opal ring for her at Genesis Jewelers. Go meet "Coco", the man who runs the shop. Be prepared for lots of haggling but a shopping experience as well. They bring you everything you could want to stay "just a little longer" and shop some more! Bottled waters, custom-selected music, seats and then's there's Coco, the jeweler showman! Sure, you might spend a few bucks extra, even after lengthy haggling, but its a fun way to pick up a great memory and souvenir!

Lovely shops. It was so much fun! Lovely shops and not so expensive shopping.The only place where you can get typical Mexican crafts for reasonable prices. The little restaurants and taverns are worth visiting too. It feels safe, but don't be too relaxed about your handbag.

People Watching. 5TH ave has so many people walking from all over the world, Playa Del CArmen is a true international destination with people from all over visiting. 5Th ave has restauranmts, bars, clubs and great shopping

Quinta Avenue. Liked the variety of shops and prices. But watch out for some of the shopkeepers who border on being obnoxious when you don't stop to visit their shop, They hurl insults at you both in English and Spanish.

"Horrible place, not the real face from Mexico". You can find everything here, like shops, MCdonals, Starbucks and so on...People - shop workers - are very agressive, make you comments, want to sell there stuff, uneducated, really stupid people. Some of them have some animals, which has nothing, absolutly NOTHING to do with mexico, they want to make you a picture with those pure animals, 16 hours working non stop for a feew US. DONT DO IT!

Nice place. Many options for everybody, a lot of places to go to have a drink, restaurants, shops, nothing spectacular, but really nice place. The best is the beach at the beginning/endIt's better go at late afternoon or night because during the day the sun is sooo shiny!

awesome parties. party till sunrise, boom! lots of bars in this area open till sunrise, definitely recommend it!If you're in Playa del Carmen please hangout here you won't regret it.. till the morning maybe ;)

Party till you drop!. To have a good time go early and leave early. After 3 am the environment is crazy, a lot of drunk people on the streets, people get obnoxious and agressive. Be careful the people you meet and always stay safe
Quinta Avenida PC. It is good to have some fun, the range of cost change from one place to another but near to the beach it is cheeper

You can find everything here.... Quinta Avenida was just a very short ride by taxi from our hotel, The Viva Wyndham Maya Resort It is a mix of new shopping establishments as well as the old market-like stalls where you can buy more local products. Here you can also catch a ferry to Cozumel island. There were so many things to see & buy. Hubby & I ended up at a jewelry store which was owned by a Chinese-Filipino and bought some nice silver pieces. Unfortunately, we were not able to try some local restaurants in the area (except for Starbucks) but I am sure that the food there would be outstanding, just like the other eateries that we've tried.
Great Avenue for a Night Stroll.. It is really being redeveloped with lots of new high-end shopping and eating establishments. It is coolest in the evening and the atmosphere is always energetic!

Intimidating!. Lots of high street style retailers as well as souvenir shops and bars/restaurants - good choice. Every street corner there was someone trying to lure you in to their shop, give you 'best price' or sell you an excursion. Got a little bit intimidating - too many bodies, too much noise/hustle n bustle for me. Some sellers just would not accept no for an answer. Did not suit me, but I'm sure that shopaholics and nightlife fans would like it.
An unforgettable place. I loved this place, specially at night, you can see people walking down the street from so many countries, many places to have dinner.

A Playa Del Carmen "Tradition" ~. There are things I like and dislike about "La Quinta" ~ however, many tourists tend to overreact to vendors on this avenue. First of all, speaking Spanish is helpful, as well as a good attitude. I only go there when I have something I specifically want to buy. I live in Mexico part time and know the system ~ a bit of playful banter goes a long way. I always let the vendors know I live in Mexico and don't need a ring, bag, shot of tequila, etc., but I will stop and chat with a few along my way. I love the amber shop ~ have been buying pieces from them for years, never pushy and great selection. Yes, there are tons of souvenir shops ~ obviously people keep them in business. Some are very tacky. There are also some very unique shops, like the little shop that sells all things heart shaped. There are some decent restaurants and hotels still, but I wouldn't want to be in the midst of all the chaos. The avenue now has a lot of big chains, such as Starbucks, Burger King, Victoria's Secret, MAC cosmetics, etc., which had really changed the vibe. It's something to do ~ if it's offensive to you, catch a cab and leave. Please do not participate in the tourist attractions that exploit wild animals, such as having your photo taken with a little monkey or iguana. This creates an imbalance in nature and many of these animals end up sick or dying from being over handled or feed inappropriate foods. Take Quinta Avenida with a grain of salt ~ have a look ~ but the beaches out of the main area are much cleaner and prettier.

5th Ave. in Playa. There is no way you can come this close to Playa and not go to 5th Ave. This is by far one of the best locations to people watch in Playa. There are people from all over the world here. No matter where you are from, you will be able to make new friends. Just keep your ears open for someone speaking your language and strike up a conversation. Works every time for me! If you are looking for a deal on trinkets and souvenirs, get away from 5th and go into the heart of the city. Same goods at 1/2 the price!

Walk the Camino. lots of shops. between Calle 1 and 28 T shirt shops and Jaladors (Barkers), but it quiets down between 30 and 40, which has some nicer shops, restaurants, good prices, less Spring breakish

Great blvd to visit.. A lot of shops,restaurants,bars to check it out.....Cigars shops, massage shops are shipper here than at any hotel( I sow signs that saids 70 minutes massages for 20-25.00 dollars. Don't know if they come with happy endings .... Lol.)Great place to see the culture of this beautiful town in the Yucatan peninsula .

Everything under the sun!. Loved this area. Unique, great restaurants as well as unique shops from the simple trinkets to the over the top luxury brand items is what makes it so much fun. Your eyes will not get a rest here as there is so much to see and do.
great time. I loved the morning walks to do excercise and drink a coffee. food is super expensive do not eat their do not recommend it. But for young people by all means go for it alot of drinking..
Good walk.. Bring some comfy shoes and lot of money, because its a long walk and you will want everything, you can find the cheapest to the fanciest.
Very Expensive. Very Nice Liked the streets. Lots to see and to buy money its what you need. With kids its kind of hard to walk; very crowed.
THE place to be!. Mandala, La Vaquita, Glass Wine Bar, El Diablito, Coco Bongo...fantastic! Love the shops especially Soho Boutique!!
funny. Chez Celine & Yaxche best in town. La vaca gaucha expensive and poor quality. Señor frogs if you get there by sunset forget the atention.

Eh, cool if you like Bourbon St or Times Square. Not for me.. My large group of 10 decided to spend the day on 5th Ave. It wasn't my cup of tea, although some in my group really enjoyed it. It was a long long stretch of really similar tourist souvenirs and cheesy bars. We didn't see a lot that was unique or well-crafted, or perhaps we didn't know where to look. It was also about a million degrees outside, and I was tired of people shouting at me and offering my husband coke. I'd skip it.

Nice area, nice stores. We took a trip over to this shopping district from our resort. I had read reviews and was not expecting much. What a nice little area this is! We found some great little shops and some very good bargains. The one larger store we visited was offering tequila tastings and was quite enjoyable. It is Westernized to some extent, and we even hit the Starbucks. We were there on a Thursday morning and enjoyed leisurely shopping and and enjoyable time. We felt quite safe and did allow our older teens to explore on their own. I'm sure the nightlife is much more exciting, but for a few hours of shopping it was perfect. There were lots of nice restaurants and cafes but we did not visit any. The prices seemed reasonable. We'd visit again for sure!
Playa Culture. The shopping scene in Playa Del Carmen. In the evneing there is a "trapeze" act in the square. There are many shops, and bargain hunting, or "arguing" is necessary.
Must go!. Long avenue with restaurants, stores, nightlife, close to the beach. Liked lot, will be back for sure.

Convenient shopping. Like the fact this area was a 5 min walk from our resort, the Playacar Palace with many different items to choose from. Lots of items made right there in Mexico. Felt safe while shopping there, didn't like how the vendors tried to get you to come look at their goods by saying,"remember me, I was your waiter last night." They know which resorts you stay at by the color of your band. Overall a good experience with any different choices of goods. I regret not buying an authentic sombrero on 5th ave for $16, they were $47 at the airport!

Pedestrian-only avenue. 5th Ave runs parallel to the beach one block in and is a great avenue to stroll with lots of other tourists with lots of bars, restaurants, galleries and shops. A little of everything and a great stroll that runs about 20 blocks from the ferry docks north. A bit touristy but for good reason...enjoyable.

Disneyland--only free. Fifth Avenue is Playa is a thousand beckoning attractions calling to thousands of happy people at once. It is a place filled with young people and families, a free market of earnest merchants meeting a throng of carefree vacationers. This is a place where you will feel completely safe--from traffic (pedestrians only) and from thieves--it is well patrolled and the merchants are honest.

Lot of restaurants: One to avoid!! and one to try!!. We liked a lot la Quinta. There are so many rest to choice and very good. One must try for breakfast is Chef Celine. The coffee is wonderful and the baguettes are awesome. They serve a breakfast combo for $8 US that comes with everything, including fresh juice, eggs, and coffee. Try also the ginger and mint lemonade. On the other hand: one rest to AVOID is Lucky Luciano since they have a very uncommon and risky practice that can end in identity thief : this is: when a customer pay with credit card they ask for an id and they (without your consent) write down all you drivers license or passport information (#, your name, address etc.). When we notice that they wrote down all of our personal information we ask them to void the transaction and explain that this was illegal, but they refuse since that was a management requirement. This is completely absurd and this practice is illegal. You should show your id to validate your identity but they can not keep all your information, THIS IS A VERY RISKY PRACTICE for you as customer...please avoid this place. What if someone take that receipt? The only 2 things needed to stole you identity is an id number and your name. Even if you pay in cash this place is not worthy. And I will not sponsor a restaurant with this practices.

Typical Mexican tourist junk. It's the typical T-shirt, souvenir peddling shops. This year everyone wanted to sell massages-this varies from year to year. There are a few very good restaurants. This year's new addition was a shopping "mall" with some US stores.
Fun times.. Quinta Avenida is a must do at PDC, fun times, cool bars. safe place. If your there during the day make sure you're ready for the heat.

Love it.............. ...........but after 2 weeks it can get very tiresome. I love the vibrant holiday atmosphere and the bars for people watching but the constant harassment seems to be getting worse. Several times it's gone beyond banter and got quite nasty this visit, with one taxi driver even asking my husband if he wants to fight him! We've been coming to Playa for a few years but I think the love affair is getting slightly jaded.

A nice change from the resort. We really enjoyed our trip to 5th avenue in Playa Del Carmen. We can only review it for what we experienced, which was about 3 hours in the afternoon, and we didn't have time to stop at a restaurant.It's certainly an area looking to grab tourist dollars, but Mexico-touristy is a lot different than Canada/US-touristy, so we found it interesting. Lots of shop employees outside the shop trying to convince you to come see their various trinkets, which is a style of business a lot of travelers to this area of Mexico should be familiar with (they pressure, barter, try to get your attention, etc.). We had no problem saying no to them, and we weren't harassed in any way when we did.There was a lot of the sort of kitschy non-unique souvenir stuff, but also some nice stuff and interesting attractions along the way (I'll review them if those individual stores appear on Tripadvisor). We didn't bother with the stores that also appear frequently in Canada/US. I imagine it would be super busy in the evening, but possibly a lot of fun, too. If you usually stick to resorts, as we had, we highly recommend 5th avenue as a break from the resort with a touch of culture, but by no means off the beaten path.

Kind of underwhelming. Can only comment on the daytime scene, as we were not there at night. Just a lot of stores looking to sell souvenirs and some were pretty high-priced. Not so many great restaurant options. Extremely hot during the afternoon and not so many air-conditioned places to enter.

Very Busy - lots of variety. When we were at the Riu Palace, we often took a walk into town and fifth avenue, is a must for shopping, booking day trips, sight seeing, or ever a wonderful massage, You can check out the ocean from this side, take a ride to Cozumel(found this out too late) or have a meal should you wish a change from the resort. It was a short 15 minute walk from our resort but it was nice to do this especially after one of the meals of the day which leaves you quite full and in need of some exercise.You will find many flea market style shops and all the specialty stores you wish, and if you are missing your coffee, yes a starbucks (no timmies for us Canadians though!!). There are a lot of bed and breakfasts that you can rent in town and we just might do this another time. Lots of fun, lots of people, and of course, lots of annoying sales people. You just say no and move on. There is a quant church and in the square some entertainment. Prices are reasonable, especially in the flea market type stores and you will also find the bus station right there if you are coming in from the airport and have a b and b booked.If you get tired, the taxi ride back is a simple 5-7 dollars.

Always Fun!. Quinta Avenida is a great place to shop and eat while you are at the beach.We travel with a family...ranging in age from 72 to 14...We got to Playa at about 9:00...paid for parking just off Quinta...and searched one of the many choices for breakfast.After eating, we secured a spot at one of the local beach clubs (about the middle of the beach) and spent a couple hours eating and swimming.Back to Quinta for shopping...Pretty good range of shops from outlet stores to trinkets. A ton of vendors trying to sell...but none were intrusive.Try the foot massage with the fish. Found this in a couple different areas...A unique experience.I would recommend going to Quinta for a fun time!
Exciting experience. Everyone looking to have good time. Don't miss Mayan Dancers at main square. There is never enough time to have a feeling of everything.

More like a 3.5/5 stars. They want those tourist dollars. It is extremely touristy, and many will call out to you to come in and look or buy their products. And if you're east asian, automatically assume you're either from China or Japan.Everyone had the look in their eyes that says "come, money, come".Well, thinking about it this is a developing country. But overall didn't sit too well with me. It does have some things to offer so it isnt all bad. Worth a quick visit if you have the free time though.

The heart of the city. We had a hotel right near this area and this area is exactly where you need to be. The shopping closes down at night at all the bars and clubs open but during the day all you shoppers eat your heart out. All the souvenirs you would need for the family as well as maybe a little something for yourself. This area is right next to the beach so you can go right to the beach before or after your shopping.

Nothing new. Playa del Carmen is a newer city. It doesn't have the nice old downtown of Puerto Vallarta. Lots of restaurants and shops. I prefer exploring. It feels like a tourist trap. But worth going at least once

Where is the good food?. For what I could tell, it is very hard to get a "town" experience near Playa. The whole coast is comprised of gated resorts, so this street was the default place to go when we wanted to leave our hotel. I had a few meals along it and they were all terrible. I couldn't find any ethnic mexican food; was hoping for panuchos de cochinita pibil, chilaquiles, pozole, menudo, or at the very least decent tacos al pastor. I kept eating americanized tacos, which suck. I won't go back if I can help it.

a TIP for buying a souvenir ?!?!!. The street itself is nice and attractive, with wide selection of shops and restaurants to satisfy any taste. I wouldn't say shopping is nearly ''great'' - unless you are have to kill time or just haven't seen anything better than Quinta Avenida(I'm not talking about souvenir shopping here) I found it average at the beginning of the trip,( US spoils when it comes to shopping) after the second day, my husband and I were simply scared to go there( our hotel was a minute walk away and didn't include meals,and booking it we knew we would have a wide selection of restaurants nearby and were exited to try something new every day) anticipating the battle with the vendors ''Amigo, where are you from?",restaurant hosts, DISGUISTINGLY pushy.By the way most food is overpriced for the quality served and the waiters are trying to up sell you in the funniest most ridiculous ways ,thinking you are really really stupid.They expect tips in some places where tips are already included in the bill,but the worst case was when we were buying a tribal mask: after negotiating the price from 50$ US to 15$ my husband handed the vendor a 20$ bill, we were waiting for the change and the vendor didn't hurry...his wife was watching us,she opened her mouth in a big surprise and said : "What, NO TIP?!?" General impression of the Quinta is - terrible,just because of this ''hunt the tourist'' attitudes, more pushy than I've ever seen.We were being attacked every day of our week long vacation,I wish I stayed in all inclusive hotel and didn't have to go explore ''a little piece of Mexico''

Fun For Tourists. Doesn't matter what day of the week you walk through Quinta Avenida, it will be bustling with people and shops. There are some great eats and the normal chain restaurants. I went to this wonderful hippie kind of shop and got a foot spa treatment for 30 mins where the little fish nibble at the dead skin (sounds weird but a fun experience). There is also wifi available throughout provided by Mastercard. There are also some benches throughout the avenida for a quick rest.

quinta avenida. a tourist trap! lots of vendors hawking their wares! some good, some cheap, some not so cheap. buyers beware! good place to watch people and quite near the beach.walking the entire avenida was an experience. bought lots of souvenirs. did not feel unsafe at all. one must at least visit this while in playa del Carmen.
