Great Shopping. Lots of choices, good prices/service. Most restaurants are good.Watch sanitary procedures of food service operators

Nice shopping, restaurant, bars and, of course, the beach!. Quinta Avenida offers the best from the city of Playa del Carmen; a nice combination of restaurants, bars, shopping, and beautiful beach in a 3-mile stretch. Definitely not to be missed.

Either by day or by night, Quinta Avenida has a magic vibe!. This Avenue is the heart of the city, and there's no such place anywhere else!Definitely a MUST during your visit to Playa del Carmen. You can walk through it, either by day or by night and you'll see endless of attractive places; from restaurants, stores, handcrafts and hotels, you name it. By the way, it has a remarkable nightlife as well.

Busy shopping area. This is a busy tourist area full of shops selling a variety of items. Some shops are regular stores with clothes, watches, etc. and air conditioning. Others are cheap stalls selling jewelry, souvenirs, knock off sunglasses, etc. The people will harass you a bit in the street to try and get you to come into their shop. A few of them were waiters at our hotel and were very pushy trying to get us to come in their shop, one was even rude and aggressive. I would suggest coming here at the end of your vacation so your waiter isn't mad at you for your whole stay.

Good if you are going shopping. This place is good if you feel the need to shop, and expensive shopping. Much better to shop in Isla Mujeres or even in Cancun downtown. I was expecting a much nicer place, but what you get is a lot of people begging for you to purchase, not very nice. We did find good food, but that's about it.
it was so beautiful and safe. we ate at restaurants on Quinta Avenida every night and it was wonderful to invite the mariachis over for a song.

Commercial Place. If you are looking for a place where you can get to know better the food and people of the area this is not the place. This is a commercial Place. Its a good place to go for a walk and drink. You find a lot of American stores in the area. Prices for a lot of the things are 3 times more then the prices from the plaza from the city. We had lunch at Adelas a two story restaurant at quinta avenida. Great food and service. The price was reasonable taking into account the location. We recommend this place specially since their where other restaurants with same type of food for 3 times the price. Their are ATM's all around so you can withdraw money. If you want to walk into the bank and withdraw money make sure you take your passport because you wont be able withdraw without it. The beach is like 2 blocks away in case you want to walk to it.

Mardi-Grass in July?. Waves and waves of tourists and locals walked this wonderful place to sit down and watch the people go by. An amazing experience lived only at La Quinta Avenida the year round Mardi-Grass experience.
nightmare and sleazy. only walked a few hundred yards and was offered drugs ,prostitutes etc avoid the women in our group felt very intimidated beggars coming up asking for money

Aggressively commercial. I understand it's how local retailers make a living, but does it work? I'd guess no. Lunging into the street and interrupting conversations can only make a negative impression.
There's supposed to be wifi for much of the strip, but that didn't work.
After a day or two of healthy paranoia faded, it does feel very safe, however.
shopping. can't say you were in cancun without shopping on 5ta avenida in playa del carmen, great deals on quality stuff. don't forget to haggel, its a mexican tradition.

Hippie, Bohemian but very comercial. I think is very crowded (Good or bad, It all depends) but pleasant to walk it, You have all kind of stores and mexican markets so you Don't have to go elsewhere to find it.
The seller in the street are very insistent but with 10 minutes walkin you get use to it.
buy your boots here!. great place to find leather boots. this is my second visit to playa del Carmen and found another beautiful, unusual pair of boots

Not what I expected.... So yes, there are a lot of shops and restaurants here but it is just like a big flea market. Sales people are very aggressive. Not a classy place.. unless you want cheaper tourist gifts.. I wouldn't recommend wasting time here.
Amazing shops. There are shops for all tastes. The bars are also amazing and very safe area to go during the day or night.

Shopping. Enjoyed my walk down the Quinta Avenida. Lots of places to shop, eat, and drink! Spent the day at Mamitas Beach, so it was very conveniently located. Also, very easy to find a taxi back to my hotel!

great place to walk and find awesome spots to eat and or drink. In this street you can find restaurants, bars, hotels, shops... is a nice place to be, is ok to be with family, friends, with your couple.
and is friendly to any budget.

Great Atmosphere!. Whether your staying in Playa del Carmen or not you should take a walk down 5th avenue. It is a street full of shops, restaurants and bars. You will enjoy the atmosphere down 5th ave., I'm sure you will find the perfect place to eat. I recommend the Bodeguita del Medio a cuban restaurant, the food is great and you can enjoy the live salsa band in the evening.
shopping. We went shopping in playa Del Carmen. There were so many shops! The prices were high, but you could barter somewhat. We enjoyed seeing the town.

Tourist Trap. This place was just a nightmare to visit as a tourist, every shop you walked past you would get hassle, 'come into my shop, let me show you my shop' etc. Also got offered weed and cocaine from a few guys, quite openly and quite disgraceful and should be policed better. Certainly not somewhere to visit as a family!! The beach is nice and there is an endless avenue of shops but be prepared to haggle with prices.

Haggle Heaven!!. Fifth Avenue what a stroll! Be prepared for an aggressive shopping experience. The more you say no the lower the price goes. Be wary of the "Mexican silver" they want you to believe it's .925 sterling but odds are it has what is called "alpaca" silver in is as well (that's a silver mixture .850 and less). Don't be faint of heart. Smile and keep going. Tons of tourist stores, jewelry, and more. There are even some cool shows to catch in the main square or at the beach entrance. It's a crazy experience not to be missed. Tons of places to eat as well, but a bit pricey. The "American" retail stores no deals there. Keep in mind Fifth Avenue is roughly 30 blocks of a lot of the same types of shops. Be aware of the peso to your currency exchange, the shops close around 10:00 pm, and there are plenty of taxis to get you back to your resort. Ask you concierge how much you should expect to pay for a taxi. We paid 20.00 US dollars for 3 people for a 20 minute taxi ride one way. Enjoy it for what it is and you won't go wrong!!!

Bring your negotiating skills. Be very aware that there are two prices...Latin American price and Tourist price. This is sad but the truth. I haggled and got about 50% off of the original prices that were asked. Most of the larger stores have good prices to begin with so If you don't feel like haggling just go there to shop. Don't be afraid to put things down and walk away. You'll be surprised that the price drops dramatically as you are almost out the door or you can low ball from the start and get to a fair price. These are the facts folks and don't buy anything at the starting price.

SKETCHY.... During our vacation, we went here to check out some shops & buy souvenirs for our friends & family. EVERY street you go down people harass you to come in their shop & see what they have. They will even continue to follow you down the street after you tell them no. All of them try to tell you that everything in their shop is "almost free today". People tried to sell us drugs (marijuana, cocaine) AT LEAST 10 different times while walking. They offered us "samples" after we said no. I guess they assume every American is there to do drugs?The "name brand" shops there (Harley Davidson, Nautica, Tommy Hilfiger, etc.) are very expensive & not any cheaper than they are in the U.S. Everything in the other shops are not exactly cheap & some stores try to confuse you with peso amounts. Make sure you know how many pesos are equivalent to your home currency so you don't over pay for something.

Fun day on 5th!. We shopped, ate, checked out the beach and plaza, and visited a Starbucks! The Cigar Shop was great fun with friendly employees. Restaurants on 5th are a little spendy for casual dining. Great, fun day overall!

5th Avenue. A long street running parallel to the beach. Full of souvenir shops, massage parlors, restaurants and bars. Not impressed. If you stay in Playas del Carmen, this will be the street you will most likely walk through each day and by the end of the 1st day you wish there was more to see. Very overpriced. If you like illegal animals being used for photos and tour operators begging you to visit their booth, then this place if for you. It was so disappointing. It was sad that there were Mariachi players strolling around waiting for someone to tip them so they could play. The 5 days I was there, I only saw one tourist pay them to play. Very sad.

Too touristy, annoying touts, high prices, often crowded. We've been to Playa a few times, and I just detest this street. Any eatery charges about 3 times what other places 2 blocks away charge, and the quality isn't that great usually. Extremely touristy with touts harassing you at almost every step. I do my best to stay away from the street as much as possible.

Tourist trap. Lots of shops and restaurants but typical tourist trap. Some of the shop keepers are annoying trying to get you in their stores.The people watching was good. Very eclectic mix of Mexico, USA, Canada, Europeans and South America.

Fun place, lots of shopping variety and great food!. Just a cute, clean place to stroll down when visiting Playa. There are many upscale shops, variety of good al fresco restaurants, entertainment, color, lights at night. A very casual and laid back lifestyle, no hurries or worries. One can even feel very safe walking alone. So glad that our condo was within walking distance so we did not have to battle trying to find a parking space. If you do need to get there by car, I would suggest getting a taxi as parking is very limited, especially at night.

Good shopping and great people.. I have a wife and two daughters 8 & 11 yrs. We love going in to Playa del Carmen and hangin out on Quinta. It's a block to the beach, there lots to see and do, places to shop, eat and have a cold one with the locals and on and on...I found the people in the area to be very friendly. They will approach you and try to get you to buy their wares but to me bartering is half the fun. Great night life as well. The area is geared for both families as well as the young single crowd. (ie. Blue Parrot, Coco Bongos & Senior Frogs to name a few.)

Harrasment. Found the visit quite stressful as we were continually being hassled to buy goods which we suspected were over priced. If only the Mexicans would allow visitors to look in peace without trying to influence their purchase. I would never go there again.
shopping, eating and drinking. Lovely shops and many eating and drinking options. Went during day but too hot. Prefer evening strolls.

Safest prettiest place to be at. You get to walk through the streets, shop, eat at any restaurant and go to the clubs. I really liked this avenue because it is safe, we were literally walking around with our phones all the time and nothing happened even tho there are lots and lots of tourists but there's also lots of police cops

Quinta for people watching. I love the hoards of people, of all ages and races, strolling along, side-by-side, in the humid tropical air. There is an endless array of things to draw your interest--shopping, eating, street artists etc---I do recommend shopping for souvenirs off of Quinta, up a few blocks for better bargains. But for late night action head down by The Blue Parrot where all the clubs throb with bass blasting until wee hours of the morning.
Quinta avenida. It's a place where you can spent goog time visiting shops, restaurants, buying souvenirs or walking along the street.
Great Shopping-Driking-Eating. 5th Ave is a pedestrians only street in Playa del Carmen, offering shops, restaurants and bars for about a mile. very relaxing and entertaining.

Entertaining. Walked every evening to Playa del Carmen. Lots to see and do. The night life was always hopping. Expect high pressure sales from the merchants, competition is strong, so shop for the best price,
Shopping Heaven. So much to see and do along the way. Since our first trip to Playa, 5th has been expanded and it's a good hike to see it all. Great restaurants and cool shops!

El Mercado. We were uneasy with people trying to dissuade us from going to the marketplace, but our concierge assured us we would be perfectly safe. We took a taxi there, cost us about $10. We shopped for hours and at no time felt threatened. All the shopkeepers were super friendly and very open to wheeling and dealing. Had a blast in Hacienda de Tequila, a super wine and spirits warehouse of sorts. Gave out samples that were full shots. Bought a lot of souvenirs. Missed out on trying street food, since we went so early in the morning - next time. Again, so happy we went!

Good basic fun.. You can be anywhere, within the tourist world, when you walk down Quinta Avenida in Playa del Carmen. The many restaurants, bars and shops, all trying to seduce you into their premises, tend to become a little stale after a few days. Nevertheless it is a good pastime to sit at one of the bars, enjoy a Margarita - or 2 if its happy hour - and watch the world go by. Lots of very atractive ladies will, as they pass, make the time go by quickly. A few good restaurants are to be found, check on the prices as the concept of "inexpensipe Mexico" can quickly dissappear.

Where to be Seen?....HERE!!!. Quinta Avenida (5th Avenue), this is where you go in the evenings! Do what all the beautiful people do, show it LARGE!! Promenade along 5th Ave with it's myriad of shops, bars, coffee houses, eatery's and clubs. It's a conglomerate of culture's, Central American, European, Mayan, Mexican, etc, etc. This is a must for anyone visiting the region, it's just as busy in the daytime, but hotter!!Stroll along at your leisure in the cool of the evening, learn some Spanish, basic is enough, Hola! Hello, Gracias..Thanks, etc etc, you will find that the service suddenly gets a little better!An experience that will linger in the memory for years to come.A Warning though.......Several vendors along the Avenue and side streets will offer Drugs for sale, Weed, coke, etc, etc. DO NOT BE TEMPTED, if you are, you will find that as you go round back to do the deal, you will end up getting a free ride in the local POLICIA CAR!!

5th avenue. This place is always a stop when we are in the area. You can find just about anything you could ever want. They have everything form jewelry, clothes, souvenirs, liquor, spices, great places to eat, and many more. You will not be disappointed if you make the trip.

Fifth Avenue Shopping. While on vacation in Playa Del Carmen we heard many people talking about Fifth Avenue. My husband who is not a shopper agreed to go only to make me happy. It was a $10 ride in each direction from our resort. The fun of shopping in Mexico is you can play let's make a deal and it is expected. Jewelry can be a great bargain there. I would definitely recommend this as your one stop for souvenirs. The best part was my husband loved it and the local people made it a fun experience.

Not what it used to be but still quaint. I've been traveling to this region for about a quarter of a century and have seen 5th Avenue change dramatically in that time. It's touristy and expensive but still...charming. I'd suggest venturing up to 10th or 15th for eats and, for hotel accommodations. As a general rule, the further you get from 5th Ave, the cheaper and more authentic your experience will be. This holds for food, for dry goods and for hotels.

No other place like 'La Quinta'. Full of good restaurants, bars, bistros, trendy clubs, cafeterias, shopping, shopping, shopping! all of this one-block away from the bright turquoise colors of the alluring Caribbean Sea, can you imagine? Plus, it's the best hottie-o-drome; the hippest catwalk that I've enjoyed in my life. You can have dinner, an ice cream or a cup of coffee and enjoy the most delightful parade featuring the most beautiful people in the world, sculped-bodied boys and girls wearing the fanciest attires in imagination. La Quinta is picturesque, hot and fun...
Great People Watching. Have walked 5th Ave many times and it never gets old. Great restaurants, good Ice Cream Shoppes, and Coffee Shops. Lots to see.

Fun place to go.. This is such a fun "tourista" place- all the vendors trying to get you into their establishments, trying their latest 'schtick' on the tourists: years ago the mantra was "...Cheaper than Walmart, almost free...", now it is "...Hey, I'm your waiter from your resort- it's my day off- come into my family's shop..."- not as cool, but certainly still creative. It's a place one can go wander & explore, ignoring the street vendors, or not, checking out the various shops, drinking offered samples of tequila and xtabentun, and just drinking in the whole, entire character of 5th Avenue. When I was there on a day by myself, on the beach I watched an indigenous Mayan group of performers do their 'male pole dance' (as I term it) -they'll start at the top of a tall pole & spin their way (upside down) all the way to the ground. It's really a neat performance & I've seen it done at Tulum also. You can still haggle with the vendors, although not as well as in previous years, but you can still get some bargains. If you ignore the Chinese imports, you can still find handicrafts made locally/regionally (silver, hanging lamps made from hollowed out gourds, things like that...) There is also a great art gallery there: Galeria de Arte 5ta Avenida, that showcases Mexican artists- definitely visit there. Unfortunately some huge commercial establishments have built a presence at one end of Fifth Avenue (Tommy Bahama, Pandora, etc) & that definitely takes away from some of the character of the Avenue- it's starting to feel somewhat more like Cancun (the States with a different accent)- but I guess that's progress (sigh). If you continue up the Avenue, you'll come to the terminal for the ferry to Cozumel (and THAT's an island worth doing a day trip to visit when you're in the Playa). All in all, it's hokey, it's touristy & it's just a lot of fun to go there. And, if you wish to party, you can do that too. It's all here. The Avenue has a certain uniqueness, a certain 'ambiance', a certain character all its own- each time we travel to Playa del Carmen we make it a point to visit & explore at least once.

Quintana Avenida. We aways enjoy walking Quintana Avenida checking out all the shops. You must haggle with prices and stick to your price because most of the time you will get a fair price this way. I have heard people say they could not get a price reduction but we were able to most of the time, and the times we did not get a decent reduction, we just walked away and went somewhere else. We have been here a few times in the past and usually have had dinner at some great resterants at night. This time we were at an all enclusive resort so had our dinners there. Quintana Avenida is a very fun experience and one must visit it.

Love, Love, Love this place!. Quinta Avenida is one of the reasons I decided to go back to Playa Del Carmen. Such a fun mix of restaurants, bars, shops, malls and it is walking distance to the beach! I can't wait go back. One restuaruant you must try is La Bodeguita. Great Paella.
Love the 5th Avenue Atmosphere..... My third time at Playa del Carmen but not my last. Mostly I love my hotel close to the 5th and on the beach. You can't see that everywhere you travel.
5th Ave. Outstanding!!!! A great place to visit and eat great food. Great place to to see. Thing to buy. Nice people.

La Quinta. Always a great place to go to dinner, shopping, drinking and people watching after a day on the beach. Although, it has changed a lot since I started going four year ago, it's still charming enough.

Shuttle to Playa Del Carmen from Grand riviera Princess. While we were on our six night stay at the resort we took the hotel shuttle,$16 round trip for the two of us, to Playa Del Carmen and Quinta Avenida. If you like shopping this may be your place. There is no vehicular traffic, and the shops go on and on. We stayed Three hours which is not near enough to see it all. Everyone was nice overall and they were not as pushy compared to say Cozumel or Progreso..One funny thing was that we had several young men approach us saying they worked for the resort we were staying at and it was their day off. They either noticed our wrist bands or the resort bag that was given to us with their logo on it. We were there in the middle of June and it was very warm..Next time we are near we will probably go back.

Busy pedestrian mall. This is where all the tourists congregate. Jewelry, souvenir shops, terraces, & cafes galore. Prices will be less expensive on the side streets or further north on the Avenida, past the very crowded area. After a day of walking in the heat, go relax on the beach, take a side street where there are beach-front cafes for a nice cold beer & tortillas with guacamole :-)

shopping and restaurants. Fun to go and meander around the area. The vendors are engaging and interesting..Lots of banter. I enjoyed the shopping and bought some great quality tequila and not so great quality silver...

Wonderful 5th Avenue. Lots of Shops, Bars, Restaurants with no cars allowed. Street musicians and other performers entertaining the diners at the sidewalk restaurants. Sure the shop keepers will try to entice you into their store. They just want to make a living. Nothing wrong with that and they usually take a "no gracias" with no problem at all. It is wonderful to stroll in the evening walking off your great dinner at one of the charming restaurants. Love it and can't wait to go back.

Undersold. Definitely make an attempt to visit this area early in your trip. There is so much to do here. You could eat out at some great looking places but we didn't realise until the last night. Lots of fantastic shops for the ladies too!

Walking 5th Avenue. 5th ave., is an interesting area to walk around, taking a cab from nearby resorts usually costs around 10 dollars each way, lots of taxis, so no worry about getting one to take you back to your resort. 5th Ave., is loaded with lots of restaurants, bars, and clubs, and is always loaded with tourists from all over. The shopping there, is not as good a deal versus Punta Cana, the retail stores are privately owned, and the prices are as marked, no haggling about the prices. The vendors on the street, also know that they will get just about what they are asking for the goods, because of the huge turnover of tourists every day, so that allows them to not vary much from the prices, the one vendor that we talked to about a silver torquise ring, would only offer a 10% discount from his asking price. But 5th. Ave., is an interesting place to see, and experience at least once while you are visiting the Riviera Maya area of Mexico.

Couldn't get away soon enough. It's not at all what I was hoping for. We were there mid day, which was so hot, and we were looking for a spot to grab some lunch. The odd thing was, even though there were lots of tourists, no one was eating. This concerned us, so we skipped lunch. Lots of callers trying to get us into the various shops. One guy even said "hey, I know you from the resort." We were pretty sure we had never met him, and then he asked us to come down the side street to his "grandfather's shop." We did, and felt very uncomfortable. Some guy followed us closely as we left. We did get suckered into one jewelry shop. Beautiful merchandise, but the man in charge was quite a pig. Made inappropriate remarks and poured tequila, which we didn't want. Bought a couple items, and even then, he wanted to take us to his cousin's shop down the street.We hailed a taxi and returned to the tranquil surroundings of our resort. Would we go back? Probably not.

Too many souvenir pushers . Quinta avenida is very clean and lit up so you don't have to worry about getting mugged or kidnapped by the cartel. I love that it has a variety of restaurants from outdoor patio seating type of restaurants to posh out if the ordinary restaurants and clubs - the only draw back is that there many vendors that are way too pushy and when you politely tell them " no thank you " they always have a comeback so you really just have to resort to just ignoring them which is rude but I found that to be most helpful or else they just won't give up trying to get you into their shop

Close to hotel and convenient. The street is lively and friendly. Our hotel was close by which helped make easily accessible. Lots of bars and restaurants and plenty of shop owners hawking their wares but in a friendly manner.

Main torutist avenue. 5ta Avenida is where the toursit go to eat, shop and do the touristy stuff. you can walk a good hour and keep seeing shops and restaurants if you want to see more local stuff you have to venture out of this avenue.

Convenience and hustling. The best part about 5th ave is convenience: anything you want at any hour of the day/night is here. There aren't many places in the world that have this little idyllic, palm-tree lined beachside strip of bars, cafes, clubs, restaurants, hotels, apartments, shops, juice bars, etc in one place - 24 hours a day. The cons: Overpriced and average food, people trying to get you to buy stuff, loud music blaring from places trying to compete with each otherTips: 5th ave is a good place to stroll around, people watch, eat, drink and be merry. Just wear a hat and sunglasses and don't make eye contact with anyone trying to sell you something for minimum hassling (including drugs). The taxis are more expensive departing from 5th ave and taxi stops compared to almost any other street. You might not care since they are so cheap anyway, but if you don't want the gringo rate flag a cab elsewhere. DO NOT: Use the ATMs on this street; they have devices that can rip off your debit card numberDO NOT: Listen to anyone who calls you "my friend" or "mi amigo". Run the other way. That person is not your friend.

Go to say you've been. Our hotel was just off 5th. So...essentially everywhere we went required us to walk through the endless barrage of hagglers. It's a super long and very diverse area. You can find everything from local vendors with souvenir type stuff to Forever 21, Hurley, and Lacoste. The local shops all want your business and as you walk down the street they shout for your attention. It's just Mexico style. I have become a master of ignoring it, I think. If I wasn't intentionally seeking out an item, I just ignored the vendor. They aren't overly aggressive, even at night, but they are aggressive. They're trying to make a living, I get that. I did notice that the prices start out ridiculous at the local vendors shops, but if you're willing to haggle with them, you can get a great deal. You can find glassware, pottery, hats, etc. at most local vendor's spots. I wouldn't buy at the first shop I visited. I'd get there best price and take that to the next guy. Make sure you're getting the best deal. The restaurants are lined up everywhere and they even shout out for your business. We didn't take time to eat on 5th. That's on the list for next time. The restaurants look charming, and you can find just almost anything you'd like to eat. I think you have to go down 5th at least once. Go at dusk when it's a little cooler and enjoy a walk. It's the most charming area, and you can look for hours. I've never seen an area quite like it. Such an ecclectic mix of local color and modern flair. For sure take a few hours to check it out.

Just Okay..... Be prepared to be approached and lured into air conditioned shops all selling the same items. You will be astonished at the amount they want you to pay for items initially. I bought a pair of silver earrings from a very persuasive lady for $20 after I got her down from $60. Don't spend too much time there unless you are able to say NO nicely. Most things do not have price tags...so you must bargain and haggle so if that's not your thing, don't bother. You will be better off shopping at the airport.

Where the action is. Great shopping and people watching with many Italian and Fish restaurants. But don't get stuck eating at the all the over priced mediocre tourist restaurants go up to Avenida 30 or just down to Avenida 1 and find where we locals eat!

Not Welcome. Corazon Avenida was a quaint little street with tiny Mexican markets. I miss the leather shop, Joe Natural and the store with Frida Kahlo items for sale. A very old beautiful tree was torn down so this huge mall could be built like a mini Vegas. I refuse to visit this place for what they took away from 5th Avenue. We have great memories of celebrating New Years Eves dancing on this corner of 5th. Its a sad change to see Playa Del Carmen become so commercialized with more malls and hotels every year.

Best shopping/walking district in the Yucatan. We enjoy the Qta Avenida and its many shops, cafes, coffee houses and outdoor restaurants. A larger and wider version of Calle Hidalgo on Isla Mujeres, the district is 20+ blocks of pedestrian-only and is both charming and great for people watching.Go in the evening to avoid the midday heat and intense sun. North of Calle 12, and especially north of Ave. Constituyentes, the feel is decidedly more European and cosmopolitan. Some of the restaurants north of Constituyentes are amazing, worth checking out.

Worth a stroll, just too expensive. It's a little like going to a carnival. Everything is overpriced and every carney is trying to get you to come to their stall. We spoke with one owner and he said he paid $7,000 US for his small location every month. So it's no wonder they have to be so expensive! The restaurants were more reasonable but still mostly nothing special. On the weekend, there were a number of very loud, drunk people at several of the restaurants so it was difficult to find a place to eat. The avenue makes for a fun evening stroll but we mainly made our purchases outside of town and our dining on little side streets.

Good shopping. Excellent to buy souvenier. There are so many big stores and little stores to choose from. You have chain stores and you have the locals. Try to negociate prices, offer what you think is appropiate for the product.
Worth the trip.. We went on Quinta Avenida twice and found the place very interesting. My wife is an avid shopper and if you are too, it's a can't miss thing to do.

Never again. As a general rule, I travel for food, and a local experience. I had never been to the Quinta before and had no idea what to expect. Concisely put, there is nothing less authentic to the experience of Mexico than the Quinta. The food is an abomination. If you are a college kid who wants to drink cheap tequila out of battery powered plastic cups, have a blast. If you are middle-aged and want to pretend you are a college kid, have a blast. If you want good food in a nice atmosphere, go elsewhere.

Unique Experience..but won't do it again. My husband and I took a taxi here from Akumal to get the full Mexican Riviera experience. We were not disappointed, as it was exactly as I've read. You WILL get store owners pleading for you to come in their store, which we don't necessarily mind so much. We were never "harassed", as people call it, though. A firm "no gracias" to those we weren't interested in and we were on our way. If you are staying at a resort and have a wristband, they street hawkers will claim to be your waiter at the restaurant and try to interact with you by saying "Are you mad at me? Why won't you talk to me? I was your waiter at so and so." It's quite amusing actually, especially when I hit back at them in Spanish calling them out for fibbing. The prices seemed to be quite high for everything from ice cream to margaritas. $4 American dollars for a teeny-tiny cup of ice cream. But it WAS delicious. :)There is a mixture of chain stores that one would see in the U.S. and Europe mixed in with little Mexican trinket shops, handicrafts, and well, just plain junk stores. It was a fun time, but once was enough. OH, and wear comfortable shoes. The streets are VERY uneven and I wore flip-flops. Big mistake.

You have to experience it. Nice mixture of traditional sombrero and shot glass stores, as well as higher end retailers. One or two good, but over-priced cigar stores. Go with the restaurants that are not begging you to eat at their place - there is a reason.

wonderful walk watching the sea. I love 5a avenida in playa del carmen with all the little shops and restaurants bars there is everything you need there. I live in playa del carmen for 6 months every year and I find so nice that there is this road without cars!!!!! unique in all riviera maya!!!
Awesome as always but more crowded every year. Too many people with aggressive sales techniques lol, it is getting too crowded and full of big business, so not as charming as it was 5-6 years ago

The best street in Playa del Carmen!. As always, its great to walk around 5th avenue. Very safe, full of restaurants and shops, you cannot get bored here. Good shoes are a must...its quite long from one end to the other.

You will be hassled... If you don't like to be shouted at to check out their store..or buy a tour ..then stay away..because that's exactly what happens..they are relentless and will not take a "no gracias" or " no thank you"..BUT..they have some good restaurants..that are way overpriced..go down to the beach and check out the restaurants there..they are still overpriced..but the view is much better..

Heart and energy of PDC, but can be a bit touristy.. Don't hesitate to bargain. As a rule of thumb, the price of items from small booths (not fancy retail) is around a third of the original quoted price. Walk away and the real price will be offered,

Avoid like the plague.. Unless you like being hassled, don't even bother walking down 5th Ave. The locals are relentless about getting up in your face (literally, you have to walk around some of them) to buy their stuff or their services. You cannot go more than 5 feet without being hassled by 3 or 4 of them. It becomes stressful to a point that you wonder if you should even bother to walk down 5th to get to where you need to go, or go up a block and walk down 10th. Terrible.

Touristy. Don't expect anything else. Souvenirs/tours will be pricey because they are catering to tourists. Sellers were aggressive in trying to hawk their merchandise but nothing we could not handle with a firm no thank you.

Great food, a beehive of activity. Over the years, we have tried several different restaurants here, and loved them all. Shopping is fun, food is tasty. If you have an urge to try something really local, find a street vendor selling chorizo (sausage) burritos - to die for. If you are shopping, make sure you bargain the price down. If they sell it to you, they are making a profit! Have fun...

Defines "tourist trap". My wife and I had to check out Quinta Avenida while on vacation in Playa Del Carmen.The good: There are several good eating spots scattered up and down the street, but I'm sure you can do better off the strip. It's a good place to people watch.The bad: There are dozens of ways to get ripped off from questionable jewelry to risky ATM's. Every 50 feet you will be invited to come check out a local shop, get a massage, or book an excursion.

Miles of outrageous shopping, drinking, Mexican entertainment!. Walk La Quinta from 0 to 48th. From Playa Car beach or the Cozumel Ferry to Palapa Suuk meditation center. Wear a swim suit by day, beautiful whites by night. Bring your honey and your babies, laugh, and be merry. Shop the handmade goods, wear a sombrero and have fish eat the skin off your Caribbean Sea kissed feet. Dine at the five star Mayan, Italian and Cuban cuisines. Taxi to your hotel with memories and dreams, thoughts in your head, "Wow, how serene." If you like the night life start it all off at Santanera, salsa lessons or a miriachi band for free, dance the Sunrise In on 12th avenue. You Only Live Once---> tomorrow is for sleep.
5th Avenue. Lots of interesting shops and great people-watching. Restaurants are plentiful and offer great Mexican cuisine.

Walking 5th. Avenue. ******5th. Avenue, is Playa's main street, where you'll find what ever your looking for, being something for your self or something nice for your family back home. Timing is everything, and weather you walk it during the day or night makes a big difference!!! During the day, people are very casual, and layed back, and at night, it takes on a whole new feeling. People are dressed up, and ready to dance the night away. Their's nothing like strolling the beach with the one you love!!! Everyone I know falls in love with Playa!!!

Everything a westernized person could want. Lots of shopping, restaurants, bars, and souvenir shops. Plenty to do and see. Loads of fun and right off the beach. Even a mall with a starbucks and other favorites.

Fantastic Shopping, Partying and Eating :). This is the street to checkout! There's practically a ladies night every night with free flowing drinks and cover for ladies. But if you're with your boyfriend, you will never get those deal. ;)

Nice downtown shopping. Lots of restaurants and interesting places. It was clean and safe and easy to find a taxi. The street was hot, but most of the shops had air conditioning. The people were very nice and welcoming. Bags of chips are ridiculously expensive.

losing it's charm. Thereare some good shops and restaurants, but Playa is losing what it had left of its small town feel. There is lots of construction, and a lot of the mom and pop shops are giving way to Starbucks, Forever 21, Victoria's Secret, etc. I could go to the mall at home for that.

a must!. you go to playa del carmen you must go to the la quinta avenida! It is full of restaurants, bars, shopping (traditional and fashion), there are even people making cuban cigars on the street, there is music everywhere, people everywhere! definitivly worth taking a stroll!
5th avenue in playa del carmen things to do. Great for walking and shopping some pubs, bars and restaurant night time best for dancing. Make sure to try cocobongo great shows.

Great for shopping but overpriced food.. 5th avenue is a great place to shop and get souviners for people, however we were a little more than unimpressed by the fact that all ATMs on the avenue only dispense american dollars and not pesos. ATMs that dispense both currencies would be better. The eateries on the ave were a little overpriced so we opted to go to 30th ave which is where the locals eat for dinner. We found a lot of better and more authentic options for dinner there.
Tons of Shops for Souvenirs.. Nice walk, free internet along the route, and lots of shops to buy jewelry, and other fun souvenirs.

A must see if you're in PDC or Cancun. This is one of my favorite places in Mexico. The shopping, food, drinks, scenery, walk...everything...is just great. Feel free to haggle on the prices of souvenirs. Try the foot and at the end of the Quinta is a park with street food vendors (YUM!!!).

More expensive than Hawaii.. Very disappointed with this experience shopping here is not enjoyable. People yelling from every which way. HEY LADY! HOLA SENOR!!!! They also rip you off charging way over what it should be. Go to the main big outlet its like ABC market place. Nobody bothers you in there and they have cheaper stuff. Not by much but no hagling required...

Disgusting. I couldn't beleive they have done this to Playa del Carmen. How come mexican people allow such a destruction to their gorgeous environment?The paradox is that it is an essentially touristic place but tourists are mistreated: taxi drivers charge what they feel like, prices in restaurants and shops are absurd, it is full of out of place luxury shops and bad taste in general.

Fun walk and tons of shopping. Quinta Avenida is the main street where all the shopping is located. You will find tons of local shops, as well as high end retail stores, restaurants, ice cream shops, bars, etc. You can even take a picture with a monkey for $5. It's a fun experience, and very safe.

One of the most perfect pedestrian roads in the world. From the funky older shops to to charming modern restaurants with impossibly perfect tropical accents to art on display, Quinta is perfect (Especially during the magic hour when the sun is setting and the lights start to glow).

sellers could be less pushy. Wonderful place to visit and for a long evening walk, its a shame that the vendors could be very pushy and we don`t understand why put the prices so high "we don`t like bargain"
Great shopping and beach front. We had a lovely afternoon here. We sat on the seafront and did a little shopping. Some good bargains to be had. Quaint little town.
Tourist spot. Tourist spot, touristy price. Every store sells same stuffs. There are very few stores that are unique, although, you can see some stores that you can see back in us or canada.
Tourist shops, resataurants, bars, botique hotels and tour. One side had very high end shops, it is along walk with many small sholps, reataurants and bars, the cross street leads to the beach.
What a GREAT place. Is my favorite place in Mexico. Great place to relax, take a beer or shop. You will find great restaurants, bars and the Best night life

Luv 5th ave. We visit 5th ave every time we visit the area. We love walking down the street stopping to have a couple of beers. Dickering with the venders. Having a couple of beers and so on. We usually spend the day between the beach and 5th ave. Get there about noon leave after midnight. Who cares were on vacation.

Go for the people watching and the dining, NOT for shopping!. No trip to Playa is complete without a trip on 5th Avenue. There's plenty to look at, and some very nice dining venues. In general, most of the restaurants in and around 5th Avenue are pricey by Mexican standards. The problem is, some of the restaurant's food quality justifies the prices and others don't. There are some very nice places to eat out and go for a drink here, I would do research on Tripadvisor and other websites beforehand however and not just wander around and look for a place, or go someplace where there is staff outside aggressively trying to bring patrons in. This is NOT a good place for shopping. Maybe its because I've been to many other parts of Mexico but the prices of the usual Mexican crafts/souvenirs are very expensive here. There are a few large shops with fixed prices in pesos, USD, and Euros (the latter two calculated at an awful exchange rate). When I was in one shop and noted that the prices are about double what I would pay for the same artisan crafts in Mexico City, I was thrown out! Many of the other smaller shops are an even worse experience. No price tags, aggressive salespeople heckling you from the street.. I would never even bother going into these places at all unless you really know what the prices of things are supposed to be. A third type of store are boutique type shops (like for clothes) and the higher end shops in the new mall on the corner of 5th and Constituyentes. These are higher end stores with fixed prices and there are NO bargains. There's nothing in this mall that could not be purchased for cheaper in the USA. The Sanborns (a well regarded Mexican chain that is a cross between a high end drugstore, book and music shop, cosmetics, perfumes, and accessories store)may be the only think worthwhile in the mall in case some necessities are needed in a pinch. The best thing about Playa, is that you only need to go a few blocks inland to get into a much more authentic Mexico. The prices come down from the rafters for booth food and shopping. The further you get from 5th avenue the more you get into the "real" Mexico. I recommend you do your actual buying there and leave 5th avenue for window shopping.Quick tips:-It is best to pay in pesos..Everywhere! Or everywhere outside your resort if staying at an AI. Those shops that take USD will take them at a bad rate. -Tax is already included on everything you buy and in all restaurants. -If coming from anywhere in Playacar, the taxi fare to and from the downtown of Playa del Carmen is 70 pesos, not 90 pesos, not $7. (Your hotel may have a higher rate posted on the board at the entrance. This is because there is a sitio surcharge when the taxi picks up at a hotel.) If you leave the hotel and hail a taxi, the fare is 70 pesos.This 70 pesos fare includes the entire zone of downtown Playa del Carmen. This area covers as far north as Calle 34 and as far inland as the highway, so don't let a taxi charge you more because you walked to the end of the downtown of 5th avenue and you have to pay more because you are on the "far end". It is still 70 pesos all the way to Calle 34

Must visit.....But..... You have to visit 5th Avenue to say you've experienced it but that's about it. Many great bars and shops however, constant hassle throughout and all you find yourself saying is "no thanks". It does get extremely annoying but it's all part of visiting here. Some great bargains to be had too.My tip is once you have walked Quinta Avenida is to head back via adjacent streets as you can find some bars, restaurants and other shops perhaps a little cheaper and quicker to get back due to no hassling.
Fun. A fun & busy place to be. Street vendors & hawkers galor! This is a must if you visit Playa. Restaurants are too many to even venture a guess busy day or night.

Worth a visit once. If you are in the area, it's worth a visit to Playa Del Carmen. Have a meal and buy some souvenirs. It is very much a tourist street. Some store have better prices than others. Shop around. It is very hot in the city compared to the beach resorts.
5th Ave. Great stores although some vendors act like hucksters and are annoying. Some very unique stores on both sides of 5th. Very disappointed to see the new Mall...detracts from the town.

It's a gauntlet!!. I liked that there was plenty of shops, restaurants, and vendors. What our family hated was the harassment by the vendors! Constantly asked, "Taxi?" "Sunglasses?" "Need a tee-shirt?" "Xel-Ha?" We quickly learned to look straight ahead and say no a lot, Our nearly 18 year-old-son ventured ONCE on his own and was asked if he wanted cocaine or women. He never left the family after that.
I love 5th Ave. Please do not be tempted to stay in your hotel for 2 weeks and not venture into PDC. 5th Ave is a melting pot of shops bars and restaurants not to be missed - something for everyone
great fun. I usually hate streets like this, but great people watching and fun. Not expensive for US but expensive for Playa. Everything from Belgian Beer to Argentine Parilla to Bar Dancing.
the 5th Avenue.... If you like motion, animation, shopping, bars and restaurants open at any time of day or night, you will find pleasure in attending the 5th Avenue.

A destination to get away from the buffet table. Look, as nice as where you are staying, you will tire and need a diversion without blowing your day on a tour bus hauling you somewhere your held hostage. This is it. You can walk from many resorts or take a ten minute five buck cab here. It's legions better than it was years ago. It's twice as long as it was with shops. Sure there is shlock, but there are also some nice shops and upscale fashion stores. Low , near the bus station is the oldest and shoddiest area, and it gets better the closer you get to The Royal Hotel street and beyond. It's very safe during the day, and even at night, if you stay reasonably in the eating and shopping area. Great array of restaurants there, cheap and good change from your hotel food.If your a young gun, the bars for you are party city, but be careful, nothing good comes too late at night there.Don't talk to the street vendors, if you just ignore them, they will look to the next guy. He doesn't care where you're from...ignore him. When you see the gypsy street entertainers at night, watch your belongings, put your wallet where it's safe and hard to pickpocket. They come with the street entertainers sometimes.And while I'm here....when you get back to your all inclusive....stop tipping. Wait to your ready to leave and hit who treated you well. They serve you because...and tips shouldn't motivate them, and only spoils their expectations. People who bring cash to the all inclusive bars will change the dynamic here. Tip...at the end of your stay.

Sightseeing. We love going to Playa del Carmen on Quint Avenida to see all the interesting shops and the local merchants. However, I dislike being pressured to buy things and go into places when I just want to look around but that is the way it is there.
A Bit of Everything. Even if shopping is not your thing, the people watching is great fun! I like to find a good perch, preferably with food nd drink available, and watch the parade.

Better than I expected. Although 5th Ave is touristy and has a fair amount of kitsch, we also discovered several fabulous boutiques featuring local designers' clothing and accessories. I would definitely come back for more shopping. :)

This place has come along way. Downtown Playa Del Carmen has come a long way in the past 8 years. My first trip to Mexico 8 years ago brought me to 5th Ave for some shopping. Back then the place was a run down dump. They have put a lot of money into this place since then. It really looks nice. One thing to add. Bring your bartering skills with you if you plan on shopping down there. No price is set in stone. If you want something you can get it for a good price if you are willing to work a little bit for it. It will cost you $7.00 US dollars to get there from the Playacar resorts (and $7 back to your resort). In closing one trip to 5th Ave each year is enough but it still is very fun to do and I would recommend everybody go down to Quinta Avenida.

Fun to Window Shop. If you like tourist traps this is the place to go, but if you like to walk the area for the atmosphere, vibe, and feeling like you're part of something then this is the place to be just don't buy anything. LOL. The one thing that really irritates me is the number of people that line the street trying to sell you trips, trinkets, etc. The side streets can look a bit scary, but I never felt unsafe. There are plenty of police around. Watch the ATMS that litter the avenue. Best place to eat is El Fagon that is about 4 blocks away. We walked there and it felt safe.

Don't see the attraction. Its junk stores...overpriced goods and annoying sales people. I went several times throughout our recent trip. Really...WHY? I guess if you are young and love partying. Otherwise...I don't understand why people subject themselves to it. Not my cup of tea. Go off the path by a block or two...cheaper, better food, and nicer sales people.

Entertaining Pedestrian Walkway. Fifth Avenue is entertaining night and day with it's endless array of shops, bars and restaurants. You can also just grab a barstool or bench and people watch for hours!

The reason Playa is great. Fifth Ave is the reason Playa is as popular as it is...With countless stores, food stops, bars, shops, etc... You can spend a whole day walking down 5th Ave... Along the way of 5th ave, you can spend time on side streets such as 12th (Where the clubs are) ... If you are staying in Playa Del Carmen... 95% of your time will be spent between Fifth Ave and the Beach

Cant miss this even if you tried.... this is the main shopping street in Playa and its pretty awesome with cool shops and funky cafes and restaurants - it will come as an expensive shock if you have been traveling around mexico and end in PLaya like we did as everything was very expensive especially the touristy shops - lucky im not into this lol
Fun to shop around!. Tons of shops and great place to get souvenirs. Don't forget to barter! The shops that aren't priced are negotiable. Spent four hours and still didn't see everything.

Good for a day visit. We visited 5th Ave with about 8 other people around dinner time (6pm). I think everyone had their own opinions of it. Me personally, I thought it was a neat atmosphere….lots to see…lots to buy. Shops are pretty tourist-y so they were slightly pricier than I had expected. We lost half our group almost right away from feeling "unsafe". I don't know that I ever felt endangered….but unusual things are def offered to you as you walk by. It may have been a better day trip than evening. Señor frogs was busy and an energetic atmosphere….if you eat down there most places have their exchange rates posted…if not and you plan to pay with US dollars ask first…and calculate your bill….our waiter did try to snaggle a few extra bucks out of us, as did one of the clerks at a store. I would NEVER bring my kid down there….but there were some people who did have kids there so I guess to each their own.

NOISY and TRASHY. Nice well kept restaurants and stores on both sides of the Quinta. However, it is full of hustlers, and people begging for money. I have been asked over and over again if I wanted to buy drugs or sex....HORRIBLE.....Not a place to walk with your mother or wife or female friend......The ocean, just a couple of blocks away, is truly beautiful and inviting..

Souvenirs , lunch and a stroll .... Its exciting , loud and a mish mash of various shops , including some well known brands inside a air conditioned mall type shopping plaza . You can find any kind of souvenir you are looking for , and there are tons of places to stop , grab a cold drink and have a bite to eat if you desire . There is a Senor Frogs if your mood permits , its off of 5th avenue , towards the very end , but you get to sit right over the beach so the view and the breeze is spectacular.The only thing that might annoy you is the Time Share Guys , persistent little buggers and you will see or hear one every 5 minutes ,, a smile and polite " no thank you " should get them to leave you alone . Everyone has a job right .The ferry to Cozumel is here and seems pretty straight forward to catch .We went just so I could buy a few trinkets and gifts , and get off the resort for a change , we ate lunch and pleasantly were surprised to see that when we were on our way back to catch our bus , the ritual ceremony of the Voladores was getting ready to start , we quickly found a spot to sit and enjoyed the show . Its free but someone with a hat will come around asking for donations , after seeing that show I can't imagine now anyone would NOT want to throw some change in his hat ! I know from previous times that we have gone to Playa Del Carmen that 5th avenue really comes alive at night . Lots of music , clubs, lounges and bars , and lots of people out having a good time . Very safe . I never encountered any problems any time that I have been there .

So much to see here!. Great pedestrian street, filled with souvenir shops, restaurants and entertainment. It is unfortunately becoming more commercialized every year. Lots of great places to eat, mostly international cuisine. Don't encourage the guys with the baby exotic animals walking around, it's sad and if nobody pays for pics, hopefully they will stop it. No taco stands, kinda stinks. If you go a few blocks off the blvd you can find some by the park. Bars and liquor galore! There is entertainment everywhere.

Lots of restaurants and stores. Many little shops and restaurants to explore and visit down this long avenue. We unfortunately had a few bad experiences being ripped off. Do NOT eat at Buenos Aires Argentinian restaurant. They rope you in with cheap menu prices, refuse to give you a proper check at the end of the meal and increase the prices greatly from what the menu offered. What should have been a $50 meal turned into a $85US meal without explanation. We were promised 2 free drinks to come in (empty restaurant) and did not get them free. Big ripoff and they are not the only ones. On the other hand, there are many friendly vendors and restaurants eager to earn your patronage. Don't be shy to barter for a better deal.

5th Avenue - great bars etc. Great bars and restaurants, including a Señor Frogs on the beach.Free wifi is a bonus but a bit of a pain - you'll find out why when you get there.Bit expensive though.Las Delicious is an great restaurant.
Great Stores and People Watching. Great variety of stores and restaurants....with patios for good people watching. Lots of cool things to do and eclectic sights and sounds.

Touristy but still fun. Came down from the Iberostar Paraiso complex and spent a few hours on 5th Ave before heading further south to Akumal. Lots of vendors trying to entice you into their shops. There were good deals on things like T-shirts and jewelry if you haggled. I thought it was fun, some in our group didn't like the chattering shop owners but they have to make a living too. Looks like it would be more fun at night.

Bigger than I expected. Fifth avenue was much bigger than I expected. I was expecting a few blocks of quaint little shops and bars, and instead found over 20 blocks of everything from tourist shops, to Starbucks, to hole in the walls to Sunglass huts. It was fun walking the street, lots of people, lots of life, and lots of food options. Day vibe is different than the night vibe, glad we experienced both.

Fun to people watch.. Fifth Avenue was just a two block walk from our hotel so we spent a lot of time here. It's closed to automobiles, has many shops and restaurants. Make sure to watch for the spider monkey and get your picture with it!

Fun for a few days.... We stayed for 8 days which was too long for our likes, but Quinta Avenida definitely has some great shops and restaurants. Be prepared to be bombarded by people trying to sell you everything! And I mean EVERYTHING! If you walk from one end to the other expect to have people try selling you things at least 10 times. Not a big deal at first but does wear one down a bit. Same goes for sitting in restaurants...Mariachi singers and groups will hit you up a few times to 7 or 8 times during the course of your dinner. If you want to avoid this simply find a restaurant with a balcony overlooking the Ave.

Tourist trap, crowded, vendors barking at you constantly. My boyfriend and I went for his 50th birthday. We stayed at a hotel just off 5th avenue and 10th street. We hated this part of Playa. Every store had someone outside calling you or trying to drag you into their stores and they don't take no for an answer. We live in a resort town and were shocked out the outrageous prices for everything -higher than in the US. I paid $22 for sunscreen. We paid $31 at Haagen-Daz for a single scoop and a double scoop. And be sure to shop around because nothing is the same price in any of the stores. I saw the same sunscreen in another store for $17. Even the pharmacies had different prices for their stuff. It's crowded and hard to walk, there are a lot of crappy restaurants and the only thing I liked was the clubs playing house music all night. It seemed nicer and more upscale around 20th so maybe we should have stayed farther north. There wasn't anything extraordinary about it, just a street full of tourist trap stores that overcharge for their junk. Would not go to this part of Playa again.

Not as good as before, but still fun.. It's getting built up, as all great destinations do. We hope it will stay "homey" for another year or two for us. Then we will have to find somewhere else with the same charm PDC had.

Changing and not for the better. Most of the locals and frequent travelers to Playa will agree with me that Quinta Avenida is changing and not for the better. In my opinion, Quinta is divided into two very different ambiances. From Avenida Constituyentes walking south, you will find the horrible new addition of a mall with a second one under construction. This area is very much a tourist trap. It attracts a heavy drinking and somewhat obnoxious crowd. It is loud and overwhelming and the restaurants are generally not very good and attract the unrefined tourists. From Ave Constituyentes walking North I have consistently had a different experience. Excellent restaurants and caffe's, more refined tourists, nicer stores, less drinking, nicer music and less pushiness. So pick your side!
If you love to get hustled - come here!. Sorry - I stayed in Playacar and ventured on to Quinta Avenida twice...hated it. If you like being sold anything and everything - this is your spot.
To loose yourself at.... Everything a person may need to satisfy their travelling needs will probably be found here.. Bars, Clubs, Pubs, Restaurants, Currency Exchange, ATMs, beach access....

so touristic. This is a busy main street in Playa del Carmen. You will find nice restaurants and shops but I would also recommend to get a bit out of this area as you can find real Mexican restaurant a bit cheaper.
Cute little town. Lots to look at...had a good afternoon with the whole family just poking around in all the shops. We got some souvenirs. It was an easy taxi ride from our resort.
Daily walk and shop. There is a little bit of every type of entertainment here. Great restaurants on every block. Daytime or nighttime its all great.

A long collection of average and common chains. The street is a mix of restaurants and stores.
It used to be a nice heclectic mix, but lately there are more and more common American chains with the typical stores that you find in every suburban mall.

For everyone. It's great to have the chance of walking by the 5th Avenue and seat there to have lunch while people goes by, stop to make some shops, seat down and relax while enjoying a coffe. It just creates a great atmosphere!

So much to see...so much time. Of course gobs of tourist T-shirt shops, lots of time share reps, some over priced restaurants, but it is a great experience walking from the Muelle-Pierfrom calle 1 for 45 blocks to Calle 45(there is an extended section now north of Calle 24 that stretches to Calle 45, terrific new restaurants, a bit quieter than the rowdy 5ta Ave from Calle 1-24. Nice shops Zingara, Touche,

1 or 2 days is more than enough. You can only by so many souveniers and the tourists and those wanting to be seen become tiresome in not to long of a time. The stores are basically over priced souvinier shops with many touts trying to compete for your tourist dollars which are the main reason Playa exists. Sad to see the poor tigers mauled for dollars on the street other than the beautiful location and a nice night or two out the street gets old quick
great shopping. Excellent shopping and sightseeing. A lot of restaurants, not a lot of parking. Be careful of slick operators - you have to bargain.
Fun on Fifth Avenue. Lots of things to shop for-everything from t-shirts, sombreros, tequila, Mexican vanilla, etc., to fine jewelry. Also fun to people watch.

Variety of Shopping for Everyone in Playa. There so many different types of shops on 5th Avenue! Everyone speaks English and uses the U.S. dollar. No need to exchange money. There aren't many bathroom options so go if you're in a restaurant. All day and night can be spent here. There is art, souvenirs, bars and patios, night clubs, street performers, etc. The beach runs parallel so you have to walk it. At the end of the street is the pier to catch the ferry to Cozumel for the day ($20), which I also highly recommend. I personally liked to buy my souvenirs from the large stores that are premarked with prices instead of bartering all the time in the streets. Note that the further away you get from the main busy center the cheaper silver jewelry gets. Silver prices continue to rise each year I visit. Don't worry if the silver isn't polished. All the jewelry I have purchased shined beautifully when I got home with a polishing cloth. I even buy the silver overlay which is much cheaper and makes for great gifts. These don't tarnish easily. If you're sick and need medicine there are many pharmacies available. This is also the street to people watch! There are plenty of international travelers, backpackers, and hostels.

Didn't Mind the Store Owners but High Prices and Same Gifts. I had an okay experience here but it wasn't anything special. Many of the reviews are unfair when it comes to the store owners yelling at you to come in. I expected it and didn't really mind. What I wasn't expecting was the prices of the souvenirs. Not only did every store sell the same thing but they were extremely pricey. Everything is priced in US dollars to make things seem cheaper. When you see that $25 is about $350 pesos you realize how expensive it is. Where I stayed in Akumal the souvenir stores there were cheaper even though almost everyone there are tourists as well. If you are expecting to find many different gifts from Mexico and at an affordable price this place is not for you. The items are all the same and the prices vary extremely. There probably was about 10 different types of things each store would have. The street itself isn't that pretty too. It really isn't a worthwhile visit if your going to Playa Del Carmen just to shop on that street. We did have some pretty good gelato.
greaat. Great place to go go for a walk and to go shopping. You will find almost everything. Also great places to eat and all 1 block from the beach!!

walking the town. Fifth Ave, Playa Del Carmen. A walking only avenue stuffed with folks from around the globe looking to buy and eat and see and enjoy and they find it all. We visited 4 times out of a 12 day stay in the area. Better at night. Not to be missed

Hey meester. I found the walk here to be tedious. We made 2 trips to the area to shop and meet family for dinner. The street was packed and promised good people watching, but the shop owners ruined it for me. I want to be left alone and don't need someone continuously in my ear. The barrage was none stop. I hate shopping anyways, so don't make it an ordeal. Couple this aggressive behavior with high prices, and you have created a place to avoid. The highlight was the 12 man smash-and-grab with shots fired at the Jewelry store while we exchanging pesos next door. Thank you to people at the Diamond's International for letting us take refuge at their store.

flea market fare and fine gifts all thrown together. Shopper's Paradise. There are also many restaurants, bars and hotels on this strip.Toward the ferry dock (south) end of Playa you will find the beginning of this pedestrian walkway. It runs all the way through town and gets a little "classier" starting around Calle 24. Vendors can be a little annoying as they try to get you to come lok at their store front. We soon got used to "Hey lady.." and "Don't you recognize me? I was waiter/bellboy/fill in the blank. Anything to get you to stop. Once you learn how to ignore this you can freely explore the cool shops and interesting people on this one of a kind street. We loved it and can't wait to go back and find more treasures.Hint-try the shops in the alleys and off streets. They get less attention and therefore seem to have better prices.

Lots of shopping. Don't eat at Karen's - the food is not authentic and it was terrible! The shopping was fun. I didn't like that most stores don't have a price on their merchandise and try to charge very high prices. You can negotiate the price down though.

Super nice spot to walk around and spend the night!. This is the perfect complement to your hotel stay in Playa del Carmen. There are nice gift shops for souvenirs, there are nice stores to buy anything you need, restaurants, bars, clubs, etc. There is a lot of life of this street, music, people, ambience, etc. Definite must visit for anyone in Playa.

Disappointing mall culture continues to spread and consume PdC. Having travelled to PdC repeatedly over the years it saddens to see it be bulldosed, gentrified, and genericized. The best parts of 5th ave have been torn down to build glossy shopping malls with "high end" merchandise which is 10-15% marked up from prices you might pay at home.With Gentrification comes the inevitable rise in prices as well. I do not mind paying the same price for a meal in PdC as I would back in Canada but if you are charging between 4 and 5 dollars for mexican beer it had best be directly on the beach not on the 5th Ave T shirt tout strip.Luckily Fusion Bar and Grill still can deliver on that note but with PdC city doing poorly on beach erosion it may be gone in a few years. Overall I still love PdC because of the climate, the weather, and the wonderful people, but I am hunting for a new last minute winter escape destination. One that has some of the charm and character of PdC of old.

Browsing shops, eating ice cream or people watching. Had a great time, as always, when visiting Quinta Avenida in Playa. :) Always fun to shop, eat ice cream, get a massage or just people watch. Safe and popular place to visit.

This is where "it's happening"!!. The street is calm during the day which is very pleasant and as the sun goes down the nightlife takes place.You get to see a lot of entertainment, restaurants and stores.You will always get bothered by the ambulant tour vendors if you are interested in an attraction, negotiate the price and don't hesitate to tell them you found cheaper elsewhere!Insist on asking how long the shuttle fair is, sometimes they pick you up at 8 and make you wait 2 hours at a store and then you loose an other hour of sleep because of the one hour drive.All the restaurant we tried were very good and everybody in town is awesomely niceWe tried the massage places, the fish spa, the waffles..... etc....We had an amazing time and enjoyed all the night clubs for free (only girls)

Nice walk. Long avenue lined with shops, excellent to wander down at night or day time, never had any hassle from shop owners or touts.Plenty of bars and restaurants. Souvenir shops a plenty but are a bit Sameish. Must see men on pole at about 7.30 pm. No litter or drunks, very refreshing!

One stop shop. This street has everything you could possibly want. Mexican souvenirs, performers, food and drink, and then a heavy American influence which keeps the huge number of visiting American folks happy. The street is clean, vibrant and outrageously colourful. Many ATMs so you will never have any issues getting out MXN or USD.There are a lot of tour operators trying to sell excursions to nearby beaches, dives, parasailing spots, ruins, cenotes etc, and the sheer number of them bidding for your commission means that you are guaranteed to find yourself a bargain, providing you are willing to negotiate a bit. The restaurants offer cheap drinks and happy hour deals to lure you in, and the food inside these establishments is a bit pricey, but great quality. One street back from the beach means that you can go for a swim and then come back for lunch and a shop, or vice versa.

Fun place. Reminded me of downtown duvall in key west,flordia loved to see all the americans living there with there full bread dogs i saw everyone with. However some the shops try to rip you off, i know hot to bargin and get a good deal and felt i only received one good deal from a shop that already had set prices.

Much improved, especially the middle and south. We last visited Quinta Avenida (Fifth Avenue) a couple of years ago and it was all shop keepers trying to drag you in off the street, telling whatever stories (or lies) they needed to. It was pretty uncomfortable if your not into the give and take (they don't give up easily once you take the bait!).This time was much better, the shops a little more polished and little aggravation. The northern end of the street and any off streets still have that feel from the earlier trip.Good selection of shops and restaurants though you'll find almost all the same items at the same prices no matter where you go. Very few exceptions.We were looking for a "Caterina" doll, the "Day of the Dead" personage and we didn't want a cheap, papier-maiche or plastic one. Turned out to be tough to find, but find we did at a small art shop right off the town square. Very nice pieces but not cheap. We selected a smaller one (partly due to the price and partly due to his cash-only policy) but the shop keeper really knew his art and had a good selection of pieces and price ranges.The square had some entertainment in the evening from Aztec-Mayan dancers to the guys who swirl down on ropes from the top of a tower (not sure where that's from).You can spend a lot or a little here, both in time and money. Still, a good diversion after a day at the beach.

I Love Playa del Carmen. Don't be afraid to walk down 5th Avenue. It's a beach town. Lots to see. Great people watching. Many good Mexican restaurants. Lots of vendors. If you are not interested in shopping, just say "Gracias, No", Smile and keep on walking. Don't be afraid to haggle for a good price if you want to buy something. Stop for a drink and a bite to eat. A tourist town with a lot to offer. Has everything from street vendors to high end shopping. Acknowledge the shop owners...a smile goes a long way. Enjoy!

Be careful. Prices are ridiculously high. The vendors make a show of weighing the silver and then will drop 50% if you say too high. Even with 50% off pretty much everything I saw in jewellry was over $100USD. I bought 2 small earrings and when I went to put them on back at the resort, the claws fell apart. I returned to the store and was given a lot of 'nothing we can do'. I was told that my visa purchase could not be refunded. Eventually I was given replacements and really that was to get me out of the store, away from other customers. Clothing is for the size 2-4 women and the prices are high.The experience was disappointing.
Ok. That's the Main Street where to walk in the night and meet new friends. All the pubs and restaurants are there. So need to walk around.
Main Street 5th Avenue. Always busy, full of bars, hotels, shops and restaurants. Noisy till all hours.So touristy, Playa del Carmen totally spoilt now, will be like Cancun soon.
Great ambiance. Lots of boutique, restaurant, music full of people every night looks like the chinese town in New York

Very aggressive sales. If you want to shop here know what you are looking for in advance and how much you want to spend because these vendors will grind you down and when you say no and start to walk away some will follow you trying to close the deal. But there are lots of shops to look in and most have unique pieces so if you don't see something you love in the first one, keep looking. It is interesting and there are lots of restaurants but they get more and more expensive the closer you get to the ferry terminal.

love vs hate. You find better food at better prices if you just go a couple streets away. There are far too many people trying to sell you things. But at the same time...there's so much action there that you have to see it, and somewhat love it :-) Everything you could possibly imagine is on that street and if you can't speak or don't want to speak Spanish than you can stay there and not have to worry.
shopping. Great place to shop, know what you want and be kind to the vendors who are asking for a Mexican minute to check out there shops.

Not my cup of tea. Went to Playa to go shopping one after while in the Mayan Riviera. There are lots of higher end stores here and it seemed like a sunglass hut on every block - weird!Way too many people, WAY overbearing shopkeepers and the same touristy stuff you can get anywhere - likely for less. The little park was beautiful - the statue at the entrance to the beach and the church. We got to see the guys performing the pole swinging dance and that was pretty awesome! I would go back to Playa but would skip this street next time.

The life of Playa del Carmen. This is where you find everything about Playa! Restaurants, shops, massage parlours, hotels, jewelry shops, etc. etc. you name it they have it. It is particularly pleasant stroll in the warm but not hot evenings. Hundreds of visitors from all over the world mingle on the avenida, walking, shopping, eating or just enjoying the atmosphere. We are in Playa for seven weeks and never got bored enough not to take a stroll again and again.

NIce, good food. La quinta avenida is the center of life in Playa del Carmen, food can be very good to very bad, but we have a good experience, prices are ok for US standards, not a good place to buy hand crafts , expensive... just 1 block from the beach and the ferry to Cozumel, very good Tacos in the 10th avenue Don Sirlon, try the Sirlon ones
nice street with loads to do. 5th Av is a nice street with loads of bars, restaurants and souvenir shops. whatever you like you can find it here. :)

this is where it is happening. I visited la Quinta Ave during day time and evening a must 2 different views of the same location, at night lots of activity Marichis, clubs and yes you may still do some shopping, enjoy a pizza, or a cold gelato and watch the people go by

Good people watching--sometimes too touristy. You should go here at least once during your stay in Playa, but be prepared for a mixed experience. There is very little that is authentic about 5th Ave. There are the same stores you see in every city and then there are a lot of cheap souvenir stands. A few good restaurants pop up here and there. Mostly it is a great place for people watching. I recommend grabbing a drink at a cafe and taking it all in for a while. The street vendors can get a little aggressive offering everything from bric-a-brac to more illicit wares and substances depending on the section and time of day. Take it all in for an afternoon or a night out and you'll be ready to go back to the beach.
Shopping. Be careful...they will take you your money if you let them! They WILL drop their price...you have to walk away for that to happen!

TOURIST TRAP. Hordes of tourists flood the streets daily. While they are a more attractive "European" set than Cancun, the feel is not much different. Make your vacation a true "getaway" by staying in Tulum instead. It's more central for the ruins anyways and has the best beaches in the Riviera Maya.

its 5th avenue baby :). any day, time of the day and even better arond 7pm and after, full of life, all sort of performances like singers, dancers, golden people and exotic mayan dancing shows on the beach. u wont be disappointed if bright colors, crouds of people,exotic sounds of music and amazing souvenirs, u wanna buy straight away left and right. is what u r looking for

Fifth Avenue. Lots of shops to visit, lots of restaurants to try, lots of places to, as one shop keeper says "let me rip you off lady". Interesting place to people watch as well. Great place to try your bargaining skills.
