Worth a visit, but buyer beware.. I've been up and down the avenue over my past 4 trips to the area probably over 20 times. On cloudy days it will be packed, on hot sunny days it is nearly unbearable, nights are really the best time to enjoy the breezy avenue and a laid back atmosphere. Beware of the hustlers, if you are ready for them, you can breeze on past them. The last scheme I encountered recently was them approaching me and saying "remember me? I was your waiter at the hotel yesterday" then they try to hook you into buying their crappy stuff. The trick is that they spot the hotel bracelet you have on. They also seem to be very skilled at spotting where you're from, anything to try to hook you into a conversation. One guy even said if I don't want souvenirs maybe I'd like pot or something harder...yikes. It's really not uncommon to get offered drugs at least once, I find it really offensive myself at the thought of how much trouble a foreigner could get into, never mind suggesting that you might be the sort of person that does drugs in the first place. For the super pushy types I don't see a problem with ignoring them, saying NO forcefully or even saying "basta" if they won't get out of your way. The high end shops won't push you at all. The gelato shops make any evening stroll a true delight. For those craving starbucks you're in luck, they have two of them.During the day it is nice to walk from one pier along the beach and then come back up to 5th ave and walk back along the avenue. Zenzi is one example of a great beach bar, it is by the lighthouse, wonderful nachos, relaxed atmosphere, and live music in the evenings.
Becoming more and more commercial. We now see more and more stores that we find in our local shopping malls. Fewer typical mexican shops and restaurants.

tiresome after a while. I actually love Quinta Avenida, but this is the first time I was there solo. There is a lot to see (if you ignore the tourist crap). Great restaurants, so nice little galleries, but you have to venture off 5th to see the real PDC.Hucksters everywhere of course, it's a tourist town. By the end of my 2 weeks I avoided 5th and walked down 10th to get anywhere.
Go further!. 5th avenue is awesome...especially past 12 calle. Keep going! The restaurants are great and the shops get better the higher the street. We love it around the 30s!
5th Ave Quinta Avendia Market. This is most interesting and excellent market in Playa Del Carmen. Right on the ocean and easy access to the water taxi to Cozumel.
Nice inviroment and clime. Like pretty much the tropical type weather.The food was not extraordinary so good,just basics typical Mexican food.

Restaurants, shopping, drinks and fun!. La 5a Avenida is the point in playa del Carmen. A block away from the beach and where all the good stuff is! Shops with international products, restaurants, bars, hotels and massages! We first had a hotel close by which was good, but staying in the 5a Avenida was even better (we stayed at a good hotel called Maya Azul - between 10 and 12 street). If you wanna save some money and it doesn't bother you to walk a little, you can stay farther from the main street and near walmart for example (it's a 4-5 blocks walk). But keep in mind you have to walk this distance with bags if you are catching the bus back to Cancun (bus station on 5a Avenida and 2nd street).There is always something to do and the only complaint is that restaurants and bars can be very loud, even late at night (even though from our room we couldn't head a thing).

Fun experience shopping.. Quinta Avenida has lots of shops and restaurants. Many of the restaurants have bars in them that have two for one happy hours, where you actually get two large margaritas for the price of one! The shop owners like to bargain, so don't accept the first offer. Some people may call them pushy, so make sure that you have some guts to keep bargaining, but they are trying to get the best deal, as is the buyer. There are several restaurants on the avenue as well. Pretty much anything is available on Quinta Avenida. Some of the shops have samples of food and liquor, so you can really have a taste of the Mexican experience. At night, there are street performers and artists, and its really just a must see! Make sure you give yourself some time because it takes more than a day to actually go and see all that the Avenue has to offer. There are bathrooms there, but most of the places request that you buy something to use the bathroom (just some fair warning).

Nifty shopping venue.... If shopping is your game....this is your playground in the area.Took my teenager daughter on a dull day & she loved it. Perfect for a spot of retail therapy. She loved the new shopping area & it was a nice touch having a Pandora outlet to top up her collection of charms, good value compared to the U.K. Pandora too, I found that you save about 30% off the RRP...it all helps when you have a daughter with expensive taste.You can pick up good prices on the high end branded cosmetics too, such as Clinique , bio therm , clarin & they even have a Mac store. Much better range than expected, and better prices than Cancun airport, get your perfumes etc here if you want to save money.It's a retail jungle out there!
Very touristy but a must see.. Any and everything in Playa is available on Quinta, for a price. Late nights have all kinds of street performers and artists.

A must in Playa area. If you are going to be in the riviera maya you need to check this gem out! Shop after shop after shop and restaurants galore. You need to go into this with good spirits as they do tend to come off pushy but if not interested a simple no thanks and carry on. The beaches there are also so beautiful and the cozumel shuttle docks right by senor frogs which is another definite must!

Exactly what one would expect. I stayed in a hotel that was 20 yards from 5th avenue and that was PLENTY close. Its convenient to have an assortment of retailers so close to your hotel....its not that convenient when you intentionally start walking a street over to avoid it and the aggressive merchants. I mean, I get it...they're trying to sell their wares, tourism is the main industry....it can just get a little overwhelming and frankly old. I still gave it a 4 because there ARE a great assortment of stores, its usually very well maintained, minimal trash strewn about, and security is not an issue at all. I was probably referred to as "Brown Sugar" by the vendors at least 40 times in 5 days on 5th Ave, annoying - yes....Uncomfortable - no. Having said that, prepare to be HEAVILY solicited on this strip and take your patience with you!

Interesting but touristy. This is a cool street to visit...lots of vendors, artists, restaurants, and stores to visit. I personally don't like the touristy feel, but we stayed right off of Quinta Avenida, so I really only walked on this street to get to somewhere else. You get hassled by people trying to sell you stuff literally every 5 seconds. And the prices are pretty ridiculous...For example, I paid $70 pesos for a pair of earrings in Chichen Itza and was offered a similar pair on Quinta Avenida for around $1,500 pesos. (Ridiculous!) Could have just been the store, but I found in general the vendors elsewhere were way cheaper. I also found you couldn't casually stroll the street and browse the different stores because of how aggressive the sales people are. We avoided this area for that reason...it just became frustrating having to constantly avoid or refuse their offers.

Nothing special. The main drag of Playa del Carmen is a combination of overpriced souvenir shops, restaurants/bars and pushy salespeople on an uneven, cobblestone street with no redeeming architectural charm. The highlight was the baggettes we bought at the French bakery.

The heart of Playa de Carmen. What is there not to love about this busy pedestrian strip! It epitomises what Playa de Carmen is. Great to people watch, drink at bars and eat at the many restaurants around. Shopping is very commercial and expensive compared to other cities like Oaxaca, Uxmal, Puebla and Merida but I expected it to be. It is a touristy haven.

A picturesque experience but beware of pushy salespeople!!. I've been living in Playa for a little over a year and still find going to 5th quite pleasant to walk with my wife. Great dining to be had from the variety of restaurants but the salespeople just kill it! Especially the novelty and souvenir places, those guys are so aggressive, pushy, and at times offensive to passerby's that instead of stopping to gaze at their stuff you pretty much hurry along so that you don't get pounced on should you decide to stop in for a quick gaze.Let the people be and they will spot your stuff, I mean it's not like you don't have it halfway out on the sidewalk. It's been recently taken over my more international famous brands and its losing its Mexican allure. I would go as far as saying that tourist will not have much to see if the trend continues and it basically turns into a trip to the mall for the average tourist.
Long, long shopping street. Fun to explore.....it's all there....the good and the bad. Some good food, some fun shopping AND a crazy "Fish Spa", where tiny fish clean your fee. What's not to love?

Very touristy, good for people watching and strolling. This is Playa del Carmen - a wonderful town by turquoise waters of the Caribbean where hundreds of superfit Europeans descend to play. The air smells like a magical mixture of sweat, fragrance, alcohol and smoke. This is the quintessential tourist stretch of PDC but don't let this bother you. Instead, embrace it, people watch, walk around and be grateful for the experience it is in itself.
Amazing restaurants and drinks. Excellent shops, restaurants and gift shops. Strongest salsa in Mexico, best Coronas and tequilas. Better go in the night - it's too hot under the sun...

unique- not to be missed. This location is deemed the 5th avenue of Playa Del Carmen/Quintana Too. Rightfully so as its name is 5th Avenue, but more impressive is its unique assortment of vendors. Everything from tequila/liquor shops that offer free tastings (which after a couple of those who needs high priced drinks at the many restaurant/bars in the area?!), to drugstores that sell souvenirs (including tequila), to fabulous coffee shops & quaint little artisan vendors. They have all kinds of trinkets & larger items as well for taking home as a remembrance of this wonderfully unique place. Busy and bustling at times & yet cozy & SAFE. Watch your pocketbook though as you may end up buying more than you thought you would. Of course that is because you NEVER pay full asking price for anything. Remember, it is an ASKING price. Have fun &check out this place with friends or family. You will take with you not just souvenirs, but memories as well. After all, isn't that what life is made of?

Fun, but a bit pricey.. Fun for the most part. We did see some fighting later at night, but normally it is a couples or family friendly experience. However be advised. The restaurants are sometimes ridiculously priced and good, cheap Mexican food can be found close by. If you look around though, there are good dels. Not great, but the environment makes up for it. Also, this is a beautiful city, but I have never been lied to by so many people in my life so check every receipt and get all tour details and such in WRITING! Consider breakfast at kolos club for 140 pesos. The buffet on the beach is great, and actually cheaper then most the over priced restaurants.

Very tourist place, but still nice and interesting to have a walk. I liked the variety of restaurants and bars, evening walks along the quinta avenida with all those people. Didn't like the pushy shop owners or attendants.

Nice but too american.. The place itself is nice but be prepared to pay overpriced souvenirs, plus the shops are not quite in touch with the authentic Mexico.The atmosphere is closer to the U.S. and far from Mexico.

Great shopping. This a great area to shop for souvenirs and enjoy the walk. Great places to eat there. The taxi drive to get there is about 50-80 dollars. Also make sure change currency the will take dollars but it easier if you change your currency.
Something to do. Fun to see, decent shopping of you are in the mood to haggle. If its within walking distance of your hotel, why not? Wouldn't take a cab to get there.

What you need to know.... There are alot of neat things about 5th avenue - the street performers (saw a fire twirler, guys costumed as Mayans, a guy with monkeys and a guy with a lemur that you could have your picture taken with), the cobblestone streets,and the lively atmosphere. The negatives are that the prices in the shops are usually higher than on 10th avenue (the rent costs them more on 5th, I'm sure), it is somewhat of a hassle to walk down the avenue with so many merchants trying to get you to "come see my store" The other thing you need to know is this: if you're staying at an all inclusive and wearing a wrist band, some of the merchants will lie and tell you they were your waiter at the resort you were staying at (ie..."hey lady, it's me Roberto, you know - your waiter from the Gran Porto Real. Come see my store.) At first, I was confused because I didn't remember him being my waiter but I couldn't figure out how he knew where we were staying. Then I remembered the wrist band. They can identify your resort from the wrist band and I heard this phrase used repeatedly - not just on me but on several others as well so beware.

Love Shopping here.. Love all the little shops with real Mexican goods and the friendliness of all the people along the way. I am hoping that they will not allow any more big malls to be build, this takes away from the ambience of 5th avenue. We do not come to Playa del Carmen to see exactly the same stores we have at home!!!!!

Expect to get hassled. I think the trip up and down 5th is worth it, just to see what the local tourist trap area is. We had numerous people that were a little to aggressive with their sales pitch, and that became offputting after awhile. We were offered everything from Cuban cigars, to illegal drugs. Not my favorite part of Playa.

Worth visiting. Worth visiting. Great to walk at night, to window shop, and to negotiate for some souvenirs. Some of the restaurants are great, but also try some places off this strip to get more delicious and much cheaper meals!

Get north of 18th and you'll like it better. We walked up and down 5th a couple of times and really hated it because of all the aggressive shopkeepers. Some will pretend to recognize you from your hotel - if you have a wristband on try to hide it so they can't play that game. We were looking for Casa del Habano and finally found it at 5th and about 28th. That part of 5th is very nice - good shopping, no hassles, some nice restaurants. Once you get back towards the taxi stand at 18th, the hassles start again.

Been There - Done That. If you've been anywhere in Mexico before, you've likely seen everything that 5th Avenue has to offer. And it shouldn't surprise you to be greeted by very aggressive vendors. Some are indeed funny with new attempts to get you to stop and look. We made a few purchases. There's a store a few blocks down from Constitution on the south side of the street that sells Christmas ornaments.

This is not Mexico. We went to visit 5th avenue late one afternoon, as we were staying at a near by resort. Not impressed. Vendors are very aggressive to the point of being annoying. Lots of expensive American stores. The street itself is nice, but the overall experience from the aggressive vendors spoils it. If I go back to the area, I will not return to 5th avenue.

Charming place. This is the street where people go out to drink, eat and buy. So if you are in Playa del Carmen, you must probably end up here doing one of these things. We really loved the restaurants in this place, It is a pity I can't quite remember the names, but anywhere you go here should be fine.

No gracias!. I was shocked to read all the great reviews and it made me wonder, do my husband and I really look like that much of suckers? My husband and I tried to enjoy ourselves but couldn't walk more than two steps without being harassed by pushy salespeople. If you are wearing a wristband from your resort it is like wearing a target, salespeople know which resort you are staying at based on your wristband. We could not enjoy ourselves because we were approached every five feet. We bought a couple bottles of tequila and quickly returned to the resort.
Busy and fun.. A lot like Times Square in NYC … practice saying "No gracias" before you visit if you don't like being bombarded by salespeople out on the streets. Lots to see and experience.

The main drag in Playa. This is a great street for browsing, shopping, or just people watching. You can find anything from jewelry to handicrafts, hand rolled cigars, liquor and restaurants to Mariachis singing at night. Very safe for walking at night through the center of town. It is touristy but it is still a fun experience.

Brilliant. Went to 5th Avenue in August 2013, great experience, safe walking around the shops and bars. the sellers were not pushy and understood the word 'NO' . If you go to this Mexico this is a must.

A very busy street, makes you feel the mexican rhythm of life.... Everything is pretty expensive. You need to bargain everywhere as the price usually reflects a 50% mark up )) especially on silver items... Better to buy souvenirs at Isla de mujeres (Women's island) and Chichen Itza...

colorful/something to do. We took a taxi from our resort which was a breeze. As soon as we got out of the car vendors were haggling us...every step of the way. We went during the day...was a little rainy but that didn't stop us. You really have to know how to deal with the aggressiveness from the vendors. It was fun though. We talked to a lot of the vendors and made it funDon't buy the first thing u see as....you will see it a million times. Very safe, never felt uncomfortable at all. Would love to go at night, but didn't get a chance. Lots to do, eat and meet people from all over...fun day out

Touristy fun. Quinta Avenida is the touristy area of Playa del Carmen. It seemed that most of the upscale shops were at one end, near Coco Bongo and more of the local stores and markets were at the other. One end had fixed prices and the other was happy to haggle with us for fun as well as sales. We tended to stay at this end, although I would note that prices here are still way above what you'd see in the market in downtown Cancun or Tulum. We did enjoy watching the street artists and playing with the pet monkey. In general the shopkeepers were aggressive, but not bothersome and very friendly and sociable. My husband bought a ring from one of the shops and questioned the average price for a comparable piece. The jeweler popped out his ipad and looked up comps on line and made sure my husband felt he was getting a good price. Not for good deals, but definitely good fun.
Enjoyable Avenue. Bars and restaurants in the afternoon and night are very good. Excelent live music, mexican and foreigner
Vivid Avenida!. Great place not to be missed - great shops, bars, restaurants and awsome clubs (on the Twelweth) for a great nightlife!

Great Ambiance!. An eclectic mix of people from all over. Great people watching! Whether haggling with shop keepers, grabbing a cold beer, or just walking around, just a fun time. Eveerything from really good and cheap tacos to high end dining. We love it.

lighten up and have a good time!. great strolling, people watching, restaurants, bars and shopping. the vendors can become annoying if you let them but we just laughed when they'd use their best lines: "hey, i'm your waiter from your hotel" or "hey mr hawaiian shirt". halloween was awesome with everyone dressed up. a must do when in playa.

FITH AVENUE FANTASTIC. Feel to be in Italy / Paris with all the charming restaurant and store full of colors and the street full of people strolling around from all over the world and you are in Mexico,playa Del Carmen to me Italian feel a place with out country people make this place original and definitely a fun place. At night is magic all the night club plaid the music you can heard from just walking around and bar get alive...with the Tequila!!!!!

5TH Avenue The Gauntlet. I liked the variety of merchandise available in the shops but if you are not accustomed to the "hard sell....in your face" etiquette of the 5th Avenue Street vender as I am....you will feel rather uncomfortable. But everyone was friendly and we actually had a good chat with several and had a few laughs.Food was excellent but beware....the price for a small meal is pretty high....Priced for the tourist for sure.

DRUGS ARE BACK ON 5th!. I was disappointed in my latest trip to Playa Del Carmen. The walk up and down Fifth Avenue was littered with "hey man do you want some weed, how about some cocaine." When I was here in April they were armed police everywhere and such activity was not so evident. I really hope that this activity gets under control as I would hate to have this area become run by the drug lords of the north. Don't get me wrong, we were never threatened or anything but I'm surprised by all the requests to sell drugs.

Worth A Walk ... Or Two. After my second visit to PDC; I will offer the following: 5th Avenue from Juarez (ADO bus terminal) north to Constitution is the better walk. The hassle from the ADO terminal down to the ferry to Cozumel has got to be the worst part of 5th Avenue. If you are doing the ferry then go down 4th or 2nd to the beach and walk the sand; trust me! Wondering how to get out of 99% of vendor hassles? Say "soy Russo!" Forgive the spelling but it means "I am Russian." Vendors don't speak Russian and they will say "oh" and wave you by. Hard to not laugh when you pull it off but wait until you are 50 feet away or they'll know you were kidding.I agree with my fellow reviewers who say buy from the side street souvenir vendors for a better price. Watch out for buying, let's say, 6 items and getting to the register and finding out there is the price you thought and the price they ring up. Do not start setting items aside; just tell them you don't want anything and nevermind. All of a sudden someone speaks English and it was just a misunderstanding. All of the larger gift shops are like this.Otherwise, enjoy the walk and browsing. Do it alt least once during the day and do not miss doing the walk at least once during the night. I prefer the night walks. Enjoy!
many stores. walk around!. There are many stores, restaurants and bar around there. it is a good place to walk around!! I like Playa del carmen more than Cancun!!! a little bit too touristy.

Extremely expensive and COUNT YOUR CHANGE but safe and fun to window shop and people watch. We are now here for a week. Super duper touristy. Typical hawking from vendors but not as bad as in Mercado 28 in Cancun. We are tired of the local food and haven't had a good meal in a month, was looking forward to great food in Mexico but have only been disappointed so we were happy to see a subway. We got 2 BLT With double meat and were in bacon heaven. Then I looked at my receipt and saw they charged us 6 times for the extra meat!!! I found this kind of thievery to be common in Mexico...starting from the minute we landed in Mexico City. We went to the OXXO in the airport and bought 2 disgusting sandwiches and were charged for 3!!! This pathetic robbery goes on all the time. In the past month, it's happened 7 times...that I was aware of. We actually came to Mexico to live for a few months or longer but after a month of many thieves and outrageous liars, (and bad food) we want out of here as soon as our last prepaid hotel day is done!

Same old same old. Typical tourist street, higher prices than side streets, shop owners behave like they used to in Turkey years ago, constant hassle at every shop. this behaviour actually puts you off looking inside. On the plus side some good offers on beer buckets and no dodgy bills during the day. However at night watch out as most tend to sneak on tips and service charges at around 10-12% of the bill. Also watch out for the Photo con, the owner will ask for a photo for his collection then will appear a few minutes later trying to sell an overpriced bottle of local spirit with you photo on.

Lively but pushy. Fifth Avenue is a bustling and energetic, with lots of colorful vendors, smells, and people watching. It is true that you can find any souvenir, but if you go only 1-2 blocks off 5th avenue the prices are much lower and for the exact same souvenirs. There are some lovely artesan shops that are unique and sell neat vintage mexican art reproductions and El Dia de los Muertos trinkets. There are TONS of high ends stores as well. There's an incredible restaurant called Restaurante Frida with colorful murals of Frida and Diego. The restaurants lure you in with great drink specials, but then give tiny portions with hardly any tequila. Watch out for this. And check your bill's change twice! On the flip side, we stayed in a precious boutique hotel right on 5th avenue. When exiting and entering, there is no eluding the very persistent street vendors. They'll try anything to get your attention. We have tried saying, "No, gracias" in a polite manner...but this tactic drew more attention to us. Ignoring the vendors with eyes straight ahead seemed to work better. After four days, sadly, it has gotten a bit exhausting. Luckily we have arental car and take day trips all over the region.
Rentals at 5th avenue. We have a very good friend at the start of 5th avenue ,rents bikes strollers for kiddies and push buggies. Called panchos strollers and bikes drop in and say hi very friendly
Non stop fun. You have all types of restaurants, all kind of music, people from everywhere and you can wear your swimming suit or an elegant outfit

5th Avenue @ Playa del Carmen Sept 2013. OK, been here plenty of times and all good. It depends on what you individually want. If you want to see the many vendors with the same item, calling you in for 'cheap' items along the avenue, then go for it. If you want a little higher end stores, they have that also, but you pay more of course. Playa is no longer a 'cheap place' due to the tourism...BUT, it still is a place that you should visit if you are in the area, just to see the sights and get a little taste of the town. The beach is beautiful and you can rent a chair/lounger and eat and watch the sea, and of course, more sights. Shopping or otherwise, a visit is a good experience. PS: Hide your wrist band if you come from a all inlcusive hotel.

All you need is here. Basically you will find here anything you need and more. From souvenirs, clothing stores, restaurants, coffee shops, bars and clubs, you name it! A cool place to go for an evening walk. The only not so good thing is shopkeepers might get in your nerves because they try too hard to sell their products. They will say or do almost anything to get your attention, so be aware! sometimes they can get too pushy and aggressive. But just say a firm no! and they will stop harassing you. But other than that this is a very touristic place to hang out. Nice!

Pushy, in your face, intimidating. We got dropped off by taxi at one end & fancied a nice stroll through the streets & browse of the shops but we barely put our feet on the ground before we were continually harassed by shopkeepers trying to persuade you to visit their shop! They even try & convince you they know you by saying they are waiters at your hotel (they clock your all inclusive wrist band so they immediately know where you're from)Honestly, could someone please let Mexican shopkeepers know that if they give the tourists some space they'd get more business!!I was pleased to see some building going on of some of the bigger chain stores (forever 21 & Victorias Secret), next I go I'll get to browse in peace!We eventually got so fed up with it we jumped in a taxi & shopped peacefully in Walmart
Full of life and nice shops and restaurants. We really like this place. Good beach clubs, restaurants, bars and shops. Nice to walk around at night before and after dinner

Great Area. You will find everything on 5th avenue, don't forget to walk both sides...from 28th to 3rd...and look through the hidden sides, you may miss great places like Casa Mediterranea great place to eat Italian food ..ask for LUCA and don't miss La Bodeguita del Medio which is an amazing bar with real Cuban band and locals dance salsa...fantastic service - ask for our bartender Claudia! She was great!! You can find everything on 5th. Be aware, most accept credit cards except American express, note that street vendors only accept pesos, so always carry some!!

Something for Everyone on Quinta Avenida. Quinta Avenida (Fifth Avenue) is the center of all tourist activity in Playa del Carmen. It features 20+ blocks of shops, restaurants and bars along a pedestrian-only street. If you go to Playa, I encourage you to stay within walking distance of Quinta Avenida - the feel (at night, especially) is fairly European mixed with South Beach. Live music is very common, and because everyone comes together on Quinta Avendia, we've always found it to be very safe and family-friendly. A must do!
Fifth Avenue is almost endless. We totally enjoyed Quinta Avenida because it wasn't just a few shops but a seemingly endless street of shops, restaurants and things to see and do.

Souvenir Shopping. It is a nice place to do souvenir shopping for gift items...clean street, nice restaurants and good looking stores! lot of tequila to choose from. However, store people would try to convince you any which way they can to invite you inside their stores...it is a little turnoff...but, it is an experience to stroll down the street and check out unique Mexican merchandise to bring home as souvenirs.

Very Quaint. This pedestrian-only street is at the center of all of the action in PDC. Love it all! So many restaurants and shops. Some shops are now becoming pretty upscale and this will become like Cancun in the next five years which may be too bad as it will take away from the quaint character of this town

Of course I love it!. Of course I love Quinta Avenida! That's one reason I go back every year or more! I especially love it at night with the hustle and bustle, the music and atmosphere as you walk around. All the restaurants and bars to choose from. Yes, the some of the vendors are aggressive but you just say, "No Gracias!" and give them a big smile....or just don't make eye contact! Some of them have started saying, "Don't you remember me from the hotel?", so I started saying it first and it throws them off guard. Just have fun with them, they mean no harm....they're just trying to make a living.
Beach is beautiful... Tonnes of shops... Bargain and barter. Pretty aggressive merchants... Be prepared to haggle and tell no one its your first time there. Make sure to visit the playa.
Nice shopping.... But watch out for pushy sales people, timeshare vendors and pick pockets. You can't walk down the avenue without someone calling out to you to enter their shop.

Don't bother with it.... This is a typical Mexican shopping district, with store owners following you down the street for blocks trying to convince you to shop in their store. I finally relented to one persistent owner, and asked if he had an umbrella. 15 minutes later, he returned to me with a cheap Totes knock-off umbrella and wanted $26 for it, when I can buy the real thing in the US for less than $10. He finally came down to $13 after following me for another two blocks, but he was never taken seriously after such an absurd opening price.I spent about 4 hours there, and got maybe 3 bargains, but the time expended in shopping would have been better spent elsewhere...

Another example of interesting walks into shops that don't sell anything I want.. This street is several blocks long filled with typical low end tourist trinkets. It is a fun walk but not exactly a shopping destination. One of the more interesting shops sold several hundred types of tequila and its variations.

Great Place to Stroll. It seems I can never get enough of Playa del Carmen and 5th Avenue. This is a favorite place of mine for my husband and I to go in the evening. There is lots of great shopping and plenty to do.

Quinta Ave shopping. Clean and nice spot to explore. Very close to the beaches. We felt very safe there as there is a lot of police presense. The shopping has some good deals, but it helps to compare different stores. Some annoying aggressive sellers but that comes with the territory.

bad place for a non shopaholic. Trinketmania, overpriced restaurants, constant assaults by hawkers.Had to use the ave to get to the bus station and the Cozumel ferry...and I have a friend , who's a shopper. I am definitely not. If u need cheap trinket gifts, it's ur place. Otherwise I avoid it.
Adventure. We really enjoyed playa del Carmen if you've never walked or toured the city it's got lots of markets and wonderful people to meet. This is where I and my husband got tats

Playa del Carmen 5th Avenue. Very good restaurants and like the fact that most have outdoor dining. Weather is usually very good in January, not hot and not cold. Many different shops with a wide variety of items. Not bothered by the hawkers, just say No Gracias and you are left alone. Like to go in the later afternoon, walk around, have a drink outside, then dinner a little later. Don't have to cover the whole 5th Ave with one visit. Only cover a small portion since we good there at least 3 times per week and usually there for 2 weeks. Also try the smaller restaurant off on the side streets where you can get great food at very good prices.

obligatory trip. as the norm for any vacation it would be a shame not to experience fifth ave. what many do not do is check out the little side streets that have much to offer too, as well as the plaza down by the ferry pier , the fruit stands with amazing stuff, the free shows that happen by the ferry outflow, people watching, cigar making, just chillin and learning. just ignore the shop keepers if you can't say no politely , maybe you should avoid it. if they catch your eye they will try.we check it out every year just for s===ts and giggles, and have never had an issue. entertainment for me, but i am easy to amuse i suppose.

Quinta Avenida - Highway to Hell. Actually it goes straight through hell. First aspect of hell, it is hot. Like face of the sun/boiling water hot. It's Mexico, you have to expect it. It does however lower your tolerance for a lot. The main aspect of Quinta Avenida, the Seventh Level of Hell are the hawkers. "Amigo...Amigo...almost free." I understand these are locals trying to make a living, but they are aggressive and obnoxious. They will follow you down the street for a while. You cannot look at anything without being accosted. I was looking at a dress and before I knew it, the lady was actually putting one on me! I couldn't get away from this place fast enough.The saving graces of the street were the restaurant Yaxche and Aldo's Ice Cream. I really wanted to like this place. It's beautiful and I enjoyed the proximity to the beach as well as the beautiful hotels. I am sure there are good values to be had, but I don't want to be harassed to get them. I left purchasing nothing. I bought souvenirs at my resort's gift shop and at the airport.

Best commercial avenue we have seen in Mexico.. Great restaurants, wide variety of shops, no one harassing tourists, and very safe and clean.Over one mile long. You can go there every day of your vacation and not get tired of the options.All of this is two blocks from the beach.The north side is newer, and nicer--I believe. Have been there twice in the past year, and going back in December.

Nightmare on 5th Avenue. Did not see Freddy Kruger but we were traumatized just the same.Constant shakedown by time share people and aggressive shop keepers spoiled the fun.5th Avenue is great in concept, safe, colourful, inviting with many interesting items to see but it is spoiled by the constant barrage of carnival style huskers with their incessant questions and offers of cash and gifts all for a few hours of your vacation time.These guys would make a killing back in the states as used car salesman !I understand they are trying to make living but enough is enough, they spoiled our visit, but on the bright side it forced us to see the real deal only a few blocks up on Avenida Juarez.Real stores, where locals shop, better prices and no one bothers you at all !Of course this is my opinion but, that is why we post on Trip advisor is it not?Intelligent people read the reviews, draw their own conclusions and decide for themselves what is of value to them.I would still recommend you go here and make the best of it !

Quinta Avenida. Great shopping and restaurants of every kind. Most vendors know English and will accept either pesos or dollars. The further south you go the more you will find some "upper end" stores with better merchandise. Watch out for a new sales strategy...I saw you at (fill in the blank) resort. Not so!

enjoy the fun. fifth avenue is very busy with locals doing their best to tempt you. Some travellers complained about this - shame on them! Locals are only trying to make a living - they love to banter with you and share a laugh and joke - go on - have some fun - after all, you are on holiday!!!!!If you are not interested, then say so..........with a smile...........at no charge

The fifth avenue. Everytime we go to Playa del Carmen, we have to go for a walk through the 5th avenue. It is visited by a lot of tourists. It has many stores, restaurants, and hotels. You can find all sorts of things here, expensive and good sales. I´d advise for you to go in the evenings, cause it´s when it is so pretty, with all kinds of different colors of lights. There is also music playing everywhere. It is a "happy street!"

5th Avenue. It just keeps getting longer and longer, I remember when it was only 3 blocks long and now its approx 2 miles it has everything you want from Amazing international restaurants , to classy boutiques , great coffee houses and ice cream stores, the beginning of 5th Ave around the bus station is the more commercial stores with venders calling you to come and buy a mexican blanket and the newer end of Little Italy is more a mixture of upmarket unique and hippy healthy food places calle 38 end Ave 5th is really nice area full of unique Restaurants Le Cuevo De Chango and Green 373 are my favourite healthy places to eat.

Great place for food, beverages, shopping and people watching .. Excellent food from many cuisines, great people watching and meeting. Shopping and beverages . Clubs for the younger set. Many new and interesting restaurants as well as old favorites.

Although not the best, can not miss it. It the common street with a lot of stores & restaurants. The stores are a combination of souvenirs , local merchandise and national chains. What i didnt like is the people all over you to get your attention and to take you to their stores, it was a bit overwhelming

The busiest street in Playa..... This street have everything you'l probably need, great restaurants, souvenir shops( in some there are even pretty good deals - i checked in many places before that in the Rivera Maya), Car rental agencies, bars, expensive shops and lots of Mexicans who are bugging you along the way....

Most of What You Want. The first time we walked 5th Avenue it was a dirt road and about 6 blocks long. Times have changed. Now it is about a mile long and loaded with a variety of restaurants and shops. They vary from the very expensive to the nicknac/tshirt shops. Many different restaurants also with quite a difference in prices. And at the end of the street is the ferry to Cozemel. With mostly one and two story buildings, not a packed foot traffic, it still has the atmosphere of a quaint town and the sales people don't exhibit much pressure.

Always something new!. 5th Ave. has always been a staple of the playa Del Carmen area. It's a place where not only cruise ship passengers are able to explore but also those staying in the area. It's not meant for the locals for most everything on the "strip" is touristas. From trinket shopping to stopping someplace for a bite to eat and a cold beverage, 5th Ave. will always remain unchanged, for the most part.My only complaint is about the venders. I've spent the last 25 years traveling to Mexico and the venders have become more and more obnoxious with time. Be it screaming across the street at you to come into their store or calling you names, there is no limit to what they will do to "entice" you into their store. If the store has an obnoxious vender outside of it or has the music so loud I can hear myself think, I just keep on walking by. Being 99% of them have never been anywhere else in the world they don't understand that is not how to gain business. There are few other places in the world with such salesmen. I tend to shop on the off streets if I need anything at all, but mainly the only way to get be to walk the stretch is just to people watch while enjoying something cold to drink. As far as I'm concerned it's become too much like Cancun and it's overpriced. However, if you need a souvenir, this is the place to go.
Great people watching!. Tequila barrel is worth a visit does great nacho's! And staff dancing in senior frogs is worth a watch!! Took the ferry to Cozumel which was great!!

Great area!!. Feel totally safe, lots to see. Great shops, restaurants. Cab fare is reasonable too from Playa Del Carmen! I know they have a European section that I didn't have a chance to see and will be back for sure!
don't miss. one of most popular places to enjoy in Playa....a 20 block long pedestrian mall just off the beach....bars, restaurants, galleries, etc. Very nice

Shopping shopping shopping!. Lots of restaurants, from italian cuisine to mexican traditional. When local musicians plays for you during finner, please pay them. On 5:th aveny there are lots of bars but you have to be prepared to say " no thanks" to all barkers. Be friendly even though the are a bit annoying. The aveny has many shops and you can buy everything between icecream and leatherbags. Even massage and excursions. Cheaper than you're hotel can do. One negative thing is the mariujuanadealers. Bad!! Can be a bit crowdy so watch out for pickpockets.

Very nice, and very dodgy, at the same time.. We were staying in a Condo one back in front of Fifth Avenue, and did so for 2 weeks. We walked up and down it fairly regularly. We were three males, so were the target of quite a bit of hassle, mainly for drugs and prostitutes (I lost count of the times I was offered someone’s sister)Some of it was good humoured, but in all honesty, some of it was a little disturbing, and some of the things we were offered could not be published on this website.It is no exaggeration to state that we would be offered “Charlie” or “Blow” possibly 5-10 times a day whilst walking up or down fifth.We often went a block further back, to get from A to B, just to avoid some of the hassle.I am sure that if you are a couple or a family, you would not experience anything like the hassle we did, so don’t be too put off.There are some nice shops, and lovely bars and restaurants, so it’s pretty much impossible to avoid Fifth Avenue if you are staying in Playa.Overall though, it started to really get on my nerves.
Great Street to Stroll. Lots of stores and places to eat. The usual Mexican stores, but there's some great gems, mixed in with Art and local, real local handicrafts.

Nice apart from the weather. A 70 peso taxi ride and you are at the start of 5th av. Just as we got out the heavens opened again and we spent the next 20 mins or so in Starbucks. Yes there are lots of touts, but, all you have to say is no and that's it.Bought some souvenirs, yes they are tacky and cheap, but that's what holidays are for. Lol.Had a coffee and a coke in a cafe and watched the world go by, never once did a tout harass you then.A few hours spent mooching around the shops etc and we will be going back again..

You can find a "Quinta Avenida" almost everywhere. If you like shops, crowded streets, cheap souvenirs, and all that kind of staff, than this is the place for you.Quinta Avenida is not México. Streets and places like this can be find in Thailand, Malaysia, Turkey, Greece, or almost every tourist spot.However, the beach seems to be great, and if you are somewhere nearby (Riviera Maia), well, it desearves a look.

Touts everywhere!. The touts here absolutely ruin my enthusiasm to go anywhere. You cannot go more than a few feet without being bothered. It prevents me going near shops that I would like to look in and makes me avoid any restaurant with them outside. It spoils the vacation completely. I would not choose to come back to central Playa del Carmen because of it. Local businesses must deal with the problem before it kills the tourism

A happening place. Taking a stroll down the Avenida.....get accosted by friendly Mexicans. It's all part of the fun in playa. All sorts of shops such as souvenir shops, jewellery shops, clothing, restaurants etc...busiest street in Playa
excellent stroll also can find a lots of restaurants. you can stroll x hours and still return x more great restaurants and also close too coco Bongo best night life

A Nice Place for a Stroll. This is the heart of the tourist district in Playa. I can't think of a better place for people-watching. It feels very safe. Lots of places to eat and drink. Prices are better everywhere else.

This is the place to shop!. You can haggle with the vendors (even in the stores). Never pay full price. There's everything imaginable at this location. Make sure to do a walk through first to compare prices. They also sell plenty of street food. The restaurants are pricey and not worth it. There's also a Mayan dance show every evening.
always a nice walk and see. it is always nice to walk without cars!!!!!! shops are nice I have done a lot of walking and la 5a avenida is always changing..during the day is different that at night...

Excellent shopping. We stayed at Playacar Palace which is a few steps away from 5th Avenue. There are many options on 5th Avenue from Tommy Hilfiger, Starbucks, to more authentic Mexican wear and jewelry. Of course, there are many hagglers trying to get you in their stores, but keep walking and say, "No, gracias." If you are looking for something special, always bargain! There is always a better price.
Safe shopping. This is always an interesting walk. Lots of shopping and restaurants and bars. We've always felt safe being here.
Toned down fifth avenue,good place to go. Lots of variety, great food,possibility of great purchases,alive and pleasant. Some soliciting could be toned down.
Great entertainment. market places with lots of crafts, restaurants and pubs. a lot of people having fun and music all over
Take walking shoes. if you going to walk across 5th avenue have some good walking shoes on, because it is long and tireness.Great shops, icecream, bars, restaurants.

5th Ave in Playa del Carmen. Had a great time shopping on Fifth Avenue in town. Took a taxi in from the Occidental Grand Xcaret and had lots of fun. We found many different kinds of shops from tourist places to artists shops to major stores like Nine West. You'll find it all on Fifth Avenue.
Hip, Chic shopping & eating. Love the vibe of Quinta Avenida. A great mixture of locals and tourists. Hip, chic shopping and music. Take stroll, eat great food and shop, shop, shop.

Great evening entertainment. Sort of a classier Mexican Bourbon Street - always someone to pose for pictures with - monkeys and Mayan warriors. Great shops, from touristy to very artsy. Lots of affordable dining options and a romantic atmosphere. A must try is the Fish Spa - have little fish nibble at your toes!

good for souvenirs. great place to buy souvenirs, only thing is prepare to be accosted at almost every shop, they will try anything to get you to come into the shops even pretending to be a waiter from the hotel they think you are from, most can guess from the colour of your wrist band if you hide this then they just take a chance and guess, one of them was apparently from the palladium and served us the other night, and then we went back about 3 days later and hi was from another hotel and served us the other night, strange i only remember staying in one hotel lol, if you can put up with this ( i chose to just ignore them and only went into the shops i liked the look of) then its a great place to pick up some bargains, but do shop around as sometimes the hotel shops can be cheaper for some items.

Main street. Just like any main street people walk and shop. The difference is that here there are lots of great restaurants, great shops and tedious vendors.On the bright side, it is a colourful street that has pretty much anything you could need. Live performances, and so many great choices for restaurants.If you wish to dance they have that too.
Fifth Avenue. Lots of shops but very tourist driven. We went mid-day and it was very hot and humid. Made a couple of purchases and was able to deal for a good price.
Great place for shopping. Do not buy at the first store, take your time to look what they offer and ask for discounts. Try the tequila, and enjoy the Mexican culture.
Awesome!!. Perfect for souvenirs and the price is right if you haggle. Too many people trying to sell you something. Be polite when declining and acknowledge people and keep walking. Works best.
Great place!. Its very European! and the people actually dress up to go out!Very attractive people you see every where this is a must trydestination.

Great shopping and reasonable prices!. We had a fun evening shopping on Quinta Avenida. It is SO clean! We went at night and were happy that we did. It was still really hot and there are quite a few people. The vendors/store owners do heckle you a bit but it's in fun and not nearly as bad as downtown Cancun. I read reviews before we went and many said that the prices are expensive. I didn't find this to be the case at all. Everything seemed very reasonable to me. There are lots of restaurants to choose from. My husband and I ate at Mi Pueblo and it was FANTASTIC. Seating was outside too so it made for great people watching.

Tacky and a hassle. Gets worse everytime we go on it. Loads of people, pushy salesmen and more and more high street chain shops with matching prices and souvenir shops selling all the same things.We bypass the first part up to Constituyentes by using 10th Av. Must say that the second part is a lot nicer to stroll but for how much longer ?

Alot has changed in 8 years. it has changed...i kind of miss the way it used to be. Things just look more commercialized, with boxed in stores instead of open air stores. Still able to find good restaurants with good prices, you just need to research...also noticed more restaurants "including" the tip with the bill--thats a new one from 8 years ago Still interesting to watch the people go by while sitting street side. Got a pint of Haggen Daz plain vanilla for 200 pesos..... that kind of sums it up. .

All the restaurants are here. It's nothing amazing but all the good restaurants are here, tons of people and all kinds of bars and clubs in Playa are around. If you are in Playa, you have to end up here
the place to be. Love strolling Quinta Avenida. Fun to people watch, grab a drink, have a meal, and shop. Everyone is out strolling, its lovely.
fun. a lot to see, very fun close to beach, good offers, very save area.Restaurants, and shops, good to walk with friend, some live music.
Quinta Avenida. Fabulous place, great shops and restaurants. Great designer shops. Try Coco Bango. I loved the evening night life!
Way too hot this time of year. Had been there before, quite interesting, lots of stores and restaurants but it was so hot that evening that we did not stay long. Lots of walking involved.
Quinta Avenida, Playa del Carmen. Lots of options for dining, shopping, great atmosphere in the evenigns. Spans over 30 blocks of fun.
great shopping!. It was fun to be able to safely leave the resort and stroll down 5th Ave. Plenty of shops to perouse in, restaurants and bars galore! Made my trip even more enjoyable!
A giggle. No, it's not the real Mexico and yes, it's full of merchants wanting to sell overpriced tat, but it's fun.
Nice place with excelent restaurants. The best restaurants in Playa are located in Quinta Avenida. besides, it is a great place to walk on a romantic tour.
The heart of Playa. This is where everything happens! Nice shops and restaurants, live music and people watching. The place to spend some time and have a drink after the beach or a tour!

Fun for everyone. La quinta avenida is just a street, but it has all kinds of restaurants and bars for every type of personality. One block from the beach, and many clubs on the nearby streets. You'll always see something different on quinta avenida. You may go into one bar and have a margarita to go and walk around, shop, then hit the next bar for another one. Don't miss visiting calle corazon!

Overpriced and not the real Mexico. Please use your money in other areas and not in the overpriced Quinta Avenida. They already get a lot of money from overcharging. You can instead eat excellent quesadillas on 10 Avenida around 12th street or further down by the market on 10 Avenida and 10th street. Or by 2nd street in where the original Playa del Carmen is. El Fogon restaurant across from Mega supermarket is also excellent and a bargain for the food.
Go early in the day. So many shops we couldn't get to all of them. Don't buy from the first shops you see, same items for half the price further down 5th.

A lot of shopping and restaurants. I liked that there was always a place to dip in and eat and/or shop. There were plenty of tequila places for you to get free shots as well. I hated the way the people stand around asking you to come into their store or restaurant... THIRSTY for your money.
La Quinta Avenida Promenade. There are tons of great shops & restaurants!! It's very laid back and the beach is a block down either to your right or left depending on which direction you're walking!
Cool place!. Eat at Yo AMo Tacos... great food! The shops are pricey but a good place to walk around! The shop owners charge mostly in dollars...
Crowded but cool. A nice walking zone. Lots of stores, restaurants, people... You can find jewelry, shoes, t shirts. It's always changing

A Must Do in Playa. All visitors to Playa del Carment need to experience the fun and craziness that is "La Quinta" (5th Avenue). Be forewarned that you will have to develop some polite, but firm repsonses for the myriad of shop owners, vendors and restaurants that will beckon to you to look at their wars or menus. Everything from "Hey Family!! My turn to rip you off!" to "Hey, I have exaclty what you are looking for..." & my favorite "Almost Free!!" Choose your restaurants carefully, some are cheap with good "deals" ($80 pesos for 3 tacos and 2 beers), but you get what you pay for in quality. I HIGHLY suggest making your way to the north side of La Quinta (north of calle 34) for better quality restaurants and shops. Just norht of calle 38 there are EXCELLENT restaurants -- Kool Fish, the Local, Como Como, El Pirata, Pacha Mama, Cueva del Chango & Piola to name a few.

Shopping-Eating-Culture. You can find it all on 5th Ave. Great atmosphere. Love the smell of all the food at the restaurants and the Mariachi bands. It is also very safe and well protected!!! No Problemo!!!
Trendy. Loved this street full of shops and bars. Very trendy! Loved that fact that I walked only two blocks from my resort and felt safe at all times.

Cool little bars and restaurants!. Very unique experience with alot of various shops, outdoor bars and restaurants. Must see! If you like to mix the locals and tourist, you have to swing by. Very safe and good security. It has some very high end bars and shopping.

Lots of variation but a complete rip off.. We came here specifically for the shops. The people trying to get you in to their shops do use funny lines like 'don't you remember me from your hotel?' I fell for that. My husband couldn't stop laughing at me. As an over all experience it was great, I didn't mind people trying to get you to their shops but my husband was a bit irritated by that. Shopping must be a girls thing. We got a pair of 'silver' earrings after a lot of hugging and even then we came home and noticed that the '925 sterling silver' stam was fake. We kinda new it was a possibly so weren't too disappointed but keep an eye and check and double check for the hallmark. Now the prices - that annoyed me the most. I've been to a lot of places and I have not been anywhere that charges such prices for small trinkets (fridge magnets etc) Actually the prices in general were all outrageous. I don't believe for a second that the price is anywhere near what a Mexican would pay. I understand they need to make money but I would have bought 3x the amount I did if I thought it was reasonable. Saying that, you can haggle about the prices, just can take a while and even then the prices are unreasonable. Example a lady ask for 70usd for sunglasses you can buy on a market stall for £5. Or a key ring for 10usd. Maybe it's just me but it all seemed a bit steep. On a separate note: the beach is beautiful totally worth the visit too. For those who smoke: buy cigarets when going home on the plane. They were cheaper than in the shops by about 10/15usd. £28 a block or £24.50 if you buy two ( for Marlboro)

Nice shops, be careful. A variety of shops and interesting experience. Be wary of pushy vendors and be careful goinginto the side streets. Some of the side street venders will offer drugs and it can seem seedy anduncomfortable in some sections. Many of the prices are a little high for cheap souvenirs, but theplaces that are not busy will discount to almost 50%.

5a Ave Shopping. It's a nice shopping experience....loved how the vendors try and get you to shop in their store with some funny lines. There's a good variety of stores from the typical name brand to the local artesania (crafts). Definitely a better value to buy souvenirs here rather than at your hotel.

Nice walking street. I had higher expectations after reading all the reviews, but it's just a place to walk. Stores are kind of boring, lots of restaurants, currency exchange and massage places. I don't know why, but it didn't impress me really. We got into one of the stores which reminded me of ABC store on Hawaii, got a t-shirt for my husband. The only place I liked was a magnet store - so many magnets! Not necessarily the best quality, but a lot of variety, and tons of magnets. Seriously, all walls covered in them!
Nice to visit. Great shops to buy souvenir's for folks back home. Great stores to shop at and clean and safe surroundings.

Love the better shops. Great restaurants and better shops are up towards the higher cross streets. Au Cacao-the chocolate shop is a favorite. A good place for souvenirs & packaged souvenir coffee is Magia. A great restaurant with upstairs dining and a great view of the street is Madre Tierra Seafood & Steak.Their coconut shrimp is delicious.

Great place to walk around, do some shop and burn some calories!!!. Great pedestrian avenue, safe to visit, with a lot of restaurant, shops, places to eat and walk around for a while.Walking this streets is priceless, you can do it from one side to the other of the street, and enjoy some food and some cerveza.The prices here are better and you have a lot of choices, and also .. "the prices are not fixed, you can always ask for a discount"The beach is close and is great. Also i posted a photo of the ADO bus terminal with the prices to different places in case that you want to save some money on your trip to chichen itza as an example.I came here using the colectivo cost me 3.50 from Gran Principe Bahia, travel time around 45 min. but in case that you are going to stay a little bit late during the night i would recommend to take a taxi is gonna cost you 30 usd to GPB.The Bad: Harrassing vendors

Shopping Bummer due to price increases!. I love 5th Ave (Quinta Avenida) in Playa del Carmen. This is my 13th or 14th trip to Playa, I visit there about every 6months. This time the prices have increased even more, the sarrongs/wraps that I have purchased for years have increased from $5 to $10-$15 USD. The food & beer prices have increased considerably too. I realize that price increase are normal, but this really put a crunch on my vacation budget.

shops, shops, shops. when walking with the family we really got hit on a lot to come in and shop, however when I was walking by myself it wasn't as bad. there is everything "Mexican" to see and buy. The prices seem to change a bit during peak times, so do some haggling!

Touristy. It's the hang out for tourists. And the shop owners know it! They will bother you for any kind of attention into their store. Always try to haggle down the prices. Can become aggravating being hassled left and right.
Nice beach walk, nothing out of the ordinary!. Nice beach walk, a lot of vendors, not much out of the ordinary. Fun if you're there to drink and hang out with friends.

So much fun!. This is a great, pedestrian only avenue on which there is a lot to see and many restaurants to eat in. It's also a great place for people watching. The restaurants and bars are pricey but good food abounds. At slow times, the restaurants will try to pull you in with offers of free drinks. It take a while to walk from one end to the other. We did this several times (different days) and always saw something we missed the previous times.

Fun town with great restaurants and bars. great town, great food. Our family had fun walking aroung and checking the local stores. It is right on the beach and the restaurants are diverse. Lots of Italian influence in this area.

Mexi-shlock. Harrassing vendors targeting the children to sell them tacky items. I resented how the vendors chased the children and then appealed to adults not to be cheap. The restaurants were adequate, but very spotty. We returned to a place we had liked and the food was totally different in quality.

Good to see. A nice pedestrian mall filled with restaurants and shops. Only problem is all the vendors calling you into their shop to buy silver and souvenirs. Would have liked not to be bothered so much by them.

A taste of Mexico!. walking the streets of Quinta Avenida is one of my favorite things to do in Playacar! The merchants will welcome you into their shops and there is so much to see and do. People watch on a swing while drinking a beer or dine at a local restaurant... We go there almost every day when on vacation in the area!

Capitalism at its Best (or worst, depends on how you look at it). If you want to see how it is to be in the Greenwich Village of NY, La Quinta Avenida is it. Growing up in NY, living in and working in that NY area qualifies it enough that the word "busy" does not even describe it. If you are looking for that then this is your place to be, if not, then just stroll through with cotton in your ears. Many of the restaurants are equally priced with that of NY, the only thing is, the employees who work there are like car sales people offering you the best food in the area, which makes it a little skeptical after a few minutes. The retail shops and tourist offices are not that far behind either, everyone is selling something. Not that you can't find something or eat something you like, it's just a little over whelming.

Check it out if you're in PdC. Lots of shops and restaurants. All the shops are ridiculously overpriced, but you can find a lot of great restaurants for any budget. There are also nightclubs, if you're interested in that.

Fun on 5th Ave!. close to sunset fishermen. great shops, restaurants and dance clubs. can take ferry to cozumel. can walk from fifth back to hotel. get ready to have people invite you into their shops as you walk along 5th. they are nice but sometimes pushy. practice your bargaining skills :-)

An Experience you should not miss. Everyone who come to Playa needs to visit 5th avenue and their shops. It is entertaining and you can get some great deals. From restaurants, to bars, shopping galore. The vendors are fun and entertaining. The other day one of the vendors said "come and see my crap, its better than everyone else's." It is truly an experience you will never forget and should absolutely do!Having come here for over twenty years I've decided I need to design my own t-shirt and point to different lines when I walk down 5th. It will read NO taxi, NO massage, NO jewellery, NO food, NO money. If you've experienced 5th avenue you will certainly understand this. Enjoy!,
Never ending Action!. People watching and shopping paradise here! Lots of fun and colorful---don't miss it.I did not like the constant pressure from vendors, so I ignored them!

Good experience. A lot of shops and restaurants. Got ice cream at a chain ice cream store and they messed up my order like 3 times... Beach and the main plaza where the church is was awesome. Great view of the beach.
Shopping. Good for souvenir shopping, but does get a bit samey after a while.Lots of hassle and some shops require a bit of haggling.

Nice walking street but way too touristy. I live in Playa and for me the best way to walk the 5th avenue is by wearing a uniform... So nobody bothers me. Otherwise people will offer everything from sombreros to even drugs or invite you in the restaurants. Other than the fact it is too touristy it still has a lot to offer:- nice food and very cool restaurants and bars- art galleries- interesting shopping opportunitiesIt is worth a strall if you are around, but stay away from it if you want to save money:)
Love 5th Avenue. La Parilla, my favorite restaurant on 5th Ave. Lots of shopping and bargaining, smile and say no thank you!
Shop 'til your wallet drops. a LOT of shops and restaurants to break away from the resort. good times. very relaxed and happy atmosphere where ever you go. Early June was perfect not over crowded

The sales persons may be pushy and even rude. We went having in mind and romantic lovely walk in such a nice long so mexican street, just to find out that the people at the many stores are very pushy and rude if you don't buy and come to their stores to check their merchandise.Why would trust in them if they are not polite?

The heart of Playa del Carmen. No visit to the Riviera Maya is complete without a stroll along the Quinta Avenida (Fifth Avenue). The many contrasts of Mexico are on display as you walk along, from indigenous artisans to luxury brands and counterfeit goods (beware).

fun but really hot. Great shopping, food and native demonstration of Maya ritual. Sooooo hot and sweaty in June. Definitely eat lobster at a restaurant, totally yummy and fun. Select with air conditioning to be comfortable.

So convenient and so many food/store options yet a bit much with the hustling. The convenience and restaurant/store options are great, but the pushy people working in such places could be annoying. Also some of the jewelry stores jack up the prices multiple times the value, so you need to be careful. They all jack it up somewhat, and bargaining is a must, but some were just ridiculous, so be careful and shop around before making any jewelry purchases.

Lots of variety, great eateries, plenty of fun. Let's face it, anywhere you travel in Mexico (or most other countries) you will be hounded by street vendors and shop touts in tourist zones. They are generally good humoured and easily ignored in Playa del Carmen. Once you get past them, it is a good experience with lots of variety and some great eateries to choose from.
We LOVE 5th Ave.. Lots of nice stores, walking fun. Don't miss it! And now the have important stores, the church is beautiful.
Beatiful street. Is a beautiful area for walk and eat, with a lot of restaurants and have a nice handcrafts shops, you should withdraw in pesos and bargain for prices
Excellent Place to visit. Evening and nightlife are excellent over there. Several gift stores, boutique stores, Fine restaurants, Bars, Sports Bars
Vacaciones 2013. Spa Fish - ok . A lot of shops and restaurants. We only stay about two hours because it was raining. Next time i will stay longer visiting more shops.
Shop & Drink!. Stroll La Quinta & Drink & Shop...Get The Good Junk!OMG 50 characters....Lets be done.I am getting frustrated with trip advisor

Lots to do and see.. It is a long street of open shops. There are souvenir chain stores mixed in now days, so it is not as quirky as it used to be. But the street is one block off the beach. You can wander away from sunburn for a diversion. There are many wonderful restaurants. There are activities such as art sales on certain evenings. You can walk to the park where there is always entertainment. It is a very safe and pleasant area.

Such a cool spot, awesome experience. I've been all over Mexico, and the first time I hit La Quinta, I fell in love. It is such a cool experience. We found ourselves walking up and down all day and night. When we would need a break, there were plenty of open air bars and restaurants to sit down and grab a cerveza or some food. The is plenty of shopping and at night, there are some pretty cool clubs, Coco Bongo is the most well know, but I liked Palazzo better.There are always a ton of people walking up and down. Find a nice spot to eat, we liked Tulipanes, Living, and an Argentinian Steak House (I forget the name) and make sure you eat outside. You enjoy great food, service, views, weather, and value (it isn't that expensive).It's only 1 block from the beach, so if you get hot, walk one block east and take a dip in the gorgeous water.We stayed at El Tukan, which was on la Quinta (5th Ave), it was a great value situated right in the heart of Playa. Can't wait to go back!

Fun if you like shopping. Its a very long street with as manny stores as restaurants. But half way youll be feelling the sun pretty good and you will probably be tired of the people calling you every name to get your attention so they can sell you something that they probably have over priced. This being said you can still find good deals if you search hard enough.

Lots of fun.... It is a really nice street with lots of restaurants and stores. Yes, the vendors are in your face most of the time, but people have to understand that is how they make a living. A simple "No, thank-you" or "No, gracias" was enough to let them know you were not interested.

Aggressive vendors are a turn off!. Quinta Avenida would be really nice if the store vendors would stop bugging you every 5 min to "come see my nice store" Ugh! Sometimes I just want to stroll and window shop without having a guy (and it's always guys) in your face. Some of the restaurants and bars looked really cool to hang out in but we had already eaten and were just looking. The farther north you go on the street (away from the ferry dock) is directly related with lower prices. Get your souvenirs above 18 or 19 street. I was so turned off by the pushy sales people that I would rate this only a "C". Only worth a couple hours of your time, certainly not all day. Mayan sky dancers (down by the ferry dock) were neat to watch although a guy on the ground begs for money before they begin the show.

shopping paradise. you can find all types of shops along this street.the people are very nice and the atmosphere is relaxed!there is also a chapel with a wonderful view to the sea... and a typical mexican show from the Voladores de Papantla for free.

Great fun!. Walked 5th Avenue several times.. Loved this part of the trip! Overpriced? only if you are willing to pay for it.. a simple "No Gracias" will do. we were never bothered by anyone. Stopped for a drink a few times, walked to the ferry, shopped, stopped and ate one evening (great restaurants), and went out early for delicious coffee. This is a must, if you are heading to Playa...felt safe in our group, even at night. Can't wait to return!

Great place to hang out and shop!. Lots of great Restaurants and shops along this strip. We spent lots of time here in 5 days. You can eat anything along this street. Lots of the shops have the stuff you will need and want. Be Prepared to Bargain. Even if there are sticker prices on the item you want. Be prepared to walk away if the price is too high.. that item will be cheaper 3 doors down the street. It can get a bit annoying with the shop keepers calling out as you walk by.

quinta avenida. kind of an "open mall" on main street (one short block from beach). curio shops, restaurants, hotels and night life. a pleasant strip to spend time after beach activities at any time. although,not enough public benches available. be selective where you eat or drink. pricier restaurants are more reliable as far as sanitation goes. authorities (marines) patrol this strip very well to protect tourists from criminals. my compliments to them. though, i'd wish they didn't have to do that. we had no troubles at all in playa. it's much safer than Cancun.

Action!. Plenty of action on 5th Ave. Lots of shopping, lots of people asking for your business. FAH Restaurant (a.k.a. Siesta Fiesta) well known for great live music til midnight just south of 10th, also, Tropical Restaurant across the street great for people watching while enjoying a 2 for 1 beer in the afternoon.

Over priced and over rated. It's nice that everything is in one or two streets. But at the same time it's too crowded and very expensive. Try going a bit further and you'll find better prices, better food, and better service.
A variety of shops, bars and restaurants + night clubs. If you like going out, Quinta Avenida is perfect place. From simple mexican diners to fancy night clubs on the beach.

Lots to chose from. Charming area full of colorful shops. Typical cheap vacation trinkets as well as nicer clothing and jewelry shops. Yummy snacks at La Vagabunda. Be sure and see the sand sculptures on the beach.
Fun. Nice that the street is for walking, browsing, and shopping. You can walk for quite a distance now. Lots of shops are the same but still fun people wathching

entertaining. There is no shortage of things to see and buy on 5th avenue, the store vendors try to get you to go into their shops as you walk by sometimes that gets to be annoying, we did have a few shop owners that were very rude because we did not buy from them but that was the exception
lovely and cozy walk through the quinta avenida. worth going to shop and walk and dine in the quinta avenida it is very cozy visit now before it gets too comercial.

A Changing Face. While the stroll here can be something similar to a walk on the midway at the local fair or exhibition that is part of its charm. Unfortunately there is a deliberate, it seems, attempt to push the older style vendors and shops out in favour of brand name and upscale shops. As this infiltrates more I think my visits to 5th avenue will become fewer and fewer. Progress isn't always good.
Nice walk. Gret shops, nice bars, friendly people. a lot of silver and Cuban cigars. And Taxis in large numbers. Interesting experience!

Busy pleasant atmosphere. Very busy touristy street with all you need in boutiques restaurants and services. Vendors are pleasantly doing their selling tacticks. Lots of street animation and people watching activities

A must in Playa!. Is the most visited and famous pedestrial street in Playa. Is a must. There are many places to eat, drink and shop. Is better and more lively walking at night. The duty free stores sell perfumes at great price, some times cheaper than in the US.

Bargain for good prices. We arrived at Playa del Carmen via a ferry boat from Cozumel through a shore excursion from a Carnival Cruise ship. We walked Fifth Avenue looking for a silver chain and several silver medals. After looking for several places we obtained a very good price at a small store located the corner of Fifth Ave. and Constituyente St. across the circle. Don't stop bargaining until you get what you like at a reasonable price. They also gave me the change in US dollars. It is very important that before you buy to be sure that will give the change in US currency. Visit the Hacienda Tequila store for good souvenirs.
Just OK. It's nice for a couple of nights but shops owners are too pushy and it makes it unbearable...Nice to buy presents and souvenirs.A few good restaurants a awfully expensive!

Something for Everyone. Are you looking for souvenirs in Mexico? Clothing (tee shirts to fancy dress)? Luxury watches (five figures not uncommon)? All kinds of restaurants from Baskin Robbins and Ben & Jerry's to authentic Mexican cuisine? Fifth Avenue in Playa Del Carmen is the place for you.Unlike some tourist areas, Fifth Avenue is relatively uncrowded, has a lot of local crafts available, and is right next to a beautiful beach where you can relax when finished shopping. The variety of goods available is exceptional.Wear a hat! The sun is very strong most times of the year. Notice the unique fountains in the plaza at the south end. Taxis are plentiful and fairly inexpensive to take you back to your resort.

A unique place in Mexico!. This is a very special ave located in Playa Del Carmen Mexico, Along its 2 miles car-free ave just one block from the beach, you can find from casual to fine restaurants, jewerly, souvenirs, tobacco stores, boutique hotels, night clubs and more!
interesting. Stop by, check it out. It costs nothing to look. You will get hassled by the locals to buy their stuff.No biggie though.I'm glad I saw this town.
$$$$$. Very nice boulevard, however the prices were not the cheapest. International food is widely available but in my opinion local food need more showcase in the area.

Fun, but a bit of a tourist trap.. It was fun to walk up and down this road and people watch. However, the vendors calling out to you are nonstop and get to be a bit too much. We were twice offered pot, but not in a scary or aggressive way. We always felt safe. We did not experience any crazy harassment, as we either said "No, gracias" or didn't even acknowledge the hecklers. We specifically stuck to stores where the prices were posted and employees left you alone, and found some fun souvenirs. (Tip: take a cab to WalMart and find clothing, food, and souvenirs for much cheaper.)

Fun, but ...... All the little shops were great, but the vendors really are pushy. The prices start high, say no thank you and walk away, and they start to decline rapidly....It was really fun to walk around here and see all the sights the little shops, places to eat. The initial kiosk vendors were the worst though, just wouldn't take no for an answer. Be firm and walk away. Go and look around before buying. Prices vary from place to place...

Aggressive vendors. This has really developed into a typical tourist trap area over the years. The aggressive and sometimes rude vendors makes the experience less than pleasant. Everyone should go there once, but once is definitely enough.
