Great fun place to visit and bargain. The little church is beautiful, bus station handy, shops interesting, vendors can be a little pushy but humour goes a long way
Nice place for a walk. Nice for an afternoon walk.. great for souvenir shopping.... for all others found the stores a bit pricey...

A bit too annoying at times. Quinta Avenida has a lot of great shops, bars and restaurants but tourists are constantly bothered by the locals trying to offer something. One of our favorite place was La Bodeguita del Medio and the Fish Spa where you can get your feet clean by fishes. A real treat. There are a few tour agencies that offer the same tours as your hotel at a much lower price.

FIFTH AVE BABY!. I am a concierge for hundreds of guests a year visiting Playa Del Carmen. I am always asked where do we go? The first thing you must see when here is LA QUINTA in Spanish, in English it translates to Fift Avenenue. There is no driving on 5th ave. All shops, stores, restaurants and of course BARS! tequilla stores, gift shops and local flavor make 5th ave a must at least once during the day and once at night.

Very interesting street, merchants are plentyful but not overbaring or overwhelming. start your negociations at 3/4 of the asking prices, i.e. they ask $60 you counter with $15. I was called a bandido but I'm sure they still made a nice profit. Sports bar/restaurants are plentyful and I ate very well. Kudos to Tequila Barrel and Los Tabarnacos

Love it, hate it, always changing, always tacky, always supreme for people watching.. I'll start by admitting that I'm one of those annoying perennial Playa visitors who say, "you should have seen it 17 years ago, it was so rustic, so funky, so laid back.." Playa, and expecially La Quinta, are not what they used to be and while we miss Old Playa, when Hotel Delfin was the biggest building around and early mornings meant lounging street dogs, not high-heeled young things tottering home from the clubs, we still enjoy the human parade that is 5th avenue. Find a table on the street and watch the world walk by. Play the "where are they from?" guessing game. Listen to the agressive salesmen run through their selection of languages, hoping you'll answer in one of them. We don't eat on 5th (except for early morning coffee at Starbucks), and we hardly shop there either, the prices are getting crazy, and you'd hardly guess you were in Mexico...but what a grand crazy scene it is. If you want a feel of old Playa, walk down 15th Av or calle 1 sur, it's still there.
trashy. Trashy and very inauthentic - it was so depressing coming back from a meal out away from 5ta in the real Mexico to this gaudy street.
Our daily excercise. We walked 5th Avenue after dinner every night. We didn't buy much at the shops but did enjoy coffee and people watching.

Lively, fun!. This place is hopping day and night! My family with young kids visited there at night and we had a very pleasant stroll from one end to the other. Plenty to see and shop. The restaurants and bars are everywhere and the party continues (minus children hopefully) until 5-7 am every night.

dirty. 1st vender charged me tax stupid me didnt realize there isnt any you could find some bargins there once you get the knack. Couldnt find a rest room without going into a restaurant, Baskin Robins 3 scoops of ice cream $11 us.

Fashion Parade. Each Year, I go to Playa del Carmen, and each Year have something new, now 5th avenue is bigger and ends at 40 st., every day is a fashion pared, if You walk or just stay in a terraza restaurant You can see What I'm talking about and goes from trendy through kinky. Try and decide what will be your new look in the next vacations

Highlight of Playa del carmen. Love the fact that the street is blocked off for long leisurely walks everyday with a few interesting shops such as seashells, or windchimes that are unique, as well as local cultural crafts. There are still a few good restaurants but they have become exorbitantly expensive... and quaint and unique restaurants with swings to sit on are gone, replaced with well-known american franchises like star bucks, hagan-daaz, diamonds international, etc... Sad but at least there is still some charms with Mariachi bands going through every night, and Mayan people with historic costumes for eyes to feast on... or kids to be scared of...

Best walking/shopping tour.. 5th Ave was so close to our resort that we walked it often. There was something different to see each time. The shop owners are not pushy and you can browse at your leisure.

5ta es donde esta!. Shops, bars, restaurants, massages, art galleries and just about anything else you can think of you can find on this avenue. This place is alive all day and night. You won't get bored walking up and down here, sit and people watch while you drink a few beers.

TOO Commercial now. Before the days of the cruise ships, 5th Avenue was the most quaint, fun and inexpensive place to get your authentic, hand made Mexican goodies. NOW, there are 2 Diamonds International stores within a block from each other. The prices are sky high - no bargains to be found on 5th Avenue anymore. It's very commercial. You have to go - yes, you have to see it, but you have a greater option of getting good, authentic goods off of the strip a bit.

Good for people watching. This is a fun street for people watching, window shopping and buskers but the hawkers form the stores and tour agencies can get irritating. Thye are always courteous however and it does not work well to become rude. Still, After 10 weeks walking by the same places we were never recognized as anything but a gringo with money in our pockets. This is normal I guess since so much of their trade is with cruise ships or people coming to a resort for a week or two. If you really do need to buy something, like flip flops, you might prefer to check out the Mega department store first or the Mexican shops along Juarez where prices are often cheaper.

interesting street. 5th Ave is a great place to go for a walk and people watch. There are hundreds of little stores selling to tourists and many places to eat and drink. Prices reflect the fact that you are in the high tourist area. Go down Benito Juarez from the bus depot East and over to 20 Ave (they go up by 5s so only 3 blocks) for better prices on food and great prices on shoes.Quinta Ave has lots to see. There are shows put on by the beach area which has a beautiful new sculpture.We did miss the food vendors that once sold churros and tacos on the street. They were all gone. The far south of 5th is now all very expensive stores in a mall type setting. There are getting to be more and more American stores, too bad. There is also a large clean public bathroom there. Make note of bathrooms as they are hard to find.Lots of ice cream store but at very high prices.

5 avenida great place for walking , window shop. i felt like i was in Toremolinos, Spain , streets were very similar and just about every corner had interesting shops, places to snack and the best is closeness to beach.
A lively place but not fo me. Seeing this place once it was enough for me ! If you enjoy noisy places ,crowds of people,souvenirs shops may be you enjoy it but i did not.

everything you need. Quinta Avenida has everything you need - shopping (from cheap souvenir shops to high-class specialty shops), food, convenience stores & a beach a couple of blocks away. Not much to dislike, except the constant attempts of people trying to get you to buy from their shops, but it was no different than any other similar area (ie, NYC).
Nice time spending. A lot of to do, it is heart of Playa! A lot of reatsurants, bars, clubs. Near to the beach and night life. :)

Fine things to shop. A small place for shopping, with some fine brands and lots of affordable stuff. Full of mexican character. Nice place to rest for a while and have a look at the marina. In the early evening they put a show of ancient people praying to their gods for a good harvest. Easy to get there and easy to leave.

A nice walk along many shops and good restaurants. Quinta Avenida (5th ave) is the main (tourist) pedestrian avenue in Playa del Carmen. It is one block from the beach. There are many shops of all types, but also excellent restaurants, mostly Italian, Mexican and Sea Food. Lively at night.

Great spot to stroll, shop, and dine. 5th Avenue is a concentration of hundreds of restaurants, clubs, bars, tour guides, shops, and hotels. It's a great way to pass a few hours strolling it's many blocks and side alleys. Parts of it are very high class with very expensive stores and boutiques. The only downside is the constant pestering of the shop vendors who all have the "best prices" and who all seemed to think that I wanted to buy drugs. Secure parking is abundant, for only 15 pesos per hour. Bathrooms can be a bit difficult to find unless you're a customer so plan on buying something if you need to use the facilities. Overall, there's something here for everybody and for every budget.

Open Air Market. First and foremost, this is a market...not the Galleria or Saks. There's a ton of things that you can buy here, but you should buy at your own risk. Yes, there's going to people in front of the store fronts that will tell you anything to get you in their store. They will even look for any kind of identifier from your hotel (bracelets, bags, umbrellas, room keys) and tell you that they work at your hotel and that you should buy from them. If you fall for that, it's your own fault. You are not obligated to buy anything, no matter how much they pressure you. Just say "No" and keep walking. This place is mainly for entertainment purposes and souvenirs. It's not a tourist trap...because you can leave anytime you want to. So I will say, if you are overly sensitive or childishly gullable, don't go. Otherwise, get a good laugh, do some people watching, and buy something only if you want to.

Fifth Avenue. We always enjoy walking down 5th avenue. It seems a lot of the "local" charm is going away, which is a good and bad things. Gone are so many of the vendors "cheaper than Kmart" "hey pretty lady" "you said I'm next", which is good in that you can just walk the avenue without the constant barrage, however, the "big dollar" shops that seem to be taking their place is certainly making the avenue lose it's local charm.
shoppers paradise. just say no gracious if you don't want to look at more jewelry..they are all very pleasant vendors that are only trying to make a buck.

Is what it is:. A fun night or afternoon, but not much more. There are a ton of restaurants, and many shops, but the aggressive shop owners sales tactics can be off putting for those that don't like that kind of shopping.
Good in small doses. Hustle bustle. Lots of action. Fun to experience and then find some away space. Fun for food and entertainment. Can get to you after a bit

Kind of Scary!. Ive been to 5th Avenue twice and the experience was the same. I am a nice person and I hate telling people no, but the vendors are so aggressive here I eneded up avoiding all conversation with them (I REALLY HATE BEING RUDE). Definatly not like shopping in the US. You will get lines like-I am the waiter at your resort....One vendor told my friend and I to look at his store. The red flag should have went up when he took us off the street and down a dark hallway to his "store". I wasn't paying attention and neither was my friend and didn't notice when he started to shut the door and lock it behind us. Thank goodness one of the guys in our group followed us and put his foot in the doorway before the guy could get it all the way shut. There is a lot of bartering, which I hate to do. So, if you want to go shopping and get a great deal, take someone with you that likes to haggle. I have bought jewelry here the last three years and I have never been disappointed with a purchase. I do love to come here and buy the namebrand knockoff sunglasses. I send a person into haggle with me and when they can negotiate the price I want, I swoop in for the buy. I have never eaten here, the food is free at the resort. I have visited Senor Frog's which was fun. I've only been here during the day, and it scary enough for me. I am working on getting the nerve to visit at night....we will see how this pans out. Ladies- I felt safe travelling with big burly guys, I dont know that I would feel safe travelling without them. Just a thought. Be safe....

Great for people watching!. This is one of my favorite things to do in the evening in Playa! I enjoy strolling 5th and finding new places to eat or sit with a coffee and people watch. Playa has such a diverse cast of characters and somehow they all fit together along 5th. I find the north end to be more enjoyable and not as "tacky" as the south. Take a stroll past 24th and head to just past 38th, the newer restaurants and new growth is in the north.....still some but not as many aggressive vendors! I just say "no gracia" and go about my stroll!

Great for strolling, eating and shopping. 5th Avenue is a pedestrian only street but autos can cross 5th. There are mostly cabs and they always wait for the pedestrians to cross. Not like 5th Ave in NY.There are varied restaurants although they are mostly Mexican. Almost all have someone outside trying to have you look at the menu or offering 2 for 1 drinks as an inducement to come in. There are all sorts of shops; clothing, jewelry, massage parlors (the ones that actually do massages) cigars, tequilla and tourist novelties. Most stores have someone outside asking you to come in and see their wares. As long as you say, no gracias, they don't push it. There are always alot of people walking on 5th Ave and there is a sense of excitement.

Absolute Tourist Trap?. Notta. There are as many vendors on 5th Ave trying to support their families as there are sharks trying to be a hassle. Learn to say no and avoid eye contact with the sharks is easy enough. When they ask "where you from?" just say Russia. They will just wave you on and you can go about your business. The vendors between Juarez and the Ferry Terminal are worse than say the vendors between Juarez and Calle 16. There is a great variety of souvenirs and best prices at a shop on the beach side between Calle 2 y Calle 4. They take pesos, USD, Euros, whatever. I got 6 t-shirts for 6 dollars USD; shot glasses for a buck. Do not try shopping on your last day early in the morning. No one opens up until after 8 or 9 and you will find yourself shopping at the airport for souvenirs. That's much more of a tourist trap than Quinta Avenida.
5a Avenida. Tipical Mexican beach vendor filled street. Food is mediocre. As usual very friendly people and avid for serving.

Absolute tourist trap. Kitsch, trinkets, souvenirs, mediocre restaurants, loud music and red tourists. Lots to waste your money on but very far from the real Yucatan. Forty years ago this was a very small village, today it's a purpose built money vacuum. Avoid if possible, but can be fun for a night.
Fun!. Everything you need you will find here no shortages on souvenirs! Restaurants and bars very lively! Just five blocks from Wal-Mart. I know, I know but we forgot a few things! LOL
shop till you drop. Any shop you can think of is here, if that is what you're after. Tons of restaurants and very lively at night. Like any seaside tourist town.

So much to see!. We love walking up and down 5th Avenida, day and night. People watching is always fun there, and your choices of restaurants are varied. If you don't want Mexican food, you'll have quite a few other options, including Italian and even Sushi, but one of our faves is Yatche- Mayan food. Yes, the store employees/owners can be agressive, but it seems less so at night. Most will barter with you, especially jewelry.

Go for food and drinks, avoid venders. Let me preface this review by saying that I am not a world traveler by any means and that I am obviously a rube tourist but here goes. I would say go down to avenida if you want to find some good food and drinks, maybe do a little people watching but stay away from the vendors they are annoying and dishonest. We got taken by a vender because he convinced us he was a waiter at our hotel.By the time I walked out of his "mommas store" that he "worked at on his day off" I had figured it out, we got sucked in because they notice the hotel bracelets people wear and know a couple things about the hotel.I am pretty sure the pendant he sold me that I bought for my mom is not silver even though it is stamped 925 and l know for sure that the necklace I bought off another vender is not silver even though it is also stamped 925 within days it turned copper, whatever coating they painted on it to look silver came right off. They are constantly yelling at you to come into there store, some even walk out in the road in front of you and start barking at you, some are rude when you do not and make rude comments as you walk by. I was also offered weed about 10 times in two hours.If you do have to do some shopping here go into the big "supermarket" type stores they leave you alone alot more. Next time we go back which we have planned for next year I will avoid this street or maybe go and hit a restaurant or two up, but I will avoid all of the vendors like the plague.
The place to be. We loved walking up and down the street and trying no places to eat. We also enjoyed the people watching.

Great place to walk around. I think it's great to walk and find a nice place to sit or to drink a cup of coffee (or beer), it has a veery big amount of possible thing to do. Buying handcrafts, it has very nice restaurants or really small ones, it's close to the beach, have an ice cream, walk your dog, shopping or just sitting and drink something and watch people pass I think its great and I love this place.

Playa's Bourbon Street--interesting, trashy, cheesy yet fun. It is exactly what the pictures show when you google it. It is Mex-americana at its best with enough tee shirt shops and tequilla stores to choke a burro. It is interesting by day and by night to people watch, listen to music, and stroll while window shopping. You don't get haggled half as much as Jamaica and the people are kind, respectful and full of pride. If you do not speak spanish, learn enough before you go to make an attempt. Ignore the Americans buying sombraros, and acting like.....americans. I know because I am one and I travel often. It really is not a place for kids--by night. It is cheesy and hokey but not offensive at all. I did not eat or drink on fifth but instead traveled a few blocks off 10th and 15th and off 30th and 40th for authentic mexican fare. If you like Senor Frogs, this is your mecca. If you want a taste of true authenticity, travel a few blocks either side of the pedestrian walkway. Do not support the men who have endangered species for photo opps--as they are poachers or work for poachers--a white tiger, a squirrel and spider monkey and a baby jaguar--all for show and taken advantage of. If you want a picture, take one and post it on fb and beg travelers to protest this practice. This exploitation will only encourage more poaching and the demise of these natural inhabitants of Mexico--remember for every animal you see, their mothers were killed to obtain the babies.

Busy Mexican tourist street. While not as touristy as Cancun, downtown Playa del Carmen still has lots of tourist traps and street vendors hawking you. There are many outstanding restaurants to try. The avenue is expanding north toward the newer resorts, so the upscale stores and restaurants tend to be on the north end of the street.

Most boring part of our trip. Quinta Avenida is one of these streets made only the tourists. No locals would ever buy there. Seems like a huge tourist trap. You find the same 4-5 kind of items in all the shots (at various prices) and all the prices are way too expensive. They hope that you won't negotiate and just pay the asking price. You can't really know the real value of what is offered and if it's fake or not.

Lots to see, little guide. Playa del Carmen's fifth avenue is a must for all people visiting the city. It is a long stretch of shops and restaurants, and a place of constant activity day and night. Two comments: Garbage containers were very difficult to get by, and since this avenue is quite lengthy, come sort of shopping guide could be made available to travelers that are with time restrictions for the visit.
Fun Street. Variety of restaurants, shopping, bars, night clubs, and no traffic - the avenue is a pedestrian thoroughfare for well over a mile. We feel completely safe in this city.

ok if you like tatt shops. We wnet a couple of time and walked around, and there are plenty of shops but the all sell the same tourist tatt, and they all try and tempt you into there shops, i know they are only trying to make a living but after a while it gets a bit to much. There is designer shops etc but its cheaper in the uk. If you love shopping and haggling then this might appeal to you
A fun way to spend a rain day. This shopping district is nothing special, but it filled the time while the sun was hiding. Most shops are just trinkets, but there were a few that tried a bit harder.

love to people watch. In Playa there are people from all over the world gathered and it is a great place to people watch, eat drink and shop! 2 things we were disapointed in. The first is that they are bringing in wild baby animals for you to take pictures with-at a fee of course-i just didn't like that..and the "land" sharks were out in force this trip-that being the time share people..really HATE that about Playa and probably one reason we may not go back.....

Playa without most of Quinta Avenida would be true paradise. I loved Playa, but with the exception of the area of 5th north of Calle 34, I hated this over commercialized, noisy, touristy, completlely tacky street. North of Calle 34, it is more pleasant and relaxing and the vendors and restauranteurs leave you alone to do what one should on holiday, relax and enjoy.
shop,shop,negotiate!. it is a vibrant busy place for shopping,do not buy the tequila on the 5th avenue,cheaper at Walmart by far!
Playacar 5th Avenue. A fun place to be for a day or an evening away from our resort. Lots of shopping, eating, walking, and another beach close to the Main Street.

Love la Quinta. A great place to be close to if staying in the Playa del Carmen area. It's nice to be able to leave your resort and go somewhere safe and entertaining after a day of lolling on the beach. You do not have to shop but there are lots of boutiques to wander through. Prices have really gone up, but if you are a negotiator you can have fun bargaining and get what you want. Good deals on massages (couple for 1 hour is $50 US). Lots of bars where you can sit and people watch and many restaurants.

We loved it !. Great place to have a drink, have a bite, buy souvenirs and go for a walk. We were really happy that our hotel was located just walking distance from 5th Avenue! it made our stay more lively and fun, we really loved it !

Lots going on. There is a ton of shopping and even more dining opportunities on Quinta. The vendors are polite. Unfortunately the prices seem to be what Americans are willing to pay, and not what the item is actually worth.

The heart of playa. Try as you might, it would be impossible to avoid Quinta Avenida as this is where all the shops, cafes and restaurants are. Best for an evening stroll when it's cooler. Plenty of ATMs about, though I suspect going to the local bank will incur you less fees.
good place to walk around. Great bars, nightclubs, stores, is a must go for sure. Teh street is very long, but walking around is easy.
Nice shopping street. Nice restaurants, nice shops and even better bars. I tried diving with one of the centers there, I recommend going with your resort instead, even if it is more expensive.

Ahh fifth ave. 5th ave is a good place for new visitors to Playa to go, however the prices are sure getting expensive there now. With that said its still fun to stroll down the street when you are in town.
Nice walk on 5th Ave. safe to walk. Lots of souvenirs to choose. The street is clean, lots of bars, restaurants, clothing stores, they are all nice.

Lots of things to see and do. Quinta Avenida is jam packed with shops, bars, restaurants, and things to do. Many of the shopkeepers will try to get your attention by calling out to you about deals or how good their merchandise is. It's fun to barter for a deal on merchandise with them but remember if you can't get to the price you want, the guy next door has pretty much the same stuff so try there.Lots of the people sitting outside shops will try to sell you drugs or say they know where you can find a prostitute. After dark, the prostitutes hand out business cards by the clubs. No one was pushy about it - just a polite 'no, thanks' and they'd leave you alone. Probably not the best place for little children but maybe the offers are tamed down if there are kids around.Personally, I loved the energy of the place. No one stuck me as dangerous and everyone was welcoming. Most everyone spoke English and those that didn't found someone close by that could.I'd go again without question.

Fun place to wander. Fifth Avenue has every possible tourist shop known to mankind, but it's fun to wander along and talk with people...sometimes buy a few souvenirs. Don't expect to find any bargains, but you can still bargain.

Best shopping strip. We come every yr for two wk stayat riviera maya. We hit the fifth avenue maybe four times during our stay...taxi fee is approx 30 to go 30 to come back, but if you go with another couple younsplit the fees so not that bad ...love bartering ...just enjoy the feeling onthe fifth, especially night shopping
great place to shop. lots of things you can buy, and palces you can eat. Have to try the icecream there at Aldos. You can take the fary to Cozumel for the day.

Changing for the better. The Quinta Avenida is probably still the most overrated shopping street in the world.While it's slowly getting better (major brands are coming now it seems, a scene of nice little boutique shops is evolving, too), it's still mostly souvenir shops, cheap jewelry and massage parlors.As for restaurants, there are quite a few nice places there. Take a look in the calles - there's tons of nice stuff to find there, too.

the fifth avenue of mexico. where you can find many wonderful mexican artifacts, gifts, jewelry,exc very relaxing many elegant yet peaceful restaurants to attend to such as italian, mexican, french, spainard food if you like variety and quality you have choosen your destination!
Some night time playtime fun bars food and $11 milkshakes. People are fun , bargaining, laughing, good food reasonably cheap,To great food , music, give it a try..

An interesting, but not great, way to spend a few hours.. Quinta Avenida was just okay. Most shops tended to have similar merchandise and very pushy, though pleasant and warm, shopkeepers. It was a little shabby and a little too touristy. However, it certainly offers a little more authenticity than just staying at an American-style All-Inclusive would!

Western, expensive. Don't shop here for souvenirs. Chichen Itza and Mercado 28 in downtown Cancun are the cheapest souvenir shopping places. Nice for people watching, nightlife and restaurants, but you could be in any western street with Starbucks and Haagen Das. Go to La Taraya restaurant on the beach, best quality and value for money Mexican food.

Shopping. 5th Avenue is full of wonderful shops but it is also full of very very rude and pushy vendors. If you walk by their shop most often they will shout insults at you. Go off of 5th Avenue (closer to the water) and find shops there - they are much nicer.

Beware!. While we had a good time shopping along Fifth Avenue, it was a little disturbing when the shop workers, etc. took your arm and tried to draw you into their shops. We would barter with them and found some good deals, but we knew to be careful.
5th Avenue is fun and worth a visit in town (P del C). Lots of bars , restaurants, and shops. Lots to see. 5th Avenue goes on for about 45 blocks....mostly pedestrian resticted forsafe walking.

This is why Playa del Carmen isn't my kind of town. When I go on holiday I seek quietness, great nature and solitude. You get none of this at "5th avenue" - actually you will not find any of this in Playa del Carmen at all."5th avenue" is packed with tourist shops, overpriced restaurants, noizy bars and tourist in general. If you primary goal when you go on holiday is to get wasted you'll find "5th avenue" fantastic. If not then go somewhere else than Playa del Carmen.
Shopping! Shopping!. Good place to spend a lot in bikinis, shorts and a good place to have fun! I really like walking in the 5th because you have a lot of stores, restaurants and bars.

Fun for all. Shopping on 5th is a hoot. There is so much to look at. Some of the shop owners are a little pushy but, a simple no, gracias works. The local drugstores are a great place to stock up on antibiotics, and other personal care items. (which are a lot cheaper than the airport stores).

Wanna see how those look with jeans?. YEP, the merchants are pushy, but theya re there to make a living...just tell them No, thank you. Went to the Rogers boots and leather - bought a GREAT purse for $120.00. get lots of compliments on it. My girlfriend bought cowboy boots...they gave her plastic bags to use for socks AND a "sleeve" of denim so she could see how they look with jeans! It was a riot!

beautiful street. We walked around la quinta avenida during our stay at The Royal , playa del carmen. This is a great place to find your souvenirs. You can also enjoy authentic mexican cuisine. You just have to ask around and you'll find the best ones.

Great street that has gotten even better in the past few years. This street has lots of shops, cafes, restaurants, bars, and people from all over the world. I recommend going there early in the evening.

Lots of hustlers. Somewhat quaint in some areas but way toooo many people trying to get you into their stores, bars, restaurants, etc. I hate ignoring people but if eye contact is made, well you know!

The heart of Playa and the main reason to come here besides the beach!. Yes, it's true - the sales people will bombard you as you try to stroll along, especially if they think you are American or Canadian, (based on appearance I'm pretty obviously one of those) but this is their livelihood so can you really blame them? Ignore them, laugh at their terrible hawking, and move on down the strip.The people watching is fantastic, and while I may be getting scammed buying seashell jewelry for a few bucks here and there, it's just awesome and still the reason we come to Playa, stay downtown in Playa, and not at a silly all-inclusive resort or Cancun. There's a small town yet cosmopolitan feel that we've never experienced anywhere else in the world.We avoid most of the restaurants on the Avenida itself because they're mostly pretty terrible, WAY overpriced, and tourist-y. Still, the street itself is an experience that changes each day you visit and each time of day you visit. It's what you do in Playa when you're not at the beach or recouping at your hotel and makes your whole holiday! There are tons of great places to eat just a few blocks off the strip so use Trip Advisor to find those and I can guarantee you'll have a hard time vacationing anywhere else.
Lots of shopping on the ocean. Too long for old folks.! Free yify at Starbucks. We got tee shirts and Kalua. Likes the restaurants. Disliked the crowds .
Fifth Ave on the Playa. A fun stroll with lots of stores and restaurantsToo much hawking tourists by the locals which got to be overwhelming.

THE PLACE TO BE. Every traveler knows that Quinta Avenida is the palce to be in Playa. Tons of good (but overpriced) eateries and shops. Locals are pleasant and inviting. Been going to Playa and walking for hours on 5ta avenida for over 25 years. Only negative is constantly hearing the come-ons to go into all the shops.

Hawkers galore, everything overpriced. We have been coming here for the past few decades. It used to be a magical little town and strip. Every visit, it got larger with more 'junk' items for sale, and the prices for food and goods kept climbing. It has now reached the level that for us - we no longer want to come back. It is far more expensive for everything than at home, There are other nearby towns that are less slammed with greed and tourists that we will opt to instead going forward. If you have been here before,I would suggest going elsewhere. If you have never been to PDC, you will enjoy it I am sure, just do not expect any bargians on anything - treat it for what it is and understand it will not be inexpensive (which is fine as long as you are aware in advance)

Busy. Food, shopping not cheap.. I liked the quiet of Le Reve. It was not crowded. I am not a beach person, but if you are an excellent choice. My wife got a cheaper, excellent massage on the beach, not connected with any resort/hotel. I prefer Jamaica.Cheaper overall. Especially Negril.

Great Shopping. People from all over the world enjoying this colorful pedestrian street shopping for Mexican art crafts or just go to see all kinds of people. At night there is a very good ambiance with a lot of places to meet people, drink a beer and have fun

Unbelievable! Almost overwhelming.. The locals call it Quinta Avenida. The Gringos call it 5th Avenue. It is the 5th avenue the runs from Calle 8, north to Calle 38, parallel to the ocean in Playa del Carmen. After a long day at the beach, or hanging out at the swimming pool, a long stroll down Quinta Avenida is a must! Restaurants, bars, shopping high end and low end, Starbuck's (2), Liverpool, tour guide, hotels, local indigenous and tacky souvenirs; all are represented on 5th Ave. This experience is an outstanding location to spend the evening just looking at the stores and the fellow walkers. A great experience, not duplicated in many other places.

Eclectic fun atmosphere. Go in the evening, discover the fun little side streets, a romantic walk down to the beach, and don't let the constant hawkers ruin a good time. Politely say " no gracias" and keep walking. A must do when in Playa!

Tourist trap, but still liked it :). It's a great place to eat and drink, shop what ever you want, the 5th got it. If you buy stuff from the big Mexican outlets that are there, you will pay around dobbelt the price than you would in a supermarket. A tequila that's 200 pesos in the supermarket is 420 in the outlet, just so you know.

Everything you could want in one place!. It's a good place to spend the day, there's an array of shops, restaurants and bars. It's on the beach and trips to cozumel are accessible from here. Coco Bongo Club is also in the area, I would advise everyone to experience it!!!
Some beautiful shops and really wonderful food.. I love this street! just give yourself time to explore all the ambiance here. Enjoy the food and stop by Ah Cocoa...amazing coffee!
lolo. good place... i had fun but it should be cleaner.........good placee... you can buy things i dont know if walmart is part of it but walmart was a very bad place i couldnt find anything

Should Be Ranked as the #1 Thing to See and Do. I am stumped why this is not ranked as the top attraction in Playa del Carmen, this is what separates Playa from Cancun and other places in the region. Avenida Quinta is great for shopping, dining, people watching, walking around, strolling or just sitting. Lights, color, music, barkers, merchandise....its all here, a virtual assault on the senses. There are hundreds of restaurants, bars and cafes. The stores lean towards cheap souvenirs, jewelry, sunglasses and beachwear but is gradually going up scale with AX, Bershka, Daniel Espinosa, Fullsand, Hugo Boss, Lacoste, Liverpool, Tommy Bahama, Tommy Hilfiger, Pull & Bear, Swarovski....more brands are expected. Almost every restaurant offers outdoor or terrace dining. There really is no other place in all of Mexico quite like Avenida Quinta.....so walk from Calle 1 Sur (the ferry landing) all the way to at least 38 Norte (the avenida is growing to the north). The best and most interesting restaurants tend to be at the northern end. The first few blocks, 2 Norte, 4 Norte, up to 6 Norte tend to be the cheaper, more souvenir oriented section with flea markets and palapa style small stores selling identical merchandise. For those of you in a hurry and unwilling to try local food, there is a huger McDonalds at Av. Juarez and a Burger King at 8 Norte and a Subway just beyond that. Take your time, this is a place to wander and stoll, but rave through.

Great shopping district and nice just to wander. Playa del Carmen's "Fifth Avenue" offers an excellent shopping experience, with all the high-end marques well-represented. Take a bit of a wander to some of the back streets off the beaten path and you'll find much better prices. Even in the high-end stores, it is not unheard of to bargain a bit for price. (The worst they can do is say "no.") Many nice restaurants and cafes at which to stop for refreshments.
My favorite place on earth. Fun advertisements, fun products and great people watching with free tequila samples.What's there not to like?
nice place to wander around. lots of shops, restaurants and cafes, in nearly all places free wifi, it is a more expensive than in town, but it is all in one place and very clean.

Stayed at hotel on 5ta for a week and loved it. I stayed at the Posada Mariposa on 5ta / 24 Nte for a whole week and I loved it. There are many shops (yes, the products all look the same at first glance, but if you dig, you can find true gems). The shop owners will try to get your attention by yelling, but if you're not interested, just keep walking. It's not personal. And if you go into a shop, the owner will leave you alone if you ask, or you could try talking to them. I met quite a few nice people that way, and got tons of tips on sales and activities in Playa!Don't miss this beautiful vibrant street, and bring your haggling skills!
Nice to be and worth the trip.. Nice little place to walk arround and shop. One tip: go one street back and find 'Artesanias MIMI' there the prices are much cheaper.
Great for people watching, entertainment. absolutely loved the heart of Playa Del Carmen. Great for people watching, a plethora of restaurants/stores/clubs to choose from. Take lots of pictures!
Fifth Avenue Fun. Dazzling, so much variety. Felt very safe. The hawkers were annoying as hell, but the mariachis, enticing sounds and smells plus the smiling tourists made it great.

Good place for picking up souvenirs. The street is lined up with shops that offer souvenirs for a lot cheaper than the hotel stores.ATMs are all over the place, but they charge $6 to use. I recommend bringing dollars directly, they accept them everywhere.

Very repetative and annoying!. One walk down this street was enough. It was the same 10 shops over and over again and the merchants were excessively aggressive (even to the point of grabbing a child's arm so the parents would have to stop). I also did not like the young panther cub I saw being manhandled for tourist pictures. There are much better places in Playa del Carmen for shopping (check out Giancarlo's at Constituyentes & 1 Avenida for quality silver). I'll go back to Playa del Carmen, but never this street again.
Shopping fun. Love the shops, and had fun negotiating! Even my kids got into the spirit, and we picked up some neat Mexican treasures!

Annoyng salespersons all along the way. Despite being the best place in Playa for shopping, eating and seeing people I just can't stand people screaming at you all the time along the entire avenue tryng to grab your atention for their sales/products. It's quite annoyng and I believe Playa's tourist authority should do something to educate them to stop with this hassle.

Playa del Carmen's heart. This is where everything happens in Playa del Carmen you will find all kind of places to eat, sit, have a coffe, an ice cream, listen to music and buy anything from traditional crafts to fashion stores. Great place to be at any time of the day although our favorite time of the day is late afternoon and evening.
Worth a visit. Do not hesitate to take local bus to get to Playa del Carmen. Clean, fast and comfortable bus. There is a bus every 10 minutes
Best area in Playa. It is indeed the best area in Playa del Carmen, clean, with nice buildings, lots of shops, pubs and bars. A promenade with luxurious vegetation.

Do not Pay retail. DO NOT pay the asking price when shopping, HAGGLE. To save money, there is a Burger King, same views as the costly/expensive restaurants. Eat there and people watch, the money you save, Shop, shop & shop : )
It's a must. Commercial street, crowded. Nice to stroll around and take in your tourist experience while in Playa del Carmen.
Playa's heart and soul. Lovely shops, restaurants, bars and artwork. Really enjoyed the daily strolls and window shopping. It's a must do when you travel to PDC.

Must visit!. Quinta Avienda is the place to see in Playa del Carmen. The street is for pedestrians only and you can walk for blocks and blocks with shops and restaurants of all sizes and values. We always make it a day during our stay and find it exciting.

Everything you want and more .... Food, Clubs, Bars, Shopping ... they have it all. The merchants do know resort bracelets and they may approach you and say that they are waiters at the resort ... i wouldn't believe them

Shop smart. Be careful not to buy the first store you walk in sometimes a different store has the same item this is your bargaining tool tell the people you saw cheaper up the street and you will get a better deal.

a taste of Mexico.... if your looking for a nice evening out and a walk after dinner, perfect area, some shopping can be done. We were told the shopping here was amazing, i didnt find that, more shopping for souvenirs.

Even it has some downsides - it's great!. After travelling through Mexico we stayed 5 nights in Playa Del Carmen. It's a lovely place. Of course full with tourists....but there's enough room for everybody.The Quinta Avenida is closed for traffic. Just very few sidestreets with traffic are crossing it. There's almost endless options to shop, drink and eat. Bring enough time with to enjoy it fully. There's lots of really good deals to shop. Of course, there are some places with high prices and low quality. That's why it's important to compare and not to rush in a deal. But for that you need time.The same with the Restaurants. Some places are really good...and some are the typical tourist traps. If you can do so, plan ahead a little and check in advance what places to eat and shop are worth it. But don't get me wrong...we had a great time here! We did shop some really good jewelry for quite low prices (in a small shop callled "Silver Traditions" around Calle 6 to Calle 8) and some nice dresses. If you look for a nice beachfront place, then the "Fusion" will be a great deal. There's also good Asian-Fusion Food in "Babe's". Great juices you'll get in "100% Natural". Along the Avenida there are also lots of small street shops selling Silver. But prices aren't that great and we prefered to shop in a real jewelry store. Besides shops and restaurants there are also countless small counters selling tours. And mostly they're quite annoying or agressive. We had one really bad experience close to the Ferry. If you're not interested in any tours it's best to avoid them by not giving eye contact or a firm "No gracias". They always try to sell "great" offers....half price....only today....but everday they do the same thing. At the south end, close to the Ferry and ADO Bus Station there are also (only until around 1pm) small lunch stalls serving simple, but great-tasting mexican food. Fresh and inexpensive!So, Quinta Avenida really got everything. And we loved it...even with the bad sides...but that's part of the experience. We came to stroll around here every day and it never got boring. Our Hotel was just around the Corner from the Quinta Avenida (Mosquito Blue....a good deal), so that was very convenient.There's even some baby lions and tigers to take pics with, if you're interested in that kind of thing. We surely will be back in Playa and back on Quinta.Wanna know more about my trips? Check my profile where you'll also find my website with more info about my travels.

Busy place. Good way to spend your afternoon or evening, plenty to look at and buy. Busy place with people everywhere but feels pretty safe. The downside is you will constantly have vendors trying yo get you in their stores. Some are pretty persistent which makes it get old pretty fast.

busy, long walk but fun. Where else can you see monkeys parots snakes starbucks coconut shrunken heads and 5 star dining all on the same block. The bargaining is good, the high end stores are plentiful, its busy bustling and fun if that is what you are looking for, it is not quiet or mall shopping and sometimes the sales pitch can get a little aggressive

Lots of shopping and restaurants. The only reason we don't like going there any more is because you can not shop in peace...they are bugging you to death, constantly, and when you do go into the shops, they follow you around as if you were going to steal something...very annoying employees...

hard work down 5th ave. Great to see whilst in the area. The shop keepers can be very pushy. We had been on 5th Ave less than 5min, and were asked if we wanted cocaine or weed, not once, twice, but four times.Politely replied no gracias, and walked on. It was bit like running the gauntlet!!We got what we went for, tequila and small nick nack gifts, tried a couple of bars, and left back for the hotel. Wasnt the best experience Ive had for sure

Great Adventure!!. We loved 5th Avenue, it is a Wonderful feeling just walking down the street to look at all the Mexican shops. You have to realize the locals only have a few short months in the winter to sell to tourist and they do their very best to get you in their shops to look around & hopefully buy something. There is also some Great restaraunts along the Quinta Aveenida, we ate at a different on every night during our stay. The food was amazingly good. We also bought lots of sovigneers to bring home. We felt quite safe & Comfortable walking 5th Ave. even late at night. If you go to Mexico looking to get into trouble, you will without a doubt find it. Just use your common sense and behave responsibily!

Great shopping and walking. You can walk trought the quinta avenida, just window shopping or buy some handcrfaft as souvenirs or anything else there are several good stores there also the most of the restaurants are there.There are several persons that harassing to sell some trips to tourist places, snorkel tips or something like that just ignore it and enjoy the walk.

Nice to go through once!. This avenue has a nice atmosphere at night, with the lights and is great if wanting to go out for a night of partying, but unfortunately walking along the streets you get hassled to go in any shop or restaurant, with comments of "come here lady!, hey honeymooners, I have what your looking for, hey heres cheaper" and the rest of it, which can sometiems be very frustrating especially if you just want to get somewhere or if you would like to browse a shop or menu but just get hassled, ... to avoid, walk along the beach!
fun and a lot of options for shopping. lots of shops and restaurants to choose.... you can walk byall night long and choose what place to visit love it
Very harrassing. we visited and came away quickly - traders were at us constantly to get people into their shops saying they worked at our hotel etc. - they dont - some designer shops but mostly tat

A never ending road of shops. It was fun to walk and walk and walk, but most of the shops were all the same thing. Everyone seemed friendly enough, but this isn't something that would draw me to the area.

Quinta Avenida the Heart of Playa!. I returned recently from a week vacation in Playa del Carmen. My 4th time here in the past 2 years actually! I love La Quinta, and visiting, shopping, walking, and enjoying a drink/meal here is a must! There is so much to do/see here you will never get bored! There are a ton of bars, restaurants, hotels, resorts, clubs, coffee shops, taco stands, ect... Getting here is very easy from anywhere in Playa. There are local shops, as well as chain stores like Converse, Starbucks, Haagan Daas Ice Cream, McDonalds, ect. This place never stops. From the time the sun rises, until the wee hours of the morning there is always something to do and see here. A lot of people here in the US say Mexico is not a safe place to visit, however I was out at 2am with my 3 children and felt more safe here then I do in my own city. Mexico is safe, and I would really truly reccomend going to La Quinta if you have the opportunity of visiting Playa! :-)
nice place. a lot of bars, restaurants, stores and so many things to do. the place is great. if you want to meet people this great place for it and its not too expensive

5th Ave is a must for those visiting PDC. 5th Ave is a street that offers almost everyone something to buy, look at, eat or drink. They have high end stores all the way down to tourist shops full of t-shirts etc. There are lots of restaurants and places to stop for a drink along the way. There are of course lots of vendors shouting trying to sell you tours, etc... a polite "no thank you" will normally quite them down. The tourist shops are all marked up really high and you can bargin with them to get to a price you both agree on. There is even a McDonald's on 5th Ave if you need a quick taste of America... LOL. Right behind 5th Ave are the ferry boats to Cozumel and on 5th Ave across from McDonalds is the ADO bus station where you can catch a ride to Cancun airport and other tours you wish to take if you are trying to save some money!
Great Shopping. Shopping for Mexican Hand Made Items, shawls, blouses, bracelets. The kids enjoyed shopping down the Quinta Avenida; people watching.

always something to see. it is funny as it trip advisor ask you as a first question before you write your comment, when did you visit? Well, I walk on 5th everyday. I live one street beside so have to walk on it everyday to go to work or to go out :). I have to say that I am still not bored walking that street. Always something going on. It is not the action missing on this street. Wish there were maybe less tourists store that sell those sombreros and t-shirts and more original boutiques but beside that, just the people watching is always very interesting. Very lively street indeed. It used to be about 9 years ago open to cars. What a great decision it was from the city to make it a pedestrian street!

Must visit at least once. Great street with shops and restaurants. Yes, you do have tacky tourist shops but also have nice shops. Go on Thursdays when local artists display their works. Restaurants are good but more expensive than ones off of 5th Ave. Great for a drink and people watching!
Souvenir Shopping!. Great pedestrian street, bring a hat and comfy shoes...! There are shops for everyone, also if you just want to walk you can see around and have a drink!
